title: New Plain Talk From Kansas
description: TOPEKAThe old Middle West is gone. However, it still lives in song and story. Give most children the choice of visiting Valley Forge or Dodge City. Dodge City wins. It is more glamorous in their imagination than Valley Forge.

title: Enthusiasm and Receipts High As Boat Show Ends Run Here
description: When the 61st National Boat Show completed its 12day run at the Coliseum yesterday, show officials toted up the attendance and found it to be 4.4 per cent below last year's mark. They broke into smiles anyway.

title: U. S. Opens a Base to New Zealanders
description: >WOODBOITRNE, New Zealand, Jan. 31  The United States Air Force opened one of its classified atmospheric observation stations to newsmen and representatives of student organizations yesterday at the request of the Prime Minister, Sir Keith Holyoake.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: New York harbor could avoid a tragic oil spill similar to the ones which have recently taken place in San Francisco and in New Haven by installing offshore tanker moorings. With offshore moorings the tankers tie up five or more miles away from the shore and pipe their cargo ashore via underwater pipelines.

title: A rea Bakers Stage Brief Strike, Then Agree on a New Contract
description: A brief strike against specialty bakeries in the metropolitan area was ended this morning after a subcommittee representing the owners voted to accept a contract with modifications made by bakers union officials.

title: Advertising:
description: Did you ever get the feeling that it wouldn't be so bad being over 30 (if indeed you are) if you weren't reminded about it quite so often? Well, it's going to be worse this fall.

title: Mrs. Barbara S. Sheppard Rewed
description: Mrs. Barbara Schreiber Sheppard was married here yesterday afternoon to Zane Klein. Rabbi Jonathan Levine performed the ceremony in the St. RegisSheraton.

title: The Screen: 'Say Hello to Yesterday':British Drama of Love Opens at the Paris Jean Simmons Spices Amusing Vignettes
description: The rather arid archness of the title, "Say Hello to Yesterday," is the final flavor of a modest, carefully wrought dramathe fleeting 10-hour relationship of a coltish English boy and an older married womanthat should have been a small gem. It misses, as surely as it pursues the right path. Will Jean Simmons ever truly come into her own?Here, as usual, she is consistently interesting and convincing, as a comfortably-off suburbanite who says good-by to her husband and two young children and entrains to London for the day. Enter now a smitten 22-year-old extrovert, played by Leonard Whiting, who brashly stalks her across town with impish exuberance. They finally bed down. They part.There is much to be said for the lean, simple construction of this British film, which moves forward neatly on a straight line, sticks closely to the principals and deftly sprinkles in just the right portion of sideline characters. Beautifully photographed in color, the various London locales have a captivating immediacy.And so does the prospect of the story, under the nimble, low-keyed direction of Alvin Rakoff, who also wrote the screenplay with Peter King. What the picture lacks is central heating and genuine emotional pull, for all its amusing vignettes, perceptive tenderness and bittersweet wrap-up.The picture is simply not moving, even in the bedroom denouement, which is intended as a revelation and which begins exquisitely. Instead, some curiously antiseptic dialogue defines two understandable but not especially appealing people.And the final scene of parting, intended as an ironic heart-tug, is a prolonged business that induces squirming. Indeed, it almost squashes the whole thing flat, as a bleating vocalist and some soppy lyrics take over the rhythmical theme by Riz Ortolani. Worse, young Whiting, capering off like a giraffe, is stickily entangled with a bunch of balloons.Even so, the open-faced zest of the actor (the most recent "Romeo") as the whimsical, free-wheeling young mod remains more intriguing than the rather glacial-souled matron professionally limned by Miss Simmons. More appealing than either, and downright delicious, is that seasoned old-timer, Evelyn Laye, as Miss Simmons's knowing mother.

title: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I.,
description: Jan. 31  Seccndseeded King Van Nostrand, a teacher at Bay Shore High School, won the New York State men's indoor tennis tournament at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today, defeating Vitas Gerulatis, of Howard Beach, Queens, 75, 64.

title: Maskie Criticizes Nixon on the War And the Economy
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 31Senator Edmund S. Muskie, the apparent frontrunner for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency in 1972, criticized the Nixon Administration tonight on the latest developments in Indochina and on the economy at home.

title: Union Set to Test Trucks, Cutting Garbage Pickups
description: The head of the sanitationmen's union announced yesterday that his men would start safety inspections of department trucks tomorrow, a move that may reduce garbagecollections in the city.

title: Cavaliers Defeat Braves
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 31 (UPI)  The Cleveland Cavaliers, with Bobby Smith tossing in 24 points and grabbing 15 rebounds, posted their fifth straight victory over Buffalo tonight, defeating the Braves, 117108.

title: BAYH PONDERS 1972; BARS NAMECALLING
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today that he might seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972.

title: 300 Routed by Flood
description: BELLINGTON, Wash., Jan. 31 (AP)  More than 300 persons were evacuated from their homes and several hundred more marooned in the mountains over the weekend as warming temperatures sent flood waters surging through northwestern Washington. Two hundred residents of Ferndale, north of here, were evacuated today as the crest of the flooding Nooksack River swept downstream toward Puget Sound.

title: Sabres Sink Canucks, 61
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 31 (UPI) Gil Perreault, a rookie center, scored his 25th and 26th goals of the season today in pacing the Buffalo Sabres to a 61 triumph over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Outside Jerusalem's Walls
description: A mayoral decision to delay construction of new Israeli highrise housing projects on the hillsides surrounding Jerusalem will be welcomed by all who cherish that historic city and the cause of peace.

title: Harlem Hospital Names Tower For King, Whose Life It Saved
description: Harlem Hospital named its new 16story tower the Martin Luther King Jr. Pavilion yesterday in honor of the assassinated civilrights leader.

title: Schoonmaker Sailing Victor
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP)James Schoonmaker sailed to victory today in the first race of the Bacardi Cup series. Thomas Blackaller of San Francisco was second and Steve Haarstict of Ithaca, N. Y., was third.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Local leaders affiliated with the Center for Community Change, a private organization, happened to be meeting in Washington last week while President Nixon was unfolding his plan to convert a number of antipoverty programs into a special form of revenue sharing with the state and local governments. These community leaders represent a cross  section of Americans in pov erty pockets, from Chicanos in the West to blacks in the Mississipi Delta. They could not have been more in disagreement with President Nixon's assessment that the proposal would return power to the people.

title: HELEN B. WARNER
description: ARDSLEY  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 31Miss Helen B. Warner, a philanthropist, died yesterday in her home in Hudson House here. She was 76 years old.

title: POOR RETAINS TITLE IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 31Tom Poor of Boston attacked with severity to defeat Kalid Mir, national titleholder of Pakistan, 159, 156, 159, and retain the Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship at ChalfonteHaddon Hall today.

title: Gift of Townhouse to City Stirs Fight
description: An Upper East Side 19thcentury townhouse, willed to the city along with $50,000 to develop a vestpocket park on the 100by16foot site, has become the subject of a fight between community residents and the Parks Department.

title: Archer Takes San Diego Golf by Shooting a 7UnderPar 65 for Total of 272
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 31George Archer won his first tournament since the 1969 Masters today by beating the field in the $150,000 Andy WilliamsSan Diego open by three strokes. Through the fog at the Torrey Pines course the slim 31yearold Gilroy, Calif., professional had a putting stroke that worked so well he finished with a sevenunderpar 65 for 272.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Adlai Stevenson has recently added his voice to criticisms of the President's revenuesharing plan on the grounds that without Federal direction and control there is an unacceptable risk of monies being misspent. This criticism is only relevant if we are discussing the disbursement of Federal tax revenues.

title: Arson Hinted in 10 Fires
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31, (AP)A string of 10 fires that were apparently set off purposely broke out early today in San Francisco's semiindustrial, semiresidential Mission District, fire department officials said. Policemen said that two suspects had been taken into custody.

title: Arts Abroad
description: LONDONLast Thursday, the day before he was 95 years old, Havergal Brian enjoyed one of the half a dozen professional performances of his works ever given. It was his ThirtySecond Symphony.

title: Lucia Role Recast
description: John Alexander will replace Franco Corelli as Edgardo ink Donizetti's Lucia di Lammermoor in the performance by the Metropolitan Opera tonight. The remainder of the cast will remain as previously announced. It includes Gail Robinson, Frank Guarrera, Paul Plishka, Nico Castel and Rod, MacWherter.

title: 3 BOROUGH CHIEFS GET $6,000 LULUS
description: The city's five Borough Presidents, who have salaries of $35,000 a year, have begun to collect $6,000 in expense funds that need not be accounted for. This brings their annual income up to the $41,000 received by administrators of the city's superagencies.

title: Mondale to Act on Opium
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Senator Walter F. Mondale, Minnesota Democrat, said today that he would introduce legislation to cut off military and economic aid to countries that refuse to limit the production of opium. He said the measure would also offer aid to cushion the impact of turning from opium to other crops.

title: Article 17  No Title
description: Article 17  No Title

title: MRS: PAUL REVERE
description: Mrs Elizabeth McCurry Reware, the widow of Paul Revere, a shoe manufacturer who was a descendant of the Paul Revere famed for his midnight ride to warn of the British troops, died Saturday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, She was 82 years old.

title: SORCERY WINNER IN FLORIDA SAIL:
description: VENICE, Fla., Jan. 31 Ja';es Baldwin's brand new 61foot Canadianbuilt sloop Sorcery was announced today as the winner of the 105mile St. PetersburgtoVenice yacht race, the opening event on the Southern Ocean Racing Conference schedule.

title: Flight to the Moon
description: Tension ran very high during the two hours last night that the Apollo 14 crew, aided by the experts in Mission Control in Houston, struggled with the problem of docking their command module with the lunar module. The final success, on the sixth try, came as a welcome relief both to those immediately involved and millions of others here on earth. The whole incident was a supreme test the astronauts ability and of the capabilities of their vehicle, a test they passed brilliantly.

title: Men in the News
description: Ten years ago, on the morning of May 5, a voice came crackling out of loudspeakers from a tiny American space capsule: Aaah, roger. Liftoff, and the clock is started  Yes, sir, reading you loud and clear. This is Freedom 7. The fuel is go  Oxygen is go. Freedom 7 is go. The voice belonged to Alan B.S h e p a r d Jr., America's first space hero, who, on the heels of a Russian lead in the space race, rode his tiny Mercury capsule 116.5 miles up into the sky, 302 miles downrange from the launching site, at a speed of 5,160 miles an hour, for a 15  minute  22  second suborbital ride into space.

title: MAN INJURED IN LEAP FROM WARWICK FIRE
description: A man in his early 20's jumped three floors from burning 30thfloor suite in the Warwick Hotel at 54th Street and Avenue of the Americas shortly after 1 A.M. today.

title: Symphony of New World In Festival of Soloists
description: Benjamin Steinberg led his Symphony of the New World in a pleasant festival of soloists yesterday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall. There were four works on the program, and six solo parts, the overabundance being accounted for by the presence of Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante in E Flat (K.364), which is in all but name a double concerto for violin and viola, and Shastakovich's Concerto for Piano, Trumpet and Strings (Op. 35, No. I).

title: Heavy Toll Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31American pilots say they destroyed or damaged nearly 2,000 enemy trucks on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in January, probably the most succe.;stul month of air strikes against the trucks on record, according to military sources.

title: Education: What Is It For?
description: WASHINGTONI have been a critic of American education for close on a quarter of a centurynot by choice but because my assignment to build nuclear submarines required a staff of intelligent and welleducated menboth for the engineering job of designing and supervising construction and for naval operation of these ships. I found none readymade. I had to set up schools to train them.

title: Eban Reports to Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 31 (UPI) The Israeli Cabinet heard a report from Foreign Minister Abba Eban on Israel's continuing contacts with Dr. Jarring.

title: Truman Takes a Stroll
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 31 (UPI)  Officials of Research Hospital announced today that former President Harry S. Truman took a stroll outside his hospital room, further'evidence of his recovery from an intestinal inflammation.

title: London Warned of Flood
description: LONDON, Monday, Feb. 1. (Reuters)Millions of Londoners were warned early today that the Thames could flood its banks following huge tides in the North Sea. A special flood center, established to coordinate relief and emergency operations, is being manned and he police and fire brigades have been alerted.

title: Hambro and Batterymarch To Form a Joint Company
description: The Hambro American Corporation and the Batterymarch Financial Management Corporation Boston, yesterday announced the formation of a joint company, HambroBatterymarch Management Corporation, to provide investment counsel to the clients of Hambro American Bank & Trust Company which is owned by Hambro American Corporation. Under the terms of the agreement, the two founding companies will have equal ownership in HambroBatterymarch. Hambro American Bank & Trust will provide administrative, custody and trustee functions.

title: COMPANY UPHELD IN PHONE DISPUTE
description: An arbitration award said last night that the New York Telephone Company had a right to bring outoftown workers here on a temporary basis in efforts to improve service.

title: OIL TALKS IN TEHERAN RESUME FOR AN HOUR
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 31, (Reuters)Talks between representatives of six Persian Gulf states and an international combine of 22 oil companies resumed here today but broke up after an hour amid conflicting statements about progress toward an agreement on prices.

title: U.N. Aide Quits to Head BirthControl Federation
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 31Julia Henderson, a key official here for 25 years, is leaving the staff to become secretary general of the International Planned Parenthood Federation in London.

title: PRESIDENT SWIMS; SEES LIFTOFF ON TV
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Jan. 31President Nixon swam in the Caribbean today under a blazing sun and then watched three American astronauts begin their journey to the moon.

title: WALTER A. KINSELLA
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Jan. 31Walter A. Kinsella, a tennis professional, died yesterday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank. He was 85 years old and lived at 16 Hamiltonian Drive.

title: 8,000 Pets Are Lost As Bronx Fire Ruins A Wholesale Outlet
description: More than 8,000 fish, birds, turtles, snakes, monkeys and lizards died yesterday morning when a twoalarm fire destroyed an unattended wholesale pet outlet in the Bronx.

title: HENRY G. BOYLE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 31Henry G. Boyle, who retired as sales manager for Pacific Mills, textiles, in 1959, died Friday in Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow. He was 79 years old and lived at 30 Cathedral Avenue.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: RUSSI CAPTURES DOWNHILL EVENT
description: MEGEVE, France, Jan. 31 (AP)  Bernhard Russi gave Switzerland its second straight victory on the Emile Allais ski track today by winning the Halmenkamm World Cup downhill event.

title: Egyptian Cabinet Meets
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31 (UPI)The United Arab Republic's Cabinet met today to discuss the possible outbreak of fighting with Israel when the ceasefire expires Friday, political sources said.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT RAIDS IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Monday, Feb. 1Army headquarters said today, that an Israeli task force attacked guerrilla bases in two Lebanese villages during the night.

title: Tidaliurn Pelo Wins Prix d Amerique
description: PARIS, Jan. 31  Twenty months ago, he was almost a dead horse. Less than eight weeks ago, one of his legs was in a cast. But Tidalium Plo just keeps getting better.

title: MILES D. RICE, MAGAZINE EDITOR
description: Charles D. Rice, author, editor and columnist, died Saturday of cancer in French Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in CrotononHudson, N.Y.

title: Texas Instruments Reports a Decline In 1970's Earnings
description: Net income of Texas Instruments, Inc., last year fell to $29,861,000, or $2.71 a share, from 1969's $33,511,000, or $3.06 a share, the company disclosed yesterdy in a preliminary report. Sales slipped to $827,915,000 from $831,822,000.

title: Faulty Sensor Misses Shepard's Heartbeat
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) A loose sensor kept ground controllers from monitoring Capt. Alan B. Shepard's heartbeat during the launching of Apollo 14.

title: Postal Talks Fail in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP) Talks to end Britain's 12day postal strike broke down tonight. The leader of the Post Office Workers Union predicted that the dispute would become increasingly bitter.

title: Bellevue Bolsters Its Security Against Traffic in Illegal Drugs
description: Bellevue Hospital is adopting strict security measures to combat the illegal drug traffic and major thefts that have long plagued the sprawling institution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A state judge's recent attack on the Federal courts for interfering with state prison conditions omits a central fact: These courts have acted only because the state judiciaries, with rare exceptions, have defaulted on their constitutional obligation under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to prevent prisoners from being brutalized.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Article 11  No Title

title: Drexel In Name Change
description: Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., investment banking and brokerage firm, has changed its name to Drexel Firestone. Inc., reflecting its recent association with the Firestone Tire & Rubber Co. The two concerns have announced that Firestone has invested $6million in Drexel in the form of loans and equity participations under an agreement giving Firestone an equity ownership of about 25 per cent.

title: Cambodians and Ally Clash
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 31 (AP)  Fighting between South Vietnamese soldiers and their Cambodian allies broke out last night for the second time in 12 hours.

title: Country is Seeking to Curb the Outflow of Marks
description: BONN, Jan. 31  Seeking more democracy and social justice in West Germany's capitalist society, Bonn's Social Democraticled Government has rolled up its sleeves to fight largescale tax evasion.

title: Space Conversations: Great. Super job, Stu
description: HOUSTONEd. This is Houston. About how far out in range are you now, would you estimate?

title: Stabbing of Boy Led to Career Training Plan for Slum Youths
description: When Sidney Augsthin's 15yearold son was stabbed in the back with a stiletto by a band of boys in Central Park last year, his initial reaction was outrage. The boy recovered, and Mr. Augstein's outrage was soon tempered by a decision to offer an alternative to young boys whose anger and idleness might touch off violence.

title: Pan Am Sulphur to Move
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The Pan American Sulphur Company said this weekend it would move its company headquarters to Alexandria. Va., from Houston.

title: BEETHOVEN LINGERS IN BRENDEL CONCERT
description: The bicentennial is over, but Alfred Brendel never needed a birthday excuse to present allBeethoven recitals.

title: California G.O.P. Hails Decision on Poverty Issue
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan.1 31The California Republican State Central Committee (Toted today Gov. Ronald Reagan's claims of victory over the California Rural Legal Assistance Program.

title: Two Americans in Italy One's Styles Say Kansas
description: ROMEFor 30 years, Seymour Jacobson manufactured dresses on New York's Seventh Avenue. Now he runs a shop called Donna Paula. And it's not in New York. It's here, at 116 Via Veneto.

title: One Killed in Los Angeles Riot Alter a MexicanAmerican Rally
description: EAST LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31One MexicanAmerican was killed tonight and several dozen were injured as a peaceful rally against alleged police brutality turned into a looting spree by several hundred youths who had attended the demonstration.

description: Article 5  No Title

title: FIRE AT WESLEYAN DAMAGES BUILDING
description: M1DDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 31 The building housing Wesleyan. University's alumni mut development offices was heavily damaged early today by a fire tentatively described as sispicious by the Fire Department. Damage was estimated at more than $200;000.

title: MISS DOROTHY CHENEY
description: MANCHESTER, Conn., Jan. 31 Dorothy Cheney, twin sister of the late Marjory Cheney, a Representative in the state Legislature, and member of the family that founded the Cheney silk mill, died yesterday at the age of 90.

title: WILLIAM GORDON
description: William Gordon, proprietor of R. Gordon & Co., 12 East 55th Street, a bookshop specializing in motoring, aeronautical and military books, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 63 years old and lived at 345 East 57th Street.

title: Mother of 4 Killed on L.I.
description: BAYSHORE, L.I., Jan, 31 A 36yearold mother of tour children was killed here at 8 o'clock last night in a twocar accident on Fifth Avenue. The police said the victim, Mrs. Esther Galan, of Westwood Drive, Brent/ood, was riding in an automobile operated by her husband, Daniel, 36, that collided with a car driven by John Michaels, 21, of Fairtown Road, North Bayshore. Mrs. Galan's 8yearold son, Carlos, was slightly injured in the accident and was hospitalized. The, three other children and the two drivers escaped injury.

title: Miss Paxton, Robert Bunim Married on L.I.
description: WOODBURY, L. I., Jan. 31 Miss MaryEllis Paxton and Robert E. Bunim were married here this afternoon at the Fox Hollow Inn by the Rev. Richard Mansfield, rector of the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church of Oxford, Ohio.

title: Bulls Beat Royals, 13199
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UPI)Every Chicago Bull player scored at least one basket and one free throw today in a 13199 romp over the Cincinnati. Royals in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Poland's Simmering Workers Revolt
description: The political explosion in Poland six weeks ago continues to reverberate and its final outcome is still uncertain. Those Polish Communists who thought they could end the unrest by ousting Wladyslaw Gomulka, replacing him with Edward Gierek and making a few economic concessions have been proved wrong.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Nobody in Wall Street had been expecting much cheer from the fourthquarter financial results of the steel industry. When these results were unveiled last weekand proved to beat at least as gloomy as anyone had forecastthe principal topic among steel analysts was whether the industry could show a convincing recovery pattern in 1971.

title: Newark Teachers Vote to Strike Today If They Fail to Get Contract
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31  The Newark Teachers Union voted today to strike if a new contract with the city were not reached by 8 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CONFESSIONS OF EDWARD DAHLBERG. 312 mums. George Braziller. $6.50.

title: Damage Suit Against Mine Union's Welfare Fund Opens Today
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31A reformist attack on the lead ership of the United Mine Workers of America reaches another major turning point here tomorrow.

title: New Island Urged as GiantShip Port in Delaware Bay
description: A group specializing in international bulk shipping plans to seek approval today for a large manmade island to be built in Delaware Bay three to four miles off the mouth of the Mispillion River.

title: Slowdown on Family Planning
description: Although it is only a few weeks ago that President Nixon signed what he hailed as a landmark population bill, there are disturbing signs that the Administration may be backing away from the President's earlier pledge to provide essential leadership in the field family planning.

title: New York Women Win
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31 The New York Metropolitan team won the Class A championship in the Howe Cup women's squash racquets competition today for the third straight year.

title: CELTICS VANQUISH 76ERS 132 TO 126
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP) Clutch free throws by Dave Cowens and Jo Jo White in the final minute lifted the Boston Celtics to a 132126 National Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: Henry E. Mullick, 65, Dies, Westchester County Official
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 31 Henry E. Mullick, manager of the buildings division of the Westchester County Department of Public Works, died today at his home. He was 65 years old and lived at 110 East Brookside Drive.

title: JOSEPH STRANAD
description: Joseph Stranad, retired director of purchasing for the National Lead Company, died Saturday of a heart attack in Aldenville. Pa where he lived. He was 66 years old and also had a home in Summit, N J.

title: COMBINED TITLE WON BY DARTMOUTH SKIER
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Jan. 31 (AP)Tecyk Weed of Dartmouth finished second in today's crosscountry race after taking third in yesterday's jumping competition to win the 1971 United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association nordic combined championship.

title: Massapequa Shopping Center Emerging After 10 Years
description: The problems, logistical and otherwise, of putting up shopping centers are often masked by streams of cars, smiles of anticipation of shoppers and the attractive stocks of stores in the suburban centers that continue to smell of new paint, fresh plaster and wood months after they open.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: Article 14  No Title

title: In FrenchTinied Madagascar, African and Asian Cultures Meet
description: TANANARIVE, MadagascarSome of the Malagasy people who inhabit Madagascar like to call themselves the first AfricanAsians.

title: TV News Chiefs Find Gloomy Economic Picture of Their Industry Is All Too Clear as They Cut Back
description: Television news is a casualty of the country's recession, forced into a holding position when its practitioners say it should be expanding; conscious of its ongoing obligation to inform, yet stalled by the economic realities that govern its existence.

title: Men in the News
description: Comdr. Edgar D. Mitchell, on his way to becoming the sixth American to set foot on the moon, used to be a cowboy on the dry Arizona range. He could ride and rope and brand, his wife said. He was very good at it.

title: First Phone Calls Since 52 Link East and West Berlin
description: BERLIN, Jan. 31The first telephone service between East and West Berlin in more than 19 years was opened today, but for thousands on both sides of the wall there soon was frustration at the inadequacy of the link.

title: Dornhoefer Puts In 2 Goals as Flyers Subdue Wings, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 (UPI)  Gary Dornhoefer's 25foot goal with 3 minutes 21 seconds remaining tonight proved to be the winning tally as the Philadelphia Flyers rallied for a 31 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: APOLLO 14 STREAKING TOWARD MOON AFTER TROUBLE IN SPACE DOCKING; DECISION ON A LANDING IS DELAYED
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Monday; Feb. 1Three American astronauts were cruising toward the moon early today after a harrowing twohour struggle last night to overcome trouble with the linking apparatus between the Apollo 14 command ship and its lunar landing craft.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I stopped some time ago expecting the Interior Department to preserve the interior. But I have, perhaps foolishly, continued to expect to see some logic ill its proceedings. Can anyone connected with the Alaska pipeline report explain how oil carried in the most militarily vulnerable manner possible  a pipeline  can be described as vital to United States security?

title: Rescued Birds Die
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (UPI)Most of the 2,000 birds rescued from the oil slick that covered 50 miles of Northern California coastline have died of the effects of the oil or the shock of being handled. Some 225 of 500 seagulls, ducks and loons still survive at the Richmond treatment center. At the San Francisco Zoo, 100 of the 1,600 birds received for treatment are still alive.

title: Gentleness Infuses Maderna's Juilliard Serenade
description: Bruno Maderna's Juilliard Serenade (Free Time I) is described in the program notes to yesterday afternoon's Tully Hall concert as being like a biography.

title: General Cable Closes Plant
description: ROME. N.Y., Jan. 31 (UPI)The General Cable Corporation ended its operations here yesterday. The plant employed 3,000 persons at its peak.

title: Boston Housing Need Cited
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)More than 100,000 families in Greater Boston, about onetenth of the area's population, need some kind of government housing assistance according to a report released today by Metropolitan Area Planning Council.

title: 11 Dayton Policemen Get a Taste of Counterparts Weekend. Routine Here
description: Patrolmen Nick Martin and Joe Winslow share a patrol car in Dayton, Ohio. Sometimes we'll go all night with one call, if we're lucky, Patrolman Winslow said.

title: Nepal's Queen Wounded
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Jan. 31 (AP)Queen Ratna of Nepal was struck in the hand and stomach by a ricocheting bullet while on a tiger hunt with the King in a tropical forest in this Himalayan kingdom's remote southwest The bullet has been removed and all necessary precautions have been taken, her physician said today. Her Majesty is making satisfactory progress.

title: G.I. Held in Officer's Death
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 (AP)The United States command said today that Pfc. James D. Moyler of Chesapeake, Va., had been charged with murder in the shooting death of his commanding officer last Wednesday. Capt. William F. Reichert of Valley Stream, L.I., was killed at his company's base camp at Ankhe in the Central Highlands.

title: Ballet of 20th Century Presents Premiere of Les Vainqueurs
description: Maurice Bejart's Les Vainqueurs (the conquerors) is a ballet full of cosmic yearnings meretricious choreographic borrowings and sumptuous vulgarity. It uses the music of IndoTibetan composers along with Wagner's Liebestod in a series of five tableaus that bring a young man from a posture of meditation through a harrowing love encounter and then again to a crosslegged meditative stance. It received its first American performance Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by the Ballet of the 20th Century.

title: If You Can't Get to the Restaurant.
description: Leonard Rankin is a shortorder cook with a modest claim to fame. He probably holds the record for flipping Reuben's apple pancakes, the caramel  coated, calorie laden dessert that is as much a part of the restaurant's lore as its corned beef, sauerkraut and melted Swiss cheese sandwich on rye.

title: ORR GETS 2 GOALS, ESPOSITO HIS 45TH
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)Bobby Orr collected his 21st and 22d goals and Phil Esposito padded his National Hockey League scoring lead with a goal and two assists in leading the Boston Bruins to a 60 victory over the St. Louis Blues today.

title: SLADKY PAIR WINS 4TH SKATE TITLE
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 31Alormer gymnastics champion and an Army private teamed today to win their fourth straight United States gold dance title as the figure skating championships ended at War Memorial Auditorium.

title: U.S B52'S STRIKE FOE'S LAOS BASES AROUND THE CLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 United States 852's continued to bomb enemy supply bases in southern Laos around the clock today, but officials at the State and Defense Departments refused for the third consecutive day to comment on speculation that an allied attack at or across the Laotian border was imminent or under way.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Harvester Pact Ratified
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP)The last of six holdout United Automobile Worker locals ratified agreements today with the International Harvester Company, and the company announced that it would resume at least partial production tomorrow. The announcement ends a twoandahalfweek strike by 40,000 workers against Harvester in 10 states.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Jan. 31President Nixon hardly expects support from the young and radical critics of American life. One nevertheless senses disappointment in his Administration that those who want change in our society have not given him more credit or even attention for the turn he took in his State of the Union address.

title: Hugh N. Mulzac, Mariner, Dies
description: Capt. Hugh N. Muizac, the first Negro to command a ship in the American merchant marine, died yesterday in Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L. I. He was 84 years old and lived at 16 Fourth Avenue, Westbury, L. I.

title: DR. ALBERT SCHILKE OF LUTHERAN SYNOD
description: NORWALX, Conn., Jan. 31The Rev. Dr. Albert P. Schilke, who was instrumental in founding the Lutheran Church of the Good Shepherd here, died yesterday at Bridgeport Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: You Actually Do See Carol Channing and Sid Caesar
description: The kindest thing I can say about Four on a Garden, which opened Saturday night at the Broadhurst Theater, is that Carol Channing and Sid Caesar do their very considerable and very effective best to save the most destructible vehicle since the good ship Titanic. Of course I exaggerate, but these two very special artists do so consummately well that lovers of histrionic chutzpah could waste their money more foolishly than in seeing the violently stylized Miss Channing and Mr. Caesar eat bricks without straw.

title: Melbourne Police Disperse Jews Marching on NeoNazis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 31 (AP)The Police disperced about 2,000 Jews marching on a house where members of the Australian National Socialist party were meeting Sunday.

title: Disorders and a General Strike Again Paralyze Reggio Calabria
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Jan. 31Disorder is paralyzing this deprived city in Italy's deep south for the third time in seven months.

title: B. G. Morse Marries Susan Markus
description: BEECHWOOD, Ohio, Jan. 31 Miss Susan Gayle Markus and Bradish Goodell Morse were married here this afternoon at the Dali Museum, division of the IMS Company, owned by the bridegroom's father. Manuel W. Rocker, Municipal judge of Shaker Heights, performed the ceremony.

title: Laotian Leader Questions U.S.
description: VIENTIANE, Jan. 31 (Agence FrancePresse) Premier Souvanna Phouma has been trying since this morning to verify rumors that a South Vietnamese invasion supported by United States air cover is imminent in Laos, informed sources said here.

title: HAROLD C. JACOB
description: ISELIN, N. J., Jan. 31 Harold C. Jacob, treasurer of the Malmstrom Chemical Corporation of Linden, died yesterday of injuries received in an autobile accident. He was 40 years old and lived at 85 Creemer Avenue.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Defining Aggression3 P.M.

title: Nigeria's Head Visits Ibos Dispatch of The Times, London
description: ENUGU, Nigeria, Jan. 31The Nigerian Head of Government, Maj. Gen. Yakubu Gowon, returned to Lagos today after a sixday tour of warravaged East Central state. The 35yearold leader, whose army crushed the bid by the Ibos for a separate Biafran state after three years of war, was making his first visit to the Ibos.

title: Hollander to Play in London
description: Lorin Hollander, the pianist, is scheduled to make his debut with the London Philharmonic Orchestra on Feb. 9 in the first of two concerts at the Royal Festival Hall, performing Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, Opus 43, under the direction of Aldo Ceccato.

title: A Form Can Bar Smut From Mail Deliveries
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)Starting tomorrow, a new law will take effect, intended to provide Americans with the machinery to keep unwanted, sexoriented literature out of their mail deliveries.

title: MRS. BARTLETT MILLER
description: NEW HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 31  Mrs. Patti Flint Millner, wife of Bartlett P. Miller, a retired vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died today in Charlotte Hungerford Hospital, Torrington. She was 72 years old.

title: Men in the News
description: Maj. Stuart A. Roosa, although on his way to the moon, will probably not get too homesick for his favorite kind of music. He had some of it taped for the voyage by top artists.

title: Mile Runners Dilatory Tactics Are Criticized by Club Coach
description: At a prominent indoor track and field meet in the United States earlier this winter, a cash bonus of $400 was offered to the athlete who won the onemile run and finished under four minutes. Smaller cash incentives were extended to any runnersup who cracked the fourminute barrier.

title: Nasser's Miracle
description: Men, women and children of Egypt, the miracle has been wrought, Egypt's late President Gamal Abdel Nasser boasted more than five years ago on completion the first major stage in Egypt's mammoth new dam across the Nile River at Aswan.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: Article 12  No Title

title: NOTRE DANT EYES NOT SMILING NOW
description: The jubilant Notre Dame basketball coach, Johnny Dee, Shouted We should be No.1 after his team upset the University of California, Los Angeles on Jan. 23.

title: BOND OFFERINGS NT THE NEEK
description: The bond market faces a pretty easy week as it tries to make up its mind over the next few days whether to resume the January decline in interest rates.

title: SOVIET JEWISH HERO REPORTED SET TO GO
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 31Maj. Grisha Feigin, the World War II Red Army hero who returned his medals for valor to the Soviet authorities last year in protest against the policies toward Soviet Jews, is reportedly being allowed to leave the Soviet Union.

title: EUROPE PONDERS FUTURE OF POUND
description: LONDON, Jan. 31  Long after the loss of the British Empire, the international use of the pound sterling provides lingering symbol of British prestige.

title: Knicks Rout Bullets, 12595, Outscoring Baltimore, 4225, in Last Quarter
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 31The Knicks, who seem to thrive on hard work, surprisingly turned in one of their finest games of the season today at Cole fieldhouse as they rolled to a 125.95 victory over the Baltimore Bullets before a capacity crowd of 13,443.

title: Said's 2Man Bobsled Wins
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 31 (AP)  Bob Said of New Canaan, Connecticut piloted his bobsled to victory in the twoman competition of the Adirondack Amateur Athletic Union today, and Jim Hickey of Plattsburgh. N.Y., guided his sled to victory in the fourman event.

title: L.I.R. EMPLOYE HURT IN JAN. 24 CRASH DIES
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Jan. 31A trainman, critically injured on Jan 24 when an eastbound Long Island Railroad train veered off a siding in Brentwood and crashed, died last night of multiple injuries here at Southside Hospital.

title: TV: Two Filmed Operas
description: One of Greek mythology's gifts to librettists, the story of Orpheus, was the subject of two diverse filmed operas, presented in tandem last night on Channel 13. They were given as part of the NET Opera Theater series and were introduced by their director, Peter Herman Adler.

title: Italian Wins Toboggan Title; W. German Girl Posts Upset
description: VALDAORA, Italy, Jan 31 (UPI)Karl Brunner of Italy won the men's world toboggan championship today after Elisabeth Demleinter of West Germany upset Erika Lechner of Italy in the women's final.

title: Puzzling Trouble With Apollo 14 Docking System, a Threat to MoonLanding Mission
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 31For almost two hours tonight, difficulties with the Apollo 14's docking system threatened to shatter chances for a landing on the moon.

title: Advertising:
description: Horse racing has joined that long list of professional sports that have jumped into the market place.

title: A Course in Home Repair That ShortCircuits Male Chauvinism
description: BALTIMORE  Memorandum to the staff and faculty of Goucher College:

title: 17,257 Cheer Bumps and Spills as Roller Derby Whirls Back Into Town
description: A record indoor roller derby crowd of 17,257, including many who we not born when the sport enjoyed its glory television days in New York from 194951, turned out yesterday at Madison Square Garden. It was the derby's first Garden appearance since last March 22, when the turnout was 15,874.

title: Aide Is Named at H.E.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)Dr. Richard Scott Brannon, an official in the Office of Economic Opportunity, was named today as special assistant to the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, effective Feb. 15. The department's Secretary, Elliot L. Richardson, said that Dr. Brannon would advise him on a broad range of departmental policies and programs and maintain liaison with various departmental constituencies.

title: Laos: Battleground for 2 Decades
description: Laos has been part of the Indochina battleground for more than two decades. After 56 years as a French protectorate and a Japanese occupation in 194546, Laos became an independent state in the French union in 1949.

title: Russell Library Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) A Richard B. Russell Memorial Library will be built in Athens, Ga., to preserve the personal and official papers of the Georgia Democratic Senator who died this month. Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today in announcing the plan that a drive for $2,075,000 was underway to finance the project.

title: Writers Toast and Roast Baseball
description: Brooks Robinson's glove, Johnny Bench's bat and Arthur J. Goldberg's briefcase replaced the Mets in the spotlight last night as New York's baseball writers retold the 1970 season in song and dance at their annual dinner.

title: Diplomats in Uganda Skeptical of New Leader's Charge of Invasion
description: KAMPALA., Uganda, Jan. 31 Diplomatic observers expressed skepticism today about the charge made last night by Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, who took power in a coup d'etat last Monday, that Uganda was being attacked by the Sudan, her northern neighbor.

title: Tense for Mrs. Shepard
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 31 (AP)Louise Shepard sat in her motel room eating an omelette while her husband and the other two Apollo 14 astronauts worked with a balky docking latch that for a time threatened their moon flight.

title: Laotians Report No Word Of an Incursion by Saigon
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 31Officials said here today that they had received no official word of a reported incursion by South Vietnamese troops into southern Laos.

title: INQUIRY ON HOOVER ASKED BY M'COVERN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Senator George S. McGovern asked today for an investigation of J. Edgar Hoover's persecution of an agent for writing a letter on the strengths and shortcomings of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 31 (AP) Jerry Chambers, Walt Hazzard and Bill Bridges combined for 73 points as the Atlanta Hawks downed the San Diego Rockets, 131120, tonight.

title: Foundation Paid Connally $225,000 While Governor
description: FORT WORTH, Jan. 31John B. Connally Jr., who has been nominated by President Nixon to be Secretary of the Treasury, was paid at least $225,000 while he was Governor of Texas by the Sid W. Richardson Foundation, which has large oil and gas holdings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have sympathy forbut a growing impatience withthe families of men who are in prisonerofwar camps in North Vietnam or other parts of Indochina. They go to Paris and try to communicate with Hanoi. But Washington has the key to their sons' and husbands' cells, and the Nixon policyby perpetuating our presence indefinitely through puppet regimes in Saigon and elsewheremeans that these men are sentenced for life. Furthermore; renewed bombing and air support in Cambodia mean inevitably that the number of men serving a life sentence in Hanoi and elsewhere will rapidly increase.

title: SEPTEMBER DATE FOR THE PRIMARY PUSHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31  The two majority leaders of the State Legislature said today that the soheauled June primary election would probably be put off until September because of reapportionment problems.

title: SUPPLY OF STEEL GETTING TIGHTER
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31The supply of steel was starting to tighten last week.

title: Houston Tense in Test of Simulators
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31It was ominously like a repeat of the drama of Apollo 13 as specialists here sought to devise a way to extricate a trio of astronauts from their difficulty thousands of miles out in space.

title: Fire Ruins Historic Site
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Jan. 31 (AP)  The William Street Methodist Church on the former site of the home of President Rutherford B. Hayes, was destroyed by fire of undetermined origin early today.

title: Bronx School Changes Stir Hopes, Fears
description: Stimulated by the decentralization law, many residents of Community School Board District Nine, a predominantly black and Puerto Rican area in the southwest Bronx, are taking a new interest in their schools and coming into conflict with the largely white teaching staff.

title: 1,000 Motorists in City Lose Licenses Under New State Plan
description: The licenses of 1,000 New York City motorists have been revoked or suspended in the first six months of a new state enforcement program against moving traffic violations in the city.

title: Filion Named for 2d Time As Harness Driver of Year
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Jan. 31 (UPI)Herve Filion, a 30yearold trainerdrive from Angers, Quebec, has been named driver of the year for 1970 by the Harness Tracks of America for the second straight season. He won the North American allround driving championship.

title: Herman Weiss, Long an Official With Blootningdale's, Dead at 82
description: Herman Weiss, vice president of Bloomingdale's, died here yesterday after an illness of several weeks. He would have been 83 years old next Wednesday. His home was at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Senegalese Hear Bishop Is Badly Beaten in Conakry
description: DAKAR, Senegal, Jan. 31 Reports reaching Senegal say that Msgr. RaymondMarie Tchidimbo, the arrested Archbishop of Conakry, has been stripped and seriously beaten.

title: C. A. PASCARELLA, 68, TRAFFIC CONSULTANT
description: BOONTON, N. J., Jan. 31Charles A. Pascarella, a former practitioner before the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal Maritime Board, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 68 years old and lived at 456 Rockaway Street.

title: Obote Returns to Tanzania
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Jan. 31 (Reuters)Milton Obote returned to Tanzania today after flying to Mombasa, where he is reported to have had talks with President Jomo Kenyatta of Kenya.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 (AP) Wilt Chamberlain's 33 points and 27 rebounds led the Los Angeles Lakers to an easy 133120 victory tonight over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Chess: Fischer Paired With Taimanov For Opening in Challenge Play
description: The first pairings for the world challenge elimination matches after the Palma, Majorca, knockout roundrobin tournament will bring together Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, and Robert Huebner, the 22yearold surprise qualifier from West Germany, and Viktor Korchnoi of the Soviet Union and Yefim Geller of the Soviet Union.

title: Susan Werner Wed To Arthur Kaufman
description: Miss Susan Roberta Werner and Arthur Stephen Kaufman, who expect to be graduated in June from the Columbia Law School, were married here yesterday afternoon at the St. RegisSheraton Roof. Rabbi Morris Kertzer performed the ceremony assisted by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: Burns Is Optimistic About Controlling inflation
description: WASHINGTON, San. 31 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he was optimistic about the chances of reducing inflation without resorting to hard controls on prices and wages, especially in view of what he termed the Administration's vigorous antiinflationary policy.

title: Piano and Voice Study Caps Debut of 8 Works
description: This listener was not able to be present for all of the eight compositions given first New York performances at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon, but of the five he heard, at least one seemed of more than routine interest.

title: NASTASE CONQUERS RICHEY, 64, 63, 61
description: OMAHA, Jan. 31 (AP)Ilie Natase of Rumania defeated Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., 6.4, 63, 61, in the final of the Midlands international indoor tennis tournament today.

title: Article 16  No Title
description: Article 16  No Title

title: Mihajlov Says He May face Jail for Article in The Times
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 31 (UPI)Mihajlo Mihajlov, a controversial Yugoslav writer, may face another prison sentence for having published an article in a Western newspaper, he said today.

title: JOSEPH QUITTNER
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Jan. 31  Joseph Quittner, a New York theatrical lawyer, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 83 years old.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Fills Post
description: Guyon H. Knight has been appointed vice president, business information division, to manage the marketing services division of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc. He succeeds Robert W. Bechtel, new president of Dun & Bradstreet International, Inc.

title: 4 of 6 in Car Killed in Crash, One of Worst on West Side
description: Four of six young men were killed yesterday when their car went out of control, mounted; a divider and hit the concrete base of a light pole on the West Side Highway at a curve between West 71st and West 72d Streets.

title: Walters. Miss Young Take Crowns in Speed Skating
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 31 (AP) Jack Walters, 25 years old, of Brighton, Mass., ended the threeyear reign of Pete Cefalu of West Allis, Wis., today when he captured the senior men's title in the 72d national outdoor speed skating races.

title: Poland to Rebuild Warsaw's Royal Castle
description: WARSAW, Jan. 31Poland's Communist leaders have begun a major appeal for funds to rebuild the Royal Castle in Warsaw.

title: Bridge: Drury Response Paves Way For Britons TitlePlay Slam
description: Whether to lead an ace against a slam often represents a difficult decision. The danger of establishing a trick for the declarer by leading the ace has to be balanced against the possible loss of the trick when the declarer has discards available.

title: NIXON TO ASK CURB ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Tan. 31In about a week President Nixon will send to Congress at least eight bills on the environment. One of the most farreaching will deal with the dumping of wastes in the ocean.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Pakistan to Grant Asylum To 2 Kashmir Hijackers
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 31 (AP)Two Kashmiris who hijacked an Indian Airlines plane to Pakistan will be given asylum here, the Government announced today.

title: SPANIARD'S VISIT TO U. S. IS OVER
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 31 Prince Juan Carlos de Sorban and his wife, Princess Sophia, ended their sixday official visit to the United States today watching the Apollo liftoff at Cape Kennedy.

title: RENT RISE IS SEEN IN PUBLIC HOUSING
description: The City Housing Authority expressed concern yesterday that rents would have to be increased for the 152,000 families 600,000 personsin its public housing projects.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Personal Finance
description: The recent record trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange amid rising prices focuses new attention on the market.

title: Ferry Rider Dies in Plunge
description: A 66yearold Staten Island woman jumped to her death yesterday from the upper deck of a ferryboat about two miles off Staten Island. She was identified through papers in a purse she left on the boat, the Private Joseph Merrill, as Mrs. Virginia Fath of 244 Gordon Street in the Stapleton section. A lifeboat with three sailors from another ferryboat, the American Legion, took her body from the water.

title: Robinson of N.Y.A.C. First In 4Mile Run in Bronx
description: Tom Robinson of the New York Athletic Club won the eighth annual Henry Isola Run yesterday around the Bronx Terminal Market in 21 minutes 31.8 seconds.

title: Jewish Notional Fund Names Administrator
description: The election of Abram Salomon, Zionist leader, as administrative head of the Jewish National Fund of America, the landdevelopment arm of the Zionist movement in Israel, was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dr. Milton Aron, who had served for the last five years.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: COLLINGWOOD, Ontario, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press)Slavomir Kardas of Toronto won the North American nordic ski championship today.

title: Mohibullah Khan and Binns Win Squash Racquets Final
description: Mohibullah Khan of the Harvard Club of Boston and Ken Binns of the Toronto Skyline Club won the David C. Johnson Memorial squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

title: GEORGE A. REICHMAN
description: George A. Reichman, national sales manager and a director of the Lamport Company, a textile converter, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital after a long illness. He was 31 years old and lived on Iroquois Trail, Harrison, N. Y.

title: FLUTEPIANO TEAM MAKES DEBUT HERE
description: Elaine Shaffer and Hephzibah Menuhin, who are making their first appearances in this country as a flute and piano duo, played at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night, and revealed that their performance styles blend neatly to achieve interpretations of aristocratic sensitivity and quality.

title: Rodriguez, Oliver Win 24 Hours of Daytona in Porsche
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31Pedro Rodriguez won the Twentyfour Hours of Daytona this afternoon in a storybook finish, clawing his way back into contention after losing an hour and 33 minutes for rebuilding of the broken transmission of his GulfPorsche 917K sports car.

title: HARRIS IS VICTOR AGAIN IN SKIER
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 31  Dave Harris, a 24yearold mechanical draftsman from West Springfield, Mass., used his preferred starting position as the last competitor in a sixmanski jumpoff to capture the Joseph K. McManus Memorial Trophy today.

title: P.C.C. Blocks Negro Challenge of Soul Station Shift
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 31The Federal Communications Commission has ruled that it has no business investigating the sudden transformation of blackoriented soul radio station into a middleoftheroad music outlet.

title: BACKING GIVEN YALE ON DEFERRED TUITION
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, said today that two or three individuals had expressed interest in helping Yale begin an experiment that would allow students to pay their tuition over a 35year period.

title: Overflow Brooklyn Heights Meeting Protests Rising Crime and Asks Aid
description: More than 500 residents of Brooklyn Heights crowded into the ballroom of the St. George Hotel yesterday to protest an increase in crime and were told by a police captain that the police do not have the cure for rising muggings and purse snatchings.

title: COUGARS CONQUER NETS 125 TO 121
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 31A 62 per cent shooting performance by the Carolina Cougars was more than the Nets could overcome, in their Atherlean, Basketball Association game before a nearcapacity crowd of 5,134 at Island Garden today, the Cougars winning, 125121.

title: Ohio Prison Guards Picket
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 31 (UPI)Striking guards at the Ohio Penitentiary set up picket lines today at the Chillicothe correctional institution in an effort to gain support for their demand for a pay increase. William Salisbury, superintendent, of the institution, said 35 of the 43 guards on the first shift honored the picket lines. The prison is 60 miles south of here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In 1935, said Leo Seltzer, he read in the Literary Digest that 93 per cent of all American fathers bought skates for their children. That magic statistic, scribbled, studied, challenged, multiplied and cubed on a tablecloth in Ricketts Restaurant in Chicago, led to Seltzer's Proposition, Anything you're good at as a kid, you'll stick with it if there's an outlet, and, in August of that year, led to the first roller derby, an endurance scramble with less drama than dance marathons and less speed than sixday bike races. But roller derby was to survive. First of all, in 1938, Damon Runyon, as inspired a hustler as he was a writer, helped devise rules that made the exhibition into something of a contest. Then, after the war, television programed so much roller derby that a feisty female skater named Toughie Brasuhn became as negotiable a piece of conversational currency as Milton Berle. And third, and most important, said Leo Seltzer, roller derby had empathy.

title: WEATHER RULES DICTATED DELAY
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 31  The 40minute delay in launching the Apollo 14 spacecraft today was dictated by new weather rules put in effect after Apollo 12's unnerving encounters with lightning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The objectives sought in revenue sharing can be accomplished by procedures sounder than by those proposed by President Nixonthe principal objective being to permit the states and local governments to share in revenue obtained from the broadbased income tax, and also to foster home rule.

title: Marquard, 6 Others in Hall of Fame
description: Richard W. (Rube) Marquard called an $11,000 lemon as a rookie, but who later won 19 consecutive games, and Charles James (Chick) Haley, who hit .317 during his career, were among seven named yesterday by the veterans committee to the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Albany Notes
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Operation Off the Hook is in full swing here. The goal is to give Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature's Republican leaders, Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges of Niagara Falls and Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea of Montauk, a means of removing their commitments to the repeal of the socalled Elaine amendment barring state aid to nonpublic schools.

title: Hal Roach Studios Agrees On Selling Its Film Assets
description: Hal Roach Studios, Inc., a New York corporation, announced yesterday it had entered into an agreement to sell substantially all of the film production, distribution and licensing assets of the company (except for an equal interest in one film) to the Portcomm Communication Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Toronto. The film is The Wonderful World of Hans Christian Andersen.

title: LINER BY WIDING EARNS DEADLOCK
description: If their eyes didn't deceive them, 17,250 fans at Madison Square Garden saw last night the emergence of the Rangers' first slump of the season.

title: Irish End Protest
description: LONDON, Jan. 31 (AP)Twenty Irish demonstrators ended a 24hour hunger strike today by handing the Government a petition for the release of 19 Irishmen jailed in Britain, mostly on charges of illegal arms deals.

title: SOVIET HIJACKER REPORTED SPARED
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31The Lithuanian Supreme Soviet was reported today to have commuted the death sentence of Vitautas Simokaitis, a Lithuanian who was convicted earlier this month of having tried to hijack a Soviet plane to Sweden.

title: EXPERIMENT IRKS SWEDISH BANKERS
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 31Toj tally unneeded  a system for ispying into the affairs of private industry a gimmick to appease the leftists

title: Alcindor, McGlocklin Excel as Bucks Triumph, 131104
description: MADISON, Wis., Jan. 31 (AP)Lew Alcindor and Jon McGlocklin combined for 52 points in leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 131104 rout of the crippled Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: Australia and Japan: Foes Become Friends
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 12  Twentyfive years ago you wouldn't have believed that anything like this could ever happen, an Australian veteran of World War II murmured to another onlooker as Prince Mikasa, younger brother of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, paid a ceremonial visit to the cemetery for Japanese war prisoners at Cowra, near here.

title: Jones and Welch Excel in Quixote
description: A highly polished ballet team that any company would be proud to present on the international dance circuit had a chance to show off its classic dancing Saturday night when Marilyn Jones and Garth Welch, the Australian Ballet's two main principals, stepped into the troupe's Don Quixote at the City Center.

title: GEORGE F. MAHE
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J. Jan. 31  George F. Mahe, member of the New York Cotton Exchange since 1923, died today at his home. He was 85 years old and lived at 240 Broadway.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We were surprised to read in your Jan. 12 news story that Dr. A. J. HaagenSmit of the California Institute of Technology feels that the job of eliminating our pollution from the automobile is over the hump. While we do not debate California's air pollution problem with Dr. HaagenSmit, we can state with certainty that this statement is not correct in reference to New York City's automotive air pollution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I write in reference to the oil disaster that hit San Francisco.

title: Tin Ear
description: The Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives has a tin ear for the new sounds which come from New York's increasingly liberal Congressional delegation. There used to be a time when the city's Congressmen were chosen by Tammany Hall, the Brooklyn machine, and the BuCkley organization in the Bronx. In those days, the New Yorkers were stalwart allies the Southerners in running the House establishment.

title: Neighborhoods: College Point Enjoys Life on an Island
description: To find a family in the College Point section of Queens that has lived in the same house for two generations is not difficult. Some families have been rooted in the same frame or clapboard home for four or five generations, and at least one family has spent six generations in one house.

title: House Committee Assignments to Liberals Are Rebuff to Top Southern Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Despite the Southern stronghold in the House Democratic leadership, there were indications last week that the power of some Southern committee chairmen was eroding.

title: Miss Christine M. M. Seidel Is Bride of Roy Thompson 2d
description: CLOSTER, N. J., Jan. 31St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Christine Mary Matthews Seidel,. daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Reginald F. Seidel of Englewood, to Roy Smith Thompson 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gleed Thompson of Bedford Hills, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ronald F. Gray.

title: MACK SHAPIRO
description: EAST MEADOW, LI., Jan. 31  Mack Shapiro, a salesman for Ketchum & Co., a wholesale drug concern in Glendale, Queens, died today in Massapequa General Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 58 years old and lived at 1527 Dieman Lane in East Meadow.

title: LABOSSIERE HELPS STARS ROUT SEALS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 31 (AP)  Gordon Labossiere scored three goals in his first home game for the Minnesota North Stars today to lead a 71 victory over the California Golden Seals.

title: New Hampshire, a Booming Vacationland, Fights to Preserve. Its Natural Beauty
description: CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 26New Hampshire has long been treated much like a park at the edge of a large city, but there is growing concern here that the entire state may be turned into a vacation slum.

title: SWISS NO. 2 BOBSLED TAKES 4MAN CROWN
description: CERVINIA, Italy, Jan. 31 (UPI) Switzerland's No. 2 team made a breakneck secondheat run down the perilous Blue Lake course today and won the 1971 world fourman bobsled championship. Due to cracks in the course, the final competition was held to two heats.

title: Hawks Down Canadiens
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Chicago Black Hawks scored in every period tonight and beat the Montreal Canadiens, 41, to widen their lead in the N.H.L.'s West Division to 17 points over the St. Louis Blues.

title: PORK BELLY BROKERS ADMIT TO VIOLATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)  The Agriculture Department announced today that 22 commodity brokers who admitted violating Federal regulations on trading in pork belly futures have agreed not to engage in such practices again.

title: Herman M. Ellis, Lawyer And Publisher, Dies at 67
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (AP) Herman M. Ellis, a lawyer and the publisher of The Philadelphia Dispatch, died Saturday in New York City while attending an auction at ParkeBernet Galleries. He was 67 years old.

title: Aeronautics Board Eases Policy on Charter Flights
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today a relaxation of its policy on charter flights and signaled that radical changes the charter regulations were coming soon.

title: A.B.C. Prepares to Trim Staff By 300
description: American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., has decided to lay off about 300 employes because of the continuing national business slump.

title: Roosa's Sleep Is Brief; He Says Bed Is Hard
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)Maj. Stuart A. Roosa found his Apollo 14 command ship couch a less than ideal bed during his first night in space.

title: 6 NATIONS STAGE WALKOUT IN O.A.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1Six Latin  American delegations walked out of a conference of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States here today in protest against what they described as an inadequate draft convention to prevent the kidnapping of diplomats and political terrorism in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Mrs. William Marston Seabury, Worker for World Causes, Dies
description: Mrs. Katharine Emerson Seabury, the widow of William Marston Seabury, a New York lawyer, died yesterday at her home, 535 Park Avenue. Her age was not revealed.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN SET A FLATWARE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) The United States and Japan today formally agreed to an annual tariff quota of 16 million dozen pieces of stainless steel flatware imported into this country.

title: The proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Defining Aggression3 P.M.

title: BOB BILLIARD, 53; WRITER OF LYRICS
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 1 (AP) Bob Hilliard, who wrote the lyrics for Dear Hearts and Gentle People, Our Day Will Come and many other wellknown songs, died today. He was 53 years old.

title: Sued in Bridge Closing
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (UPI)The Northeast Ohio Chapter of the Sierra Club filed a $9,960,000 suit today against the Harshaw Chemical Company, charging that fluoride emissions from its plant here for the last 22 years had destroyed the Harvard Dennison bridge over the Cuyahoga Valley. The bridge was closed last March after engineers found it unsafe.

title: MISS VISLOCKY GIVES GRAB RAGS IN DANCE
description: Dorothy Vislocky is interested in clutter. She incorporates it into her dances and even passed some empty cartons out among the audience at her concert Sunday afternoon at Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Mens and Young Womens Hebrew Association, Lexing Avenue and 92d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Clayton Riley has said it all in his brilliant OpEd piece on the Mighty Horse [Jan. 26]. Black children are being destroyed by heroin in Harlem and across the country, while the nation flutters about surburban kids dropping acid and smoking pot. The Horse has ravaged our communities for decades, but no one would hear our cries of anguish.

title: A Girl Pleads for Release of Parents, Victims of Brazil's Police Repression
description: BRASILIA, Feb. 1Eleven days ago a 15yearold Brazilian girl watched her prominent father, his head covered by a black hood, led from their home by unidentified Government security agents. The next day she was hooded and taken with her mother to an army police barracks in Rio de Janeiro.

title: TV: Turned On Crisis
description: The concept behind modern public broadcasting is that the network shouldn't be merely a parochial showcase for the likes, say, of Channel 13 in New York. Ideally, the service should be a collective agency for TV deserving of national distribution, a twoway network enabling a set owner to learn about people, problems and pledges of other sections of the country besides his own.

title: NotGuilty Pleas Entered By 2 Upstate Legislators
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 1 (AP)Two Erie County legislators accused of accepting bribes to influence their votes for a proposed domed sports stadium pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today.

title: 302 Young Policemen Here Receiiie Transfers
description: The Police Department, in one of the largest transfers in recent years, shifted 302 young policemen to new assignments yesterday.

title: Advertising.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The American Advertising Federation's plan for industry selfregulation has begun to take form. As the federation began its 13th annual government affairs conference here today it received words of encouragement, an offer of help and a word of warning.

title: January Auto Output Up By 210/0 From 70 Month
description: Total production by the four major domestic automobile manufacturers in January rose by 21 per cent compared to a year earlier, the companies announced yesterday. All reportled production gains except the American Motors Corporation, where output slipped to 19,851 units last month from 25,921 a year ago.

title: Game CalledFrostbite
description: SPRINGVALE, Maine, Feb. 1 (AP)Nasson College won a 90 forfeit hockey victory tonight when the Belknap College team refused to play after the first period because of frostbite. The game was played on an outdoor rink with the temperature near zero.

title: Prince Back in Madrid
description: MADRID, Feb. 1 (AP)  The heir to the Spanish throne Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, and his wife, Princess Sophia, arrived from New York today after an official visit to the United States.

title: Role of Coal Mine Operators Association Disputed in U.M.W. Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The little  known, multi  million dollar business dealings of the United Mine Workers of America and the union's even wealthier subsidiaries  the U.M.W. Welfare and Retirement Fund, Inc., and the National Bank of Washingtonbegan to unfold publicly today for the first time.

title: Obote Talks with Selassie
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 1 (Reuters)Mr. Obote paid a surprise fivehour visit to Addis Ababa today for talks with Emperor Haile Selassie. His unannounced visit here is understood to have been part of his campaign to block recognition of the new Ugandan Government.

title: Fosse Is Handcuffed By Venezuelan Curve
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 1 (UPI) Ray Fosse, the Cleveland Indians No. 1 catcher, who was to be honored here tonight at the annual baseball writers Ribs and Roast dinner, is being detained in Venezuala until the end of the baseball season there Wednesday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Fatrleigh Beats Iona
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Feb. 1Howie Weinstein scored 16 of his gamehigh 21 points in the second half to spark Fairleigh Dickinson's 6349 victory over Iona tonight. Pete Tierney added 18 and played an outstanding defensive game.

title: MRS. FELIX M. SUTTON
description: Mrs. Felix Marshall Sutton, the former Marjorie Mildred Coe, died in her sleep yesterday at her home, 16 East 98th Street. She was 54 years old.

title: Returnable Bottles Are Proving Unpopular With Dealers Here
description: Under pressure from environmentalists concerned about litter, CocaCola, since the beginning of the year, has been offering 5 cents to everyone who brings back a returnable bottle. But it hasn't been easy to collect that nickel.

title: Market Place: Ways of cuering BackOffice Ils
description: William Picciurro is proof of the maxim that America is the land of opportunity. He started out more than a decade ago as an 18yearold clerk in aWall Street brokerage house's back office.

title: Architect Heads A.S.P.C.A.
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has announced the election of Charles S. Haines as president. Mr. Haines, a partner in the architectural firm of Haines, Lundberg & Waehler in New York City, has been senior vice president of the society. He succeeds John Thompson, Jr., of Whytheville, Va.

title: Basketball Poll
description: The leading college basketball teams with points tabulated on a 2018161412109876.54321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records through last Saturday.

title: Israelis Honor Mrs. Meir
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 1 (AP)Results of Israel's Man of the Year poll were published today, and Premier Golda Heir won with 31 per cent of the rott Defense Minister Mr he Dayan received per sent.

title: APOLLO CLEARED TO MAKE MOON LANDING ON FRIDAY; NO DOCKING FLAWS FOUND
description: HOUSTON, Tuesday, Feb. 2 Apollo 14 was cleared yesterday to proceed toward its planned moon landing early Friday, and the craft was moving smoothly toward that goal today.

title: Prints V an Gogh Used in Studio Are Shown in Brooklyn Museum
description: More than 100 lithographs, wocd engravings and other prints collected by Vincent van Gogh and used in his studio as source material for his paintings went on exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum yesterday, preceding an exhibition of his paintings and drawings that opens Feb. 14. The two exhibitions will run concurrently until April 4.

title: 2 New Gauges, Used to Measure U.S. Payment Flow
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1The Council of Economic Advisers published today two new measures of the United States balance of international payments. It said both were under consideration as improvements over the two measures now used, which are widely regarded as unsatisfactory.

title: Art Teacher Slain; Philadelphia Police Arrest Youth, 14
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 (UPI), A white teacher was shot to death in the back of the neck today by an eighth grader he had suspended for cursing in the hallway of a junior high school, the police said.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Sine Nomine Group Is Dulcet In a Sang Flight Into the Past
description: For no better reason than that they wrote nothing for the symphony orchestra or the piano, those touchstones of musical taste in our century, most of the great composers of history are scarcely more than names to the concertgoing public. Still, now and again a program such as the Sine Nomine Singers presented on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall comes along to remind us of how narrow a perspective it is that does not take in such figures as Johannes Ockeghem, Josquin des Prez, Orlando di Lasso, Claude le Jeune, Ludwig Senfl and Don Carlo Gesualdo.

title: Stockyard Closing Enjoined
description: CHICAGO. Feb. 1 (UPI) Federal District Court Judge Hubert L. Will signed an injunction today ordering the Chicago Union Stockyards to remain open until Aug. 1. The South Side yards announced in October that cattle and sheep trading would cease today. The yards stopped handling pigs last May 15. The ruling came on a suit by cattle buyers, sellers and feeders to keep the yards open until a new facility under construction at Joliet, about 40 miles southwest, could be completed.

title: WOMAN IS ACCEPTED AS 9TH SEALE JUROR
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 1An unemployed waitress with three years of college education became the ninth juror accepted as jury selection for the trial of Black Panthers Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins began its 11th week today.

title: NELSON MAYNARD
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 1Nelson Maynard, a director since 1933 of Wood Industries in Plainfield, died Saturday after a short illness at his home, 764 Scotland Road. He was 87 years old.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL IS UP FOR A FIFTH WEEK
description: Steel production last week recorded the fifth sharp gain in succession, advancing by 2.5 per cent from output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington.

title: Cairo Sees No Progress
description: CAIRO, Feb. 1With lessi than four days remaining before the expiration of the ceasefire, Egypt insisted that no progress had been made in the peace talks.

title: Spaghetti Breakfast All in the Day's Work
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 1 (UPI)The menu for the Apollo 14 astronauts breakfast in space today called for spaghetti, and meat sauce, tomato soup and peach ambrosia.

title: Letters to the Editor
