description: The defense tried to show yesterday that the police undercover man who helped gather evidence against 13 Black Panthers on trial for an alleged bomb conspiracy was a marijuanasmoking, heavydrinking woman chaser.

title: Ginzburg Sentence Of 3 Years Upheld By Appeals Court
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) Ralph Ginzburg, convicted of mailing sexoriented, obscene advertising and books, has lost a new bid to stay out of jail.

title: General Foods to Split Stock
description: Directors of the General Foods Corporation voted yesterday a 2for1 stock split to take place about March 29, and also raised the quarterly dividend on the present shares to 70 cents from 65 cents, payable March to holders of record Feb. 16.

title: Mayor and Senator Harris Head A Panel to Study Cities Plight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Mayor Lindsay of New York and Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma were named cochairmen today of a new panel to study the plight of the cities.

title: Michael Gordon Directs a Domestic 'How Do I Love Thee?'
description: "How Do I Love Thee?" which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is the kind of movie that some years ago, whether good or bad, would have been made with a measure of care and affection. Some traces of affection remain, at least in a few of the characterizations, but for all the care that has been expended, this might as well have been the first run-through of a television pilot with a lot of polishing still to be done before presenting itself for oblivion.Readers and nonreaders alike will recognize the source of the titlewhich will put them one up on most of the cast (newspapermen, college teachers, and the like), upon whose ignorance of that sonnet's authorship the plot more or less depends.The film's situation, which is different from and rather more important than its plot, is another matter. Essentially, it concerns a relationship between father and son (Jackie Gleason and Rick Lenz) that might in a better movie prove both touching and complicated and that even here suggests the material of a domestic comedy that sees domesticity not as a sour joke but rather as a way of living.Gleason plays a Miami small businessman, a mover, a self-educated athiest who battles for the mind and spirit of his son, Tom (after Tom Paine), with a wife (Maureen O'Hara) whose devotion to the godhead seems to encompass several major orthodoxies and some splinter sects as well.Set mostly as a flashback of Tom's, the film includes various family crises, his father's mature dalliance (Shelly Winters), his own marriage (Rosemary Forsyth), his studies and his eventual appointment as chairman of the philosophy department at what has to be the worst college in America.But all these ordinary, and rather traditionally cinematic, and by no means disreputable sweet memories become in "How Do I Love Thee?" a collection of routine skits, which Michael Gordon seems mostly to have abstained from directing. I have never before been quite so conscious of watching professional actors so sadly at a loss, at any given moment, for what to do next.If only for a lot of other movies in her career, I must nevertheless praise the beautiful Maureen O'Hara. And Jackie Gleason, despite far too rich a sun tan and the suggestion of too much good living for this partwhen called upon to move a piano, he moves a piano. And there is something to be said for truth even at that level.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 21 editorial entitled Status Quo Wins describes in the closing paragraph Representative Hale Boggs (recently chosen majority leader) as a man who has the intelligence to be responsive to the new currents of feeling.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Food for Wintry Thought
description: BRANFORD, Conn.Several days ago, Oliver (Bud) Beckley of Branford, Conn., and I got together for our annual bluebill hunt on Long Island Sound, but instead of shooting ducks we spent most of our time chatting in the kitchen of his shorefront home, facing the fact that we were deep in the caution of middle age. We ventured forth only once to throw corn to a flock of icebound mallards.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A number of states report plans to revise laws regarding possession and use of marijuana. I should like to propose grouping marijuana with alcohol and tobacco for regulatory purposes. While these drugs differ in their addictive qualities and in their hazards to health, some form of restriction is required to protect the young.JAMES I. WENDELL Jr., M.D. Pottstown, Pa., Jan. 20, 1971

title: News Analysis
description: NEWARK, Feb. 3After seven months in office, Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson faces two serious crises that are exacerbated by this city's latent racial hostilities.

title: On Third 'Julius Caesar' Filming: Et tu, Jason Robards et al!
description: "Ye gods! Must I endure all this?" understandably bellows Cassius (Richard Johnson) in the last lap of the third filming of William Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar," which opened yesterday at the Kips Bay Theater. Made in England and Spain and in color, with a perfectly viable cast headed by Jason Robards and Charlton Heston, the new picture is generally as flat and juiceless as a dead haddock. In this third go-round, Willie and Julius, both, really get the business.It's Shakespeare all right, at least in dialogue. Dramaturgically, the blueprint adheres to the Hollywood version back in 1953. That solid, intelligent treatment may have lacked majesty but it did have two fire-and-ice performances by John Gielgud as Cassius and Marlon Brando as Mark Antony. And the tormented soul of the real hero, Brutus (James Mason), was sufficiently and touchingly bared.Then there was an even earlier "Julius Caesar" from Chicago, of all places, with a newcomer named Charlton Heston as Antony, which he repeats here. The movie did have a raw, shoestring vigor and a bit more.The new movie moves sluggishly, as directed by Stuart Burge. As the center of the whole thing, Robards is incredibly dull and wooden as Brutus, the "noblest Roman of them all." Heston supplies laconic bite and delivers a good, ferocious funeral oration. For all his professionalism, Gielgud's Caesar is just an old shrewdie who yields to his ego.In Sir John's former Cassius slot, Johnson looks anything but "lean and hungry," with a bearded sneer, contrasting Robert Vaughn's bland, eye-rolling Casca. However, Diana Rigg and Richard Chamberlain, as Portia and Octavius Caesar, are briefly excellent in their quicksliver precision and feeling.But it's hopeless. Now "Julius Caesar" looks left out all night.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Brooklyn Garden Apartments Approved Despite Opposition
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday approveddespite community opposition plans for a 904unit gardentype apartment project in Brooklyn. The commission also cleared up a technical error by voting again to advance the proposal for a new Manhattan House of Detention for Men.

title: SYDNEY ALBERT, 63, IN BELLANCA DEALS
description: Sydney L. Albert of Akron, Ohio, a financier, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Doctors Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Theater: Skye, a Musical Fairy Tale
description: In addition to its regular series of plays at the Master Institute, the Equity Library Theater occasionally showcases musicals in the auditorium of the Lincoln Center Library. Last night a new musical called Skye finished a threeperformance run.

title: Scribner Would Let Girls Play Against Boys in Some Sports
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has recommended that girls be permitted to compete with boys on high school athletic teams in such noncontact sports as tennis and swimming.

title: 100 Protest LowIncome Housing for Forest Hills
description: About 100 Forest Hills resi dents, protesting plans for an 850unit, lowincome public housing project in their area, marched into the Queens Criminal Court Building in Kew Gardens last fiight where a boroughwide planning meeting was under way.

title: HOUSTON FACES L.I.U. AT GARDEN TONIGHT
description: Houston, seeking a postseason tournament bid and a higher ranking in the polls, will oppose Long Island University tonight in the second game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. In the opener at 7 P.M., Manhattan is paired against New York University.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS UPHOLD SENIORITY BY30VOTE MARGIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Efforts of liberals to topple the seniority system failed today as House Democrats refused to unseat an elderly committee chairman.

title: Badillo Wins His Battle on House Committee Assignment, but Mrs. Abzug Loses
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 3Representative Herman Badillo won his fight today to have his committee assignment changed from Agriculture to Education and Labor, but another New York Democrat, Bella S. Abzug, lost her bid for a seat on the Armed Services Committee.

title: Raids on Trail Continue
description: SAIGON, Feb. 3  The United States command today reported continued raids by B52's over the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: Montclair State Wins 11th
description: LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 3  Montclair State College gained its 11th victory in 13 starts tonight by downing Monmouth College, 83.79.

title: National Voter Registration Proposed by Senator Bayh
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, proposed today a national voter registration law for Federal elections.

title: COMPUTER LESSOR SETS REFINANCING
description: The board of the Scientific Resources Corporation of Philadelphia approved yesterday plan to refinance a major portion of the company's debt and estimated that the company would report a loss of $43million for the year ended Sept. 30, 1970.

title: Crosscurrents in the House
description: The liberal Democrats in the House of Representatives have been faring well at the hands of the leadership, but badly in the secret votes of the caucus. This discrepancy occurs partly because conservative Southerners who rarely support the national party are relatively numerous in the House, but the leadership realistically recognizes that the Northern and. Western liberals come from the states where Presidential elections are won or lost.

title: BERNARD SPINDEL, WIRETAPPER, DIES
description: CARMEL, N. Y., Feb. 3 (AP) Bernard B. Spindel, a professional wiretapper under a prison sentence for his electronic eavesdropping, died today at Putnam Community Hospital at the age of 48. He had suffered the latest in a series of heart attacks on Friday.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Baseball to Admit Negro St4rs of PreIntegration Era Into Hall of Fame
description: The major leagues established a system yesterday to elect stars from the old Negro leagues into baseball's Hall of Fame.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Hawks End Rangers 26Game Home Unbeaten Streak, 4 to
description: The Rangers lost at home last might for the first time this season, falling victims to an expert Chicago Black Hawk outfit as well as their own unsure tentative play that has gripped them for nine games.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The big but still barely visible joust in Washington this season is between President Nixon and Wilbur D. Mills, the man known variously here as the country lawyer from Harvard or the de Gaulle from the Ozarks, and always as the powerful chairman of the House Committee on Ways and Means. Mr. Mills, a Democrat from Arkansas, figures hugely in Mr. Nix on's dream of a New American Revolution and of a decent chance for reelection, because he controls the switch that will regulate the flow of the President's major domestic interests between now and November, 1972: welfare reform, health care reform, Social Security improvements, trade limitation, tax reform and, above all at the moment, what is called revenue sharing.

title: SPORT STARS SET FOR PHOENIX GOLF
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb 3Nine professional athletes will represent New York in the $30,000 American Airlines Astrojet golf tournament beginning Friday at the GoodyearGolf and Country Club.

title: Advertising:
description: In a statement issued yesterday, International Playtex said that its split with Young & Rubicarn resulted from its belief that the agency's creative work had not been satisfactory.

title: Layer Makes It 8 in a Row
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 3Rod Laver of Australia ran his string of victories in the $210000 Tennis Champions Classics to eight in a row and his earnings to $80,000 by defeating Roger Taylor of Great Britain tonight in the Forum, 63, 75, 62. Laver will next meet Tom Okker Saturday at Madison Square Garden in New York.

title: Penguins Triumph, 61
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 3 (UPI)Rod Zaine, a rookie, scored two goals as the Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the California Golden Seals, 61, tonight in a Na tional Hackey League game.

title: Leafs Beat Blues, 62
description: TORONTO, Feb. 3 (UPI)Paul Henderson scored a key goal midway in the second period tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs spotted St. Louis a twogoal lead and then got six straight tallies to beat the Blues, 62.

title: MARKET INCHES UP IN HECTIC TRADING
description: The stock market turned around yesterday from a slight drop in the morning to a slight gain in the afternoon. Volume continued along the same hectic pace it has maintained thus far in 1971.

title: A Comics Magazine Defies Code Ban on Drug Stories
description: For the first time since its adoption 16 years ago, the Code of the Comics Magazine Association of America, which governs the contents of more than 300 million comic books published each year in the United States, has been overhauled.

title: Stackpole and Chappell Bat Aussies to Draw in Cricket
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 3 (Reuters)  A secondwicket stand of 202 runs by Keith Stackpole and Ian Chappell enabled Australia to gain a draw against England today in the sixth cricket test.

title: White House Services Set
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 3 (AP) A Lutheran official, the Rev. Dr. Jacob A. O. Preus, St. Louis will conduct worship services at the White House Sunday. Dr. Preus is president of the threemillionmember Lutheran Church, Missouri Synod.

title: Nixon Appoints 13 to Panel Studying Tourism in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI)  President Nixon appointed 10 business leaders and 3 Government officials today to the National Tourism Review Commission, which is studying ways to promote foreign travel in the United States.

title: Macy Names Treasurer
description: Jack Hanson, who has been senior vice president for corporate control and finance of R. H. Macy & Co., Inc., has been appointed vice president for corporate control and treasurer. The treasurer's post is being relinquished by Donald B. Smiley, chairman, whose appointment as chief executive officer was announced earlier.

title: Continental's Chief Derides Hysteria Of Most Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Robert F. Six, the controversial but perennially successful president of Continental Airlines, told the Senate Commerce Committee this morning that the financial hysteria among his industry colleagues should be largely ignored.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Was the publication of F. Reid Buckley's spiteful distortion of reaction to the Burgos Basque trials [OpEd. Jan. 27] a contribution by The Times to the welcome of Prince Juan Carlos, currently on a state visit here? Those trials reminded everyone of the role of the Basques in the Spanish Civil War, but few understand that role to this day.

title: Near Minneapolis, 2 New Towns Border on Success
description: CHASKA, Minn.  Clyde Ryberg skidded his utility wagon to a halt on a snowcovered meadow and pointed to a cluster of buildings under constructionhouses up to $50,000 and apartments for lowincome and moderateincome families.

title: The Talk of Iowa City
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, Feb. 1The effete East and the avantgarde West may look upon this part of the United States as the middle of nowhere, but sooner or later most of the established and aspiring writers in America make a pilgrimage here.

title: U.S. ESTABLISHING NEW CRIME INDEX
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Federal Government is establishing a new system of crime statistics designed to gauge the level of damage and anxiety caused by crime, as well as to provide a more accurate measure of the crime rate.

title: JACOB L. SIROTA
description: Jacob L. Sirota, a law assistant at the Kings County Supreme Court, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 488 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn. He was 63 years old.

title: East Side Fire Kills Girl, 2; 4 Others in Family Injured
description: A 2yearold girl was killed last night and four of her brothers and sisters were treated for burns after a fire raced through the top floor of an apartment house at 31 Oliver Street in the Two Bridges section on the Lower East Side.

title: Rear Adm. John K. Leydon, ExNavy Research Chief
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3, (AP) Rear Adm. John K. Leydon, former chief of research for the Navy, died today at the United States Naval Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Lahaska.

title: Truda T. Weil, Innovator in Schools Is Dead at
description: Truda T. Weil, who retired as Assistant Superintendent of Schools in charge of elementary schools in 1969, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. She was 71 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: ROYALS SET BACK CELTICS BY 134115
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 3 (AP) Flynn Robinson scored all 17 of his points in the second quarter tonight as the Cincinnati Royals tallied 43 and beat the Boston Celtics, 134115, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Boston Museum Mounts an Unusual New Art Show
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3The Museum of Fine Arts, which has long been under attack in Boston art circles for its traditional policy of paying little or no attention to contemporary art, has suddenly upstaged its critics by mounting an extremely audacious exhibition of new artan exhibition that includes the use of real fire, some wild life, lots of water and sundry other natural and technological phenomena. Entitled Earth, Air, Fire, Water: Elements of Art and consisting for the most part of very large and highly unorthodox constructions, tableaus and happenings, the exhibition is the final event of the museum's centennial program. It opens to the public tomorrow and remains on view through April 4.

title: $48Million Loss Posted By Pan American in 70
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., announced yesterday a $48,032,000 loss for 1970, which followed a $25,888,000 loss in 1969. Pan American's fourthquarter loss was $46, 762,000, compared with a loss of $18,932,000 in the yearearlier quarter.

title: Credit Markets: Activity Revived in Bond Trading
description: The bond markets, which had been Suffering the midwinter blahs for the last five days, came to life late yesterday afternoon.

title: U.A.W. Chrysler Employes Ratify ThreeYear Contract
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers announced today that its 110,000 hourly rated workers at Chrysler Corporation's American and Canadian plants had ratified a new threeyear contract with the company.

title: HORACE BRITT, 89, CONCERT CELLIST
description: Horace Britt, a concert cellist, who taught cello at the University of Texas from 1948 to 1965, died yesterday at nursing home in Austin, Tex. He was 89 years old.

title: In Palm Beach, Dinner Jacket Is Worn to the Polls
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 This city's monthlong political cammign which consisted maimy of a continuous round Of cocktail parties and other assorted social events, came to an end yesterday with the election of Earl E.T. Smith, the 67yearold financier and former. Ambassador to Cuba, as Mayor of Palm BeaclFlorida's, and possibly, the country's, most exelusive resort.

title: An Experiment in International Cooking
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.You scoop out the avocados, Marilyn Seabury was saying, and I'll do the mashies. Mashies, it turned out, were the lemons that were being squeezed into what would become a dish of guacamole.

title: Portrait of a Prince in Exile
description: PEKINGIn a large villa in Peking lives Prince Samdech Norodom Sihanouk, one of our century's many exiles, deposed during his absence by a coup d'etat on March 18, 1970, and the leader of his country's war of liberation against the Lon Nol regime. Now 49, he has been Cambodia's leader since tke age of eighteen.

title: Man in the News
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 3Two years ago, the Westchester County Democratic chairman, William F. Luddy, put Max Berking in charge of a committee to find someone to run for County Executive.

title: Wings, Stars Play 44 Tie
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 3 (UPI)Nick Libett scored with 29 seconds to play to give the Detroit Red Wings a 44 tie with the Minnesota North Stars tonight in a National Hockey League game.

title: Mrs. Rockefeller Leaves Lincoln Center $10Million
description: Lincoln Center of the Performing Arts has received $10million, the largest of 14 charitable bequests totaling $36.5million, the bulk of the estate of the late Mrs. Martha Baird Rockefeller, widow of John D. Rockefeller Jr.

title: Market Place: Canadian Island Probed for Fuel
description: The present confrontation between 10 major oilproducing nations, which account for 90 per cent of the world's petroleum exports, and the oilconsuming countries has underscored the importance of having ample energy supplies in friendly hands.

title: Gen. Fred S. Robillard, 80, Led Marine Transportation
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Fb. 3Maj. Gen. Fred S. Robillard U.S.M.C., retired, of Miami Shores, Fla., died on Sunday in Stamford Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: CARL F. WENTE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 (UPI)Carl F. Wente, former president of the Bank of America, died Monday evening. He was 81 years old.

title: EXPERTS SCORE COUGH MIXTURES
description: An independent team of physicians who are experts on therapeutics has condemned the widespread use of commercial cough mixtures as probably ineffective, potentially dangerous and subject to abuse by youngsters looking for kicks.

title: Con Edison Cuts Voltage By 5% for 3d Straight Day
description: For the third consecutive day, the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday imposed a 5 per cent voltage reduction to stretch its power supply for extraheavy heating demands.

title: Scottish Curlers End Tour By Winning 4 of 7 Matches
description: MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Feb. 3Royal Caledonian Curling Club women of Scotland concluded their American tour today by winning four matches, losing one and tying two in exhibitions at St. Andrew's Golf Club and Ardsley Curling Club.

title: Ranking of Legislatures
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The following table lists the states in order of their legislatures ability to meet their responsibilities, as judged by the Citizens Conference on State Legislatures. Overall ranking was based on ranking five categories: functional ability, based on staff, membership, organization and procedures; accountability to the people, as based on the ability of the public to make its will known and find out what the legislature is doing; capability of the body to collect and constructively use information; independence of members from a wide range of influence, including special interests and conflict of interest; how well the legislature is representative of the people.

title: News of Skiing
description: A new competition, the national championship of exhibition skiing, has been announced for Waterville Valley in New Hampshire's rugged Ski 93 country. It will be held March 5 and 6. The event will emphasize exciting performances  great leaps with style and control and imaginative use of the course with speed and daring.

title: Bruins Win
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Bobby Orr and John Bucyk scored two goals apiece to give the East Division, leading Boston Bruins a 73 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Assembly Votes to Allow Silent Prayer in School
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3Attempts by members of the Assembly to escape today from this refrigerated capital for the weekend were slowed considerably when the legislators took up three favorite debate topicsreligion, the flag and alcohol.

title: Blast at Arms Plant In Georgia Kills 24; 33 Are Hospitalized
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., Feb. 3At least 24 persons were killed today when a blast and fire leveled a munitions building at a Thiokol Chemical Corporation plant.

title: Executive Changes
description: Yardney Electric Corporation announced yesterday the election of Dr. Joseph Seton Smith, 4s years old, as president and chief executive officer. These posts were formerly held by Joseph Kleiman, who continues as chairman. Dr. Smith had been vice president of Litton Industries, Inc., and president of its guidance and control division.

title: Wife Raises Historic Flag
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Mrs. Alan B. Shepard Jr. raised an American flag today that once flew over the nation's Capitol. Mrs. Shepard said the flag was presented to her husband after he made the first United States manned space flight on May 5, 1961.

title: SOVIET ECONOMY REBOUNDED IN 70
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3The Soviet Union announced today that its economy rebounded more strongly in 1970 than had first been predicted but that it failed to achieve most of the longrange goals set under the fiveyear plan that ended Dec. 31.

title: 4 JOCKEYS CLAIM FOUL IN ONE RACE
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 3 (AP)If there at'e no more objections, today's first race at Pimlico can be considered official.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 21 editorial, Telephone Test, disregards both the facts and the humanities involved.

title: U.S. School Lunch Aid Cut Off In 92 Districts Across Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Federal school lunch aid was cut off last month from 92 school districts that failed to file required policy statements on providing free or tokenpriced lunches to needy children, officials disclosed today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  When Indictments were returned against Father Philip Berrigan and others for allegedly plotting to kidnap Henry Kissinger and blow up the Government heating plant, I wrote that hoped no such vile scheme actually was concocted in the name of peace and justice.

title: Text of Connally Fee Pact
description: Following is the text of a letter John B. Connally Jr. supplied to the Senate Finance Committee that sets forth the agreement under which he was to receive $750,000 in deferred payments as coexecutor of the estate of Sid W. Richardson:

title: EGYPTIANS AGREE TO EXTEND TRUCE FOR MONTH MORE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The United Arab Republic has informed the United States that it will continue for one more month the truce with Israel, due to expire on Friday, American officials said today.

title: Boston U. Six Tops Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 3Steve Stirling and Don Cahoon scored two goals apiece tonight, leading Boston University to a 51 hockey victory over Yale. Bob Brown got the other goal for the winners, who have a 1611 wonlosttied record. Brian Bird scored for Yale, whose record dropped to 3121.

title: Falsification Found In Basel Subsidiary Of California Bank
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 3 (AP)  The city prosecutor said tonight that his investigation had confirmed a massive falsification of balance sheets to cover up a loss of more than $30million at the Basel subsidiary of the United California Bank of Los Angeles.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS CURBS ON. STRIKES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3President Nixon, in his fourth legislative message to the 92d Congress, renewed today his plea for stronger machinery to ward off strikes in the transportation industry.

title: Advertising:
description: It's very cold and very barren, and all the drawers are shut, said the adman. He was talking about the employment situation in the agency business.

title: New L.I. Beach Show Plan
description: The Jones Beach State Park Authority and Guy Lombardo announced yesterday that 1,000 seats at the 8,200seat Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, L.I., will be made available at $2 each every night next summer for performances of The Sound of Music. The Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, which played at the Long Island theater last summer, opens there on July 7 and will play nightly through Sept. 5th.

title: To Save the Commonwealth
description: One observer said the 31nation Commonwealth survived its recent summit conference only because in Mr. Heath's day, membership appears to mean more to the former colonies than it does to Britain. In any event it is now primarily up to the mothei country to determine whether the outcome at Singapore represents merely a reprieve for this unique international organization or the beginning of another period of useful activity.

title: Mrs. Textor Married To Emerson Swartz
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3 Mrs. Janice Fleming Textor of Garden City, L. I., widow of George C. Textor, chairman of the board of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company of New York, was married here on Jan. 14 in a civil ceremony to Emerson Swartz, a lawyer, also of Garden City.

title: About Pro Basketball
description: The tough time the Cincinnati Royals gave the Knicks Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, before the Knicks finally posted the expected victory, 115108, Served as well as anything to focus attention on the way the National Basketball Association playoffs are shaping up. The two teams will probably meet in the first round, and the Knicks were impressed by Cin cinnati's energy more than by any other facet of their play. A sevengame playoff series, compressed into a short period of time, could become an ordeal for the Knicks.

title: Census Study Finds An Education Cap
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 3A Census Bureau study released today shows an explosive growth in the amount of education obtained by young Americans in the last 30 years.

title: Knesset Appeals to World To Aid Jews in Arab Lands
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 3A call for international pressure on Arab governments to halt alleged persecution of their Jewish subjects and to permit them to emigrate was issued today by the Knesset in Jerusalem.

title: Oil Exporting Countries Plan Sharp Price Rise
description: LONDON, Feb. 3The major oil exporting countries laid plans in Teheran today to impose sharply higher prices on Western oil companies.

title: Theater: Waiting for Godot Revived
description: Some 15 years ago Samuel Beckett's play Waiting for Godot seemed difficult, even to many of its admirers. It was revived again, and very finely revived, at the Sheridan Square Playhouse last night, and this time I suspect it will not be found difficult even by its detractors. Time catches up with genius, and time, by the way, is the essence of Beckett's purpose.

title: Mine Union Chief Criticizes Choice for Safety Enforcer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers, criticized today the selection of Edward D. Failor for the $30,000ayear job of enforcer of Federal coal mine safety standards.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The children were standing around laughing at mother again. Behind her back and out of earshot, of course.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 25 editorial on marijuana merits serious thought by every human being with an interest in his own health as well as the health of his fellow man.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Sales of Savings Bonds Again Top Redemptions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. (UPI)  Savings Bond sales exceeded redemptions by $9million in January, the fourth straight month in which savers added to their bond holdings, the Treasury reported today.

title: CheckingAccount Turnover In U.S. Up 4% in December
description: The turnover of checking accounts at the nation's banks increased substantially during December, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday. At banks in New York Cityperhaps as a reflection of a rising volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchangedebits, or charges to demand deposit accounts came to a record $5trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up 4 per cent from November, and 19.5 per cent from December 1969.

title: Sales of New Cars Rose by 13% in January
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3  American car makers reported that their new model sales rate in the final third of January climbed 10 per cent from last year, and for the full month rose 13 per cent above 1970.

title: South Vietnamese Attack In Cambodia Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3  South Vietnamese officials reported tonight that 10,000 Government troops were engaged in a new campaign in Cambodia to clean out what were described as enemy border sanctuaries.

title: Bridge: Use of the Limit Jump Raisd Makes Problem for Responder
description: A majority of topranking experts and a substantial number of tournament enthusiasts use limit jump raises.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: Soviet Says Laos Invasion Perils Settlement Efforts
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3The Soviet Union today denounced what it called the armed invasion by United States and Saigon puppet troops in Laos.

title: Fordham Surge in 2d Half Checks Army, 6560, Giving Rams 141 Record
description: It was another typical ArmyFordham basketball game. It was a wara war that Army was winning in its usual tenacious, defensive styleuntil the final five minutes.

title: Erpf Memorial Next Week
description: A memorial service for Armand G. Erpf, a senior partner in Loeb, Rhoades & Co., who died Tuesday, will be held at 9:30 A.M. next Thursday at the Whitney Museum of American, Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: Deepest Part of the Ocean Is Pinpointed by New Atlas
description: WASHINGTON  How deep is the ocean?

title: State Senate Committee Charges City Lags on Proposals for Reforms at Tombs
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3The Senate Committee on Crime and Correction charged today that the New York City Department of Correction had made little or no effort to implement proposals it made after the October riots at the Tombs to humanize conditions there.

title: Senators Assail Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The official embargo on news reports from Saigon about the South Vietnamese operation at the Laotian border was severely criticized today by several leading Democrats and Republican Senators.

title: Agnew Calls for Recognition of 18YearOlds as Mature Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Vice President Agnew sympathized today with what he called the youth liberation movement and called for recognition of 18yearolds as mature Americans.

title: Highlights of Apollo Flight
description: Following are highlights of the Apollo 14 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern standard.

title: On Dig in Turkey, People Called Her Mister Director
description: When she first went to Cnidus in Turkey in 1967, the village women would gather around Iris Love to stare her and touch her:

title: Lawrence Fanning, Publisher of Paper In Anchorage, Dies
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 3Lawrence. Fanning, editor and publisher of The Anchorage Daily News and formerly a top executive of the Marshall Field publishing enterprises in Chicago, died at Providence Hospital today of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There are today differing views on whether the dangers of marijuana are real or exaggerated, but there can be no disagreement that the penalties for its use are barbaric and hopelessly antiquated. Medical research will provide the answer to the first question but enlightened legislation is needed for the second. The law as it exists today has lagged far behind the public need.

title: MAJOR DRIVE NEAR LAOS BY G.I.'S AND VIETNAMESE IS ANNOUNCED IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 4United States and South Vietnamese troops have launched a major operation into the northwest corner of South Vietnam, the United States command announced. This cleared the way for a possible South Vietnamese strike against the Ho Ohi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: TV: Miller's The Price
description: Arthur Miller's play, The Price, a feature of the 1968 season on Broadway, lent itself admirably to a television adaptation last night on the Hallmark Hall of Fame of the National Broadcasting Company. The tight focus of the TV camera captured superbly the agony of two brothers resurrecting a family portrait with different brushes.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Shop Talk
description: BergdorfGoodman is transplanting a little bit of London to its sixth floor and Barbara Hulanicki and her husband, Stephen FitzSimon, are here to watch the transformation. So is their 3yearold son, Witold, who has been romping around in his lacedup boots, getting in the workmen's way and occasionally giving a few orders, lust as he does in his shop at home. His shop is Biba, on High Street in Kensington, which his parents started a few years before he was born. The FitzSimons are used to their son strutting around as if he owned the place, and they didn't dream of leaving him home when they came to New York.

title: JIM FRENCH WINS BAHAMAS BY HEAD
description: MIAMI, Feb. 3It looked as if it was going to be a frustrating day for the irrepressible Johnny Campo, but in the end Campo had the whole world in his handsat least that part of it bounded by the hedges of Hialeah Race Course.

title: LA SALLE DOWNS LOYOLA, 74 TO 53
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP)  Kenney Durrett scored 10 points in 48 seconds to spark La Salle to an 180 lead as the 12thranked Explorers went on to beat Loyola of New Orleans, 7453, tonight. La Salle posted its 15th victory against one loss.

title: Abbado: Big Sonorities With Control
description: First it was. Russian music at the Philadelphia Orchestra concert Tuesday night in Philharmonic Hall, and then the Beethoven Eroica. Every young conductor has to show the world his special, patented, epochmaking Eroica, and Claudio Abbado is no exception. But his program also contained the ballet music from Prokofiev's Chout and Scriabin's Poem of Ecstasy, and both of those works are sufficiently unusual, though the Scriabin orchestral music has been getting a bit of an outing these days.

title: Evocations by Ruggles
description: Two premieres gave the National Orchestral Association's concert on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall a promising prospect: the first performance in its orchestral version of Carl Ruggles's Evocations, and the New York debut with symphonic orchestra of John Perras, the guest conductor. Both the music and the musician made moderately successful bows at best.

title: M'GOVERN CRITICIZES BUDGET ON HUNGER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Nixon Administration's new antihunger budget proposals fall short even of the President's own announced goals, Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today. The Senator urged Congress and the Administration to set June 30, 1972, as deadline for ending hunger in the nation.

title: Networks to Televise Excursions on Moon
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)The three major networks will televise the scheduled moon excursions Friday and Saturday.

title: Columbia Blocking Registration for 2 Till Key ls Returned
description: Columbia University has prohibited two Puerto Rican students from registering for the spring semester until a key taken before a sitin at the school earlier this week is returned to university officials.

title: STUDY. PANEL NAMED ON EFFECTS OF SST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans appointed a committee of private scientists and engineers today to study the potential effect of supersonic transport planes on weather, climate and radiation levels.

title: Prudential Lines Struck in Fight Over Crew for New Cargo Ship
description: The International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, struck the Prudential Grace Lines yesterday in a dispute over the deployment of deck officers on the new LASH cargo vessels.

title: Toure Calm on Criticism of Executions
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 2During a week's visit this correspondent saw the bodies of four former Government officials hanging from a bridge over a main street in this West African capital. Informed sources said four others had been executed in various upcountry towns.

title: POMPIDOU STARTS A VISIT TO AFRICA
description: PARIS. Feb. 3President Pompidou flew to Mauritania today to begin what he termed a friendship visit to five African nations that were once under French domination.

title: BANK TIE APPROVED AND ANOTHER DENIED
description: The New York State Banking Board denied yesterday the proposed acquisition by Marine Midland Banks, Inc., of the Chenango County National Bank and Trust Company of Norwich, N. Y. But at the same time, the board approved a proposal by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation to take over the Industrial Bank of Binghamton, N. Y.

title: Winslow, Cohn Indicted by U.S. for Violating Credit Regulations
description: The stock brokerage concern of Winslow, Cohn & Stetson, Inc., was indicted by a special (grand jury yesterday on charges of violating Federal regulations by extending credit of up to 100 per cent to major buyers of registered securities.

title: Apollo 14 Rockets Into Orbit of Moon; Lunar Landing is Scheduled Tomorrow
description: HOUSTON, Thursday, Feb. 4 Apollo 14 rocketed into an orbit of the moon early today and prepared to sweep lower into position for the planned lunar landing tomorrow morning.

title: Dismissal of Drug Charge Against Detective Studied
description: Three separate agencies are trying to find out why the office of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell permitted a detective accused of conspiring to sell heroin  a felony  to plead guilty to a misdemeanor charge of official misconduct.

title: Mrs. Onassis Returns For White House Visit
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 3 (UPI)Mrs. Aristotle Onassis and her two children, Caroline and John F. Kennedy Jr., returned to the White House tonight for their first visit since December, 1963, shortly after the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: Books of The Tithes.
description: They've revived No, No, Nanette! Can we bring back Philip Wylie? He's never been away, of course, but a certain nostalgia attends the publication of a sequel to his most famous book, Generation of Vipers (1943), in which he told us America was a mess. Published at a moment in World War II when loud, rude criticism.

title: About Pro Footbill
description: Karl Douglas of Texas A. and I is the latest in a long line of candidates who aspired to become the first successful black quarterback in pro football. Douglas was a thirdround draft choice of the Baltimore Colts last week. He and Sam Havrilak, a thirdyear pro, are to be groomed next season as eventual replacements for John Unitas and Earl Morrall, who will be 38 and 37. Douglas intends to be a quarterliack. None of that switching positions for me, he said recently by telephone from the campus in Kingsville, Tex. I'm going to make it at quarterback.

title: Parley on Wall St. Held by White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Peter M. Flanigan, an assistant to President Nixon, reportedly told 12 leaders of the securities industry last week that the White House believed there were aspects of the industry that needed study and change.White House could work together to thwart or blunt scheduled investigations of the securities industry by committees of the House and Senate, which are both controlled by Democrats.

title: BARRY'S 30 POINTS AID NETS VICTORY
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 3Rick Barry scored 14 points in the last quarter tonight to give the New York Nets a 104100 victory over the Floridians in an American Basketball Association game at Island Garden.

title: Penn Central Train Derailed
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 3 (UPI)Thirtytwo cars of an 81car Penn Central freight train derailed east of Rochester today, blocking the railroad's eastbound mainline. Cars and coal were strewn along threefourths of a mile of track.

title: BUDGET GAP FACED IN NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 3 (UPI)Mayor Frank Garito today called an emergency meeting of city and school leaders for Friday in efforts to find money to run the school district next year.

title: Arbitrating Crisis Strikes
description: The strongest argument in favor of President Nixon's renewed call for better statutory protection against transportation strike emergencies is the abysmal record of collective bargaining in the railroad industry since the President first made his proposal less than a year ago.

title: A Letter to JeanPaul Sartre
description: Dear Sartre: What new, if anything, does the American New Left bring to us Europeans?

title: MRS. S. B. LITTAUER
description: Mrs. Bella Light Littauer, wife of Prof. Sebastian B. Littauer, emeritus professor of operations research in Columbia University's School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, died Tu'esday at their home, 430 West 116th Street. She was 75 years old.

title: Report Filed on Coed's Death
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I. Feb. 3The Nassau County Medical Examiner said today that his preliminary examination into the death of Linda Mea Jarrigan disclosed that she probably died from a combination of exposure, alcohol and barbiturates. The 19yearold coed, a sophomore honor student at C. W. Post College, disappeared after a party at the school last Friday night. Her frozen body was found in a remote area of the campus yesterday.

title: RUTH HILL VIGUERS, WROTE FOR CHILDREN
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)Ruth Hill Viguers, an author, editor and international expert on children's books, died today in a hospital after a long illness. She was 67 years old.

title: Pace Beats C.C.N.Y., 8280
description: Torn McKenna left the bench in the second half to lead Pace College to an 8280 victory over C.C.N.Y. last night on the victors court.

title: Strike Strands 100,000 Cars in Garages
description: Almost 100,000 cars were stranded in locked garages yesterday as 3,500 workers struck 650 parking garages in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed, corporations. The report includes the following:

title: American Motors Bags a 3Month Profit
description: DETROIT, Feb. 3Roy D. Chapin Jr., chairman of the American Motors Corporation, said today that it had a profit of $5.9million, or 26 cents a share, in its first fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, and that it was emerging from a chaotic and troubled period.

title: Snowmobile Menace
description: Just as the conclusion dawns on man that the automobile is not an unmixed blessing, along comes the snowmobile to spread its worst features to the most remote countryside. It is no longer necessary to keep to the nation's roads in order to be assailed by gasoline fumes, threatened by speed maniacs and unnerved by the din of engines pushed to the point of agony. Now it can all be had in the wilderness.

title: PROTESTERS BATTLE TROOPS IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Thursday, Feb. 4 (AP) Machinegun bursts were fired at an army reserve headquarters in one part of Belfast, and British troops battled Roman Catholic demonstrators in other sections of the city last night and early, today.

title: Specialty Steel Makers Move To Limit Fast Rising Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3Producers of specialty steel products and their counterparts in the United Steelworkers Union began a major campaign today, to limit rapidly rising imports.

title: Tuesday Night Fights
description: New York (Sunnyside Garden}John Clohessy, 203 pounds, New York, outpointed Brian O'Melia, 199, Jersey City, 6 rounds.

title: Collette Sports Notes
description: The Soviet men's and women's gymnastics teams arrived at Penn State yesterday where they will compete tomorrow and Saturday nights. The women will meet a United States team and the men will take on a team of present and former Penn State gymnasts.

title: Borrowing of Eurodollars Dropped in Week to Jan. 27
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Reuters)Eurodollar borrowing by United States banks from their foreign branches dropped by $1,293,000,000 to a total outstanding of $6.53billion in the week ended Jan. 27, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: UN. NET DOWN $10MILLION IN 70
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a decline of about $10million, or 1 cent a share, in 1970 net income despite record operating revenues.

title: Ethiopia's Black Jews Are Building in the Wilderness
description: AMBOBER, Ethiopia, Jan. 14Five thousand acres of wilderness in the malariainfested lowlands of northwestern Ethiopia are becoming something of a 20thcentury promised land for 25,000 black Falasha Jews.

title: STOCKS CLOSE OFF ON LONDON BOARD
description: Prices moved lower on the London stock market after a steady to slightly firmer opening, mainly because of weakness in Australian issues.

title: Rostropovich Cancels Again
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 3Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet cellist who has reportedly been barred from traveling for six months, has canceled a scheduled concert here. He will, however, perform in Yugoslavia next season, the Belgrade Philharmonic added. Scheduled appearances have already been canceled in Finland. France and the United States.

title: CONNALLY SHOWS FEE AGREEMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3John B. Connally Jr., President Nixon's nominee as Secretary of the Treasury, supplied the Senate Finance Committee today with figures showing that he received $575,000 in legal fees from the estate of Sid W. Richardson while Governor of Texas.

title: 3 FREED IN BRITAIN IN SECRETSACT CASE
description: LONDON, Feb. 3An important prosecution aimed at newspaper publication of Government secrets ended today in the acquittal of all defendants.

title: Amex Stocks Climb in Heavy Trading
description: The American Stock Exchange made a strong advance yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than four months.

title: No Progress in Newark School Strike
description: NEWARK, Feb. 3No progress toward a settlement of the strike of publicschool teachers here was evident tonight as the third day of the walkout ended.

title: Exhaustive Checks Clear Lunar Module Battery
description: Apollo 14 flight directors spent long hours yesterday worrying about a lowvoltage reading in a spacecraft battery that could have conceivably I upset plans for a lunar landing.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: F.T.C. Asks Congress to Require Stiff Warning in Cigarette Ads and on Packs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3The Federal Trade Commission asked Congress today to require a stiff health warning in all cigarette advertisements and on the front of cigarette packages.

title: Yoga Cult Accuses Swami of Misusing Organization Funds
description: Dissident disciples of a yoga cult charged yesterday that their leader, Swami Vishnu Devananda, was misusing their organization's funds for his own personal use.

title: 8 Dead as Gas Explosions Destroy 4 Homes in Jersey
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Feb. 3 At least eight persons were killed and nine others injured in two gas main explosions and fires that destroyed four homes in this Delaware River town early today.

title: CORN FUTURES DIP IN PROFIT TAKING
description: After rising the day before, wheat and corn futures came under profit taking on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday dropping as much as more than one cent a bushel on some contracts.

title: 70 NET FELL 52 AT BOISE CASCADE
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, producers of building materials and paper products, had a decline of 52 per cent in 1970 earnings, R. V. Hansberger, president, reported yesterday. Stock of the company reacted to the news with a decline of 11/2 points to 463/ on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you are having difficulty buying insurance for your car, home apartment or personal belongingsand thousands of people are todaydon't be surprised if your insurance man asks for a service fee before long to help you find coverage.

title: Laotian Island in Mekong Waits in Eye of the Storm
description: KHONG ISLAND, Laos, Feb. 3  This island in the broad Mekong River is set in the eye of the storm but seems the most tranquil corner of Indochina.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Chess: Improves His Standing With a Tie for Third in Italy
description: A young New York master, Andrew Soltis, champion of the Marshall Chess Club, improved his international rating during the 13th annual New Year's chess tournament at Reggio Emilia, Italy. Soltis scored 105 during the 16man round robin, tying for third with Grandmaster Mato Damianovic of Yugoslavia.

title: France Gets Algerian Gas
description: ALGIERS, Feb. 3 (Reuters)France will receive 3.5 billion cubic meters of Algerian natural gas a year for the next 15 years under a contract signed here today. First shipments are scheduled for next year.

title: Bonspiel Begins Tonight
description: Curlers will begin the Cuthbertson Bonspiel at 8 o'clock tonight at the St. Andrews Golf Club, HastingsonHudson, N.Y. Tomorrow and Saturday there will be 9 A.M.11 P.M. sessions; on Sunday the final is scheduled for 1 P.M.

title: News of Dogs
description: Mrs. Betty Durland scoffs at the exhibitor who maintains a dog cannot be shown, in obedience and breed rings at the same show.

title: City Housing Aide Resigns
description: Harry Levy, the general counsel for the New York City Housing Authority, will retire this month after 11 years in that position, the authority announced yesterday. Mr. Levy has been with the authority's legal department for 25 years. He is 62 years old.

title: FOREIGN POLICY BODY NAMES 13 DIRECTORS
description: William A. Lydgate, chairman of the board of directors of the Foreign Policy. Association, announced yesterday the election of 13 scholars, businessmen and civic leaders to the association's board.

title: MRS. ERWIN SINGER
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 3Mrs. Helene Pitkin Singer, wife of Dr. Erwin Singer, professor of psychology in the School of Education of City University of New York, died today in White Plains Hospital after a long illness. She was 53 years old and lived at 33 Dunham Road.

title: Brown Sinks Princeton, 42
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 3Connie Schmidt, Brown's captain, made a goal and an assist tonight as the Bruin hockey team defeated Princeton, 42, for its fifth victory in six Ivy League games.

title: Monteverdi's L'Incoronazione Presented in a Concert Version
description: During the concert performance of Monteverdi's L'Incoronazione di Poppea presented by the Opera Orchestra of New York at Tully Hall on Tuesday night, this listener began to wonder if the first producers of the opera in Venice in the 1640's ran into trouble in casting the work and achieving stylish and convincing interpretations of it.

title: Western Pacific Cuts Force
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 (AP)The Western Pacific Railroad disclosed today a 6 per cent reduction in work force which a spokesman indicated amounts to a little under 200 jobs. The line has approxi mately 3,200 employes.

title: Capitalist Music Brings Jail
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 3 (UPI) A Hanoi newspaper said today that eight North Vietnamese musicians had been sentenced to prison terms of up to 15 years for having played what was termed capitalistic music.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (UPI)Seattle's playercoach, Lenny Wilkens, scored 30 points, including four foul shots in the final 34 seconds tonight, to give the Sonics a 9895 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Nanking, With imperial Past, Modernizes With Grace
description: NANKING, ChinaOn a huge billboard in the center of Nanking, Mao Tsetung looms in full color before a representation of China's proudest feat of engineering, the great bridge here across the Yangtze River.

title: 60 Are Held in New Outbreak of Violence in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 4More than 60 people were arrested here in the last 24 hours after a new wave of violence erupted.

title: Installment Credit Rose $21Million During December
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)United States consumers increased their total installment credit slightly in December, the Federal Reserve said today. The $21million increase in consumer credit followed two months of declines primarily because of the General Motors strike.

title: Schlee Leads Hawaiian Golf by Shot With 66
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 4 (UPI)John Schlee posted a sixunderpar 66 today for the firstround lead in the $200,000 Hawaiian open.

title: GAINS REPORTED BY RETAIL CHAINS 9 Big Concerns List Sales Increases for January
description: Despite one shopping day less than last year, and snowstorms in various parts of the country, nine of the largest retail chains reported yesterday higher sales in January over, the yearearlier month.

title: Art: Getting in Shape for the Olympics in Munich
description: Although brawn has always been given top priority in the Olympic Games, brain has been making its wayinto the meets in recent years in the form of cultural events. A part of those events has been devoted to the visual arts. In 1968, Mexico, in what seemed to be the most enthusiastic consideration the arts had been given in any Olympic meet, literally covered its capital with speciallycommissioned sculptures, new buildings, exhibitions emphasizing art from all countries and an ambitious graphics program that enabled designers not only to have a free hand in creating exciting paper publicity for the games but also in painting the streets and even the buildings with their designs.

title: Advertising:
description: In the modest opinion of Donald M. Casey, staff vice president of Trans World Airlines, his outfit has developed The largest and most comprehensive leisure program anyone has ever developed.

title: Dance: Eleo Poinare Gives Premieres at ANTA
description: The Elect Pomare Dance Company, the last of three troupes appearing in the current split week at the ANTA Theater as part of the City Center American Dance Season, gave the first of its two performances last night.

title: Hinojosa Aboard Six Winners, Establishing Liberty Bell Mark
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 (AP) Herb Hinojosa set a Liberty Bell record today by riding six winners on the ninerace card, four of them in a row.

title: Adoptive Parents Lose Boy, 3, To Mother Who Changed Mind
description: MINEOLA, L. L. Feb. 4  A blond, 3yearold boy struggled in the arms of his natural mother here today as he cried, I want to go to my mommy, and reached out his arms for the only mother he had known since birth.

title: Brazilian Workers Killed
description: BELO HORTZONTE, Brazil, Feb. 4 (AP)A concrete roof collapsed on 200 construction workers today as they ate lunch. By nightfall 18 bodies had been recovered, and rescue workers feared as many as 50 were killed.

title: Umass Conquers Iona
description: AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 4 (AP)Julius Erving, a junior allAmerican candidate, scored 29 points and grabbed 17 rebounds tonight as Massachusetts rolled to a 9251 triumph over Iona.

title: Board of Education in Newark Makes New Offer to Teachers
description: NEWARK, Feb. 4The Board of Education tonight awaited a reply form the Newark teachers union to a revised contract package proposed by the Board that it hoped would lead to an early settlement of the teacherss strike.

title: Loss of Major Companies Conceded by City Official
description: The exodus of major corporations from the city appears to be increasing, and at least 12 concerns are currently considering moving their headquarters to the suburbs, according to Ken Patton, the city's Economic Development Administrator.

title: Rails and 2 Unions Agree; Signalmen Threaten Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The nation's railroads and two of the four unions that shut them down with a brief strike in December have reached a tentative contract agreement, railroad spokesman announced today.

title: The Collapse of Rolls
description: RollsRoyce, the huge British aerospace company which also makes one of the world's finest automobiles, has gone into receivership and the British Government calls its demise a major national tragedy. Rolls's failure resulted from soaring costs in the development of an engine for the American Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's Tristar jetliner, the L1011.

title: G.E. PLANS LAYOFFS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)The General Electric Company plans to cut back its job force in Massachusetts by 2,000 this year.

title: Gross Errors in Contract Laid to Managers
description: LONDON, Feb. 4  In the view of the British Government, the grim denouement of the RollsRoyce story  the bitter news disclosed to Parliament and the public today  is a result of business inefficiency.

title: McDaniel, Aker Among Six Signing Yankee Contracts
description: The Yankees made their first move in the contract signing game yesterday, receiving acceptances from six players, including Lindy McDaniel and Jack Aker, their top righthanded relief pitchers last season, who earned what the team called substantial raises.

title: News of Skiing
description: The black market in stolen ski equipment must be booming. Harry Vallin, the owner of three metropolitan New York ski shops, has had $3,000 worth of skis, bindings, poles and boots, rented in the past four weeks, disappear.

title: Quaker City Event Shifted
description: The 1971 Quaker City basketball tournament will return to the University of Pennsylvania's Palestra next December 27 to 30 after three years in the Philadelphia Spectrum, the Eastern College Athletic Conference announced yesterday. The 1971 rivals will be Tennessee, South Carolina, Boston College. Fairlied, Manhattan, Massachusetts, Villanova and La Salle.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE OFF FROM 70 WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Jan. 30 were both below the volume in the corresponding 1970 week.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: U.S. News Blackout in Saigon Tried To Keep Even Its Existence Secret
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4For correspondents and military men alike, the newly lifted blackout of news from the northwest corner of South Vietnam was six days of confusion, cloakanddagger secrecy and a seemingly endless effort to keep secret even the fact that a news blackout existed.

title: ADM. HAROLD C. FITZ, PACIFIC NAVAL HERO
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Rear Adm. Harold C. Fitz, who as captain of the light cruiser Santa Fe, commanded rescue operations when Japanese bombs struck the carrier Franklin off the southern coast of Japan on March 19, 1945, died here yesterday at the age of 72.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I think that Cardinal Cooke's case for state aid for nonpublic schools in his letter to Governor Rockefeller (news story Jan. 26) is illadvised and that his assumption that such aid is constitutional as a result of various court decisions, whether or not the Blaine Amendment is repealed, is highly hypothetical.

title: EXDRUGGIST FOUND GUILTY OF ASSAULT
description: Carroll James Lombard!, a former Manhattan pharmacist, was convicted last night on two counts of a fivecount indictment charging hith with assault and attempted rape.

title: PETKEVICH GAINS LED IN SKATING
description: PETERSBOROUGH, Ontario, Feb. 4United States skaters held decisive leads in three categories tonight at the conclusion of the first day of the North American figure skating championships.

title: U.S. Officials Say Invasion Of Laos is Still Possible
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  Ofcials continued today to hold open the possibility of a South Vietnamese strike against the Ho CM Minh Trail in southern Laos.

title: TALKS AT IMPASSE IN GARAGE DISPUTE
description: Meyer Drucker, a state mediator, declared the dispute here between garage owners and employes at an impasse yesterday as the workers strike continued for a second full day.

title: Advertising:
description: While the flyboys of T.W.A. were having a news conference at the Barclay, the big wheels from Avis were doing the same at the St. Regis, where even the elevator operators wore buttons with the new slogan, Avis is going to be No. 1. We try harder.

title: Belgian Traders Protest Tax
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 4An estimated 40,000 small shopkeepers and artisans in the Belgian province of Liege closed their doors for half the day today in a warning strike against the application of the European Common Market's valueadded tax, which Belgium introduced on Jan. 1. The Government decided to impose an advance levy equivalent to what the tax will yield over two months. The tax is on the value that a businessman adds to any product he sells.

title: Layer Stays Unbeaten in Series
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 4 (AP)Rod Laver overpowwered an old nemesis, Roger Taylor of England, in straight sets last night for his eighth consecutive $10,000 victory in the Tennis Champions Classic. The scores were 63, 75. 62.

title: In Rodchenko Art Show, Echoes of Russian History
description: One of the most interesting figures in the history of the Russian avantgardeAlexander Rodchenko (18911956) is the subject of a small but important exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. Rodchenko Is one of those artists important to connoisseurs of abstract art but virtually unknown to the public at large. The current exhibition, organized by Jennifer Licht, associate curator of painting and sculpture at the museum, is said to be the first exhibition of Rodchenko's work ever held outside the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The bizarre contradictions that indicate the depth of social unrest in this country were never more apparent than in the recent New York police job action.

title: Alworth, 8 Partners Sued Over Business Contract
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 4 (UPI)A $157,000 breach of contract suit was filed today against Lance Alworth, the San Diego Chargers wide receiver, and eight of his business partners.

title: Met's 9th Fidelio of Season Is Full of New Faces
description: Any new opera production, by the time its ninth performance of the season rolls around, will show a few different wrinkles from those it had at birth. But the Metropolitan Opera's ninth Fidelio on Wednesday night presented enough changes to qualify as a complete facelift.

title: Full Airline Status Sought
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP)Executive Airlines, a Bostonbased commuter air carrier, said today that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to certify it as a regular airline. Executive, organized in 1958, operates 27 aircraft with passenger capacities of five to 19, on routes in New England, including Cape Cod.

title: WITNESSES SPLIT ON RESIDENCE BILL
description: Proposed bills to require new policemen, firemen and sanitation workers to live within the city were endorsed yesterday by city officials and denounced by union leaders representing municipal employes.

title: 2 ASTRONAUTS LAND ON MOON; PREPARE TO EXPLORE SURFACE
description: HOUSTON, Friday, Feb. 5 Two astronauts of Apollo 14the fifth and sixth human beings everlanded on the moon early this morning.

title: F.T.C. Challenges Insurance Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission moved into the insurance field for the first time today, challenging the 1969 acquisition by the American General Insurance Company of Houston of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Baltimore.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 4Those goddam tankers! Specialist 4 Steven Hill said as he leaned on his surveyor's staff the other day and peered through the mist at a line of artillery tanks grinding along the road his engineering battalion had just reopened to this damp, cloudswept field.

title: At 30, U.S.0. Has Low Military Profile
description: Some 27 million Americans have been in uniform since the United Services Organizations was born 30 years ago yesterday. But nowadays more than 80 per cent of the servicemen using the Times Square U.S.O. center are in civilian clothes.

title: Agnew Skips Illinois Visit
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 4 (UPI)Vice Pres'dent Agenw's visit to the Illinois capital to promote President Nixon's proposed Federal revenuesharing program today was dropped because rainy weather forced cancellation of Mr. Agenw's flight from Washington.

title: Store Sales Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $523million, virtually unchanged from the yearearlier $522million. Total retail store sales last week were about $6,440,000,000, up 3 per cent from $6,229,000,000.

title: Kennedy and Hatfield Disagree At Hearing on Volunteer Army
description: WASHINGTON; Feb. 4Two Senators with records of longstanding opposition to the Indochina war took conflicting positions today on the advisability of a volunteer Army.

title: South Africa Expels Cleric
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africaa, Feb. 4The Rev. Colin Davison, a Britishborn Anglican clergyman who has been living in South Africa for eight years, was expelled today. Mr. Davison, who was arrested last year during an illegal march to demonstrate against the detentio, of 22 Africans without trial, was given until the end of the month to leave the country.

title: Drug Raids Held on Campus
description: AIVIHERST, Mass., Feb. 4 (AP)  State troopers joined University of Massachusetts campus officers in a series of drug raids on three campus dormitories today. The police said 10 persons had been arrested and a variety of drugs confiscated from Washington, Pierpont and McKimmie halls.

title: Named to Pro Football's Shrine
description: The late Vince Lombardi and two old Giant heroes, Andy Robustelli and Y.A. Tittle, were among seven named yesterday to pro football's Hall of Fame. Others were Jim Brown, acclaimed as the best running back ever; Norm Van Brocklin, coach of the Atlanta Falcons; and two preWorld War II players, Frank (Bruiser) Kinard and the late Bill Hewitt.

title: U.S. Cutter Sent to Soviet Fleet Fishing in Prohibited Area Off Cape May
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A United States Coast Guard cutter was reported to have sailed into international waters off Cape May, N. J., today in an effort to inform a fleet of Soviet vessels that it was fishing in violation of a United StatesSoviet pact.

title: A RIGHTS OFFICE BURNED IN SOUTH
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 4An intentionally set fire today destroyed a frame office building housing the interracial law firm of Julius L. Chambers, a civil rights lawyer who represents the Negro plaintiffs in the Charlotte school desegration case now before the United States Supreme Court.

title: SUN RA. PRESENTS EMMA TRIP
description: Sun Ra and his Space Arkestra, those masters of musical mayhem, opened their contribution to the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Composers in Performance series on Tuesday night with a 15minute blast compounded of instrumental shrieks and electronic blare that blew several subscribers to the series right out of Grace Raney Rogers Auditorium.

title: Hobart Asks Dismissal of Case Charging Criminal Coercion
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Feb 14Defense counsel in the trial of Hobart College on criminal charges of coercion moved today to have the case dropped on the ground of insufficient evidence to warrant a conviction.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON DECLINE SHARPLY Bankruptcy of RollsRoyce Main Factor in Setback
description: The London stock market closed sharply lower yesterday When RollsRoyce, Ltd. went into receivership. The exchange suspended RollsRoyce trading at the company's request. The decline of RollsRoyce was also felt on the Amsterdam Exchange, where Fokker aircraft issues lost about 56 cents.

title: Laos to Protest Communist Offensive
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 4Premier Souvanna Phouma said today he would protest to Britain and the Soviet Union, cochairmen of the Geneva Conference of 1962, over what he termed a new offensive launched this week in northern Laos by North Vietnamese and Communist  led Pathet Lao troops. He stated the protest would be over attacks yesterday on points near the royal capital of Luang Prabang and the capture the sume clay of Muong Suoi, an important Gpvernment defense position on western fringe of the Plaine des Jarres.

title: Apollo 12 Landing Difficulties Led to Modified Control System
description: Because dust churned by the spacecraft's rocket engine added so much to the hazards of the Apollo 12 moon landing in 1969, the Apollo 14 vehicle was equipped with a modified control system to simplify the final maneuvers.

title: Market Place: Making a Profit From Recycling
description: What this country needs is a good junk manor so it would seem if you ride the highways past scores of rusting auto hulks and mountains of waste at city dumps.

title: RollsRoyce is Bankrupt; Blames Lockheed Project
description: LONDON, Feb. 4RollsRoyce, Ltd., Britain's quality symbol for fine automobiles and sophisticated jet engines, declared bankruptcy today. The public reacted with consternation and politicians called it a major national tragedy.

title: Tornado Kills 7 in Mississippi As House Trailer Is Torn Apart
description: GRENADA, Miss., Feb. 4 (AP)A tornado ripped apart a house trailer today and killed seven persons, including the wife and three children of a Grenada policeman.

title: TROOPS OF ALLIES MASS NEAR LAOS; CROSSING DENIED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4  Thousands of American and South Vietnamese troops, supported by armored columns and planes, were moving near the Laotian border today in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam.

title: M'MILLAN OUSTER BEATEN IN HOUSE

The dumping ruling sets the stage for an inquiry by the United States Tariff Commission to determine if additional duties should be imposed on the merchandise.

title: Canadian Bill Yields Rise
description: OTTAWA. Feb. 4 (Reuters)Average yields on today's weekly issue of $165million in Canadian Government 91day Treasury bills rose to 4.79 per cent from last week's 4.68 per cent while the average price fell to $98.819 from last week's $98.847. On the weekly issue of $45million in 182day bills average yield rose to 4.94 per cent from last week's 4.89 per cent.

title: Suit Alleges Bias in U.S. Job Testing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  A group of black Federal employes filed suit here today charging that the principal test that qualifies college graduates for Federal employment and promotion was culturally and raciI ally discriminatory.

title: Rutgers Downs Boston U.
description: BOSTON, Feb. 4 (AP)Rutgers scored an easy, 8251 basketball victory over Boston University here tonight.

description: ALBANY, Feb. 4The State Education Department, in a report released today, said that nearly half the black students in public schools in this state attended schools where at least half the total enrollment was black.

description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (UPI) Charles Watson, the fifth accused killer in the Sharon Tate murders, was declared mentally competent today. District Attorney Joseph Busch said he would proceed to bring him to trial.

The two who claimed their prizes were Ugo Cesaro, of 5 Glendon Road, in nearby Hamilton Township, and Barbara Reynolds of 555 Maple Avenue, Woodbridge.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey urged the Port of New York Authority tonight to fimance the construction of new rail tunnel under the Hudson River between New Jersey and New York.

title: Squires Win, 138129
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 (UPI)Neil Johnson and Mike Barrett scored 25 points each to lead the Virginia Squires to a 138129 American Basketball Association victory tonight over the Floridians in double overtime. Larry Jones was high scorer for the Floridians with 38 points. Mack Calvin added 30.

title: Trail Blazers Win, 137123
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 4 (AP)The Portland Trail Blazers checked Atlanta's highscoring guards and romped to 137123 victory tonight.

title: Bridge: After Incredible Bid, South Ekes Out an Unmakable Slam
description: The weirdest system ever used in international competition was Marmic, whose adherents were expected to pass with a very strong balanced hand in first or second position or following an opponent's opening.

title: Books of The Times
description: The late Ben B. Seligman has done very well with what may strike some people as a dreary projecta narrative history of American business from colonial times to the present. I will happily devote the majority of this review to itemizing the assets of The Potentates, which is the third volume in Dial Press's projected 30volume series on Two Centuries in American Life. Mr. Seligman has avoided obvious extremes by writing neither an everupwardandonward celebration of good old American resourcefulness that made our country great, nor a ragging denunciation of greed and venality. Instead, he has told the story with a dispassionate bemusement that shouldn't seriously offend anyone to the left of H. L. Hunt or to the right of Eugene D. Genovese. Mr. Seligman holds to the theory that businessmen are in it for the dollar, and that the pursuit of the dollar has rarely been pro bono public How many people are going to object to that in this day and age, especially when it comes from a former tradeunion economist and contributor to such publications as Partisan Review and The New York Review of Books?

title: 29 U.S. Battle Deaths Are Reported for Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4 (AP)  The United States command reported today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Vietnam last week, compared with 50 the week before, and that 15 others died of accidents and other nonhostile causes.
