title: Excerpts From the Message on Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message today setting forth his proposal for the general, unrestricted return of $5billion in Federal revenues to the cities and the states:

title: First National City Sets Suffolk Bank
description: The First National City Corporation, in what appeared likely to be the harbinger of a series of similar moves by major New York City banking organizations, announced plans yesterday to form a new bank in Suffolk County.

title: Undercutting Legal Aid
description: The Office of Economic Opportunity's most successful programlegal services for the indigenthas had to walk on thin ice in the last year. Lawsuits and class actions on behalf of the poor have brought justice in such fields as housing, consumer affairs, welfare and domestic relations. But the ice is starting to crack especially in Californiaand is thereby endangering the entire Federal program.

title: SHARES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: The American Stock Exchange scored another advance yesterday, its seventeenth in the last eighteen sessions, in the heaviest trading in more than four months.

title: SST Ban Urged in Colorado
description: DENVER, Feb. 4 (AP)Legislation proposing a ban on the operation of the supersonic transport in and over Colorado and providing payment for damages to health and property from its noise was introduced in the state Legislature today.

title: Guineans Seem Fearful Amid Deep Political Turmoil
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 2The overriding impression that a visitor takes away with him is that Guinea is undergoing serious political turmoil. There is a mood of apprehension.

title: Braniff Operates at Profit
description: Braniff Airways, Inc., reported yesterday that it had a profitable fourth quarter in 1970, but that the loss for the full year had made it necessary to suspend cash dividends in order to conserve cash for future equipment purchases.

title: PRESIDENT REBUTS RISING CRITICISM OF REVENUE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 President Nixon formally asked Congress today to turn over to state and local governments $5billion in unrestricted Federal funds. He also sought to rebut criticisms of the plan that have been gathering momentum on Capitol Hill.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 109.5 Tuesday from 108.1 last week.

title: 200 Trainees at Ft. Dix Get Course in Race Relations
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 4Two hundred young Army inductees, fresh from lessons on how to use the M16 rifle, were instructed today in a topic new to the basic training cyclerace relations.

title: Rhoads and Torres Lead Satellite Tourney With 67's
description: ONTARIO, Calif., Jan. 4 (UPI) Rick Rhoads and Gene Torres shot a fourunderpar 67 each today and tied for the firstround lead in the $25,000 United Air Lines Ontario open, a satellite tournament of the Professional Golfers Association tour.

title: Tuna Stocks Now Called Safe; Mercury Taint Not Widespread
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 The Food and Drug Administration announced today that all stocks of mercurytainted tuna had been removed from the market and that the contamination problem was not so bad as had been believed.

title: Recording Academy Lists Final Grammy Nominations
description: The final nominations for the 13th annual Grammy Awards, the top recording industry prizes, were announced yesterday by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. The academy selects winners in the classical and popular fields.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Aryeh Neier's Jan. 20 letter about the Supreme Court's decision on the James case calls for comment. I've been a caseworker with New York City Department of Welfare (now lovingly called the Department of Social Services) for twelve years, and during that time I have never searched the home of a welfare recipient and never seen a search carried out. There have been, in the past, cases of the midnight raids, which indeed may have been unconstitutional, but the Supreme Court decision in the James case recognizes this possibility.

title: For the First Time, Scientific Exploration Is the Prime Objective of Lunar Mission
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4For the first time men have made scientific exploration their prime objective for a landing on the moon.

title: Saigon Defends an Invasion
description: PARIS, Feb. 4South Vietnam today defended largescale operations into Laos and Cambodia by accusing North Vietnam of threatening its security through aggression in those countries.

title: Miss Bartkowicz Advances In Virginia Slims Tourney
description: SEWANEE, Tenn., Feb. 4 (UPI)Peaches Bartkowicz defeated Denise Carter, 62, 36. 76, today in the opening round of the Virginia Slims Tennis Invitation tourney, the fifth stop on a $100,000 circuit.

title: COLONELS MEE NETS BY 10699
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 4 (UPI)Dan Issel and Mike Pratt, former University of Kentucky teammates, teamed against the New York Nets tonight to lead the Kentucky Colonels to a 10699 victory in an American Basketball Association game.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Defining Aggression10:30 A.M.

title: U.S. Offer Reported Special to The New York Tithes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 4The United States was reliably reported today to have told a Big Four meeting today that if indirect ArabIsraeli peace talks showed signs of serious progress it would be willing to discuss the issue of bigpower guarantees to back settlement.

title: S. Carolina W ins, 11883, As Roche Gets 56 Points
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 4 (AP)John Roche of South Carolina set an Atlantic Coast Conference singlegame basketball scoring record of 56 points tonight as he led the Gamecocks to a 11883 victory over Furman.

title: Asya L. Kadis, Psychiatrist, Group Therapy Expert, Dead
description: Mrs. Asya L. Kadis, dirctor of the Group Therapy Clinic at the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health and assistant professor, department of psychiatry, at the Downstate Medical Center, died Wednesday at her home, 1060 Park Avenue. Her age was 69.

title: Maynard Is Given 10Year Sentence In Village Slaying
description: William A. Maynard Jr., who was convicted last December of having killed a man in an argument on a Greenwich Village street, was sentenced yesterday to 10 to 20 years in prison.

title: Income Tax Ahead
description: New York is not alone. The citizens of Connecticut and Pennsylvania have learned in recent days that their states face a choice between an income tax or bankruptcy. New Jersey, another of the nine states in the nation without an income tax, is still debating the problem, but its day of reckoning cannot be postponed much longer.

title: Rangers Turn Back Red Wings, 10, for Villemure's 6th Shutout of Season
description: DETROIT, Feb. 4The New York Rangers scored only one goal against the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game tonight, but that was enough to win. The tally Came at 3:47 of the second period and was made by Rod Gilbert, the flashy center.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Administration Making Significant Gains in Antihunger Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Nixon Admnistration's antihunger program has produced significant, often dramatic gains, reports on the program from 10 areas around the country disclosed today. Bt the job is only half done, many of the poor people and experts interviewed said, and they now fear a leveling off of Federal efforts.

title: YOUTH IS ARRESTED IN PELHAM SHOOTING
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 4 (UPI)The police arrested an 18yearold youth tonight in connection with a shooting in Pelham, N.Y., in which a 14yearold student was wounded.

title: The Mayor V Very Brave Man
description: Mayor Lindsay, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and other top police commanders went to Brooklyn's aging Greenpoint Hospital yesterday to vist a patrolman who was seriously wounded Wednesday night while attempting to make a narcotics arrest.

title: JOHN C. BURTON DIES; RETIRED AD MAN, 85
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 4John Carlton Burton, a retired newspaper and advertising man, died yesterday at the Carolton Convalescent Home here. He was 85 years old and lived in Southport.

title: Mrs. John C. Fremont Is Dead; Crusader for Cleaner City, 95
description: Mrs. Julie Fay Bradley Shipman Fremont, widow of Capt. John C. Fremont, U.S.N., retired, grandson and namesake of the 19thcentury explorer and politician, died Wednesday at her home, 765 Park Avenue, after a long illness. She was 95 years old.

title: Losing Coach Is Out
description: WHEATON, Ill., Feb. 4 (AP) Mal Pearson, whose Wheaton College football team had a 171 wonlosttied record last, season, was dismissed as head coach today.

title: G.I.'s Feel They're Preparing the Way
description: LANGVEI, South Vietnam. Feb. 4American soldiers on one of their largest and perhaps one of their last major combat operations, appeared relaxed todaybecause so far they have had no large clashes with North Vietnamese troops  and relievedbecause they had orders not to attack the enemy in Laos, which is only a few miles from here.

title: Oil Nations Set Deadline Of Feb. 15 for an Accord
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb 4The international oil companies have been given until Feb. 15 to accede to the demands of the 10nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for increased revenues. If no settlement is reached by then, the member countries, which account for 85 per cent of the nonCommunist world's oil, will pass legislation to raise prices unilaterally.

title: Seton Hall Defeated
description: EASTON, Pa., Feb. 4 (AP)Tracy Tripucka scored 26 points to lead Lafayette to a 6759 victory tonight over Seton Hall.

title: Chichester Completes TransAtlantic Voyage
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 4 (UPI)  Sir Francis Chichester of Britain sailed into San Juan del Norte today, ending a 22day, 4,000mile transAtlantic voyage from Bissau, Portuguese Guinea, the national radio reported.

title: Alioto Seeks to Testify in Reported Inquiry Into His Legal Fees
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4Mayor Joseph L. Alioto said today that he would ask to be heard by a Federal grand jury in Seattle that reportedly is investigating his division of law yer's fees with public officials in Washington State five years ago.

title: Laird Gives Rebuff To Moscow on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird declared today that the forum for discussing possible reductions in American fighterbombers deployed within range of the Soviet Union was not the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks but a future conference that should seek mutual reductions of tactical forces in eastern and western Europe.

title: Milwaukee Road Lists Loss
description: The Chicago. Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $1,864,318 for the fourth quarter of last year, but a $10,992,173 net loss for the full year. In 1969 the carrier reported a fourth quarter profit of $1,040,046, while it incurred a $5,641,369 net loss for all 1969.

title: Dollar Holdings Up in 70 Despite S.D.R. Allotment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The industrial nations of Western Europe, Canada and Japan added the massive sum $10.8billion to their holdings of foreign exchange, almost entirely dollars, last year, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: ROCKEFELLER SETS TAXSHARING GOAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4Governor Rockefeller kicked off his own national lobbying effort in behalf of Federal revenue sharing today, but he said the goal for a nostringsattached fund should be $10billion, twice the amount proposed by President Nixon.

title: East Germany Makes an Offer on Berlin
description: BERLIN, Feb. 4East Germany held out an offer today for agreements with the West Berlin city administration on travel to West Germany and East Berlin on condition that all political ties with Bonn be cut.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Shortly after the Jets had produced their astonishing Super Bowl victory over the Colts a couple of years ago, an unregenerate and somewhat resentful Giant fan met Gerry Philbin for the first time. The Giant follower was so impressed by the big Jet defensive end that he offered his reactions to a buddy, a rabid Jet fan.

title: Warriors Top Suns, 117105
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 4 (AP) The San Francisco Warriors outscored the Phoenix Suns. 228, at the start of the second half and continued to a 117105 National Basketball Association victory tonight.

title: Pratt & Whitney Awarded $67Million Navy Contract
description: The United Aircraft Corporation's Pratt & Whitney division received yesterday a $67.9million Navy contract for J52 and TF30 engines used in various Navy aircraft.

title: Surprise Camera Noise Stirs Doubts on Photos
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 4 (UPI)A mysterious clacking noise in Apollo 14's telescopic camera raised doubts today whether the astronauts were getting pictures of the rugged crater Descartes, landing site of Apollo 16.

title: Houston Wins, 81 to 75; Manhattan Tops N.Y. N.Y.U.
description: Houston came to New York last night to enhance its national reputation, but was hardpressed to escape with victory.

title: Qualified Satisfaction in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 4 (Reuters)Israeli officials tonight expressed only qualified satisfaction at Egypt's decision to extend the ceasefire for 30 days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Under normal circumstances, I should have been in agreement with your Jan. 31 editorial titled That GroundHog Mythas I am with most of your positions.

title: Books of The Times
description: About a year ago a young Philadelphia writer named Tom McHale came out with a novel called Principato, which was promptly hailed as revealing a remarkable new talent. The comparisons to Roth, Updike and Bruce Jay Friedman flew from reviewers typewriters as thick as mayflies in July. It was also widely noted that at last a neglected group in America, the Irish, had been accorded a voice they had not had since James T. Farrell's Studs. Lonigan or Edwin O'Connor's novels not to mention the city of Philadelphia, where the book was set, a place, according to the canard, that whenever you go there it is closed. In this very space John Leonard hailed Principato as a comic novel in what I hope will become the McHale tradition. With the appearance of his second novel, Farragan's Retreat, it becomes obvious that the McHale tradition is indeed a lively one and that Mr. McHale is staking himself out a nice plot of American literary acreage.

title: House Unit Assails 2 U.S. Agencies On Defection Attempt by Lithuanian
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4  A House subcommittee accused the Coast Guard and the State Department today of ineptitude in frustrating the attempted defection of a Lithuanian seaman last Nov. 23.

title: MUNDT IS REPLACED IN POSTS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)Senate Republicans have temporarily assigned Senators Charles H. Percy of Illinois and Charles McC. Mathias Jr. of Maryland to positions held by Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota.

title: The Ho Chi Minh Trail: A Spidery, Constantly Shifting Route
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4As in every year of the Vietnam war, the abatement of the monsoon rains last fall brought a quickening of enemy activity along the spidery track network through Laos that is known as the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

title: Federal Pay Levels
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Radical Group Challenges Law on Flag Desecration
description: A group of radical artists and their supporters, including Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, filed a suit in Federal Court here yesterday to chal lenge the constitutionality of laws against flag desecration.

title: Amin Regime in Uganda Is Recognized by Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters)  Britain recognized today the new Uganda Government of Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, who seized power in a military coup 12 days a go.

title: Preminger Is Seeking to Adopt His Son by Late Gypsy Rose Lee
description: The 26yearold son of the late Gypsy Rose Lee, who learned 9 years ago that Otto Preminger, the movie producer, was his real father, said yes terday he plans to change his name to Preminger.

title: Rites for Captain Mulzac
description: Capt. Hugh N. Mulzac, the Negro who skippered a Liberty ship in World War II, was buried Thursday in Hicksville, I.. I. He is survived by five children, including Mrs. Elaine Mulzac Hackley. Her name was inadvertently omitted from the obituary of Captain Mulzac in last Monday's New York Times.

title: Okker Will Try Today to End Laver's String in Tennis Classic
description: The relaxed figure stand ing in the path of rampaging Rod Laver's ninth consecu tive Tennis Champions Clas sic victory today is Tom Ok ker of the Netherlands.

title: Cleveland Teachers Meet
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 5 (UPI) About 5,000 of the city's 6,000 public school teachers cut their afternoon classes to formulate a demand for a $2,000 raise in starting salaries. While they were gone, students at four schools broke windows and caused other damage.

title: Misses Harter, Goolagong Gain at New Zealand Net
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea and, Feb. 5 (AP)Kathy Har er of Seal Beach, Calif., gained he semifinals of the New Zea and lawn tennis championships oday with a 62, 06, 62 tri mph over Trudi Walhof of the Netherlands.

title: Negro Women's Group Has First Cotillion
description: Thirty young women, wearing the long white dresses traditional for debu tantes, and their escorts, in white tie and tails, performed cotillion figures in the Impe rial Ballroom at the Ameri cana Hotel last night.

title: MAYS SHOWS STYLE IN ASTROJET GOLF Willie and Gossett Card Net 60 to Lead at Phoenix
Strike in Union Township
description: NEWARK, Feb. 5 (AP)1 Teachers in Union Township, Union County, struck for the first time today, but the Board of Education kept schools open.

title: BAR URGED TO AIR EXAM BIAS CHARGE
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 5The presi dent of the National Bar Association, a predominantly black lawyers group, called to day upon leaders of other bar groups to consider whether bar examinations should be elimi nated as racially discriminatory.

title: Two Plays Off Broadway Offer Comedy of Sorts
description: Two grotesque (American Gothic?) comedies are run ning off Off Broadway. At the Theater Genesis, there is Walter }ladles Grand Mal Crick, which is an absurdist vision of a Tobacco Roadlike family, complete with incest, murder and strident patriot ism (one of the lead charac ters is Uncle Sam Crick). At La Mama E.T.C. there is Mario Fratti's The Refriger ators, which is about incest, bestiality and freshfrozen people.

title: MRS. H. A. CRANEFIELD
description: Mrs. Eleanor Goltz Crane field, emeritus professor of so cial work at the University of Michigan, died Thursday in Clearwater, Fla., where she lived. Her age was 64. She was the widow of Harold A. Crane field, former general counsel for the United Auto Workers Union.

title: Troops for Cancer War
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Hard Hats Finding Fat Raises Do Not Help
description: DETROIT, Feb. 5  The union looks out for us boys, Ed Belloli, a $7.50an hour plasterer, said admiringly as he worked on a job here the other day. We make good money. But with the high cost of living, it's gone.

title: JEWISH EDUCATOR BACKS STATE AID Day  School Representative Urges Legislature to Act
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 5 The head of the major coordi nating body, for 425 Jewish day schools in the country urged the State Legislature to day to approve a nonpartisan bill providing tuition grants to private school pupils.

title: PLAN SUGGESTED TO DIVIDE PENNSY Retired Wall Streeter Urges Setting Up Two Systems
description: A plan of reorganization for the Penn Central Transporta tion Company that would divide the bankrupt railroad into two systems offering freight service only has been proposed by Roy al F. Herdeg of Fort Lauder dale, Fla.

title: Reginald A. Bradley, Veteran Of Indian Wars, Dies at 105
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Reginald A. Bradley, one of the last two surviving veterans of the Indian Wars, died today in Grass Valley, Calif., at the age of 105, the Veterans Ad ministration reported. This leaves Fredrak W. Fraske, 99, of Chicago, as the only living veteran of the wars.

title: Nepela Retains Title
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 5 (AP)Ondrej Nepela of Czech oslovakia won his third straight European men's figure skating title tonight with a triumphant free program.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAXIMUM SECURITY WARD. 19641970. By Ramon Guthrie. 143 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $7.50.

title: Doctors Seeking Early Clues For Victims of Heart Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The person who dies suddenly of heart disease has often been to his doctor within the pre vious week, but his symptoms tend to be too vague to prove that serious heart trouble ex ists, an expert said today.

title: Boxing Referee Who Fought Switch Loses License
description: State Drops Feld for Garden Action That Led to Ejection

title: NANCE AND SHU JOIN IN A JAZZ CONCERT
description: Two unusually versatile jazz musicians joined their varied talents yesterday at the weekly noontime Jazz Adventure se ries at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue and 42d Street.

title: U.S. Ready to Open Talks On Guarantees in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The United States has informed the Soviet Union, Britain and France that it is prepared to open preliminary discussions next Friday on guarantees by the Big Four for a Middle East settlement, without awaiting further progress in the indirect ArabIsraeli peace talks.

title: Newsmen's Group In Saigon Protests Scope of Embargo
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5  The Association of Foreign Correspondents in Vi etnam charged today that the American command's order bar ring mention of the sixday news embargo on the military operation near the Laotian bor der had deprived news corre spondents from exercising their elementary professional respon sibility.

title: Romney Resuming Subsidized Housing In 21 Areas of U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, announced today a select ed resumption of the low and moderate income subsidized housing program.

title: Taxi Commission Ahead
description: Taxicab riders in this city seem likely at last to win the long struggle for an effective official watchdog to protect their interests. After four years of inaction, the City Council is reported ready to vote approval next week of a Taxicab Commission clothed with sufficient power to regulate the taxi industry in the manner of public utility.

title: ANTIFASCIST CROWD BATTLES ROME POLICE
description: ROME, Feb. 5 (Reuters)  Streetfighting broke out in cen tral Rome tonight as the police battled with leftwing demon strators following protest marches against alleged Fascist violence.

title: Refurbished Mecca Draws More Pilgrims Than Ever for the Hadj
description: AL SNEMISI, Saudia Arabia, Feb. 1The main road to Mecca has been crowded with a rush of pilgrims that is de scribed as unprecedented in Is lam's history.

title: Divorce, UnItalian Style
description: ROMEDivorce has finally made its entrance in Italy! This country has joined all the others in Europe, leaving behind only Turkey and Spain.

title: South Vietnamese Forces Reported Preparing for Imminent Drive Into Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5Preparations were re ported under way today in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam for a South Vietnam ese attack on enemy supply routes in Laos.

title: FARMCROP REPORTS TO CHANGE A LITTLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) The Agriculture Department has decided to make compara tively modest changes in some of its farm crop reports, but has abandoned plans to elimi nate a number of major reports.

title: WELFARE CUTOFF ON FATHERS ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Nixon Administration moved today to reduce welfare rolls by cutting off some fathers who have been working part time while receiving aid.

title: Flu Outbreak Forces Closing Of Some Jersey Public Schools
description: New Jersey health officials have reported that a mild form of influenza virus is causing widespread absenteeism in the state's schools.

title: U.S. Sues 2 Areas in South on School Integration
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) The Justice Department filed suit against two Southern school districts today, charging them with operating segregated school systems in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Philco Is Dropping Its Semiconductors
description: The PhilcoFord Corporation said yesterday that it planned to get out of the semiconductor business. A semiconductor is a miniature electronic device that performs the functions of many vacuum tubes.

title: BOOKKEEPING MEMO ISSUED BY BIG BOARD
description: The Department of Member Firms of the New York Stock Exchange warned the member ship yesterday to keep all books and records on a current and accurate basis, despite the recent upsurge in trading volume.

title: Lacrosse Official Named
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 (AP) George M. Chandler Jr., lacrosse coach at Gilman School in Balti more for 23 years, has been ap pointed executive secretary of the Lacrosse Hall of Fame Foundation.

title: 18YearOld Vote Is Stalled Across Nation
description: The 18  year  old vote, re solved for national elections by Federal legislation and a Supreme Court decision, is still a controversial and unresolved issue at the state level across the country.

title: Heartbeat Normal on Moon
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)  Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr.'s heartbeat was normal today when he landed on the moon. The Apollo 14 flight director here, Gerald Griffin, said that the sensor recording the heart beat measured 80 beats a min ute. That's just about normal, Mr. Griffin said. but he's a pretty cool guy.

title: 3 Soviet Ships Reported on Way to Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 2014; Three Soviet naval vessels, in cluding a submarine tender, are on their way to Cuba, the Defense Department said to day. The two other ships are said to be a guidedmissile; cruiser and a merchant tanker.

title: POLICEMEN LOSE SUBPOENA SUIT
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the legality of subpoenas for 14 police officers to appear before the city's Knapp Commission, which is investigating alleged police cor ruption.

title: Risks in OffShore Wells
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Municipal Blunder
description: The decision by State Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol in the police parity case makes it plain that the city blundered badlyperhaps catastrophicallyin its 1969 pay agreement with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: PETKEVICH WINS IN FIGURE SKATING Shelley Duo Also Scores in North American Title Meet
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Feb. 5United States skaters recorded two victories tonight in the men's singles and pairs events of the North American figure skating championships.

title: LINDBERGH OPPOSES FURTHER SST WORK
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 5 (UPI) Charles A. Lindbergh, the first man to fly nonstop from New York to Paris alone, said today that further work on the supersonic transport program would be a mistake.

title: C.B.S. to Cut Personnel by 15 Per Cent
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System formally confirmed last night institution of major econ omies, including a layoff of per sonnel. In Hollywood, it was reported that a reduction of 15 per cent in the number of per sons on the payroll had been fixed as a target.

title: Ohlsson and Beethoven
description: Looming big over the New York Philharmonic concert on ThursdaY evening in Phil harmonic Hall was the young pianist Garrick Ohlsson, and he is indeed a learner, as anybody so enormous neces sarily rrtust be. It was his first Philharmonic appear ance. Mr. Ohlsson not long ago won the prestigious Chopin competition in War saw, but he did not play ro mantic music at this concert. Instead he was heard in Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1.

title: Les Snow's Time Best In Daytona Beach Trials
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 (UPI)Les Snow of Bloom ington, Ill., in a 1969 Plymouth, posted the fastest qualifying time today for the Automo bile Racing Club of America 300mile race at the Daytona Speedway on Sunday.

title: Two Trains Derail Upstate
description: LITTLE FALLS, N. Y., Feb. (UPI)Penn Central passenger service between New York City and Buffalo was delayed today after two freight trains side swiped and derailed in the Mohawk Valley. No one was hurt, but the crash blocked the railroad's main line through the state, forcing the company to bus passengers between Sya cuse and Albany. Authorities said it would be at least a day before the way would be cleared.

title: L.I. GROUP PLAYS BIT OF EVERYTHING
description: What kind of music is being played for school children to day? The answer was given in part by the Orchestra da Camera of Long Island in concert at Tully Hall on Thursday night. The ensemble, possibly the most successful in its field, is a professional group that is in residence in the Mineola Public Schools.

title: Legislation Gains in Maine
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 5 (AP)  Legislation to lower Maine's voting age in state and local elections from 20 to 18 won initial acceptance in the Sen ate today.

title: Alexander Thompson, 76, Travers & Hume Partner
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Feb. 5  Alexander Ramsay Thomp son, a partner in the firm of Travers & Hume, stockbrokers, 120 Broadway, New York, died here Wednesday. He was 76 years old and lived at 385 Harbor Road.

title: Joseph Stein, Executive With Textron, Inc., Unit
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Feb. 5  Joseph S. Stein, executive vice president of Donahue Sales,a division of Textron, Inc., died today after a long illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 152 Woodmere Boulevard South.

title: Cigarette Concerns Will Present Data On Tar and Nicotine
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Advertisements prepared af ter today by all but one or the nation's cigarette makers will list tar and nicotine content a factor the Public Health Serv ice has declared crucial to links between smoking and disease.

title: COUNTESS ALESSANDRA
description: Countess Alessandra Gray di San Marzano, wife of Col. James A. Gray, Army, retired, executive director of the Inter national Fund for Monuments, Inc., which has restoration programs around the world, died Thursday, She was 44 years old and lived at 128 Marine Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: VIRGINIA YOUNG, 70, LORD TAYLOR AIDE
description: Mrs. Virginia Sperry Young, a former buyer for the Lord & Taylor department store here and from 1927 to 1931 a fash ion buyer in Paris for American stores, died Thursday of can cer in West Palm Beach, Fla., where she lived. Her age was 70.

title: Union City Pact Rejected
description: UNION CITY, N. J., Feb. 5 (UPI)Teachers here voted to day to reject a new contract offer and to keep the schools closed until their demands were met.

title: 3 Detectives Get Year in Jail As Seekers of Narcotics Graft
description: Three city detectives, all of whom served at least 14 years on the police force, were sen tenced to maximum terms of a year in jail yesterday for offi cial misconduct involving an effort to get cash and narcotics for not making arrests.

title: JOHN W. DOW, AIDE AT THE PLAYBILL, 67
description: DIX HILLS, L. I., Feb. 5 John W. Dow, associate editor and art director of The Playbill, the program distributed in Broadway theaters, from 1934 to 1957, died Wednesday in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip. He was 67 years old and lived at 627 Half Hollow Road.

title: Carmichael Urges U.S. Blacks to Look to Africa
description: The following article was written by Jonathan Power, an English economist and free lance journalist who was in Guinea from Jan. 25 to Tues day. He is believed to have been the first Western writer admitted in months.

title: Moon Landing Excites Few New Yorkers
description: The third landing on the moon was received here yes terday with enthusiasm by a few, polite interest by many and boredom and hostility by some.

title: PROLONGED STRIKE AT GARAGES IS SEEN
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, advised Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the city was in for a prolonged garage strike.

title: JOHN STEELE BRICE, NEW CANAAN LAWYER
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 5John Steele Brice, a lawyer who served as legaladviser for the Fairfield County Council on Alcoholism, died of a heart at tack at his home on Tuesday. He was 65 years old and lived at 9 Colonial Drive.

title: For Smaller Museums
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Art:  Jack Tworkov's  Latest at Whitney
description: Nearly seven years have passed since the Whitney Museum of American Art mounted a large retrospec tive exhibition, of the paint ings of Jack Tworkov, whose work had for some years been closely identified with the abstract expressionist movement. Now the Whitney has organized a smaller show of Mr. Tworkov's new paintings to bring us up to date on his recent develop ment. The show, directed by Marcia Tucker, opened yes terday in the museum's small firstfloor gallery at Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: Letters to the Editor

title: SAMUEL LEWIS, HEAD OF A MOSLEM SECT, 74
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 The body of Samuel L. Lewis, leader of the Sufi Moslem sect here, has been released to his followers for entombment in the mountains of New Mexico.

title: Court With a Quick Access to Justice
description: For one woman, the proc ess started when a leg on her dining room table buckled and her guests had to eat Thanksgiving Day dinner on the floor.

title: GOVERNORS SUPPORT APPALACHIAN GROUP
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Feb. 5 (UPI)Thirteen Appalachian state Governors adopted today a resolution urging extension of the Ap palachian Regional Commission for four years. President Nixon has proposed that it be elimin ated and replaced with a form of revenue sharing.

title: 2 Subway Derailments Slow RushHour Service
description: Morning and wening subway rushhour service was slowed down and curtailed yesterday by two derailments and a stalled train. There were no in juries in the derailments.

title: L. I. Nursing Home Employee Charged in Death of Patient
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 5 An 18yearold nurses aide was charged with firstdegree man slaughter tonight in the death of an 86yearold patient at a nursing home who died as a result of burns said to have been received when she was bathed.

title: Hanover Bank Is Halting Sonic Credit Card Activity
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company confirmed yes terday that it had notified roughly three dozen of its cor respondent banks that it had decided to discontinue the pro cessing of Master Charge credit cards for them.

title: In 1904, a Milestone: Mr. Rolls, Meet Mr. Royce
description: Aristocrat Took Up a Selling Career

title: 6 Hurt in Ski Lift Fall
description: SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Feb. 5 (UPI)Six persons were in jured, two seriously, today when several chairs on a ski lift derailed and dropped 10 feet to the snowcovered ground lat Squaw Valley.

title: Unheard Lunar Footfalls Are Recorded in Houston
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5As the Apollo 14 astronauts labored and cavorted on the moon to day their footfalls were inaudi ble in the airless environment there, but they were loud and clear at the Manned Spacecraft Center here, thanks to a seis mometer on the moon and a luni tuner here.

title: Cowles Sets Meeting Date
description: Cowles Communications, Inc., said yesterday that the pre viously announced record date for the company's special meeting of stockholders March 10, 1971, has been changed from Feb. 5, 1971, to the close of business on Thursday, Feb. 11. The special meeting was called to act on the company's proposed transactions with The New York Times, which in volve the sale by Cowles of some publishing properties and a television station to The Times.

title: HARD TALKS LOOM ON ROLLS'S ENGINE
description: LONDON, Feb. 5  Prime Minister Heath telephoned Pres ident Nixon Wednesday night to give him the news that Rolls Royce, Ltd., would go into bank ruptcy the next morning.

title: Holograms From Sound
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The PerkinElmer Corpora tion, manufacturer of scienti fic instruments, received a patent this week for means of producing holograms, or

title: Israelis Said to Have Advised 2 In Leningrad Case Against Act
description: PARIS, Feb. 5According to a smuggled account of the re cent hijackingplot trial in Len ingrad, 2 of the 11 defendants said that they had consulted Israel on their plan to flee the Soviet Union and that Israel ad vised against it.

title: Weather and Men on Moon Add Up to Power Cutback
description: Rain, gloom, ice and the men on the moon were combined yesterday in another day of difficult commuting and power cutbacks for the New York metropolitan area.

title: STERLING DISPUTE TERMED PIVOTAL French Said to Feel British Assurances Are Needed Before E.E.C. Entry
description: PARIS, Feb. 5French Gov ernment sources said today that Britain could not join the Common Market without a com mitment to end the reserve role of sterling.

title: Toll in Cambodia Reported
description: SAIGON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Mil itary spokesmen said here to day that South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops searching suspected enemy sanctuaries in Cambodia had reported killing 69 Communists in a battle yes terday. The allied toll was put at 7 South Vietnamese killed and 28 wounded.

title: India Bolsters Guard at Besieged Pakistani Mission
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 5  The Indian authorities stationed more than 1,000 riot policemen around the compound of the Pakistani High Commission to day to keep out the mobs that have been besieging the com pound since Wednesday. The Indians, many throwing stones, have been protesting the hi jacking and blowing up of an Indian plane by two Kashmiris.

title: Rescuing Dying Cities
description: One hears incessantly of various rescue plans to save the beleaguered cities. The most common method sug gested is revenue sharing. What profound, near religious connotation this has! Just like children, we should share, not be selfcentered, miserly,

title: Harry Hopman Marries Mrs. Fox
description: Harry Hopman of Port Washington, L. I., former captain of the Australian Davis Cup Team, and Mrs. Lucy Pope Fox of Boston were married Tuesday eve ning by. State Supreme Court Justice Manuel W. Levine at the judge's home in Port Washington.

title: Thousands Watch in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, Feb. 5Polish television provided hundreds of thousands of viewers here today with live coverage of the first portion of the moon walk.

title: Auto Insurance Claims Decline Under Bay State NoFault Plan
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)Insur ance industry spokesmen and Massachusetts officials indicat ed today that a 50 per cent decrease in personal injury claims in the first month under the state's new nofault auto mobile insurance law was far greater than expected.

title: Pride Amid Gloom: Workers Await Ax
description: DERBY, England, Feb. 5  We still make the best aero engines in the world. I'll fight anyone on that.

title: Matson Makes 684 Put
description: FORT WORTH, Feb 5 (UPI) The world outdoor shotput champion, Randy Matson, turned in a toss of 68 feet 4 inches tonight and defeated the world indoor recordholder, Al Feuerbach.

title: J.D.A. MORROW, 89, COAL MINING LEADER
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 (AP) J. D. A. Morrow, retired pres ident of Joy Manufacturing Company and an international lyknown mining machinery expert, died Wednesday at his home in suburban Edgeworth. He was 89 years old.

title: Shaw Posts 5UnderPar 67 for 135 Total and Stroke Lead in Hawaiian Open
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 5 (UPI) Tom Shaw put on a dazzling putting show today, scored a fiveunderpar 67 and took the lead in the $200,000 Hawaiian open. His total of 135 led Arnold Palmer and DeWitt Weaver by a stroke.

title: PENN TROUNCES CORNELL, 79 TO 46 Posts 17th Victory in Row Fordham Wins, 6853
JERSEY LAWMAKER IS FACING INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5The New Jersey Supreme Court has ordered a disciplinary hearing for Assemblyman David J. Friedland of Hudson County, the Democratic minority leader, who was charged along with two other legislators in 1968 with being too comfortable with members of organized crime.

title: City Seeks New Unit To Finance Housing
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced a bipartisan drive to seek the creation of a city housing finance agency that would float $700  million in bonds to provide mortgages for 25,000 new and rehabilitated apartments here in two years.

title: Amex Orders Fine And a Suspension Of Allied Member
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had taken disciplinary action against one of the exchange's allied members for an appar ent misuse of inside informa tion.

title: GUITARIST HAMMOND PLAYS AT GASLIGHT
description: Guitaristsinger John Ham mond Jr. is one of those per formers who has studied the blues so hard and so well he now is almost indistinguishable from his idols.

title: U.S. AGENCY RECALLS SWORDFISH IN A. &
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) The Food and Drug Adminis tration announced today the recall of 500,000 pounds of mercury  contaminated frozen swordfish from A. & P. stores, but indicated that most of the fish had already been sold.

title: Pole Vaulting Features: Free Flight and Terpsichore
description: Marty Liquori, who said he had trouble psyching himself tip, won his 12th consecutive race in Madison Square Gar den last night at the Knights of Columbus indoor track meet.

title: Portugal Bank Rate Up
description: LISBON, Feb. 6 (Saturday) (Reuters)The Bank of Portu gal announced early today that the discount rate would go up from 3.5 to 3.75 per cent.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 5  Britain's decision was received enthusiastically in Uganda ac cording to reports, but it has caused some consternation in other parts of Africa, where sympathies still lie with Mr. Obote.

title: It's Just Another Moon Walk for Marysville, Kan.
description: MARYSVILLE, Kan., Feb. 5 During the week that Neil A. Armstrong became the first man to walk on the moon, most of the gleaming new television sets on display in Ott Electric were going full blast through out the day and the people of Marysville were coming in off the streets to see the show.

title: Doctors Find Astronauts Used Less Body Energy Than Had Been Predicted
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5  The Apollo 14 astronauts used about 20 per cent less body energy than space agency doctors had predicted as they dragged a rickshawlike cart, dug up an cient lunar rocks and hopped like kangaroos on the sur face of the moon today.

title: Direct From Moon
description: Following are conversations between flight controllers in Houston and Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. and Comdr. Edgar D. Mitchell of the Navy, as recorded by The New York Times. The conversations occurred during the first moon walk yesterday, when the astronauts left the lunar lander, Antares.

title: WORKS AUTHORIZED BY EASTMAN SCHOOL
description: The Eastman School of Music of the University of Rochester has commissioned works from 21 composers as part of its 50th anniversary celebration. The announcement was made here yesterday by Walter Hendl, director of the school.

title: In Rohr's Miniatures, the Unexpected
description: The miniature paintings by Robert Rohr in his first one man show at the Kornblee Gallery, 58 East 79th Street, are just about as unexpected as possible. It may be that their unexpectedness is their greatest virtue. It is at any rate an attractive virtue if not an important one. Mr. Rohr, according to an infor mation sheet issued by the gallery, is a craftsman whose work has included the resto ration of antique furniture and enameling for museum reproductions. His paintings which get down to about five inches square and never go beyond 20 inches in their greatest dimensionare just plain staggering in their technical precision. It is this precision on extremely small scale that is so unexpected today.

title: SOME AT AUBURN REMAIN ISOLATED
description: SOME AT AUBURN REMAIN ISOLATED Took Part in Nov. 4 Seizure Called Still Rebellious

title: Police Get Black Leather Jackets
description: By the middle of March, many city policemen will be wearing new black leather jackets while patrolling in radio cars.

title: EL PASO GAS SETS WRITEOFF ON UNIT Move Involves Unprofitable Beaunit Rayon Plants
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Com pany announced yesterday that its directors had approved a writeoff and writedown by approximately $7.8million of certain unprofitable Beaunit Corporation rayon plants under a plan aimed at improving fu ture contributions to consoli dated earnings by this subsid iary, whose performance last year was said to be particu larly disappointing.

title: Franklin B. Lord Jr., 59, Dead; Lawyer Was ExNavy Officer
description: Franklin B. Lord Jr., a re tired partner in the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, died yesterday in the Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. He was 59 years old and lived at 15 Valley View Road, Chappaqua, N. Y.

title: The Romans Didn't Waste Any Time About Shorts
description: ROME  Looking at the girls in shorts at a party recently, Sophia Loren said that she didn't think shorts were for her. Not on the street, anyway. Two days later she went to a fashion show in a sable coatand shorts.

title: Navy Tests Armed Missile
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (Reu ters)  The Navy announced today the first successful test firing of a Condor airtosurface missile armed with a live war head. The missile, guided by television to targets out of sight of the launching spot, was fined yesterday from an A6 Intruder aircraft and scored a direct hit on an obsolete ship target, a Navy statement said. The test was carried out near San Cle mente Island, off the California Coast.

title: Deeper and Deeper in Southeast Asia
description: Letters to the Editor

title: The Natural Goodness of Artifice
description: No additives whatsoever. Noth ing artificial. Completely natural. So proud are the claims of so many food advertisers these days that any one who champions synthetic foods will be charged with hypocrisy, ulteri or commercial motive, sacrilege and anticonsumerism.

title: Stage: Equity's 'Heloise
description: Earnest, a discouraging la bel; is perhaps the best word for the Equity Library Thea ter's ambitious production of 'Heloise. It opened Thursday might at the Master Theater, 103d Street and Riverside Drive,..and will run through the matinee of Feb. 14. To put it bluntly, in the second of three acts, the bottom falls out.

title: New Pressure in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 5 North Vietnamese and Laotian Communistled forces today were reported to be continu ing their pressure on Govern ment forces in northern Laos with smallscale attacks and aggressive patrolling near Sam Thong and Long Tieng, 80 air miles north of Vientiane. Both are Governmenthed mountain strongpoints near the Plaine des Jarres.

title: Charles dePesthy, 60, Dies; Fencing Coach at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 5  Charles dePesthy, fencing and tennis coach at Rutgers since 1962, died this evening at Middlesex Hospital here. He would have been 61 years old Monday.

title: New City Editor Named By The New York Post
description: The appointment of Robert Spitzler, night managing edi tor of The New York Post since last February, as city editor was announced yes terday. He succeeds John R. Bott, who resigned to become executive editor of The Sante Fe New Mexican.

title: Group Here Urges Backing of Protest Alleging A.&P. Bias
description: A group of public officials and community leaders an nounced their support yester day of 22 clergymen who re cently took over the executive offices of the A.&P. foodstore chain in a protest over alleged discrimination in hiring prac tices,

title: The Talk of Berlin
description: BERLIN, Feb. 5We were stuck 18 hours at Lauenburg from Wednesday to Thurs day, said the truck driver from Kiel, 7 hours at Drei linden on Friday and 18 hours again from Sunday to Monday at Lauenburg.

title: 2 Canadian Airlines Seek Domestic Rate Increases
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 5 (UPI) Canada's two major airlines, Air Canada and Canadian Pacific Air, announced proposed increases today in domestic passenger fares and freight and express rates. They would be gin in March.

title: JURY CALLS POLICE IN GAMING INQUIRY
description: A Brooklyn grand jury is in vestigating reports of corrupt links among more than 30 po licemen and former policemen, a judge and a gambling empire allegedly operated by a Brook lyn figure with a long criminal record.

title: Polansky of C.C.N.Y. Quits Basketball Post
description: Dave Polansky, basketball coach at City College for 15 seasons, announced his re tirement yesterday, effective immediately.

title: Group Is Formed To Fight Tax Bill On Art Donations
description: Representatives of 29 art or ganizations that met recently in protest of provisions affecting working artists in the Federal income tax law, effective last month, have forced a Confer ence of American Artists to combat the legislation.

title: Landfill Company and Aide Convicted of Polluting Bay
description: A Queens landfill corpora tion and its president were found guilty by a Federal Dis trict Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday on criminal charges of polluting Flushing Bay at! College Point.

title: Man in the News
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 5At an early age, Horace Dwight Taft, the grandson of a Presi dent (William Howard Taft) and the son of a United States Senator (Robert A. Taft), de cided against going into poli tics.

title: Zoned Environment
description: The town of Huntington, L. I., has set the stage for a significant advance in protection of the environment. If expected funds are forthcoming from both the Federal Government and private foundations, a detailed study of the township's resources is to be made by a team of recognized authorities in the ecological aspects of regional planning. On the basis of their findings new zoning law will then be drawn up which, it is hoped, will be a model environmentally and sociologically, yet one that is economically feasible, politically practical and legally tenable.

title: M.E.I. TO SELL STOCK OF TEXAS AIRLINES Wyant Group Buys Shares in $13Million Deal
description: The M.E.T. Corporation, for merly Minnesota Enterprises, said yesterday it had agreed to sell its stock in Texas Inter national Airlines to William M. Wyant Jr. and associates for $13million.

title: Robber Seized Through Ad Given 7 Jail Term
description: The first bank robber to be arrested as a result of recent, newspaper ads showing pic tures taken by a concealed camera during the holdup was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn.

title: 15thCentury Monk Who Made Maps Gave His Name to Lunar Landing Area
description: Fra Mauro began pioneering work 514 years ago on what was to become the most ac curate map of the earth the world had ever known.

title: Rosemary Casals Is Upset In Chattanooga Pro Tennis
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 5 (UPI)Secondseeded Rose mary Casals of San Francisco was upset by Kerry Melville of Australia, 46, 76, 75, today in the quarterfinals of the Vir ginia Slims invitation tennis tournament.

title: BRITISH ROLLS BID BEINGS NO REPLY U.S. Is Believed Assessing Magnitude of Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The United States has not yet re plied to Britain's general invi tation to try to work out some arrangement to salvage Rolls Royce production of engines for a new Lockheed commer cial airliner, individuals familiar with the situation said today.

title: News Analysis
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 5Plans for tuition deferment, or pay asyou earn, have been both opposed and praised in the aca demic community since they were first proposed a decade ago.

title: TV Coverage Scheduled Till Two Craft Rejoin
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  Live television coverage of the Apollo 14 moon mis sion by the three major Amer ican networks will continue tomorrow.

title: Matyas Rakosi of Hungary Dies; Communist Leader in Stalin Era
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 5 (AP) Matyas Rakosi, the Hungarian Communist party leader in the Stalin years, who has lived in the Soviet Union since he was exiled in 1956, died at Gorky today at the age of 78, the Hun garian press agency, M.T.I., re ported.

title: Sports of The Times At the Movies
description: During the filming of Paper Lion three years ago, Alan Alda, virtually the only experienced actor in the cast, described the advantages of being a player among football players. These guys are great, said Alda, gesturing toward Alex Karras and assorted Detroit Lions. They have more natural presence, as a group, than many actors. They are performers in a way, used to reading each other. They can improvise right up to the edge of the thing and go with whatever feeling is in the air. And, of course, I never have to worry about them stealing scenes from me.

title: Unemployment Rate Down For First Time in 7 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The unemployment rate dropped somewhat in January, its first decline in seven months, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: DEFECTIVE SWITCH POSED A PROBLEM
description: It took some ingenious re writing of a computer program and about 60 rapidfire punches on a cockpit keyboard to clear the way for the Apollo lunar landing yesterday.

title: DEFERRED TUITION APPROVED BY YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 5King man Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, today an nounced the formal adoption of a program to allow students to defer payment of a portion of their tuition for up to 35 years.

title: COUGARS DEFEAT KENTUCKY,156139 Caldwell Scores Record of 56 After Day in a Hospital
Theater: Pinter Festival Bows at Lincoln Center
description: For some time it has been evident that the work the Lin coln Center Repertory Com pany was doing at the Forum Theater, in the basement of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, was occasionally more vital than what was being achieved on the upper level. Last night the Forum opened what is called a Harold Pinter Festi val, with a new revival of The Birthday Party. The doublebill Landscape and Silence will be added to the repertory next week.

title: Dr. Andrew Truxal Dies; ExHead of Hood College
description: FREDERICK, Md., Feb. 5 (AP)Dr. Andrew G. Truxal, who served as president of Hood College from 1948 to 1961, died Wednesday night at his winter home in Naples, Fla., after a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: Court Won't Reinstate Employe in Waldorf Hotel Welfare Case
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice in Brooklyn refused yes terday to reinstate a Human Resources Administration em ploye who was suspended Jan. 20 for placing a welfare fam ily in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Soldier and 2 Civilians Killed in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Saturday, Feb. 6 (Reuters)A British soldier and two civilians were shot to death early today during rioting in Catholic areas of Belfast.

title: Benedict Gimbel Jr., 71, Dies; Had Owned Radio Station WIP
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) Benedict Gimbel Jr., a mem ber of the Gimbel department store family and a broadcast ing executive, died today in hospital after an illness. He was 71 years old.

title: MOIS AVRAM, 90, LONG AN ENGINEER Consultant to Governments and Companies Is Dead
description: Mois H. Avram, a consulting industrial engineer to many for eign governments and to com panies throughout the world, died Thursday at his home, 25 Fifth Avenue at the age of 90.

title: Home EcOut of the Kitchen and Into the World
description: Home Economics. To many women who were once home ec students in junior high or high school, those words conjure up memories of making white sauce or putting hems in skirts or baking chocolate chip cook ies that could be sneaked to boyfriends in the next class.

title: Nixon Aide Defends Economic Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, faced with skepticism from some Congressional Democrats, defended today the Adminis tration's optimistic forecast for the economy this year, terming the prediction reasonable and attainable.

title: Rolls Deal Pursued in Japan
description: TOKYO. Feb. 5 (Reuters) Kawasaki Heavy Industries said today it hoped to get a license from RollsRoyce Ltd., to man ufacture gasturbine engines despite the British company's bankruptcy step. Kawasaki, which signed the licensing con tract Wednesday, said it was to pay royalties on engines produced trom RoilsRoyce blue prints.

title: Court Upholds Patrolmen On Retroactive Pay Claim
description: State Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol ruled yester day that the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had a valid contract with the city requiring a $100amonth ret roactive pay increase for 27,000 patrolmen.

title: Antares on the Moon
description: In the early hours of yesterday morning, as Antares moved toward its lunar landing, many a space official as well as the ordinary space buff must have wondered whether Apollo 14 was not a jinxed flight. Beginning with the rain clouds that delayed its blastoff on Sunday, continuing through the docking and battery problems that plagued the long climb to the moon, and culminating in the computer and radar difficulties that disconcerted the crew of Antares on the final leg of the journey, almost seemed as if some powerful malign force was seeking to raise everhigher obstacles to the goal. It was with a particular sense of relief, therefore, that all con cerned finally heard the good news that Antares had landed safely almost precisely where planned.

title: Merger Talks Held By North Central And Mohawk Line
description: UTICA, Feb. 5 (AP)Strike bound Mohawk Airlines and representatives of North Cen tral Airlines in Minneapolis have been discussing the pos sibility of merger.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS FEEL NIXON HAS DECIDED ON STRIKE IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  Strong indications emerged here today that the Nixon Admin istration had decided to golf ahead with a strike by South Vietnamese troops against enemy supply lines in southern Laos.

title: U.S. FILES APPEAL ON EAVESDROPPING
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 5 (AP) The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Ap peals for the Sixth Circuit today to affirm the right of the Attorney General, acting with out court permission, to order eavesdropping on persons sus pected of activity contrary to the national interest.

title: CELTICS SUBDUE ROYALS BY 114110 White, Havlicek Score 26 Each to Lead Victory
12 Hurt in Racial Fight
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  A fight involving black and white pupils at Sam Houston High School today left at least 12 pupils injured.

title: SPAIN DROPS CURBS IN BASQUE PROVINCE
description: MADRID, Feb. 5The Gov ernment today ended the state of exception that it imposed two months ago in Guipuzcoa Province at a time of intense agitation over the courtmar tialing of 15 Basque activists.

title: Brooks Robinson Signs $100,000 Oriole Pact
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 5 (AP) Brooks Robinson joined Frank Robinson in the Baltimore Orioles' $100,000 pay bracket today when he signed his baseball contract. It rep resented a $20,000 salary in crease.

title: Court Warns Arkansas Board to Integrate Schools
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., Feb. 5 Members of a public school board found in open defiance of a Federal court desegrega tion order were ordered today to comply by Thursday or go to jail for the rest of the school year.

title: Delegates to 2d White House Hunger Parley Attack President's Programs
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Feb. 5  Officials of the second White House conference on hunger assailed the Nixon Ad ministration today for what they described as its failure to treat continued, serious hunger in America as a national emer gency.

title: FANNY MAY FORMS CAN BE AMENDED
description: The head of the Federal Na tional Mortgage Association disclosed here yesterday that certain items on uniform home mortgage forms being drafted by his agency could be sub ject to amendment as a result of negotiations between lender and borrower.

title: Enough Noise to Make Anyone Sulk
description: Even Joan Sutherland wouldn't have been heard above the garbage disposer's growl, the blender's roar, the dishwash er's hum, the exhaust fan's moan and the thunderous storm of water un leashed from the kitchen faucet.

title: Negro to Challenge Rizzo
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (UPI) State Representative Hardy Williams, a 39yearold Negro who is a freshman legislator with strong support in the black community, announced today that he would challenge former Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo for the Demo cratic nomination for Mayor of Philadelphia.

title: Why We Escalated
description: Tomorrow marks the sixth anniver sary of America's massive intervention in Vietnam, a decision which was sig naled by the bombing of the North, a decision which ultimately cost Lyn don Johnson a second term and shat tered his dream of creating a Great Society.

title: Name of Drive by Allies Tied to Wet 69 Battle
description: The allied operation in the northern part. of South Viet nam is codenamed Dewey Canyon II, after a 1969 cam paign in the same area in which United States Marines seized several hilltops just inside the Laotian border.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Neptune Meter Company announced yester day the election of Stephen A. Furbacher as presi dent and chief executive officer. He succeeds Wil liam H. Cochrane who will continue as chairman. Mr. Furbacher, who is presently president of the AMAX Aluminum Company and a vice president and director of American Metal Climax, Inc., sub mitted his resignation, effective Feb. 28, in order to accept his new position effective March 1. Charles B. Huizenga will become president of the AMAX Aluminum Company.

title: MET WILL HONOR DOROTHY KIRSTEN
description: The Metropolitan Opera will observe the 25th anniversary

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: Letters to the Editor

title: SargentWelch Election
description: The SargentWelch Scientific Company announced that John 0. Melhorn would be elected president and chief operating officer on Feb. 16. He had been chairman of the Fischer Scientific Company, Ltd., of Canada T. M. Mints Jr., chair man and president, will con tinue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: 3 UNION OFFICIALS SEIZED IN NEWARK Striking Teachers Leaders Surrender to Sheriff
description: NEWARK, Feb. 6The three top officers of the Newark Teachers Union surrendered early today to Essex County Sheriff's deputies after arrest warrants were issued charging them with violating a yearold permanent injunction against teachers strikes.

title: VIRGINIA M. BERSAGEL
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5Vir ginia M. Bersagel, librarian for the Institute of Life Insurance in New York, died yesterday in Fairview Hospital. Her age was 48. She had been receiving treatment for a heart ailment since last August.

title: Lockheed Deal Sought
description: Suddenly confronted with a second chance at a $400mil lionplus market that they thought they lost three years ago, two United States com panies moved quickly yester day in an effort to capitalize on the RollsRoyce Company's disastrous troubles with the jet engine for Lockheed's Tristar airliner.

title: The First Man on the Moon
description: YUMA, Ariz., Feb. 5 (AP) While the moonwalk was in progress today, the first man to set foot on the moon, Neil A. Armstrong, was here, ob serving a test flight of the Cheyenne helicopter. Neither he nor members of the official observing party would comment on tlw performance of the Lockheedbuilt aircraft.

title: Jinx Falkenburg Rejects Nassau Consumer Post
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Feb. 5 (UPI)Mrs. Jinx Falkenburg McCrary, the broadcasting personality, said today she would reject an offer to be come a $10,000ayear con sultant to the Nassau County Department of Consumer Af fairs.

title: A Laotian General Cool to Bigger War
description: DONG HENE, Laos, Feb. 5 The commander of Laotian combat troops in the center of the panhandle of Laos said at his beleaguered forward command post today that the situation was critical and he did not expect to be able to hold out under mounting North Vietnamese pressure.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION ADVANCES IN WEEK G.M. Accounts for 116,711 of 194,221Car Output
U.A.R. Held Able to Stage An Attack Across Canal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Egyptian military preparations over the last six weeks lead Western and Israeli military sources to conclude that the Egyptian Army, supported by an improved airdefense sys tem, is in a position to stage a major attack across the Suez Canal.

title: President Praises Role Of National Endowment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) President Nixon commended today the innovative and vital role of the National Endow ment for the Humanities and urged Congress to extend the life of the National Foundation of the Arts and Humanities, of which it is a part.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 5  A perceptive American lawyer remarked here recently on how the governments of supposedly capitalist nations cushion key industries nowadaysprotect big companies, when they are thought vital to the economy, from the conse quences of their own inefficiency. In those areas, he said, failure is not allowed.

title: Police Bravery in 1863 Riots Recalled
description: On July 17, 1863, three citizens of New York sat down to lunch in a restau rant on lower Fifth Avenue and founded a relief fund to aid the families of policemen who were killed during the riots here against the Union's first military draft.

title: 2D WALK IS BEGUN
description: HOUSTON, Saturday, Feb. 6 Two American astronauts walked the gentle slopes of Fra Mauro yesterday, setting up instruments, collecting rocks and probing subsurface reaches in search of clues to the moon's earliest history.

title: No More Trawlers Sighted

title: the traveler's world
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaGondar's major tourist attractions, the somewhat characterless 17thcen tury palace and outriding build ings, are valid enough reason for the trip but, more important, they bring the tourist out of the capital to walk about a small provincial city. The 15minute drive from the airport through lovely Woods and fields with walking villagers, goats, burros and youngsters sharing the macadam, leads into a small city of low stone buildings, some in pastel colors, standing shoulder to shoulder as if they were in southern Italy. Of course! The Italians were here, filtering down when they occupied Eritrea, Ethiopia's north easterly province, and later the whole country.

title: Eisenhower Revisited A Political Genius? A Brilliant Man?
description: IT has been slightly more than a decade since Robert Frost greeted the dawn of a next Augustan age . . . of poetry and power and Dwight D. Eisenhower, exPresident, left Washington for Gettysburgstill an immensely popular figure who, had the law permitted and the spirit and the flesh been willing, could easily have been the man taking the oath of office on January 20, 1961, thus deferring the Augustan age for at least four more years. Eisenhower was held in high esteem for the rest of his life, but throughout most of the sixties those amateurs who sit in more or less professional judgment on Presidentsother politicians, his torians, journalistscame more and more into agreement that his eight years in the White House had been a period of meager accomplishment and lackadaisical leadership. The greatest failure, the consensus seemed to be, was one of anticipation. What a prescient statesman could have foreseen in the fifties, the argu ment runs, was that the ship of state was headed for a sea of troubles, and this the 34th President conspicu ously failed to perceive. He lacked foresight and imagination and thus bore considerable responsibility for the difficulties of the three men who succeeded him in the sixties.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In Robert L. Fish's THE GREEN HELL TREASURE (Put nam's, $4.95), the ninth case for Capt. Jose da Silva of the Brazilian police and Wilson of Interpol, both operatives again complement one another bril liantly in deduction and repar tee. Fifteen years ago, a half million in jewels was stolen from the Porto Alegre, a ship anchored in the roadstead off Barbados. The thieves were rounded up, but not the loot. Now, when their mastermind (the cruel and impressive Mc Neil) is released from stir, his activities excite from the law a certain curiosity. How, wonder da Silva and Wilson, may the wily McNeil be induced to lead them to the booty? And will a feminine ploy bear fruit? The Green Hell Treasure is an outstanding title in a first rate seriesand Mr. Fish's Car ibbean backdrops will stir yearnings in every traveler who remembers season in the sun.

title: The Yale Faculty Makes the Scene
description: PITY poor Yale. For years it had been the stuffedshirted, Repub lican square of the Ivy League. All those crewcuts, J. Press jackets, potatoesinthemouth New Canaan accents and talk of squash rackets, yachting and the bond market. A col lege where the future corporation lawyers and Wall Street partners of America might pick up a smattering of liberal arts knowledge about Im manuel Kant, Frans Hals and the Lake poets from a faculty made up mainly of pipesmoking, tweedy, up tight WASP's who had themselves gone to Yale. A faculty, too, whose members were virtually unknown to the world beyond New Haven. And meanwhile, to Yale's chagrin, its bit terest rival Harvard was generally acclaimed as the hot center of Ameri can intellectual life  With It, Where It's Happening, to use a pair of execrable phrases from the recent past. Moreover, the Harvard faculty seemed to be aglitter with famous names  prominent White House ad visers, Nobel and Pulitzer Prize win ners, and assorted other celebrities who peered frequently out at Amer ica from the covers of Time and Newsweek. John Kenneth Galbraith turned up on latenight television to chitchat with Johnny Carson, William Alfred commuted from Cambridge to New York to write the book for a Broadway musical and Arthur Schle singer Jr. was, for God's sake, the movie critic for Vogue. And who did Yale have to compete in such high powered company? Nobody.

title: Hickory, Dickory, Dock, News Around the Clock
description: WHEN I was just a teen the radio ac companiment to breakfast invariably meant some beloved, slick spieling disk jockey and the shaboomboom bleats of Danny and the Dressmak ers (or was it Eva and the Yellevators?). Now, of course, the all news radio stationcurrently broadcast ing in some 20 U.S. cities makes our mornings Mean ingful by enlightening us about what the rest of the universe has been up to since we nodded goodnight to Johnny. Well, maybe Rip Van Winkle would hear it that way. But to this overexposed listener, at least, the all news formats are all start ing to sound like just an other brand of platter chat ter. Consider this transcript of what could qualify as a typical performance:

title: Sid, Carol, Abe and the Missing Picnic

The particular per formers I'm thinking of to day, and have been for a week, are Carol Channing and Sid Caesar, deserving creatures both, and the home they're in need of is called the musical revue. The mu sical revue just doesn't exist any more.
