Clifford, for mer Secretary of Defense, and Mrs. Clifford of Washington, was married here this after noon in a civil ceremony to Granville A. Burland, a television music producer and composer, of New York and Bridgehampton.

title: German Shepherd Wins Crafts Champions Title
description: LONDON, Feb. 6 (Reuters) A 2yearold German shep herd named Ramacon Swash buckler won the champion of champions title at Crufts dog show tonight. The victory set his estimated commercial value at $12,000.

title: Lichstein Closes With 5 Straight Strikes to Win $75,000 Bowling Tourney
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI)Larry Lichstein of Wind sor Locks, Conn., finished with five straight strikes today and beat the defending champion, Dave Davis of Miami, by seven pins in the title match of the $75,000 Ebonite open bowling tournament.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONEven in win. ter, there is a sense of charm and order along Porter's Bayou in the Mississippi cotton coun try town of Shaw. The big homes are set off by broad lawns and shade trees. When it rains, storm sewers quickly drain off the puddles, and dark ness is held at bay by a chain of new mercury vapor street lights.

title: Loeb, of Brokerage Firm, Heads Harvard Fund Drive
description: John L. Loeb, senior partner in the brokerage firm of Loeb, Rhoades & Company, will be come general chairman of an $11.4million capital campaign for Harvard, it was annouced yesterday by the fellows of Har vard College.

title: HALE IS WINNER IN WEIGHT THROW
description: Al Hall set a meet record of 67 feet 6 inches in winning the 35pound weight throw of the Knights of Columbus indoor meet yesterday at the Mason Airdome at Columbia's Baker Field. The track events were contested Friday night at Madi son Square Garden.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWThe largest book store here is Dom Knigi, and on the same counter where works exposing the evils of capitalism are sold, a thick, S07page volume extolling Amer ican business methods went on sale the other day. Copies were quickly bought by eager custom ers.

title: Undercover Agents Robbed
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 6 (AP) Two narcotics agents, Rich ard Lucas and Ed McNealy, are $142 poorer after a weekend attempt to nab two men sus pected of selling marijuana. The agents of the Richland County sheriffs department met the men at a prearranged location and were held up for all the cash they had, most of it county funds for the undercover pur chase.

title: PILOT U.S. PROJECT AIDING RETARDED
description: ROSWELL, N. M., Feb. 6 David, 20 years old, is em ployed as a kennel assistant by a local veterinarian. Eloise, also 20, is an assistant at a Roswell hospital. Robert, 22, works at a livestock auction market.

title: New National Atlas, $100 a Copy, Tells Story of U.S. in Maps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Where can an American woman go in the United States to find a man? Or viceversa?

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Could you write the history of the modern world on a fabric? The answer would be yes if you planned to use white ink and selected blue denim as the fabric. This tex tile material, made of rather coarse yarns, has had its own historyone of remarkable stability over the last 120 years.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 6 (AP)Bobby Hull tied Mau rice (Rocket) Richard's career record with three goals tonight in leading the Chicago Black Hawks to a 62 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Long Hair Costly on Job in California
U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: After more than six years of planning, clearing, digging and building, dewntown Worcester is beginning to emerge in .a new concrete, brick, steel and bronze Plexi glas shape.

title: Housewife Puts Boat Listings in Stew
description: A housewife from Miami has become the first woman in the history of the Ameri can Power Boat Association to win a national high point championship in outboard pleasure craft racing, while the Florida Inboard Race Club led the nation with six individual championships in that category for 1970.

title: Lunar Triumph
description: Astronauts Shepard and Mitchell have enacted a bril liant chapter in the history of lunar exploration these past two days. They spent more time traveling over the lunar surface and covered a greater area of the moon than men have ever done before. They set up more scientific instruments, they conducted more experiments than any of their predecessors, and in a region of ex traordinary geological interest they gathered far more lunar rocks and soil than the astronauts of Apollo 11 and 12 or the unmanned Soviet Luna 16 device. If they return safely to earth with their precious cargo, man's knowl edge and understanding of the moon and of the origin the solar system are likely to reach a peak well above the present leveL

title: Laotians Retake Town
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)Royal Laotian forces have reoccupied the strategic town of Muong Phalane, in central Laos, which they evacuated three weeks ago under enemy mortar attack, military sources said today.

title: It's Quite Amazing What Can Develop From a Car Pool
description: At a boutique called the Widow Lane's Country Elegance that specializes in patchwork and quilt ing. In foreground is shop's owner, Susan Lane, who met her chief knitter and crocheter in car pool. Mrs. Lane is in a cro chetted patchwork skirt. She's holding macrame evening shawl, bestsell ing item at $125.

title: Reader's Report
description: As this novel about the na tion's first woman airline pilot was rolling off the presses, the first international woman air line pilot, a flight officer named Turi Wideroe, began taking great silver birds aloft for Scan dinavian Airlines. (Life and art are running neck and neck these days.) I hope that Turi will escape the fate of Dudney Amelia (for Earhart) Devlin, Mr. Serling's aviatrix. After battling the brass of TransCoastal Air lines for her wings, and proving that she has super quali fications, Dudney has a dis abling runin with Dan Cupid. How. this involves the F.A.A., you can find out from Mr. Ser ling. The author, whose pre vious thriller was The Presi dent's Plane Is Missing, also went to considerable pains to get the technical stuff right in this one.

title: The Nation
description: NEWARKThe highest inci dence of per capita crime in the nation . . . the greatest percent age of slum housing . . . the worst incidence of venereal di sease and maternal mortality. The city of Newark, still showing the physical and emotional scars of the explosive race riots of 1967, endures. Last week, resi dents asked themselves: How long?

title: A chicken in every pot au feu
description: It's a peasant's dish. It's as basic as a black skillet. But for a cold winter night's feast, there's nothing more gratifying than that rural French dish known as pot an feu. Its com ponents vary from pot to pot chicken, pigs knuckles, saus ages, cabbage, potatoes and other mat and vegetables. The version here calls for a stuffed chicken, but the stuffing, like most other things in a pot au feu, is optional. The accom paniments for the dish might include horseradish and mus tard and, if desired, the tomato sauce given on this page.

title: Another Slain in Manila
description: MANILA. Feb. 6 (Reuters)  An oil company employe was stabbed to death today as striking minibus drivers and students continued their sixth day of protest against fuel price increases. it was not cer tain that the incident was con nected with the unrest, in which six persons have been killed.

title: Problem Not Nationwide
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Labor Department's public in formation officer, Phil Mason, said today that the Department knew of no state guidelines that would prohibit hippie types from receiving unemployment benefits, with the exception of the California case.

title: Foyt Posts 182M.P.H. Lap and Earns Pole for Next Sunday's Daytona 500
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (UPI)A. J. Foyt, threetime Indianapolis 500 champion, pushed his red and white 1971, Mercury to a speed of 182.744 miles an hour today and earned the pole position for the Day tona 500.

title: AnneGro Buer Will Be Bride Of a Publisher
description: Miss AnneGro Buer, man ager for North America of Mytravel, Inc., in Oslo, Nor way and Arthur Hill Diedrick Jr. of New York and Licht field, Conn., will be married this spring.

title: PRIEST CRITICIZES IDEAS ON TEACHING
description: A controversial Roman Cath olic monsignor assailed compul sory education in a talk before the American Educational Re search Association here yester day.

title: HORLEN DUO LEADS IN ASTROJET GOLF
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 6 Craig Morton, the Dallas Cow boys quarterback, couldn't do it with his team in football but thinks he can help his partner, Joel Horlen, the White Sox pitcher, win the fifth annual $30,000 American Airlines As trojet Golf Classic.

title: PRINCETON SCORES 8TH TRACK SUCCESS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 6 Princeton University's unde feated track team, led by Bill Foucher's recordsetting per formances in the long jump and 60yard hurdles, broke six meet records at Jadwin Gymnasium today to defeat Army, 5950, for its eighth victory of the season.

title: Cornell Triumphs, 52
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 6  Cornell built a 50 lead and then coasted to a 52 victory over Dartmouth at Linah Rink tonight.

title: Headliners
description: When it comes to sports, the traditional policy in New York City as in the statehas been to separate the boys from the girls. Last week 16yearold Phyllis Graber achieved a victory for women's lib that could change all that. Miss Graber had sought a place on the Jamaica High School boys tennis teamthere was no girls team but had been turned down because of her sex even though the coach thought she was good enough to play. She appealed, and last week won support from Harvey B. Scribner, chancellor of the city's schools. Dr. Scribner recommended to the Board of Education that girls be allowed to compete with boys on high school teams in non contact sports such as tennis and swimming. I wanted to pave the way for girls interested in athletics, Miss Graber said.

title: CITY LEADERS ASK CONSULTANT CURB All on Estimate Unit Except Lindsay Bid State Act
description: Board of Estimate members with the notable exception of Mayor Lindsayhave teamed up to ask the Legislature to re quire public hearings when New York City awards consultant contracts.

title: STATE UNIT ISSUES A HOUSING REPORT
description: The State Urban Develop ment Corporation, set up in 1968 amid hopes that it would build housing on a vast scale, has reported that it began con struction last year on 6,901 apartments, a figure substan tially below its goal of 10,000.

title: A New, Faster Method Used for Rendezvous of 2 Spacecraft in Lunar Orbit
description: The two astronauts in the lunar module used a new, more direct, faster procedure yester day for rocketing from the moon to rejoin the command ship in lunar orbit.

title: Shanker Proposes Parents Be Allowed to Pick Child's School
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teach ers, has proposed that parents here be allowed to shop around among public schools so they may choose a style of education that suits them informal as opposed to tradi tional, for example.

title: SCULPTURE SETS OFF 16thCENTURY MUSIC
description: The vaulted, resonant spaces of the Medieval Sculpture Court in the Metropolitan Museum of Art provide an apt setting for the chaste model interplay of 16thcentury polyphony.

title: AKIYOSHI QUARTET PLAYS BLAND JAZZ Personal Dimension Series Presents Japanese Unit
description: Carnegie Recital Hall's an nual series, Jazz: The Personal Dimension, began its season on Friday night with a concert by the Toshiko Akiyoshi Quar tet, which, for a jazz concert, was remarkably impersonal.

title: More Countries Listed Rise In Unemployment Last Year
description: GENEVA, Feb. 6The num ber of countries reporting high er unemployment increased no ticeably toward the end of last year, according to a survey by the International Labor Organ ization.

title: Brooklyn College Rifle Victor
description: The undefeated Brooklyn Col lege rifle team won its seventh match of the season yesterday by defeating St. Peter's, 1,023 to 1,007. Todd Berman paced the Kingsmen with a score of 265. Ed Brown, 261; Barry Edenbaum, 253, and Jerry Rashal, 244, also exceled foor the winners.

title: AUSTRALIA PICKS SLOOPS FOR CUP
description: Australia's team for the 1971 Admiral's Cup will be three Sydney sloops, Ragamuffin, Salacia II and Koomooloo, the Cruising Yacht Club of Au stralia has announced.

title: The Good Word: The Politics of Reviewing
description: You laughed when The Times Book Review said, Mr. Bagbalm has al ways had a special interest in his tory books  announcing its re viewers as it might be Evelyn Waugh introducing an idiot nephew. But did you ever stop to think what editorial desperation this might speak for? how awesomely little there is to say about the average reviewer? or how even those cautious tags often overstated his qualifications wildly? Did you stop at all to think about those things?

title: About Motor Sports
description: Next Sunday's 500mile stock car race at Daytona Beach, Fla., will be the first superspeedway event of 1971 conducted under the new scale of carburetor restric tions imposed by the Na tional Association for Stock Car Auto Racing. In balanc ing the competitiveness of the various types and sizes of en ginesfrom 305 to 430 cubic inches displace mentthe new rules place an extra premium on driving skill. This is why the technique of drafting and its companion, the slingshot, will play a more important role than usual in the Day. tona 500.

title: Reader's Report
description: Well, Lady Ingram's room is all bricked up, if you must know. But spirited Arabel Mur ray, posing as a governess to gain entree to ominous Ingle dale Manor in the wilds of northern England (a story in itself!), finds the secret passage through a trapdoor in the fire place. Here, she confronts Scott ScottIngram, the cousin of Sir Luke. Now go on with the story: So they have gone, said Scott ScottIngram, weighty. In that case I'll have to go back to my original plan and use the nurse's confession. Somehow we must get Luke to come up here to look as if he has just discovered it. Well, I fancy we can manage that between us. Jason, he added in a louder, persuasive tone, should you like to be wealthy beyond your dreams? If you will help me now, I shall promise you the whole of my grand mother's fortune for your own.'

title: Barbara Bueltman Is Betrothed
description: WANTAGH, L. I., Feb. 6 The engagement of Miss Bar bara Lynn Bueltman to Rob ert J. Schwecherl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Schwe cherl of Wantagh, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Buchman, also of Wantagh. A wedding in the summer is planned.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Suddenly it is extremely important to upper drawer White House people to be kidnapped. This began when the F.B.I. accused several nuns and priests of planning to kidnap Henry Kissinger of the White House staff. According to Hoover, the ecclesiastics intended to hold Kissinger until the United States agreed to end the Vietnam war.

title: Nixon Goes to Camp David

title: VON RUDEN'S 3:59.4 WINS AT FORT WORTH
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Feb. 6 (AP)Tom Von Ruden ran the first sub4 minute indoor mile in three years tonight as he captured the feature race in the Fort Worth Coaches Indoor Games in 3 minutes 59.4 sec onds.

title: Sapporo on Eve of Winter PreOlympics: A Splash of Bunting and Building
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 6 This city of 1 million, Japan's northernmost metropolis, opens a weeklong festival tomorrow that will be an elaborate dress rehearsal for the 11th Winter Olympics to be held here next year. A total of 260 participants from 23 countries, plus 873 from the host country, will test their skills against one another in 35 events in six winter sportsskiing, skat ing, ice hockey, bobsledding, luge and the biathlon.

description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates signed today Vic Davalillo, recently acquired from St. Louis.

title: Good Black Plays But Those Strobe Lights
description: SOME toys should be taken away from our playwrights, I think. Strobe lights, to begin with. The strobe light that cuts sharply into Clarence Young III's Perry's Mis sion, the opening play in the Negro Ensemble Company's new program of oneacters, doesn't precisely spoil the piece. Mr. Young writes with a strong forked tongue, he makes the white tart and the perspiring white accountant who have invaded an essen tially hostile black bar seem plausible interlopers there, he gives his black teenagers and drinkcadging strays an easy conversational life that enables us to settle com fortably with these people before they, and we, are blown apart.

description: LETTERS

title: Reader's Report
description: There are commonalities about growing up; and there are transient styles in growing up. David Marsh, coming of age in Larchmmrt in the 1950's, has his share of both exper iences. Next door lives his best friend Eddie Reilly, who is fond of hanging upside down in trees and who forever dreams of going away. You can find the likes of Eddie all the way back to Samuel Clemens. On the other hand, the thin but un mistakable flavor of the fifties finds its way into David's life.

title: Mrs. King and Mrs. Jones Score Semifinal Victories
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 6 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King and another former Wimbledon champion, Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain, advanced to the final of a $12,500 women's profes sional tennis tournament today.

Brown, a realty and mortgage inves tor here and in Connecticut, and Mrs. Brown, both of New York and Hartford, and Dr. Norman Straker, chief resident in child psychiatry at Mount Sinai Hospital, were married last evening. The ceremony was performed in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre by Rabbi David J. Seligson of the Central Syna gogue. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. Manuel Stra ker, associate professor of psychiatry at the McGill Uni versity Medical School, and Mrs. Straker, both of Mon treal.

title: SOVIET GYMNASTS DEFEAT U.S. TEAM Voronin Helps Seal Victory Despite Shoulder Injury
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Feb. 6  Mikhail Voronin returned from an injury to compete in the last event tonight and help seal a victory by the Soviet Union national men's gymnas tics team over a team from the United States. The score in the special exhibition was 225.9 points to 221.95

title: Personal statement
description: The most satisfying rooms of all may be those assembled with a collector's eye and a designer's flair. Harrison Cultra, a designer, is blessed with both attributes. His small city duplex is furnished with a highly personal assemblage of family heirlooms and furnishings, each with its own history, dating from his student days in Paris or selected piece by piece here and abroad. The overall success of these interiors is due to the way furniture and art fit into the spaces as smoothly as a hand slips into a glove. Harsh colors and crowded arrangements were carefully avoided to allow each piecewhether a period painting or heirloom deskto stand on its own. For all their tradition, the rooms are contem porary in feeling, yet timeless, unthreatened by fleeting fashion.

title: Nemerov Wins a $10,000 Grant
description: Howard Nemerov, profes sor of English at Washington University in St. Louis, has been awarded the $10,000 1971 fellowship of the Acade my of American Poets, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Hugh Bullock, academy president.

title: The atom can produce plenty of electricity, but consider
description: AMERICA is the most powerhungry nation in the world and it shows no sign of a letup in increasing its demands for electricity. At the turn of the century, the annual per capita consumption of electricity amounted to 50 kilo watthours, enough energy to keep a 100watt bulb burning for about three weeks. I estimate that by the end of the century this figure will soar to 30, 000 kilowatthours per person for one year. That is a 600fold increase in energy consumption per capita. Of course, by the year 2000 there will be more capita, about 300 million of them, but this represents only a quadrupling of the 1900 popu lation. It's not the population explosion but rather the energy explosion that is so fearful.

title: News Notes
description: THE Horticultural Soci ety of New York has announced its sched ule of activities for the year. Included are 21 lectures, eight courses, nine flower shows and seven ex hibitions. A copy of the schedule is free on request to the society's headquarters, 128 West 58th Street, New York, N. Y. 10019. The so ciety is a nonprofit educa tional organization founded in 1900.

title: The Black Mayonnaise At the Bottom Of Jamaica Bay
description: EARLY in December, a spell of cold weather froze the surface of the two ponds in the Ja maica Bay Wildlife Refuge. The clos ing ice pushed out most of the ducks and geese that had collected there since August, and the birds either moved into the salt water of the bay or flew south, hunting for ponds still open. Despite the exodus, when the ice melted late in the month, many greenwinged teal remained, dipping yellow rumps upfor food along the edges of the ponds. Coots wad dled on the shore and pecked in the grass. In the lee of tall brown reeds, hundreds of canvasback ducks rested, bills tucked into their back feathers. A squadron of five snowy egrets played a graceful avian leapfrog, each bird trying to precede the others as they chased minnows in the shal lows. Overhead, black ducks and mallards, baldpates and scaup, ruddy ducks and buffleheads hurried to food and safe havens, their wings ringing against the wind.

title: The Bay at Dawn
description: When I was newly hooked on birds, a friend and I might well decide, of a May evening, that the next day would be ideal for a trip out to Jamaica Bay. At 2 or 3 in the morning, carrying binoculars and a telescope mounted on a tripod, we headed for the subway; in company with subway sleepers, drunks and a few couples bound for home after a night in Manhat tan, we rode out under Brooklyn. After about an hour, when the train rumbled out onto the bridge toward Broad Channel Island, we stood by the doors and peered through the dirty glass into the gloom for a glimpse of bird sil houettes on the East Pond as we passed. Twenty minutes later, we were seated on a bench beside the West Pond, waiting for dawn.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  If you believe that the draft should be eliminated and replaced by a betterpaid allvolunteer force, answer these questions: Do you really think that any significant number of men from upper and uppermiddle income classes will vol unteer? Could you go to the nearest college campus and find enough volunteers to man the smallest infantry pa trol? Is it fair that youths from the lower classes, the ones who can be induced by money to enlist, should carry the burden of fighting a war, while their better  educated, better  heeled counterparts stay home?

title: RED CROSS REPORTS OUTLAYS SET RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The cost of emergency services to civilians and servicemen around the world rose to a record $149million during the 196970 fiscal year, the Red Cross re ported this week in its annual report.

title: Headliners
description: Since the assassination of President Kennedy seven years ago, his widow, now Mrs. Aristotle Onassis, had turned down White House invitations as being too painful and too soon after her tragedy. But last week she and her two children, Caroline and John, secretly visited the Executive Mansion for the first time as guests of Presi dent and Mrs. Nixon. The purpose was to preview official portraits of President Kennedy and Mrs. Onassis that went on public display the following day. The portraits, painted by Aaron Shikler, show the former President with arms folded and in a pensive mood, and his widow in a fulllength impression that has been described as haunting (see detail above) and right out of Camelot.

description: Letters to the Editor

title: Country of the aged and the sad
description: By John McGahern. 167 pp. Boston: AtlanticLittle, Brown. $4.95.

title: JACKSON COURTED BY PARTY HAWKS HardLine Democrats Urge Presidential Bid in 72
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  Is there a place for a hawk in na tional Democratic politics?

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A Percentage Of the Take
description: There was a tide which, taken at flood, led on to being Water commissioner

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The owners of the lease hold on the west blockfront of the Avenue of the Ameri cas between 55th and 56th Streets, a prospective office building site, have begun at tempts to clear a 15story apartment house of its tenants.

title: Kaczorek Wins Road Run
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 6 Charles Kaczorek of the Mill rose Athletic Association won the 5.2mile road run, spon sored by the Hudson Coun ty Heart Association, today through the streets of Jersey City. Kaczorek was clocked in 25 minutes 27.8 seconds. He finished 220 yards ahead of Richard Layer of St. John's, who was timed in 26 minutes, Daryl Reese of St. John's was third in 26:14.

title: C.C.N.Y. Fencers Score
description: Robert Figueroa won all three of his saber bouts and Carl Richie won his three in foil for City College yesterday as the C.C.N.Y. fencers gained their first victory of the season, beat ing Rutgers by 189.

title: Placing the Living Shakespeare Before Us
description: IN his invaluable book, The Empty Space, full of sophisticated common sense, Peter Brook writes: When I hear a direc tor speaking glibly of serving the author, of letting a play speak for itself, my suspicions are aroused, because this is the hardest job of all. If you just let a play speak, it may not make a sound. If what you want is for the play to be heard, then you must con jure its sound from it.

title: Some Good Skates in Park Don't Object to City's Midwinter Thaw
description: After more than a week of subfreezing weather, New Yorkers enjoyed something of a midwinter thaw yester day as the temperature lin gered in the forties most of the day.

title: TO LAND TUESDAY
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 6The moon explorers of Apollo 14 broke out of lunar orbit tonight with a blast of their space ship's rocket and set out on their threeday homeward voy age.

title: BRITISH MAY ALTER STIFF SECRETS ACT Acquittal of 4 Spurs Move on 60YearOld Law
description: LONDON, Feb. 6A former British Attorney General, Sir Lionel Heald, said once that a newspaper would violate the law if it reported the number of cups of tea consumed per week in a Government depart ment.

title: ExQueen Elizabeth: Slow Boat to China
description: PORT EVERGLADES, Fla., Feb. 6At dawn on Tuesday, weather permitting, a chartered 82,997ton luxury liner, the world's largest oceanliner afloat, will leave Port Ever glades on a slow voyage to the Orient and to an uncertain future.

title: Larry Jay Lawrence Marries Miss Nichols, Juilliard Alumna
description: PRAIRIE VILLAGE, Kan., Feb. 6  Miss Martha Blair Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Clyde Nichols Jr., was married here tonight to Larry Jay Lawrence, son of Mrs. William S. Thornhill and the late Joseph Stagg Law rence.

title: Article 23  No Title
description: TONSONATE, El SalvadorIzalco, the 7,828foot volcano situated near here, is a monument to un predictability: For almost two centuries its schedule of fiery eruptions was so regularevery 15 minutes that ship captains called it the light the Pacific.

title: The World
description: LONDON  On March 30, 1968, British newspapers head lined the story of the coun try's greatest export sale in his tory: A contract won by Rolls Royce to supply a new engine. the RB211, for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's new Tri Star jet. The initial order was for 540 enginesand there could be hundreds more  with sales worth perhaps $2.5billion.

title: Saint Francis And His Four Ladies
description: By Joan Mowat Erikson. Illustrated. 140 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $5.

title: City's Teacher Aides Can Get Degrees
description: The Board of Education and the City University made public last week details of a $450,000 plan to allow the people who, serve as teachers aides to at tend college and become teach ers themselves.

title: Jeffrey Hern Will Wed Miss Otis A. Thompson
description: PALOS VERDES PENIN SULA, Calif., Feb. 6Miss Otis Ann Thompson and Jef frey Horn of Northampton, Mass., plan to be married June 1 in the Helen Hills Chapel at Smith College in Northampton.

title: Revolution by Court Order
description: A recent decision by a Federal Circuit Court in the South, if upheld, can do as much to improve the daily lives of black Americans as the Supreme Court did through its landmark decision on school desegregation in 1954. The ruling can also have the considerably less desirable effect of injecting the courts, already involved in education, apportionment and protection of the en vironment, into the very heart of town and city politics.

title: OilTanker Repair Booms at Lisbon Docks
description: LISBON, Feb. 6Five hun dred years after their first sea faring exploits, the Portuguese have embarked on a promising new maritime careerinterna tional ship repair.

title: 23 Million Children in U.S. Vaccinated Against Rubella
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) About 23 million children have been vaccinated against rubellaGerman measlesdur ing the last 18 months, accord ing to the Health, Education and Welfare Department.

title: Repeatedly Brave Scores
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Feb. 6 (AP) Taking the lead after a brief test of speed toward the first turn, the Crown Stable's Re peatedly Brave scored by six lengths over Mediate today in the $7,500 Cranston Handicap at Lincoln Downs.

title: F.B.I. Silent on Rap Brown; Surrender Bid Is Reported
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investi gation said today it had no comment on a Baltimore Sun report that H. Rap Brown, the fugitive black militant, wanted to surrender and stand trial on arson and riot charges for allegedly inciting a riot in 1967 in Cambridge, Md.

title: City Opera Plans Revival of 'Louise, Absent Since 1963
description: The second week of the New York City Opera's spring sea son at the New York State, Theater will be highlighted by the revival on Feb. 28 of Charpentier's Louise, which has been absent from the com pany's active repertory since 1963.

title: Garage Strike Here Goes On With No Negotiations Due
description: The fourdayold strike of 3,500 garage workers continued yesterday with no negotiations in sight.

title: Dr. Benjamin Finkelstein, A Veterinarian 50 Years
description: Dr. Benjamin J. Finkelstein, a veterinarian for 50 years, died yesterday in the Down state Medical Center, Brook lyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 7261 113th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: U.S. WILL LIBERALIZE FARM LOAN PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Agriculture Department has announced plans to liberal ize a program of loans to help farmers build grain storage and drying facilities.

title: REACTOR ON COAST CALLED A HAZARD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The last of the Atomic Energy Com mission's nuclear reactors at Hanford, Wash., saved by a White House order from im mediate deactivation last week, was described by an authorita tive Nixon Administration of ficial this week as unreliable and a possible safety hazard.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: Music Mailbag

title: Child Care Centers Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Senator Birch Bayh, Demo crat of Indiana, introduced a bill in the Senate Tuesday to provide $12billion over the next three years for child care centers across the nation. He said the centers were needed because more than 14 million children in this nation have working mothers, and that fig ure is increasing every day.

title: Medicine
description: Serum Hepatitis: A Threat To Use of Blood by Hospitals

title: Jeff Wood's Musicians Reach Into Past for Black Sources
description: A strongly knit 10piece group devoted to explora tions of black source music made an impressive debut Saturday night at Cami Hall. The ensemble, called Ijinle Dudu, or Essence of Black ness, was led by Aiye Ni waju, also known as Jeff Wood.

title: Dublin Statue Destroyed
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, Monday, Feb. 8 (Reuters)An explosion today destroyed a monument to an 18thcentury Irish patriot, Wolfe Tone, the police reported here. The 14 foothigh monu ment had stood on St. Steph en's Green in the center of the city.

title: A NEW VATICAN PACT IS ASKED BY SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 7 (UPI)The Spanish Government said to day that the 1953 Concordat between Spain and the Vatican was obsolete and that a new agreement should be made.

title: AURELIO ASSAILS LETTER ON CORONA
description: The controversy in the Cor ona section of Queens over a high school and athletic field site took a new turn yesterday when Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio assailed a letter on the subject that was sent to the affected homeowners late last week by an assistant Corpora tion Counsel.

title: Penn Coaching Team Divides, Now Both Conquer East Foes
description: Harter and Phelps is not a vaudeville team. They are the young coaches of the two top college basketball teams in the East.

title: Advertising:
description: Ted Bates and Grey will get the bulk of the interna tional business of Interna tional Playtex that is exiting from Young & Rubicam. For the domestic, creativeonly assignment Playtex is looking for a major package goods agency.

title: Those Who Have Been There Aid Breast Surgery Patients
description: For many women, one of the most traumatic things in life is the surgical removal of a breast. They fear that their husbands will no longer find them attractive. They worry about how their children will accept them, whether they will be able to wear beautiful clothes again, and whether they will regain the strength to play tennis or swim or do the other things they used to do.

title: Screen: Haunting Ramparts of Clay
description: If its purity and skill were matched by power, a remarkably made film, Ramparts of Clay, would have been a masterpiece. Why quibble? The new pic ture, directed by a young man named JeanLouis Bertucelli, is fascinating and haunting. It opened yester day at Cinema II. See it, by all means.

title: Janet Baker Outsings Basketballers
description: At Hunter College Assem bly Hall on Saturday night, Janet Baker gave a recital, accompanied by Martin Isepp, pianist, and the HunterPratt basketball game.

title: No G.I.'s Used in Laos, Pentagon Says
description: WASHINGTON, Monday, Feb. 8The Nixon Administration said today that No United States ground combat person ??el or advisers will be involved in the incursion into Laos.

title: Hull's Goal Decisive
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI) Bobby Hull's 34th goal of the 3cason gave the Chica;p Bach Hawks a 10 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight. goal tied him with Mau rice (Rocket) Richard for the secondhighest total in National Hockey League historyeach with 544 goals.

title: Bridge: Alert 'Sandwich Play' Leaves South With Egg on His Face
description: An important defensive ma neuver that is often over looked in practice might be termed the sandwich play. It arises when a defender with three high cards not in sequence is in a position to surround or sandwich the highest card held to his right.

title: Apollo Mission Director
description: Man In the News

title: VANINA B FIRST IN PRIX DE FRANCE
description: PARIS, Feb. 7  Vanina B. a mare almost too big for her own good, won the 545,000 Prix de Franca today at Vin cennes. The race is the second leg in the French triple crown of trotting.

title: A Look at the Girls in Connecticut Gets Yugoslav Seaman the Attention of White House
description: A Yugoslav seaman wandered into a New London, Conn., bar Saturday morning to look at the girls. But because he spoke no English except for the one word immigration, he touched off a series of com munications that spiraled up ward to the White House.

title: IRISH WEIGH CURB ON CHURCH'S ROLE
description: DUBLINThe Irish Govern ment is contemplating constitu tional changes to reduce the special position of the Roman Catholic Church in Irish life. The purpose would be to im proverelations with hostile Protestants in Northern Ireland.

title: Quake Rocks Aleutian Island
description: PALMER, Alaska, Feb. 7 (UPI)  Residents of Adak strongly felt an earthquake yesterday that was centered about 40 miles south of Adak Island in the Aleutians, spokesman at the Palmer Ob servatory said today. The quake was measured at 6.7 on the Richter scale. The spokesman said no damage was reported.

title: The Problem of MIRV: I
description: WASHINGTONIn developing na tional security policy it is always neces sary to estimate the capabilities and intentions of potential hostile nations and then evaluate the risks to national security from alternate decisions on force levels.

title: WATTS PERFORMS WITH BRILLIANCE
description: Andre Watts, running true to form, gave an extravagant per formance of a big pianistic showpiece when he played with the National Symphony Sunday afternoon at Philharmonic Hall.

title: GUY JOHNSON, 85, TYPE EXPORTER
description: Guy D. Johnson, president of Guy D. Johnson, Inc., exporters of printing equipment, died at his home yesterday, He was 85 years old and lived at 969 Park Avenue.

title: State's Electrical Week Gets Off to a Dim Start
description: The power failure last night came as the state, by proc lamation of Governor Rocke feller, began what he called Electrical Week.

description: Text of the Thieu statement will be found on Page 14.

title: BOMB IN FIRE HURTS AN EAST SIDE BOY, 8
description: A paper bag containing a homemade bomb blew up in a Lower East Side public school yard yesterday morning injur ing an 8 year old boy who was playing nearby, the police re ported.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 7Judging by the press, Britain's current beau ideal is a 42yearold Malayan railway porter.

title: Hotels Offer Candlelight
description: Guests arriving at some East Side hotels last night were escorted to their rooms by bellboys carrying candles. At the Commodore Hotel, next to Grand Central Terminal, group of guests sang songs or played cards in the candlelit lobby while they waited for the blackout to end.

title: Poles Suspend Gomulka From Highest. Party Body
description: WARSAW, Monday, Feb. 8 Wladyslaw Gomulka. Poland's former Communist party chief, was suspended last night from the party's Central Committee, its highest body, because of serious mistakes in recent years.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  Following is the text of Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu's message, as released tonight by the South Vietnamese Em bassy here, on the operations in Laos:

title: Dr. Jacob GershonCohen, Cancer Researcher, Dead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP) Dr. Jacob GershonCohen, who developed a method for de tecting breast cancer in its early stages, died yesterday at the age of 72.

title: Leafs Defeat Sabres
description: BUFFALO, N. Y. (AP)Feb. 7The Toronto Maple Leafs scored on their first two shots and went on to defeat the Buf falo Sabres, 43, tonight.

title: PRINCE'S U.S. TRIP ASSESSED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Feb. 7The recent visit of Prince Juan Carlos de Borbn to the United States appears to have increased his prestige among his countrymen.

title: ARE SPY CHARGE DENIED BY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Army has come up with what Pentagon officials consider con clusive evidence that Army Military Intelligence agents did not spy on Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d.

description: News Analysis

title: AUGERT BARELY WINS IN CUP SLALOM RACE
description: MUERREN, Switzerland, Feb. 7 (UPI)JeanNoel Augert of France won the men's World Cup slalom race of the 36th ArlbergKandahar ski classic to day, beating Tyler Palmer of Kearsage, N.H., by less than halfsecond.

title: PARITY IN RAISES SOUGHT BY ABEL
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5  I. W. Abel, the president of the United Steelworkers union, said that his union was de termined to win wage increas es that compared with those al ready won by major unions last year and urged the Ad ministration not to inject it self into the coming negotia tions.

title: Vacuum Used by Apollo The Best and Cheapest
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The $55million Apollo 14 spacecraft has the best, and least expensive, vaccum cleaner in the universethe universe itself.

title: Chicken Is Easing Budgets
description: Forget all that business about which came first, the chicken or the egg. Think instead of the prices of both. They're low; so low in fact that they're one of the biggest food bargains around, especially eggs. And remem ber, they're both chock full of protein.

title: Robinson Wins Title
description: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif. Feb. 7 (AP)  Nate Robinson, weighing 147 pounds, defeated Gil King, also 147, last night to capture the California wel terweight boxing title on a 12 round decision.

title: Shaw Takes Hawaiian Open by Stroke
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 7 (UPI) Tom Shaw of Milwaukie, Ore., sank two pressurepacked birdie putts today and won the $40,000 first prize in the Hawaiian open with a 15under par 273 for the 72 holes.

title: 9 Exporters of Oil Threaten to Cut Off Supplies in 2 Weeks
description: VIENNA Feb. 7 (Reuters) Nine major oilproducing coun tries today threatened to cut off all oil shipments in two weeks. Such a move could crip ple industry and transporta tion in Western Europe and Japan.

title: Ottawa Seeking Rules
description: OTTAWA, Feb 7 (Canadian Press)  The Government is working toward a set of rules intended to balance a maximum degree of Canadian ownership with suitable encouragement for foreign capital, Energy Minister Greene said today on a television show, Encounter.

title: Hota Wins State Cup Final, 10
description: Proving that its defense was a match for the GermanHun garian team's offense. New, York Hota recorded a 10 vic tory yesterday to win the New York final of the United States Challenge Cup, the most covet ed prize in American soccer.

title: Hiring of Minority Plumbers Lagging
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7One year ago the Nixon Administra tion announced a $1.4million, program to put to work in the construction field 500 plumbers from minority groups. The project was praised by George P. Shultz, then the Secretary of Labor, as a major breakthrough.

title: BAD LOANS GREW Al BANKS IN 1970
description: The six largest banks in New York City charged off as un collectible $166.7million in bad loans during 1970, or more than four times their average chargeoffs during the preced ing four years. The largest banks in San Francisco and Chicago had combined charge offs of almost $50million, which also represented a sub stantial rise from earlier years.

title: Controller Asks Mayor to Drop East River BridgeToll Study
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday urged Mayor Lindsay to suspend a $197,500 engineering contract for devel opment of a tollcollection sys tem for the four East River bridges.

title: Redding, Conn., Votes to Preserve A Wild Area Steichen Has Owned
description: REDDING, Conn., Feb. 7 A quiet woodland setting where there are a lake, a swamp and a mountain has been saved from potential housing developers here by a display of citizen power.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MERRY MONTH OF MAY. By James Jones. 361 pages. Delacorte. $7.95.

title: BARBER HITS 217 TO WIN SKI JUMP
description: ROSENDALE, N. Y., Feb. 7 Hugh Barber, the surprising Middlebury College sophomore, broke the hill record on Joppen bergh Mountain for the second straight day as he triumphed in the annual Rosendale Nordic Ski Club's jumping tournament.

title: Nixon Nears Move On Shoe Importing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Pres ident Nixon is approaching the single most important decision in the foreign trade field, apart from legislative recommenda tions to Congress, that he has faced in his two years in office.

title: Plainfield No. 1 Rink Wins
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 7 The Plainfield (N. J.) Curling Club No. 1 rink won the Cuth bertson bonspiel today by de feating Plainfield No. 2. 13.7, in the 12end final at the St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: 5th in Row for Lakers
description: LOS ANG9LES, Feb. 7 (AP)  Jerry West pumped in 37 points and Wilt Chamberlain grabbed 22 rebounds tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers won their fifth straight game, 119104 triumph over the San Francisco Warriors.

title: CREDIT DATA ABUSES CRITICIZED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 Americans are being as subtly; victimized by the surveillance and intelligence gathering ac tivities of corporate investiga tors as by those of the Govern ment, Ralph Nader said tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Setback for the O.A.S.
description: An effort by foreign ministers in Washington last week to devise effective action against political kid napping in the Americas was a disaster. It produced walkout, further polarization among countries of this hemisphere and a spate of Yankeebaiting. It raised fresh doubts about the capacity of the Organization American States to deal with any major problem.

title: Annie Famose of France Wins Downhill as Sapporo's PreOlympics Begin
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 7 The Sapporo International Win ter Sports Week opened under brilliant blue skies today and lithe Annie Famose of France won the first event, the wom en's downhill ski race.

title: APOLLO SHARPENS ITS AIM FOR SPLASH IN SEA TOMORROW
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 7  The homewardbound Apollo 14 as tronauts relaxed today, and ad justed their aim on earth for their scheduled splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 4:04 P.M. Eastern standard time Tuesday.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Black Challenge to Local TV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  In its first formal response to challenges by the black com munity against local television, the Federal Communications Commission has renewed the license of WMALTV here to the Washington Evening Star Broadcasting Company, which has held the station since 1946.

title: Steel Stockpiling Is Called Economic Recovery Spur
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7The steel inventory boom was starting to contribute to the general economic recovery last week.

title: Monroe Sinks Pistons
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets, led by Earl Monroe's 25 points, de feated the Detroit Pistons, 108 105, today.

title: Two Teams Gain in Series
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 7 (AP) Bill Zachary pitched a five hitter as Licev's Dominican Re public champions blanked Her mosillo, the Mexican League champion, 50, for their second victory in the Caribbean base ball championship series today. In the second game of the series doubleheader at Hiram Bithorn Stadium. La Guaira of Venezuela defeated Santurce of Puerto Rico, 65.

title: Reagan Deals Blow to Nixon's Choice for Top Antipoverty Position
description: Washington Notes

title: Rockets Beat Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 7 (AP)The San Diego Rockets continued their dominance of the Seattle Sonics tonight with a 124107 victory. Elvin Hayes paced the winners with 32 points. Seattle was without Lenny Wilkens, who has a bladder infection.

title: Harlem Coop's Head Says We Lost a Lot of Money
description: The directors of the Har lem River Consumer Coopera tive, which recently won a court ruling ending an 18 month strike at the super market it operates, told stockholders yesterday that the coop lost a lot of money, but declined to say how much.

title: Lufthansa Employes Accept Wage Offer and End Strike
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 7 (Reuters)  A 10day strike by Lufthansa ground per sonnel that grounded about, threequarters of the West Ger man airline's passenger flights was called off today.

title: POWER OFF 4 HOURS
description: An equipment failure in a Consolidated Edison power plant plunged parts of midtown Manhattan into darkness for more than four hours last night.

title: For an AllVolunteer Army
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional ac tion to pave the way for an allvolun teer armed force is now becoming imperative.

title: Purchasing Managers See Signs Increasing for Economic Upturn
description: Early signs of the hopedfor improvement in the economy are apparent as 1971 opened on the upbeat, according to the monthly survey of its members by the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc.

title: Ghetto Kids Dig Tennis Scene As Bus Ride Bridges 2 Worlds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7At 12:15 P.M. today a bus left recreation center in the heart of this city's ghetto for Mc Kinley Tech High School and a professional tennis match.

title: How Executive Recruiters Choose Own Head
description: What does a leading execu tive recruiting concern do when it must recruit a new chief executive for itself? If, as with most of its clients it finds that it has not de veloped a new top man, it conducts a search as it would for any client.

title: Y.M.C.A. Council Picks New Executive Director
description: The appointment of Dr. Robert W. Harlan as execu tive director of the National Council of Young Men's Christian Associations of the United States was announced yesterday, at the annual meeting of the National Board of Y.M.C.A.'s.

title: Torrential Rain Stalls Cars and Floods Streets Here
description: A torrential rainstorm struck the city last night, stalling traf fic, closing midtown streets and causing flooding on major arteries.

title: 92 Yachts Widely Scattered In Race to Fort Lauderdale
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP)The 92 yachts racing 400 miles from St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale ran into stiff headwinds and squalls that slowed them considerably today and scattered the boats over a wide area of the Gulf of Mexico.

title: CHRISTOPHER STRACHAN
description: SEA GIRT, N. J., Feb. 7 Christopher Strachan, a marine engineer who held patents on a submarine exhaust used by the Navy, died today at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch. He was 71 years old and lived here at 223 Stockton Boule vard.

title: ISRAEL TO QUERY U.A.R. ON CANAL
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 7The Israeli Cabinet decided today to seek clarification, through diplomatic channels, of a pro posal by the Egyptian Presi dent, Anwar elSadat, to reopen the Suez Canal after a partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from the Sinai Peninsula.

title: Oil Spill in Chelsea River
description: REVERE, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP)About 100,000 gallons of oil leaked into the Chelsea River from a barge at the Gibbs Oil Company here, the Coast Guard reported yester day. However, the oil was contained to the immediate area by a floating boom and ice on the river.

title: 100 Injured in Florida Coast Tornado
description: GULF BREEZE. Fla. Feb. 7, (AP)  A tornado struck in predawn darkness today, bat tering an expensive apartment complex, demolishing a cluster of tourist cottages and injur ing at least 100 persons in this Gulf Coast peninsula commun ity of about 5,000 population.

title: Del Monte Picks President
description: The Del Monte Corporation has announced the election of Richard G. Landis as president and chief operations officer and Ross B. Yerby Jr. as vice chair man. Alfred W. Eames Jr., who relinquishes the presidency of the food company, remains as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: BOWIE OPENS MEET OF 59 DAYS TODAY
description: BOWIE, Md. Feb., 7 (AP) Bowie Race Course, free of competition from Delaware and New Jersey, opens a 59day meeting tomorrow.

title: Guard Is Ordered to Wilmington, N.C.
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Feb. 7 Several hundred National Guard troops moved into this Atlantic Coast city today after a week of racial violence that led to the deaths of two men and the wounding of several others.

title: MINERS IN FRANCE OCCUPY OFFICES
description: MERLEBACH, France, Feb. 7  Since Thursday several hundred miners have been camping day and night in the headquarters of the Lorraine coal basin in this little eastern town near the German border. Their homes and their liveli hoods are in Faulquemont, 12 miles to the southwest, and they are occupying the head quarters here because they feel both are threatened.

title: RANDOLPH V. DALY
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J., Feb. 7 Randolph V. Daly, who re tired in 1968 as an examiner for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died yesterday at his home, 16 Godwin Ave nue. His age was 66.

title: Peace Hopes Voiced
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)As the Apollo 14 astronauts headed back to earth today they ex pressed the hope that the space program might contribute to peace on earth.

title: Mother Held After Fire Kills Children Left Alone
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Feb. 7 A charge of criminally negli gent homicide has been lodged against a Newburgh woman in connection with the deaths of three of her four children in fire here last night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Suggestion Box
description: The call by Senator George McGovern for an investiga tion of the alleged persecution by F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover of one of his former agents is simply a matter of decency and justice. It could also advance the cause of effective law enforcement.

title: Sailor, Alone Five Months, Arrives at Australian Port
description: PERTH, Australia, Feb. 7 (Reuters)A lone British yachtsman, Bill King, today made his first direct contact with anyone in more than five months when he landed near here only 40 minutes later than expected.

title: Suits and Trials including That of Hobart College for Coercion Have Followed Tommy the Traveler
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Feb. 7  Shortly after 1 A.M. last June 5, Ontario County sheriff's deputies and Geneva policemen, accompanied by a campus un dercover agent, arrested three students in a drug raid on Ho bart College, a 150yearold Episcopal college.

title: HENRY WESSELMAN, LAWYER, 61, IS DEAD
description: Henry B. Wesselman, a law yer, died at University Hospital after a heart attack on Satur day. He was 61 years old and lived at 965 Fifth Avenue.

title: A Harlequin Pattern Of Black and White
description: Midtown Manhattan was divided for a while last night halfablaze, halfdarkas the island's vital center be came in an odd patchwork in the blackout.

title: Soviet Speed Skater Wins World Meet
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Feb. 7 (Reuters)The European cham pion, Nina Statkevich of the Soviet Union, won the women's speed skating title at the world championships today.

title: How Troops Entered Laos
description: ON THE LAOTIAN BORDER, Monday, Feb. 8 (Reuters) South Vietnamese troops poured across the border into Laos early today beneath an um brella of American helicopter gunships.

title: FAILURE AFFECTS DAILY NEWS, U.P.I.
description: Last night's power failure temporarily halted production of The Daily News and crippled local operations of United Press Interntional, which rents space in the News Building, at 220 East 42d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Yacht Races Converging
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7 (UPI)  Yacht officials said today there was a good possibility that Ocean Spirit, leader in the CapetowntoRio de Janeiro race, and Ondine, first in the Buenos AirestoRio race, would each reach the finish line to morrow.

title: City Faces Power Crises For at Least 3 Months
description: New York City appears fated to operate on the edge of elec tric power failures for at least the next three months.

title: PONIARE BURNT ASH IS DANCED AT ANTA
description: Elea Pomare has a secure choreographic feel for people in crisis, whether it is the crunch of social conditions or the vein popping clinch of the Junkie's belt. The formal structuring of dances has never been his strongest skill. In the Burnt Ash premiere Saturday eve ning at the ANTA theater he created a disappointing dance that used people as symbols in an ineffective collage of protest situations. It was all style and no substance.

title: A New Mood in WarScarred Suez Port
description: PORT TAUFIQ, U.A.R., Feb. 7Under the rather noncha lant watch of three Israeli soldiers less than 200 yards away, Egyptian soldiers in battle gear aimed their rifles across the Suez Canal today.

title: Stoning in Londonderry
description: BELAST, Feb. 7 (AP)Riot ers stoned British troops in Londonderry Wight after week end violence had brought at least five deaths and nearly 200 arrests in Northern Ireland's two major cities.

title: Millions of TV Viewers Lose Nearly 3 Hours of Programs in Power Failure
description: Television reception for mil lions of viewers in the metro politan area was interrupted from 7:15 P.M. to about 9:40 P.M. because of the Consoli dated Edison power failure last night.

title: Swiss Women Given the Federal Vote
description: GENEVA, Feb. 7 Swit zerland, the last citadel in the Western world of men's ex clusive Tight to control a coun try's politics, today gave wo men the right to vote in federal elections and to hold federal office.

title: 76ers Hand Knicks Third Straight Loss, 12799, and Trail by 3 Games
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 The Knicks suddenly found themselves in a race for the Atlantic Division title tonight when the Philadelphia 76ers handed them a 12799 trounc ing. A pleased crowd of 15,035 at the Spectrum watched the Knicks absorb their most one sided defeat of the National Basketball Association season.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY DELAY CITED ON BLAINE REPEALER
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. conceded yesterday that the Legislature was de laying prospective repeal of the socalled Blaine Amendment, which bars state aid to paro chial schools.

title: 3 Marks Set in Norway
description: HAMAR, Norway, Feb. 7 (UPI) Norway's Sten Stensen won two gold medals and set a Nor wegian record of 4 minutes 21.2 seconds for 3,000 meters today in international speed skating.

title: UNIONS STUDYING GROUP LEGAL AID
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7Officials of the American Bar Association expect group legal insurance programs, similar to the Blue CrossBlue Shield medical plans, to be adopted by labor unions across the country in the next few years.

title: Chess: Fischer Capitalized on Error By Gligoric in Palma Tourney
description: Before the recent Palma, Majorca, interzonal knock out tournament, Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia was favored to finish in the top six, assuring him of quali fication. Gligoric, however, missed the goal by a full point. Particularly galling to him was the Benoni Defense as White, against Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the tournament winner.

title: GEORGE CARMANY SR., L.I. HOTEL OWNER, 72
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 George W. Carmany Sr., proprietor of the Howell House, a hotel in West Hampton Beach, L. I., and manager of the Sea gate Hotel and Beach Club here, died yesterday. He was 72 years old.

title: Heath Finds a Moral in Failure of Rolls
description: LONDON, Feb. 7  Fori too long much of our apparent prosperity has been based on illusions.

title: Red Wings Triumph Over Seals by 52; Howe Gets 2 Goals
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI)  Gordie Howe scored twice to help the Detroit Red Wings break a fivegame vic toryless streak with a 52 tri umph over the California Seals today.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH OVER BULLS, 10496
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)John Havlicek and Jo Jo White sparked an amazing secondhalf performance by the Boston Cel tics today that earned the Celtics a 10496 National Bas ketball Association victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: BIRDIE BY MAZEROSKI WINS ASTROJET GOLF
description: PHOENIX, Ariz, Feb. 7 (AP)  Bill. Mazeroski, Pittsburgh Pirate second baseman, carded a birdie on the first sudden death hole today to win the $30,000 Astrojet golf tourna pent for the third time in five years.

title: Oil Deal in Canada Is Unresolved
description: TORONTO, Feb. 7Robert A. Brown Jr., an Alberta oil mag nate who dashed from Toronto to Ottawa, Washington and New York in his executive jet last week and could not be found this weekend, is a man with a secret.

title: Sir Otto Niemeyer Dead at 87; ExOfficer of Bank of England
description: LONDON, Feb. 7Sir Otto Niemeyer, a former director of the Bank of England, died yes terday at his Sussex home. He was 87 years old.

title: Pope, Hailing Flight, Calls Man Prince of Heavens
description: ROME, Feb. 7 (Reuters) Pope Paul VI expressed amazement and admiration today at the achievements of the Apollo 14 moon flight and said man was king of the earth and now also prince of the heavens.

title: GIRL INMATES RIOT AT NASSAU FACILITY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 7 (AP)Girl inmates assaulted one another and a male guard, tore off doors and smashed windows, stoves and chairs in an hourlong distrubance at the Nassau County Children's De tention Center here today.

title: White Plains: A Center for Medicine
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 7  The National Foundation March of Dimes  head quartered in New York City since its founding by Presi dent Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1938announced last week that it would move its of fices to White Plains on Feb. 16.

title: Puzzle of Downfall Child With Faye Dunaway Here
description: The tale of how a young and beautiful woman is raised high for her loveliness and then brought low to per sonal confusion and despair is a story so favored by the movies as to amount almost to ritual celebration. Like most such stories, it accepts its changes, survives its fail ures and achieves a kind of graceful domination of the medium that means to make use of it.

title: We Are Hurting Spreads As Nation's Economic Cry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Ber nard Burns, a fire battalion chief in Pittsburgh, is worried about his jobnot about losing it but about doing it right. With a citywide economy move on, some fire engines are now manned by only three men about half the complement of 20 years agoand the cutback, he fears, could be disastrous.Bernard Burns, fire battalion chief in Pittsburgh, is afraid that cutbacks in manpower on engines could be disastrous.

title: Costello Finds Drive Illuminating Experience
description: Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello, deputy chairman of the Emergency Control Board, climbed into his car at City Hall two minutes before power was fully restored at 11:42 P.M. and announced to a passenger, I'm going to look for where the lights ain't.

title: Confrontation in Teheran
description: The ten oilproducing nations linked in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are putting the squeeze on American, British and other international oil com panies for a huge price increase.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Will you be ready when opportunity knocks? Or have you just been lying around all winter, betting the rat races in the office pool? When OffTrack Betting opens its golden door, will you be on the threshold with an idea or two? Or hanging back with the neverhappen guys, too lazy to store up nuts, too dumb to know how to sleep late and still catch the worm and the early bird, too? Don't get left, brother. Get ready. When Howard J. Samuels unfolds the master planallsports betting, no tax on win ningsyou can have the answers. And you can let your unconscious do the work

title: Planning Council Proposes State Agency to Review Local Zoning
description: The Citizens Housing and Planning Council warned yes terday that unless the Legisla ture adopted a state mechanism to review and strike down lo cal zoning ordinances, many suburbs would continue to be unavailableto lowincome apart ment dwellers.

title: Power Failure Is Brought Home to Luce
description: Charles F. Luce, chairman of the board of. Consolidated Edison, was watching Jules Verne's Journey to the Center of the Earth on television at his Bronxville home last night when the screen went blank.

title: Lunar Adventure
description: It was a stroke of genius for Alan Shepard to give his golf demonstration just before the end of his second day on the lunar surface. The incident provided a moment of playful intellectual and emotional contact between the astronauts and millions here on earth to whom the space program's scientific and technical contents are largely alien.

title: Cooler Nearer the Lake Is a Pleasant Diversion
description: The Plaza 9Music Hall downstairs in the Plaza Hotel is a bright, redplush cabaret, a comfortable place for light, lateevening enter tainment. Last night, Chi cago's current Second City Company opened a limited run of a show called Cooler Near the Lake. It is, for the most part, a pleasant diver sion, but it is not on a level with past Second City shows I have seen.

title: U. C. L.A.Wins By Cooling It
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7  Slowdown basketball, a strate gy John Wooden had often op posed when it was used in at tempts to halt his University of California, Los Angeles, team in the past, was responsible for the Bruins' most important vic tory of the season Saturday night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Zigzag Hemlines Are Shown
description: Only the shorts remain the same. For practically every thing else, French and Ameri can designers are operating on two different wave lengths.

title: CRIME REDUCTION CITED BY AIRLINES
description: The airlines serving New York's three airports, which sharply oppose a plan to give the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor jurisdiction over airport crime, asserted yes terday that their own policing efforts had reduced airport car go theft by 59 per cent last year.

title: Duke's Assignment Criticized
description: LONDON, Feb. 7The popu lar Sunday papers here strongly criticized the army's decision to send the Duke of Kent, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, to North ern Ireland.

title: TERRELL TOPS HOWE IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: Unseeded and unabashed, 22 yearold Larry Terrell of Haver ford, Pa., scored a stunning squash racquets upset yester day by beating Samuel P. Howe 3d of Philadelphia, the top seeded player, in the final of the 25th Harry Cowles invita tion tournament.

title: Blazers Score, 112103
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 7 (AP) Geoff Petrie's 12point burst in the third quarter sent the Portland Trail Blazers on their way to a 112103 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers to night.

title: Mayor Lindsay's Statement on Blackout
description: Following is the text of the message on last night's blachout issued by Mayor Lindsay at 8:25:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Cross Asserts 2 City Aides Fail To Help Cut Costs
description: Blue Cross officials here have complained that Gordon Chase and Mrs. Bess Myerson Grant failed to help hold down hos pital costs.

title: MRS. THOMAS COSTIGAN
description: Mrs. Margaret Owens Costi gan, widow of Thomas Costi gan, a New York lawyer who died in 1963, died yesterday in the Brandywine Nursing Home Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. She was 85 years old.

title: Student Peace Group Urges Protest Against Laos Action
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 7 A national student conference on a people's peace treaty ended today with calls for demonstration in Washington during the first week of May and nationwide local demon strations Wednesday to protest what the conference charged was an invasion of Laos. The conference ended before the formal announcement was made of the drive into Laos.

title: Blackford Defeats Warner
description: Dave Blackford of the Mont clair Club won the Lone Star Boat Club Class B invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday by defeating Dan Warner of the Columbia Club. 915, 1415, 153, 1513, 1510.

title: Williams and Percy Seek U.S. Mass Transit Grants
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) Senators Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, and Charles H. Percy, Republi can of Illinois, said today that they planned to introduce legis lation calling for $75million an nually in Federal subsidies to help operate mass transit sys tems.

title: COSTS ADDED UP IN ROLLS'S STEP
description: LONDON, Feb. 7With the fate of the disastrously costly RollsRoyce RB211 aircraft en gine still undecided, British business is adding up the cost of the company's bankruptcy.

title: Kennedy and Audubon Won't Share Same Wall
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)  After receiving a number of complaining tele phone calls, the White House said today that a painting of the naturalist, James Audu bon, holding a rifle, would be removed from the Green Room when the official por trait of President Kennedy is permanently hung there.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 7 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King continued her domination of the $100,000 women profes sional tennis tour by defeating Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain, 64, 61, in the final of the fifth tournament today.

title: CHARLOTTE HEYWOOD
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Feb. 7Miss Charlotte Heywood, professor emeritus of physiol ogy and former chairman of the Department of Physiology at Mount Holyoke College, died yesterday in Holyoke Hospital. She was 74 years old.

title: Bolt 2d in Caracas Open
description: CARACAS Venezula, Feb. 7 (UPI)  David Graham of Australia withstood a last round drive by Tommy Bolt of the United States to win the Caracas open a stroke today. Graham shot a oneunderpar 69 at the Valle Arriba Golf Club course for a total 272, eight under par, and first prize of $4,000.

title: The Rule 22 Debate
description: The Senate continues to drone its way through a tedious filibuster over the issue of its right to make its own rules by majority vote. Vice President Agnew could have prevented this talkathonand can still do so by changing his mindif he ruled that a Senate majority at the beginning of a new Congress is master of its own affairs until it decides otherwise. By evading this issue, the Vice President, in effect, declares that Rule 22 carries over from the previous Congress. Rule 22 states that a twothirds majoritynot a simple majorityis required to shut off debate.

title: VON RUDER RUNS A MILE IN 3:59.4
description: Tom Von Ruden slept only three hours between meets in Toronto and Fort Worth, yet registered the first sub four minute indoor mile in three years, with a 3:59.4 clocking last Saturday night at the Fort Worth Coaches indoor games.

title: Woman, 30, Dies in Plunge
description: An unidentified woman about 30 years old plunged yesterday morning 250 feet to her death from the pedestrian walk of the George Washington Bridge in to the icecoated Hudson River, the police reported. The 5 foot 4 inch woman with long black hair, wearing a green coat and dark slacks, eluded a Port Au thority policeman and a truck driver who attempted to stop her.

title: Keane Victor in Fencing
description: Jack Keane of the New York Athletic Club, Pan American Games champion, won the George Worth Medal yesterday at the Metropolitan saber open tournament on his home strips. Keane defeated Todd Makler of Salle Csiszar of Philadelphia in a fenceoff, 54, after each had finished with 71 wonlost rec ords in the nineman final round robin.

title: Barry's 34 Points Lead Nets To 10384 Victory Over Pros
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 7 Scoring 20 of his gamehigh 34 points in the fourth quarter, Rick Barry led the New York Nets to a 103 84 victory over the Memphis Pros before 5,589 fans today in the Island Garden.

title: Miss Harter's Team Wins
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea land, Feb. 7 (Reuters)  Kathy Harter of the United States teamed with Winnie Shaw of Britain today to win the wom en's doubles in the New Zea land lawn tennis champion ships.

title: A Clarification
description: The RCA Corporation said over the weekend that it still manufactures semiconductors. It operates facilities at Findlay, Ohio, and Mountaintop, Pa., although, as reported in Satur day's New York Times, the company closed its semicon ductor operations at Cincinnati.

title: Paris Is Still the Main City of Independent SubSaharan Africa
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast From the arid wastelands of Mauritania to the swampy jun gles of Gabon, from flourish ing Abidjan to the dirtpoor villages of eastern Senegal; French subSaharan Africa sprawls across a land larger than the continental United States.

title: Triumphant U.S. Skaters Take Breather Before World Tourney
description: PETERBOROUGH, Ontario, Feb.7Unlike last week, when the American figure skating team arrived for the North American championships as a group, members departed today in different directions.

title: Oh! Calcutta! Moving To Theater on Broadway
description: Oh! Calcutta, the Off Broadway revue that features sketches of erotica by such writers as Samuel Beckett, Jules Feiffer, John Lennon and Kenneth Tynan, is mov ing to Broadway.

title: Nixon Back in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)  President Nixon returned to Washington this morning after an overnight stay at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland. The President at tended latemorning religious services in the White House.

title: Mideast Puzzle: Some Clues Emerge
description: News Analysis

title: Hawks Edge Royals
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 7 (AP) Pete Maravich and Walt Bel lamy combined for 6 points with 1:23 remaining tonight, lifting the Atlanta Hawks to 121118 victory over the Cin cinnati Royals.

title: Shots Again Exchanged in Belf ast After Bombings Near Border
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Monday, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Brit ish soldiers exchanged fire in Belfast early today with Irish rioters.

title: Apollo Flight Highlights As Journey Nears End
description: Following are highlights of the Apollo 14 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mis sion. Times are Eastern stand ard.

title: ALLENDE EXPRESSES CAUTION ON SEIZURES
description: MACHALL Chile, Feb. 7 (AP) President Salvador Allende Gossens said today that Chile would try to avoid reprisals from Washington when his Gov ernment nationalized United States copper interests so that they do not close the doors of credit to United States.

title: BRUIN HOME SKEIN IS STOPPED AT 19
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)The Minnesota North Stars struck for three firstperiod goals to night and held on for a 44 Na tional Hockey League tie with Boston that snapped the Bruins' 19game home winning streak.

title: Vote to Let In Big Jets Barely Wins in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Feb. 7  The canton of Geneva voted $12 million today in a referen dum on airport improve ments that would permit jumbo jets to land here reg ularly.

title: Personal Finance: Retirement Plans
description: Age 50 is none too soon to think about retirement. More than just thinking about it, John Duncan, a retirement counselor for the C.N.A. Fi nancial Corporation, urges men and women who have reached that midpoint to start figuring as well.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
HICKEY'S 4MAN TEAM WINS BOBSLED TITLE
description: LAKE PLACID, N, Y., Feb. 7 (UPI)Staff Sgt. Jim Hickey of the United States Air Force piloted his fourman team to victory today in the national Amateur Athletic Union four man bobsled races on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run.

title: BIG BOARD HOLDING SHARE OF TREK
description: A study currently making the rounds of Wall Street in dicates that the New York Stock Exchange has maintained its share of the trading volume in listed stocks and has not lost ground to other markets as a whole.

title: Car Drivers Protest Insurance Canceling
description: The offices of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz and the State insurance Depart ment are being inundated by a wave of consumer complaints about insurance companies' unwillingness to renew auto mobile policies.

title: EDWARD POOR, 88, SYLVANIA OFFICER
description: Edward J. Poor, one of three brothers who founded the elec tronics concern that became the current GTE Sylvania, Inc., died yesterday in Broward General Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: MRS. ISAAC SLAVIN
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 7 Mrs. Fannie Slavin, widow of Isaac Slavin, who had oper ated women's specialty shops in Newark, died yesterday in the Daughters of Israel Pleasant Valley Home. She was 85 years old.

title: U.S. Asks if Jersey Wants Land in Gateway Project
description: The Nixon Administration has moved to dispose of 1,033 acres of Fort Hancock on Sandy Hook, bringing into doubt the proposed Gateway National Rec reation Area project in New York City and New Jersey of which the acreage was to be a major part.

title: NASTASE VICTOR AT RICHMOND NET
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 7 (AP) Fourthseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania completed his string of upsets today by winning the sixth annual Fidelity invitation tennis tournament with a 36, 62, 64 victory over third ranked Arthur Ashe of Rich mond.

title: Police Climb the Empire State in Blackout
description: When Sgt. Joseph Raguso and Patrolman Harry Goulding burst panting from the stairs into the darkened 86thfloor observatory of the Empire State Building last night, a ragged cheer arose from the 40 tour ists huddled in the gloom.

title: G.M. Is Assailed on Tarrytown Plans
description: Plans filed by General Motors in Federal Court for curbing pollution of the Hudson River at the corporation's assembly plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., have come under heavy attack from environmentalists.

title: 2 Unseeded Players Reach Eastern Tennis Semifinals
description: Two unseeded players gained the semifinals of the Eastern men's indoor tennis champion ship yesterday at the Stadium Tennis Center in the Bronx.

title: KATONA, IN DODGE, WINS AT DAYTONA
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. Feb. 7 (UP1)Iggy Katona held off a lastminute charge by Red Farmer today and won the 8th. annual 300mile race of the Auto Racing Club of America at the Daytona International Speedway.

title: Historic Treasures Ruined in Italian Town byQuake Fatal to 18
description: TUSCANIA, Italy, Feb. 7 (AP) The historic center of Tus cania, one of the jewels among central Italy's ancient Estrus can hill towns, lay in ruins today in the wake of an earth quake.

title: Common Market Sets Up A CentralBank Hot Line
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 7 Central bankers of the Common Market are setting up a hot line for instantaneous com munication as part of efforts to coordinate monetary policies and eventually establish a com mon currency.

title: Bombing on Coast Campus
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 7 (UPI)Fire bombs were thrown against the rear of a sheriff's station on the Univer sity of California, Santa Bar bara campus early today. The flames were extinguished with out damage to the building and deputies arrested a suspect whose name was not im mediately released.

title: Jews' Aid to Israel Listed
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 7 (AP) The world's Jews have con tributed more than $1billion to Israel since the 1967 Arab Israeli war. Louis A. Pincus, head of the Jewish Agency, announced today. He said also that 115,000 Jews had immi grated to Israel since the war 50 per cent of them teen agers.

title: Theater:
