description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Rep resentative John B. Anderson of Illinois, the number three, man in the House Republican leadership, made the first de tailed counterback today against those who are criticiz ing the Administration's plan for revenue sharing.

title: Seoul's Troops Will Succeed G.I.'s on Line by June 30
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9 The United Nations com mand announced today that he replacement of United States troops by South Korean soldiers along the demilitarized zone would be carried out over a period of time unit by unit.

title: The Dalai Lama Speaks
description: UPPER DHARMSALA, IndiaAc cording to every principle of inter national law and custom, whether historical, geographical, cultural or linguistical, we Tibetans are an inde pendent nation distinct from China.

title: PRO GOLF'S STARS STIRRED BY QUAKE
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 9 (AP)Arnold Palmer and Bil ly Casper, shaken by an earth quake and plagued with prob lems head a slimmeddown field of 136 professionals for the $140,000 Bob Hope Desert Clas sic golf tournament.

title: British Are Pessimistic
description: LONDON, Feb. 9British sources said today that any move to save the RollsRoyce engine for the Lockheed Tri star airbus would have to begin on the other side of the At lantic.

title: City and Union Told to Resume Negotiations in Building Strike
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, ordered striking build ing service employes and the city to resume negotiations to day as city officials reported that the walkout had left 2,500 families living in urban renewal areas without heat.

title: PLAN ON POLICE PAY ASSAILED BY SUTTON
description: Mayor Lindsay's plan to pay most of $200million in back salaries out of the capital budg et if policemen win their parity pay case was labeled an out rageous misuse of city construc tion money yesterday by Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Bor ough President.

title: SUFFOLK WILL JOIN CITY'S RELIEF SUIT
description: HAUPPAUGE. L. I., Feb. 9 The Sufffolk County. Legisla ture voted today to join with New York City and Nassau County in a possible legal chal lenge of Federal and stateman dated social service cost.

title: SIHANOUK IN PEKING AFTER VISIT TO HANOI
description: PEKING, Feb. 9  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, exiled Cam bodian leader, flew back yes terday from a previously un announced visit to Hanoi, where he conferred with his allies in Indochina.

title: Mamadi Soudavar Weds Jane Seskis
description: Miss Jane Andrea Seskis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Y. Seskis of New York and Hewlett Neck, L. I., was married here last evening to Mamadi Soudavar of Teheran, Iran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Freidoun Soudavar of Te heran.

title: JOHN B. HUNTER SR.
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR. N. J., Feb. 9John B. Hunter Sr., who retired in 1956 as a vice presi dent of N. W. Ayer & Son, New York and Philadelphia advertis ing agency, died today in a nursing home in Cedar Grove. He was 78 years old and lived at 51 Braemore Blvd. Mr. Hunter was a 1914 graduate of Wil liams College.

title: Hairdos Evoke Memories
description: It was the era of Glenn Miller, Spam dinners and pinup girls. Rosie the Riveter jitterbugged when she got off the swing shift and drank rum and Coke for energy. Men were off to war and Bette Davis was to sing, They're either too young or too old, about those who were left.

title: 17,000 in March Draft Call
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Pentagon called today for the draft of 17,000 men into the Army in March. This was the third straight month the draft call has totaled 17,000.

title: Volume Is Highest Since Dec. 31, 1969, As Amex Declines
description: Trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday was the heaviest in more than a year as prices retreated after, a strong opening.

title: Riessen Is Upset
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 John Alexander, a 19yearold Australian, scored with aces and passing shots to upset Marty Riessen of Evanston, III., 64, 76, in the opening round of the $62,500 Phila delphia international indoor tennis tournament at the Spec Crum tonight.

title: Cleveland Orchestra's Series Opens With Kubelik Conducting
description: The death of George Szell last summer in Cleveland was probably not felt so keenly by New Yorkers until Monday night at Carnegie Hall just be fore the concert began. There was the Cleveland Orchestra onstage, ready to begin the first of its annual series of pro grams here. There was also the knowledge that the tall, com manding figure of its conductor for 24 years would not be strid ingout briskly, as was his habit, to loom over his en semble from the podium and enter immediately into a superb performance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AIDES BELIEVE THRUST MAY COST FOE YEAR OR MORE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Ad ministration planners asserted privately today that the allied military incursion into Laos could buy a year or possibly two during which it would be extremely hard for North Viet nam to mount an effective of fensive of any size in either South Vietnam or Cambodia.

title: Bulls Lose to Celtics, 9088
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (UPI) Dave Cowens sank the go ahead basket with 36 seconds to play and dropped in a free throw with two seconds re maining tonight to give the Boston Celtics a 90.88 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Laotians to Explain Views
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 9 Laotian missions abroad acted today on a worldwide basis to explain Laotian objections to the advance begun yesterday by South Vietnamese troops, with United States air support, against North Vietnamese trans port routes and bases along the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: Garrett Decides to Stay in Pro Football
description: About Pro Football

title: Richter Scale Invented By California Scientist
description: The Richter Scale used to measure earthquakes was de veloped in 1931 by Charles Francis Richter, a California Institute of Technology seis mologist, who is now retired.

title: An Earthquake Theory Predicted That 1971 Would Be a Bad Year
description: The Commerce Department made public last Thursday a report noting that one theory of earthquake indicated that 1971 would be a peak year for them.

title: Miss de los Angeles to Sing
description: Victoria de los Angeles will sing in this country for the first time in five years in an American tour scheduled for next October and November. The Spanish soprano will give two concerts in New York dur ing the tour. The dates and places will be announced later. Miss de los Angeles made her New York debut at Carnegie Hall in 1950 and returned regu larly for recitals and opera ap pearance, in the enusing 15 years.

title: ' Little Murders' Is Back As Film Arkin Directed
description: Almost everyone must know the history of Jules Feiffer's "Little Murders," how it opened on Broadway in 1967, closed within a week, played successfully in London, and then reopened in 1969 to high praise and a long run for an Off Broadway production staged by Alan Arkin. I assume that everybody also knows the story of "Little Murders," of how Alfred the apathist marries Patsy the optimist and how she is shot dead on their wedding night, thus freeing him to find salvation in the arms and with the armaments of her perfectly mad average-American upper-middle-class New York family.It is, of course, a comedy, of a sort and of a quality that repetition does not ruin. I never saw the play, but I read it after seeing the movie twice, and I still found it funny and movingsomewhat funnier and very much more moving than the film version, also directed by Alan Arkin, which opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater.I suspect that "Little Murders" (the play) has always been better drama and lesser social satire than most of its detractors or its champions have been prepared to admit. Feiffer is such a brilliantly accurate cartoonist that there has been a tendency to read "Little Murders" as animated cartoon rather than to accept the quite extraordinary theatricality of his drama of dark domestic comedy and maniacal declamation. There is a cartoon quality in the film, but it is special to the film, and it seems to result less from a habit of mind than from a failure in imagination.In a rather old-fashioned sense. Arkin has opened up the playas if to make it into cinemaso that while there are now many sequences that could not have occurred on stage, there are also several that need not occur on screen. Patsy's pursuit of Alfred (a weekend at the Concord); Alfred's return to Chicago, where his mom and dad, a pair of aging automatic intellectuals, sound like rejects for a succession of Feiffer panels; the wedding arrangements; above all, Alfred's brushes with the world after Patsy's murderall serve to rearrange the priorities and sometimes embarrassingly expose the deficiencies of "Little Murders."Especially the character of Alfred (quite beautifully played, against difficult odds, by Elliott Gould) the photographer who understands the world as excrement and chooses not to fight back when attacked, is made to develop by visual rather than intellectual metaphors after his bride's death. So he rides a subway in blood-drenched shirt and takes a walk in Central Park, the motto of which might be "Only don't connect," and he emerges finally as happy assassinas if there were to be an external analogue explaining, if you will, the reasons for the family that slays together.But Feiffer has no real reasons, no recognition of an order behind the disorder that is his film's central subject. Essentially "Little Murders" constructs its world from the point of view of someone sitting behind the locked doors of an apartment on the Upper West Sideand so long as it maintains the conditions of that point of view it worksdramatically, cinematically, whatever way you will. Once it breaks with those conditions it becomes unterrifying, unfunny, superficial, inadequate.But "Little Murders" usually is funny  in its great harangues and sermons, in its superlative cast, and in Arkin's direct intelligence in handling most of the dramatic moments. I wish there were space to praise everybody in the cast who should be praisedbut perhaps because they are not so well known to movie audiences I should single out Jon Korkes, who plays Patsy Newquist's swish kid brother as if he were an anthology from the last moments of Claire Quilty, and Marcia Rodd as Patsy herself. Small, dark, the very spirit of indomitable New York, she is the film's most interesting casting, and she succeeds better than anyone else in realizing the human value that is sufficiently contained within the two dimensions of her character.

title: TAPE FALLS BEHIND
description: Surging volume set a record of 28.25 million shares yester day on the New York Stock Exchange although the market finished mixed as late profit taking erased most of the ear lier gains.

title: Nixon Declares Major Disaster And Begins Wide Relief Effort
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 President Nixon declared the southern California earthquake zone a major disaster area to day and asked Vice President Agnew to leave tomorrow for Los Angeles to meet with Gov. Ronald Reagan and Mayor Samuel W. Yorty.

title: Senator Hughes Plans Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa, who has been mentioned as a possible DemocraticPresi dential candidate in 1972, wilt begin a week's speaking tour of six states on Feb. 28. He will visit Chicago; Oxford, Miss.; San Marcos, Tex.; Los Angeles; Claremont and Pomona, Calif.; Boise, Idaho, and Helena, Mont.

title: M'MANUS DOWNS TIRIAC IN 3 SETS
description: HAWTHORNE, N. J., Feb. 9 If you were lefthanded and smaller than your opponent, today was the day to compete in the $30,000 Clean Air Tennis Classic here. The first four matches were won by lefties over taller righthanded play ers.

title: $5,000 in Unusual Bills Stolen At Chase Bank's Money Museum
description: Currency valued at $5.000 was stolen early yesterday from the Chase Manhattan Bank's Money Museum in the RCA Building by a thief or thieves who used a briefcase stuffed with rocks to smash a glass door.

title: Rockefeller Renewing His Bid To Let P.S.C. Pick Power Sites
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would renew a request to the Legislature to let the State Public Service Commission make decisions on sites for electric power plants after hearings.

title: In Reno These Days, It's the Marriage Business That's Booming
description: RENO, Feb. 9  The bride wore navy blue slacks, a short red jacket over a white blouse, and red sneakers. The bridegroom was in hip: hugging jeans and consider able agony.

title: U.S. Officials Encouraged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 American officials said today that they found both the Egyp tian proposal for opening the Suez Canal and the Israeli re sponse interesting and encour aging despite negativesound ing rhetoric from both sides.

title: China Reports Violation
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 9 (Reu tersChina charged that a United States military plane in truded over Kwangtung Prov ince today in a renewed United States violation of Chinese air space. Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, monitored here, said the plane had flown over the Tung Island area of the Hsisha Islands off the southern province.

title: CHUCK DAVIS TROUPE DANCES AT CUBICULO
description: The Chuck Davis Dance Com pany presented a mixed pro gram of modern and African dance Monday evening at the Cubiculo. Great care has ob viously gone into the folk dances to insure authenticity of costuming and choreographic movement, but as yet only a few of the company members have the requisite strength of technique to make the dances truly effective, though all are plainly enthusiastic about them.

title: Quake Insurance Is Carried by Few; Coverage Is Costly
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (UPI) Most of the damage in to day's earthquake probably was not covered by insurance.

title: Worth All the Doubt
description: News Analysis

title: Families of Astronauts Celebrate Splashdown
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 9, (UPI) Champagne corks popped and cheers rose today at the River Oaks mansion of Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr. as the Apollo 14 commander flew to a perfect splashdown in the Pacific.

title: A.T.&T.'S ISSUE IS SOLD QUICKLY
description: American Telephone's $500 million bond issue yielding 7.06 per cent sold out quickly yes terday and gave the rest of the bond market a shot in the arm.

title: U.N. COUNCIL BACKS BHUTAN'S ADMISSION
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 9The Security Council, meeting in closed session as the committee on membership, voted unanimously today to recommend the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan to be the 128th member nation.

title: F. G. C. APPROVES TELEGRAPH RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Rate increases put into ef fect by the Western Union Telegraph Company over the last few years have been found to be reasonable by the Fed eral Communications Commis sion.

title: Basketball Poll WRITERS' RATINGS
description: The top 20, with points fig ured on a 201816141210 98764321 basis for first through 15th places (firstplace votes in parentheses) and won lost records through games of last Saturday.

title: Sports of The Times
description: One of the more memorable of the many philosophical gems scattered over the years by Leroy (Satchel) Paige was this: Don't look back. Something might be gaining on you. But Ol' Satch looked back yesterday and was pleased to see that his reputation as an extraordinary pitcher had caught up with him. Formal notification was given this ageless marvel at a Toots Shor recep tion that a special committee had elected him to a special section of the baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown.

title: Subway Trackman Killed
description: A Transit Authority trackman was killed in Brooklyn yester day when he was hit by a train that was being moved from a yard into a tunnel, the authority reported. The operator tried un successfully to stop the train, which was moving at five miles an hour, without passengers, in the East New York station. The dead man was identified as Percy C. Mosely, 46 years old, of 11917 234th Street, St. Al bans, Queens.

title: Man Is Found Dead In His Townhouse; Shot Once in Bach
description: The owner of an East Side townhouse, John Stewart Kel logg, was found shot to death in his home last night.

title: A Plan to Save 5th Ave.
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a zoning proposal de signed to preserve the prestige retail character of Fifth Ave nue, now threatened by com peting uses, rising rents and soaring land values.

title: Harried Britons Think Decimal; Shift to New Money Is Nearing
description: LONDON, Feb. 9From the corner grocer to Barclay's Bank, British business is pre paring to change to a decimal money system beginning Mon day.

title: Knicks Beaten by 114109
description: For the second time this sea son, the world champion New York Knickerbockers have lost four successive games. The pesky Atlanta Hawks were re sponsible for loss No. 4, beating the Knicks, 114109, before an other sellout crowd of 19,500 in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Publicity Is Said to Bar Better Credit for City
description: The city's bad publicity re sulting from crime, strikes welfare and other municipal problems has been a major fac tor in the failure to upgrade the city's credit rating, a major investmentrating service re ported yesterday.

title: ...and the Untamed Earth
description: As if to humble man in his moment of exhilaration over Apollo 14's conquest of the moon, nature provided a tragic reminder in Southern California yesterday how little mastery man yet has over his own planet.

title: A MAJOR DISASTER
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9  A major earthquake rumbled through southern California early today, killing at least 35 persons, injuring hundreds and causing more than a billion dollars in damage to homes, businesses and roadways in Los Angeles and the surround ing areas.

title: Klimenko Standout Against U.S. Stars In Gymnastics Meet
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) The Soviet men's and wom en's combined national gym nastics team dominated the competition tonight against the Eastern AllStars from the United States in an exhibition meet at Temple University.

title: BIG BOARD SUSPENDS A COMPANY'S SHARES
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock. Exchange voted yesterday to suspend trading immediately in com mon and preferred stock of the Scientific Resources Corpo ration. The Philadelphiabased company is active in banking, real estate and equipment leas ing.

title: MOTHER OF 10 SUES FOR STERILIZATION
description: A mother of 10 children has filed suit in Federal Court here to compel Fordham Hospital to give her a sterilization opera tion.

title: U.S. Maintains Routine Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The United States is carrying on routine daytoday business in Uganda but has not formally extended diplomatic recognition to her new Government, a State Department spokesman said to day.

title: Pioneering Hospital Director Florence Small Gaynor
description: Woman in the News

title: OSCAR P. WENNSTROEM
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 9Oscar P. Wennstroem, a retired in surance executive, died today in St. Frances Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 308 South Barry Avenue, Mamaroneck, N. Y. He had been visiting relatives here when he was stricken at Christmas.

title: 2 Are Killed in Argument In a Chinese Restaurant
description: Two Negro men were shot dead in an argument with two white men in a Chinese restau rant in the financial district late night.

title: Canadiens Top Penguins On Lemaire's Goals, 41
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 9 (UPI) Jacques Lemaire scored twice tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 41 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in a National Hockey League contest.

title: Nebraska Scores U.S. Plan
description: LINCOLN Neb., Feb. 9 (AP) Nebraska's onehouse Legis lature unanimously approved today a resolution denouncing President Nixon's proposal to eliminate the Secretary of Ag riculture as a separate Cabinet member. The resolution de clared that the plan would deny agriculture its rightful rank as a basic Cabinetlevel participant in Federal Government coun cils.

title: ANTHONY E. MATZ
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (UPI)  Anthony E. Matz, president emeritus of the International Brotherhood of Firemen and Oilers, died on Saturday at Methodist Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: Jersey Court to Rule Today On Joint Recall Petitions
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 9 (AP) A Superior Court judge re served decision today until to morrow whether to allow a second group demanding a city recall election to combine the 22,000 signatures it has col lected with 17,000 already submitted.

title: Action to Reform Adoption Law Is Promised by Assembly Leaders
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9  Spurred by two recent court rulings in which children were taken from their wouldbe adoptive parents and returried to their natural mothers, Assembly leaders and members from both parties promised today to work for re form of the state's adoption law.

title: A Food Boutique With a StarryEyed Beginning
description: A new food boutique opened at exactly 1:23 P.M. in Yorkville the other day with three features that seem to go along with the times. The word liberation is in the store's name. The owners are women. And the products are health foods.

title: 69 Ask a Dr. King Holiday
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) Sixtynine House members joined today in introducing a bill to designate Jan. 15, the birth day of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., as a national holiday. Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michi gan, who introduced a similar bill shortly after Dr. King's as sassination in April, 1968, was the chief sponsor of the new bill. Sixtyone Democrats and seven Republicans added their names to it.

title: Normal Life Is Returning in Reggio Calabria as General Strike Ends After 18 Days
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy Feb. 9A measure of normal ity returned to this rebellious city in Italy's deep south today as a general strike ended after 18 days, and violence abated in a regional dispute that be came a revolt against the na tional Government in Rome.

title: Bomb Found in Music Hall
description: An explosive device was found by a cleaning woman at the Radio City Music Hall yes terday before the theatre opened for performances. The device found by the woman, Mrs. Marie Hurst, was in a cigarette case that had been inserted in a seat, according to detectives of the bomb section.

title: Profit Down 62% New Chief Named
description: The International Paper Com pany reported yesterday that 1970 earningsafter extraordi nary, nonrecurring charges were down 62 per cent from the 1969 level. At the same time, it announced that its 57 yearold president would be succeeded by Paul A. Gorman.

title: GORDON C. HAMILTON, EXAIRPORT OFFICIAL
description: Gordon C. Hamilton, the for mer unofficial chief of pro tocol at Kennedy Airport, died on Monday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 72 years old and lived at 25035 41st Road, Lit tle Neck, Queens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Civilians Killed in Ulster By Blast on Country Road
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 9 (AP)  A boobytrap ap parently intended for British soldiers, killed five civilians today. Northern Ireland's civil strife persisted, with Protes tants and Roman Catholics battling at two runerals.

title: Metropolitan Museum To Keep Longer Hours
description: Beginning Friday, Lincoln's Birthday, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be open for two hours and 45 min utes longer on holidays and Sundays to accommodate the greater number of visitors in attendance on those days.

title: Rail Clerks Break Off Talks and Set Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The head of a large railway union broke off bargaining with the nation's railroads over wages and work rules today and ordered a strike to begin at 12:01 A.M. March 1.

title: Black Maine Students Bid Muskie Call Talks on Funds
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 9 The AfroAmerican Society at Bowdoin College asked Sena tor Edmund S. Muskie today to call a statewide conference to find ways to obtain money for programs for minority and ec onomically deprived students in Maine colleges.

title: COAST ARCHBISHOP GETS 2 AUXILIARIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Appointment of the Very Rev. William R. Johnson and the Rev. Juan Arzube as aux iliary bishops to Archbishop Timothy Manning of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Los Angeles was announced today.

title: $30,000 Award Upheld For TrapGun Victim
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 9 (AP)The Iowa Supreme Court upheld today a $30,000 damage award assessed against an Eddyville farm couple who had set a trap gun that wounded a prowler in a vacant house.

title: 2 Funds Aiding Older Americans Who Are in Arts
description: Older American writers and artists, generally neglect ed in the awarding of grants for creative work, are the focus of two new funds es tablished specifically to help them. One is the Mark Rothko Foundation, set up by the painter who died last Febru ary at the age of 66. The other is the Horace Gregory Fund, named for the poet and critic, who is 72.

title: Lakers Win, 116111
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 (UPI) Gail Goodrich scored a season high of 42 points and Happy Hairston added 31 tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 116111 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Hanoi Warns Allies
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 9 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese press and radio warned the United States and South Vietnam today that the liberated zone of Laos would be the tomb of the Americans and their agents.

title: Noreen Sweeney, J.H.Mahoney Wed
description: Miss Noreen Mary Sweeney and John H. Mahoney, senior vice president for sales with Seaboard World Airlines were married in Our Lady of the Skies Roman Catholic Chapel at John F. Kennedy Airport yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Joseph Fox per formed the ceremony. The couple left immediately by air for a honeymoon in Anti gua, W. 1.

title: Explorers' Return ...
description: The most successful manned space flight in history ended in brilliant style yesterday as the Apollo 14 crew landed on schedule in full television view of the world. The precision and speed of the Navy's recovery opera tion measured up to the extraordinary standards the astronauts themselves had set throughout the flight the moon and back.

title: C.A.B. DENOUNCED AS AIRLINES' TOOL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9  The Civil Aeronautics Board, a battered target in the con tinuing Senate inquiry into the state of the airlines, was de nounced by a consumer spokes man this morning as an in strument of the airline indus try cartel.

title: PETER VOSBIKIAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP) Peter S. Vosbikian, an in ventor in widely differing fields, died here yesterday. He was 78 years old, and retired in 1968. He owned two tool companies.

title: Britain Ready to Consult
description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP) Foreign Secretary Sir Alec DouglasHome today expressed Britain's readiness to consult with China and the Soviet Union on ways of negotiating an Indochina peace settlement.

title: Scientists to Evaluate Effect of Lunar Eclipse
description: Scientists at the Manned Spacecraft Center in Hous ton are to begin evaluating today the possible effects on the moon of this morning's lunar eclipse.

title: Lindsay Leaving for Coast
description: Mayor Lindsay leaves to night for San Francisco to at tend a twoday meeting of the legislative action committee of the Conference of Mayors. Mr. Lindsay, chairman of the com mittee, will hold a news con ference with other committee members to present a detailed analysis of President Nixon's budget.

title: Wagner Resigns as Chief Of Ethical Culture Schools
description: Dr. Daniel Wagrier has an notinced that he will resign as director of the Ethical Culture Schools, effective July 1.

title: I.C.C. CHIEF DENIES PRESSURE BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today that the White House had pressured it into holding up a proposed Increase in the rates for moving mobile homes by truck.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRUSSELS, Belgium  General de Gaulle, who was perhaps the last of them, used to say the age of giants is over and indeed, when one regards the current political horizon, few towering figures are seen.

title: Egypt Stresses Withdrawal
description: CAIRO, Feb. 9An Egyptian spokesman, commenting to night on Premier Meir's objec tions to President Sadat's terms for reopening the Suez Canal, emphasized that Cairo considered an Israeli troop withdrawal from the eastern bank of the waterway an es sential condition.

title: India's Political Schisms Extend to a Noble Family
description: RAMPUR, India, Feb. 3  The Ali Khan brothers are feuding again. The elder has more money but the younger still has Mom on his side.

title: Road Damage Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 10 (AP) South Vietnamese troops and tanks, pressing west in south ern Laos yesterday, were re ported slowed both by bad weather and by the craters gouged in the road by United States bombers.

title: New AllOut Drive To Fill In Potholes Is Opened by City
description: The Highways Department has begun another all  out emergency drive to improve the lunarlike surface of the city's streets that are pock marked with thousands of craters better known as pot holes.

title: Former City Aide Now Receives $130 a Day as Consultant's Fee
description: Eugenia M. Flatow, former executive director of the Mod el Cities program here, has been a $130aday consultant to the; City Planning Commission; since November, when Mayori Lindsay laid off 500 city em ployes in an economy move.

title: Musical Rarities Brought to Light By New Amsterdam
description: Chamber music repertory is like an iceberg. Only about 20 per cent of it ever surfaces in the concert hall. Those pieces are in the standard forms: The string quartets, the violin and piano sonatas, and so forth.

title: Fight Fans on Ticket Line At Radio City Music Hall
description: Boxing fans joined movie goers on the line at Radio City Music Hall yesterday to pur chase tickets for the Muham mad AliJoe Frazier champion ship bout on March 8, which will be screened at the theater.

title: Gains for Gierek in the Polish Leadership
description: News Analysis

title: Soviet Dance Director Gets Plea About Jews
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 (AP)The director of a Rus sian dance company touring the United States has agreed to carry back a request that Soviet Jews be permitted to emigrate and retain their cul ture and religion.

title: Protest Rallies and Marches Set For Today on Drive Into Laos
description: Protest rallies and marches by students opposed to the drive into Laos are scheduled for today in various places across the country, but indi cations are that they may be more subdued those those over Cambodia last spring.

title: Broadcasters Contest Smoking Ad Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 The National Association of Broadcasters moved today to contest the constitutionality of the Federal law barring ciga rette advertising from television and radio.

title: Bridge: Analysis May Show Bemoaner Of His Fate Helped It Along
description: The category of players who bemoan the blows in flicted by the fates is always rather bigger than it should be. Later analysis may dem onstrate that a player con tributed to his own misfor tune.

title: Mrs. Meir's Positive Response
description: Israeli Premier Golda Meir's public response to Egyp tian proposals to reopen the Suez Canal in exchange for an Israeli troop withdrawal from the east bank of the canal keeps the door open for further exploration of the Egyptian initiative in private talks at the United Nations.

title: Rockets Top Sonics
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 9 (AP) Elvin Hayes scored 36 points tonight to pace the San Diego Rockets to a 132115 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: BLUES TIE LEAFS, 33, ON BORDELEAU GOAL
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9 (UPI) Christian Bordeleau scored with less than five minutes remain ing in the game tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 33 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ky Asserts an Invasion Of North Is Way to Win
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (Agence France Presse)Vice President Ngu yen Cao Ky has warned against treating the South Vietnamese operation in Laos as a game of double or noth ing and has suggested that the best way to make sure of winning is to invade North Vietnam.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON END SESSION OFF
description: The London Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had lifted its suspension of trading in RollsRoyce, effec tive today. The suspension was instituted at RollsRoyce's re quest when the company re cently went into receivership.

title: 45 Arabs Seized by Israel As Members of Fatah Cell
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 9Forty five Arabs were detained after a cell of Fatah based in the Hebron Hills was broken up it was announced today. According to officials, caches of weapons, ammunition and explosives were found in the villages of Nusa Khalkhul and Jaba.

title: At a California Hospital, Everything Came Down
description: SYLMAR. Calif., Feb. 9It was a bright 82degree after noon, and the men tearing at the rubble of the San Fernan do Veterans Hospital were sweating in the warm sun as they went on digging through the ruins of the hospital, where the force of the earth quake hit hardest, still search ing for bodies.

title: At Least 30 Are Killed In German Train Wreck
description: AITRANG, West Germany, Feb. 9 (Reuters)At least 30 persons died and 40 were in jured today when a luxury express train jumped the rails and crashed on a curve near this little southern German town.

title: Agnew Completes Journey To Back Revenue Sharing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (AP)  Vice President Agnew completed a trip to promote the Nixon Administration's revenue sharing program today by call ing it a very substantial be ginning.

title: BENGUET'S DEAL OFF WITH HERCULES OIL
description: Benguet Consolidated, Inc., and the Hercules Oil and Min eral Corporation said yesterday that they had terminated an agreement under which Her cules would have paid $32 million for a 60 per, cent in terest in Benguet.

title: UGANDA EXCHIEF VOWS TO GO HOME
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Feb. 9Milton Obote, the de posed President of Uganda, vowed today that he would definitely go back home, al though he could not say when.

title: French Mine Strike Widens: TV Is Disrupted by Walkout
description: PARIS, Feb. 9 (Reuters)A strike by French miners spread today.

title: End to Lockheed Aid Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the financial crisis facing Lockheed had been worsened by the Rolls bank ruptcy. He added that Congress should refuse to appropriate any more funds for Lockheed defense contracts in payment for cost overruns until there was full public disclosure of company's finances.

title: CocaCola Denies Deception In Sales Promotion, Contest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The CocaCola Company, facing a formal Federal Trade Commission complaint, denied today that it had deceived par ticipants in the 1969 Big Name Bingo promotion by in voicing an undisclosed contest rule that eliminated many po tential $100winners.

title: Executive Changes
description: Three of the four leading companies in the electric power industry became indirectly involved yesterday in a change of executives at two com panies. The Babcock & Wilcox Company announced that A. P. Taber, a vice president, had been named to head the company's power generation division. He succeeds Ellis T. Cox, who resigned to accept another position. Later, it was learned the other position was vice president of the AllisChalmers Manufacturing Company, where he will also serve as a group executive in the electric utility equip ment group.

title: Newton Denounces 2 Missing Panthers
description: Huey P. Newton, national leader of the Black Panther party, denounced two New York Panther leaders yesterday as enemies of the people who had put party leaders and members in jeopardy by dis appearing while on trial here.

title: Cincinnati Enquirer to Be Sold To a Trading Stamp Company
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 9 (AP) The E. W. Schipps Company said today it planned to sell its controlling interest in The Cin cinnati Enquirer to a California trading stamp concern and to scrap its agreement to sell the morning daily to Enquirer mi nority shareholders.

title: Dr. Norman Knox, 47, Dies; Hunter English Professor
description: Dr. Norman E. Knox, asso ciate professor of English at Hunter College, died Monday after suffering a heart attack at his home, 5 East 73d Street. He was 47 years old.

title: Dormitory Votes Target of State Bill
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9A bill to define clearly the voting resi dence of 18yearold voters and prevent mass dormitory votes in small college communities is being drafted by the chairman of the Joint Legislative Com mittee on the Election Law.

title: ROBERT BLAKE JR.; RECORDED OPERAS
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 9 Robert E. Blake Jr., a recording engineer who lived in this city for many years, died yesterday in Sanford, Fla., where he had recently made his home. He was 56 years old.

title: Stage: Pincer's Landscape and Silence
description: The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center, by offering Harold Pinter's first produced fulllength play, The Birth day Party, in repertory with his most recent works, Land scape and Silence (which opened last night in the Forum Theater), illuminates an artistingrowth.

title: 4 Seized With Guns and Bank Blueprints
description: Four young men who were stopped for a traffic offense in Greenwich Village last night were arrrested after their car was found to contain three guns, blueprints for several banks, newspaper clippings on sniping incidents and a volumi nous ledger that included a no tation on a murdered nightclub operator.

title: APOLLO ASTRONAUTS LAND WITHIN A MILE OF TARGET AFTER A TERRIFIC FLIGHT
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 9  The Apollo 14 astronauts rode their spaceship to a safe, suc cessful and precise splashdown in the Pacific Ocean at 4:05 P.M. today, Eastern standard time.

title: Western Electric Net Up
description: The Western Electric Com pany reported yesterday gains in sales and net income for 1970. The preliminary annual report placed sales at $5,856, 160,000 up from $4,883,221,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to $253,447,000 from $227,025, 000 in 1969.

title: INBAL INTERPRETS DANCES OF YEMEN
description: The Inbal Dance Theater of Israel, whose repertory stems principally from the Yemenite background of its original mem bers and its founderdirector, Sara LeviTanai, opened at the City Center last night for a run through Sunday night.

title: Lockheed to Revise Plan On Delivery of Airbuses
description: After meeting with its lead ing nonGovernment customers here all day, the Lockheed Air craft Corporation said yester day that within approximately two weeks it expected to issue a revised proposal on how it would make good on delivery of 178 Tristar airbuses for which it had orders.

title: Repair Cost For Cars Up 111% Since '60
description: One of the country's lead ing insurance industry trade groups said yesterday that the biggest single factor behind rapidly rising auto insurance rates was not medical costs but runaway autorepair bills.

title: Civic Group Is Formed
description: More than 100 of the city's most prominent business lead ers have formed an association to deal with municipal prob lems, beginning with a private ly financed program to clean midtown streets.

title: Hearings on Jobless Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) A Senate Public Works sub committee will hold a series of field hearings beginning next week on a proposed $950mil lion Federal aid work program in areas of high unemployment. The measure would authorize Federal grants for local public works in arras with unemploy ment of 8.75 per cent or higher.

title: Autopsy on C. W. Post Coed Shows She Froze to Death
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Feb. 9 (UPI)  An autopsy on a C. W. Post College coed, Linda Mae Jarnigan, disclosed today that she had frozen to death while under the influence of drugs and alcohol.

title: President to Ask Stiff Environmental Protection Standards for Strip Mining
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Nixon Administration will send to Congress tomorrow a pro posal for stringent standards for environmental protection in the surface mining, or strip mining, industry.

title: MOSCOW EXPELS FOREIGN NEWSMAN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9The So viet Government today ordered the expulsion from the country of Per Egil Hegge, a correspond ent for three Scandinavian newspapers who had had unique contact with Alcksandr I. Sol zhenitsyn, the Soviet novelist.

title: Merrill Lynch Chief Asks Curb On Firms With Processing Lag
description: Donald T. Regan, chairman of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., recommended yesterday that restric tions be imposed on brokerage firms incapable of handling the heavy trading volume that had been surging into the stock market in recent sessions. He said he felt either the Securities and Exchange Commission or the major stock exchanges should invoke a quota system to prevent such firms from taking in more business than they could process without opera tional difficulties.

title: JAZZ BAND STEPS INTO ITS 6TH YEAR
description: One Of the most unusual en gagements is the history of New York jazz reached a mile stone Monday night when the Thad JonesMel Lewis Jazz Band started its sixth year at the Village Vanguard. The band, a collection of some of the best freelance jazzmen in New York, made its first public ap pearance at the Vanguard on Feb. 7, 1966, a Monday night, when the Vanguard would nor mally have been closed.

title: CURFEW IS HALTED IN WILMINGTON, N. C.
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Feb. 9 (UPI)A nighttime curfew was lifted here today, but 600 Na tional Guardsmen continued to patrol the streets, where two persons have been killed in racial violence.

title: Maritime Agency Appoints
description: Francis J. O'Donnell has been appointed chief of the office of market development in the Maritime Administration's east ern region, Capt. Thomas A. King, director of the region, announced yesterday. Mr. O'Donnell was formerly with MooreMcCormack Lines.

title: BAR ASSOCIATION NAMES BOSTONIAN
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP)Robert W. Meserve, a Boston trial law yer who was a teacher at the Harvard Law School, was nomi nated today as presidentelect of the American Bar Associa tion.

title: Handy & Harman Results Delayed by Gold Shortage
description: Handy & Harman, the New Yorkbased processor and fab ricator of precious metals, said yesterday that its audited finan cial results would be delayed about two weeks because the concern had discovered a short age of about $1.8million in the gold inventory at a plant in At tleboro, Mass.

title: Next Season's TV LineUp Starting to Take Form
description: The television networks have begun assembling and selling their fall entertainment sched ules, and although no lineups are complete yet, a picture of what viewers will likely see on their home screens has begun to emerge.

title: DR. KENNETH BERRIEN OF RUTGERS FACULTY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 9 (AP)Dr. Kenneth Ber rien, a professor of psychology at Rutgers University and the author of six books on psychol ogy, died at a hospital here to day. He was 61 years old and lived in Somerville.

title: Guardians of Morals
description: To stand as the protector of public morality is an attractive pose for a politician just before an election. And so it was not surprising that many politicians took pains last fall to discredit or condemn the Federal Commission on Obscenity and Pornography. It was convenient shorthand message to the voters.

title: FREDERICK KUETHER, PASTORAL ADVISER
description: Frederick C. Kuether, direc tor of training at the American Foundation of Religion and Psychiatry, 3 West 29th Street, died at BeekmanDowntown Hospital Monday evening after having undergone surgery. He was 59 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N. Y.

title: Millions Have Died in Past Earthquakes
description: Earthquakes throughout history have taken millions of lives and caused damage in the hundreds of billions of dollars.

title: Paiement's 4 Goals Rout Sabres for Canucks, 63
description: VANCOUVER, Feb. 9 (UPI)  Hardskating Rosaire Paie meat scored four goals tonight to lead the Vancouver Canucks to a 63 triumph over the Buf falo Sabres in a National Hoc key League game.

title: EXASSEMBLYMAN WINS SENATE SEAT
description: William J. Giordano, a 47 yearold former Assemblyman who resigned his seat last month in Brooklyn's 53d As sembly District to run for a vacant seat in the State Senate, won the Senate seat by a large margin in a special election yesterday.

title: DUPING OF STEEL LAID TO JAPANESE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Three major producers of specialtysteel products an nounced the filing today of dumping charges against eight Japanese producers of stainless steel.

title: Market Place:Pressures Stir On Certificate
description: Pressures arc building for the early elimination of the stock certificate as record volume on the New York Stock Exchange once again raises the specter of a paper work logjam.

title: Croatian Nationalism Gets New Impetus
description: ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Feb. 6 A strange alliance of Com munists and Roman Catholics, politicians and intellectuals, has coalesced here to assert the rights of some 4.5 million Croats to guide their own des tinies and control their own riches.

title: Astronauts Begin Quarantine to Guard the Earth Against Possible Lunar Diseases
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 9After the Apollo 14 crew was picked up in the Pacific Ocean today, the three astronauts began what some health officials expect will be the last quarantine needed to protect inhabitants of the earth from any possible lunar disease hazards.

title: Harry F. Kelly, Former Governor And Judge in Michigan, Is Dead
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (UPI)  Harry F. Kelly, who served as Governor of Michigan during World War II and then spent 17 years as a member of the Michigan Su preme Court, died here last night after suffering a stroke Friday. He was 75 years old.

title: DR. WILLIAM WACKER JR.
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Feb. 9Dr. William F. Wacker Jr., a physician here for 36 years, died yesterday at the Elizabeth General Hospital after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived here at 1224 Salem Avenue. He retired four years ago.

title: Dartmouth Six Wins, 32
description: HANOVER. Feb. 10 Mike Turner's power play goal at 16:59 of the third period, his second of the period, sent Dartmouth to a 3.2 victory over St. Lawrence in hockey at Davis Rink tonight.

title: EARNINGS INCREASE LISTED BY G.M.A.C.
description: General Motors Acceptance Corporation consolidated net income for 1970 totaled $68, 233,621, compared with $47, 160,332 the year before, the company reported yesterday Results include a lax credit re lated to the operations of its subsidiary, Motors Insurance Corporation, amounting to $2,497,767.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESTON H. KELSEY
description: RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif., Feb. 10  Preston H. Kelsey, retired president for Pacific Northwest operations of Marsh & McLennan, Inc., national insurance brokers, died today in Scripps Memorial Hospital, La Jolla. He was 67 years old.

title: Soviet Ships Near Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today the arrival of three Soviet naval vessels in Cuban waters but refused to discuss any details.

title: EDWARD J. TAYLOR
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10  Edward J. Taylor, a public accountant, formerly vice presi dent in charge of finance for Arnold Bakers, Inc.. and earlier with Lybrand Ross Bros. & Montgomery, accountants, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 316 Eastchester Road.

title: Persistence Pays Off in Championship
description: News of Dogs

title: CHURCH OPPOSING MINING PROJECT
description: The Episcopal Church has submitted proxy resolutions to the Securities and Exchange Commission in an attempt to delay a Puerto Rican copper mining project by two United States companies.

title: Warriors Down Sonics
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10 (UPI) Nick Jones, a reserve guard, scored a careerhigh 28 points tonight and sparked the San Francisco Warriors to a 133122 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: U.S. Recalls C.I.A. Chief in Costa Rica
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The United States is quietly withdrawing from Costa Rica Earl J. Williamson, its Central Intelligence Agency station chief there, in a compromise move to placate President Jos Figueres Ferrer.

title: FIRST LOCAL DRIVE SLATED FOR FILION
description: YONKERS, Feb. 10  Fresh from an icefishing vacation in northern Canada, Herve Filion, the world champion harness racing driver, is set to make his first drive of 1971 in this country. The 30yearold Filion, of Angers, Quebec, will be in the sulky behind Mountain Pride N. in tomorrow night's fea tured handicap onemile Mid dletown Trot at Yonkers Race way.

title: Earthquake Measurer Charles Francis Richter
description: Man in the News

title: Four Last Songs Is Given Premiere By Bejart Troupe
description: The aggressively modernist Ballet of The Twentieth Cen tury took a modest and charming step backward into the sensibility of the 19th, Tuesday evening, presenting Maurice Bejart's lyrical mood ballet Four Last Songs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Miss Horne Sings Troyens Scenes
description: New York has never seen a staged performance of Berlioz's Vergilian epic Les Troyens, but judging from the revivalist tremor in the air it should not be long be fore someone gives us the fourhour opera in full. London's Covent Garden mounted the Berlioz com plete and in French in 1969, which improved prospects elsewhere, and since then leading singers have been getting in their bids for favorite roles.

title: MRS. EDITH MARZANI OF ANTIWAR WOMEN
description: Mrs. Edith Eisner Marzani, former wife of Carl A. Marzani, the leftist writer, film director and publisher, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, Tuesday at her home, 312 West 87th Street. She was 56 years old.

title: C.A.B. Chief Sees AirlineFare Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, indicated today that a general increase in airline fares was coming soon. At the same time he dampened the air line industry's hope of broad er regulatory relief.

title: Margaret and 1,000 at Barbados Fete
description: ST. JAMES, Barbados, Feb. 10 Princess Margaret emerged briefly from her cocoon of privacy last night to attend a charity dance held at Hold ers House, a 325yearold for mer plantation house owned by Mrs. Janet Kidd, daughter of Lord Beaverbrook, the late British publisher.

title: TRUSTEES MAKE BIDS FOR RAILROAD FUNDS
description: The trustees of two carriers in reorganization, the Boston & Maine and the Central Rail road of New Jersey, are taking steps to get the Transportation Department's guarantee of $10 million of trustee certificates for each line.

title: L.I. Youth, 16, Wins Suit on Auto License
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 10  A 16yearold boy who acted as his own attorney in State Supreme Court to challenge a restriction that prohibits hold ers of junior operators' licenses from driving in Nassau County won his case today.

title: Julie Holmes Holds Lead In PreOlympics Skating
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 10 (AP)Julie Holmes captured the compulsory figure phase of the women's figure skating corn petitoin today and was within reach of America's first gold medal of the preOlympic win ter sports festival.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: When does a hunter miss his duck but eventually kill a bird with the same shot? He does this when a few of the spent pellets from his gun are taken into the digestive system of a feeding duck, which then dies of lead, poi soning.

title: Mills Demands a Revision Of Welfare Reform Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 President Nixon's latest welfare reform plan has been before the new Congress for less than a month, and it already is in seri ous trouble.

title: Soviet Accuses U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 10The So viet Union accused the United States today of undermining the Big Four talks on the Mid dle East by its support of Is raeli positions.

title: Knicks Drop Fifth in a Row, 10699
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 10  The Knickerbockers lost their fifth successive game, the longest streak of Red Holzman's New York coaching career, but more importantly, they lost Willis Reed for five days as they dropped a 106.99 decision to the Buffalo Braves tonight.

title: Suspended Welfare Aide Says He Acted Properly on Waldorf
description: The welfare worker sus pended from the Department of Social Services for helping to place a welfare family in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel testi fied yesterday that he had fol lowed all department proce dures before receiving his superiors'; approval to book the family there.

title: Film:
description: After most recent films, good as well as bad, Howard Hawks's Rio Lobo, which opened yesterday at neigh borhood theaters, comes al most as a reminder of what moviemaking is all about. With only one viewing, I'm notsure it is a great movie, or even the best of Hawks. But it relates (and refers) to the best of Hawksespecial ly Rio Bravo (1959) and El Dorado (1966)and I suspect that it is close enough to greatness to stand above everything else so far in the current season.

title: Greenberg Play to Bow
description: Stanley R. Greenberg's new play, Pueblo, dealing with the: capture of the U.S.S. Pueblo off the coast of North Korea, will be produced at the Arena Theater in Washington, March 3 through April 4.

title: INQUIRY IS PURSUED ON SLAIN EXECUTIVE
description: Detectives investigating the fatal shooting Tuesday of an advertising executive at the doorway of his upper East Side townhouse were not able yes terday to ascertain whether the shot was fired from a hand gun or a rifle.

title: First Test for Local Rule
description: A major question raised by President Nixon's proposal that the Federal Government give $5 billion without strings to the states and localities is whether the extra money will go where it is needed most.

title: Report on Rise in Ski Injuries Is Disputed by Area Operators
description: News of Skiing

title: ST. PETER'S SINKS MANHATTAN, 8785
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10  Ed Cierski's two free throws with 13 seconds remaining broke an 8585 tie and earned St. Peter's College a 8785 victory over Manhattan College tonight be fore 1,882 at the Jersey City Armory.

title: Mayor Elected After 2 Ties
description: SCRANTON, S. C., Feb. 10 (AP)Ray DuBose, a Republi can, was elected Mayor yester day, 155 to 114, after two dead locked elections. Mr. DuBose and John G. Singletary tied, 86 to 86, in their first contest last Oct. 6. On Oct. 20, the two men tied again, 93 to 93. After a recount, Mr. DuBose had 94 votes to Mr. Singletary's 93. However, a contested ballot was ruled legal, it counted for Mr. Singletary and the results were tied again, 94 to 94.

title: EXAIDE TO DR. KING SEEKS DALEY'S JOB
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 10The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a former aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was granted a leave of absence today from the South ern Christian Leadership Con ference to run as an independ ent for Mayor of Chicago.

title: Ethel Linder Reiner, 65, Dies; Producer on Broadway in 50's
description: Ethel Linder Reiner, a Broad way producer in the nineteen fifties, died last Monday in Barbados after a long illness. She was 65 years old.

title: The Six Off Dead Center...
description: Once again the Common Market Six have pulled them selves together to break the stalemate and regain some momentum along the road to integration and union Western Europe. The first step will be modest but is designed to generate additional progress, the final goal being monetary union and a single currency area by 1980.

title: JOSEPH SPELIVIAN, PATHOLOGIST, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10  Dr. Joseph W. Spelman, this city's medical examiner for 15 years, died last night in Jef ferson Hospital. He was 52 years old.

title: DELISTING OF STOCK IS STAYED BY COURT
description: The Federal Court in Phila delphia yesterday granted a temporary restraining order prohibiting the New York Stock Exchange from taking any steps to delist the stock of Scientific Resources Corporation.

title: Rockets Fired Into Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia Thurs day, Feb. 11 (AP)  Enemy gunners fired at least four roc kets into Pnompenh and its outskirts early today and also attacked the nearby Cambo dian Navy headquarters on the Mekong River, a Cambodian spokesman said. The attackers were reportedly beaten back after an allnight battle.

title: Screen: Benedek's 'The Night Visitor'
description: As a tense how-was-it-done, "The Night Visitor" is an uncommonly fascinating film shot in beautiful color against authentic wintry Swedish and Danish backgrounds. But the English-language import that arrived at the Cinema Rendezvous and R.K.O. twin theaters yesterday, which obviously also was meant as an exploration in depth of murderous, abnormal psychology, is sadly, somewhat less than an incisive probing of the hearts and minds of its driven principals.Laslo Benedek's task of directing a mountingly suspenseful tale is made fairly smooth by the professionalism of such Scandinavian stalwarts as Max Von Sydow, Liv Ullmann and Per Oscarsson and Britain's Trevor Howard. A viewer is caught up at the outset in brooding mystery as the scantily clothed Von Sydow approaches a farmhouse across a snowy landscape, kills two young women and then, just as stealthily, sneaks off into the night.It is not ungallant to note that he has escaped from an asylum to wreak revenge on the people he is convinced framed him into the asylum on false charges of murder. It also is fair to indicate that his victims are his sister, Hanne Bork and his girl, Lottie Freddie. And, it's right to note that he makes a second, vengeful sortie to eliminate a lawyer, Rupert Davies, another sister, Liv Ullmann, and implicate her frantic doctor-husband, Per Oscarsson, before detective inspector Trevor Howard arrives at a surprising denouncement.However, the motivations for all the machinations and Gothic horrors are merely touched on and hinted at but not made especially convincing in the convoluted goings-on. But the methods of madness are the thing here. The classic enigma of the locked cell and how our designing killer manages to escape and return to it in that towering, fortress-like asylum does make for gripping melodrama.Under Laslo Benedek's workmanlike direction, an observer is soon aware that his cast is properly reacting to varied stresses but that Max Von Sydow and Liv Ullmann are not involved in trenchant, philosophical upheavals as they've previously been in Ingmar Bergman's "Shame" and "Hour of the Wolf." But they, as well as Per Oscarsson and Trevor Howard give taut but controlled performances that underline the tensions that make "The Night Visitor" a captivating, moody and scenic thriller.

title: General Dynamics Moving Headquarters Out of City
description: The General Dynamics Cor poration, the 33d largest indus trial concern in the country, announced yesterday that it would move its national head quarters from New York City to St. Louis by this summer.

title: Democratic Rivals Agree Not to Feud In Presidency Bids
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The major Democratic Presidential contenders agreed at a meet ing last night, in the interests of party unity, to refrain from attacking one another, Law rence F. O'Brien, the putty chairman, said today.

title: School Coach Makes Shift
description: CANYON, Tex., Feb. 10 (AP) Gene Mayfield, who said he had often wondered if he could be as successful on the college level as he was at Odessa Permian High School, was named athletic director and head football coach at West Texas State University today.

title: DEATHS RISE TO 51 IN QUAKE ON COAST; CLEANUP STARTED
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10The list of dead in yesterday's ma jor earthquake rose to 51 today as the Los Angeles area began pulling itself together.

title: Writers Attack Censorship of TV Scene
description: The first major test of a Joint effort by Hollywood pro ducers and writers to curb cen sorship on television has ended in a draw, with a tie vote of 33 on whether a white man lawyer and a black girl lawyer should be shown socializing at a bar.

title: Soviet Track Team Arrives For 3Meet Tour of U.S.
description: A Soviet indoor track team, scheduled to compete in three United States meets, arrived in New York last night.

title: Rosewall Is Upset by Davidson in First Round of Philadelphia Open Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 Ken Rosewall, who will receive a gold racquet as the 1970 ten nis player of the year tomorrow afternoon, was upset tonight by Owen Davidson in the opening round of the $62,500 Philadel phia international indoor open championships.

title: Eurodollar Borrowings Off
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (Reu ters)  Eurodollar borrowings by United States banks from their foreign branches dropped $138million in the week ended Feb. 3, bringing liabilities out standing to 36.399billion, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: G.I.'s Report Fighting
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Some United States soldiers belonging to Troop D, Seventh Battalion, 17th Air Cavalry, said here today that 100 or more Amer ican ground troops had been in Laos during the last three days and had fought the Com munists, but United States spokesmen denied that any American ground forces were in Laos.

title: RADICALS ASSAILED BY MRS. MITCHELL
description: Mrs. John N. Mitchell thinks anyone who advocates violent revolution in the United States should be shipped off to Cuba on the next plane.

title: JAMES R. C. HARDY
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Feb. 10James Ramsay Gor don Hardy, a retired electrical sales engineer for the Nickel Cadmium Battery Company, died today at his home. He was 68 years old and lived on Sunset Road.

title: Two Assistants Named
description: AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 10 (UPI)Two new assistants, in eluding the head coach at Union College in Schenectady, N. Y., were added to Dick MacPher son's football staff at the Uni versity of Massachusetts today.

title: City Agency Scored on Ski Trips for Slum Children
description: The Federal Government has advised the South Bronx Model Cities agency to stop sending slum children to luxury ski resorts.

title: Troops Frisky as They Entered Laos
description: Th following account was given by Nguyen Ngoc Luong, a Vietnamese part time correspondent of The New York Times who ac companied South Vietnamese troops into Laos.

title: WEATHER BESETS FLORIDA ORANGES
description: In commodity futures trad ing, the weather is often good for an argument. Recently the Florida orange crop has been the subject of much discussion as to how much it has been Zipped by frost.

title: Barnard Raises Tuition
description: The trustees of Barnard Col lege voted yesterday to in crease tuition and other fees from the current $2,300 to no more than $2,550 for the 1971 72 academic year. The tuition rise is $200.

title: CAMBODIAN CHIEF SUFFERS A STROKE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 10  Premier Lon Nol suf fered a stroke Monday that par alyzed half his body, reliable sources close to the Cambodian Government said today. An of ficial statement said he had been ordered to stop all activi ties for medical reasons.

title: Countess Ethelyn d'Esternaux, Diplomat's Widow, Dies at 92
description: Countess Ethelyn d'Ester naux, painter and poet, died Sunday at her home, 140 West 57th Street. She was 92 years old, the widow of Count Fre deric d'Esternaux, a diplomat and banker.

title: Ad Sign Change Ordered
description: The giant $1 and the much smaller .99 used on signs in store windows and advertise ments to indicate that the cost of an item is $1.99, will disap pear under a regulation issued yesterday by Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson Grant. the new rule requires that price endings. the tech nical term for the cents that an item costs, must now be print ed in numbers at least half as high and half as broad as the dollars.

title: Eban Bids Cairo Consider Israeli Position Carefully
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 10 Foreign Minister Abba Eban called on the Egyptian leader ship today to consider care fully the possible openings pre sented by Premier Golda Meir yesterday in a speech that sug gested a relaxation of the mili tary confrontation along the Suez Canal.

title: Market Place: Another View Of the Budget
description: Sam I. Nakagama is teach ing Economics I in his weekly letter prepared for the Argus Research Corporation and in it he chides the press for what he believes to be mis interpretations of President Nixon's fiscal 1972 Budget and Economic Report.

title: More Blacks in Suburbs, but Ratio Stays Stable
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10A growing number of blacks moved to the suburbs in the nineteensixties, but the largely white character of the suburbs was maintained by a huge si multaneous movement of whites there, a 1970 census report dis closed today.

title: FREDRIC M. LEGLER
description: Fredric Mills Legler of South bury, Conn., a former New York advertising man and more recently vice president of Lind blad Travel. Inc.. here, died Tuesday in Waterbury (Conn.) Hospital. His age was 77.

title: John D. Archbold Will Marry Mrs. Phoebe W. van Beuren
description: Mrs. Phoebe Wildman van Beuren and John D. Arch bold, the sportsman and Standard Oil heir, plan to be married, but have not yet set the date for their wedding.

title: Mills Expects Bid to Raise U.S. Debt Ceiling $40Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The Administration is expect ed to ask for a $40billion in crease in the national debt ceil ing, to a total of $435billion, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said to day.

title: $1Billion More for Housing Sought in Ryan Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Representative Wil liam F. Ryan, Democrat of Man hattan, introduced legislation today that would pump nearly $1billion more into five Fed eral programs affecting hous ing.

title: NICHOLAS CAPUTO, A PROSECUTOR, 46
description: Nicholas J. Caputo, Queens assistant district attorney head ing the Criminal Courts bureau, died apparently of a heart at tack yesterday as he was leav ing the County Executive Building. He was 46 years old and lived at 18403 90th Ave nue, Jamaica, Queens.

title: Laotian General Said to Ask for Reinforcements
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10 Concern increased here today over the situation at Sam Thong and Long Tieng, the two im portant Governrinent positions southwest of Plaine des Janes that have come under inereas ing pressure from North Viet namese and Laotian Communist forces.

title: Layoffs at Lockheed
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration announced yesterday it was laying off up to 6,500 employes as a result of the financial collapse of Rolls Royce, Ltd., and the British concern's inability to make scheduled deliveries of engines for Lockheed's new airbus.

title: WEEKENDERS WAIT FOURDAY SPECIAL
description: A fourday holiday weekend, created by changes in Federal and state laws, La beckoning New Yorkers by the thousands to warm resorts; snowlayered slopes and as far away as Europe.

title: OffStage Role for Betsy Palmer: Star of Simpatico Kitchen
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J.Do you entertain theater peo ple? a visitor asked Betsy Palmer, the actress, over a cup of hot tea. I'll cook for anybody, she said and laughed, looking radiant. Betsy Palmer always looks radiant. Just before noon she made a quickly cooked dish, shrimp ginger and oyster sauce with garlic and parsley. In the course of the morning three cats ran in and out of the kitchen, a collie named Lady barked at anything that moved in the kitchen, there were two or three friends making small talk and the garage man stopped by to pick up an automobile that had skidded on the ice and suffered a broken axle. And through it all the lady maintained her smiling com posure.

title: Potato Crop Cuts Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department recommended today that acre ages for 1971 late summer and fall crop potatoes be cut 6 per cent and 9 per cent respectively from last year. It suggested that growers plant 1,012,720 acres for fall harvest and 118, 055 acres for late summer har vest.

title: Advertising:
description: Over the years as Doyle Dane Bernbach's reputation for creative advertising grew ever larger, a favorite con versational ploy among greeneyed cats in ad alley has been: Sure they do all right with things like Volkswagen and Polaroid that sell themselves, or institutional stuff like American Airlines and Avis. But they can't sell package goods.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Most of Gain Put to NewCar Volume
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Retail sales, seasonally adjust ed, rose about $300million in January on the basis of pre liminary estimates, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: 3 Dead and 1 Missing Alter a Fire in Newark
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10Three persons died and at least one was missing as the result of earlymorning explosions and fire in a small chemical con cern in the city's Ironbound district.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Shepard Becomes First Astronaut to Have Gained Weight in Space
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 10  Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr.. the com mander of the Apollo 14 mis sion, has become the first man to gain weight while in space.

title: KENNEDY ASSAILS MITCHELL ON GUNS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Senator Edward M. Kennedy today accused Attorney General John N. Mitchell of washing your hands of responsibilty Pot gun control at a time when the Senator said a lack of Fed eral action was encouraging crime and violence in the na tion's cities.

title: Trapped Ships Rusting in Suez Canal
description: ISMAILIA, United Arab Re public, Feb. 10 (AP)While Egyptian and Israeli diplomats issue statements about the fu ture of the Suez Canal, rust and salt are eating away at the 14 foreign ships stranded in the waterway since the outbreak of the sixday war in June, 1967.

title: CAHILL PROMISES NO 1971 TAX RISE
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10  Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he would not recommend any new or increased taxes in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature next Tues day.

title: Controlling Ship Traffic
description: The impending collision of two oil tankers near the Golden Gate Bridge recently was spotted on the screen of an experimental shorebased radar but could not be averted because officials on shore were unable to contact the bridge of one of the vessels involved.

title: 1970 Decline Is 8%
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation report ed yesterday an 8 per cent decline in 1970 net income despite a gain of 5 per cent in combined revenues and sales.

title: Alex Bernstein Dies at 91, Led Fur Trade Foundation
description: Alex A. Bernstein, a retired fur dealer who was a founder and for many years president of the Fur Trade Foundation, died Tuesday at his home, 110 East 87th Street. His age was 91.

title: FISHER TO RETIRE FROM THE TINES
description: Andrew Fisher, one of three executive vice presidents of The New York Times, announced yesterday that he would retire from the company, effective March 1, to seek a new and different career.

title: House Democratic Chiefs Ask WagePrice Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)  The House Democratic leadership urged President Nix on today to freeze wages and prices immediately to curb in flation.

title: Hialeah Sweep for Vasquez
description: MIAMI, Feb. 10Jacinto Vas quez, the leading rider at New York tracks last year, is only second best at Hialeah this winter and he will start a five day suspension on Friday. But he was the leading figure at Hialeah today as he won both halves of the $50,250 Columbi ana Handicap for fillies with a versatile riding exhibition.

title: Public Service and Private Law
description: A few key members of the Lindsay administration, although paid well from the public treasury, risk com promising the public interest by engaging in the private practice of law. There may even be a violation of the City Charter in this dual role.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Wiretapping and bugging now ap pear to be the wave of the future in American law enforcement, and all those who think the resulting dimi nution of personal privacy and indi vidual liberty is a good thing should stand up and cheer the American Bar Association.

title: Detroit Trial Delayed
description: DETROIT, Feb. 10 (AP)The conspiracy trial of three mem bers of the radical White Pan ther party has been postponed indefinitely, pending the out come of a Government appeal on a wiretapping ruling. The defendants, John S. Sinclair, Lawrence R. Plamondon and John W. Forest, were to have gone on trial yesterday on charges of conspiring to dyna mite a Central Intelligence Agency office in Ann Arbor in September, 1968.

title: MAIL ORDER UNITS ACCUSED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  The Federal Trade Commission accused two of the country's largest mail order houses today of violating the TruthinLend ifig Act.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethiopian Seeks U.N. Post
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  Endalkachew Makonnen, an Ethiopian who hopes to succeed Secretary General Thant at the United Nations, said today that he planned a series of worldwide visits seeking support. Mr. Makonnen, who is 44 years old, was twice President of the Security Council.

title: Weight Is Thrown 63
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 10 Doug Greenwood, a Princeton sophomore, threw the 35pound weight 63 feet  inches, the best effort in college competi tion this season to help Prince ton's track team beat Rutgers, 7048, tonight at Jadw Gym nasium.

title: LAWMAKERS SEE NO WELFARE RISE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10  The chairmen of the Legislature's two welfare committees ex pressed doubt today that a cost ofliving increase for welfare recipients, totaling $26.9million would be enacted this year by lawmakers eager to whittle away at a request by Governor Rockefeller for $1.1billion in new taxes.

title: JERSEY IS WARNED ON LEGAL CASINOS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 10William F. Hyland, former chairman of the New Jersey State Commis sion on Investigation, testified today that organized crime was plotting to infiltrate gambling casinos if the latter were legal ized in Atlantic City.

title: Beholdl! Signs Cast
description: Diana Sands, Robert Hooks and Earle Hyman have been signed as costars of Behold! Cometh the Vanderkellans, the William Wellington Mackey play, opening March 24 at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Rutgers, W. Va. To Play Tonight On Garden Bill
description: West Virginia's tall band of running and shooting Mountain eers will challenge Rutgers hopes for a postseason tourna ment bid in the second half of the college doubleheader at Madison. Square Garden tonight.

title: CANDIDATE'S NEPHEW ARRESTED IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 10 The police arrested a 15year old nephew of the opposition presidential candidate Kim Dae Jung, today, on charges of set ting off a homemade toy bomb at Mr. Kim's residence here two weeks ago.

title: Indictment Quashed In Fire Fatal to 11 In Brooklyn Home
description: At the most, the deaths were noncriminal homicides re sulting from an unfortunate ac cident, he said.

title: Chilean Senate Gives Allende Power To Nationalize U.S. Copper Interests
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 10 The Chilean Senate approved constitutional amendment to day giving President Salvador Allende Gossens wide powers to nationalize United States in terests in copper, Chile's main industry.

title: Chess:

Larsen scored 10 4 in the 16man round rob in. The significance of this triumph was evident from the partial list of grandmas ters who competed:

title: Evacuated From Area of Endangered Dam, 80,000 Wait to Hear They Can Return
description: GRANADA HILLS, Calif., Feb. 10  For the 80,000 per sons evacuated from 20 square miles of pleasant suburban neighborhoods below the linger ing threat of an earthquake damaged dam, there is nothing to do but wait.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: Penguins Stop Flyers, 53
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 10 (UPI)  The Pittsburgh Penguins scored four goals in the first period, including Greg Polis's 17th of the season, to beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 53, in a National Hockey League game tonight. Polis's goal broke the club record for goals by a first year player set two seasons ago by Jean Pronovost.

title: Assembly Democrats Propose State Health Insurance for All
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10Demo cratic members of the Assembly today proposed a comprehen sive health insurance plan to cover virtually every resident of the state and to provide better health care for less cost.

title: ALDER CONNERY, 72, OF WESTERN UNION
description: FREEPORT, L. L. Feb. 10 Alder F. Connery, an inventor who retired in 1965 as an en gineering executive of the Western Union Telegraph Com pany, died yesterday at his home. He was 72 years old and lived here at 164 Garfield Street.

description: PARIS, Feb. 10Any possi bility of serious negotiation at the Vietnam peace talks has apparently been written off for the next few months by the United States.

description: Mrs. Teresa Schwab Wood Gray, widow of Austen Gray, a stockbroker, died yesterday at her home, 485 Park Avenue.

description: MOSCOW, Thursday, Feb. 11 (AP)The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union signed a treaty today ban ning nuclear weapons and other instruments of mass destruction from seabeds and ocean floors.

description: LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP)Two girls who went to work in hot pants were in N hot water today for raising male tern peratures and lowering the production of British cars and cookies.
