description: Preliminary study of the earthquake that struck north of Los Angeles Tuesday, killing several dozen persons has led specialists to suspect that the (chances of a truly catastrophic quake, in the area are as great as ever.

title: SHIFTS UNLIKELY IN ABORTION LAW
description: ALBANY, Feb. 10  New York new abortion law, the most permissive in the country, appears virtually sure to re main basically intact this year, despite efforts by some up state legislators to amend at.

title: Down 5% for Year
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company the nation's largest lumber pro ducer and a major factor in the pulp, paperboard and con tainer fields, had record sales in 1970 but a 5 per cent de cline in earnings. It showed the best performance of any major forest products company last year. Fourthquarter profits fell 15 per cent, the Tacoma, Wash ington, based company reported yesterday.

title: MRS. EDWARD EHLERS
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Feb. 10  Mrs. Mary Rogers Ehlers, widow of Dr. Edward C. Ehlers, a physician, died yesterday at her home after a short illness. She was 87 years old and lived at 23 King Street.

description: The New York Stock Ex change issued a report yester day showing that financial in stitutions had more than tripled their memberships on regional exchanges in less than two years and that these exchanges were increasing their share of trad ing in Big Board stocks.

But to those interested in official activities it became plain by midmorning that Government offices, instead of opening late, were not opening at all.

description: SAIGON, Feb. 10 (AP) South Vietnamese sources re ported that after the task force reached Tchepone today engi neers began rebuilding the town's abandoned dirt airstrip, which will enable the South Vietnamese to fly in supplies and reinforcements.

description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  Ni geria and Communist China have agreed to establish diplo matic relations at the ambas sadorial level, the Government announced today, noting that it had recognized the Govern ment in Peking as the sole legal representative of the Chinese people.

title: Miss Curtin Sings in Copland Concert
description: Aaron Copland, who was 70 years old on Nov. 14. went through a round of birthday concerts in a few weeks that, for this season at least, were outnumbered only by Beethoven's. A kind of postcript was added to those concerts at Hunter College Playhouse Tuesday night, with a program devoted to Mr. Copland's vocal music.

title: MRS. WALTER M. DEAR
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10Mrs. Maud Fuller Dear, widow of Walter M. Dear, who was pub lisher of The Jersey Journal and president of the American Newspaper Publishers Associa tion, died yesterday in her sleep. She was 96 years old.

title: 'Wild Country' and Western Pioneers
description: That good old reliable, the Walt Disney organization, has done it again, quietly and commendably, with a wholesome, sturdily old-fashioned film of a Western pioneer family titled "The Wild Country." The picture is excellent viewing for children up to about 11 years old, in a jet age that wastes little time and film footage on the youngsters.Photographed in color amidst a magnificent sweep of primitive, southwest Wyoming, the picture is a good bit more than a pretty, pat formula exercise of pioneer survival. The family quartet from Pittsburgh, including Steve Forrest, Vera Miles, young Ronny Howard and little Clint Howard, are winning folks of estimable character and grit.Under Robert Totten's able direction, the gentle, warm tone of the story is seasoned with some healthy, unflinching realism, most of it pegged to a maniacally mean neighbor. Typical are the wondering expressions of the two boys when exposed, with the audience, to the foaling of a mare.The neatly sensible screenplay is further enhanced by a few sideline performances, especially Jack Elam as a burly family friend. All told, the picture is hard to resist on its own plain, simple terms, doggedly concerned with such matters as family love, true grit and legal justice. The Disney people, like the ones we see here, have something.

title: SQUEEZE ON CASH SEEN AT LOCKHEED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has only enough cash for sev eral more weeks of operations on its new L1011 Tristar air liner and its other commercial programs, according to well placed members of the banking community.

description: The Caribbean, previously thought to be an ancient and wayward piece of the Pacific Ocean, now appears to be far more youthful, and possibly a byproduct of the rupture be tween the Americas and Africa.

They flashed through the split sides of the brown and white skirt with the gray chiffon shirt. Mrs. Childs leaned for ward in her seat, deliberately flipped up the skirt so every one could see the shorts and let out a long, cool whistle. Can you imagine? At Mainbocher.

description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 10 Mayor Lindsay of New York met here today with H. Lee Dennison, the Suffolk County Executive, to discuss a variety of regional problems, particu larly welfare costs.

title: Sports of The Times A Little Rusted Up
description: I never figured I'd be some kind of symbol. Well, if I was, I had to admit I was a little rusted up. You get rusted when you got to come all the way from the slums of Mobile, Ala., from hiding from truant officers and cops, from reform school. And while I was coming all that way, I guess I'd been a lot of things people said I wasa no good kid, a guy who left his team when money looked better some place else, a chaser. I'd been those things, but I'd also been a fine pitcherone of the best. The event that stimulated those thoughts, which are from Satchel Paige's 1961 autobiography, May be I'll Pitch Forever, was his promotion in 1948 to the major leagues. In an action The Sporting News called a publicity stunt, Bill Veeck signed Paige to a Cleveland Indian contract, and the 42yearold super star pitcher of the Negro leagues offered all America what was left of his bloop ers, loopers and droopers, his jumpballs, screwballs, wobbly balls, hurryup balls, nothin' balls and bat badgers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Some Girls Do' Arrives at the Victoria
description: There's a gaggle of gorgeous lovelies who could be enlivening Playboy centerfolds in "Some Girls Do," a British pseudo-comic adventure made in 1968 that turned up yesterday at the Victoria as the associate attraction to the revived "Irma La Douce." Perhaps "Irma" needs help at this point but this addlepated distant cousin of James Bond. Our Man Flint and Bulldog Drummond only serves to make an oldie like "Irma" look fairly new.Richard Johnson, the glum Drummond of this mishmash of an intrigue (he also was Drummond in "Deadlier Than the Male" in 1967) is called on to save Britain's supersonic airliner from that scientific dastard James Villiers, his well-stacked aides led by Daliah Lavi and Beba Loncar, and their destructive "infrasonic" gadget.The fact that he swats would-be killers like flies, parachutes to safety, drives a super speedboat and avoids the clutches of a succession of delectable dolls like Sydne Rome simply proves that an imitative spoof not only can be unfunny but also boring. Most of Villiers's robotlike lassies, it's revealed, have been programed through "artificial brains," which sounds logical, considering the script of this limp lampoon.

title: Administration and Senate Open Round on Rights Aid to Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Nixon Administration and the Senate opened a new round today in the battle to provide financial assistance to school districts in the process of inte grating.

title: British Thriller, 'Sudden Terror,' Bows
description: "Sudden Terror," a new British thriller, is an exasperating model of how not to film the fable of the boy who cried wolf, with a killer in hot pursuit and nobody heeding. What ever happened to British restraint? The tone of the film is even more hysterical than the boy, young Mark Lester of "Oliver!" fame.Under John Hough's direction, the picture raucously careens after the sprinting lad, with the nervous color camera all but doing a back flip, plus a blaring score of eerie sounds and spookier rock 'n' roll. Worst of all, the screenplay continually cuts from the boy and his plight to some singularly dull adults, including Lionel Jeffries as his arch grandfather and Susan George and Tony Bonner as a two humdrum young mods. The twitching police inspector, Jeremy Kemp, who needs a psychiatrist himself, is as repulsive as the killer, Peter Vaughan.The picture almost zestfully reaps a harvest of corpses along the way. We counted eight. Exactly one, the first, would have sufficed. Not a note of music was needed.However, the island background of Malta (unspecified) comes over beautifully and intriguingly as the film careens across it. And the graphic opening of the assassination of a visiting President, who rates hardly a backward glance, is truly gripping.Remember Hollywood's 1949 version of the boy who cried wolf called "The Window"? Ah, there's a quiet beauty that still chills to the bone. Catch it on TV.

title: LUDWIG ZIRNER, 64; LED OPERA TROUPE
description: URBANA, Ill., Feb. 10 Lud wig Ernst Zirner, founder and director of the University of Illinois Opera Group, died yes terday at Carle Hospital where he had been a patient for sev eral weeks. He was 64 years old.

title: CON EDISON PUTS INDIAN POINT UNIT BACK IN SERVICE
description: The nuclear power plant whose shutdown nine months ago started a drawnout electri cal power squeeze for New Yorkers has gone back into service, the Consolidated Edi son Company announced yes terday.

title: ECONOMIC POLICIES OF SPAIN GET PRAISE
description: MADRID, Feb. 10The Or ganization for Economic Co operation and Development praised Spain today, for having cooled down an overheated economy without diminishing her rate of growth.

title: Soviet Embassy in Denial

title: Phillips and Renzulli Play Piano Oddities
description: A symphony by Claude Debussy? A symphony? Yes, there is one. He composed it in 1880 for piano four hands. It was intended for Nadejda von Meek, the patroness of Tchaikovsky, for whom De hussy was the house pianist and teacher. Forgotten for many years, the first move ment of the score was discovered in Russia and published in 1933. What happened to the other movements, nobody knows. Whether or not Debussy in tended orchestrating it, no body knows, pursue.

title: Beanie Assails Listing of Plans Before City Has Cash Available
description: The city's chief financial of ficer and the city's top plan ners disagreed yesterday over a matter of an elusive $5bil lion.

title: Apollo 15 Will See Bit of Everything
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 10On America's next mission to the moon, scheduled for July, Apollo astronauts plan to ex plore in 66 hours just about every type of known lunar featurea towering mountain range, volcanic hills, craters in a relatively new plain and a 600footdeep canyon.

title: Chase Auction Attempt Blocked On Parsons Detroit Bank Stock
description: DETROIT, Feb. 10 The crumpled banking empire of Donald H. Parsons ended be fore Federal bankruptcy ref erees today, who stopped the Chase Manhattan Bank from attempting to auction Mr. Par sons's loan collateral, several million shares of Detroit's Bank of the Commonwealth stock.

title: Chile Denies Curbing Press
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 10 (Reuters)  President Salvador Allende Gossens said last night that he had sent a telegraph to the president of the Interamer ican Press Association  Julio Mezquita Neto, publisher of the Brazilian newspaper O Estado of Sao Paulo  denying a charge by the association's Freedom of the Press Commit tee that his leftwing govern ment was restricting the press in Chile.

title: Speaks to Businessmen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 Officers of more than 200 major industries were assured by President Nixon today that they would not be made scapegoats of the drive for cleaner air and water.

title: M'GOVERN CHARGES HOOVER CONTEMPT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI)  Senator George S. Mc Govern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that J. Ed gar Hoover should be held in contempt of Congress for re fusing to give information on a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent and then disclosing details of the case in a Georgia newspaper.

title: MARKET PAUSES TO CATCH BREATH
description: The stock market caught its breath yesterday as prices mostly declined in the slowest trading in almost two weeks.

title: Congressman Breaks Arm
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) Representative Dante B. Fas cell, Democrat of Florida, fell and broke his right amt Mon day during a workout in the House of Representatives gym nasium, his press aide said today.

title: F.C.C. REVIVES STUDY ON STATION OWNERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10The Federal Communications Com mission revived and expanded today a inquiry into broadcast ownership.

title: Public Network to Carry William Buckley Program
description: Firing Line, the interview program with William F. Buck ley, will move from commercial syndication to the Public Broad casting Service noncommercial network in May. The announce ment was made jointly by P.B.S., the Corporation for Pub lic Broadcasting, The National Review, of which Mr. Buckley is editor, and the Southern Edu cational Communications Asso ciation producing agency for Firing Line.

title: Ashe Applies Again to Play in South African Open
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 Arthur Ashe confirmed to night that he had applied again for a visa to play in the South African open ten nis championships in April. But he declined to comment as to his reasons except to say, You weigh everything.

title: Houthakker Defends Figure for G.N.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Council of Economic Ad visers fully expects the gross national product this year to attain approximately the target figure of $1,065billion and the figure was not imposed on the council for political rea sons, a member of the group said today.

title: PENNSY TRUSTEES CITE LABOR COSTS
description: The trustees of the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company yesterday told the Federal Dis trict Court in Philadelphia: The rationalizing of employment, and labor relations policies and costs is the most critical single condition to making the rail road viable and permitting its reorganization.

title: KOSYGIN ASSURES BRANDT ON POLIC
description: BONN, Feb. 10  ??ier Aleksei N. Kosygin has assured Chancellor Willy Brandt that the Soviet Union remains in terested in improving its rela tions with West Germany.

title: Computers Help Hospitals In City to Cut Their Costs
description: New York City hospitals, plagued with cost problems and understaffing, are in creasingly relying on the use of computers in major areas of medical care.

title: Zumwalt Says Navy Plans to Develop Hydrofoil and AirCushion Craft Faster Than Existing Vessels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 The Navy plans to develop hy drofoils and craft capable of riding over land or sea on a cushion of forced air at speeds two to three times as fast as any existing naval craft.

title: PACT NOW LIKELY ON MIDEAST'S OIL
description: PARIS, Feb. 10  There were growing signs today that the Middle Eastern oil dispute would be settled  at a price that would mean bigger fuel bills for Western Europe and Japan.

title: Rangers Beat North Stars, 43, as Irvine Gets Two Goals and Two Assists
66 by Fleckman Leads Bob Hope Golf by Stroke
description: PALM SPRINGS. Calif., Feb. 10 (AP)  Marty Fleckman carded a sixunderpar 66 for a, onestroke lead over Arnold Palmer in the first round today of the fiveday. 90hole Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: Moon Instruments Called Undamaged By Lunar Eclipse
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 10Scien tific instruments left on the moon by Apollo astronauts sur vived without any apparent damage despite the sudden and sharp drop in surface tempera tures as a result of this morn ing's lunar eclipse.

title: South Carolina Electric Sets $500Million Complex
description: The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company will, announce today at Columbia, S. C., plans for a $500million power com plex on the Broad River near Parr. S. C.

title: Toward a Better Environment
description: WASHINGTONAs we read about, live through, and see one environmen tal crisis after another, perhaps the most difficult task facing each of us is to put the environmental picture into perspective.

title: City Wants to Redeploy Sanitationmen for Efficiency
description: City environmental offi cials are trying in negotia tions now going on to im prove garbage collection by changing the deployment of sanitationmen, which they believe shortchanges both labor and management.

title: St. Joseph's Wins, 9869
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 10 St. Joseph's defeated Hofstra, 9869, tonight as Mike Bantam scored 25 points and added IS rebounds.

title: The Old Church Scene (R.C.)
description: It was a great scene, the oldchurch scene. (R.C.); I wouldn't want to have missed it for anything. Not that I hanker after it, as some still do with longing laments for bingo and food chiseling in Lent, for churchings and car blessings. That world had to go, and the people who sent it off did so not because they didn't love it but because they saw, or thought they saw something better. That world is dead; dead it should be. Which doesn't mean one can't look back nostalgically.

title: GERMANTRAINWRECK LAID TO HIGH SPEED
description: KAUFBEUREN, Germany, Feb. 10 (AP) A state prosecutor today blamed excessive speed on a curve for the derailment of the MunichZurich express, which caused one of the worst train wrecks in West German history.

title: POLL FINDS BLACKS ARE COOL TO NIXON
description: President Nixon still has had little success in attracting sup port among the nation's Ne groes, a Gallup Poll released in Princeton, N. J., indicated yes terday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stony Brook Downs Queens
description: Stony Brook defeated Queens. 8578, last night at the loser's gym. Stony Brook was led by Rodger Howard's 28 points. Queens erased a 5844 deficit midway in the second half and went ahead, 6766, before Stony Brook took the lead for good.

title: TEACHERS CONTINUE NEW ARK PICKETING
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10Many of Newark's striking teachers continued picketing for the eighth day today despite a threat by the president of the Board of Education that he would personally serve war rants for their arrest.

title: The Queen Elizabeth Sails for a New Life in Orient
description: PORT EVERGLADES, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP)To the roar of a cheering crowd, the once proud ocean liner Queen Elizabeth, rusting and marred by age, sailed slowly into the Atlantic today on a voy age to a new life.

title: Fairmont Remains No. 1
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 11 (AP) Fairmont State of West Vir ginia, unbeaten in 22 games, retained the top spot today in the weekly basketball rankings of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics. Ken tucky State, 171, remained No. 2.

title: Man, 68, Is Found Alive After 2 Days in Debris
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (UPI)  A 68yearold man trapped for two and onehalf days beneath the rubble of the veterans hospital that collapsed in the Los Angeles earthquake was brought out alive today, with only a broken wrist.

title: Deane Ramey, 67, Counsel For 2 Corporations, Dies
description: Deane Ramey, general coun sel for D.H.J. Industries, tex tiles, and Sanitized, Inc., chem icals, died Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 67 years old and also lived in the Milton Harbor House, Rye, N. Y.

title: 3 Operators of Bar In Basement Jailed On U.S. Tax Charge
description: Three operators of an after hours bar called The Sewer were convicted, sentenced and sent to jail late Wednesday night on charges of failure to pay a Federal liquor tax.

title: Money Ease Seen Continuing
description: The Federal Reserve System continued its moderately easy money policy during the last two weeks, banking data pub lished yesterday showed.

title: Palmer, Murphy, Yancey and Hixon Tie for Lead at 138 in Bob Hope Classic
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP)Arnold Palmer man aged only a oneunderpar 71 but moved into a share of first place today in the second round of the $140,000 Bob Hope Des ert Classic golf tournament.

title: Unusual Dinner Honors Aurelio
description: City Hall Notes

title: U.S. Copter Pilots Taking Some of Worst Fire of War
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 11I've been flying for six months, took my first hit yesterday, and since then I've taken 13, said Maj. Burt Al len of Obion, Tenn., as he brought his bulletpierced heli copter in for a safe ??ding here today.

title: Dr. Herman Goodman, 76, Dies; An Authority on Dermatology
description: Dr. Herman Goodman, a der matologist and syphilologist, medical educator and author, died at his home Tuesday after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 18 East 89th Street.

title: Beliveau Gets 500th Goal
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 11 (UPI) Jean Beliveau reached a mile stone in his National Hockey League career tonight with a threegoal scoring effort, giving him 500 goals, as the Montreal Canadiens routed the Minnesota North Stars, 62.

title: BUILDING UNIONS BAR WAGE MOVE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 11 The presidents of the big national construction unions said today that they would put forward no program of their own in response to President Nixon's request that prompt ac tion be taken to end the wage and price spiral in their in dustry.

title: 12 Jailed and Student Shot In Stanford Clash on War
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 11 A high school student was shot, three other persons were injured and at least 12 were arrested last night as several hundred radicals protesting Stanford University's involve ment in the Southeast Asian war clashed with the police.

title: Police Extend the GoodNeighbor Policy
description: It was lunch hour and thousands of persons were walking or driving along Roosevelt Avenue, near Main Street, the shopping heart of the Flushing section of Queens. They pushed baby carriages. They poured into and out of the subway sta tion. They queued up for buses.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's department store sales at $547 million, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $506million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $6,399,000,000, up 4 per cent from $6,141,000,000.

title: LONDON MARKET REOPENS MONDAY
description: The London Stock Exchange was idle yesterday and will re main closed today to prepare for Britain's change to the deci mal system. Beginning Monday, the pound sterling (still valued at the equivalent of $2.40) will consist of 100 new pence, re placing the shillingandpence combination. The Financial Times industrial index and 500 stock index were suspended un til Monday.

title: Breaking Down Job Walls
description: The love affair between the Nixon Administration and the hardhats in the construction unions seems to have foundered on the ageold rock of freer entry for blacks into skilled building jobs. The unions have announced their determination to fight new apprenticeship rules proposed by the Labor Department, even though two years of toplevel negotiation preceded their issuance last month. They have also spurned the President's plea for joint action with the contractors to curb the runaway wageprice spiral in their industry.

title: Head of Democratic Coalition Won't Run Again
description: Prof. Daniel G. Collins, the first state chairman of the New Democratic Coalition, has decided that he will not run for the office again when his term expires in March.

title: AWE PRICES RISE AS VOLUME SLIPS
description: Prices moved forward throughout the session in ac tive trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: JARRING QUERIES ISRAEL AND U.A.R.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 11  Dr. Gunnar V. Jar ring, the United Nations inter mediary in the indirect Middle East peace talks here, is un derstood to have sent written questions to Israel and the United Arab Republic in an effort to get them to respond to each other's views.

title: AMINES URGED TO TRIM ROUTES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Department of Transporta tion said today that airlines could solve their financial cri sis by trimming their schedules, without a fare increase.

title: Nixon's Budget Attacked By Mayors as a Setback
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11  The United States Con ference of Mayors attacked President Nixon's proposed budget today as a severe set back for the cities, and said that the revenuesharing pro posal was misleading and revealed the Administration's intention to withhold the spend ing of funds already appropriat ed by Congress.

title: Royals Obtain Sonics' Black
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 11 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals acquired a 6foot10inch center, Tom Black, on waivers from the Seattle Supersonics today.

title: REV.V.A. M'QUADE, HEADED COLLEGE
description: The Very Rev. Vincent A. McQuade, founder and former president of Merrimack College in Andover, Mass., and treas urer of the Augustinian pro vince of St. Thomas of Villa nova, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Mary's Collegiate Seminary at Villa nova University, where he re sided. He was 61 years old.

title: Screen: Garden of Delights Returns
description: The following review orig inally appeared on Sept. 19. 1970, when the film was shown at the New York Film Festival. The movie is being exhibited here commercially at the Lin coln Art Theater.

title: Bond Prices Register Decline;
description: The corporate bond market ran into what was described as a fullfledged selloff yes terday, and underwriters gave up trying to find purchasers willing to accept a yield of 6.80 per cent for $150million of Aaarated Southwestern Bell Telephone Company deben tures.

title: 3 Are Arrested
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 11  The three indicted men were arrested at Fort Carson by Federal agents from Denver less than an hour after the in dictment was returned.

title: Subsidiary Brings Suit Against I.0.S. For $44Million
description: Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the giant mutualfund group, was sued here yesterday along with several I.O.S. com panies and their major bene factor, the International Con trols Corporation, on charges that included fraud manip ulative devices and contriv ances.

title: S.E.C. SETS APRIL 1 TO END FIXED FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Securities and Exchange Com mission set a deadline of April 1 today for the New York Stock Exchange to get rid of its traditional practice, of fixedsales commissions, in molar as they apply to orders worth more than $500,000.

title: Jersey Has Biggest Lottery
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. 11 (AP)With 5.8 million tickets sold, the New Jersey lottery drawn today was the largest since its inception Jan. 4. The winning ticket was 800093, and six $50,000 prizes will be given on it.

title: Bridge: New York Association Holds Its First Tournament of Year
description: The first tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association in this calendar year begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: DAVID KENNEDY GETS SAIGON ASSIGNMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (Reu ters)David M. Kennedy, for mer Secretary of the Treasury, was assigned by President Nixon today to help South Vietnam repair its warravaged economy and to plan for peace full development when the Indo china conflict ends.

title: Haefliger to Sing Tonight, Replacing FischerDieskau
description: Ernst Haefliger, tenor, will replace Dietrich FischerDieskau in the concert of Baroque music to be given tonight at Hunter College Assembly Hall. Mr. FischerDieskau is ill and will be unable to sing for a few weeks. He has returned to Germany, but is expected to come back to the United States in April to complete his engagements.

title: Fordham Sinks Rhode Island, 10987, and Registers 17th Victory in 18 Games
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Feb. 11 Fordham, led by Charlie Yel verton's 27 points, overwhelmed Rhode Island, 10987, to record its fifth straight victory and 17th triumph in 18 games this season.

title: FILION TRIUMPHS IN 1971 U.S. DEBUT
description: YONKERS, Feb. 11Making his first start of the year in this country, Herve Filion drove Mountain Pride N. to a come frontbehind victory in tonight's feature mile handicap trot at Yonkers Raceway. Minutes after the reinsman had re ceived the plaudits of the fans, he said he had no special plans to surpass the world record of 486 triumphs he Set in 1970.

title: Rail Charge Seeks End of Crew Laws
description: Eastern railroads, in an at tempt to secure repeal of what they call excess crew laws of New York, Indiana and Ohio, announced yesterday plans for filing tariffs that would permit them to collect a surcharge of $10 on each car of freight either originating or terminating in the three states.

title: Whites Leave Arkansas School As Board Yields on Integration
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., Feb. 11 (AP)  Many white pupils walked out of Watson Chapel High School shortly after class es opened today as the district began operating under a court ordered desegregation plan.

title: WORLD REVIEW DUE FROM NIXON FEB. 25
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 11President Nixon's annual review of foreign policy  known as the State of the World messagewill be made public Feb. 25, the White House said today.

title: Bogs Victor Over Fullmer In Copenhagen 10Rounder
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 11 (AP)  Tom Bogs of Denmark, for mer European middleweight boxing champion, scored a 10 round decision tonight over Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah.

title: Julie Holmes Triumphs in Skating for First U.S. PreOlympics Gold Medal
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 11 (AP)Julie Holmes earned the United States its first gold medal of International Winter Sports Week today with a sparkling victory in figure skat ing.

title: Secory Retires as Umpire
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11 (AP)Frank Secory, 53 years old, a Nationol League umpire for 19 years, announced his retirement today. The league president, Charles S. Feeney, also said Al Barlick, 56, who had intended to retire, had de cided to work during the 1971 season.

title: JACKSON FORESEES FIRM 1972 STANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Senator Henry M. Jackson pre dicted today that powerful ele ments of the Democratic party would insist on the nomina tion of a 1972 Presidential can didate with a responsible posi tion in the area of national security.

title: LIEUT. GEN. ALI AMER OF EGYPT. DIES AT 64
description: CAIRO, Feb. 11 (AP)Lieut. Gen. Ali Ali Amer, former chief of staff of the Egyptian armed forces, died yesterday in Alex andria at the age of 64, press reports said today.

title: Golf Writers Hail Shot Seen Round the World
description: Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr., the first man to hit a golf ball on the moon, will be honored with a Mulligan Award at the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association's annual awards dinner Tues day at the Hotel Americana.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest per centage gains on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: DRIVE TO CRASH SITE IN LAOS IS DOUBTED
description: QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP)  It appeared doubtful today that troops could reach the site of a heli copter shot down in southern Laos with four press photogra phers aboard.

title: Condors Triumph Over Nets,114110; Barry Held to 16
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 11 (AP) John Brisker scored 29 points to pace the Pittsburgh Condors to a 114110 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Suzanne Farrell Is Seen as Juliet In Bejart Premiere
description: One of the most pleasing incidental acts of the Ballet of the 20th Century has been to return Suzanne Farrell to the New York stage even if only for a brief tour of three weeks: Wednesday evening Miss Farrell and Jorge Donn danced the lovers in Maurice Mart's Romeo and Juliet Suite, seen in the United States for the first time at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Lincoln's Birthday
description: Today is Lincoln's Birth day. Following is a list of services that are, or are not, affected:

title: Commodity Price Index Rose to 110 From 109.5
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 110.0 Tuesday from 109.5 last week.

title: Nixon Urges Study Of Plan to Revamp Regulatory Boards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 President Nixon stepped gin gerly toward revamping of the Federal regulatory agencies to day. He called for vigorous public discussion of a plan to streamline five major com missions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times
description: Muhammad AU, the compulsive conver sationalist, has long been the delight of promoters, publicity men and sports writers on the prowl for quotable quotes. He's like one of those mechanical dolls the gagsters used to make jokes about a few years ago. Wind him up and he talks. But no one ever had to crank up the former Cassius Clay. The words just spilled forth.

title: MYLES LEVINSON
description: Myles Levinson, a lawyer in Brooklyn for 30 years and owner of the Sunny Oaks Hotel in Woodridge, N.Y., died yester day, apparently of a heart at tack in Miami Beach, where he had moved after retiring last year. He was 68 years old.

title: A.&P. Chairman to Retire at 59
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, Inc., America's largest food retailer, which has improved its sagging profits but not solved its in terracial problems, announced yesterday the early retire ment of Melvin W. Alldredge, its chairman and chief execu tive officer, effective April 16.

title: Fund Cutoff Linked to Mayors' Attack
description: News Analysis

title: Commuting Corridor is Planned
description: Hoping to get more motorists to switch to mass transit, and spurred by the success of the special bus lane on the main New Jersey approach to the Lincoln Tunnel, transportation agencies here have prepared plans to make bus travel even faster and more attractive.

title: St. John's Wins, 8271;
description: Mel Davis and Greg Cluess put out their best scoring ef forts of the season last night to lead St. John's to an 8271 victory over Niagara before 3,912 fans at the Redmen's gymnasium in Jamaica, Queens.

title: A BATTLE ERUPTS IN AMMAN SUBURB
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11 Jordanian troops and Pales tinian guerrillas fought a pitched battle in Amman to day and issued statements blaming each other for having started the shooting.

title: BuildingLabor Expert John Thomas Dunlop
description: Man in the News

title: Earthquakes Strike Assisi And an Iranian Province
description: ASSISI, Italy, Feb. 11 (AP) An earthquake jolted this central Italian town, the birth place of St. Francis of Assisi, on Thursday night. Some medi eval walls cracked and panic spread but damage was light and no injuries were reported.

title: U.S.L.T. A. Agrees to Lift Ban On Dissident Women's Pro Unit
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 The United States Lawn Ten nis Association has agreed to lift the suspensions of top American women players, who bolted the association and formed their own professional tour this year.

title: Soviet Sources Say Lithuanian Barred By the U.S. Is Well
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP)  Reliable Soviet sources said to day that Simas A. Kudirka, the Lithuanian sailor who was re fused political asylum in the United States after he had jumped aboard a Coast. Guard cutter last November, is well and living in a new apart ment.

title: Eastern Ski Center Operators Brace for a FourDay Invasion
description: News of Skiing

title: Request Made by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The British Government's an nouncement that it was extend ing the Rolls RB211 engine program for another three weeks followed a request that it do so by David Packard, the Deputy Secretary of De fense, wellplaced informants said today.

title: Crew of Apollo 14 To Begin Quarantine At Texas Lab Today
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Scientists prepared the Lunar Receiving Laboratory here to day for the arrival of the Apollo 14 astronauts and the scientifically precious rocks they brought from the moon.

title: PUBLIC HEALTH UNIT FACES WIDE REVIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) Elliot L. Richardson ordered today a review of the Public Health Service's commissioned corps, a quasimilitary force of 6,000 uniformed officers that has done research and provided medical services for nearly a century.

title: New York Cosmos Assigned To Northern Soccer Group
description: The Cosmos, New York's en try in the North American Soc cer League, will compete in the Northern Division of the eight team loop when the expanded league opens its season in April.

title: Here and in Scotland, Descendant Keeps Scott's Memory Bright
description: With a lock of his hair, his purse and his spectacles, a great  great  great  grand daughter of Sir Walter Scott was here to celebrate the 200th anniversary of his birth and to invite New Yorkers to celebrate it in Scotland this summer.

title: Reed Stays Home to Rest As Knicks Go to Atlanta
description: While his teammates were traveling to Atlanta for a game tonight against the Hawks, Willis Reed of the Knicks flew here from Buffalo yesterday for treatment of tendonitis in his left knee that will sideline him until Tuesday.

title: Cambodian Premier Improves, But Total Recovery Is in Doubt
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 11 (UPI)Premier Lon Nol was reported today to be slightly im proved after a paralytic stroke and to have regained his ability to speak and to use his right arm.

title: 38 IN SENATE SEEK TO END FILIBUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Thirtyeight Senators filed petition today to close out the debate, now in its 14th day, on a proposed modification of the Senate's filibuster rule.

title: MANSON DISCIPLE INSISTS SHE LIED
description: LOS ANGELES. Feb. 11 Susan Atkins insisted under crossexamination today that she lied in December, 1969, when she told a grand jury that Charles M. Manson had ordered the killings of Sharon Tate and six other persons.

title: Eva Peron's Mother Dies
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 11 (UPI)Mrs. Juana Ibarguern Duarte, mother of the late Eva Peron, the wife of Col. Juan D. Peron, the exiled dic tator, died here today of an abdominal ailment. She was 76 years old. Eva Pern died of cancer in 1952. Colonel Pern was deposed in 1955.

title: Goelet Is Elected New Head Of Historical Society Here
description: Robert G. Goelet, business executive and conservationist, has been elected president of the board of trustees of the NewYork Historical Society, the librarymuseum of New York lore at 170 Central Park West.

title: INCOME TAX URGED IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 11 Gov. Walter R. Peterson Jr. proposed today that New Hampshire give up its position as the last holdout in the na tion against broadbased state taxes and enact a 3 per cent state income tax.

title: Virginia Commuters Hail Reserved Bus Lane Idea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10  Carol Morton acknowledges perverse pleasure in seeing motorists intraffic jams when she goes to work each day. Miss Morton used to be part of the bumpertobumper traf fic; now she sails past it  in a bus with a road all to itself.

title: U. S. Reconnaissance in Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP)Official sources said today that United States recon naissance teams were operating inside Laosbut only in an intelligencegathering roleand that there were no American ground combat troops in that country.

title: The World of Lincoln
description: In his messages to Congress, while leading a war of fire and conscience in his own land, Abraham Lincoln called attention to the need for the United States to be a farce for mediation and peace among all nations. He did not put limitations of honor in his timetable for peace; his word for it was forbearance in our foreign relations.

title: 23d Headmaster, 39, Named By the Collegiate School Here
description: The Collegiate School, the nation's oldest independent clay school, announced yesterday that it had ended a search of more than a year with the appointment of Paul B. Mott Jr. as its 23d headmaster.

title: Masters Discloses He Wed Mrs. Johnson Last Month
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11 (AP) Dr. William H. Masters said to night that he married his col league in sex research, Mrs. Virginia Johnson, in Fayette ville, Ark., last month.

title: ARTHUR SCHNEIDER, A SOUND ENGINEER
description: Arthur W. Schneider, a con sulting sound engineer, died Tuesday in Palm Springs, Calif., where he lived. His age was 64.

title: Dining Out on Fiery Cuisine
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Enzymes Reported Dropped From Tide
description: Enzyme additives, which have been under attack as a health hazard, are being removed from the Procter & Gamble Company's Tide, the largest selling detergent in the coun try, according to union officials at the company's plant on Staten Island.

title: 'The Wishing Machine'
description: Few companies excluding the Disney outfit and a sprinkling of other groups, are bothering these days with a substantial potential of theater customers, small children.The Xerox Company, showing admirable determination, is taking steps, with a batch of foreign-made features aimed specifically at the small fry, now dubbed into English and set for weekend showings in key cities. The first one, "The Wishing Machine," will play matinees in 50 showcases today through Sunday with repeats on two successive weekends.The 78-minute feature is very nice. Filmed in Czechoslovakia in fetching color, with a lilting musical background, the live-action picture follows two disarming little boys as they play hooky from school, encounter a magic computer at an industrial fair, and daydream some perky adventures involving a rocket ship and a fantasy kingdom.The two boys are delightful, the English dubbing is fine, and the tone of the picture is briskly gentle and never sticky, Best of all, the entire enterprise is geared to the viewpoint of the capering youngsters, minus cutesiepie condescension. Filmwise, Xerox is off on the right foot.

title: Harry L. Gold, Executive Of Printing Corporation
description: Harry L. Gold, a former mo tion picture executive and more recently vice president of Amp co PrintingAdvertising Offset Corporation here, died yester day in Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 116 Central Park South.

title: Some Campaign Gifts to Rep. Ford Not Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford, did not report $11,500 in campaign contribu tions last fall from stock brokers, an oilman, bankers, doctors and a union group.

title: The $10Billion Misunderstanding
description: WASHINGTONLast November Dr. Carl Kaysen, the director of the Insti tute for Advanced Study at Princeton and a former deputy special assistant to President Kennedy for national security affairs, testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommit tee on United. States Security Agree ments: and Commitments Abroad. There was no press coverage for Dr. Kaysen's testimony because public at tention was absorbed at that time by the dramatic raid on the North Viet namese P.O.W. camp at Sontay. Never theless, Dr. Kaysen had a very impor tant message to deliverthe defense budget for nonnuclear forces, in his opinion, could in the next year or so be reduced by $10 billion.

title: Ad Agencies Weigh Return to Creating TV Shows
description: Several major advertising agencies, including J. Walter Thompson and Young & Rubi cam, are contemplating a re turn to television program de velopment under which they would offer presentations di rectly to individual stations rather than through the three national networks.

title: U.N. Wheat Conference Fails To Keep Pricing in New Accord
description: GENEVA. Feb. 11  A con ference called by the United Nations to negotiate a new in ternational agreement to stabil ize world trade in wheat has lowered its sights by abandon ing hope of getting an accord covering prices.

title: A PRIEST AND AIDE ACCUSED IN BRAZIL
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 11 The Brazilian Government has charged a Roman Catholic priest and his assistant, a social worker, with subversion 10 days after they were arrested here by the political police.

title: AMERICAN TROOPS REPORTED IN LAOS
description: Reports broadcast by the American Broadcasting Com pany and the Columbia Broad casting System yesterday said that American ground troops were taking part in the South Vietnamese incursion into southern Laos, some in South Vietnamese uniforms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Visiting a Landmark In the Neighborhood
description: WASHINGTONLike New Yorkers who live in the shadow of the Empire State Building but have never been to the top, Tom Lumpkin and his family never went through the White House until this week, even though they live less than 10 miles from it.

title: 3 G.I.'S INDICTED IN CAMP BOMBING
description: MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11  A Federal grand jury indicted today three Army enlisted men, one o them a Vietnam War veteran, on charges or stealing explosives and blowing up telephone exchange, an electric substation and a water works at Camp McCoy, Wis., last July.

title: Port Authority to Restudy Its Role in Mass Transit
description: The Port of New York Authority, in an abrupt move, said yesterday that it would, in effect, reexamine its role in mass transit in the New York metropolitan area. The Port Authority has long been a target of criticism from poli ticians, civic leaders and citi zens' groups for its seemingly overwhelming commitment to automotive transportation and its reluctance to move more of its activitiesand money into mass transit.

title: Bomb Explodes in the Bronx
description: Twenty families were evacu ated from a fivestory tene ment in the Bronx yesterday after a pipe bomb exploded in the foyer of the building. There were no injuries and damage was minor. The small bomb, in an airlines bag, went off at 10:25 A.M. at 465 East 149th Street. After a search of the building by detectives, the oc cupants were allowed to return to their apartments.

title: WESTFALL STARS IN BRUIN VICTORY
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11 (UPI) Eddie Westfall scored three goals tonight for the second time in his 10year career in the National Hockey League and led the Boston Bruins to a 53 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Screen:
description: The new Danish pastry ar riving yesterday at the New Embassy Theater with the title of Relations is as dull as it is dirty. This is the tired old saw about no fool like an old fool, as a gray ing prosperous businessman gets hooked by a pretty, slimy sensualist, with the ex pected ugly consequences. Spicing up the dreary pro ceedings are some breathless intercuttings of nudity and specific sexuality, along with aberrations.

title: Museum Presents Wide Media Range
description: Don't refer to Daniel Buren by the dirty word artist. I work with my head, ex plained the bearded French man, as technicians began to suspend his 66x32foot ban ner of striped awning canvas from the skylight ceiling of the Guggenheim Museum. I don't need a cultural con text for my work, and I think both artists and museums in the traditional sense are ob solete.

title: To the Voters in Her Home District in India, Mrs. Gandhi Can Do No Wrong
description: RAE BARELI, India, Feb. 4 If anything is close to certain in India's unpredictable nation al election early next month, it is that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will be reelected to Parliament by her own district.

title: GUARDS CLEARED IN 4 JAIL DEATHS
description: A grand jury investigating four prison deaths in Man hattan reported yesterday that it could find no evidence to support criminal charges against correction officers in the cases.

title: VOTEAT18 GAINS IN JERSEY RUING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 11 State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. ruled today that it was legal to hold another referendum in New Jersey next November on whether to lower the voting age of 21 to 18 in state and local elections.

title: WILLIAM A. KANE
description: William A. Kane, former industrial director of the Yonkers Chamber of Com merce and director of conces sions at the New York World's Fair of 196465, died Wednesday at the National Bank of Yonkers, where he worked in the business pro motion department. He lived at 26 Pondfield Road West, Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Nutritionist Derides Scare On Mercury FoodPoisoning
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 11 (AP) The current scare about mer cury poisoning in food is for the birds, says the chairman of Harvard's nutrition depart ment.

title: EXTENSION IS SET ON ROLLS ENGINE
description: LONDON, Feb. 11The Brit ish Government agreed today to keep the RollsRoyce RB211 jetengine project going for three more weeks.

title: Pnompenh Corrects Report
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 11 (AP)  A total of 12 rock ets struck Pnompenh and its outskirts early today, not four as originally reported, a mili tary source reported. He said they had caused little damage.

title: Hamilton Edges Foyt in 500 Trial; Pearson Is Victor
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (UPI)Pete Hamilton and David Pearson won a pair of qualifying races by the nar rowest of margins today to nail down high starting positions for the Daytona 500 stock car classic on Sunday.

title: Georgetown, Rutgers Score at Garden;
description: The Rutgers band and the Rutgers basketball team brought a sparse Madison Square Garden crowd to life last night after New York Uni versity lulled the fans into sleepiness while failing to gain its first twogame winning streak of the season.

title: Pope Paul Wants to Resign, Austrian Cardinal Says
description: VIENNA, Feb. 7The Romani, Catholic Archbishop of Vienna, Franz Cardinal Konig, thinks that Pope Paul VI wants to re sign and that a non  Italian churchman probably will suc ceed him.

title: Lessons of Lincoln's Dictatorship
description: Since the Civil War, a number of PresidentsWoodrow Wilson, Frank lin Roosevelt, Harry Truman and John Kennedyhave acted with notable in dependence in meeting emergency sit uations. But no President has as yet matched the nation's first major crisis leader, Abraham Lincoln, in his con ception and exercise of Presidential power under emergency conditions. All subsequent American crisis govern ments have followed the basic princi ples of emergency rule which Lincoln established during the rebellion.

title: Ecuador Frees Fishing Boat
description: GUAYAQUIL. Ecuador, Feb. 11 (AP)A United States fish ing vessel, the John F. Kennedy, was released by the Ecuadorian Government yesterday niter $40.050 was paid to cover fines and the cost of fishing permits, a naval sprokesman said.

title: Connally Praised by Nixon as He Is Sworn In as Treasury Secretary
description: WASHINGTON. Feb. 11 (AP)  John B. Connally Jr. was sworn in today as Secre tary of the Treasury to suc ceed David M. Kennedy.

title: Poor Left Behind in Europe's Boom
description: LONDON, Feb. 11  Near the docks of London's seamy East End, Mrs. Jane Kerr sits in the living room of her four room tenement flat and sips a cup of tea. Her feet are swol len and her hands tremble. Her first husband died of can cer and her second husband has moved to Liverpool. Ten of her 11 children live with her, as do a soninlaw and a grand child.

title: 4th Body Found in Newark In Chemical Plant Explosion
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11 (AP)A fourth body was found here to day in the rubble of two chemi cal plants reduced to ruins yesterday by an early morning explosion.

title: Irish Beaten
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 Villanova never expected things to be so easy tonight as the Wildcats controlled the boards, worked the fast break with profitable abandon and trounced Notre Dame, 9981, before 9,289 persons in the Palestra.

title: A Pioneer Recalls Struggle For Study of Negro History
description: James Egert Allen, a pro moter of Negro History Week for more than four decades relaxed in his memorabilia filled study yesterday and said he was grateful for the current surge of interest in black history.

title: Kosygin Asks More Pacts
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin hailed the signing of the treaty barring nuclear weapons from the sea bed today and said the Soviet Union would do its utmost to find further ways of ending the arms race.

title: BOARD POSTPONES DAYCARE CENTER
description: With some 50 members of the audience standing in sullen protest and making occasional mocking comments, the Board of Estimate acted on a long calendar yesterday, approving items ranging from controver sial luxuryhousing zoning to new industrial developments.

title: Administrative Judge Named
description: The appointment of Supreme Court Justice Thomas P. Farley as administrative judge of Nas sau County was announced yesterday by Presiding Justice Samuel Rabin of the Appellate Division, Second Department. Judge Farley succeeds Justice Frank A. Gulotta, who was designated recently to serve as an associate justice of the Ap pellate Division.

title: Hockey Club Hires Coach
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 11 (UPI)The Jacksonville Rock ets of the Eastern Hockey League hired Jack Leclair, one time Montreal Canadiens play er, as coach last night.

title: Raleigh Hotel Fire Kills One
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Feb. 11 (UPI)A fire that raged early today through a wing of the Andrew Johnson Hotel, an old brick structure near the center of the city, left one elderly mad dead and at least two other persons injured. The au thorities said the building had been sparsely occupied and its few other occupants escaped.

title: Stravinsky Memories Well Sung
description: The Igor Stravinsky Retro spective that the Perform ers' Committee for 20th Cen tury Music mounted on Wednesday night did not mark a birthday, or other milestone of the sort usually used as a pretext for such events. One reason could be discerned, however, and it was one the composer might choose, if asked: Many peo ple simply want to hear Mr. Stravinsky's music, even such bypassed and lesserknown works as made up this pro gram in Columbia Univer sity's McMillin Theater.

title: Operation in Cambodia
description: SAIGON. Feb. 11 (AP)  South Vietnamese military headquarters reported today that its troops operating in eastern Camboiia had killed 164 enemy soldiers in six engage ments.

title: Lumbermen vs. Conservationists in Fight Over a Thicket in Texas
description: SARATOGA, Tex.  The Iurnbermen who cut its oak and pine and magnolia call the Big Thicket a romantic state of mind. Their trade association says that the bears exist now only in the natives' tall tales, that the wilderness is no longer pri meval and that the whole brooding area differs chief ly from the rest of east Tex as in being a little flatter, a little wetter and possessed of more abundant crawfish.

title: Daily Double Pays $3,111, 2d Largest at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 11 (UPI) The daily double paid $3,111.20 today at Santa Anita, second largest in the history of the track.

title: Henry Brant Score Of Beethoven Work Played by Quintet
description: Perhaps it was audacious of the composer Henry Brant to take Beethoven's String Quar tet, Op. 131, and restore it for woodwind quintet. Some will even deem it sacrilegious, some just foolish.

title: 24 U.S. Combat Deaths Reported in Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (UPI)United States headquarters said today that 24 Americans were killed in battle in Vietnam last week, the lowest sevenday toll this year. But South Vietnamese combat deaths increased sharply.

title: WILSON, DURYEA PRESSING DRIVES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  Spot lighting their behindthescenes struggle to succeed Governor Rockefeller, Lieut. Gov. Mal colm Wilson and Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. will speak at rival Republican dinners in Brooklyn tomorrow night.

title: Your Own Business Is the Goal
description: Robert Ilario, Sy Holsman and Gary Alleccia, whose mot to is stay out of electron ics, are friends and pro spective business partners who were seeking a new line of work yesterday at the opening of the 13th annual Start Your Own Business Ex position at the New York Coliseum.

title: CLACKER INJURIES REPORTED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI)  Citing at least four injuries, the Food and Drug Administra tion issued a public warning yesterday against the clacker. a toy enjoying a popularity surge similar to that of the hulahoop in years past.

title: Guillotine Cut Is TimeSaver
description: Shop Talk

title: Mrs. Victor J. Fink Is Dead; Civic Leader in Rye Neck
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Feb. 11Mrs. Thekla Fishman Fink wife of Victor J. Fink, a retired photographicchemicals manu facturer, died Saturday in White Plains Hospital after long illness. She was 58 years old and lived at 636 Shore Acres Drive.

title: Politics Disclosed on Mine Safety Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  The Interior Department dis closed today that seven of the 13 appointments Under Secre tary Fred J. Russell was re quired to make for an expert advisory council on coal mine safety were persons without ?? or engineering experi ?? with strong creden ?? in the Republican party.

title: Taylor Troupe Steps Forward With New Look at Old Beliefs
description: The sharpest political satire In town at the moment is being presented by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on its third program in the City Center American Dance Season at the ANTA Theater.

title: Abortion Agencies Assailed on Fees
description: Witness after witness com plained to the State Attorney General yesterday of what they called exorbitant and often mis represented fees charged by commercial abortion referral agencies.

title: And Now, the Making of Caesar
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11 Seated on stage, clipboard in hand and busily scratching changes in and out of the colorfully marked typescript of his first play. Theodore H. White, journalist, historian and chonicler of the quad rennial American rush to political power, had the happy look of a bespectacled gnome held spellbound by the echo of his own words.

title: U.S. FREEZES AID EXPECTED BY CITY TO MAR SLUMS
description: The Federal Government or dered an immediate embargo yesterday on its contributions to New York City's slumclear ance program, charging that the city had failed to find de cent, safe and sanitary hous ing for families displaced by the program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SENATE CONFIRMS 5 FOR SECURITIES UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Senate confirmed today the nominations of fivedirec tors of the Securities Invest ment Protection Corporation.

title: Threat of Flooding Eases in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 The threat of flooding from a damaged reservoir dam de creased steadily, and the ten sion that had gripped Los Angeles since Tuesday's earth quake began to unwind.

title: JAMES TODD JR.
description: James Todd Jr., a former vice president of the United Paper Board Company and president of Todd Industries here died Tuesday in Phoenix, Ariz., at the age of 75. He lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: BERT CLARK THAYER
description: TEMPLE CITY, Calif., Feb. 11 (UPI)Bert Clark Thayer, well known photographer of race horses, died today at a con valescent hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: KEY BASCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 11 (APPresident Nixon ar rived today for the weekend. His plane landed at nearby Homestead Air Force Base at 5:47 P.M.

title: ALBANY GETS 2 BILLS FOR SEPT. 14 PRIMARY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11Two Republican legislators intro duced bills in the Senate and Assembly today to postpone the scheduled June primary this year to Sept. 14.

title: Venezuelan Says Oil Concerns Want Imposed Price Settlement
description: Venezuela's Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons predicted yesterday that the international oil companies would not come to an agreement with the major petroleumexporting nations be fore the Feb. 15 deadline set by these states.

title: RALSTON DEFEATS ROCHE IN 2 SETS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11  Dennis Ralston says he is play ing better than ever. After to night's convincing 75. 6.4 vic tory over fourthseeded Tony Roche in the $62,500 Philadel phia International Indoor tour ney, there is every reason to believe him.

title: Legislature Gets A Compromise Bill On Corona Homes
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  A bill to implement a compromise plan that would spare a group of condemned homes in Corona Queens was filed in the Legis lature today along with a re quest from Mayor Lindsay for the earliest possible ap proval.

title: PORTUGAL TRIES ANGOLAN PRIEST
description: LISBON, Feb. 11A former chancellor of the Archdiocese of Luanda, Angola went on trial here today on charges that he was connected with the nationalist movement in that Portuguese African colony.

title: Town Evacuated for Fire
description: ASHKUM, Ill., Feb. 11 (AP) A railroad tank car containing a flammable chemical was al lowed to burn under control today as the 600 residents of Ashkum remained away from their homes. The burning car was next to a tank car con taining methyl alcohol, which produces a toxic gas when it burns. The fire started after the derailment of 22 cars of an Il linois Central freight train yes terday.

title: WILLIAM F. MURTHA
description: MERRICK, L. I., Feb. 11 William F. Murtha, a reporter for The Daily News for 36 years, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 56 years old and lived at 35 Roydan Drive.

title: Screen:
description: Why Not, a feature length film by Arakawa, the young New York conceptual painter, is the current movie, showing through Feb. 17, in the Whitney Museum's New American Film Makers Series. I shall be very much sur prised if it does not become the hit of the series, a veri table succes de scandale, of which there have recently been depressingly few in the avantgarde cinema scene.

title: A Rise in Business Sales Reported for December
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11  Total business sales rose in De cember for the first time since July, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Track Coach, 68, to Retire
description: DENTON, Tex., Feb. 11 (AP) Winton Noah, 68 years old, said today he would retire next August after 24 years as track coach at North Texas State.

title: Rockets on Top, 119111
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 11 (UPI) Calvin Murphy scored 10 of his 26 points in the final quar ter tonight to help the San Diego Rockets post a 119111 victory over the San Francisco Warriors. San Diego utilized a fast break and a strong de fense to race from a 3227 firstquarter advantage to a 59 36 lead, their largest of the game.

title: PANTHER DEFENSE PRESSES WITNESS
description: A police undercover agent stuck to his story in State Su preme Court here yesterday that he had seen dynamite change hands between two Black Panthers, despite inten sive attempts by the defense to shake his testimony.

title: Air Force Cats B1 Bomber Plan To Save Money and Speed Work
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Air Force announced today that it would cut back the de velopment program of its new B1 strategic bomber  suc cessor to the aging B52to save money and to get the more advanced aircraft ready for production a little sooner than originally planned.

title: Kinsella Snaps Swim Mark
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 11 (AP)John Kinsella, an In diana University freshman, shattered the National Colle giate 500yard freestyle swim ming record today with a clocking of 4 minutes 31.8 sec onds. The previous mark was 4.32.3.

title: STEERS EXTEND NOLL'S CONTRACT
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Steelers, look ing at the bright side of Chuck Noll's rebuilding program rather than his teams' records, ex tended his contract as head coach today for two years through 1973.

title: LAKERS TROUNCED BY BUCKS, 12288
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 (AP) With Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson dominating play, the Milwaukee Bucks crushed the Los Angeles Lakers, 12288, in a National Basketball Associa tion game tonight.

title: Major Powers Circumspect About Their Stake in Cairo's Proposals for Reopening the Suez Canal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The reopening of the Suez Canal under an Egyptian pro posal that is receiving wide attention would benefit the So viet Union, the United States and Western European powers, but all have been circumspect about commenting on the pro posal, made a week ago by President Anwar elSadat.

title: Communists at Paris Talks Say 10 U.S. Battalions Fight in Laos
description: PARIS, Feb. 11Communist representatives at the Vietnam peace talks said today that 10 American battalions were en gaged in ground combat in Laos and named the divisions the units came fromthe Fifth Mechanized, the 101st Airborne and the Americal. But the American spokesman, Stephen Ledogar, accusing the Com munists of heaping exaggera tions upon lies, said, That's all nonsense.

title: Britain Shows Deficit For Trade in January
description: LONDON, Feb. 11 (Reuters) Britain's overseas trade showed a defidt of $26.4mil lion in January, the Govern ment announced today.

title: Market Plac 4161: Sears's Record On Mutual Fund
description: The business was launched with fanfare a little less than a year ago. The news was certainly momentous and not a little disconcerting for the highly competitive mu tualfund industry.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BRUSSELSIf, as suggested in a previous column, gigantic figures no longer dominate international relation ships, the obvious substitute for per sonal ascendancy is a continuation of the existing momentum of national policies. In this respect, Soviet Russia benefits.

title: Advertising: Bates to Poll Time Readers on the Generation Gap
description: Give the kids a break seems to be the underlying message in a Ted Bates & Co. New York ad that will be running in the Feb. 22 issue of Time magazine.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: London  Joe Bugner, 216 pounds, London, and Bill Drover, 2051/2, Montreal, drew, 10 rounds.

title: H.E.W. Asks Funds For Investigations Of Welfare Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Secretary Elliot L. Richardson of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare an nounced today that he would ask Congress for money for spotcheck system that would allow Federal inspectors to en ter the homes of welfare re cipients.

title: Pollution Curbs Urged for Existing Cars
description: The city's Commissioner of Air Resources called yesterday for amendments to Federal antipollution legislation to re quire better pollutioncontrol devices on existing cars as well as new cars.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Business Spark
description: The Association for a Better New York, just formed under the auspices of most of the city's top real estate operators and building contractors, is the latest ex pression of neardesperation in the business community over advanced municipal decay. Its efforts at civic regeneration will be pooled with those of such existing groups as the Economic Development Council of New York City, the Commerce and Industry Association, the Citizens Budget Commission and the New York Coalition.

title: British Doubles Team Posts Upset in Clean Air Tennis
description: HAWTHORNE, N. J., Feb. 11 (AP)  Gerald Battrick and Peter Curtis of Britain scored an upset victory over an Amer ican doubles team today at the $30,000 Clean Air Tennis Classic.

title: Books of The Times
description: A PERCENTAGE OF THE TAKE. By Walter Goodman. 226 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $6.95.

title: MISS NELSON SINGS VANGUARD PROGRAM
description: The transformation of No vella Nelson from actress to nightclub singer, which began a little more than two years ago at the Village Vanguard, has taken a great step forward since then, even though that debut was unusually auspicious. During the intervening time, Miss Nelson has returned to acting, both without music off Broadway and with music on Broadway in one of the lead ing roles of Purlie.

title: Soviet Jew Reaches Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 11 (Reuter) Grisha Feigin, a Soviet Jew ish war veteran who was put into a mental hospital after he had surrendered his medals in protest Soviet treatment of Jews, settled into a kibbutz after arriving as an immigrant today.

title: Lockheed Pleased by Move
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP)  A Lockheed spokes mart today called the British Government's announcement very encouraging. He said the company would like to stay with the Rolls engine, especial ly since test flights showed the engine was doing better now than it ever has.

title: School Critics of Scribner Visit Bahamas to Hear . . . Scribner
description: FREEPORT, the Bahamas, Feb., 11  Members of the group that represents most of the principals and other super visors In the New York City school system arrived here by chartered plane this evening for the start of their annual convention and learned, to the surprise of many, that their ma jor speaker would be Chan cellor Harvey B. Scribner.

title: FALSE FOOD ADS CHARGED BY F.T.G.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Federal Trade Commission ac cused the manufacturers of Swift's baby foods and Ocean Spray cranberry juice cocktail today of exaggerating the nu tritional value of the products in advertisements.

title: Post Beats C.C.N.Y., 8855, As Klimkowski Hits for 24
description: C. W. Post dominated through out as it rolled to an 8855 victory over City College of New York last night at the C.C.N.Y. Gymnasium.

title: Be fart Makes a Ballet Of Early Webern Suite
description: With so many dance com panies in town and so much dance activity to be covered, there have been one or two performances of importance that have so far slipped through our net. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music Sunday afternoon, for exam ple, Maurice Mart's Ballet of the 20th Century gave the American premiere of Mr. Be jart's Opus 5, a work to Webern's 1930 string orches tra version of the very early Five Pieces for String Quar tet, which is having its sec ond Brooklyn performance tonight.

title: Senate SST Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee announced today it would hold two days of hear ings next month on the super sonic transport. The chairman, Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, said the hearings would be held March 4 and 5.

title: TRINITY SCHOOL WILL ADMIT GIRLS
description: Trinity School which started as a private school for boys and girls 262 years ago but barred girls after 133 years has decided to welcome them back next fall in its high school.

title: Recession Spurs Rise in Early Filing for Tax Refunds
description: The bite of recession seems to have made taxpayers here more conscious that the Fed eral Government has refunds waiting for them, and the to tal could reach $800million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE FELL 4% IN WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Feb. 6 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

title: Percentage Drops
description: Stocks with the largest per centage losses on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Even when you get the facts on what is happen ing in Indochina, it's not easy to reconcile the gains with the sacri fices, but we are now coming into a new phase of the war in Laos where it is going to be more difficult even to get at the facts.

title: P.S.C. Sees Power Scarce in the State Throughout Spring
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11  The State Public Service Commis sion told Governor Rockefeller in a report made public to day, that there was little pros pect of substantial improve ment in electric generating ca pacity in this state during the next few months.

title: Canadian Bills Auctioned
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press)The Canadian Govern ment auctioned today $165 million in treasury bonds at an average price and yield of 98.819 and 4.79 per cent. Also auctioned were $45million in 182day bills at 97.722 and 4.68 per cent. The same amount and term last week brought 97.594 and 4.94 per cent.

title: Monmouth Names Publicist
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Feb. 11 (UPI)Ray Haight, a race caller at Maryland tracks the last 20 years, was named to day as the director of public relations at Monmouth Park.

title: Bomb Blast Near the Vatican Laid to Feuding Little Mafias
description: ROME. Feb. 11 A violent blast early this morning, seem ingly inside the Vatican, set off rumors of a bombing plot against the Pope, awakened high prelates, alarmed resi dents of the middleclass neigh borhood near St. Peter's Square and alerted the police.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Buchanan 21 to Keep Title Tonight
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP)  Ruben Navarro, the lightweight contender from Los Angeles who gained crack at the title as a last minute substitute, might prove a rugged opponent for the champion, Ken Buchanan of Scotland, when they meet in a 15round bout tomorrow night in the Sports Arena.

title: EARNINGS OF AVCO FELL 59% IN 1970
description: The generally depressed busi ness climate, pushed 1970 earn ings of the Avco Corporation 59 per cent below from the level the year before on a sales drop of 16 per cent.

title: MARKET RESUMES ITS UPWARD TREK
description: The stock market picked up some steam yesterday as prices and volume rose after Wednesday's slowdown.

title: DR. JOHN BAUER, 91, A RETIRED SURGEON
description: Dr. John Leopold Bauer, a retired Brooklyn surgeon and former president of the Kings County Medical Society, died Wednesday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. His age was 91.

title: Zucchini Casserole for Weekend Cooks
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Lunokhod Survives Eclipse
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (UPI) The Lunokhod 1 moon robot survived drastic temperature changes during an eclipse of the sun yesterday without go ing into mechanical hiberna tion as it had done previously, the official press agency Tass said today. While the earth blocked out the sun for three hours, Tass said, the vehicle, remained stationary, but un harmed in temperatures of more than 148 degrees below zero.

title: BAN ON ATOM ARMS ON SEABED SIGNED IN THREE CAPITALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The United States and the Soviet Union today signed the new treaty barring nuclear weapons from the ocean floor. The area covers about 70 per cent of the earth's surface.

title: Resistance Termed Light As Laos Drive Continues
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 12South Vietnam ese forces were reported push ing deeper into Laos today in the fifth day of their drive against enemy supply trails and bases. But it was said they had not yet encountered the kind of ground resistance that was ex pected when the push began on Monday.

title: CORNELL REVEALS ELECTRON BEAN
description: Cornell University scientists have developed an electron beam intense enough to pro duce the enormously high tem peratures needed for fusing hy drogen atoms into helium atoms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Thompson, Giant Pick, Enters Dash at Garden
description: Ralph (Rocky) Thompson, the first choice of the New York Giants in the recent National Football League draft, will make his New York sports debut next Fri day nightin another sport.

title: Hanoi Accuses U.S.
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Foreign Ministry charged today that American warships invaded North Vietnamese ter ritorial waters off Quangbinh Province in southern North Vietnam last night and shelled fishing vessels and junks, kill ing a number of persons and wounding others.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TEHERAN, Iran. Feb. 11 (Reuters)  A strong earth quake hit the northwestern pro vince of Azerbijan today, caus ing damage in four towns, ac cording to reports reaching Teheran. First reports said there were no casualties, but 100 houses were damaged in the town of Arasbaran and 70 homes and shops were de stroyed in the village of Ahar.

title: DR. BERTRAM EPSTEIN OF CITY COLLEGE, 60
description: Dr. Bertram Epstein, former director of research at City College's Graduate School of Education, died yesterday in Beth Abraham Hospital, the Bronx, after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 250 West 94th Street.

title: Dartmouth Hires Kopp
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 11 (AP)Tom Kopp, defensive backfield coach at the Univer sity of Connecticut, was named to the same post on the Dartmouth football staff to day.

title: Concert
description: Joseph and Lillian Fuchs and Artur Balsam took equal billing in Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, as be fits a community of equals. Joseph, the violinist, has been collaborating with Mr. Balsam at the piano for 30 years or so. Lillian, Joseph's sister, is one of the best violists anywhere, though in recent years she has been making fewer and fewer public per formances.

title: The Next Time Charlie Should Stay Home, Too
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 11 (AP) Jack Gibbons, secretary of the Minnesota State Athletic Commission, said today he had uncovered evidence that the boxer knocked out in the first round by the heavy weight contender, George Foreman, here Monday was not Phil Smith of Washington.

title: 20,000. Being Evacuated From Periled Laos Area
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 11 With enemy forces threatening the Government strongpoints of Sam Thong and Long Tieng, 20,000 to 30.000 civilians are reported on the move from the area near the Plaine des Jarres, 80 miles north of here.

title: CENSUS DATA SHOW BLACKS STILL POOR
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The income of young black Northern couples with children rose dramatically in the nine teensixties, but for a larger number of black families, head ed only by a mother, the dec ade ended the way it began in deep poverty.

title: CONNECTICUT VISIT PLANNED IN SLAYING
description: Detectives investigating the slaying of John Stewart Kellogg in his East Side townhouse are planning a visit to the Famous Schools in Westport, Conn., where Mr. Kellogg was em ployed as advertising manager.

title: The Silent Dangers
description: Pesticides, atomic radiation, chemicals, mercury and other toxic metalsthese are the silent dangers to man and nature. President Nixon's message on the environ ment makes several progressive recommendations deal with these toxic substances.

title: 91 and 182Day Bill Rates Fall At Treasury's Weekly Auction
