His was not restless and purposeless activism, but the activity he discovered at work in the physical world and the phenom enon of man, a phrase that is the title of one of his best known early works.

title: Penguins Get Four Goals in First Period and Set Back Black Hawks, 54
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 (UPI) Two power play goals in the first period by Syl Apps Jr. carried the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 54 victory over the Chi cago Black Hawks today in a National Hockey League game.

title: Harvey Blitz to Wed Judith Klavan
description: The engagement of Miss Judith Rachelle Klavan to Harvey Eugene Blitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Blitz of Oak Park, Mich., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Klavan of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: RETIREMENT AT 70 URGED FOR JUDGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI)  An advisory commission created by Congress recom mended today that state and local judges be required to re tire at age 70 and that justice of the peace courts be hauled or abolished.

title: QUEENS RETAINS CROWN IN TRACK
description: Queens College captured the first three places in the one mile run and maintained the team lead throughout in de fending its title yesterday in the 15th annual City Univer sity indoor track championships at Queens' Fitzgerald Gymna sium.

title: An Author Finds Great Neck Ideal for Skulking
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 13 Bruce Jay Friedman, the writer, moved to Glen Cove to forget the Bronx, then to Great Neck to forget Glen Cove, he thinks.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13Everyone seems agreed now that the invasion of Laos is not an invasion but an in cursion. The newspapers call it an incursion. Radio and television call it an incursion. The official voices of the United States Government call an incursion.

title: Simon on Sarris
description: ANDREW SARRIS is the main repre sentative in America of a kind of movie criticism called auteur criticism, a term perhaps not yet so generally known as not to require some explanation. Under the aegis of the late Andre Bazin, the French film critic and founder of La Revue du Cinma (1947), which turned into the Cahiers du Cinma, there developed the new breed of socalled Cahiers critics.

title: Sharon Welsh Is Betrothed
description: WILTON, Conn., Feb. 13 Miss Sharon Marie Welsh and James Dalton Butler plan to be married here June 5 in Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: CON ED DELAYING ITS MAINTENANCE
description: No preventive maintenance at all is scheduled during Febru ary for Consolidated Edison Company  electrical plants serving the city and Westches ter County.

title: IcelandA Great Place to arm Your Bones
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandHaving once read in an encyclopedia that Ice land is abounding in hot springs and that the Reykjavik region in the southwest, although only a few miles from the Arctic Circle, remains warm in winter because it is brushed by the Gulf Stream, I had harbored a desire for years to see if this could be so. My curiosity was further aroused a few weeks ago when Hannes Kjartanssen, the Consul General of Iceland in New York, told me that these salubrious conditions did indeed prevail and that, moreover, openair swimming was a popular Reykjavik winter pastime. And when I discovered that I could spend four days and three nights in Iceland for about $250, including meals, I capitu lated to my curiosity, packed my bathing trunks and flew off late last month for a midwinter holiday.

title: Layer, Newcombe Gain Final; Miss Durr Conquers Mrs. King
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 John Newcombe won a thrill ing tiebreaker playoff in the fifth set, Mrs. Billie Jean King had her incredible winning streak ended and Rod Laver moved one match closer to an other $10,000 tonight in the Philadelphia international in door tennis tournament.

title: Queens Wins City Swim; 3 Firsts to Lehman's Coyne
description: Ed Coyne, a freshman from Lehman College, won three events and Queens captured the team title in the 10th an nual City University swimming championships last night at the Queens pool.

title: Florida Asks Resumption Of Work on Barge Canal
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 13 (UPI)Suit was filed in Fed eral court yesterday seeking to reverse President Nixon's order halting construction of the CrossFlorida Barge Canal.

title: R. V. Dunn Weds Catherine Hayslip
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Miss Catherine M. Hayslip, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Hayslip of New York, was married to Robert V. Dunn, son of Mrs. Thomas F. Dunn of New York and the late Mr. Dunn. The Rev. Thomas McNamara per formed the ceremonoy.

title: When Everybody Went to the Movies
description: THE interview with Bus by Berkeley wasn't go ing well. Oh, he was saying some interest ing things; about how, when he staged those fantastic musical numbers of his, he carried in his mind every cut, every camera move ment, so that when he was done all the editor had to do was lay one end of film against the next (and the next and the next) to com plete his work. The camera felt natural to me, he said, as if I'd always been with it. The trouble was that there was no give and take between Berkeley and me. His responses to my ques tions were brief to the point of abruptness and, try as might, I couldn't get him to expand on them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Vols' Quintet Paints the Town Orange
description: KNOXVILLE, Feb. 13 This is Big Orange Country.

title: Emigr Nobility: We All Cling Together
description: WASHINGTONThe recent visit here of Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon of Spain and Princess Sophia, his Greek born wife, was a shot in the arm to residential and Administration society and the occasion of a rousing hurrah on, the local aristocratic migr scene.

title: Show at Asbury Park Stresses Boating Fun in '71
description: The 18th annual Jersey Coast Boat Show opened yes terday in Asbury Park, with the theme, More Boating Fun in '71. It will run through Feb. 21.

title: For Young Readers
description: Somewhere east of the Wayne and west of Arness, the romantic Cowboy Hero was tracked down by a posse of hardeyed realists and told to va moose. It was time for a Truth about the Old West. Ever since, we've known that cowboys were subject to, all the ills that flesh is heir to. Take the days of the great trail drives after the Civil War. Peak years for the cow boy, but the work was hard, condi tions harder, pay poor. No guitar strumming Technicolor dude would have lasted a day out there in long horn country. If the heat didn't get him, or the dirt, or a stampede, chances are he'd have fainted dead away from the brotherly aroma of his unwashed saddle mates

title: RIGHT TO LONG HAIR IS DENIED BY JUSTICE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) Justice Hugo L. Black, all but bald and going on 85, has con cluded that the Constitution does not give high school boys the right to wear their hair long.

title: LETTERS
description: Among the case histories outlined in Hardluck Class of '70 (Jan, 31) I took par ticular note of one that con cerned a wouldbe teacher of elementary school children.

title: Ski Weekends Too Expensive? Cut the Cost by Driving Your Own Lodge
description: HUNTER, N. Y.Don Adams, a 36year old engineer from Fairfield, Conn., came down Hunter Mountain and maneuvered his skis to a stop a few feet from his motor home.

title: City Starts a Massive Cleanup Effort in Brooklyn and Queens
description: A massive city cleanup of fort has been going on in Brooklyn and Queens, the center of outraged corn plaints in the past over snow tieups and skipping of refuse pickups  and even rioting last year over littered Brownsville strets.

title: Three Sign With Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP)The Boston Red Sox announced today the signing of George Scott, first baseman, Ken Brett, a pitcher, and George Thomas, a utility player, raising to 18 the number of players in the fold for 1971.

title: CONTRACT PROS IN NET RANKINGS,
description: BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 13 For the first time the United States Lawn Tennis Association has issued national rankings with contract professionals in cluded.

title: 9 DAYCARE CENTERS APPROVED BY CITY
description: The city has agreed to have private developers erect or sub stantially alter nine buildings to serve as daycare centers to be operated by the Department of Social Services.

title: EDWARD G. MILBURN
description: Edward G. Milburn, Eastern regional vice president of W. T. Grant Company, a department store chain, died Friday of heart attack at his office, 1441 Broadway. His age was 52. He lived at 6040 Boulevard East, West New York, N.J.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: City College 6865 Victor
description: City College rallied from 9point deficit. to defeat Tren ton State, 6865, last night at the winners' Wingate Gym.

title: Reviving soul in Newark, N. J.
description: The blackarts movement has reached a new level of com mitment and sophistication; its focus is no longer protest against white America, but an embracement and celebra tion of the black experience. It is not surprising that Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones)a black artist who, having been successful in the mainstream literary world, returned to Newark, N. J., to head a black cultural center and involve himself in local politicsis at the forefront of this movement. His latest book, In Our Ter ribleness, in which he collab orates with photographer Fundi (Billy Abernathy), is an exam ple of the new direction that black art is taking.

title: Smaller Part of U.S. Income Goes for Food, Hardin Says
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (UPI) The average American family spent a smaller part of its income on food last year be cause it had more money to spend, according to Agriculture Secretary Clifford M. Hardin.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Newark School Strike Splits Blacks
description: NEWARK, Feb. 13  The Newark teachers strike, which enters its third week tomorrow, has created deep splits in the black community here.

title: Tanker Collision in San Francisco Bay Spurs Demands for Stiff Harbor Controls
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 13 At 1:41 A.M. on Jan. 18, Adam Mowinckel stood as forward lookout on the tanker Arizona Standard as she approached the narrow channel under the Golden Gate Bridge. He said he had heard a whistle not too close, and then through fog saw a white light and a red light.

title: ICE CREAM ORDER PRECEDES NIXON
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 13Leon Riley, who manages the Alpha Beta Supermarket, is usually among the first to know when President Nixon will be arriving here for a stay at the Western White House atop a 75foot cliff overlooking the Pa cific Ocean.

title: Wisconsin Quartet In Best 2Mile Run
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13  The University of Wisconsin two mile relay team, anchord by Mark Winzenried, ran the fast est time ever indoors in the United States Track and Field Federation's indoor champion ships at the Astrodome tonight.

title: Diane C. Polier Plans Nuptials
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 Mr. and Mrs. Dan A. Polier of Beverly Hills have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Carol Polier, to James Michael Powers, who is in the executive training pro gram of the Martin Meat Processing Plant in Denver. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Powers of Westfield, N.J. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Son to Gilbert Goods
description: EAST WINDSOR TOWN SHIP, N.J., Feb. 13A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert K. Good on Jan. 12 in Princeton Hospital. Mrs. Good is the former Miss Regine Hess, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Hess of New York. Mr. Good is cir culation sales manager of The Wall Street Journal. The child has been named Brad ley Alfred.

title: On Ho Chi Minh Trail, Painted Traffic Signs
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 13The South Vietnamese opened for inspection today a milelong section of the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos. It turned out to have painted traf fic signs, and a latticework roof covered with camouflaging veg etation.

title: For Young Readers
description: Twelveyears old and living in Co lumbus, Ohio, Stonewall Jackson sus pects being black is a sin, even if people didn't come right out and say so. Thus, when the white lady clad only in long red hair and slippers hands Stoney his weekly 11 cents for delivering papers past her vicious dog, he wonders if this vision proves he's saved! With Stoney, who has a spot on one lung, the reader lives and learns. It is better (literally) to swim than sink: the sickest do not always die the quickest.

title: Kings Point Wins Swim
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 13 Curt Yost of the United States Merchant Marine Acad emy was a double winner as Kings Point defeated Stony Brook, 7240, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Swimming Confer ence meet today in Marshall Pool. Yost won the 200yard individual medley in 2 minutes 20.4 seconds and the 200yard freestyle in 5:29.5.

title: Mail:
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward B. Stott Becomes Fiance Of Janie Warner
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Feb. 13  Mr. and Mrs. R. Miles Warner of Southport and St. James Parrish, Barbados, W.I., have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Janie Warner, to Edward Bar rington Stott of Vail, Colo.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The contrast is so sharp as to be al most disconcerting. When a special com mittee recently named seven men to the Baseball Hall of Fame at Cooperstown there was a noticeable lack of enthusiasm for most of the choices. But when seven men were tapped a few days later for admittance to the Pro Football Hall of Fame at Canton, Ohio, there were emphatic expressions of warm approval at the uni form excellence of the selections.

title: Soviet Economic Plan Is the 8th of a Series
description: The Soviet economic plan for 197175, announced to. day, is the eighth of a series of fiveyear programs by which Moscow has been plan ping the nation's economic development.

title: Wantagh Teachers to Vote
description: PLAINVIEW, L.I., Feb. 13 Teachers in the Wantagh School District will hold a union rep resentation election Wednes day. Seeking to win the status of exclusive bargaining agent is the local affiliate of the American Federation of Teach ers, A.F.L.C.I.O. The Long Island Teachers Federation, with headquarters here, is backing its local affiliate. In the last election, in Oceanside, the union group won by a nar row margin.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The current very high vol ume of market activity tends to overshadow the fact that the securities industry has just emerged from its most trying period in 40 years. Inevitably, the weak nesses revealed during the past three years have prompted some heavy criti cism of the industry. By the same token, however, the industry lies displayed a sense of public responsibili ty for which it has received little credit.

title: First Azucena Role By Shirley Verrett To Be Sung at Met
description: Shirley Verrett, mezzoso prano, will make her first ap pearance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera during the company's 26th week, which begins March 8. She will be heard as Azucena in Il Trova tore, a role she has not previously sung here.

title: The Nation
description: Thomas A. Edison's dream has become Charles F. Luce's night mare.

title: Medicine
description: WASHINGTONPresident Johnson told the nation on signing Medicare into law tint no longer will older Americans he denied the healing miracle of modern medicine  no longer will illness crush and destroy their savings  no longer will young families see their own incomes and their own hopes eaten away . . . carry ing out their deep moral ob ligations  and no longer will this nation refuse the hand of justice to those who have given a lifetime of serv ice . . .

title: Harriman to Head Slate of 49 Judges At Show in Garden
description: O. Carley Harriman of Pebble Beach, Calif., heads a slate of 49 judges for Westminster. The arbiters come from 19 states, the Virgin Islands and Canada.

title: Nindl Triumphs In Pro Slalom At Boyne Mountain
description: BOYNE MOUNTAIN, Mich., Feb. 13 (AP)Hugo Nindl of Hunter Mountain, N.Y., de feated Mike Schwaiger of Kitz buhel, Austria today in a giant slalom match in the first half of the $15,000 Kircher Cup races at Boyne Mountain.

title: The High Country Illuminator By Daniel Ford. 155 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $5.95.
description: I like one gag in Mr. Ford's drafty little fable. At a winter resort there is a fellow who can't ski. (Too dangerous.) So how come he is a ski bum? (It's what's happening.) For the rest of it, the book floats off into a world of blarney.

title: Barbara Anne Van Ess Is Affianced
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 13The engagement of Miss Barbara Anne Van Ess to Lieut. Thomas K. McInerney, U.S.M.C., has been an nounced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Van Ess. The fu ture bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James H. Mc Inerney of Larchmont and Osterville, Mass.

title: JEWS' DISCONTENT IN SOVIET DENIED
description: VIENNA, Feb. 13Aron Ver gelis, the editor of a Yiddish literary monthly published in Moscow, said in a recent visit here that in general all was well with Soviet Jews. They just want to he left alone, he said, adding that all reports to the contrary are malicious lies.

title: Cornell Defeats Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 13 The Cornell track team scored its fifth straight victory of the season today as it de feated Yale, 6148.

title: Bridge
description: TO do the right thing unobtrusive ly is an advantage at the bridge table. A player who makes it obvious that he has a problem gives informa tion to the enemy, particularly if he does so at the first trick. Card play ers should bear in mind one of Lao Tse's valuable pieces of advice: A leader is best when people barely know that he exists.

title: Philip Spalding to Wed Jill G. Weldon, Editor
description: Henry H. Weldon of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and Mrs. Nathan Milstein of London have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Jill Gloria Weldon, who is literary editor of British Vogue, to Philip Lef fingwell Spalding, a docu mentaryfilm producer. He is the son of Philip Spalding of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Sydney, Australia, and the late Mrs. Emily Thomas Spalding Jacob of Morris town, N. J.

title: PENDER TIES RECORD IN MASONDIXON DASH
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 13 (AP)Mel Ponder defeated Jim Green by a yard tonight in capturing the 70yard dash at the 11th annual MasonDixon Games and tying the world record of 6.8 seconds.

title: Saturday Riots a Way of Life For Catholic Boys of Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 13 (AP)The boys in the Crack Club, 11 to 17 years old, give the impression that they are ready to die for Irish unity.

title: 19 CLUBS STAGING SPECIALTY SHOWS
description: Today is Specialty Day in the metropolitan area. With 19 clubs holding shows at eight sites, 1,581 dogs will he com peting.

title: Some of the Jobless Fight It
description: SAN JOSE, Calif.  The Peninsula, which is the leg of land that forms the south western shore of San Fran cisco Bay, has long been a fertile ground for technologi cal creativity  and the money that this implies.

title: Grania Mary Hoskins Married To John Westervelt Ackley 3d
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., Feb. 13Miss Grania Mary Hos kins and John Westervelt Ackley 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ackley Jr. of New York and Stonington, Conn., were married here this evening in Grace Episcopal Church by the Rev. John C. Beaven.

title: Architecture
description: IT gives us absolutely no pleasure to announce that the matter of the Villard Houses has gone exactly according to the script. The script appeared here two and a half years ago and de tailed how a landmark gets backed toward extinction by the wonderful world of real estate.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON The Unit ed States Supreme Court is now in its traditional mid winter recessmarking the halfway point in its 1970 1971 term. As a result of what it has doneand not doneso far, some things about this Court are now clear and the outlines of oth ers, though still shadowy, are beginning to emerge.

title: Reader's Report
description: The title role in this elegant study in psychosis is taken by, a hallucinating Hollander with a game leg. Hugo Lenz inhabits a fantastic garret in Amster dam, ekes out his private in come by translating pornogra phy, and relates best to his cat, who figures in his Techni color reveries. Mr. Beelanan's approach to his hero's madness is poetic rather than analytical. Hugo is a fearful nut, it is true: He is withdrawn, self pitying, significantly paranoid. But the author exalts him in stead of explaining him away. Hugo has such magnificent fan tasies as a matter of routine, that when a friend spikes his water with LSD, his delirium suffers by comparison with his nightmares.

title: A New Round of Fighting Leaves Casualties in Amman
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 13, (Reuters)A new round of fighting between Jordanian forces and Palestinian guerril las ended in Amman early to day, leaving many killed and wounded.

title: CHIHUAHUA AWARD TO CHOCOLATE CHIP
description: Chihuahuas are in the canine limelight, with a golden red longcoat having been runner up at the largest dog show in the world, Crufts in London, earlier this month.

title: U.A.W. Dues Will Double Because of Strike Deficit
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 (UPI) Most of the United Automobile Workers' 1.4 million members can expect to pay double dues at least through March to help retire a $22.4million deficit caused mainly by the union's 67day strike against the Gen eral Motors Corporation last fall.

title: Girls Basketball Team Wins 81 Games in Row
description: MONTEZUMA, Iowa, Feb. 13 (UPI)  The Montezuma High School girls basketball team has won 81 straight games, a consecutive victory record for this state, where high school basketballfor girls and for boysis big news.

title: Air Defense Exercise Set
description: OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 13 (UPI) Air Force planes of the Stra tegic Air Command and the North American Air Defense Command will participate in a joint exercise during the even ing of Feb. 16 and the early morning of Feb. 17. The Air Force said some sonic booms may be heard as the planes fly over the northwestern and north central United States and southwestern and south central Canada.

title: Miss Rodgers Is Wed To Daniel Greenfield
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 13  In the chapel at the Hackley School here today, Miss Marguerite Helene Rod gers, an alumna of the New ton (Mass.) College of the Sacred Heart, was married to Daniel Paul Greenfield, who expects to receive an M.D. degree in June from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The Rev. John Wintermeyer, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman of ficated.

title: New Canal Zone Governor
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 13 (Reuters)President Nixon to day nominated Maj. Gen. David Stuart Parker to a fouryear term as Governor of the Canal Zone, replacing Maj. Gen. Walter P. Leber.

title: The Antagonists By Ernest K. Gann. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $6.95.
description: Near the shores of the Dead Sea is the fortress of Masada, built by Jonathan Maccabeus, and later used by Eleazar and his Zealots in their last stand (73 A.D.) against the Roman military  industrial  complex. Anyone with a decent encyclo pedia should know that Eleazar and his tiny band held off the invaders for as long as they could, and then committed themselves to a suicidal holo caust. Mr. Gann makes the con test between these forces a microcosm of military con frontation, with all shades of war and homefront sentiment represented.

title: Free Throws Beat Drake
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13 (AP) Harry Rogers hit two free throws with 19 seconds left today, giving St. Louis Univer sity a 6462 triumph over Drake in a Missouri Valley con ference game.

title: ROME STAMPS OUT RACKET IN MAIDS
description: ROME, Feb. 13The police closed 50 employment agencies here this week to stamp out what they called a racket that preyed on at least 100,000 Roman families that clamor for household help.

title: ROSES TO DISPLACE ICE HOCKEY SQUAD
description: Just as the winter gives way to the spring, the Ice on the Long Island Arena will give way next month to grass, trees and flowers.

title: Art in London
description: THE exhibition now being held at Burlington House, Vienna Seces sion: Art Nouveau to 1970, makes an agreeable afternoon refuge from a cold, drab London winter day. Like many exhibitions, it is far too large  most of the dater exhibits, and some of the works by nonViennese art ists, could usefully have been dispensed with. It includes, nevertheless, a central core of talent  genius, I think, ?? probably too strong a wordbefore which the visi tor can warm his hands. Here everything glows and smoul ders and sparkles. Gustav Klimt's pictures have an immense vitality; and so, in a more disturbing fashion, have the works of Egon Schiele. Both were ex tremely literary artists, deeply influenced by the poems and novels of fin de sicle Europe.

title: Nixon Plan Keeps Drive On Cancer in Old Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13The Administration made known to day its strategy for the con quest of cancer, a national goal President Nixon announced in his State of the Union Message.

title: COPTER AMBULANCES WILL SERVE NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, LI., Feb. 13A plan to provide emergency heli copter service to several strategically located hospitals throughout Nassau County has been announced by County Ex ecutive Ralph G. Caso.

title: Students Are Available As Rented Pallbearers
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13 (AP) Wayne State University placement service has added rentapallbearer to its list of jobs for students who want extra spending money.

title: NETS BOW, 109105, TO MEMPHIS CLUB
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 13 (AP)Jimmy and Steve Jones scored 63 points between them and Wendall Ladner got 25 in pacing the Memphis Pros to a 109105 American Basket ball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Foreign Notes
description: The United States, Rus sia, Britain and most other United Nations members signed a treaty last Thurs day barring nuclear weapons from 70 per cent of the earth's surface  the ocean floor beyond the generally recognized 12mile national limits. The pact, signed in ceremonies in Washington, Moscow and London, will enter into force as soon as it is ratified by 22 nations.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: TO OUR READERS

title: BUYING POWER HERE OUTRUNS PRICE RISE
description: Factory workers' buying pow er in the New YorkNortheast New Jersey area increased last December as aftertax gains for the factory worker more than offset a sharp 0.8 per cent rise in consumer prices, the United States Department of Labor re ported yesterday.

title: No different from Americans, only more mediocre
description: The last six months have not been joyous ones in Canada, and consider ing the huge increase in unemploy ment since Christmas and the begin ning of the Front de Liberation Quebecois trials in Quebec, one can not predict a happy 1971. In addition to these internal troubles, and gen erated by them, a wave of national ism is sweeping the country and, as usual, it takes the form of antiAmeri canism.

title: WRITERS TO HONOR GOLF CHAMPIONS
description: Golf on the moon and in the United States will be major topics at the national awards dinner of the Metropolitan Golf Writers on Tuesday, at the Hotel Americana.

title: Hayes Registers an Upset In Port Washington Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 Dick Finger, the fourthseeded player from Texas, was upset today by John Hayes of Cos Cob, Conn., 62, 3.6, 62, in the Port Washington Tennis Classic for juniors. They played in the 18year division.

title: MAGAZINE COMPANY IS BOUGHT BY CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 13 The Chilean Government has purchased the Zig Zag Publish ing Enterprise, the largest pub lisher of magazines in Chile, and established a state publish ing concern with the plant and equipment.

title: SHELTER BAY TRIUMPHS
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13Rokeby Stable's Fort Marcy, America's horse of the year in 1970, was a most impressive loser today in his first start in three months.

title: Soviet Ships in Cuba Seen as Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The Soviet Union appears once again to be challenging the Nixon Administration's under standing of how far the United States will tolerate Soviet naval operations in Cuban waters.

title: Holiday Traffic Snarls Quake CleanUp
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 13 (AP) Massive traffic jams threat ened the Los Angeles area to day as thousands of holiday weekend motorists steamed out of the earthquakebattred area and cleanup crews moved in.

title: $200Million State Authorized 10 Months Ago to Treat Addicts Is Unused
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  Despite the concern over the narcotics addiction problem, no local government or private agency in the state has applied for funds to build or purchase treatment facilities under a 10 monthold state program mak ing $200million in lowinterest loans available for that pur pose.

title: Joan L. Cooper To Be a Bride
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Feb. 13.Mr. and Mrs. Chester L. Cooper have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Law rence Cooper, to Ronald Jay Gould. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Gould of Larchmont, N. Y.

title: W. Kentucky Triumphs
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky., Feb. 13 (UPI)Western Kentucky, led by the recordbreaking scor ing of Jim Rose and Jim Mc Daniels, defeated Tennessee Tech, 6757, tonight.

title: SPARE GETS POST WITH CHARGERS
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 13 (AP) Harland Svare, assistant defen sive coach of the Washington Redskins and former Los An geles Rams head coach, was appointed today as general manager of the San Diego Chargers.

title: Egyptian Champion Is Killed In WeightLifting Accident
description: CAIRO, Feb. 13 (Reuters) Said Shaaban, Egypt's middle weight weightlifting champion was crushed to death today by 290 pounds of weights he was trying to hoist above his head.

title: Miss Margaret Graham Bride of Dr. Jere Lord Jr.
description: BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Feb. 13The Bedford Presby terian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Margaret Humphreys Graham, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Graham of Bedford, to Dr. Jere W. Lord Jr., a cardio vascular surgeon. He is the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Lord of Baltimore. The Rev. Thomas A. Hughart per formed the ceremony, as sisted by the Rev. Dr. Adam Weir Craig.

title: School Turns Over a List. Of Students to the F.B.I.
description: EUGENE, Ore., Feb. 13 (UPI) Robert D. Clark, president of the University of Oregon, has turned over a list of students registered in a fallterm class to the Federal Bureau of Inves tigation in connection with a campus bombing in December.

title: Nixon Gives Promotions To Mitchell and Roosa
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 13 (UPI)Following tradi tion, President Nixon today promoted the two space rookies among the Apollo 14 moon explorers.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Panthers' Allegation of Killings By Police Disputed in Magazine
description: An article in the current is sue of The New Yorker disputes the frequently repeated charge by the Black Panthers that 19 or more party members have been killed by the police in a campaign of genocide against the group.

title: Mets' Advance Tickets Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: The New York Mets will open 350 locations tomorrow and Tuesday as outlets for advance ticket sales in the metropolitan area for the 1971 season.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Coins
description: BRITAIN the last ma jor country to switch to decimal coinage makes the changeover official tomorrow and, judg ing by the furor the new mon ies have created, Lord Fiske, chairman of the Government Decimal Currency Board, might have to hide for a while in some remote treasury vault.

title: 15 Test Coal Mine Shelter And Report No Problems
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 (AP) Fifteen men who spent two days in a steel shelter designed to protect trapped coal miners from gas and water reported no problems with the structure, but they said it was still not ready for use.

title: Rose Lopez to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Rose Marie Lopez, a senior at Hunter College, to Cadet Gary E. Clemente of the United States Air Force Acad emy, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Anthony F. Lopez of Jamaica, Queens, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. L. Gary Clemente of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Mr. Clemente, a former United States Representative. Mr. Lopez is president of Tubeco Mecanica, S.A., in Bilbao, Spain.

title: APOLLO 14 FILMS SHOW BIG ROCKS
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 13The National Aeronautics and Space Administration released today the first set of motion pictures and still photographs of the light gray soil, craters, undu lating hills, massive boulders and starkly black sky that were taken at the Apollo 14 landing site on the moon.

title: Flyers Tie Stars, 22
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 13 (AP)  Gary Dornhoefer's goal with 29 seconds to play gave the Philadelphia Flyers 22 tie with the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Honorably Released War Objector Plans Future
description: The first West Point graduate to get an honorable discharge from the Army as a conscien tious objector plans to become a physician, so that he can do something with social value.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 13 Harvard, utilizing the leaping abilities of 6foot7 Floyd Lewis, downed Cornell, 8060, at Ithaca tonight.

title: Delia Murphy, 68, Singer Of Irish Ballads, Is Dead
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 13 (AP)Delia Murphy, the ballad singer and widow of a former Irish Am bassador to the United States, died today at the age of 68.

title: Heart Monitors Will Be Installed in Nassau Police Ambulances
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 13 A heartmonitoring system will be installed in Nassau County police ambulances this month in an attempt to reduce the number of deaths that occur from the time a victim has a heart attack until he receives attention in a hospital.

title: To Many Young Saudi Arabians, Water Pipe Is a Drag
description: UMM AS SALAM, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 7  The water pipe, otherwise known as the hookah, the narghlle, or hub blybubbly, is showing signs of fading from the Saudi Ara bian social scene.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Child to Mrs. Marcus
description: A daughter was born on Jan. 12 to Dr. and Mrs. Steven M. Marcus at the United States Naval Dispen sary, Keflavik, Iceland.

title: Australian Puts Portnoy in a Class With Rabelais
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 13 (Reuters)An Australian court was told this week that Phillip Roth's Portnoy's Complaint was in a class with the works of Rabelais and Chaucer.

title: B.B.C. Seeks New Heights
description: LONDON, Feb. 13 (Reuters) An eightman B.B.C. televi sion team left here today to join an international effort to climb the unconquered south west face of Mount Everest. Led by a 30yearold South African, Anthony Lewis, the British Broadcasting Corpora tion team will join 23 men and a woman at Katmandu for month's march before attempt ing to clib the world's highest mountain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne Robinson To Be a Bride
description: COVENTRY, Conn., Feb. 13 Miss Anne Russell Robin son and Richard Bryan Mark ham plan to marry June 27.

title: SYMPHONY GAINS QUEENS SUPPORT
description: David Katz was a conductor without anyone to lead. He lived in Forest Hills, Queens, and decided to raise a follow ing close to home. And that's ??ow the Queens Symphony Orchestra came into being 17 years ago.

title: Tories in Ontario Designate Davis As Next Premier
description: TORONTO, Feb. 13The next Premier of Ontario, where one third of all Canadians live, is expected to be William Davis, the 41yearold Minister of Education in the government of the retiring Premier, John P. Robarts.

title: Syracuse to Play Villanova
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 13 (AP) Syracuse University has added Villanova to its 1975 football schedule to fill a date that was left open when the State Uni versity at Buffalo dropped in tercollegiate football last month. Buffalo had been sched uled to meet Syracuse in 1975 and 1976.

title: INSURANCE CRISIS PLAGUES SCHOOLS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13  The State Legislature has taken early action this year to deal with a critical problem of su burban school districts, includ ing many on Long Islandthe rise of fireinsurance costs to prohibitive levels.

title: TAXES MAY RISE 38% IN MICHIGAN
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 13 The Michigan Legislature, fac ing a $108million deficit in the present year's budget, was urged this week to increase state income taxes 38 per cent to avoid another financial crisis next year.

title: Graebner Defeats Nastase and Franulovic Tops Koch in Tennis Semifinals
description: Clark Graebner, refusing to let Ilie Nastase's lobs and gags get the better of him, beat the Rumanian in two exciting tie breakers last night, 76, 76, and reached the final of the $30,000 Clean Air Tennis Classic.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGONThousands of South Vietnamese troops, lifted and supplied by American helicop ters, continued their slow push into Laos last week and the ab sence of enemy resistance on the ground left Allied command ers both relieved and apprehen sive.

title: Allende's Sister Visits Cuba To Study State Programs
description: MIAMI, Feb. 13 (AP)  A Chilean Congressman, Laura Allende, sister of President Sal vador AllendeGossens, has ar rived in Cuba at the invitation of the government, Radio Havana said today in a broad cast monitored here.

title: Susan Coombe Plans Wedding
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 13The engagement of Miss Susan Coombe, a sophomore at Connecticut College, to Robert Richard Wolff, who attends the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George William Coombe, Jr., parents of the future bride. Mr. Wolff, a graduate of Princeton Uni versity, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Wolff.

title: Art
description: THE late Stuart Davis (18941964) once re marked: I paint what I see in America, in other words, I paint the American scene. It was, however, a strictly personal version of the American scene that Davis painted. His recurrent subjects were the storefronts, bistros and street scenes of New York City and the wharves and harbor ac tivities of Gloucester, Mass. the New England fishing town where he summered for many years.

title: American League
description: The third annual chase of the Baltimore Orioles is about to begin in the American League, but the spring spotlight more likely will focus on one of the Orioles' neighbors on the east coast of Florida, the Washington Senators.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Airports, big business In themselves, are also genera tors of business  big, mid dling and modest. Airport development, in turn, is a closely watched and often highly competitive matter in itself, focusing increased at tention on adjacent land prospects, employment pros pects and economic growth prospects.

title: SOVIET MAY LET MUSCOVITE LEAVE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) Informants said today that the Soviet Union has told Leonid Rigerman, a Jewish resident of Moscow who claims American citizenship, that he and his mother will be allowed to leave Russia.

title: Television
description: TELEVISION right now is providing us with an electronic example of the old saw that when it rains it pours. The sluggish economy has cut into its profitability and some nice people are getting pink slips in sizable numbers; albeit nothing com pared to the beleaguered aviation indus try. In October the networks will have a halfhour less time on weekdaysand an hour less on Sundays  to pro grant Boston mothers think children should be shielded from Saturday morn ing advertising plugs, The Demo crats still believe they Post the 1970 election because of the televised report age of the Chicago uproar. And Presi dent Nixon is careful to have TV con versations only with video's gentle elder statesmen  the commentators  rather than the more knowledgeable re porters regularly assigned to the White House.

title: FORDHAM TOPS ST. JOHN'S;
description: Fordham almost ran itself and St. John's into the ground by the intensity of its fullcourt speed and agility yesterday, but held on just long enough to gain a 7672 victory over the Redmen in a thrilling bat tle at Madison Square Garden.

title: PARLIAMENT GETS NEW POLISH PLAN
description: WARSAW, Feb. 13  Parlia ment began work today on the new economic plan for 1971 aimed at easing the discontent that led to riots in December.

title: Criminals At Large
description: That Albert Campion, the amiable English sleuth who drew his first fictional breath in 1929, should pass from our ken in 1971 seems a pity. Un fortunately, the death last year of Youngman Carter (who car ried on with Campion follow ing the passing of Carter's wife Margery Allingham in 1966) means that after MR. CAM PION'S QUARRY (Morrow, $5.95) we shall hear of him no moreand I am consider ably saddened at the thought. Quarry, though no hairrais ing thriller, provides a nice contrast between the detectival techniques of another era and the procedures of today. Cam pionnow age 60is asked to investigate what may be a case of industrial espionage: Omega Oils fears that one of its retainers, a querulous and brilliant geologist, may be hawking company secrets to competition. As Campion probes, a great deal more comes in view  including several bodies, an archeological dig, and a gross villain jerking strings offstage.

title: Off the mother! Off the father! Off the child!
description: It is difficult for a man who has been through what he considers to be a transcendental and purifying experience to return to the flaws of the normal world as a witness and explain what he has learned to its citizens. Indeed, what he has learned may well be unteachable, for it is the ineffability of his experience that makes an apocalyptic romantic want to reach out, grab us, shake us and say Be me, and then you will know what I know.

title: Group Winners Who Will Be Back at THE Show
description: Westminster, the blueribbon show in America, starts a two day run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow. One of the oldest continuous sports events in America, Westminster has been held every year since 1877. This 95th edition has drawn 3,031 dogs representing 123 breeds and varieties, which makes it the largest West minster since 1939, when it was a threeday fixture.

title: Bowdoin Six 132 Victor
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 13 Bowdoin College's hockey team rolled up its highest goal total in nine years today in crushing Holy Cross, 132. Jim Burnett, Pete Flynn, Dick Donovan, Ned Dowd and Bernie Quinlan scored two goals apiece for the winners.

title: Notre Dame, Led by Carr, Sinks. DePaul, 10776, and Raises Record to 136
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 13 (UPI) Austin Carr scored 36 points to lead Notre Dame to a 10776 victory over De Paul today in the highestscoring game for the Irish this season.

title: NUNS QUIT SCHOOL IN RACE DISPUTE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 13All nine nuns on the staff of a Roman Catholic elementary school in northeast Detroit quit their) jobs this week, charging the parents of their students with racism and unChristian at titudes.

title: A Plan to Muffle All Jets Draws Airline Opposition
description: An intense, emotional battle has been started by a Govern ment proposal that would re quire the nation's airlines to make airliners of the prejumbo jet era quieter.

title: Boat Show Boasts 7Foot MiniModel
description: When the Marine Recreation Boat Show opened its annual nineday run yesterday at the Island Garden in West Hem stead, L. I., one of the biggest attractions was a 7footer that would never go to sea.

title: Janice Thomson And Roy Levin Plan Marriage
description: WESTON, Conn., Feb. 13 Mr. and Mrs. Donald Ward law Thomson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janice Irene Thomson, to Roy Levin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Levin of Wilton. The couple plan to be married June 12 at the Wilton Congregational Church.

title: Sarris on Simon
description: FROM the time I started writing on film in 1955, I have published close to a miliion and a half words without once mentioning the name of John Simon. I have known him off and on, mostly off, for about eight years. We once stumbled into a double date; I invited him to my wed ding and he came, and to a party at my home. We have several mutual friends and innumerable mutual acquain tances. Indeed, I am always running into kind souls who insist that Simon is a lost lamb misunderstood merely because of the blood dripping from his wolf's fangs. There are merrymakers at every party who can do John Simon imitations, and with a few drinks I can do the Count Dracula of critics myself.

title: BRONX TRIAL WAIT IS PUT AT 6 MONTHS
description: A suspect in a criminal case in the Bronx now must wait an average of nearly six months from the time of his arrest to the day his case is put on the court trial calendar, according to figures released by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

title: Khayam's Apollo Afghan Show's Best
description: Khayam's Apollo, a black and tan Afghan who is awaiting confirmation of his champion ship from the American Kennel Club, took top honors yesterday in the 32d annual national spe cialty show of the Afghan Hound Club of America at the StatlerHilton Hotel.

title: Tire Council Warns Drivers To Make Safety Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UP1) The Tire Industry Safety Council has warned motorists to examine their tires for proper air pressure, excessive tread wear, fabric breaks, cuts and other damage.

title: For Blacks, a Strong Indian Mixture on L.I.
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Feb. 13 Most of his classmates at the grammar school here don't know it, but Tracey Crowe, a husky 11yearold, could tell them a good deal about the Long Island of yesterday.

title: Six Top Dogs of 1970 Get Awards
description: With two representatives from each area, the East Coast, West Coast and Mid west shared honors when the Oscars of the dog show world were presented at the 16th annual KenLRation awards dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night.

title: The Merry Month of May By James Jones. 361 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $7.95.
description: James Jones writes abominably, like Dreiser, which is to say that his sentences are dismal monstrosities of kitsch, while his novels (some of them, anyway) render the world with great power. Jones is a typical prod uct of a culture that finds it so easy to sneer at the mandarin finesse of Henry James and believes in its heart of hearts that the only art worth cleaving to at all is rough hewn, untutored, and springs not from emotion remembered in tran quility  where in the true American life is that?but from action remembered in the midst of still more action. In short, art becomes journalism, the writing that gets done with the guns still pounding outside: Stephen Crane, Hemingway . . . and James Jones at his best.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: IllinoisIndiana Tremor
description: MOUNT CARMEL, Ill., Feb. 13 (UPI)Homes shook and windows rattled along the Illi noisIndiana border when a small earthquake measuring from 3.5 to 4 on the Richter scale jarred the Wabash Valley yesterday. No damage was re ported.

title: Top Junior Handler at Show Tuesday
description: On Tuesday night at the Garden, the champion junior handler of the United States will be proclaimed. Dog show officials feel the event is im portant enough to schedule the final just before the best brace and best in show have been selected.

title: Jewish Activists Disrupt Soviet Dancers in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (UPI) A performance by a Soviet dance group at Constitution Hall was briefly disrupted to night by members of a group calling itself Student Activists for Soviet Jewery.

title: INWOOD'S LEADERS AIDED BY QUAKERS
description: Let's keep Inwood the way Inwood has been for the past 30 to 40 years, said James L. Casey, the Republican district leader in the area, during committee meeting of Commu nity Board 12.

title: Top Prizes for Homebreds
description: Two bestinshow trophies the James Mortimer and The Leash  remained in the cus tody of the Westminster Kennel Club from 1965 until 1969. Both prizes go to the winner of the top award, only if the dog or bitch is Americanbred. In 1966, 1967 and 1968, the winners at the Garden were imports.

title: Stankiewicz Is Rehired
description: The Long Island Ducks hockey team has rehired Eddie Stankiewicz as coach and gen eral manager for the 197172 season.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: A.S.P.C.A. Elects Haines
description: Charles S. Haines has been elected president of the Amer ican Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title: Pop
description: PAUL KANTNER JEF FERSON STARSHIP: Blows Against The Em pire (RCA LSP4448). The Jefferson Starship ob viously is a spinoff from the Jefferson Airplane. Led by guitarist Paul Kantner, it also includes Airplane regu lars Grace Slick, Jack Cas ady and Joey Covington. Among the additional par ticipants are such West Coast rock luminaries as David Crosby, Harvey Brooks, Jerry Garcia and Graham Nash.

title: Bonnies Beat Seton Hall
description: OLEAN, N. Y., Feb. 13 (UPI) Greg Gary scored 21 points and pulled down 10 rebounds tonight in leading St. Bonaven ture to an 8174 victory over Seton Hall. It was the Bonnie's 15th victory in 18 games.

title: SOUTH KOREANS SET 3D FIVEYEAR PLAN
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 13  The South Korean Govern ment has announced the na tion's third fiveyear economic plan, calling for an average an nual growth rate of 8.6 per cent from 1972 to 1976.

title: Lafayette Quintet to Play Gettysburg This Saturday
description: A basketball game with Gettysburg features Lafayette's sport schedule this week. Coach Hal Wissel's basketball team, in line for its first winning sea son in six years, will be host to the Bullets on Saturday. It also has an engagement earlier in the week against Pitt at Pitts burgh.

title: ST. PETER'S BEATS ST. FRANCIS, 11189
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 13Rich Rinaldi established a Jersey City Armory record and a St. Peter's College singlegame mark by scoring 54 points in leading St. Peter's to a 111.89 victory over St. Francis of New York before 2,000 fans tonight.

title: Boat Show Opens on L.I.
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 13 (UPI)The 14th annual Long Island Marine Recreation Boat Show opened today at the Island Garden in West Hemp stead. Admission to the show, which will run for nine days, is $2 for adults and $1 for chil dren under 12. The show visit ing hours are weekdays, 6 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.; Sundays, 2 to 9 P.M., and Washington's Birthday, 2 to 11 P.M. Nearly 200 craft are on display.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONIt already seems likely that President Nixon's revenue sharing proposal will stir the most searching domestic debate in many years in this usually hidebound city. That is not just because of the idea's virtues, which are numerous, but be cause it raises in the most specific way the question of how to spend the nation's money, and on what.

title: Steelers Sign New Receiver
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 13 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Steelers an nounced today the signing of Al Young, a wide receiver, their 13th draft choice, who played with South Carolina State.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONNine months ago, when American and South Vietnamese troops first swept across the border into Cambodia, the United States erupted in a paroxysm of anguish. By the end of the first week of the in vasion, its people were divided, its campuses closed, four young students were dead in Ohio and Kent State had become the ral lying cry for a generation. Twice in the course of that first week the President went directly to the people on television, once to explain his decision, a sec ond time to plead for a cooling of the rhetoric and time to prove the merits of what he had done.

title: 63 FORM A GROUP TO GUARD MORALS
description: Formation of the Committee to Unite America, Inc., aiming to halt further erosion of this nation's moral standards, in stitutions and common pur poses, was announced here yesterday by its president, Lady Malcolm DouglasHamilton, the former Natalie Wales.

title: Ireland Loses in Rugby
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 13 (Reuters) England beat Ireland, 96, in a Five Nations international rugby match here today.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Dow Anniversary

title: the traveler's world
description: THIS column is a Valentine Day's salute to a small group of men and a very few women who labored not quietly but mostly behind the political scenes for more than 30 years to change the holiday habit patterns of America and to make it possible for millions of us to be enjoying a three day holiday week end right now. It was a long, tedious campaign they waged, and it is fitting that on this first of the country's new schedule of five threeday holiday week ends every yearwith every one of the five holidays falling on a Monday credit be bestowed where it is due.

title: Parking Fees Are Doubled Near Cleveland Stadium
description: CLEVELAND (UPI)  It will cost baseball and football fans an extra $1 this year to park at the municipal stadium.

title: Robert Greene Jr., Journalist, Marries Susan Bonnet Koebel
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 13Miss Susan Bonnet Koe bel and Robert Bernard Greene Jr. were married here this afternoon at the Colum bus Club by the Rev. John Morrett of St. Alban's Epis copal Church.

title: Davidson Scores, 8070
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 13 (AP)Duncan Postma's jump shot with 4:16 remaining broke a tic and sparked Davidson to a 8070 victory over Richmond today in the Southern Con ference.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Karen Ewoldsen Is Wed
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 13 The marriage of Miss Karen Ewoldsen to Lieut. Thomas Daniel Kenneally, USN., took place here today in the Catholic Chapel at the Naval Postgraduate School. Capt. Joseph Cloonan, Chap lain Corps, U.S.N., performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Ernst Ewoldsen of Oakland and the late Mr. Ewoldsen. Lieuten ant Kenneally's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fran cis Kenneally of Middlebtish, N.J.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Wladyslaw Gomulka came into power in Communist Po land in 1956, following the Poznam riots. Last week, he was stripped of the last ves tiges of that poweras the result of similar labor riots.

title: Susan Reinish Engaged
description: SOUTH HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 13The engagement of Miss Susan Jane Reinish to Howard Graff, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Graff of Rockville Centre, has been announced by the future bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Reinish of South Hempstead. Miss Reinish is a graduate of the State University of New York at Buffalo. Her fianc, who attends the law school of Rutgers University, was graduated from the School of Government at American Uni versity in Washington.

title: Debating and Maneuvering in '71 To Be Key '72 Election Factors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 The politics of 1971 will take place on at least three levels, and what happens at each will have a bearing on the 1972 Presidential campaign. This year, in other words, the politicians will not just be playing exhibition games.

title: MIDDLEBURY WINS SKI MEET HONORS
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 13 Hugh Barber, a Middlebury College sophomore, won the jumping title in fog and light rain today and led the Panthers to a convincing team victory in the 61st annual Dartmouth Col lege Winter Carnival.

title: How Hanoi's Supplies Move Through the Web of the Ho Chi Minh Trail
A COSTLY OIL PACT IN IRAN HELD NEAR
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 13 Both sides in the continuing negotiations between 23 West ern oil companies and six Persian Gulf states predicted tonight that there would be an agreement tomorrow. The agreement was expected to bring sharply higher oil prices and assurances of stable mar keting conditions.

title: Dr. Nelson Glueck Dead at 70; Archeologist and College Head
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 13  Dr. Nelson Glueck, eminent Biblical archeologist and president of Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion, died last night of cancer in Holmes Hos pital. His age was 70.

title: 2 Local Boards in Brooklyn Split on Site for School
description: A Brooklyn community school hoard is bitterly opposing a site for a new school in a neighbor ing district because it fears that the proximity of the school would draw white students out of its own system and tilt a precarious ethnic balance.

title: MOSCOW UNVEILS NEW 5YEAR PLAN AIDING CONSUMER
description: MOSCOW, Sunday, Feb. 14 The Soviet Union made public today its new fiveyear plan, which aims at using modern technology, greater efficiency and better management to raise substantially the living standards of its people by 1975.

title: BOSTON SUBDUES MAPLE LEAFS, 51
description: TORONTO, Feb. 14 (UPI) Phil Esposito, Wayne Cashman and Johnny Bucyk scored a goal each to lead the Boston Bruins to a 51 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs to day, ending a 13game Toron to victory string at home.

title: U.S. Copters Get Rain of Fire in Laos
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 14As 40 Americanpiloted helicopters ferrying South Viet namese troops into Laos pre pared to set down in the jun gle, mortar shells began raining on the clearing.

title: Retraining Plan Proposed For Jobless L.I. Engineers
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I, Feb. 14 The Long Island Association has offered the Suffolk County Economic Task Force a plan to retrain unemployed aerospace engineers for other professions.

title: Personal Finance
description: Many people have the no tion that it really doesn't pay to shop around for automo bile insurance because the cost is pretty much the same, regardless of the company you're talking to.

title: MAIL TALKS RAISE HOPES IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 Hopes rose tonight for an end to the strike that has halted Britain's mail service for nearly a month.

title: SCHLOSS ADVANCES IN NATIONAL TENNIS
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 14 (AP)Lenny Schloss returned to his home state today and defeated Brazil's Ronnie Barnes, 62, 76, at the start of the national indoor open tennis championships today.

title: MINOR BILLS CLOG THE LEGISLATURE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14The Leg islature has not passed a major bill in two weeks and is not likely to improve much on that record in the next two weeks.

title: Paying Political Debts First
description: Caught in a desperate budgetary crisis, New York City cannot affordif it ever couldsuch politicsas usual activities as have recently come to light in the padding of payrolls with political cronies and paying them as parttime consultants at the generous rate $100 to $130 a day.

title: ScurryRainbow Profit Up
description: ScurryRainbow Oil, Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, announces earnings of $264.000, or 10.1 cents a share, for the first quarter of its fiscal year, ended Dec. 31. This profit, on sales of $1,969,000, was up from yearearlier earnings of $253.000, or 9.7 cents a share, on sales of $1,836,000.

title: A POWER SQUEEZE TO '74 OR '75 SEEN
description: Tight conditions for elec tricity will continue for the next two to three years for New York City and Westches ter County customers, and not until 1974 or 1975 will there be a comfortable reserve again, a Consolidated Edison Company spokesman warned yesterday.

title: CANADIANS STUDY ECONOMIC GAUGES
description: TORONTO, Feb. 14Season ally adjusted, the Canadian Governments economic strate gists have come through Janu ary relatively unscathed.

title: New Hope for Soviet Consumer
description: News Analysis

title: NIXON AIDE SCORES EXCLUSIVITY OF CATV
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 President Nixon's chief adviser on telecommunications policy said yesterday that it was un necessary and unwise for cities to grant exclusive operating rights to any cable television companies.

title: Chess: Dreifingger Title Winner In Senior High School Play
description: The senior high school tournament, a sixround Swiss event, was won by Alex Dreifingger of Abraham Lincoln High School with a score of 5. He drew only with Alex Ocipoff of Bayside High School, who finished in a tic for second at 4 with Roy Green berg of Lincoln and Howard Gee of High School of Science.

title: Congress Braces for a Battle Over Campaign Spending Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Congress is bracing for what is likely to be the first major political battle of the new ses sion, the issue of regulating campaign spending.

title: ARRESTS BY WIRETAP RISE 200% IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Three times as many persons were arrested last year under the state's wiretap law as in 1969, the first year the law took effect, the state police an nounced today.

title: Black Legal Help For G.I.'s Is Urged
description: Nathaniel R. Jones, the general counsel for the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People, called yesterday for black civilian lawyers to be sent to West Germany to defend Negro soldiers facing military trials there.

title: PRESIDENT RETURNS FROM BAHAMAS VISIT
description: He gave his wife, Pat, and his elder daughter, Tricia, heart shaped boxes of candy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Marlene Quintero Is Bride Here
description: Miss Linda Marlene Quin tero and Shashi Kumar Tejpaul, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fakirchand Tejpaul of Bom bay, India, were married yes terday afternoon in Trinity Lutheran Church, Long Island City, Queens. The bride's parents are J. Michael Quin tero of Guayaquil, Ecuador, and Mrs. Thomae Quintero of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Stage: Bed Stuy Drama
description: Delano Stewart has con ducted an adventurous ex periment in urban reclama tion with his BedStuy Thea ter. At 1407 Bedford Ave nue, deep in the middle of the BedfordStuyvesant sec tion of Brooklyn, this store front is fulfilling a need for black community theater.

title: Wings Blank Kings
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP)Tom Webster and Tim Rutherford, both rookies, teamed with the old pro, Gordie Howe, to give the Detroit Red Wings a 40 victory over the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

title: U.S. Vaulter Sets Mark
description: LENINGRAD, Feb. 14 (AP) Steve Smith, a 19yearold student from Long Beach, Calif., set a stadium pole vault record today with a jump of 16 feet 6 inches at the Izvestia Cup indoor track meet at Leningrad Winter Stadium.

title: Before the Quest for Ribbons, a Bit of Morning Air
description: Early walkers in midtown yesterday were treated to a parade of champions. Hundreds of dog fanciers and their pets, from massive St. Bernards to tiny Chihuahuas, took their morning strolls in the shadows of New York's largest buildings.

title: Shriver to Resume Practice; Joining a Law Firm Here
description: The law firm of Strasser, Spiegelberg, Fried & Frank announced yesterday that San gent Shriver, former Ambas sador to France, would become a member of the firm, effective tomorrow.

title: U.S. Girl Ties Skate Mark
description: INZELL, Germany, Feb. 14 (AP)  Fifteenyearold Anne Henning of Northbrook, Ill., unofficially equaled the wom en's 500meter world speed skating record of 43.2 seconds today in a tuneup for next weekend's world champion ships.

title: Sports of The Times Charity Begins at HomePlate
description: Among the current fundraising devices is the tennis benefit: for $25 you can challenge Clark Graebner to minimatch in front of your friends. If you score 2 points against him, you get your money back. Should you lose, your entrance fee becomes a contribution. According Gene Scott, who has promoted a number of these shows, the exhibition tennis match is replacing theater benefits and white elephant sales. Scott added: For one thing, they get people home and in bed by 11 P.M. with their tax deduction intact, He might have added, too, that the tennis benefit could he the start of a whole new charityball game.

title: NETS WIN, 118117, ON SHOT BY BARRY
description: DENVER, Feb. 14  Rick Barry's 15foot Jumper with two seconds to go brought the New York Nets a 118117 vic tory over the Denver Rockets in the American Basketball Asso ciation today.

title: Duquesne Quintet Triumphs Over Rhode Island by 11695
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 (UPI) Mickey Davis and Jarrett Durham combined for 65 points today to lead Duquesne to its 13th straight victory, 11695, over Rhode Island.

title: 2 HUNTER TITLES TO OPENING NIGHT
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 14 Opening Night, owned and rid den by Mrs. Ronnie Mutch of Weston, Conn., made a clean sweep of the regular and green working hunter divisions today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Horse Show.

title: Northwestern Mutual Life Announces Gains for 1970
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company of Mil waukee announced over the weekend that its insurance in force had climbed to $19.5 billion at the close of 1970, compared with $18.2billion at the end of 1969.

title: Port Authority Scores City Tax Idea
description: A city proposal to impose tax on the now taxexempt Port of the New York Author ity in place of voulntary pay ments in lieu of taxes was criticized by the Port Authority yesterday as an apparent product of confusion and mis understanding.

title: C.B.S. Cuts Its Broadcast News Staff
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that members of its news depart ment were being dismissed as part of the general 15 per cent budget cut instituted by the company. The acknowledgment followed several reports late last week that C.B.S. News per sonnel here and in Washington were being let go.

title: Alice Redington Wright, 85, Retired Y.W.C.A. Director
description: Miss Alice Redington Wright, retired program director and associate executive director of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York, died yesterday at her home, 3 East 71st Street. Her age was 85.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Word for Science
description: Until recently rich and revered as the great American faith, science has fallen on lean and hungry days. Some 50,000 assorted scientists and engi neers are now walking the streets, driving taxis or running gas stations. Where industry recruiters once stood in line to snag fledgling physicists be fore they could even shed their com mencement robes, nearly half the 1967 crop of Ph.D's in physics still had not found fulltime work in their field two years after graduation.

title: Miss Susan A. Egbert Wed to Brian Sawchuk
description: NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Feb. 14In St. Mary's Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church here today Miss Su san Ann Egbert, a 1970 grad uate of the University of Rhode Island, was married to Brian Sawchuk, a Rhode Island senior. The Rev. John Arrigan, resident chaplain at the university, performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Assemblyman Richard Gottfried Marries Frances Louise Rubin
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 14 Richard N. Gottfried of New York, at 23 the young est member of the New York State Assembly, and Miss Frances Louise Rubin, the girl he met at a neighbor hood bench painting party, were married today in the Westbury Hebrew Congrega tion. Rabbi Melvin Kieffer performed the ceremony.

title: Defense League Resumes Protests Against Russians
description: The Jewish Defense League last night resumed its tactics of antiSoviet demonstrations and harassment of Soviet di plomats and their families, which the organization had Suspended last month.

title: VERMONT JUMPERS TAKE 4 SKI CROWNS
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Feb. 14  Brattleboro Outing Club members won four of the five decisions of the metropolitan ski jumping tournament as the 1971 season came to a close today.

title: FidelioCastChangeTonight
description: In the performance of Bee thoven's Fidelio to be given tonight by the Metropolitan Opera, Leonie Rysanek will re place Catarina, Ligendza as Leonore. The remainder of the cast, otherwise unchanged, will include Edith Mathis, Helge Brilioth, William Dooley and John Macurdy.

title: Ch. Ahtram Legacy Comes Out of Retirement to Take Irish Terrier Laurels
description: Cheers and tears, greeted the victory yesterday in a return to the ring by a retired Irish terrier champion in the 54th specialty show of the Associated Terrier Club at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Sabres on Top, 32
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 14 (AP)Gil Perreault scored his 29th goal tonight and it proved to be the deciding one as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Philadelphia Flyers, 32.

title: Adm. Paul Halloran Dies at 74; Chief of Seabees in Marianas
description: Rear Adm. Paul James Hal loran, Civil Engineer Corps, U.S.N., retired, died yesterday at his home in Yorktown Height, N. Y. His age was 74.

title: Irish Setter Takes Top Honors At Combined Clubs Specialty
description: A high school chemistry teacher, Beurmann Brewbaker of Farmington, Mich., came up with the right formula at the Combined Setter Clubs of America specialty as his Irish setter, Ch. Rockherin Rebecca, was named best of 249 red coated dogs at the Statler Hilton yesterday,

title: SCHENK SETS MARK IN WORLD SKATING
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Feb. 14 (AP)  Ard Schenk of the Ne therlands won his second con secutive world speed skating title today with a record total of 171.130 points.

title: CLASHES ERUPT AGAIN IN REGGIO CALABRIA
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Feb. 14 (Reuters)The police tonight used water cannon and clubs to disperse demonstrators in this defiant city in Italy's deep south.

title: Veteran Who Defended Flag At Protest to Get Award
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 14 (AP)A Navy veteran who stood alone and protected the American flag from student protesters trying to take it down will receive the Freedoms Foundations highest award to morrow.

title: HULL SCORES TWICE AND PASSES RICHARD
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (UPI) Bobby Hull got his 35th and 36th goals of the season and moved into second place among N.H.L. career scorers tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Vancouver Ca nucks, 31.

title: Fletcher of Times Wins 2 Dog Writers' Prizes
description: Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times received two awards at the Dog Writers' Association of Amer ica annual dinner at the Stat ler Hilton Hotel last night.

title: Politicizing Mine Safety
description: The Nixon Administration is playing politics with the safety of the nation's miners. Its appointment of seven Republican party stalwarts, who have no mining experi ence or other apparent qualifications, to an expert ad visory committee on coal mine safety makes this fact plain.

title: NIGHT PATROL NAMED TOP BOSTON TERRIER
description: Court Barton Night Patrol, imported from England, came out of the classes yesterday and won the 63d annual spe cialty show of the Boston Ter rier Club of New York at the City Squire Motor Inn.

title: Hospital Lets Teenagers Act Their Age
description: Constance Coley, an 18 yearold freshman at Cornell University, was something less than delighted when she disscovered she had an infec tion that would require hos pitalization. She was in for a pleasant surprise.

title: Sonics Snap out or Slump
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 14 (AP)  The Seattle Sonics came out of a slump today to rout the San Francisco Warriors, 146101. Spencer Haywood led the vic tors with 25 points.

title: Reese Advances to Final Of U.S. Squash Racquets
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 14  John Reese of New York City, after eliminating defending cham pion Anil Nayar of Boston in the quarterfinal round, ad vanced to the final today in the national squash racquets singles championship at the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club.

title: House Panel Investigates Loans to Pennsy Officers
description: Wright Patman, the power ful chairman of the House Banking and Currency Commit tee, thinks his investigation of the Penn Central Transporta tion Company's collapse has disclosed enough irregularities that Federal and state agencies should move to determine whether there have been viola tions of securities, transporta tion or other laws and regu lations.

title: Roger Kyes, ExDeputy Defense Secretary, Dies
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 14 Roger M. Kyes, who was Depu ty Secretary of Defense under President Dwight D. Eisenhow er, died yesterday of a heart at tack. He was 64 years old.

title: SOVIET SAID TO LET 7 FAMILIES LEAVE
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14 Soviet authorities were reported to day to have given unexpected permission to seven Moscow Jewish families to leave the country. AU have been vocal an complaining about Soviet visa policies and most had been turned down previously.

title: W. W. STEPHENSON Sr.
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., Feb. 14 William W. Stephenson Sr., a naval architect with Hopeman Bros., Inc., New York, since 1917, died yesterday here. He was 82 years old and lived at 839 Bradford Avenue.

title: Rocket Launching Delayed
description: UCHINOURA, Japan, Feb. 14 (AP)Japanese scientists post poned because of bad weather today the scheduled launching of an MU4S rocket to orbit a scientific satellite. The launch ing was rescheduled for Tues day.

title: The Eve of the Bluing of America
description: A considerable number of American intellectuals have been on a kick of revolution talk for the last few years. It began in a left mood, with fantasies of political revolution colored red or black. The mood now appears to have shifted somewhat. The fantasies have shifted to cultural revolution, which, we are told, will color America green.

title: CHEATING ALLEGED ON ARMY EXAMS
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 14 (AP)Two former Army lieu tenants say that superiors allowed officers to cheat on qualifying exams for posts that put them in a position to supervise the firing of defen sive nuclear missiles, according to The Daily Oklahoman.

title: Irishmen Protest in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP) Irish nationalist demonstrators tried today to place a black coffin on the doorstep of 10 Downing Street, Prime Minister Heath's residence, but the police turned them away.

title: ROBERT L. MORA, PRESS EXECUTIVE Herald Tribune Editor Dies Helped Revive Army Paper
description: MEDFORD LAKES, N.J., Feb. 14Robert L. Moora, a public relations executive of the RCA Corporation in Camden and a former editor on The New York Herald Tribune, was found dead in his automobile near here today.

title: ST. FRANCIS DOWNS IONA IN HOCKEY, 74
description: Scoring two goals each, Jim Daly and Julio Acosta led St. Francis to a 74 victory over Iona in a Metropolitan Inter collegiate Hockey League game before 4,113 fans in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BOYNE MOUNTAIN, Mich., Feb. 14 (AP)Hias Leitner of Stratton Mountain, Vt., cap tured the Boyne Mountain sla lom championship and $1,875 of the $15,000 total purse at Boyne Mountain, ski area today.

title: BLUES DEFEATED IN GARDEN BY 21
description: The Rangers and St. Louis Blues, frustrated teams with nowhere to go but sideways, completed last night a home andhome weekend in which they traded victories.

title: REHEARSAL ENDS, OLYMPICS NEXT
description: SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 14 (UPI)  The dress rehearsal for the 1972 winter Olympic Games closed tonight as ath letes from 23 nations were awarded medals won during the Sapporo International Sports Week.

title: Mr. Nixon and the Bishops of Journalism
description: The comments about relations be tween press and President remind me of nothing so much as the celebration of a pontifical mass.

title: GIRL DIES OF BURNS; STEPFATHER SEIZED
description: The stepfather of a 3year old girl was arrested yesterday when the child died of burns the police said she had suffered when he placed her on a radi ator as a form of punishment.

title: Bulls Easy Victors
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 14 (UPI) The Chicago Bulls were threat ened only once on the way to an easy 10883 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers today.

title: Black Caucus Agrees on Bills To Be Offered to Legislature
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14Delegates from the state unit of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People and black state legislators agreed today on a package of bills that will be introduced in the State Legislature dealing with legislative reapportion ment, elimination of the Board of Examiners for teachers in New York City and onthejob training.

title: BUCKS VANQUISH HAWKS BY 12488
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 14 (UPI) The hot Milwaukee Bucks stormed to a 19point lead, then coasted to a 12488 triumph over the Atlanta Hawks today in the National Basketball As sociation.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 14Through the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, American policy in Indochina has fo cused almost entirely on military force. American troops are slowly withdraw ing now, but the war goes on by other means: Vietnamization, expanded bombings, close air support by Amer ican planes over wider fronts. The offi cial talk is still of punishing the enemy; it is the familiar talk of vic tory.

title: CHIHUAHUA AWARD TO TIJUANA BRASS
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Feb. 14 Ch. Varga's Tijuana Brass, a perky, fawn and white 2year old, was judged best in show at the 17th annual Chihuahua Club of MidJersey unbenched specialty at Veterans Memorial Hall today.

title: Two East German Women Tie Indoor Track Records
description: BERLIN, Feb. 14 (AP) Renate StecherMeissner tied a world record in the 50meter dash and Annelle Ehrhardt Jahns equaled the 50meter hurdle mark today in East Ger many's indoor track champion ships.

title: Terms of Agreement With 6 Oil Producers
description: The fiveyear pact between six oilproducing countries on the Persian Gulf and 23 West ern oil companies that ex port it include the following:

title: Moscow's New Plan
description: The new Soviet fiveyear plan is an outline of national priorities, a hortatory document intended to spur the population to greater effort, and a propaganda instrument designed to impress both friends and foes. It throws light on the Kremlin's assumptions about the likely state the world in the next five years, as well as on the rela tive balance of power among Kremlin interest groups.

title: 3 Allies Proposing Looser Bonn Ties With West Berlin
description: BONN, Feb. 14  The Unit ed States, Britain and France haye proposed to the Soviet Union that West Berlin forgo its claim to be an integral part of the West German Republic, Western allied sources said here today.

title: Alaska Pipeline Study Set
