description: HONOLULU, Feb. 15 (AP) The ailing Cambodian Premier, Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol, was re ported to be showing slight but significant improvement today at Tripler United States Army Hospital. A medical spokesman said that the Pre mier, who suffered a stroke last Monday, was out of bed and walking with assistance.

title: Unstarchy U.S. General in Vietnam
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb.14In the oneroom trail er near here occupied by Brig. Gen. John G. Hill Jr., the man in, charge of protecting the people providing logistical support for the South Viet namese drive into Laos, there Is only one small selfindul gence: a coffeepot on a

title: Wartime Papers Tell of U.S.British Pledge on Atomic Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Wartime agreements between the United States and Britain on atomic energyincluding a pledge not to use atomic weap ons against third parties without each other's consent are detailed in a new series of Government documents made public by the State Depart ment today.

title: POWER MEMORIAL WINS TRACK CROWN
description: St. Francis Prep upset arch bishop Molloy and Power Memorial edged La Salle Academy for team honors yes terday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor sectional track cham pionships.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
CITY WILL GARNISH PAY OF SCOFFLAWS
description: City marshals will be em powered next month to seize the personal property or attach the salaries of parking scoff laws with three or more tickets unpaid since last July.

title: The Return of Palmer
description: With a spectacular putto Ar nold Palmer has renewed his confidence and achieved an other golfing goal.

title: CANON BOARDIVIAIV, A RECTOR IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15Canon George Boardman, rector of St. Michael's Episcopal Church since 1959 and canon of Trinity Cathedral here since 1965, died Sunday after conducting serv ices. He apparently suffered a stroke. He was 60 years old and lived at 39 Titus Avenue, Law renceville.

title: BOSTON BANK GIVEN FUNDS BY EXIMBANK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) The ExportImport Bank an nounced today it was making $10million available to the First National Bank of Boston to support $22.2million in ex port sales under the Export Import Bank's cooperative fi nancing facility.

title: Dr. Paul Zucker Is Dead at 82; Many Years at Cooper Union
description: Dr. Paul Zucker, architect, author and for many years a professor of city planning and the history of art and archi tecture at Cooper Union here, died Sunday at his home after a short illness. He was 82 years old and lived at 227 East 57th Street.

title: A.B C.'s Goldenson Rides the Current of TV
description: News Analysis

title: REVENUE SHARING OPPOSED BYLABOR
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 15 The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. called today for rejection of President Nixon's proposal for general revenue sharing of $5billion with the states on a nostrings basis.

title: Books of The Times
description: Her destiny, say the authors of their subject in a somewhat grandiloquent phrase, was to publish James Joyce in England. And it may have been. But the dayby day labor of carrying out that destiny would have exhausted the patience and broken the strength of an angel. She had the perfect combination of qualities neces

title: MONROE SELIGMAN
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Feb. 15 Monroe Seligman, president since 1945 of Tenney Engineer ing, Inc., of Union, died Satur day after a brief illness at his home at 115 The Circle. He was 60 years old.

title: Group Winners Picked on Westminster's First Night
description: Ch. O'Connell of Kerry Oaks, a Kerry blue owned by Florence Coe of Atherton, Calif., became the first dog to gain tonight's final of the Westminster Kennel Club Show at Madison Square Garden when the 22monthold dog was named the best terrier last night.

title: News Analysis
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 15The dead lock at the Big Four talks on Berlin has produced a, notice able, probablyinevitable, cool ing in SovietWest German relations.

title: Jury Set to Study Attack on Newark Teachers
description: NEWARK, Feb. 15An Es sex County grand jury will be gin hearing information this week concerning the attack on striking Newark teachers by group of black youths two weeks ago, it was disclosed today.

title: Kansas Tops Oklahoma
description: NORMAN, Okla., Feb. 15 (UPI)Kansas rallied in the second half tonight to escape its closest scare of the Big Eight season and defeat Oklahoma, 7168.

title: Tight Gas Supply Prompts Curbs on New Customers
description: Problems of supplying natural gas have brought restrictions against new customers by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, and three upstate gas utilities and a priority system by a fifth, the State Public Service Com mission said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Stresses Exports
description: The Soviet Union is count ing on a major expansion of its foreign trade to help make possible the realization of its new ninth fiveyear plan for 19711975.

title: STUDIES QUESTION PAYMENTS ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15  Two new studies by three well known economists have inde pendently reached the same striking conclusionthat hence forth the United States should run its economy entirely on the basis of what is best for prices and employment at home and stop worrying about the balance of international pay ments.

title: Blake Stops Mahanga in 8th
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 15 (AP) Eric Blaek of Bri tain scored an eighthround knockout over Kahu Mahanga lof New Zealand tonight in their scheduled 10round middle Iweight bout. Blake weighed 153 pounds, Mahanga 159

title: Remington Aims
description: The Remington Arms Com pany, Inc., reported yesterday net income for 1970 of $11, 275,000, or $1.49 a share, down front $12,834,000, or $1.70 a share, the year before. Sales fell to $122,403,000 from $129, 499,000. The, earnings, decline was attributed primarily to higher manufacturing costs in cluding startup charges for the new ammunition plant in Lo noke, Ark. Net income bene fited from a lower surcharge tax and included a nonrecur ring gain of 14 cents a share.

title: European Farm Talks Are Halted by 3 Cows
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 15Three cows brought proceedings to a halt today at a meeting of the Common Market's Coun cil of Ministers called to dis cuss plans for European farm reform.

title: New Religious Communities: Alternative to Life in Convent
description: PITTSBURGH  I came to Family Service Corps be cause I felt there was more leeway here, more of a chance to be directly in volved with people without the isolation and regimenta tion of the convent, said Miss Francis Billat.

title: Florida Upsets Vols, 5655
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) Florida's Gators con tinued to play the role of S.E.C. spoilers tonight when they up set the Tennessee Vols, 5655, in the last second.

title: THEODORE BECKER
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15 (UPI) Theodore Becker, administrative director of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office in the Capitol, died yesterday at Albany Medical Center Hospital after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

title: 3 DEPUTY SHERIFFS ARE SLAIN IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS, Feb. 15 (AP) Three deputy sheriffs were shot to death today when they were overpowered by two men they were questioning about a bur glary, according to the police.

title: Peruvian Trade Surplus
description: LIMA, Peru, Feb. 15 (Reuters) Peru had a trade surplus of $388,479,000 in the first 11 months of 1970, the Central Bank announced today. The bank said Peruvian exports amounted to $966,200,000 and imports to $577,721,000.

title: HardPressed City Owes $81.3Million To Rainy Day Fund
description: Faced with a projected $1 billion deficit in his expense budget for fiscal 197172, Mayor Lindsay was con fronted yesterday with an other problemthe city's need to repay more than $81million to the rainy day fund.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.Fog beaded on window screens, fog and moisture filled the hollows, the melancholy moaning of fog horns in the waters surrounding the is land came across the wet, brown land, but we were listening to another sound the voices of two young hounds in the scrub oaks of M?? Vineyard in pursuit of cottontail rabbits.

title: Putting on the Dog Is Brisk Business
description: In all its yapping splendor, the exposition rotunda at Madison Square Garden was where all the dogs, noise, people and hawkers were yesterday at the 95th West minster Kennel Club Show.

title: MURPHY PROPOSES ECONOMY POLICING
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy last night urged new directions for crime prevention thatdid not incur new expendi tures.

title: CROWDS TURN OUT TO MARK HOLIDAY
description: There was the annual pa rade. There were the inevit able store sales, and there was a brief ceremony that recalled a windy battle on Harlem Heights in 1776.

title: MERCURY IN AIR STIRRING CONCERN
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 15  Mer cury, which has gained atten tion up to now as a contami nant in tuna and swordfish, is now stirring concern among scientists as a pollution prob lem in the air.

title: Phone Service Restored
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 15 The New York Telephone Com pany restored service today to 42,000 Westchester County subscribers whose phones were cut off yesterday when a water main break caused flooding in the White Plains central office.

title: Casualty Reports by U. S. Again Raise Skepticism
description: FIRE SUPPORT BASE VAN. DERGRIFT, South Vietnam, Feb. 14An enemy rocket made a direct hit two nights ago on an American bunker at this ar tillery base on Route 9 between Khesanh and Quangtri.

title: NETS DEAL STARS A 9889 SETBACK
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 15 (AP) The New York Nets, playing most of the second half without Rick Barry, posted 9889 American Basketball As sociation victory over Utah to night that broke the Stars' homecourt, winning streak at 12 games.

title: York Dispatch Resumes
description: YORK, Pa., Feb. 15 (UPI) The York Dispatch resumed publication today following a settlement of a pressmen's strike that had prevented publi cation Saturday. It was the first strike in the 95year history of the evening newspaper, which has a circulation of 47,000.

title: Italian Sacred Music Played By Metropolitan Opera Studio
description: When prosaic nations ad dress their gods, they mum ble and drone, or, in moments of high religious ecstasy, chant; the Italians sing arias. There is, at any rate, a strong theatrical strain running through much 19th century Italian sacred music, break ing out most grandly and operatically in the Verdi Requiem.

title: Army Aides Disturbed by Marked Decline in Percentage of Black Officers, Especially in Lower Ranks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 A marked decline in the percent age of black Army officers, particularly in the lower ranks, has occurred in recent years, and disturbed senior officials are studying ways in which re cruitment of black and other minority officer, candidates can be increased.

title: U.S. Strength in Vietnam Drops 2,100 to 332,900
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 (AP)The United States command announced today that the number of American troops in South Vietnam dropped by 2,100 last week to 332,900 and that 1,555 more were being pre pared for withdrawal.

title: Thant Seeks Quake Warning
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 15. (AP)SecretaryGen eral U Thant is suggesting study of the possibility of set ting up a. worldwide early warning system against earth quakes and other natural disas ters.

title: Richard, Trailing Hull in Goals, Says Scoring Is Easier Today
description: Maurice Richard once was the essence of hockey. When he retired a decade ago; his 544 regularseason goals were a National Hockey League mile stone. His competitive torch had guided the Montreal Ca nadiens to five consecutive Stanley Cup titles, a record. He held 21 various scoring rec ords.

title: Post Defeats Southampton In Overtime Game, 6761
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Feb. 15 C. W. Post scored the last points in overtime tonight and scored a 6761 victory over Southampton.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Even before the track and field season began, there was high puzzlement in high circles as to just how high the indoor pole vault record was. Officially recognized was the 17 feet 6 inches of Bob Seagren, the Olympic champion. But a freakish happen stance during the outdoor championships of the National Collegiate Athletic Asso ciation at Des Moines last June messed up the entire situation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REFORMS URGED IN DEGREE SYSTEM
description: Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia Univer sity, criticized American so ciety yesterday as being un usually taken up with creden tials and in many respects less interested in real achieve ments than in pieces of paper certifying proficiency.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) The Defense Department an ??ounced today the names of the following men from New York who have been killed in the Indochina war:

title: Tiger, Tiger, Burning Bright
description: NEW DELHIFirst of all the bare factsafter all this is what matters. Twenty years ago we in India had roughly 40,000 tigers in our jungles; now the latest census says 1,500.

title: Bridge: Mixed Pair Title Play Is Won By Joseph and Rosalind Low
description: The Mixed Pair Champion ship that on Monday ended the Greater New York Asso ciation's George Washington Birthday tournament at the New York Hilton was won by Joseph and Rosalind Low of New York. This fine perform ance in a field containing many wellknown stars cast further doubt on the theory that husbandandwife com binations are not effective in tournament play.

title: The Young Marijuana Sellers: Thousands Got Start as Users
description: Carl, a quiet, softspoken parttime student at the Uni versity of California, ran his fingers through the mound of brownishgreen flakes in a box lid on his lap and selected a pinch that suited him. As he rolled it deftly into a cigarette paper, he expained how he came to be a marijuana dealer.

title: $1.8Million to Aid OffCampus Studies
description: The Carnegie Corporation and the Ford Foundation have awarded the State University of New York and the State Education Department grants totaling $1.8million to help start two new offcampus de gree programs.

title: 3 Hurt in Coast Explosion
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) An explosion blew out four units of a twostory brick apartment building today, critically burning an elderly man and injuring two others, fire officials said. The explo sion was believed to have been caused by natural gas.

title: U.S.G.A. to Set Up Conference To Review Rules for Amateurs
description: Golfing amateurs have peti tioned the United States Golf Association for a review of the amateur code, Philip Strubing, president of the organization, disclosed yesterday.

title: STOCKS ON FENCE IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market virtually shrugged off yesterday's quar terpoint reduction in the prime rate and the similar cut in the discount rate late last Friday by closing just about on the fence.

title: AMEX STOCKS POST 4TH STRAIGHT GAIN
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange scored their fourth consecutive advance yesterday. The list rose in heavy trading.

title: Prices Dip in Bond Trading
description: It was a strange day yester day in the credit markets.

title: Bonanno's Son Admlts Guilt On Tax Evasion Charges
description: Salvatore (Bill) Bonanno, 38 yearold son of the reputed un derworld chieftain Joseph Bon anno, pleaded guilty yesterday to an indictment charging that he had concealed assets from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Antiwar Troupe Formed to Tour Bases
description: Jane Fonda, Mike Nichols and Elliott Gould are among a dozen wellknown entertainers who have formed a comedy troupe in the hope of touring military bases across the coun try with an antiwar stage show for the forgotten soldiers.

title: Will Lindsay Switch?
description: News Analysis

title: Laver Aiming at $100,000 In Playing Ralston Tonight
description: Dennis Ralston, who beats leading Australian tennis play ers with more regularity than he does American rivals, will attempt to end Rod Laver's perfect record in the $210,000 Tennis Champions Classic series tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: A BIGBOARD LIMIT ON FUNDS SOUGHT
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, one of the nation's leading mutual fund organizations, has urged the New York Stock Exchange to call a halt to the formation of mutual funds by member firms, pending a resolution of the issue of institutional access to the exchange.

title: Dewey Heads a Centennial
description: Former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, a member of the board of trustees of Roosevelt Hospi tal, was named yesterday to the honorary chairmanship of the hospital's centennial ob servance committee. H. Whit field Carhart, president of the hospital, said the institution entered its centennial year last Nov. 2 and would mark its 100th anniversary on Nov. 2 this year.

title: NEW YORK
description: Keeping up with the political moods and fads of the United States these days Is a puzzling business. They go up and down like women's skirts. Less than a year ago the university community and the black community were in a rebellious mood, and now, we are told, they are leaderless, di vided and apathetic.

title: Extension of I.O.S. Loan Of $5Million Is Weighed
description: GENEVA, Feb. 16The $5 million loan that the Inter national Controls Corporation of New Jersey made to Inves tors Overseas Services, Ltd., may be extended beyond its due date next May, an I.O.S. official said tonight.

title: Suns Pin 119to116 Defeat on Celtics
description: BOSTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Connie Hawkins of Phoenix scored 17 points in the last quarter today as the Suns de feated the Boston Celtics, 119 116, in a National Basketball Association game.

title: A Long Way From Sumter
description: Surely one of the more notable signs of the times is the wooing of black voters now proceeding in the Con gressional district of the late L. Mendel Rivers. A Negro may not succeed the Representative from Charleston, S. C., but that is beside the question. The point is that, thanks to voter registration drives, whoever is to win the Rivers seat will have to show as much regard for black citizens as if he were running in Detroit or Phila delphia.

title: 2 Persons Shot to Death While Locked in Car Trunk
description: EUSTIS, Fla. Feb. 16 (UPI)  Two thieves locked a Con necticut couple and a local real estate dealer in the trunk of a oar yesterday, then riddled it with bullets.

title: 1970 GAINS LISTED BY WESTERN UNION
description: The Western Union Corpora tion reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1970. Consolidated operating revenues and other income rose to $399,500,000 from $393,700,000 a year earlier. Net income increased to $23,350,000, equal to $2.28 a share, from $22,774,000, or $2.37 a share, in 1969. The average weighted shares out standing totaled 9,054,818 in 1970 compared with 8,426,079 a year earlier.

title: Cab Industry Urges Council Act Quickly on Rise in Fare
description: The Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, in telegrams sent yesterday to all members of the City Council, sought im mediate favorable action on its appeals for a fare increase.

title: City Seeks Donor to Offer $1,700 for 423 Neckties
description: A deputy said yesterday City Hall would be grateful if some civicminded citizen would con tribute $1,700 to pay for 423 blue neckties.

title: U.S. Approves Oil Accord In Hope of Price Stability
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The State Department today characterized the new inter national oil  price agreement reached Sunday in Teheran as the most satisfactory possible under the circumstances.

title: 22 ARE INDICTED IN CAROLINA RIOT
description: DARLINGTON, S.C., Feb. 16 A Darlington County grand jury indicted 22 men today on riot charges stemming from an incident last March 3 In Lamar, where two school buses were overturned by a white mob pro testing a school desegregation court order.

title: AUCTION BAR LIFTED FOR BANK IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP)  A restraining order specifically barring auction of some 39 per cent of stock in Detroit's Bank of the Commonwealth has been lifted by a Federal judge, al lowing the auction to be con ducted.

title: INDUSTRY OUTPUT ROSE IN JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  Industrial production rose in January, but the increase mainly reflected the recovery of automobile production from the General Motors strike.

title: Ailing Marr Leaves Tour
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) Dave Marr, the 37yearold pro, said today he would be away from the golf tour at least three months while recovering from mononucleosis. He was at his mother's home here.

title: Palmer Vaults to 3d Place On $56,126 Golf Earnings
description: Toni Shaw retained his moneywinning lead this week on the pro golf tour, but Arnold Palmer jumped from sixth to third after his victory in the Bob Hope Desert Classic Sun day.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Woo Labor Council
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16 The winter meetings here of the executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. are attracting leading Democratic possibilities for the 1972 Presidential race. But leadets of the 13.5million member federation, though flat tered by the clear implication that they have political clout, are taking some pains at this early stage to preserve an offi cially neutral stance.

title: Higher Cost for Wrong Numbers?
description: The New York Telephone Company, whose service has so grossly deteriorated in recent years, yesterday peti tioned the Public Service Commission for permission to charge higher rates. It gave a number of arguments for the increase, including one heavily touched with irony. Because its service is bad, the company said, additional revenues are required to improve it.

title: Chewing Gum May Soon Hit 8c
description: The nickel package of Wrigley chewing gum for which many New Yorkers have been paying 7 cents may soon cost them 8 cents at the corner drug or to bacco store.

title: Earl Wild Plays Liszt Piano Classics
description: Earl Wild's playing, by it self, gives enormous pleasure and excitement. The pianist has a technique that makes it possible for him to perform anything without apparent effort. He is incapable of making an ugly sound. Yet those were only means to an end in his recital in Alice Tully Hall Monday night.

title: A Times Reporter in Vietnam Wins a Polk Award
description: Gloria Emerson, a member of the news staff of The New York Times, was among the winners of 12 categories of George Polk Memorial Awards announced yesterday by the Brooklyn Cen ter of Long Island University for outstanding achievements in journalism during 1970.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Coleman Company, Inc., announced in Wichita yesterday the election of Lawrence M. Jones as president and Charles R. Henry as executive vice president. Mr. Jones, 39 years old, succeeds Sheldon Coleman, who has served as president for 20 years and remains chairman and chief executive officer. Both Mr. Jones and Mr. Henry were formerly senior vice presidents.

title: TwoWay Cable TV System Is Getting a Trial Here
description: An experimental twoway communications network, the precursor to a system whereby shopping, selling, polling, bank ing and a variety of social services could be performed electronically, is under way in Manhattan.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: We announce with deep sorrow the death of our dear friend and partner

title: Indian Party Stumps for New Symbol
description: BACHHRAWAN, India, Feb. 5We have many great hur dles to cross this time, said V. P. Mishra, a bloc leader for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party in this rural north Indian town. 'We must get the new symbol print ed and take it to all the vil lages so that the people will become familiar with it.

title: John B. Gellatly, Officer Of Real Estate Company
description: FAIR LAWN, N.J., Feb. 16 John B. Gellatly, assistant treasurer of Previews, Inc., in ternational realestate market ing organization with head quarters in New York, died of a heart attack at his home Sat urday. He was 59 years old and had been with Previews since 1935, when the concern was one year old.

title: ExCopeland Business Associate Is Indicted on Kickback Charges
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16Thomas A. Shaheen Jr., a former close business associate of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., was in dicted today by a Federal grand jury along with Joseph De Paola, president of the Journeymen Barbers, Hair dressers, Cosmetologists and Proprietors International Union of America.

title: Tel Aviv Revue Is Coming
description: Israel Folk Company, a re vue with 36 singers, musical soloists, drummers, mimes, com edians, musicians and folk dancers, will open on Broadway late in March. The group is from Tel Aviv and will be mak ing its American debut under the auspices of the American Canadian Concerts and Artists, Inc.

title: JOHN E. CLAREY
description: BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me., Feb. 16John E. Clarey, a for mer mayor of Madison, N. J., and former publisher of The Madison Eagle, died today of a heart attack. He was 83 years old.

title: Market Place: Plea for Caution In Stock Arena
description: There was a time when the New York Stock Exchange was telling everybody to buy a piece of American business. And even now, judging from the 20millionshare days we're seeing with increasing frequency, it would appear that everybody is doing just that.

title: Venezuela to Increase Price
description: VIENNA, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Venezuela, a supplier of the United States market, will in crease her oil prices next month by about 25 per cent, an oil official said here today.

title: Army Reform Plan Stirs Debate on Whether G.I. Will Have Needed Discipline in War
description: The United States Army's program to improve service life has precipitated a sharp debate in military circles here and abroad.

title: M'Phail Lauds Yankee Pitchers, Even Holdouts
description: Lee MacPhail, the Yankee general manager, says the team has a better pitching staff than Baltimore. But some of his pitchers apparently are having a difficult time convincing him he means what he says.

title: RABBI IS OUSTED BY CONGREGATION
description: The members of a 126year old Reform synagogue on the Upper East Side narrowly voted at an emotional meeting last night to oust their 37yearold rabbi.

title: A Colonel Is Given 3Year Drag Term
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16A United States Air Force colonel was sentenced today to three years in prison and was fined $15,000 for smoking marijuana, asking a sergeant in his squadron to get him some marijuana and giving some to four enlisted men.

title: Fred Iselin, Ski Instructor, CoAuthor of Two Books
description: ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 16 (AP) Fred Iselin, a Swiss native known in international ski circles, died in his sleep Sun day in this ski community. He was 57 years old.

title: Apple Growers' Loss, Shoppers' Gain
description: McIntosh apples  so good for snacks, so useful in cook ing  are selling at bargain prices these days.

title: R. A. STRITZINGER JR. OF BAKERY CONCERN
description: WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 16 Raymond K. Stritzinger Jr., retired chairman of the Con tinental Baking Company of New York, died here on Sun day. He was 82 years old.

title: Ali Feeds Fans a Potpourri of Tough Lip and Fast Fists Steamed in Hot Air
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 16 Muhammad Ali brought his act to the Fifth Street Gym today. Engaging in a special workout, with the public ad mitted at $1 a head, the former Cassius Clay, also the former heavyweight cham pion of the world, showed himself in top form, physical as well as vocal.

title: J. HARRY STEINKAMPF
description: YONKERS, Feb. 16J. Harry Steinkampf a partner in Shear son, Hammill & Co., Wall Street stockbrokers, from 1928 to 1950, died today in Lawrence Hospital after a short illness. He was 85 years old and lived here at 48 Bradford Boulevard.

title: Judah StraightSets Victor In Fowler Squash Racquets
description: Doug Judah of Heights Casino was the only player to advance in straight sets yester day in the opening round of the Fowler Memorial Class C squash racquets tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory. He defeated Richard Daniels of the University Club, 1512, 1815, 158.

title: NOBUKO IMAM VIOLA PLEASES IN RECITAL
description: Viola recitals tend to be rather predictable affairs ow ing to the sparse solo reper tory for this instrument. Even so, most of the music available to the violist is of exceptional ly high quality, and a good player can always make a pleas ing effect. Nobuko Imai is just such a finished musican, and her concert Monday night in Town Hall was in most respects a beauty.

title: Medal of Honor Given To 12 Posthumously
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)With President Nixon looking on, the Medal of Honor was presented today to the families of 12 men killed in Vietnam.

title: MRS. K. A. L. FOSTER
description: Mrs. Jane Culbertson Foster, the wife of Kendall A. L. Foster, executive director of the AHEAD Foundation and consultant of Toyomenka, Inc., died on Monday at New York Hospital. She was 56 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Vouet Painting Is Sold To Cincinnati Museum
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The Cincinnati Art Museum has acquired a painting by the 17century master Simon Vouet that had hung in a hotel here for 57 years. The purchase price was not divulged.

title: Bucks Win, 135103
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The Milwaukee Bucks outscored the Buffalo Braves, 3910, in the final quarter tonight on their way to a 135103 victory.

title: Senator Seeks to Block Atom Plants
description: Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, an nounced last night that he would sponsor a bill to im pose a moratorium on the construction of nuclear pow er plants, and to make utili ties financially responsible for nuclear accidents.

title: State Plans Prize Of $25,000 a Year For Life in Lottery
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16  A new state lottery prize of $25,000 a year for life, with a guaran teed minimum of $500,000, was announced today by the State Tax Commissioner, Norman Gellman.

title: Queen Elizabeth Under Tow
description: MIAMI, Feb. 16 (Reuters) The former Cunard luxury liner Queen Elizabeth, crippled by boiler failure in the Caribbean, was taken under tow by a com mercial tug today, the United States Coast Guard here re ported. A spokesman said that the 83,000ton vessel, on her way to Hong Kong to become a float ing university, was being towed toward Kingston, Jamaica.

title: IMPEACH NIXON, G.O.P FOE URGES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Representative Paul N. McClos key Jr., Republican of Califor nia, said tonight that President Nixon should be threatened with impeachment as a means of changing the Administra tion's Vietnam policy.

title: Democratic Convention Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The following table shows the effects of the proposed revisions in the allocation of votes at the 1972 Democratic National Convention:

title: CANADIANS WARY ON MERCURY RATE
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 16Canadian officials who in 1969 set the world's strictest levels for mer cury contamination permitted in fish said today that these levels might have to be made even more stringent.

title: Ethiopian Church Struggles to Find Leaders
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia Several mornings a week Alaka Baye Alemu leaves his mud walled home in Lalibala and walks to the nearby Emmanuel Church. He reads prayers for three hours, returns home for breakfast and then sets out for a day of work in his fields.

title: Counterfeit Money Seized
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16 (AP) Secret Service agents an nounced today the seizure of about $1million in counterfeit $20 notes from a farm in ad joining St. Charles County and at a print shop in St. Louis County. Charles Peyton, agent in charge, said that the seizures appeared to have cracked a counterfeit ring that may have operated on a national scale.

title: Pennsylvania Aide Named
description: HARRISBURG, Feb. 16 (AP) Gov Milton J. Shapp today named Dr. J, Finton Speller, 60 years old, of Philadelphia, as his Secretary of Health. Dr. Speller, a Negro, has headed the Social Health Section of the Philadelphia County Health Department for 11 years.

title: McGill Assails Class Disruption And Insists on Right to Teach
description: Dr. William J. McGill, presi dent of Columbia University, has condemned the attempt by a group of militant students to disrupt class in political science last Friday afternoon.

title: NASTASE PRESSED TO WIN IN TENNIS
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 16 (AP)The defending champion, Ilie Nastase of Rumania, was given a stern test tonight by 18 yearold Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., in gaining the third round of the $50,000 na tional indoor open tennis championships.

title: Blues Trounce Seals, 51
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16 (UPI) The St. Louis Blues scored three goals against the Califor nia goalie, Gary Smith, in the first four minutes tonight and went on to a 51 National Hockey League victory over the Golden Seals.

title: The Eager Claimants
description: There is no shortage of eager claimants for President Nixon's power. One DemocratSenator McGovern of South Dakotahas already announced his candidacy. A halfdozen others are busily testing the political atmos phere and scouting about for support.

title: LEAP Is Making Big Strides on the Lower East Side
description: It started in 1962 with a storefront, boys and what ever Cash and time, its two middleclass founders could spare, It was a social club for Puerto Rican street kids of the lower East Side and its main activity that year was free judo lessons.

title: U.S. Athletes Win at Riga
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (UPI) United States athletes won three events today in a track and field meet at Riga, Tass, the Soviet press agency, re ported from the Latvian capi tal. Glen Norman was timed in 57.1 seconds in winning the 400 meters, Katherine Jones dash in 6.2 seconds and Barry Shepard took the high jump at 7 feet  inch.

title: School Drug Programs Get $7Million
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16Governor Rockefeller announced today the approval of grants totalling $7.1million to the Board of Education, six community school boards and a private school, all in New York City, for narcotics treatment and prevention programs.

title: PAYMENTS DEFICIT STEADY FOR 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The underlying deficit in the United States balance of pay ments in 1970 was probably not much different from the $4.5billion underlying deficit in 1969, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: We announce with deep sorrow the death of our friend and associate

title: NADER SUPPORTS CITY AD PROPOSAL
description: Ralph Nader yesterday backed a proposed city regula tion that would require adver tisers who make comparative claims or use testimonials in their copy to be able to sub stantiate them if asked to do so by the Consumer Affairs Department.

title: Control Data Has Loss;
description: The Control Data Corpora tion went $2.7million into the red in 1970, a sum that would have been much larger but for the contribution of its Com mercial Credit Corporation sub sidiary, according to a report released by the Minneapolis based company yesterday.

title: David Burns Signed for Role
description: David Burns has been signed for a starring role in 70, Girls, 70, the new musical by John Kander, Fred Ebb and Norman L. Martin, which is scheduled to open on Broadway In April.

title: Briton Scores Knockout
description: LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP) Ralph Charles of Britain, the European welterweight cham pion, knocked out Bob Wil liams of Memphis, Tenn., in the third round of their sched uled 10round fight at Royal Albert Hall tonight. In a co feature Alan Rudkin of Britain won the European bantam weight title by stopping the defending champion. Franco Zurlo of Italy, in the 11th.

title: Syria Names a Parliament
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 16 (AP)Syria established her first parliament in six years to night by government decree. The Damascus radio announced the move and broadcast the names of the 173 members ap pointed by the Government.

title: Phone Company Seeking 29% Rise in State Rates
description: The New York Telephone Company, conceding the ex istence of service problems in some areas, asked the Public Service Commission yesterday to approve a twostage rate increase that would increase the customers' basic rate by 29.1 per cent and bring in $391million in additional rev enue annually.

title: Building for Elderly Burns
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 16 (UPI)One man was seriously burned and at least five others were treated for smoke inhalation early today when fire broke out on the top floor of a 13story apartment complex for senior citizens. The authorities said the remaining 186 occupants of The Pikes Peak Towers were evacuated without serious injury.

title: Grosses Up Along With 7:30 Curtain
description: The new 7:30 evening cur tain time, instituted on Jan. 4, is being credited for the recent increase in weekly grosses by a majority of Broadway legitimate theater owners.

title: EUROPE APOLLO ROLE IS STILL NOT SETTLED
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16Nearly a year after President Nixon; invited the European nations to take part in the first Apollo (program of space exploration, the two sides still fail to agree on how this could be done.

title: A Correction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  In the first two editions of The New York Times of Feb. 11, a Washington dispatch on the meeting of President Nixon with the National Industrial Pollution Control Council said that the Justice Department had filed an antipollution suit against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. This statement, based on information supplied by the Justice Department, was incorrect. Although some plants of Bethlehem Steel are not in compliance with water quality standards, they have been given time to correct the pollution. No suit has been filed against the company. The Times regrets the error.

title: Erich Leinsdorf Conducts Cleveland Orchestra
description: As a way of giving strength and interest to the concert edi fice, there is nothing more ef fective than stark contrast. Erich Leinsdorf, who conducted the Cleveland Orchestra at Car negie Hall on Monday night, demonstrated that with a pro gram that neatly balanced the finely spun steel wire of Mozart against the torsionless con struction beams of Bruckner.

title: Governor of Alaska Favors Oil Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI)Gov. William A. Egan of Alaska said yesterday that the prosperity of his state and its people hinged on ap proval of the controversial transAlaskan oil pipeline.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe argument about the news embargo at the start of Laotian operations has become as ridiculous as it is bitter and distorted. What is wholly forgotten is the fact that Amer ican and other reporters in Indochina have been permitted to operate with a freedom, not to say abandon, that would have seemed paradisaical to their older colleagues of World War II.

title: W. Claude Fields Jr. Dies; Lawyer, Son of Comedian
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 W. Claude Fields Jr., lawyer and a son of the late W. C. Fields, died today in St. John's Hospital, Santa Monica. He was in his sixties. His father the comedian died in 1946.

title: A Limited Seabed Treaty
description: Three years ago Maltese Ambassador Arvid Pardo called on the United Nations to ban military activities on the ocean floor and to reserve the resources of the seabed for use in the interests of mankind. The treaty signed by 62 nations at ceremonies in Washington, Lon don and Moscow the other day represents a timid step toward achieving Ambassador Pardo's farsighted objec tives and the broader goal of nuclear disarmament.

title: Mets Are in Familiar Hole: Third Baseman Is Needed
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 16On the eve of spring train ing, the New York Mets suf fered a reversal today when their regular third baseman, Wayne Garrett, was called to active duty by the Army.

title: PICKETING IS BARRED AT NEWARK PAPER
description: NEWARK, Feb. 16A Federal judge issued a restraining order today prohibiting picketing by pressmen at the Newark Star Ledger.

title: Used Car Buyer Protection
description: CONCORD, N.H. Feb. 16 (UPI) A measure introduced today in the New Hampshire Legisla ture would require sworn state ments on the mileage and any physical damage over $500 to cars being sold second hand.

title: Controversial Commerce Chief Maurice Hubert Stans
description: Man in the News

title: Wallace Johnson Is Dead at 81; Among Tennis Leaders of 20's
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UPD)  Wallace Ford John son, former tennis star of na tional ranking and tennis coach at the University of Pennsyl vania for nearly 30 years, died yesterday at Bryn Mawr Hos pital. He was 81 years old.

title: American Legion Hears Nixon Plea For a Strong U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Presi ??ent Nixon told several thou and members of the American ??egion tonight that the United States must remain as strong in peacetime as it has been in war ??ime in order to maintain the ??eace.

title: U.S. STUDY URGED IN TOMBS DEATH
description: Four members of Congress asserted yesterday, that a Man hattan grand jury investigating an inmate's death in the Tombs may be whitewashing this mat ter and possibly sweeping the facts under the rug.

title: 1,500 AT FUNERAL FOR J. C. PENNEY
description: J. C. Penney, founder of the department store chain who died last Friday at the age of 95, was eulogized at his funer al yesterday as a true prac titioner of the Golden Rule.

title: Ryun Enters Coast Mile
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 16 (AP) Jim Ryun, the holder of the world mile record at 3:51.1, said today lie would compete in Friday's San Diego Indoor Games.

title: Lon Nol Is Gaining
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Premier Lon Nol of Cam bodia is receiving two daily ses sions of therapy, a spokesman at Tripler General Hospital said today. The Premier, who was flown here during the weekend for treatment of partial paraly sis after a stroke, continues to show, progress in his rehabilita tion program, the spokesman said.

title: JOSEPH BERNHARD
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 16Joseph Bernhard, re tired chairman of Conso Prod ucts Company of New York, died at his home here on Mon day after a short illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Charge Dismissed Against 2 Accused Of Hiding Berrigan
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 16 (AP)Indictments against Dr. William Stringfellow, a theolo gian, and Anthony Towne, a poet, charging them with har boring the Rev. Daniel J. Berri gan, were dismissed today in United States District Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Defeat as Capital Brings New Reggio Calabria Riots
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Wednesday, Feb. 17 (AP)Dem onstrators fired guns at the po lice and attacked them with stones and fire bombs yester day In an outburst of anger over losing the fight to make Reggio Calabria the regional capital. A civilian was wounded, in the head by a stray bullet. The police said they did not return the protesters' gunfire.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FRESHMEN GIVEN VARSITY RIGHTS
description: Major Eastern colleges, which had long prohibited the use of freshmen on varsity teams, gave limited approval yesterday to their participation.

title: Fashion Director Of Hess's, Is Dead
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Feb. 16 Gerard W. Golden, fashion di rector of Hess's, department store here, died yesterday at the age of 55.

title: Advertising: Interpublic Gets a New Chief
description: Paul Foley, chairman and chief executive of McCann Erickson, will move up to the Interpublic Group of Companies on April 1 as president and chief execu tive.

title: Greece Jails U.S. Airman
description: ATHENS, Feb. 16A Greek court today sentenced Airman William Hanson of Seattle to 14 months in prison, and a Greek businessman to seven years, on charges of rape, cor ruption of minors, use of nar cotics and illegal possession of arms. A United States Air Force sergeant was found innocent of the charges after the threeday trial.

title: Tate Trial Jurors Allowed To Go Home Every Night
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) Jurors in the Sharon Tate murder trial, who have been locked up nightly for seven months to avoid exposure to possibly prejudicial publicity, were told today that they could live at home during the remaining days of the gentenc ling hearing.

title: Aides Confirm That Nixon Is Weighing PriceWage Freeze in Construction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 High Government officials con firmed today that President Nixon is considering imposing a price and wage freeze in the construction industry. This would mark a partial reversal of the President's longstand ing opposition to controls.

title: WILLIAM P. FORTUNE
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 16 William P. Fortune, a retired millinery manufacturer, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. His age was 68; he lived at 720 Cedar Road, Southport.

title: Hunter Beats Brooklyn Five
description: Hunter College raised its wonlost record to 17 and 2 and its Knickerbocker Confer ence mark to 80 with a 72 59 victory over Brooklyn Col lege, last night. Bill Gallagher led Hunter and Bob Kronish was high for Brooklyn with 18 points each.

title: CITY UNIT ENTERS DISPUTE AT A. & P.
description: The city's Commission on Human Rights has started a fullfledged investigation into allegations that the A. & P. food store chain discriminates against minority groups in its hiring and promotion practices.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MOONSCAPE FOOLED HIKERS NEAR CRATER
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) Scientists reported today that two men of the Apollo 14 crew had been fooled by the barren lunar landscape and had turned back within 160 feet of a crater that was one of their prime, objectives on the moon.

title: Trading Is Started In Tomato Futures
description: Tomatoes are a Juicy, ripe business. Consumption of can ned tomato productsfrom the peeled varieties to paste for pizza to sauce for spaghetti exceeds 10 billion pounds a year. The figure does not in clude the large numbers of tomatoes that appear, sliced fresh, on salads and in sand wiches.

title: Saigon Seeks to Shift Talks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 16 (Reuters)South Vietnam will suggest at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris on Thurs day that the meetings be moved to Southeast Asia, Foreign Min ister Tran Van Lam said today.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS HOUSING BIAS BILL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 16Governor Rockefeller sent to the Legisla ture today five antidiscrimina tion bills, one of which would subject to the provisions of the state's Human Rights Law all houses where rentals are involved, apartments and com mercial boarding houses.

title: Health Stand Reversed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said to day that it had reversed its position and would provide $16.4million this year for con struction of new acutecare hospital facilities.

title: MESKILL PROPOSES A SALES TAX OF 7% FOR CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 16  Gov. Thomas J. Meskill called today for an increase in the Connecticut state sales tax to 7 per cent, a level that would make it the highest in the coun try. At the same time, the Gov ernor urged that the tax, now 5 per cent, be applied to a number of previously exempted items.

title: U. S. OPPOSES PLAN BY ISRAEL TO BUILD NEAR JERUSALEM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The State Department took sharp issue today with Israel's plans to construct large hous ing projects in the hills around Jerusalem captured from Jordan during the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Debray Leaves Chile for Cuba With Study of Allende Regime
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 16 Regis Debray, a French ex ponent of Marxist revolution in Latin America, left for Cuba to day carrying a manuscript of a study he has prepared on Socialist prospects in Chile under President Salvador Al lende Gossens.

title: Charles L. Bergmann, 64, Dies; Wall Street Railroad Expert
description: Charles L. Bergmann, a se curities executive closely asso ciated with railroad financing and mergers for many years, died in St. Luke's Hospital Monday after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 403 Lenox Avenue, South Or ange, N. J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Although most American Jews re main vitally concerned with Israel's security, a small but growing number of Jewish youth have become disen chanted with Israel. A few actually support the Palestinian terrorists. In 1969 a delegation of Students for a Democratic Society visited Amman to express solidarity with the Pales tinians. Some of the group were Jewish.

title: Prime Rate Is Cut to 5%;
description: The banking industry lopped another  point from its prime lending rate yesterday, bringing this increasingly sensitive charge to topquality corporate customers to 5 per cent, the lowest level since November, 1967.

title: Basque Repression Seen
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 16 (Reuters) Two world labor organiza tions charged today that the Spanish Government had en gaged in a vast repression of workers in the Basque prov inces since the courtmartial of 16 Basque nationalists in December.

title: Medical Complex Aims to Build Over Drive
description: A complex of major hospitals, medical schools and research institutions on Manhattan's East Side has prepared a pre liminary plan for a $300million expansion above the East River Drive.

title: Moscow Assails a Conference Set for Belgium on Soviet Jews
description: MOSCOW, Feb, 16  The Soviet Union assailed today the convening of a world Jewish conference in Brussels next week to discuss the question of Soviet Jews.

title: GEORGE LYON DIES; EXEDITOR WAS 80
description: George H. Lyon, a New York newspaperman, editor and pub lic relations consultant, died yesterday In Jamaica Hospital of pneumonia after a brief ill ness. He was 80 years old and lived at 8838 195th Street, Hollis, Queens.

title: $10BILLION ASKED FOR 110 NEW CITIES
description: David Rockefeller chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, proposed yesterday that a corporation be created to raise $10billion in private invest ment to begin development of 110 new American cities.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At about this time 13 years ago Horace Stoneham of the New York Giants and Walter O'Malley of the Brooklyn Dodgers were packing their carpetbags and head ing for the Golden West to make their fortunes, one club as the San Francisco Giants and the other as the Los Angeles Dodgers. They struck it rich from the start. But where Walter is still doing well, even if on a somewhat reduced scale, Horace is in trouble.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON RECORD ADVANCE
description: The London stock market closed firm in quiet trading yes terday. The possibility of a set tlement of Britain's long postal strike created a confident at mosphere as buyers returned to the market. RollsRoyce stock again attracted speculative in terest. Its price fluctuated sharply, with the high at about 48 cents.

title: For Fellini's Next Film, Favorite Subject: Rome
description: ROME  With Federico Fellini's latest picture, The Clowns, having been pre sented on television and now in the cinema houses, the director has turned his at tention to another subject dear to him: Rome. The Clowns was a freewheeling documentary in which the marked influence of the circus on Mr. Fellini was amusingly explained. His film on Rome will also have sug gestions of a documentary.

title: DANIEL DOMB HEARD IN MUSEUM RECITAL
description: Daniel Domb made an im pressive debut in 1963 as a win ner of the Concert Artists Guild award, but the Israeliborn cellist has appeared here rarely since then. Now 26 years old and a teacher at the Oberlin Conservatory, Mr. Domb gave his only New York recital of the season Monday night at the Metropolitan Musem.

title: C.B.S. Payroll Cuts Wait on Budget Allotments
description: Personnel cuts in some major groups of the Columbia Broad casting System will be briefly deferred because of the com plexity of determining how many persons must be dis charged to meet the required reductions in the company's budget. A final tally had been expected Friday night.

title: CPC Earnings Set High
description: Sales and earnings of CPC International set records last year and in the final quarter, with foreign business contrib uting more than half of the re turns, Howard C. Harder, chair man, reported yesterday.

title: Army Questions Con Edison On Effects of Astoria Plan
description: The Army Corps of En gineers asked the Consoli dated Edison Company, yes terday to submit a five point statement on the en vironmental impact of its controversial 800,000kilowatt Astoria, Queens, electric pow er project, which requires an Army permit for the East River work involved.

title: Bulls Set Back Hawks
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (UPI) Jerry Sloan's 32 points led the Chicago Bulls to a 118102 vic tory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: LAIRD EXPECTING SOME TOUGH DAYS IN LAOS CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird advised President Nixon and members of the Cabinet today to expect some tough days ahead in the allied ef fort to cut the Ho CM Minh Trail supply line In southern Laos.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DICK GIBSON SHOW. By Stanley Elkin. 335 pages. Random House, $6,95.

title: BIG 4 AIDES CONFER ON BERLIN QUESTION
description: BERLIN, Feb. 16  Political advisers from Britain, France and the United States met here today with their Soviet coun terparts for the third time since the West submitted its new position paper on Berlin on Feb. 5.

title: Poland's Authorities Rule Out More Concessions to Workers
description: WARSAW, Feb. 16  The Polish people were told today that the decision to restore food prices to pre  December levels represented the last ma jor economic concession left to the Government.

title: English Springer Spaniel Is Selected as Best at the 95th Westminster Show
description: An English springer spaniel, Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, who answers to the name of D. J., was named best last night at the 95th show of the West minster Kennel Club at Madison Square Garden. 0. Carley Har riman of Pebble Beach, Calif., required 12 minutes to judge the final and choose the dog owned by Dr. Milton Prickett of Lexington, Ky., ending the twoday event, which had 3,031 entries.

title: Admiral May Stop Making Color TV Picture Tubes
description: The color television industry appeared yesterday to be los ing another picturetube manu facturer. The Admiral Corpora tion and the RCA Corporation confirmed that they were hav ing discussions over the possi ble sale to RCA of Admiral's color TV picturetube manufac turing equipment.

title: Winner Chosen From 3,031 Entries Called A Nearly Perfect Dog by the Judge
description: I used to work in an of fice, said Sue Baines yes terday, and I never thought it would be possible to make a living running around on weekends with a dog.

title: BRITISH POST OFFICE BARS MEDIATION BID
description: LONDON, Feb. 16 (Reuters) The Post Office tonight dis couraged hopes of an end to Britain's 27day postal strike by turning down a plea by Tom Jackson, leader of the 230,000member Union of Pos tal Workers, for a mediator in negotiations.

title: Mexico City Bars Old Taxis
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16 (UPI) The police today banned taxis more than eight years old from this capital's streets. The department said it would no longer issue licenses to cabs manufactured in 1963 or earlier to make transportation safer.

title: Kennedy Expansion Into Bay Assailed In Federal Report
description: A Federal study group has drawn up a report strongly op posing proposals for immediate major expansion of Kennedy International Airport into Ja maica Bay.

title: Rollbar Cage Gets Victor's Flag For LifeSaving Role at Daytona
description: About Motor Sports

title: PENN CENTRAL SUED ON INSURING OF AIDES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb, 16 (AP) Lloyd's of London filed suit in the Federal District Court here today against the Penn Central Transportation Com pany seeking to rescind a $10 million insurance policy cover ing 71 railroad officers and di rectors against liability for im proper conduct of their offices. Lloyd's was joined in the suit by 16 underwriting companies.

title: Air Force to Try 14 In Study of Misuse Of Mess Hall Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) The Air Force announced to day that it would courtmartial two officers and 12 noncommis sioned officers charged with mishandling mess hall funds in Thailand.

title: Madrid Liberalizes Law on Labor Syndicates, but Only Slightly
description: MADRID, Feb. 16After three years of debate, false starts, new drafts and strenu ous political infighting, the Spanish regime has enacted law regulating the status of labor organizations here.

title: U.S. Says East Germans Hold American Deserter
description: BERLIN, Feb. 17  The United States authorities said today that an American army deserter was in jail in East Ger many on charges of having at tempted to flee the country.

title: SAIGON LABOR CHIEF ASSAILS U.S. POLICY
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 16 The head of the main federa tion of labor unions in South Vietnam said today that he feared that the United States and its allies were putting too much emphasis on winning militarily while leaving the Vietcong free to build up their political apparatus.

title: Delegate Reform: A Democratic Showdown
description: News Analysis

title: DETECTIVE TELLS OF PANTHER ROLE
description: Ralph White, a detective as signed to infiltrate the Black Panther party, played a very active leadership role in the New York branch, it was brought out yesterday by one of the lawyers for 13 Black Panthers on trial in State Supreme Court.

title: Reserve's Role Debated
description: Economic Analysis

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today, the following spot primary prices for the week ended Feb. 9.

title: Two Children Die in Crash
description: RADFORD, Va., Feb. 16 (AP) Two school children were killed and 23 were injured to day when a school bus and a truck collided seven miles northeast of here. The police said the truck, loaded with dirt, struck the school bus broad side at an intersection.

title: EXCONVICT SOUGHT IN 3 TEXAS KILLINGS
description: DALLAS, Feb. 16 (Reuters) The police pressed a search in this state today for a former convict charged with the slay ing of three sheriff's deputies in West Dallas last night.

title: GENERAL FOODS SETS SWEDISH ACQUISITION
description: The General Foods Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy for cash all the outstand ing shares of Victor Th. Engwall & Co., KB, Sweden's largest coffee processor.

title: JURY TOLD OF PLOT TO MELT SILVER
description: A coin dealer testified yester day that he joined Joseph Co lombo Jr. and two other men in a scheme to melt silver coins after he had suffered a $50,000 business loss.

title: FILM SOCIETY GETS A $216,000 GRANT
description: The Film Society of Lincoln Center has been awarded a grant of $216,000 by the Helena Rubinstein Foundation for the innovation and presentation of a series of films for children.

title: WHITE HOUSE PUTS ITS TRUST IN STANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The White House expressed total confidence today in Sec retary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans, who faces a possible conflictofinterest investigation into some of his stockholdings.

title: Missile Sites in North Vietnam Attacked by U. S. 3d Day in Row
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 17American jets attacked missile sites in North Vietnam yesterday for the third successive day, the United States command an nounced today.

title: SANITY UNIT FINDS CALLEY NORMAL
description: FORT KENNING, Ga., Feb. 16 First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., accused of murdering at least 102 unarmed Vietnamese civilians during the socalled Mylai massacre, has been found normal in every re spect by an Army sanity board.

title: ABM System Head Named
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Secretary, of Defense Melvin R. Laird named Maj. Gen. Walker P. Leber today to head the Army's Safeguard antibal listic missile program now be ing deployed at intercontinen tal ballistic sites. General Leber, who has been governor of the Panama Canal Zone since 1967, succeeds Lt. Gen. Alfred D. Starbird, who will retire April 1.

title: RESERVE OFF TARGET ON MONEY EXPANSION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The Federal Reserve's Open garket Committee has been experi encing some difficulty in achiev ing its targets for expansion of the money supply, reports of the November and December meetings indicated today.

title: Dr. Ruth Guy Dieuaide, 80, Retired Pediatrician, Dies
description: Dr. Ruth Guy Dieuaide, a re tired pediatrician, died Monday in St, Joseph's Hospital, Stam ford, Conn., after a long illness. She was 80 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street here.

title: Woodcock Criticizes A.M.A. On U.S. Health Statistics
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 (UPI) The president of the United Automobile Workers, Leonard Woodcock, said today the American Medical Association had been reporting carefully selected facts which conceal the truth about the deteriorat ing health status of Americans.

title: LOUIS PAUL JONAS, ANIMAL SCULPTOR
description: CHURCHTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 16 (AP)Louis Paul Jonas, the sculptor who designed the di nosaurs shown at the New York World's Fair of 196465, died yesterday. He was 77 years old.

title: FORD'S PROFIT UP BY 5%IN QUARTER
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16The Ford Motor Company reported today fourthquarter net income of $151million, or $1.40 a share, up 5 per cent from $144million, or $1.33, the year before.

title: The Hillsides of Jerusalem
description: The Israeli Housing Ministry's announced plan to push ahead with the construction of new housing for Israelis on former Arab lands in East Jerusalem constitutes a serious threat to the future of the Holy City and to the cause of peace.

title: 6 Students Seized on IRT In Robberies and Muggings
description: Six youths described by the police as students at Julia Richman High School were ar rested yesterday in connection with the mugging and robbery of two Bronx women on a northbound Lexington Avenue IRT local at the 103d Street sta tion.

title: Kollek Bars U.S. Suggestion
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 16  Mayor Teddy Kollek said to night that Israel's right to build housing developments in the former Arab territories around. Jerusalem is a right that cannot be shaken.

title: BRILIOTH APPEARS AS MET FLORESTAN
description: Helge Brilioth, singing the role of Florestan for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera Monday night, produced a fine crackle of theatrical electricity when he finally got his chance to sing in the second act.

title: Kansas Geologists Oppose a Nuclear Waste Dump
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 16  A state geological report, sharply critical of plans to build a permanent nuclear waste dump in a central Kansas salt mine, was made public today amid rising opposition to the project.

title: 41 Policemen Are Subpoenaed By Knapp Unit in Betting Inquiry
description: The Knapp Commission in vestigating allegations of cor ruption within the New York Police Department has sub poenaed the 41 policemen as signed to enforcing antigambl ing laws in the northwest corner of Manhattan.

title: Beaned Golf Star Hart In Tennis With Agnew
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) Doug Sanders, once hit in the head by one of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's errant golf balls, today was at home in a wheelchair with injuries suf fered in a tennis match with the Vice President.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kutztown Appoints Coach
description: KUTZTOWN, Pa., Feb. 16 (AP)Lee L. Hill, a former semiprofessional soccer play er, was named today to coach soccer and lacrosse at Kultz town State College.

title: Shah Seen Strengthened
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 16  The Shah of Iran has strength ened his position as the dom inant political figure In the Persian Gulf through his active and successful role in the Teheran oil negotiations.

title: Steel Production in Nation Showed Increase for Week
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday rose 1.6 per cent, from the week before, the American Iron and Steel In stitute reported in Washington yesterday.

title: Husak Instructs Czech Lawyers To Halt Dunning of 1968 Exiles
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 16 (Reuters)  The Czechoslovak Commu nist party leader, Gustav Husak. said today that lawyers had been ordered to stop sending refugees in the West demands for money to pay the defense costs at their trials in absen tia.

title: Maxon Shirt Plant to Close
description: Oxford Industries of Atlanta announced yesterday that it planned to close its Maxon Shirt Company operation in Greenville, S. C., by the end of April

title: A Senate Vote on Filibuster Rule Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  The future of electoral reform for the next two years may be decided on Thursday when the Senate takes a key procedural vote on a technically unrelated subject  modification of its filibuster rule.

title: Israelis Charge Deletions
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 16Israeli officials charged today that all references to the recognition of Israel's territorial integrity and the possibility of making peace expressed by President Anwar elSadat of the United Arab Re public in his interview with Newsweek magazine published this week were deleted from a version circulated today by the Egyptian Middle East News Agency.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Backs N.B.A. in Haywood Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 (AP)  The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today the National Basketball Asso ciation could penalize the Se attle SuperSonics if the Sonics continued to play Spencer Hay wood while an appeal on the legality of his contract was still pending.

title: Theater: Phoenix's School for Wives, a Treasure
description: We never get enough classic theater in New York. Certainly we don't get enough classic theater of the quality of the Phoenix Thea ter's producton of Moliere's The School for Wives, which opened last night at the Lyceum Theater. It once more shows that Molire can be funny, blithe and totally enchanting.

title: Negro in Social Register a Poet First
description: He's a poet and she's a painter, and somehow that seems more important to a young couple collaborating on a labor of love than, say, the fact that she is a prod uct of the Philadelphia Main Line and he came out of the South Side of Chicago; or that the former Susan Rush Hoffman is white and her husband, Meredith Shannon Johns Jr., is not.

title: CAHILL PRESENTS PRESENTS AUSTERITY BUDGET Asks $1.78Billion Outlay That Avoids New Taxes
description: TRENTON, Feb. 16Gov. William T. Cahill recommended to the New Jersey Legislature today a $1.78billion austerity state budget that sought to avoid any new or increased taxes in a legislative election year.

title: CANUCKS TRIUMPH OVER BRUINS, 54
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Feb. 16 (UPI)Rosaire Pele ment scored three goals, Includ ing the winning one with 47 seconds remaining, and made one assist tonight as the Van couver Canucks scored a 54 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game.

title: Aide of Cabinet Panel Named
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (UPI) The White House announced today the appointment of An tonio F. Rodriquez as executive director of the Cabinet Com mittee on Opportunities for the Spanish Speaking. Mr. Rod riquez has been the commis sioner of the American section of the United StatesMexico Commission for Development and Friendship since 1969.

title: Marinaro and Kiarsis Win Eastern Football Honors
description: Ed Marinaro of Cornell and Dave Kiarsis of Trinity of Connecticut, the national groundgaining leaders in major and smallcollege foot ball last season, were honored as the East's football players of the year at the annual Eastern College Athletic Con ference Awards dinner last night.

title: Fire in Americana Put Out
description: Firemen put out a small fire last night on the 33d floor of the 50story Americana Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 52d Street. There were no injuries.

title: Vietnamese General and a G.I. Who Want to See Victory
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 14Brig. Gen. Pham Van Phu, commander of the First Infantry Division, which is among the forces pushing into southern Laos, and Specialist Charles Heffley of Brighton, Colo., have not met, although they work here a few hundred yards of each other.

title: Rendel Is Again Voted Dog Writer of Year
description: John Bendel, who retired recently after 45 years with The New York Times, was voted the dog writer of the year for the third time in a nationwide poll conducted by the Gaines Dog Research Center of White Plains.

title: Pistons Subdue Bullets
description: DETROIT, Feb. 16 (UPI)  The Detroit Pistons held the Baltimore Bullets to 34 points in the second half tonight in scoring a 11095 victory.

title: U.S. JUDGE CLEARS 3 IN MINE UNION SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) All charges were dropped to day against three defendants in a $75million conspiracy dam age suit involving the leader ship of the softcoal industry.

title: KNICKS TROUNCED BY LAKERS,130115
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Feb. 16 Willis Reed returned to the New York Knicks' lineup to night, but the Knicks were badly outsped and outgunned in the second half by the Los Angeles Lakers and lost, 130115.

title: Twins Give Killebrew First $100,000 Contract
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 16 (UPI)Harmon Killebrew accepted a Minnesota Twins contract for 1971 that will put him over the $100,000 mark, the club president, Cal vin Griffith, said today.

title: Showing How Real People Look in Hot Pants
description: There was something of a hot pants Jamboree at Alex ander's yesterday. Models were modeling them, ??e girls with chubby thighs were modeling them, men were modeling them, and a little girl named Pamela was modeling them.

title: Republicsteel Cuts Dividend
description: Directors of the Republic Steel Corporation reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday to 40 cents a share, payable March 19 to stockholders of record Feb, 26, from 62 cents paid quarterly since November, 1966.

title: Cornell 30 Hockey Victor
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 16 Cornell scored in each period to defeat St. Lawrence, 30, to night in a penaltyfilled hockey game at Lynah Rink.

title: New Boss At Chanel
description: PARIS, Feb. 16 (UPI) Gaston Berthelot, former de signer of readytowear for the Christian Dior firm in Paris and New York, has been named artistic co ordinator to replace, more or less, the late designer, Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel.

title: Fordham Eyes Notre Dame's Carr Tonight
description: The telephone rang in the basketball office at Madison Square Garden yesterday and the caller asked, Who will guard Austin Carr? It was a good question.

title: Nixon Is Expected to Ask Health Insurance on Job
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17President Nixon's longawaited package of health care proposals, to be sent to Congress tomorrow, is expected to contain a requirement that em ployers provide private health insurance for employes, with levels of benefits to be set by the Federal Government.

title: McLain Says Victory Has Its Sting, Too
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17The public's insatiable cu riosity for the currently hot item made Ted Williams a be nign background figure today as his Washington Senators be gan spring training and it placed Denny McLain in the perpetualinterrogation seat.

title: A.T.&T. TO OFFER HUGE NEW ISSUE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to seek stockholder approval at the annual meeting on April 22 for authorization of an addi tional 150 million shares of common stock and 50 million shares of preferred stock.

title: Boston Editor to Retire
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17 (AP)  C. Edward Holland, managing editor of The Boston Record American, is retiring this week after 50 years with the Hearst newspapers in Boston. Mr. Holland, now 66 years old, began his career as an office boy while still in school. He will he succeeded as managing editor by John C. McLean, assistant managing editor of the Sunday Advertiser.

title: Novelist Denies Murder
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., Feb. 17 (UPI)Jesse Hill Ford, the novelist, pleaded not guilty to day to a charge of firstdegree murder in the shooting of a black soldier, Pvt. George H. Doaks Jr. Judge Ralph Lawler set June 29 as the date for the trial and allowed Mr. Ford to remain free on $20,000 bond.

title: FLORIDA JUMP WON BY CHARLES STREET
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 17Mr. and Mrs. Patrick But ler's Charles Street, with Steve Stephens riding captured the first open jumper class today in the Central Florida Hunter and Jumper horse show.

title: Sonics 130126 Victors
description: SEATTLE, Feb. 17 (AP)The Seattle SuperSonics lost a 15 point lead in the fourth quarter tonight, but regained control in time to post a 130126 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of the following Army men front the New York area who have been killed in the Indochina war:

title: GIEREK VISITS CITY NEAR SOVIET UNION
description: WARSAW, Feb. 17Edward Gierek, Poland's Communist party leader, paid a visit today to Bialystok, 35 miles from the Soviet border. The trip prompt ed speculation that he was seeking to solve new internal problems.

title: Space Shuttle May Be Opposed If Vast New Facilities Are Needed
description: Representative Olin E. Teague, chairman of the House Manned Space Flight Subcom mittee, said yesterday that he would oppose the proposed space shuttle program if it meant building a vast new complex of manufacturing, test ing and launching facilities.

title: Army Plan to Spy on Civilians Was Sent to 319 U.S. Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17  Representative Ogden R. Reid of Westchester disclosed today that the Army's controversial intelligence surveillance of ci vilian dissent and political ac tivity was so widely known in government from 1968 en that even the military aides to all 50 state Governors were in formed of its scope and opera tions.

title: Jerusalem Housing Compromise Sought
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 17May or Teddy Kollek tried today to work out a compromise to scale down the national Govern ment's proposals for major housing developments in the barren but scenic valleys and hillsides around Jerusalem as conservation groups demanded that the plans be halted alto gether.

title: JOHN A. TUCKER, 73, COMPOSER, FIREMAN
description: John A. Tucker, a member of the New York Fire Department who became a composer and conductor, died on Sunday. He was 73 years old and lived in Woodside, Queens.

title: Jacoby to Head Conference
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 17 (UPI)Fred Jacoby, 43year old commissioner of the Wis consin State University Confer ence since July, was named commissioner today of the Mid American Conference. He will take over his new duties March 1. Jacoby succeeds Robert C. James, who has been named commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: Trenton Teachers Begin a Stoppage As Pay Talks Fail
description: TRENTON, Feb. 17Teach ers in this city's 21 public schools walked off their jobs today, joining policemen and firemen in demands for more Money.

title: STEWART B. ATKINSON
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 17  Stewart Bryon Atkinson, for mer principal of Darien High School, died Monday in Clear water, Fla., where he had been visiting. He was 70 years old and lived at 13 Beach Drive, Noroton.

title: 3Door Model of Ford Pinto Will Go on Sale Next Week
description: DETROIT, Feb. 17The Ford Motor Company will put a threedoor version of its small Pinto car on sale Feb. 25. The third door is at the rear, open ing upward and allowing the entire back of the car to be used for trunk space.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17A top secret memorandum to Attorney Gen eral John Mitchell from his antitrust division recently fell into the hands of this newspaper, after having been smuggled out of the Justice Depart ment via its heating tunnel by two nuns who infiltrated the mail room. The memo is reprinted here in its en tirety as a service to history:

title: Suns Down Royals
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 17 (AP) The Phoenix Suns scored 10 straight points early in the fourth quarter and went on to register a 133.117 National Bas ketball Association victory over the Cincinnati Royals tonight. Clem Haskins of the Suns led all scorers with 29 points.

title: PARIS AIDE CALLS COURTS TOO SOFT
description: PARIS, Feb. 17Rend Toma sini suddenly became a house hold word in France today with remarks about television news and permissive courts that some compared to those of Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Church's FM Station Will Accept Ads
description: The Riverside Church an nounced yesterday that its FM radio station, WRVR, would soon abandon its noncom mercial policy and accept a limited amount of commercial advertising.

title: Ground Broken for the First Of 5 Health Centers in Bronx
description: A new concept of health care was formally set in mo tion yesterday at ground breaking ceremonies for a $6.6  million neighborhood familycare center in the Morrisania section of the Bronx.

title: Carnegie Report Calls for an Increase in Aid to Black Colleges
description: The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education called yester day for greatly increased pub lic and private support to help the country's 105 black col leges and universities emerge from their historic isolation into the mainstream of Ameri can higher education.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Railroad Petition Approved
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 17 (AP) A Federal judge approved yes terday a petition calling for the Penn Central Railroad to reor ganize the Boston & Providence Railroad Corporation. This was once a subsidiary of the New Haven Railroad, which has been taken over by the Penn Central.

title: Britain, in Shift, Joins NATO Project
description: LONDON, Feb. 17  Britain changed her mind today and agreed to join other European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in a pro gram to strengthen military facilities.

title: Marijuana Sentence Upheld
description: LANSING, Mich., Feb. 17 (UPI)The Michigan Court of Appeals upheld today the con viction of a White Panther leader, John A. Sinclair, who was sentenced to 9 to 10 years in prison after giving two marijuana cigarettes to an undercover police agent.
