description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18  The marriage of Mrs. Phoebe Wildman van Beuren of Malvern to John D. Arch bold, the sportsman and Standard Oil heir, took place here today. District Court Judge John B. Hannum per formed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Pleasure Boat News
description: Rhode Island is a spunky state, Proud, too. So it is only natural that Rhode Islanders are the same. Like Bantam hens, they make up chauvinism what they lack in size.

title: A Donor Volunteers For That Old City Tie
description: A tempest in a tie box said S. Joseph Tankoos as, with a smile, he presented a $1,728 check yesterday to the city's Public Events Commis sioner, John S. (Bud) Palmer.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Johnny Bench of the Cincinnati Reds has hands so huge that he can hold seven baseballs in one oversized paw. He has talents so enormous he will some day carry to the bank the highest salary check ever given a ballplayer. The boy wonder of the National League and its most valuable player already has rocked the Redleg front office on its heels by coolly asking for half a million dollars for the next three sea sons. And Bench is only 23 years old.

title: Safety Panel Says Reuther's Jet Had A Faulty Altimeter
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)An altimeter in the plane that carried Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, to his death last May 9 had some parts missing and one part installed upside down, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On a Filibuster Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the Senate defeated today a move to halt debate on a proposal to make it easier to cut off fili busters (twothirds vote re quired):

title: Turkish Trousers Scores
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI)Turkish Trousers scored the first stakes victory of her career today, a fourlength vic tory in the $33,800 Santa Ynez Stakes for 3yearold fillies at Santa Anita.

title: Fordham Tops Notre Dame, 9488 Before 19,500, College Record at Garden
description: Fordham followed a game plan to perfection last night, chopped the big men down to size once again and upset mighty Notre Dame, 9488, be fore the largest nontournament college basketball crowd in Madison Square Garden history 19,500.

title: LOLITA PUTS OFF BROADWAY DEBUT
description: Lolita, My Love, the new musical by Alan Jay Lerner and John Barry, has postponed its Broadway opening at the Mark Hettinger Theater from March 30 to April 13.

title: Young Shoes and the Good Old Days
description: Shop Talk

title: Thalidomide Trial Is Opened in Japan After Five Years
description: TOKYO, Feb. 18  The case of the children born with de formed limbs after their mothers took the sedative thalidomide during pregnancy finally came to court in Japan today, after similar cases had been disposed of in West Ger many and other European countries.

title: BRITISH IMPATIENT AT MAIL WALKOUT
description: LONDON, Feb. 18The Brit ish, faced with a deadlocked fourweekold Post Office strike, turned somewhat un British today. They grew impa tient.

title: Music: A Neglected Schoenberg Work
description: Erich Leinsdorf and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, in Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday evening, gave New Yorkers a chance to hear Arnold Schoenberg's Variations for Orchestra (Op. 31). But not everybody availed himself of the chance; there were many empty seats in the hall. And this even though, the program was can nily built around two of the most popular works in the repertorySchubert's Un finished Symphony and Bartk's Concerto for Or chestra.

title: LA CENERENTOLA RINGS IN SEASON
description: The New York City Opera's La Cenerentola is about as happy a choice as could be to open a season, which is just what the Rossini opera did at the New York State Theater Wednesday night.

title: U.S. SUIT OPPOSES GEORGIA BANK DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI)  The Justice Department filed suit today challenging the merger of two banks in Dekalb County, Ga., and their sub sequent acquisitions.

title: Back From England, He Says Engine for Tristar Is Sound
description: The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said yester day that his trip to England had convinced him that the jet engine that threw RollsRoyce, Ltd., into receivership had no fundamentally serious tech nical problems.

title: BLOC IN CONGRESS URGED TO AID CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Mayor Lindsay urged the New York City Congressional dele gation today to act as a single concerted bloc to bring New York City's tax dollars back home.

title: CONNIPTION VICTOR IN FLORIDA JUMPING
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 18Tony D'Ambrosio Jr. of Mount Kisco, N. Y., rode Har mony Farm's Conniption to vic tory over 45 other mounts to day in the preliminary jumper class at the Central Florida Hunter and Jumper horse show.

title: Army to Test AllOut Campaign on Radio and TV
description: The $3  million network television buy for Army re cruiting, reported earlier this week, was just the frosting on the cake. The Army will actually be spending an un precedented $10.6million in a fourmonth saturation experi mental radio and TV cam paign aimed at seeing if ad vertising can create an all volunteer Army.

title: EGYPT SEEKS WAY TO REOPEN CANAL
description: PARIS, Feb. 18Egyptian of ficials have been quietly sound ing out shipsalvage companies in Europe on clearing the Suez Canal.

title: DAVID POTTER, 60, HISTORIAN, DIES
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 18 (UPI)David M. Potter, presi dent of the American Histori cal Association and an au thority on the. Confederacy and the Civil War, died of can cer today at the Stanford Uni versity Medical Center. He was 60 years old.

title: Nixon to See Governors
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) President Nixon will be host at a White House dinner next Tuesday night for the nation's Governors, who will be in Washington attending sessions of the National Governors Con ference, it was annouced today.

description: President Nixon's health mes sage received general approval yesterday from the American Medical Association, qualified approval from the Association of American Medical Colleges and strong disapproval from the head of the New York City Health Services Administration.

description: BUFFALO, Feb. 18(UPI) Don Marshall's goal midway (through the final period gave the Buffalo Sabres a 66 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 18 (AP)Four more boats crossed the finish line of the Capetown toRio yacht race today, bring ing down to 14 the number of yachts yet to arrive.

title: Soviet Stars to Compete On Garden Track Tonight
description: Nine track and field athletes from the Soviet Union, includ ing a highjumper who flops, a halfmiler who digs Tom Jones tunes, an Olympic triple jump champion, and a front running miler, will challenge some of America's top talent tonight in the third United States Olympic invitation meet at Madison Square Garden.

title: From Triumphant Lamb to Limp Salad
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: AMEX PRICES EASE THROUGHOUT DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the second consecutive ses sion in the slowest trading in three weeks.

title: Puerto Rican Students Occupy C.C.N.Y. Offices for 6 Hours
description: Puerto Rican students at City College occupied offices of the romance languages department yesterday for six hours to un derscore their demands that our problems be immediately considered.

title: Tax Plan Scored at Albany Hearing
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18Governor Rockefeller's proposed $1.1bil lion package of tax increases was denounced for hours here today as an unconscionable proposal that would drive busi ness from the state and make an endangered species of the taxpayer.

title: Nine Hanged in Pakistan
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Nine men sen tenced to death by a military court for burning nine persons alive in a family feud went to the gallows here today.

title: Freezing Construction Wages
description: In declaring his intention to act against the runaway wageprice spiral in construction, President Nixon is demonstrating a welcome resolve to plug the most gaping hole in the Administration's antiinflation program.

title: Sorry, Wrong Borough
description: Residents of Queens who return to New York by air are regularly confronted by refusals on the part of many cab drivers to take them to their homes. They are denied service not to a highcrime area but to a predominantly middleclass residential section, simply because drivers prefer the longer haul to Manhattan. Agile passengers who, in desperation, claim squatter's rights in an empty cab must expect exposure to black looks If not a stream of profanity.

title: Display Pays Tribute to Glarner Art
description: The three years between 1925 and 1928 were pivotal ones in the pictorial develop ment of the Swissborn painter Fritz Glarner. It was then, in Paris, that he met Mondrian and Vantongerloo. Both Dutchmen were cham pioning the esthetic of neo plasticism, which sought a complete nonassociational re finement of art into a pure and simple language of form and color. Only much later, however, did their work ex ercise an appreciable influ ence on Glarner.

title: Russi and Miss Proell Win Downhill Ski Events in Maine
description: KINGFIELD, Me., Feb. 18 Switzerland and Austria shared the top victories in the down hill event today as the World Cup racing circus moved to Sugarloaf Mountain here from Canada.

title: Kodak Profit Off 2% in Quarter
description: Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company achieved records last year de spite a 2 per cent decline in earnings for the fourth quar ter when sales reached a new peak, the Rochesterbased com pany reported yesterday.

title: EDWARD C. SCHMIDLI
description: Edward C. Schmidli, direc tor of car maintenance for the shippers car line division of ACF Industries Inc., here, died. Wednesday apparently after a heart attack in Charleston, W. Va., while on a business trip. He was 54 years old and lived at 68 Heights Terrace, Middle town, N. J.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Trading in major commodity futures markets yesterday moved in an aimless fashion without many significant changes.

title: U.S. Specialists Doubt Peking Will Send Troops to Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 United States Government spe cialists on China voiced confi dence today that Peking would not commit troops to the war in Indochina.

title: Health Plan Stresses Preventive Care
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The President's proposal for a na tional health insurance pro gram offers something to al most everyone.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials slipped to 109.8 Tuesday from 110.0 last week.

title: Oriole Camp to Tickle No Funnybones
description: MIAMI, Feb. 18When a team has the right to call it self World champion, after winning a second straight American League pennant by a large margin and the World Series in five games, starting a new spring training season must be fun, right?

description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 18 UPI) A rainstorm washed out the first round of the 72hole $110, 000 Tucson open today when water became so deep on the greens that golf balls sank out of sight.

description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18 Top leaders of the A.F.L. C.I.O. called today for amend ment of the Railway Labor Act to permit selective or partial strikes and bring an end to what they described as arti ficially created national emer gencies.

title: Marcus Gets Early Parole On 2d Bribery Conviction

description: City Councilman Carter Bur den said yesterday that the City Council was preparing, to play a major roleits proper rolein helping to bring about prison reform.

Mondale of Minnesota and Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan told a news conference that they would introduce legislation au thorizing such a commission.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Talk of Lodi

title: A Reggio Calabria Area Cleared of Barricades
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Feb. 18About 1,000 police men with armored half tracks and bulldozers today razed barricades that rioters had built on the southern outskirts of this rebellious city earlier this week.

title: Army Reprimands Officer Who Faked Data on Medals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The Army said today that the officer who ordered fake citations awarding medals to a general in Vietnam had been reprimanded and investigation of the incident was complete.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18The South Vietnamese command reported today that the forward units of its forces advancing across Communist supply trails in southern Laos were now operating 22 miles from the border.

description: CHICAGOAmong Catholic liber als the only subject for discussion is l'affaire Berrigan.

description: KENT, Ohio, Feb. 18 (AP) Robert I. White asked today to be relieved as president of Kent State University, where four students were shot to death in a confrontation with National Guardsmen last May 4.

title: Mr. Nixon's Health Plan
description: President Nixon's proposals for a reorganization of the United States health care system represent a creative and useful contribution to the growing national debate on this topic. Up to now public discussion of the subject has largely turned on the merits and defects of national health insurance, as projected, for example, by Senator Kennedy. Mr. Nixon has offered a serious alternative which attempts to minimize direct government inter vention and expenditure, while taking advantage of the indubitable strengths of the existing system.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Federal Reserve moved into the Government securities markets yesterday with all cannons firing, and it drove interest rates downward.

title: Illegal Suspensions of PublicSchool Pupils Charged by Civil Liberties Union
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union accused city school of ficials yesterday of a flagrant disregard of their own regula tions and of state law in im properly or illegally suspending many pupils from school.

description: Six scholarships, intended to help educational broadcasters from minority groups improve their skills, have been awarded by the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, it was announced yesterday.

description: The American Bridge Asso ciation, which for almost 40 years has provided for the tournament needs of black bridge players, may be the only national bridge organi zation in the world to have a woman at its head.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Housing starts dropped sharply in January from the nearrec ord levels of December, the Commerce Department report ed today.

title: INSKO REACHING FOR GOLDEN GOAL
description: YONKERS, Feb. 18  Del Insko is in his 26th year as a harness horseman. He was six days short of his 15th birthday when he drove in his first race, on July 4, 1946.

description: Thirteen persons were arrest ed in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday as members of a gang that forged automobile and truck registrations for car thieves and truck hijackers.

Evans of the Union League, 715, 1510, 154, 1513, yester day in the first round of the 23d annual Fowler Memorial Class C squash racquets tourna ment at the Seventh Regiment Armory Squash Club. In an other match, Dave Stafford of Bronxville won by default from John Koeniger of Short Hills, the fourthseeded player.

description: DENVER, Feb. 18 (AP) Three Fort Carson enlisted men, indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges stemming from bombings at a Wisconsin mili tary post last summer, have waived a formal hearing here and are to be taken to Madison, Wis., within the next three weeks to face charges. The soldiers are Stephen G. Geden of Milton, Mass.; Dannie E. Kreps of Torrence, Calif., and Thomas M. Chase of Glen Rock, N. J., all 21 years of age.

title: ExAntipoverty Official Seized As Armed Bank Robber Here
description: A former antipoverty official under indictment for anarchy and arson as a member of the Revolutionary Action Move ment (RAM) was arrested yesterday on charges of bank robbery.

title: Reinforcements Sought The Washington Star
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 18  Laotian military sources report ed today that the United States had asked Thailand for more troops to shore up the battered defenses of the American backed base at Long Tieng, near the Plaine des Jarres.

title: American War Deaths Double to 51 in Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18 (AP) The United States command reported to day that 51 Americans were killed in combat last week in Indochina, more than twice the previous week's toll of 24.

description: To the Editor:

description: PARIS, Feb. 18  The Paris judiciary marched in black robed silence today in protest against an attack on court leniency by the Gaullist party chief.

title: Israelis Get U.A.R. Reply
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 18  The text of Egypt's response to the peace proposals of Dr. Gun nar V. Jarring, the United Na tions intermediary for the Mid dle East, reached Jerusalem in the small hours of this morn ing. It was communicated to the Cabinet by Foreign Minister Abba Eban. After a twohour discussion, the Cabinet ad journed until Sunday.

title: 3 WIN $100,000 EACH IN STATE'S LOTTERY
description: Three ticketholders here were winners yesterday of $100,000 each in the state's January lottery drawing.

title: Screen: Bronte Revival:Scenes Glitter Anew in 'Wuthering Heights'
description: There are recurring moments in the new British film version of "Wuthering Heights" when it's possible to comprehend something of the nature of the wild and beautiful physical environment out of which Emily Bront, almost 125 years ago, created her unique novel of transcendental love and hate, of venegeful marriages and of awful deeds that often, as in the hanging of a litter of puppies, were directed toward the innocent.If you squint your eyes, and look around and beyond the actors carrying on in the middle of the screen, mostly as if they were on a hysterical picnic, you can get some sense of the magnificence of the Yorkshire moors, which have been photographed in all sorts of weather and in all sorts of light. There is also that feeling of connections to a primeval past in the architecture of the ancient farm buildings at Wuthering Heights, which seem to have erupted out of glacier rock, rather than to have been built by man.Such peripheral things describe Miss Bront's marvelous and demented Heathcliff and Cathy in ways that are quite beyond the capabilities of the movie's principal performers. This "Wuthering Heights," which opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, is simply petulant when it tries to be overwrought, which may be what American International Pictures publicity people mean when they describe the film as "youth-oriented."As did the lovely 1939 film version, which was directed by William Wyler and written by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur, this adaptation confines itself entirely to the first half of the novel, beginning with the introduction of the mysterious gypsy boy, Heathcliff, into the Earnshaw household, and concluding a half-generation later when the see-through shade of Heathcliff is finally reunited with the see-through shade of Cathy at Pennistone Crag.Because Miss Bront's "Wuthering Heights" defies easy or consistent interpretation, even in an age illuminated by Freud, Robert Feust, the director, and Patrick Tilley, who did the adaptation, have felt free to make bluntly clear relationships that in the novel remain forever ambiguous. Thus there is no doubt in this "Wuthering Heights" that Heathcliff and Cathy are half-brother and half-sister.The shape of the film is similarly straightforward, a chronicle spanning 10 or 12 years, although the effect of the chronicle is more than a little confusing because the characters all seem to grow up at different rates of speed, and seldom does a child actor have much physical relation to the adult actor who takes on his character later in the film.This would be nit-picking in a movie that was otherwise touched with any kind of cinematic grace or intelligence, both totally absent from the decisions made by Fuest and Tilley. The screenwriter, who often uses bits of dialogue from the novel, doesn't hesitate to add new material that is completely inappropriate. Cathy exclaims, when her brother Hindley is having a drunken card game at Wuthering Heights: "He's just got to get those dreadful people out of the house!"a line that would do credit only to the Johnny Carson Art Players.Even more amusing, and less impressive, are Fuest's different ways of creating mystery (frame Heathcliff in a doorway as a dark silhouette), suspense (a stranger enters a scene shot from the knees down, more or less feet-first), debauchery (close-up of an overturned tankard). It is some kind of reverse triumph that under his direction a rock formation on the moors looks less symbolic, or even phallic, thanwellsuggestive.Timothy Dalton and Anna Calder-Marshall play the star-crossed lovers in degrees of effectiveness that depend largely on camera angles. Dalton, under certain conditions, bears a remarkable resemblance to the young Laurence Olivier for whom the Wyler version was a triumph. Miss Calder-Marshall is not a great beauty, but her face at times expresses an almost witchlike ferocity, which is, more often than not, immediately neutralized by a long shot that reveals a short, rather square figure, somewhat reminiscent of Annette Funicello's.The supporting cast includes some very decent character actors (Harry Andrews, Hugh Griffith), most of whom, like the babies born of the mismatched marriages, die at unspecified times off-screen.Contemporary history note: This "Wuthering Heights" apparently marks a revival of film interest in the Bronts. I've just received word that Richard Fleischer ("Ch!") plans a biographical film about the writing family in which Bramwell Bront will be portrayed as "one of the original dropouts" in a script by Christopher Fry.

title: Bone Traces Man Back 5 Million Years
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18A fragment of jawbone that appears to push early man back to five and a half million years ago has been discovered in Kenya.

title: New Lord Chief Justice Appointed in England
description: LONDON, Feb. 18  Sir John Passmore Widgery was named Lord Chief Justice of England today in succession to Lord Parker. The post ranks next to that of Lord Chancellor in the legal hier archy, and Lord Parker has held it for 12 years.

title: 8 New Members Elected To the Institute of Arts
description: Eight new members have been elected into the National Institute of Arts and Letters, the nation's foremost honor society of fine arts.

title: POLLUTION LINKED TO RISE IN WEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18  Dramatic gains in American af fluence in the next 30 years will pose a far greater threat to the quality of life than in creased population, the Census Bureau's leading authority on income said today.

title: JACKSON NAME OFF BALLOT IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (Reuters) The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, a former aide to the Rev. Mar tin Luther King Jr., lost another round today in his fight to en ter the mayoral election against Mayor Ribhard J. Daley.

title: Cosmos 395 Is Launched
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (UPI)  The Soviet Union launched to day an unmanned earth satel lite, Cosmos 395, the press agency Toss said.

title: Museum to Open DrugAbuse Exhibit
description: The Museum of the City of New Yorkwhich must be more than just a mirror to the past, according to its directorwill soon enter an area normally avoided by museums: drugabuse educa tion.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed easier in quiet trading, discouraged by the decline in earnings of Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's highest un employment figures since 1963, and the continuing deadlock in the postal strike.

title: Soviet Accuses Zionism Of Subverting Red Lands
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18Pravda, the Communist party news paper, said today that world Zionism carried on subversive activity in Communist coun tries and suggested that Zion ists were to blame for the liberalization in Czechoslo vakia in 1968.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18When Pres ident Nixon came into the White House he said, We were elected to initiate an era of change. We intend to begin a decade of government reform such as this nation has not witnessed in half a century. . . . That is the watch word of this Administration: reform.

title: ANOTHER TRIUMPH SCORED BY POOLE
description: MIAMI, Feb, 18  George Poole, who has saddled three stakes winners in nine days, during the current meeting, came through with another success today when he sent out C.V. Whitney's Forever Wild in the second race at Hialeah.

title: Major Leagues Establish a Program to Control Taking of Drugs by Players
description: Major league baseball has or ganized a drug education pro gram for its clubs, Commis sioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

title: Bronx Man Appointed State Human Rights Chief
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18Governor Rockefeller today appointed Jack M. Sable, Director of the State Office for Community Affairs, as the State Human Rights Commissioner.

title: State's Highest Court to Review Reversal of Brooklyn Adoption
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18The State Court of Appeals agreed today to hear an appeal against low ercourt orders directing a Brooklyn couple to return their 8monthold adopted daughter to her natural mother.

title: Two Italian Dishes For Weekend Chef
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: House Unit Backs Plan for Sale Of LongTerm Treasury Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 18 The Treasury would be able to sell some longterm market able bonds for the first time in more than five years under legislation, approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee, that provides a limited exception to the ceiling on the bonds' interest rate.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Feb. 18 (AP)The winning number in the weekly New Jersey lottery drawing Thursday was 845974, producing four winners of the top $50,000 prize from a record sale of tickets.

title: The new fourdoor sedan in the Opel 1900 series has an overall length of 164.6 inches
description: A fourdoor Opel sedan will be sold in this country for the first time next month, it was announced yesterday.

title: Air France to Suspend Flights in a Labor Dispute
description: PARIS, Feb. 19Air France and two other carriers said to day that they would suspend flights indefinitely Monday when pilots and other person nel are scheduled to end a walkout that began today.

title: Trade Center Fire Brings Complaints From City Firemen
description: The 30th blaze in 14 months at the Port Authority's World Trade Center broke out early yesterday and brought sharp criticism from the heads of two firemen's associations.

title: Sweaters Patterned After Art
description: Samuel Freund, the knit wear designer, made it into the big time in August, 1965. Yves Saint Laurent had just shown a collection of jersey dresses, inspired by Mondri an designs, in Paris  his mother had given him a book of the painter's work and he'd transposed the designs to clothes. Mr. Freund had based some sweaters on the same idea: he'd admired the paintings in the Museum of Modern Art. He found him self linked to the couturier in the press first, then soon in the stores.

title: Thant Assails Israel on Work At U.N. Site in Jerusalem
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 19Secretary General Thant in a public report today accused Israel of conducting bulldozing operations illegally on the grounds of Government House, the headquarters of United Na tions observers in Jerusalem. He requested that the opera tions halt immediately.

title: DDT Is Too Much With Us
description: Chairman W. R. (Bob) Poage of the House Committee on Agriculture will hold hearings next week on the use of pesticides in agriculture. He wants to know about their environ mental effects and the possible effects that would follow sharp restrictions on their use.

title: SAMUEL EDEN
description: Samuel Eden, a lawyer and senior partner in Eden & Eden, 150 Broadway, died of cancer yesterday in Manhasset, L.I. Medical Center after a long ill ness. He was 65 years old and lived at 50 Plaza Street in Brooklyn and in Surfside, Fla.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Shelter Resources Corporation has elected Carl D. Glickman chairman of the executive com mittee, chief executive officer and a director. The modular and mobile home manufacturer and finan cial services company also elected Alvin H. Ein bender president, chief operating officer and a director. Mr. Glickman has been chairman of Ameri can Steel & Pump Corporation, and Mr. Einbender is formerly vice presidentcorporate finance depart ment of Bear Stearns & Co. investment bankers. Richard E. Memhard, previously president of Shelter Resources has submitted his resignation for per sonal reasons. The company also elected Daniel Coven, vice president of the Cole National Corpora tion, and Frank B. Fisher, president of Capital Na tional Bank of Cleveland, to the board of directors. John Patanelli was made president of Winston In dustries, a subsidiary of Shelter. Resources.

title: MANSFIELD WARNS ON DRIVE IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Senator Mike Mansfield, the Senate Democratic leader, said today that South Vietnam's op eration in Laos represented a military gamble that could lead to an extended, broadened war in Indochina.

title: L.I.R. Plans New Tickets To Cut Nonpaying Riders
description: The Long Island Railroad will soon start selling a new type of ticket, one that will not be easy to lend to neighbors or to counterfeit.

title: Market Place: Problems Seen In Quick Quotes
description: That NASDAQ quotation system, which last week went into operation offering instant bid and asked prices on 2500 overthecounter stocks, didn't please every one.

title: MY PROCEDURE HELD TO BE BIASED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit overturned the bribery convic tions of three individuals and three corporations today on the ground that women were dis criminated against in the selec tion of a Newark grand jury.

title: Your Move, Mr. Agnew
description: The Senate's failure this week to muster a twothirds majority for closure means that the unnecessary talka thon goes on. Southern conservatives are determined to block a modest reform of the filibuster rule which would permit the Senate to close debate by a threefifths rather than a twothirds majority. Enough Republicans from the Middle West and the Mountain States tacitly agree with the Southerners for the minority to prevail.

title: Thompson Speedy In Fun City Debut, But Thief Is Faster
description: In 6.2 seconds last night Rocky Thompson learned what life in Fun City is all about.

title: Italian Premier Holds Talks With Officials in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  Italy's visiting Pre mier, Emilio Colombo, con ferred today with a group of highranking officials who han dle economic, financial and trade affairs in the Nixon Ad ministration. He also met with Secretary of State William P. Rogers.

title: Jersey Employes Join Guild
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19Editorial employes at The Evening News of Newark voted today to join the American Newspaper Guild. The vote was 151 to 90, with one abstention. Bargaining for a contract covering editorial em ployes is expected to start soon, a spokesman for the guild said.

title: Cars of 3 Russians Attacked in Washington Area
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The cars of three Soviet diplomats were attacked today in nearby Maryland in actions deplored by the United States as senseless and criminal.

title: Murphy Changing Procedures For Plainclothes Morals Units
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that to reduce the possibility of police corruption he was changing the methods and or ganization of the patrolmen assigned to enforce the gam bling, prostitution and liquor laws.

title: MISS MILLER GAINS LEAD BY 2 SHOTS
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP)  Sharon Miller, a poker  playing blonde from Michigan, shot a twounder par 71 today, and gained the firstround lead in the $60,000 Sears Women's World Classic.

title: Support From Governor
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19 (AP)  Gov. Rockefeller endorsed to day President Nixon's health care proposals that would pro vide most Americans with pri vate health insurance, saying that a national universal health insurance system is clearly the most desirable method for providing for this need.

title: 50% CAB FARE RISE AND A TAXI PANEL VOTED BY COUNCIL
description: A controversial bill raising the cost of an average cab ride by nearly 50 per cent and set ting up a taxi commission was approved by the City Council last night.

title: National Justice Standards Are Proposed by Mitchell
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 19 (AP)Attorney General John N. Mitchell called today for national standards for police forces, courts and prisons to help modernize the country's criminal justice system.

title: Paul Neilson, 55, Director With the State Department
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) N. Paul Neilson, director of public affairs for the State De partment's East Asia Bureau, died of a heart attack at his home last night. He was 55 years old.

title: Profit Rises at Carnation
description: The Carnation Company yes terday proposed a stock split, announced highlevel manage ment changes and reported in creased earnings in 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Consolidated Gas Lists Dip in Profits. As Revenue Is Up
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company reported yesterday a decline in 1970 net income de spite higher revenues.

title: Pacific Power and Light
description: The Pacific Power and Light Company reported yesterday gains in gross operating rev enues and net income for 1970. Revenues rose by 7 per cent to $158,893,000, while net income of $30,768,000 was 14 per cent higher than the 1969 level. Per share earnings increased by 9 cents to $1.67, according to the preliminary report.

title: ADDICTED CONVICT SUES FOR THERAPY
description: A trial was ordered yesterday to determine whether a heroin addict in the Women's House of Detention in Manhattan must be given the methadone treat ment by the city's Department of Correction.

title: Paper Clamp Helps Save Boy's Life
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Feb. 19A 10cent metal paper clamp helped save the life of a 2yearold hemophiliac at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center here after all known standard medical procedures had failed to halt his bleeding

title: TWO AT 66 SHARE TUCSON GOLF LEAD
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 19 (AP)  DeWitt Weaver and J. C. Snead, a nephew of Sam Snead, carded sixunderpar 66's today and tied for the lead in the raindelayed first round in the Tucson open golf tournament.

title: Base Under Attack
description: SAIGON, Feb. 19 (AP)A strong North Vietnamese force kept a South Vietnamese artil lery base in Laos under heavy attack today, according to in formed American sources in the northern part of South Vietnam.

title: Black Doll Is Natural Success
description: Baby Nancy was born in the wake of the Watts riots. She weighed 10 pounds, stood 13 inches tall and had long, dense straight hair. Her lips were thicker, her nose broad er and her skin blacker than any of her counterparts. And she wet the bed.

title: LOUIS BONN, 79, DIES; EASTMAN KODAK AIDE
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Feb. 19 Louis A. Bonn, retired vice president of motionpicture sales of the Eastman Kodak Company, died on Wednesday at a convalescent home here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Bridge: WellPlayed Slam Helps Pair Win a Unitwide Event in City
description: The Unitwide game, in which pairs play the same deals at many different clubs at the same time, is now a firmly established monthly event on the Greater New York Bridge Association calendar.

title: Nastase Gains SemiFinals
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 19 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the defending champion, and Clark Graebner, of New York rallied tonight to gain the semi finals of the national indoor open tennis championships.

title: '6,700 Get Protection On SexOriented Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)The names of 6,700 persons will appear tomor row on the Postal Service's first list of those who do not want to receive sexoriented mail.

title: Fans Rejoice Over Fordham Quintet's Success
description: The enthusiasm following Fordham's 9488 victory over Notre Dame Thursday night spilled over yesterday at Madison Square Garden, the Ram campus and Beacon, N. Y.

title: Deadline for Bald Head
description: Time is running out for Bald Head, the nation's north ernmost tropical island lying at the mouth of the Cape Fear River in North Carolina. A syndicate of private developers bought this beautiful, untouched island last summer for $5.5 million. The sale of house lots is now expected to begin in April unless Federal or state offi cials come to the rescue.

title: U.S. FUNDS AVERT RENT RISE BY CITY
description: The City Housing Authority announced yesterday that a lastminute $5million alloca tion from the Federal Govern ment would help meet operat ing expenses in public housing here and forestall rent increases for 153,000 lowincome families.

title: Kennecott Dividend Cut
description: The Kennecott Copper Cor poration announced yesterday that it would reduce the quar terly dividend to 50 cents, from 65 cents, payable March 22 to holders of record March 1.

title: MISS YOON IS HEARD IN A PIANO RECITAL
description: Mee Kyung Yoon, a Korean pianist who has been a scholar ship student of Adele Marcus at the Juilliard School since 1968, was presented In a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night by the Rotary Interna tional District 749.

title: S.E.C. Orders Trading Halt In American Environmental
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered a 10day temporary suspension of overthecounter trading in the securities of the American Environmental Control Cor poration of Brooklyn.

title: GENEVIEVE HAMPER, STAGE ACTRESS, 82
description: Genevieve Hamper, a Shake spearean actress of an earlier generation, died Saturday in the Sanger Nursing Home, 500 West 57th Street, after a long illness, She was 82 years old and lived at 457 West 57th Street.

title: Assessment Is Sought
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 19The re call of Ambassador Rabin for consultations was interpreted here as an indication that the Israeli Government wants to assess Washington's probable reaction before deciding on a response to the Egyptian memo randum.

title: Mideast Breakthrough?
description: Reports that Egypt has signified readiness to sign a peace agreement with Israel, to recognize Israel and to accept an international force at Sharm el Sheik to insure the freedom of Israeli shipping through the Strait of Tiran indicate a significant breakthrough in Middle East peace negotiations.

title: The Lesson of The Confession
description: When my American friends saw the film, The Confession, they asked only one question: Were the real prisoners of the Slansky trials treated as brutally as the characters are treated in this film? I was disturbed to learn that they were surprised by the brutality that exists in the Soviet bloc.

title: Chief of Lockheed Meets With British
description: LONDON, Feb. 19  Daniel J. Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, had what, he called an ex ploratory meeting with Brit ish officials today oh the fu ture of the RollsRoyce engine designed to power the Lock heed Tristar airbus.

title: 10 European Nations to Build Huge Atom Smasher
description: GENEVA, Feb. 19  Ten Western European nations agreed today to join in building the world's largest research in strument, an atom smasher fitted into a tunnel forming a ring 1.4 miles wide. It is to be placed on the frontier between France and Switzerland.

title: Cards, With Allen Gone, Are Still DissenterProne
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb, 19The St. Louis Cardi nals opened spring training today with six catchers, 15 pitchers, one infielder, six holdouts and a new image.

title: 20 Seized in South Africa Under the Terrorism Act
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Feb. 19 (UPI)The police arrested about 20 persons today in raids throughout South Africa under provisions of the Terror ism Act, authorities reported.

title: Tobacco Sales Show Rise
description: Smoking tobacco sales last year rose to 74.1 million pounds, the largest volume since 1964, it was announced yesterday by the Pipe and Tobacco Council of America. The record sales figure included 65.6 million pounds of domes tically manufactured tobacco, or 3 million pounds more than in 1969.

title: MercedesBenz Displays 19Passenger Shuttle Bus
description: A specially designed bus to shuttle people between air ports and hotels and from the suburbs to shopping centers will be put on display today by MercedesBenz at the Chi cago Auto Show.

title: DARTMOUTH LEADS WILLIAMS SKIING
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 19The Dartmouth ski team took the lead in the Wil liams Winter Carnival today, scoring heavily in the cross country race after establishing a slight edge in the giant slalom.

title: SAUL SILBERMAN, 75, RACE TRACK OWNER
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19 (UPI)Saul Silberman, owner and president of the Tropical Park race track for the last 18 years and for mer owner of the Cleveland Browns professional football team, died of a stroke today. He was 75 years old.

title: DR. JOHN L. SULLIVAN
description: Dr. John Lawrence Sullivan, a member of the staff of St. Vincent's and New York Hos pitals, died at his home yester day. He was 63 years old and lived at 530 East 23d Street.

title: Alfred Ski Team Captures National Junior College Title
description: BANNER ELK, N.C. Feb. 19 (AP)  Alfred won team hon ors in the National Junior Col lege Athletic Association ski championships today, with Morris County, N. J., second and the host, LeesMcRae, third.

title: Look Where I'm At Set
description: The new musical, Look Where I'm At, adapted from Thorne Smith's novel, Rain in the Doorway, will open March 3 at Theater Four, Ninth Ave nue and 55th Street. Ron Hus mann will star. Jimmy Lessor has written a book, with mu sic and lyrics by Jordan Ramin, Frank Stanton and Murray Semos.

title: LINDSAY ATTACKS RACING OPERATORS
description: Mayor Lindsay accused race track operators yesterday of de fying state law and the public interest by trying to block the projected start of offtrack bet ting on March 15.

title: Convicted in Flag Case
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. 19 (AP)Deborah Luscomb, a 21 yearold Granby woman, has been convicted and fined $50 for wearing an American flag sewed to the seat of her pants. But she filed an appeal of the decision after it was handed down in Holyoke District Court today by Judge Michael Dono hue.

title: Books of The Times
description: Letters of Thomas Mann 18891955. Selected and translated from the German by Richard and Clara Winston. Introduction by Richard Winston, 690 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.50.

title: Electrical Device Used to Treat Nerve Deafness
description: Patents of the Week

title: RCACoronet Merger Is Voted by Holders
description: Merger News

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI AIDE SEES HOPE IN U.A.R. MOVE
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 19An Israeli Cabinet minister who is a close associate of Premier Golda Meir said here today that Egypt's reported willingness to sign a peace agreement with Israel was a positive eiement that should not be ignored.

title: Museum Extends Hours
description: The Brooklyn Museum has announced that henceforth it will open an hour earlier and close an hour later on Sundays, from 12 noon to 6 P.M., to ac commodate the large flow of visitors to its exhibition, Vin cent Van Gogh: Paintings and Drawings. In addition, the dis play will remain open until 9 P.M. on six successive Monday nights beginning next week.

title: Penn Triumphs, 10372;
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 Harvard displayed better look ing hairdos, but Penn had far superior basketball ability to night and that's why the Quak ers gained their 21st victory in 21 games this season.

title: CONOVER'S BAND HAS NEW IDENTITY
description: The 15piece jazz band that was called the Bill BerryWillis Conover Jazz Band when it was heard around town last spring and summer returned to action yesterday after a six month layoff and with a new identity. It is now called the Al CohnWillis Conover New York Band because Mr. Berry, a trumpeter on the Mery Grif fin television show, has moved with Mr. Griffin to Los An geles where he has organized a West Coast branch of the New York band.

title: Soviet Jews in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 19General Dragunsky, a threestar general of the Soviet Army, said here today that Soviet Jews were barred from emigrating to Israel if they were likely to swell the ranks of the Israeli Army.

title: Revere Reduces Prices;
description: Revere Copper & Brass, Inc., announced yesterday that it would reduce its distributor prices for standard sizes of sheet, roll and strip copper by 4.37 cents a pound, effective with shipments Monday.

title: BEATLES' LAWYER SCORES MANAGER
description: LONDON, Feb. 19Paul Mc Cartney pressed his legal bid in high court today to break up the Beatles, charging that the group's manager, Allen Klein, cannot be trusted.

title: 3Judge Panel Ordered to Rule On Law on Pornography Labels
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the conven ing of a threejudge court to determine the constitutionality of a new law that requires that notices be placed on sexually oriented mail.

title: A Rabbi's Lecture At Papal University Is First for School
description: ROME, Feb. 19For the first time in the 419year history of the Pontifical Gregorian Uni versity, the alma mater of six of the last eight Popes, a Rabbi lectured today on Judaism.

title: Embassy in Pnompenh Bombed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sat urday, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  A large bomb explosion rocked the Thai Embassy in central Pnompenh early today.

title: Texas Utilities
description: The Texas Utilities Company reported yesterday gains in rev enues and net income for the fourth quarter, and for 1970. Revenues in the quarter rose to $107,461,075 from $99,044,491 a year ago, while net income increased to $20,055,985, or 77 cents a share, from $17,806,947, or 69 cents a share, in the like period of 1969. Revenues for the full year totaled $453,035,411, up from $416,934,222 a year earlier. Net income in 1970 was $86,496,236, or $3.33 a share, an increase from $77,082,388, or $3.03 a share, in 1969.

title: Hollway Rehires 2 Aides
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19 (AP) Bob Hollway, new head coach of the St. Louis Cardinals rehired two defensive aides, Dick Voris and Chuck Drulis, today. Both had been on the staff of the deposed coach, Charlie Winner.

title: INDIANS DENOUNCE TRENDS IN BUREAU
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Feb. 19 Leaders of more than 50 Indian reservations in 12 states put the Government on notice to day that they were dissatisfied with the trends in the Interior Department's Bureau of Indian Affairs and wary of Govern ment overreaction to demands of young red power militants.

title: PEAK DEPOSITS MADE AT 16 SAVINGS BANKS
description: The 16 largest savings banks in New York City had a record deposit inflow of $114million during the first half of Feb ruary, the Savings Banks As sociation of New York State reported yesterday. By con trast, there was an outflow of $23million in deposits in the same period last year.

title: 18,545 SEE BULLS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (UPI)  Chet Walker scored 4 points in the final 38 seconds of regu lation time tonight to tie the score at 101101, and then tal lied 11 in the fiveminute over time to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 115114 triumph over the Detroit Pistons.

title: Kent State Panel Set Up
description: KENT, Ohio, Feb. 19 (AP) Dr. Kenneth W. Clement, Cleve land surgeon and political fig ure, was named today to head the committee to find a succes sor to the Kent State University president, Robert I. White, who announced his resignation yes terday.

title: Financial Agreement Set By Pennstar Company
description: The Pennstar Company an nounced yesterday it had en tered into an agreement with the Northern Financial Corpo ration to buy some $2million receivables due from the Riker Delaware Corporation, current ly under Chapter X bankruptcy proceedings.

title: ALLIED INCURSION IN LAOS STALLED FOR SECOND DAY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Feb. 19  For the second succes sive day, the South Vietnamese sweep in southern Laos remained at a standstill, the military command reported to day.

title: Troops at Khesanh, Recalling Siege By the Enemy in 1968, Are Digging In
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 19  Reminders of the marines who fought off the fivemonth enemy siege in 1968 are everywhere here, and the Army troops who have reoccu pied the base since Jan. 30 are digging in deeply.

title: Princeton Wins, 9781
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 Two sophomores, Ted Manakas and Brian Taylor, combined for 53 points tonight to pace Princeton to a 9781 triumph over Dartmouth.

title: Soviet Aides Tour U.S Looking for a Good Steak
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 19The Russians are look ing for a good steak.

title: Schoenberg 2d Time
description: Arnold Schoenberg back to back on two successive days: Will wonders never cease? It was Wednesday evening that Erich Leinsdorf and the Boston Symphony presented Schoenberg's Vari for Orchestra (Op. 31). Thursday evening saw Seiji Ozawa and the New York Philharmonic, with Peter Serkin as soloist, in the Schoenberg Piano Concerto.

title: MRS. GLEN LEET
description: WESTON, Conn. Feb. 19 Mrs. Marcia Hatch Leet, the wife of Glen Leet, executive director of the SavetheChil dren Foundation and the Com munity Development Founda dation of Norwalk, died of a heart attack last evening. She was 52 years old and lived on Briar Oak Drive here.

title: Mutual Funds Bought Stock On Balance During January
description: The nation's mutual funds were net purchasers of $151.5 million of common stock and net sellers of $200.7million of other securities during January, the Investment Company Insti tute reported yesterday.

title: NEW ISSUES POST 9TH RISE IN ROW
description: The newissue market, where shares of companies that have never had public owners are traded, registered its ninth con secutive advance this week in active trading.

title: James Darren Triumphs
description: With 23,503 fans on hand, Friday night's featured Mount Vernon Pace, a Class AA handi cap onemile test for $17,500, went to the Carmine Abbatiello driven James Darren ($8.20) in 2:01 4/5. Joseph Scott, the 3to 5 favorite, broke stride at the start and finished last, wiping out $21,616 wagered on him across the board.

title: PRICE INDEX HERE IS UP A FRACTION
description: The consumers price index in the New York metropolitan area rose onetenth of 1 per cent last month, the smallest such increase reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in three years.

title: S.E.C. Disciplines Haight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (Reu ters)The Securities and Ex change Commission has re voked the brokerdealer regis tration of Haight & Co., Inc., formerly Hodgdon & Co., Inc., of Washington, for alleged viola tions of registration, antifraud and other provisions of Federal Securities laws.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolls Ties to Be Investigated
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The House Armed Services Committee disclosed today plans to inquire into Defense Department contracts with bankrupt RollsRoyce for en gines for United States military aircraft.

title: Texas Maintains March Oil Quota At February Level
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 19  In the presence of three Fed eral oil officials whose agencies have been critical of state oil proration, the Texas Railroad Commission set today oil pro duction for March at the same levels as February despite data showing substantial increases in aboveground stocks of crude oil in the last year.

title: 4Man Patrol on the Erie Line Is Reducing Vandalism
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Feb. 19 There are four of them here. men with flat  brimmed campaign hats trimmed in gold, and wearinob Sam Browne belts with pearl handled revolvers, with im pressive brass insignia on their uniforms.

title: Democrats Reform Rules On Convention Delegates
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 19  After a daylong dispute on a relatively minor issue, marked by parliamentary bickering and impassioned speeches, the Dem ocratic National Committee approved without debate today a farreaching set of reforms in the selection of delegates to the party's national conven tion.

title: Labor Department Finds Irregularities In Vote of Miners
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The Labor Department said today that a 10week investigation had found irregularities in an elec tion held in the United Mine Workers of America District 5 last December. The department evidence appeared certain to lead to months of courtroom argument about the election outcome.

title: 2 SENTENCED TO DIE IN GUARDS' SLAYING
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Feb. 19 (UPI)  Two prison inmates convicted of killing a deputy sheriff in an escape attempt were sentenced here today to die in the electric chair in the week starting April 5.

title: Travelers Lists Net Drop;
description: The Travelers Corporation the secondlargest allline in surer in the country after Aet na Life and Casualtyreported yesterday that aftertax earn ings fell to $80,598,000 last year from, $82,640,000 a year earlier.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19, (UPI) The Defense Department said today that the following service men from the New York area had been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: Lucille Lortel Gets Post
description: Lucille Lortel, artistic direc tor of the ANTA Matinee Series at the Theater DeLys, has been elected to the board of directors of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Agreement, Not Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Au thoritative diplomatic sources today pointed out a semantic complexity of the major Egyp tian diplomatic peace initiative made to Dr. Jarring this week week.

title: Ribicoff to Propose Revamping Of PX Purchasing Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff told American businessmen today that he would urge Con gress to order a complete re vamping of military post ex change purchasing procedures as a result of evidence of ex tensive bribery.

title: Mrs. Mallory Wed to C. M. Stilman Jr.
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 19 Mrs. Eleanor Davis Mallory, daughter of Mrs. Howard Carter Davis of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Davis, was married here this evening to Claude Mendenhall Stil man Jr., a widower and son of Mr. and Mrs. Stilman.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE RECENT DECLINES
description: The stock market plunged below the 880 support level yesterday as it closed lower for the third consecutive day.

title: Frank G. Siscoe, Expert on Reds As Foreign Service Aide, Dead
description: Frank G. Siscoe, a lawyer and a Foreign Service officer specializing in Communist af fairs for more than 20 years before his retirement in 1968, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home, 138 East Seventh Street, Plainfield, N.J. His age was 57.

title: Compton Coach Suspended
description: COMPTON, Calif, Feb. 19 (UPI)Jim Newman, the Comp ton College basketball coach, is under suspension today for hit ting a referee during a game against Ventura College last Wednesday night. According to college officials, Newman was reported to have rushed across the court and struck the referee, Rudy Aguilera. A wild scene followed during which pop bot tles were thrown and girl cheer leaders' blouses were ripped.

title: German Language Is Becoming Fractured Along the EastWest Frontier
description: BONN, Feb. 19  The Ger man language is slowly but perceptibly developing two fairly distinct vocabularies.

title: SCRIBNER URGES EDUCATION SHIFTS
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, Chancellor of New York City's public schools, said yesterday that a fundamental change was needed in what we define as education, in what we view as the purpose of the schools.

title: Con Ed Fixes Price Of $24.70 a Share On Stock Offering
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany of New York, Inc., fixed a subscription price of $24.70 a share yesterday on the 3,536, 167 shares of common stock being offered common Stock holders through a rights offer ing. The new shares are be ing offered to holders of record on Feb. 18 on the basis of one new share for each 12 shares held on the record date.

title: Free Phone Lines to Help G.M. Deal With Complaints
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19The Gen eral Motors Corporation says it will test a new method of handling customer complaints by putting a tollfree telephone connection between Chicago and G.M.'s headquarters in Detroit.

title: Polish Writer Reports Gierek Is Facing Opposition
description: WARSAW, Feb. 19A prom inent Polish writer said today that Edward Gierek, the Com munist party chief, was facing internal opposition from those who felt threatened by his new political and economic policies.

title: The Dance: Petrushka
description: A modified, greatly im proved version of the City Center Joffrey Ballet's pro duction of Petrushka was seen for the first time Thurs day night at the City Center.

title: BURNS HINTS NIXON IS TOO OPTIMISTIC ON OUTPUT FOR '71
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that the Federal Reserve believed the Nixon Administration's fore cast for the economy this year was probably too optimistic.

title: Columbia Defeats Brown
description: After Columbia's 6865 vic tory over Brown before 1,493 fans in University Gym last night, Jack Rohan, the Lions' coach, spent almost 20 minutes in the locker room talking to his players.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Anzi and Miss Proell Post World Cup Victories
description: KINGFIELD, Me., Feb. 19 An initial triumph in World Cup competition by Stefano Anzi of Italy, a repeat victory by Anne Marie Proell of Austria and a derringdo one ski performance by David Zwilling, also of Austria, were the highlights today on Sugar loaf Mountain.

title: N.B.C. Gets Waiver To Offer Programs 3 Hours Sundays
description: The Federal Communications Commission has granted a waiver to the National Broad casting Company to permit the television network to schedule programing from 7:30 to 11 P.M. on Sunday evenings next season.

title: TWO ARE KILLED IN GUNFIGHT HERE
description: A patrolman and a narcotics suspect were shot to death last night in a gunfight in a Harlem tenement hallway.

title: Nixon Gets V.F.W. Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  Herbert R. Rainwater, na tional commander of the Vet erans of Foreign Wars, said today that President Nixon was taking under advisement a VFW request that no more United States troops be with drawan from Indochina until North Vietnam agrees to an ex change of war prisoners. Mr. Rainwater made his statement after confering with the Presi dent.

title: French Youth, Center of Judicial Storm, Freed on Appeal
description: PARIS, Feb. 19As 10,000 young people waited in a near by boulevard behind lines of riot policemen today, an ap peals court freed a student who had been sentenced to prison on charges of having punched a policeman during a demonstra tion.

title: Tate Defendant Willing to Face Death
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19  Patricia Krenwinkel followed up her admission yesterday to participating in the TateLa Bianca slayings by telling the jury today that she was per fectly willing to face anything my own death.

title: Consumer Price Increase Is Smallest in Four Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  PostChristmas reductions in the prices of apparel along with other seasonal developments held the rise in the Consumer Price Index in January to its lowest level in four years.

title: 13 House Members Oppose Transfers Of 5 Antiwar G.I.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Thirteen members of the House of Representatives from New York charged today that five members of the 26th United States Army band stationed at Fort Wadsworth, S. I., are scheduled to be transferred to Korea and Vietnam because of their antiwar activities.

title: STOCK COMMITTEE. TO WATCH BIG BOARD
description: The Committee on Securities Industries Operations, reacti vated on Feb. 4 by securities industries leaders in the midst of the expanding trading vol ume, met yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange and de cided to meet at least once a week in order to keep watch on the volume of trading and its impact on backoffice proc essing.

title: 9 Motions Filed in Ray Case
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 19 (AP) Attorneys for James Earl Ray filed nine motions today de manding that the state of Ten nessee be forced to let the de fense examine evidence un covered in the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in April, 1968. The state has asked Judge William H. Wil liams of Criminal Court to re ject Ray's petition that his guilty plea and 99year prison sentence in the King murder be set aside. He seeks a new trial.

title: Aid for Children Accounts for 64% Of Rise in Welfare
description: Of the 17,988 persons added to the welfare roils in Decem ber, 64 per cent were in the Aid to Dependent Children category, Controller Abraham D. Beame reported yesterday.

title: Antiques: 18thCentury Dutch Silver Attracts New Attention
description: Increased interest in 18th century Dutch silver has been evident in both London and Amsterdam recently, Shops and auction rooms in both cities have been offering a variety of work in the rococo and neoclassical styles.

title: J. H. BAUMGARTNER, A RAIL PUBLICIST, 85
description: MADISON, N. J., Feb. 19 J. Hampton Baumgartner, re tired manager of public rela tions for the former Lacka wanna Railroad, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 51 Fairwoods Road.

title: Cambridge Theater Stages Shaw Play; Bergman Has Lead
description: LONDON, Feb. 19As Shaw wrote Captain Brassbound's Conversion as a vehicle for Ellen Terry, only a prig could object to its revival by the Cambridge Theater on the same terms for Ingrid Bergman. If anything, I suspect that its masterful heroine, Lady Cicely Waynflete, fits Miss Bergman's queenly style better than the softgrained femininity of the actress Shaw tried to portray.

title: Boston's Vincent Club: Elite and Thriving
description: BOSTONThe rituals and traditions of Old Guard society may be under siege these days, but the Vincent Club, considered the most exclusive women's club in this land of Cabots and Lodges and one of the most lite on the Eastern seaboard, is not only alive but thriving.

title: Bus Terminal
description: While the filthiness of the Bus Terminal at Eighth Avenue and 40th Street may be a relatively small matter, it reflects a publicbedamned attitude of the. New York Port Authority, which operates the disgracefully main tained terminal. This attitude is underlined in larger matters by the Authority's persistent refusal to make New York City more adequate payment in lieu of taxes it pays the city $10 million a year, in lieu of taxes that city officials now estimate would come to $66 million as well as in its historic neglect of mass transit needs. New Jersey Governor Cahill's welltaken criticism of the Authority on this score, coupled with rumblings in the New York Legislature, may yet force some overdue changes in the Port Authority's priorities.

title: Apollo Crew Found First Moon Stones With Angular Faces
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Some moon stones brought back to earth by the Apollo 14 astronauts have angular faces and fresh fractures un like any lunar matter seen be fore by man, space scientists said today.

title: Illegal School Suspensions
description: The study by the New York Civil Liberties Union of 115 instances in which pupils were suspended last year from their schools adds up to a serious indictment of the system's disciplinary practices. Students' rights in many cases appear to have been given short shrift. The fact that in one year the staggering total of 14,000 suspen sions took place raises questions why this form of punish ment was so exclusively used.

title: C. W. Post Wins, 8972, From St. Anselm's Five
description: BROOKVILLE. L. I., Feb. 19 Jim Webber scored 22 points to pace C. W. Post to an 8972 Northeast League victory over St. Anselm's tonight.

title: Adolf A. Berle Jr.
description: Adolf A. Berle Jr., adviser to Presidents of both parties since Woodrow Wilson, knew almost everything that was happening in government circlesand made more of it happen than most. Brilliant, articulate and aware of his own impressive attributes, he could have played the role of eminence grise, but his was too shimmering a character to be thought of as any shade of gray.

title: 9 INDICTED IN THEFT OF AIRLINE TICKETS
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19 (AP)An Essex County grand jury has indicted nine persons, seven of them from New Jersey, on charges involving the theft and forgery of airline tickets that could have cost the carriers up to $1million in fares.

title: Jews in Soviet Are Warned Against Espousing Zionism
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19Pravda, the Communist party news paper, warned Soviet Jews today that anyone espousing Zionist beliefs would automatically become an agent of in ternational Zionism and hence an enemy of the Soviet people.

title: Upstate and Downstate Differ on Tax Plan
description: News Analysis

title: Art: Marin Retrospective at Whitney
description: When John Marin, whose big retrospective exhibition opened at the Whitney Mu seum Thursday, died at the age of 83 in 1953, he was at once the grand old man of modernism in American paint ing and an artist who was generally conceded to have finished his career, as far as important work was con cerned, in the 1920's. During those years he had developed a vigorous personal style that split its loyalties be tween cubist organization and expressionist freedom both rather adventurous sources at that time. The energy of New York City and the energy of nature were expressed in cubistically dis rupted skyscrapers and wind filled landscapes and sea scapes of the Maine coast. The word energy probably occurred more frequently in discussions of Marin's early work than in those of any other painter.

title: PRICE RECORDS SET ON LIGHT MINK FURS
description: A group of 100,000 lightskin mutation mink furs offered by the United Mink Producers As sociation yesterday drew the highest prices of the season for such skins at the Hudson's Bay Fur Auction Company here.

title: Dr. Frank L. Horsfall Jr. Dies; SloanKettering Institute Head
description: Dr. Frank L. Horsfall Jr., president and director of the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research, died last eve ning at the institute, 410 East 68th Street. He was 64 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Comsat
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)  The Communications Satel lite Corporation reported today that net income for 1970 rose to $17.5million, or $1.75 a share, up from $7.1million, or 71 cents a share, in 1969.

title: TEDDY HART DIES; STAGE COMEDIAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19  Teddy Hart, the comedian of stage and screen, died Wednes day evening in Westside Hos pital. He was 74 years old.

title: TREIGLE COMPLETES ROLE DESPITE COLD
description: One had to give the devil his due on Thursday night at the State Theater. The New York City Opera was giving its first performance of Mefistofele in its current season, and Norman Treigle struggled through the title role triumphantly despite a bad cold.

title: 4Year Search That. Paid Off in a Duplex
description: ST. LOUISFourteen years ago, Frank H. Schwaiger, then 16, delivered a package for his mother to a tenant a nineteenthirties building and found himself an apart mentalthough he didn't know it at the time.

title: A Hospital Owner Tells Inquiry He Has AbortionSteering Unit
description: A surgeon who is part owner of Madison Avenue Hospital a profitmaking institution where abortions are performed on a large scaleacknowledged yesterday that he had set up an agency to steer patients to his hospital.

title: Railroads' Freight Traffic Fell by 5% in Latest Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week ended Feb. 13 totaled an esti mated 13.9 billion tonmiles, 5 per cent below the correspond ing week last year.

title: RENT IS CUT OFF IN WELFARE CASE
description: The Human Resources Ad ministration has cut off a rent allowance for the welfare client who lived in the WaldorfAs toria Hotel at city expense on Jan. 19 and 20.

title: COUNT BELA NADIK, A DOG BREEDER, 66
description: Count Bela Hadik of Chester, N. H., where he founded the Futaki Kennels and bred Vizsla Hungarian pointers, died Tues day in Camden, S. C., after a long illness. His age was 66.

title: Opera: Werther Revival
description: Massenet's Werther, re vived last night by the Metro politan Opera in a new pro duction, went on without one of its big guns. There was a delay before the curtain went up, and then Osie Hawkins, the stage manager, appeared to make an announcement. He said that Franco Corelli was indisposed, and that on 15minute notice, Enrico Di Giuseppe would replace him.

title: SCRIPPS TO SELL CINCINNATI PAPER
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 19  The E. W. Scripps Company has agreed to sell control of this city's morning and Sunday newspaper, The Enquirer, to the American Financial Corpo ration.

title: 2 Coast Bishops Named
description: ROME, Feb, 19 (AP)Pope Paul VI has named two new Auxiliary, Bishops for Los Angeles, the Vatican announced today. Both men were made Bishops. They are the Right Rev. William R. Johnson, 52 years old, a native of Tonopah, Nev., and the Rev. Juan A. Ar zube, also 52, who was born in Ecuador.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTONThe Bureau of Labor Statistics reported to day the following spot primary prices for the week ended Feb. 16:

title: Price of Silver Shows Small. Gain In Dull Trading
description: In Another dull timemarking day for most commodity fu tures, silver futures showed a little gleam. Prices firmed at least a cent and a half for all deliveries in moderate volume of 1,937 contracts.

title: Outstanding Individual Performances Sparkle in the Olympic Meet
description: Tom Von Ruden celebrated his honeymoon with a world indoor record, Cheryl Toussaint showed courage where it counted and Marty Liquori won his 13th consecutive race at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: 5 Seized and 5 Hurt in Fights Inside George Washington High
description: Fighting broke out between Spanishspeaking students and black students in the George Washington High School cafe teria yesterday after robberies in the school earlier this week of Spanish girl students.

title: 10TH JUROR SET FOR SEALE TRIAL
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 A young black woman who said she had never discussed the Black Panthers with anyone was added today to the jury that will hear the murder case against Bobby G. Seale, co founder and chairman of the Black Panther Party.

title: Delegate Strength Table
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The following table shows the allocation of delegates to the states at the 1968 Democratic National Convention, together with the recommendations of the O'Hara reform commission for the 1972 convention and the plan for 1972 adopted today by the Democratic Na tional Committee at a meeting here:

title: ROCHE AGAIN SEES HIGH '71 CAR SALES
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19  James M. Roche, chairman of the Gen eral Motors Corporation, said today that the auto industry was not out of the woods yet, but we believe a 9.5 million to 10 million year for cars is with in reach.

title: Elections? Rural India Shrugs
description: The Talk of Uttar Pradesh

title: Laver Outlasts Emerson, 63, 57, 63, 36, 63, for a Sweep of 11 Matches
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19And then there were none.

title: BROWNING SOLOIST IN PROKOFIEV THIRD
description: John Browning played Pro kofiev's Third Piano Concerto with the Cleveland Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Thursday night as though the work were his private tour de force.

title: Book's 2 Pigs Stir Censorship Row
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19The American Library Association wheeled up its anticensorship guns today and prepared to do battle in support of two pigs and a donkey named Sylvester.

title: BUILDING WORKERS VOTE TO END STRIKE
description: Striking building service work ers voted yesterday to end a 19dayold walkout in city owned buildings scheduled for demolition in urban renewal areas.

title: MISS HILLEBRECHT IN MET'S ELEKTRA
description: The season's fourth Elektra brought a new Chrysothemis to the Metropolitan Opera produc tion of Strauss's gory oneact tale. Hildegarde Hillebrecht, handsomely buxom and wear ing long blonde curls of the sort that infallibly identify rel atively innocent young women in operas, filled the role quite nimbly, both vocally and physi cally. As weak sister to Birgit Nilsson's Elektra, Miss Hille brecht performed most credibly. Barring a few places where her large and mezzotinted but not overpowering soprano voice sagged under the strain and lost focus and pitch on top, she met most requirements nicely.

title: De Vicenzo's 67 for a 137 Leads Panama Golf by Shot
description: PANAMA, Feb. 19 (UPI) Roberto de Vicenzo of Argen tina shot a 5underpar 67 to day to lead the second round of the Panama open with a total of 137 for 36 holes.

title: Dunphy Voted Award
description: Don Dunphy, who has broad cast over 1,000 major fights in the last three decades, was an nounced yesterday by the Box ing Writers Association as the winner of the James J. Walker Memorial Award for long and meritorious service to boxing.

title: Retail Chains' Sales Rose 7.9% in January Over '70
description: Leading chainstore organi zations in the country began the new year with a sales gain of 7.9 per cent over 1970, re porting volume of $2,150,997, 612 last month, compared with $1,993,468,828 in January of 1970.

title: Knicks Oppose Pistons Tonight
description: Having escaped luckily with an even break on their two game road trip to Southern California, the Knicks  still unsteady despite the return of Willis Reed  resume action tonight at Madison Square Gar den against the Detroit Pis tons.

title: Lunokhod to Rest Again
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (Reuters)  Soviet scientists put their automated moon cart, Luno khod 1, through its paces again today for the last time before parking the remotecontrolled vehicle for its third lunar night. The press agency Tass said the eightwheel lunokhod, landed on the moon's Sea of Rains Nov. 17, had carried out the concluding experiments of its fourth lunar day.

title: HERBERT W. SUTER
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, Feb. 19 Herbert W. Suter, a retired di rector and senior vice presi dentmarketing of Champion Papers, Inc., died at his home here on Tuesday. He was 87 years old.

title: Brandt Welcomes Big 4 Gains on Berlin
description: BERLIN, Feb. 19Chancel lor Willy Brandt today wel comed the progress made by the Big Four in their talks on Berlin but refused to comment in detail about Western pro posals that rule out constitu tional links between West Ber lin and West Germany.

title: His Face Outmoded CleanCut Look
description: He looks like a gaucho on the pampas, a Venetian gon dolier or a Greek fisherman in a waterfront taverna. He has a drooping mustache, an arrowshaped nose and sleepy blue eyes.

title: Dutschke Leaves Britain
description: LONDON, Feb. 19  Rudi Dutschke, the radical student leader from West Germany, left Britain today, five weeks after a Government tribunal declared that his continued presence would endanger na tional security. Mr. Dutschke, who is 30 years old, is taking up a teaching appointment at Aarhus University in Denmark.

title: Ryan Equals Record Of 3: 56.4 in Coast Mile
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 19 (UPI) Jim Ryun, the former Kan sas University distance flash, equaled the world indoor mile record tonight at the San Diego Indoor Games when he was timed in 3 min utes 56.4 seconds.

title: True North Favored in Widener Today
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19  A field of 13, with C.V. Whitney's True North the likely favorite, has been named for the Widener Handicap at Hialeah tomorrow.

title: U.S. TO PAY HOLDERS OF SEIZED CONCERN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (Reu ters)The United States Court of Claims today ordered the Government to pay $22.2mil lion to Americans whose stock in the General Dyestuffs Corpo ration was seized in 1942 on suspicion the concern was con trolled by the powerful Ger man cartel, I. G, Farben Indus trie A.G.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: On a Street of Racial Harmony in Jakarta, Electric Power to the People
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 19Jalan Sumbing is an up permiddleclass dirt side street here that in most American cities would be on the other side of the tracks. It has 46 families living in 34 houses, all but one of which are singlestory.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE. The New York Times Biographical Edition. Profiles of today's newsmakers in a loose leaf edition. Write: The New York Times. Library Services, Box FP480, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036Advt.

title: On the Platform With Mao Tsetung
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.As an N.A.A.C.P. official forced to flee the South in 1961, I had not the slightest concept of the magnitude of the forces that would hew my destiny.

title: Du Pont Statement
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 19 Du Pont said today in a state ment that it had a major en vironmental control program under way at East Chicago!

title: Reward Offered in Theft
description: ATTLEBORO, Mass., Feb. 19 (UPI)The Handy and Harman Company announced today it had offered a $5,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons responsible for the theft of $1.8 million in gold. The company disclosed Feb. 9 that a physical inventory taken in conjunction with a yearend audit had re vealed a shortage of $1.8mil lion in gold at its plant here.

title: Maria Mallen Bride of Lieutenant
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 19Miss Maria Lavell Mallen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Mallen, was married here this afternoon in St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church to Lieut. Paul Frederick Hefele, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hefele of Yonkers.
