The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles J. Mur phy, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: JOHN J. HOGAN SR., 67 WITH PUBLIC WORKS
description: John J. Hogan Sr., senior management consulting engi neer of the Department of Pub lic Works, and a troubleshooter on concrete construction, died here Thursday. He was 67 years old and lived at 380 East 201st Street, the Bronx.

title: Cornell Trounces Yale
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 19 Cornell built a halftime lead of 4321 tonight and went on to trounce Yale, 9372, in an Ivy League game.

title: Mrs. Winthrop Rockefeller Will Divorce Former Governor
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19 Winthrop Rockefeller and his wife announced today, through an aide of the former Arkansas Governor here, that they would be divorced.

title: PACE SERIES GETS ITS FIRST ENTRY
description: YONKERS, Feb. 19 Thomas E. Lynch, the execu tive vice president of Yonkers Raceway, telephoned this morn ing from Christchurch, New Zealand to announce that Mount Eden would represent Australia in the raceway's 12th annual International pacing series next spring.

title: U.S. Rules Out Aid To Feed the Needy In 10 Balky Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI)  A Nixon Administra tion spokesman today ruled out direct Federal action, to feed needy families In 10 holdout counties that have refused to cooperate, in adopting Govern ment food aid programs.

title: DUPONT, U.S. STEEL SUED AS POLLUTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Federal Government filed suit today to force the United States Steel Corporation and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. to stop polluting waters in northwestern Indiana.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mink PriceFixing Laid to Dressers In F.T.C. Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion accused various New York fur dressers today of fixing prices of mink pelts destined for fur coats.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON DRIFT DOWNWARD
description: The London stock market drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday. The lack of substan tial selling limited losses, how ever, and special situations helped retain interest.

title: HODGSON PLEDGES NO WAGE FREEZE
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson assured labor's top command today that President Nixon was not interested in imposing overall wage and price controls on the nation's economy.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 19  For the last three years a journal called A Chronicle of Current Events has appeared about every two months in the Soviet Union. Its purpose is to tell the truth about political trials and the other ways in which dissenters are persecuted in the O.S.S.R.

title: Soccer Ace Sold at $408,0001
description: DERBY, England, Feb. 19 (AP)Derby County of the Brit ish Soccer League bought Colin Todd from Sunderland today for $408,000, a British record for (the transfer of one player.

title: AMEX DIP BIGGEST SINCE NOVEMBER
description: The American. Stock Ex change took its Worst beating yesterday in more than three months as the list retreated in moderate trading.

title: RITES FOR DETECTIVE ATTENDED BY 4,000
description: About 3,000 fellow police men, Mayor Lindsay and other dignitaries were among 4,000 mourners yesterday at the fu neral of Detective. Joseph Pic ciano Jr.

title: Consider Vermont
description: WHEELOCK, Vt.When our family moved to northern Vermont, friends in the city and suburbs were envious. I wish we could do that, they said. So there might seem little need to defend or justify the escape from the metropolis and from all those awful, insoluble problems.

title: Shulton Officer Resigns
description: Shulton, Inc., announced yes terday the resignation of Wil liam H. O'Brien as president and a director of the company, effective Feb. 28. George L. Schultz, chairman and chief ex ecutive officer, will reassume the responsibilities of president. The reason behind the move by Mr. O'Brien was to devote his time to other business and personal interests, the company said.

title: War Protests Set For 12 Campuses Beginning Monday
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 19 Plans for teachins to re kindle student opposition to the war in Indochina are gathering steam on a dozen campuses throughout the country.

title: Paul Signac, an Artist of Imitation
description: There have been recent at tempts  more commercial than critical to elevate Paul Signac, the neoImpressionist seascape painter, to the aw some ranks of master. De spite these efforts he remains not a great artist but rather an artist of a certain talent.

title: Service Academies Strive to Stay in Step With the Times
description: Hello. . . . this is General Clark. . . . Thank you for calling. . . . When you hear the dial tone, please state your question, problem or complaint. If you desire, you may give your name, address or unit as signment. . . . Either way, I'll see you get an answer.

title: NEPENTHE TAKES RACE TO LUCAYA
description: LUCAYA, Bahamas, Feb. 19 With the two glamour yachts, American Eagle and Windward Passage, dismasted in the tur bulent Gulf Stream, the 50foot sloop Nepenthe today won the 150mile MiamiLucaya race.

title: Morton Postpones Decision on Alaskan Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, told Con gress today that he was a long way from deciding that an 800mile pipeline was the best way to tap Alaska's rich north ern oil reserves.

title: MUSEUM PUTS OFF REMOVAL OF STAIR
description: Deferring to public feeling, the Metropolitan Museum has indefintely postponed a decision to remove the Grand Stair in its main hall, which leads to the secondfloor exhibition gal leries.

title: Chase Buys Bank in Detroit From Itself
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday went through an elaborate legal charade, which resulted in Chase buying from itself 39 per cent control of the Bank of the Common wealth, Detroit, for $5:4million.

title: ROBINSON TO GET SEAT ON RING UNIT
description: Jackie Robinson confirmed yesterday his imminent ap pointment to the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: Psychiatrist Ousted as Calley Witness And All of His Testimony Is Expunged
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 19 A New York psychiatrist was dismissed as a defense witness in the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L.. Calley Jr. this morning after the military judge expressed doubt as to the truth of his sworn testi mony.

title: Edward Weeks Weds Miss Adams
description: THOMPSON, Conn., Feb. 19Miss Phoebe Adams of Boston, an editor of The At lantic Monthly, and Edward A. Weeks, also of Boston, senior editor and consultant with The Atlantic Monthly Press, were married here this afternoon, the bridegroom's 73d birthday.

title: Higher Auto Output Set
description: DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP)  Domestic car production was scheduled to reach a threeyear high this week, with auto makers planning to assemble 196,404 vehiclesthe largest output since the week ended Dec. 14, 1968, when 203,803 cars were made.

title: Tax Agent Is Found Guilty Of Perjury in Bribery Case
description: A special Internal Revenue Service agent was convicted in Federal District Court here yes terday of perjury before a grand jury investigating bribery charges in tax cases.

title: SOME DEMOCRATS LAUD NIXON PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19  President Nixon's health care proposals prompted suprisingly cordial comments by some De mocrats today as White House aides worked to finish drafting the initial legislation that will be sent to Congress Monday.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Johnny Gandia lay on a rubbing table, his head propped on a black overnight bag, and Stared at a yellow stone wall. I'm confident, he said. I got a lot of confidence. But I'm a little nervous. These are better guys than last week. I'm gonna have to go out and make it fast, knock 'im right out.

title: W.A.C. TRACK LEAD TO BRIGHAM YOUNG
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20 (UPI)The defending cham pion, Brigham Young Univer sity, took a 4136 lead over University of Texas at El Paso last night in the first night of the Western Athletic Confer ence indoor track champion ships.

title: Employes Accuse Company of. Fraud
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs said yester day that it had received com plaints that a corporation here had defrauded newly hired em ployes of thousands of dollars after providing them with an armload of dreams.

title: Miss Maddock Plans Nuptials
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20Miss Paula Mimi Mad dock and William Tyson Kemble Jr. plan to be mar ried here on April 10.

title: London Contest Shunned
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 20 (Reuters)Organizers of the nonwhite Miss Africa South contest have voted against sending a contestant to this year's Miss World competition in London because doing so might be interpreted as accept ing South Africa's laws on apartheid, or separation of the races.

title: Jazz: A Piano Roll Sampler
description: PARLOR PIANO, 19171927 (Biograph 1001 Q). THOMAS FATS WALLER, 19231924 (Biograph 1002 Q). JAMES P. JOHNSON, 191721 (Bio graph 1003 Q). JELLY ROLL MORTON, 192426 (Biograph 1004 Q). Recordings made by jazz pianists in the early twen ties, are for the most part, rel atively crude examples of re cording technique which of ten survive today only on scratchy disks. The piano rolls that these pianists made at the same time have not suffered as much deteriora tion but they had technical limitations of their own. How ever, reproduced with con temporary recording facilities, these rolls can give us a less fuzzy view of the pianist's work, particularly when the recording of the rolls has been supervised by as knowl edgeable a piano roll expert as Michael Montgomery who has selected the tempos, pumped the rolls and written the excellent annotation for this series of transfers from QRS rolls made between 1917 and 1927

title: COMPUTER HELPS FIRE DEPARTMENT
description: Faced with an evergrowing number of fires to fight and limited resources for the job, the Fire Department has begun streamlining operations with the aid of a computerized model that simulates and eval uates the deployment of men and equipment.

title: The Nation
description: LOS ANGELESA fellow Re publican Governor was musing last week about the record of Ronald Reagan. You know, he said, Reagan was first elected with all that Birch Societytype rhetoric. After he got in he seemed to be learning. I was delighted with his progress. But that last budget of his goes back to all that Birch Society stuff.

title: Public Housing Is Fought in Forest Hills
description: Residents of Forest Hills and surrounding areas in Queens are trying to prevent the build ing of a huge lowincome public I housing project in their middle class neighborhood, but the city is continuing with its plan to begin construction this summer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: POST OFFICES TO AID PASSPORT PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The State Department says it plans to start issuing passports through selected post offices across the nation by the end of this year.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Fashion is becoming in volved in short shortsof ten referred to as hot pants and the subject is generat ing much discussion on Sev ??th Avenue where it is im portant to know how a style trend will be received.

title: Is the Mediterranean Dying?
description: IF some of Italy's most prominent scientists are correct, the death of the Mediterranean is imminent. While the United States and Britain are getting used to the idea that pollution can be overcome, Italythe country with what may be the worst problem in the worldhas not begun to think in terms of solution at all; it has barely recognized that a problem exists.

title: JACKSONVILLE WINS 14TH IN ROW, 12490
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)A freewheeling at tack gave the sixthranked Jacksonville Dolphins their 14th straight victory today in a 12490 rout of Valdosta State.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Ice on Lines Cuts the Power To 2 Upstate TV Stations
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20 (UPI)  Two television stations and sev eral FM radio stations were put off the air today by weather connected power trouble in the Thatcher Park area southwest of here.

title: TRIBE IN RHODESIA LOSING LAND FIGHT
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 20 (AP)For four years Tang wena tribesmen have defied the Government by occupying land set aside for whites. Now, it seems, legal pressure is work ing and the Africans are begin ning to realize that there is lit tle point in fighting further.

title: Petersham Rink Reaches Semifinals at St. Andrew's
description: MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 20The defending champion Petersham, Mass., Curling Club rink, skipped by Edward Getto, advanced to the semifinals of the 16th annual St. Andrews international mixed bonspiel today. It defetated Rochester C. C., skipped by E. F. (Saint) St. Mary, 124, at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Reader's Report
description: Jewish mystique, Southern style, is the exotic shortening in which this melodrama is bast ed. Talk about parochialism boy howdy! (One rabbi of Man nerville, La.'s, Temple Isaiah was let go for using too much Hebrew in the Friday night services.) The tragic hero of Mr. Ansell's tale is the patri archal Arthur Sherman, mer chant prince, pillar of the B'nai B'rith and past president of the country club. Sherman belongs to an American subcul ture that has been carefully as similated into a background of wisteria trees. In fact, he suc ceeds in being the most unob trusively powerful man in townuntil a pointless disaster destroys his reputation and his way of life.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Blacks
description: Selecting a representative group of paperbacks dealing with significant issues involving Negroes is no easy matter. Paperback publishers seem increasingly bereft of viable criteria of relevance in the choice of books they issue on Negroes: Anything that touches on Negro topics seems pub lishable, and standards of relevance, caliber and sophistication are tossed to the winds.

title: Dance: Paul Sutherland
description: Prodigal sons are tradi tionally, welcome and al though I am not sure whether there was a fatted calf backstage at the City. Center Friday night, it was certainly a pleasure to see Paul Sutherland make his New York return with the City Center Joffrey Ballet.

title: Victoria Castao Wed to Joseph Roach
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Feb. 20 Miss Victoria Lynne Castao and Joseph Justin Roach were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Ro man Catholic Church by the Rev. Alfred J. Rogers, who celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Colombo Leaves Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Premier Emilo Colombo of Italy completed a twoday offi cial visit to Washington today with an hourlong meeting with President Nixon before heading for Houston, where he is to visit the Manned Spacecraft Center. He is to go to Boston tomorrow and to New York Monday.

title: National Notes
description: Macon County Sheriff Lucius D. Amerson is the first Negro elected sheriff in Alabama since Reconstruction days. Last week he was indicted by a Federal grand juryunder a Reconstruc tionera civil rights act designed to protect the rights of newly emancipated slaves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeper of Small Zoo in Flushing Meadow Says City Neglects
description: We are supposed to be zoo, said Mrs. Tatiana Gill etteInfante. Do we have mon keys, elephants, tigers, lions, giraffes? No. We are supposed to be what somebody said was tb be a North American zoo. O.K., but we don't even have ine North American cat.

title: CHARLES STEWART VICTOR IN SHOW
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 20Mr. and Mrs. Patrick But ler, who have produced a long line of top jumpersmany of which they have contributed to the United States Equestrian Team apparently have come up with another winner.

title: Dance
description: WHATEVER one thinks of Igor Stravinsky as an artist, the im pression left by his writing, and that of his oddly literary alter ego, Robert Craft, is of a querulous old man. His writingand that of Mr. Craftprobably does his personality an injustice, but in any event it would be a hard heart that could not feel compassion for Stravin sky for the way his Firebird music was being used last week at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music by the French choreographer Maurice Mart. I only trust that Stravinsky is getting his royalty pay ments properly, for nothing else could offset the choreog raphic insult to his music.

title: A Wider War?
description: President Nixon's threat to employ American air power without restraint throughout Indochina and his refusal to rule out a South Vietnamese invasion of North Viet nam remove virtually all doubt that the President still thinking in terms of the willo'thewisp of military victory in Southeast Asia.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Gardens
description: SPRING will be a little sad this year for New Yorkers. Their fa vorite preview, the International Flower Show, will not be held at the Coliseum. Officials announced can cellation of the show because of finan cial losses over the last three years. In 1970, the International lost about $60,000.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)  Ted Abernathy, relief pitcher for the Kansas City Royals, worked out for the first time with the club in spring training today. He is starting his 11th season in the major leagues and his 20th in pro baseball. Abernathy will be 38 years old when the Royals start exhibition play here March 6. He had a 93 wonlost record with the Roy als last year.

title: Dance Mailbag
description: HOW difficult it is for me to put into words all that my colleagues and I feel after three weeks of performances in New York. We have had a very positive experience, which will enable us to take an important step, not only artistically but even more in a deep human sense. For we have experienced the enthusi asm and love of an audience in another of the world's great cities, and it is this quality of response which nourishes every creative artist.

title: A Chinese Puzzle in the Jungle: Work Stops on New Laos Road
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 14 Highway One, the mystery road the Chinese Communists are building from Yunnan Province of China into northern Laos, has become more of a puzzle than ever.

title: Polish Consumer:
description: WARSAWFor many Polish families, life has become a joy less grind, marked by short ages, bureaucracy, restrictions and regulations.

title: The Nation
description: SAIGON  Indochina, ironi cally, is hardly the place to be to learn the resultsif, indeed, there are any substantial re sultsof the South Vietnamese drive into Laos to cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail. Compared to the allied drive into the Cam bodian sanctuaries last year, with American ground forces fighting theme for two months, the Laos campaign seems almost invisible from here.

title: Wings' Rally Beats Sabres
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20 (UPI) Red Berenson capped a furious Red Wing rally with a goal at 19:14 of the third period tonight and Detroit registered a 65 vic tory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: SATELLITE TO SEND POLLUTION DATA
description: GENEVA, Feb. 20  The United States is preparing to launch next year a new earth resources surveying satellite that will supply data on air and water pollution to any country that asks for it.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Karen Shelby Reinauer Engaged
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 20Miss Karen Shelby Rein auer, a laboratory technolo gist with the pathology de partment at New England Deaconess Hospital and Jos lin Clinic in Boston, plans to be married in September to Roger W. Raffetto.

title: Movies
description: HE came from out of the north by northwest, and hardly anyone had heard of him. And then all of a sudden, THERE HE WAS: A 71yearold Indian chief from British Columbia with a flowing silver mane and a kindly, hewnoutofbuckskin face and 36 grandchildren. But what made Chief Dan George's name a household wordat least in the households of film critics and Dustin Hoffman fans was his outstanding performance as the wise and lovable old chief in Arthur Penn's Little Big Man, a Custerand theIndians saga from the Indians' point of view for a change. Both the New York Film Critics and the National So ciety of Film Critics gave him their awards as Best Supporting Actor of 1970, and he is a strong contender for an Oscar nomination tomorrow.

title: Medical School Applications Up Despite Lag in Funds and Space
description: American medical schools in the last 10 years have rejected nearly 100,000 applicants twice what Federal officials say is the current national shortage of doctorsthough admissions committees considered many of those who were turned down to be eminently qualified to be physicians.

title: NEW LAW SCHOOL RISES AT HOFSTRA
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Feb. 20  Dean Malachy T. Mahon gazed out of the office window where construction was still going on at Hofstra University for the first law school to be established in the state in 45 years and discussed the great est problem in starting a law school money.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Leafs Beat Blues, 31
description: TORONOTO, Feb. 20 (UPI) Two goals In the third period by Dave Keon enabled the Toronto Maple Leafs to defeat the St. Louis Blues, 31 tonight.

title: Forcible Shearing of Long Haired Youths Near Athens Raises Protests
description: ATHENS, Feb. 20The forc ible shearing of 40 longhaired men at a police station in a workingclass suburb of Athens has suddenly become what is regarded as a test of the mili tarybacked regime's respect for its own laws.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Triumphs by 7562, Foiling Cornell's Late Rally
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 20 Brown University held off a late Cornell rally tonight to de feat the Big Red, 7562.

title: ISRAEL TO REVIEW JERUSALEM Pun
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 20Isra el's Ministry of Housing has agreed to demands by Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem for a broad review of the largest and most controversial of the new housing projects planned for the hills and valleys around the city.

title: Only the Poor Riding Buses in Many Cities
description: WINSTON  SALEM, N. C. Feb. 20Once there were two bus lines in this city one for Negroes, one for whites. Now there is only oneand it is on the brink of collapse.

title: Carol Moore Is Betrothed
description: BERWICK, Pa., Feb. 20 Miss Carol Arline Moore, a reporter for the Public Broad casting Service in Washing ton, will be married in May to Geoffrey Evans Geilich, acting director of Public af fairs, United States Equal Employment Opportunity Cotrimission.

title: Bill Bars Supersonic Plane
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 20 (AP) A bill to prohibit a supersonic transport from ever landing in Maine has been filed by Rep resentative Jay P. McCloskey, Democrat of Bangor. It would bar any aircraft emitting a noise level greater than 108 perceived decibels. That is the limit placed on subsonic trans ports by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: COLUMBIA FENCERS BEAT CORNELL, 198
description: Columbia's fencers, the de fending Ivy League Champions, raised their season wonlost record to 71 by defeating Cornell, 19.8, in University Gym yesterday.

title: Mrs. King and Miss Durr Advance to Final in Tennis
description: LIGHTHOUSE POINT, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King reached the finale of a women's professional tennis tournament today with a 75, 64 victory over Kerry Melville of Australia.

title: For a Russian Strong Man, Life Can Weigh Heavily
description: PARIS, Feb. 20 (UPI)If there's one thing that Vasily Alekseyev of the Soviet Union hates, it's being called the strong est man in the world.

title: Corporate Wives Studied
description: Most wives agreed with the corporation; they too felt that the good wife is the wife who adjusts graciously to the system, curbs open intellec tualism or the desire to be alone.

title: Favored Daryl's Joy Rallies to Win $65,300 San Luis Obispo on Turf
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 20 (UPI)New Zealandbred Dar yl's Joy scored his third straight stakes success today when he raced to a halflength victory in the $65,300 San Luis Obispo Handicap on the turf at Santa Anita.

title: HOFSTRA SUBDUES WAGNER, 91 TO 80
description: Quinas Brower's 16 points in the second half led Hofstra to a 9180 victory over Wagner last night at the Wagner court. Dave Bell and Ed Link paced the winners with 18 and 16 points, respectively. Gene Guer riero was high man for the losers with 26 points.

title: THE WEEK. IN FINANCE
description: ANEW moodmore cautious and more question ing but perhaps quite temporary as well  ap peared to be enveloping investors last week the spectacular rally in the financial markets finally began to taper off after its threemonth surge.

title: Nuclear Alert Proves False
description: A human error yesterday put Americans on an emergency alert of the type that would be used in a nuclear attack.

title: Brewster Sees a Moral Flaw in Vietnam Policy
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20King mon Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University, declared today that the basic flaw in qui Southeastern Asian war policy is moral.

title: Mayor John Belk of Charlotte Weds Judge Claudia Watkins
description: DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 20 Mayor John Montgomery Belk of Charlotte and District Court Judge Claudia Erwin Watkins, also of Charlotte, were married here today. The ceremony was performed in St, Phillip's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thomas Eugene Bollinger.

title: Royals Defeat Braves
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 20 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals ran off 15 straight points in the second period to open a 5436 lead and then coasted to a 12094 victory over the Buffalo Braves tonight.

title: Coast Guard Helicopter Seeks Pollution in L.I. Sound
description: Lieut. Comdr. Thomas Keane pointed the nose of his Coast Guard rescue heli copter out over the Atlantic from Floyd Bennett Field, wheeled across Jones Beach and headed for Long Island Sound. His mission was to search the shorelines for ev idence of oil pollution.

title: Carolyn Russell Is Betrothed To William Waldo Mauritz
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam Hutchins Russell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Walker Russell, to William Wado Mauritz, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Waldo Mauritz of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Petraglia Defeats Lichstein in Bowling Final
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Feb. 20 (UPI)Johnny Petrag lia defeated Larry Lichstein, 202196, today to capture the $80,000 WinstonSalem Bowl ing Classic.

title: Michelle Milikowsky Is Engaged
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20 Mrs. Matthew Milikowsky has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Michelle Milikowsky, to Rich ard S. Harman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abbot A. Harman of New York.

title: Left of Lincoln
description: Foremost among 19thcentury champions of equal rights for black Americans, Charles Sum ner helped translate the equal itarian objectives of the aboli tionist movement into national policy. In his Pulitzer Prize winning biography Charles Sumner and the Coming of the Civil War (1960), David Don ald traced the first 50 years of this son of Brahmin Boston his role in carrying antislavery radicalism into politics; his part in the founding of the Repub lican party; his martyrdom at the hands of Representative Preston Brooks of South Car olina, who caned the defense less Sumner into unconscious ness on the Senate floor in 1856. By the time of Lincoln's election and the secession of the South, Sumner had emerged as a leader of the Republican faction called radicals be cause of their uncompromising hostility toward slavery.

title: Pros and Cons: Should Colleges Allow the Dunk?
description: Bring back the dunk, say many of the nation's college basketball coaches.

title: Basic bisque
description: Back in the old days, the thick cream soup we call bisque was usually made with crawfish or other shellfish. Later, the repertory of bisques came to include game, both furred and featheredquail and pheasant and rabbit and the like. The name bisque is in all probability not unrelated to biscuit, for the original bisque contained bread made into a sort of mush. Modernday bisques are a blessing of the electric blender, easily made either of shellfish, such as lobster and clams, or vegetables. Those here are rich and elegant. And delicious.

title: Art
description: SAIGON.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Iran, with a population of 27 million, has more narcotics addicts than any other coun try in the worldexcept the United States. Beginning in the 1950's, the Iranian Gov ernment tried to cut the supply of opium and the opium derivatives morphine and heroin used by the coun try's 250,000 addicts, but smugglers from Turkey and Afghanistan, traveling wild mountain passes, usually out witted the government agents. The smugglers were paid in gold and their trade, apart from the social havoc it wrought, also caused a minia ture gold drain on Iran's treasury.

title: O'Brien Proposes Alternatives To RevenueSharing Program
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Lawrence F. O'Brien, the chair man of the Democratic Na tional Committee, proposed enactment today of a number of alternatives to President Nixon's revenuesharing plan. Among them was a new pro gram of financial assistance to states and cities for construc tion of antipollution facilities and expanded Federal financing of welfare and education pro grams and jobs for the un employed.

title: Mrs. Spilman Married
description: The marriage of Mrs. Pris cilla Spilman to Dr. Robert W. Laidlaiv, both of Man hattan, took place here yes terday afternoon at the bridegroom's home at the Beekman Hotel. Judge Arthur Goldberg of the Crithinal Court performed the cere mony. The bride's previous marriage, to the Rev. William Stahel Spilman of Cold Spring Harbor, LI., ended in divorce. Dr. Laidlaw, a psy chiatrist in private practice, was formerly chief and clini cal director of the depart ment of psychiatry at Roose velt Hospital. His two pre vious marriages ended in divorce.

title: Saints Sign Vol Back
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 (AP) The New Orleans Saints an nounced today the signing of Bobby Scott, Tennessee quart terback, to a 1971 contract. Scott, a 6  foot  1  inch, 201 pounder, led the Vols to a 10 wonlost record last season end a Sugar Bowl victory.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: A company may be moving In the right direction, says the new president of Pull man, Inc., but if too many other companies are moving past it, it isn't moving fast enough.

title: No Comment by Barron
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20  Mr. Barron declined to comment today on his indict ment. I would prefer not to say anything until I have been officially informed, he de clared.

title: International Travel
description: TO help hotelhunting travelers find what they're after, most European nations obligingly list and more or less judiciously rate their hotels. Such rated listingsavailable at the various government tourist offices of the countries involved and at many travel agenciespresent the traveler with packs or categories of hotels he can deal with and pick from. The packs come neatly stacked, of course, with the poshest on top.

title: Last Chance for Strip Mining
description: Human and environmental damage attributable to the coal industry has been staggering. Tens of thou sands of miners have been killed or crippled. Countless others cough out their shortened lives as victims of various respiratory diseases.

title: Abrams Says Unlawful Sidewalk Cafes Deprive the City of $500,000 a Year
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx ventured into Manhattan yesterday to charge that dozens of side walk cafes an the East Side were operating without licenses and franchises, depriving the city of $500,000 a year in reve nue.

title: Off Broadway: The House of Blue Leaves
description: THE House or Blue Leaves, John Guare's new play, takes place on Oct. 4, 1965, the day the Pope came to New York, and concerns a zoo keeper named Artie Shaugh nessy. Artie's wife, Bananas Shaughnessy, is an hysterical lunatic, and Artie is in love with his downstairs neigh bor, Bunny Flingus; he wants to elope with Bunny to Holly wood and become a song writer. Artie's son Ronnie is a soldier, AWOL from Fort Dix or someplace like that, who dresses up as an altar boy in order to blow up the Pope. Have you got all that? Well, it will do for a start.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MIAMI Feb. 20 (UPI)The Baltimore Oriole manager Earl Weaver, admitted today that he was giving serious thought to player cuts he would make before his world champions move north in early April.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Leeds Maintains 3Point English Soccer Lead With a 30 Triumph
description: LONDON, Feb. 20 (Reuters) Leeds United, eliminated from Football Association Cup play last week by Fourth  Division Colchester United, maintained its soccer lead in the English First Division today with a 30 victory that ended Wolverham ton Wanderers' run of seven league matches without defeat.

title: Sun Roof for Subcompacts
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20 (UPI) American Motors Corporation bas announced that it will introduce a siding sun roof on its subcompact cars beginning April 1. The sun roof will be available as an option on the fourpassenger Gremlin, the two??or sedan Hornet and the Hornet Sportabout, R. W. Mc Nealy, vice presidentmarketing, said Tuesday.

title: Camden Team Penalized
description: ROBBINSVILLE, N. J., Feb. 20 (AP)Camden High School has been dropped from the state high school basketball tournament and has been placed on probation for a year because of a fight that broke out follow ing a game on Feb. 6, the New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association said today.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: CAMBODIAN ROAD TO SEA PERILOUS
description: TRAPEANG KRALENG, Cam bodia, Feb. 20In the month since South Vietnamese and Cambodian troops, with the open support of American jets and helicopters, fought to re open Highway 4, Cambodia's vital outlet to the Gulf of Siam, just two oil convoys totaling 30 trucks have been able to use the road.

title: RICHEY ADVANCES TO INDOOR FINAL
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 20 In similar fiveset struggles, Cliff, Richey and Clark Graeb ner qualified today for the title match of the $50,000 United States national indoor open ten nis tournament.

title: Hopes for Peace and Hints of Spring Warm the Mood of Cairo
description: CAIRO, Feb. 20Hints of spring and peace have begun to warm the mood in Cairo in recent days.

title: Snowshoes Growing in Popularity
description: THOSE venerable snowshoes of our grandfathers' time are enjoying a popularity upsurge in New Eng land. It used to be that snow shoes were worn mostly for hunting, but now they are used extensively just for hiking, a shift that has helped in crease snowshoe sales at one sports center in southern New Hampshire by 35 per cent over last winter. Today, even women and children buy snow shoes, says John Cocorette, the owner of the center. They find them great for a walk in the woods, and they're unbeatable for climbing.

title: Two Bold Experiments Are in Trouble
description: Classes such as this at Harlem Pre paratory School may be in jeopardy was revealed last week that. Harlem Prep and the New York Urban League's Street Academiestwo unorthodox but promising educational ventures aimed at retrieving highschool dropouts and getting them back on trackhad lost major corporate and foundation financ ing and face uncertain futures. Among the reasons cited are the recession and lapses in educational leadership and fiscal management. If saved, it'll be miracle; if not saved, it'll be a crime, said Harlem Prep's board chairman, Robert J. Mangum.

title: Stamps
description: LONDON

title: Air Base at Danang Shelled
description: SAIGON, Sunday, Feb. 21 (Reuters)  Vietcong gunners shelled the air base at Danang early this morning, destroying a C130 transport plane used to carry supplies for the attack on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: Jennifer O'Neill Making a HorseShow Comeback
description: Horse Show News

title: Wagons Ho! Is Heard Again As Modern Pioneers Go West
description: WE had barely finished our eve ning meal when the sky and wind changed suddenly. The women and children rushed for cover in the wagons, while the men hurried to line them up for protection from the Cements. The wagons were arranged in a circle, three deep and placed so that the wind would rush through them and not broadside against them. A wagon had been knocked over the year before, but fortunately we didn't learn about that until long after the 50mileanhour gale had passed.

title: Convoy Reaches Capital
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 20 (AP)A convoy of trucks carrying gasoline and other supplies ran through an enemy ambush on Highway 4 and reached Pnompenh today from Kompong Som.

title: Dumb like a fox
description: Although fashion has gone gaga, there are still women who just want to look pretty rather than with it. Not for them the gypsy garb or cowgirl gear or any pants hot or cold. They prefer dressessimple, easy and beautiful. Since clothes like these are not headline makers, they are often called (even by their creators) dumb dresses. Since when is it dumb to be beautiful?

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon, fresh from taking the political initiative from the Democrats on revenue shar ing and governmental re organization, is preparing to do it again on the ticklish issue of law and order.

title: Columbia Subdues Yale, 9271, As Gordon and Gallus Stand Out
description: After taking a full 20 min utes to get serious about a mediocre Yale team last night, Columbia came out in the sec ond half and turned the contest into a slaughter by defeating the Eli, 9271, before 1,459 fans in University Gym.

title: Consultation in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 20 (Reut ers)Premier Golda Moir of Israel consulted with political leaders and Cabinet members today on the offer by Egypt to sign a peace agreement, politi cal sources said.

title: Rev. Eugene O'Keefe Dies; Hospital Chaplain Was 67
description: The Rev. Eugene J. O'Keefe, a Roman Catholic chaplain who was imprisoned by the Japanese in the Philippines for three years in World War II, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospi tal, Orange, N. J. He was 67 years old.

title: Antiwar Bill in New Mexico
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 20 (UPI)A bill sponsored by two Democrats and a Republican has been introduced in the State Senate prohibting the use of New Mexico servicemen in undeclared wars, such as the conflict in Indochina. The meas ure, introduced yesterday, was similar to a bill that became law in Massachusetts last year, aimed to rest the legality of the Vietnam War.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Worldwide Mission
description: Ralph Hilton's Worldwide Mission is a firstrate account of the United States Foreign Service from its Revolutionary War origins to the present. The author traces the Service's bur geoning part in the nation's growth through the expansive 19thcentury years to the 20th century with its world wars and international confronta tions (hot and cold). Here are not only the increasingly diver sified activities of the Foreign Service but political, military and economic history as well.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Royals Sell 4,440 Tickets
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) The Kansas City Royals said today they had sold 4,440 sea son tickets for the baseball sea son and expected the sale to reach slightly more than 5,000 by March 10.

title: Red China Terms Laos Drive a Grave Menace
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 20Com munist China returned to the attack against the United States today, condemning recent ac tions in Indochina and state ments of intention by President Nixon regarding the war there.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Helicopter Rescues Twin Brothers, 12, From Ice on Central Park Lake
description: A police helicopter hover ing inches above the thin ice on the Central Park lake res cued twin brothers who were marooned 100 feet from the shore yesterday afternoon.

title: Job without sores
description: The memorable fictional seekers after truth have shown a mixture of eccentricity and profundity. Mr. Quattlebaum may qualify. He is Job without sores, Don Quixote minus wind mills, Candide outside El Dorado and, possibly, Worm wood when a mail strike si lenced Uncle Screwtape.

title: Reader's Report
description: Michael Campbell has a flair for inventing idiosyncratic peo ple and squeezing endless high and low comedy out of their grotesque possibilities. To wit: a toothiless giantess in her sev enties living on a remittance in a Dublin pension named the Glocca Mora. Harriet de Cour cey is a berserk Auntie Mame who rattles around Dublin in a cab, attending to her hobbies  pyromania and disturbing the peace. Ennui still threatens to overtake heruntil a neph ew makes her the heroine of a novel that describes her too well. Aunt Harriet is not too crazy not to sue for libel, and therein begins an insane romp roundabout Dublin, elsewhere described as A village filled with people hating each other for the love of God.

title: Art
description: OF all dirty adjectives ap plicable to painting, literary has been the dirtiest in the twen tieth century. Literary paint ing, with its illustrative and anecdotal character or, if not that, its less direct literary ness as pictorial description that seems to have been cre ated for translation into words, was the favorite kind of painting for a wide public in the first part of our cen tury. And it had to be beaten to death by critics, historians, and teachers if that same public was to understand what pure painting was all about.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Marie Louise Barney Is Married
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, Feb. 20In St. John's Episco pal Church here today, Miss Marie Louise Barney and E. Ronald Beecher Jr., 1970 graduates of Dickinson Col lege, were married by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. William Hadwen Barney of Manhasset and Nantucket, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Evan Beecher of Middletown, N.J.

title: Carolyn Trois Engaged
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Arthur H. Trois of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Trois, to Richard J. Sheehan Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sheehan.

title: TRACKS WATCHING A LABOR DISPUTE
description: Major negotiations are sched uled tomorrow in a labor dis pute that affects most of the nation's racetracks.

title: Bowdoin Triumphs, 71
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 20 Bob Petrie and Dick Donovan scored two goals each tonight to lead Bowdoin College to a 71 victory over Salem State. It was the seventh consecutive victory for Bowdoin and kept it in first place in the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division II standings with a 121 record.

title: Beverly Knight Engaged to Wed Edmund Olson
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 20 Miss Beverly Hoover Knight and Edmund Olson, a special agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Boston, will be married here on June 19.

title: Yazd Hasn't Changed Much Since Marco Polo Passed This may
description: YAZD, IranThe muezzin, or priest at the local mosque here, who used to ascend a lofty minaret five times a day to summon the Moslem faithful to prayer now issues his chant with the help of records and a loudspeaker. This concession to moder nity is one of a few signs of progress in Yazd, where the flavor of a civiliza tion that has flourished for millenia still dominates.

title: Drive Against Illicit Drug Traffic To Be Expanded Here by U.S.
description: Federal prosecutors will in vestigate the taxes of major narcotics suspects and look into the diversion of legally manufactured amphetamines to illicit markets as part, of an ex panded effort to combat nar cotics traffic here.

title: SHOW OF ANTIQUES STARTS AT GARDEN
description: Almost all the latest styles in popular collecting are in the huge grab bag to be explored at the National Antiques Show, an annual drawing card that opened yesterday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Queens Defeats Lehman
description: Queens College defeated Lehman, 70.64, last night at the winners's gum. Queens's Knights rallied after a 3128 halftime deficit, led by Joe Clancy, who finished with 21 points.

title: Nixon Panel to Ask Firm Commitment to Economic Opportunities for Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The United States cannot afford to wait for a gradual increase in economic opportunities for mi norities, a panel appointed by President Nixon will tell him on Monday.

title: Iona Downs St. Francis
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 20Iona College captured its second consecutive Middle Eastern Collegiate Athletic As sociation basketball title to night, beating St. Francis of New York, 8271. Iona finished its conference competition with a 50 record and is now 810 over all.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Pinto
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Allen Pinto of Riverdale, the Bronx, on Feb. 5 in the New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospi tal. Mrs. Pinto is the former Miss Marion Merri Ente of New York.

title: National Notes
description: Twothirds of the 110,000 parking tickets dispensed in New York City each week are ignoredand the Parking Viola tions Bureau is peeved. Last week bureau director Anthony Atlas called for help from the city marshals. The specific tar get: those 2,000 motorists who have failed to pay up on three or more tickets since last July. The marshals will send the scoff laws letters, first; if there is no response within seven days, they are empowered to seize personal property or attach salaries.

title: Chess
description: DURING the 24man knockout round robin at Marjorca, Spain, the following six qualified for the forthcoming elimination matches: Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, 184, Yefim Geller of the Soviet Union, 158; Robert Huebner of West Germany, 158; Bent Larsen of Den mark, 158; Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union, 149; Wolfgang Uhlmann of East Germany, 149.

title: New Letter Demands a $1Million Ransom for Dr. Fly
description: A second letter purporting to be from the urban guerrillas who kidnapped Dr. Claude L. Fly, a United States agricul tural expert, in Uruguay last Aug. 7 was received here yes terday.

title: 3,500 Nassau Students in Fight to End Drug Abuse
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 20  They are called DEANS but they are students, not teachers. They are 3,500 strong and their growth over the last five years is a measure of the drug prob lem among Nassau County youths.

title: Music
description: COLOGNE.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Consul's Release Awaited
description: MONTEVIDEO Uruguay, Feb. 20 (UPI)The Brazilian Embas sy today awaited the release of the Brazilian Consul. Aloysio Dias Gomide, as had been promised by terrorists.

title: National Notes
description: If there is one thing the United States Senate enjoys more than talking, it is talking about the inviolability of its right to talk. Thus it came as no particular surprise when the attempt last week to stop the past month of talking (in order to take up the question of limiting future talk ing) failed, 48 to 37, to achieve the necessary twothirds ma jority.

title: ExWife to Pay Support
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 20 (AP)  A Pontiac woman has been ordered to pay $35 a week in child support to her former husband, who has custody of the couple's five children, aged 7 to 12. Judge William Beer of Oakland County Circuit Court said Tuesday that he ordered Barbara J. Duncan to make the payments to her former hus band, Eddie, because she made $125 a week while Mr. Duncan earned only $80 a week.

title: Vietnam
description: One might think that we long ago reached the point where there is nothing new to say about the war in Indochina. The lines of debate have been clearly drawn, and each day's new information  to those who can still bear to read and listen  often only confirms what one already knew or expected, or feared. We are mor ally and physically tired of the war; yet the war that wore us down, that drummed us into insensibility or into righteous crusades is not the same war today as it was yesterday, or last week, or last year.

title: Miss Pacella and John Oldham, Psychiatrists, Will Be Married
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Pacella of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Dr. Karen Joan Pacella, to Dr. John Michael Oldham, son of Mrs. Henry Newland Oldham of Dallas and the late Mr. Oldham.

title: Indiana Swimmers Fastest
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 20 (AP)Indiana University swimmers posted the fastest times in the nation this season in two events today as they heat Cincinnati, 9419, for their 61st consecutive dual meet vic tory. Gary Hall was timed in 1 minute 49.7 seconds in the 200 yard butterfly, and the medley relay team was clocked in 3:27.6.

title: Books: Merger Pains
description: Sooner or later the man agement of almost every small company with growing pains thinks in terms of merger. At the same time almost every big company is on the prowl these days for little companies.

title: Malaysians Crown King And Restore Parliament
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Fob, 20 (UPI)  Malaysia crowned a king today. At nearly the same time she returned to parliamentary democracy aft er 21 months of emergency rule by Premier Abdul Razak and his special council.

title: Hunter Edges Yeshiva
description: Hunter College, with an 182 record, defeated Yeshiva, 6562, in a Knickerbocker Conference game last night.

title: NELSON TOPS ADAMS IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 20 John Nelson of the Harvard Club of New York led the way into the semifinals of the annual Apa wamis Club squash racquets tournament today. He defeated Dinsmore Adams Harvard Club, 15.8, 159, 18.13;

title: It comes as a shock that not everything had been said, after
description: When he received the Nobel Prize in 1929 Thomas Mann was 55 years old. With several lifetimes worth of work behind him ranging from Bud denbrooks and The Magic Moun tain to countless essays, stories and novellas, crowned at last with the ultimate accolade, he seemed destined for early immortality, another stone face on Parnassus and perch for German pigeons in the park some where between the busts of Grill parzer and Goethe.

title: In Declining East Flatbush, $500,000 City Grant Helps Rebuild Community Confidence
description: Hostility, fear, crime, filth and a dearth of recreational facllities are under attack through a 500,000 Neighbor hood Action Program designed by the city to stem the decline of East Flatbush.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The latest official explanation of the President's Indochina policy is that he is backing out of the saloon with both guns fir ing, but there is a catch to this.

title: Banks, an Actor, Bows Out of Theater to Produce Karate Shows
description: Before Aaron Banks drop ped out of show business to take up karate, martial arts tournaments on the East Coast were a sometime thing. Now they happen at least once a month.

title: Prisoner Hangs Himself In an Observation Ward
description: A Rikers Island inmate who was in an observation wing after a suicide attempt hanged himself Friday night.

title: Coins
description: THREE more countries have joined the coin age plan of the Food and Agricultural Organ ization of the United Nations, it was announced last week. Since 1966, the FAO has been urging world governments to issue monies with a food or agricultural motif in their de signs, both for general cir culation and as collector items.

title: METS CAMP SITE HAS TRAFFIC JAM
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20Seventeen of the teams of the major leagues were in ac tion in Florida this weekend in spring training, the seven others in the southwest, and despite the fact that their camps were pitched in beach resorts, deserts and tourists oasis, all of them were getting reminders that civilization was creeping closer.

title: CONVERSIONS STIR A JEWISH DISPUTE
description: VIENNA, Feb. 20  What might be the pride of another religious faith is threatening to grow into an international scan dal for Judaism: Converts have been made here at the rate of about three a month.

title: Foreign Notes
description: The use of marijuana by American forces in Vietnam had become such a military problem by early this year that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States commander, ordered his of ficers to mount a strenuous campaign to combat it. Last week, as part of that cam paign, an Air Force colonel was brought before a court martial, charged with smok ing marijuana, asking a ser geant to get him some mari juana and giving some to four enlisted men.

title: G.O.P. PICKS DOCTOR TO SEEK RIVERS SEAT
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 20 (UPI)Dr. James B. Edwards, 44yearold oral surgeon, was chosen today by South Carolina Republicans to seek the Con gressional seat left vacant by the death of Representative L. Mendel Rivers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Car of Soviet Scientist Found on Road in Geneva
description: GENEVA, Feb. 20 (UPI)The automoble of a missing Soviet nuclear physicist and his family has been found, apparently abandoned, on a road along Lake Geneva here, Swiss au thorities reported today.

title: Art
description: THE early career of William Baziotes, who died in 1963 at the age of 50, was quintes sential New York School. Born and raised in Penn sylvania  where he was ap prenticed briefly to a newspaper and to a stained glass firm before contracting the art bughe came to New York in the early 1930's, sur vived the Depression and met other ambitious young artists in W.P.A. art projects, fell in love with French painting, was deeply impressed by Sur realism and had his first oneman show in 1944 at Peggy Guggenheim's legen dary Art of This Century Gal lery. Identified and identify ing from the start with the new American painting while hanging back from the allout abstraction, dashing procedures and big scale of its more scandalous propo nents in favor of a more pal atable, gently lyrical Surrealismhe was among the first in the movement to enjoy a measure of public renown. From 1946 to 1954, only one year passed without a new Baziotes show at the impor tant Kootz Gallery.

title: T. G. Day Marries Marcia Brown
description: Miss Marcia Brown was married here yesterday morn ing to Thomas Graham Day. The Rev. Vincent Fox per formed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: the traveler's world
description: THE beginning of the end for Trans Caribbean Airways began last week when Trans Carib's arrivals and departures were moved from the National Airlines terminal at Ken nedy International Airport, where they had been anchored for many years, to the American Airlines terminal. This was the first outward physical effect of the Civil Aeronautics Boardapproved merger in which American rescued Trans Carib from bankruptcy by advancing several million dollars to keep it afloat through 1970, and finally took it over intact.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)  Bobby Wine, shortstop, checked into the Montreal Expos' training camp today, four days early. Check in late on the third day of train ing for batterymen were pitcher, Bob Reynolds, held up by car problems en route from Texas and a catcher, Terry Humphrey, who had a military committment.

title: The Nation
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla,  The 1970 list of the 10 richest men in America has just been an nounced: First is Howard Hughes, and then come nine construction workers.

title: Bad Day At Cairo, Ill
description: Sister will be waiting But she can't take me across Because I got one more river To to to cross.

title: Soviet Reported Tracking U.S. Ships in Caribbean
description: UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba. Feb. 19Soviet ships re portedly have begun electronic surveillance of United States naval vessels in the Caribbean.

title: Kings Point Victor
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 20 Kings Point clinched a tie for second place in the Knicker bocker Conference with a 69.51 basketball victory over Brook lyn Poly today. The triumph gave the Mariners a 72 won lost league record and 12.12 over all. Joe Homicki led them with 14 points.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Unlike the Cambodian operation last spring which was accompanied by con siderable White House fanfare, President Nixon for two weeks had maintained silence on the Laotian fighting. Combined with the embargo on much of the news from Indochina itself, the silence cast a haze of confusion over the whole campaign.

title: SOVIET DISCLOSES PAY FOR JOBLESS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20A Soviet economics journal disclosed today that administrative per sonnel laid off as part of a na tionwide paring of staffs have been eligible for nearly a year to receive a form of unemploy ment insurance while training for new jobs.

title: Football Unit Elects Jurist
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP) Judge Leo Weinrott of the Philadelphia County Common Pleas Court was reelected to day as commissioner of the Middle Atlantic Intercollegiate Football Association.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  For those who opposed the candidates and policies of the Johnson Adminis tration, the 1968 Democratic Na tional Convention seemed, as one insurgent leader said later, like a fixed race.

title: Legion Post Yields To Army Pressure And Accepts Black
description: ABERDEEN, Md., Feb. 20 Threatened with being placed offlimits to Army personnel, an American Legion post here has agreed to accept a mem bership application from a black enlisted man who has been refused service at its bar.

title: The Brooklyn Crowd On Mount Parnassus
description: Talent may be harvested in Manhattan, headquarters for publishers, producers, gal leries, agents and money, but it was grown in Brooklyn. Many of the names in lights after sunset on the West Side first saw the sun rise over East New York.

title: Dispute Over Control of Church Divides Russian Congregation at Sea Cliff
description: SEA CLIFF, L. L, Feb. 20  Most of us fought against the Bolsheviks, said the wife of a former Czarist officer, but now they are calling us Bol sheviks.

title: Bob Hope at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Bob Hope and a young mu sical group, Up With People, will entertain at a White House dinner on Monday night. The Governors of all 50 states and their wives have been invited.

title: Hospitals in Nassau and Suffolk Meeting Demand for Abortions
description: Health officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties report that Long Island hospitals have had no difficulty keeping up with the demand for abortions since the state's law was lib eralized last July.

title: Sin A. Larsen, a Teacher Here, Bride of Stanley G. Mortimer 3d
description: Miss Siri Aagot Larsen, a teacher at the Manhattan Country School on East 96th Street, was married yesterday afternoon in Manhasset, L. I., to Stanley G. Mortimer 3d, a descendant of early settlers of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and a member of the Cushing fam ily of Boston.

title: The Taos Indians Have a Small Generation Gap
description: TAOS, N. M.

title: SapRise
description: Some years the maple sap begins to flow the last week in February. And some years it waifs till mid March. The calendar date is of no importance to a tree.

title: Miss Annis of Arizona State Captures Badminton Crown
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20  Sue Annis of Arizona State won the intercollegiate women's bad minton championship today by defeating Penny Dezen of Cali fornia State, 113, 711, 117, in the final at Temple.

title: Elderly Exerting Power In Elections in Suburbs
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 20 A high school bond issue de feated in Rye. A swimming pool referendum turned down in Bronxville. A petition for reduced bus fares that is signed by 10,000 people. Lo cal candidates who show up at senior citizens' centers pre pared for undemanding pleas antries and find themselves the targets of tough political questions.

title: Muncey Switching to Outboard Today
description: Bill Muncey, one of the most successsful drivers of unlimited hydroplane racing, will switch to an outboard for today's nine hour endurance race in Parker, Ariz.

title: Our radio classic?
description: Catch a latenight panel of radio voices discussing Esperanto or the earth's flatness, or better still listen to those phonein programs on which the caller's hangups and heartburns are broadcast to the world yet sealed off in personto person privacyand you'll have some idea of the staggering national resource from which Stanley Elkin has created The Dick Gibson Show. This is his third novel and his best a funny, melancholy, frightening, scabrous, absolutely American com pendium that may turn out to be our classic about radio.

title: Breaking out of a box
description: In most modern apartments, the rooms are mere boxes devoid of rich mold ings, handsome windows, lofty ceilingsdevoid of the romance of older buildings and brownstones. So, designer Ruben de Saavedra decided to give his typical highrise apartment a 20thcentury elegance. Smallyet very importantchanges, such as lacquered and mirrored walls, chrome moldings and a dramatic entrance to the living room, made the transformation this bold new background, the designer brought modern and antique furniture, geometric art and treesize plantsthe latter used almost as sculpture.

title: Trade Strategy Is Mapped
description: One strategy for prevent ing a world trade war:

title: TRUE NORTH TAKES WIDENER, WITH TWOGUNDAN NEXT
description: MIAMI, Feb. 20Under a brilliant ride by Bobby Wood house, C. V. Whitney's True North came through with a fine stretch run today to win the $149,000 Widener Handicap at Hialeah.

title: KNICKS BEAT PISTONS, 10894;
description: The Knicks emerged from a weird nightmare that had seen them lose seven of nine games because of shoddy play with a sparkling 108.94 victory over the Detroit Pistons last night at Madison Square Garden before the National Basketball Associa tion's 18th capacity crowd (19,500) here.

title: RIGERMANS GREETED BY HUNDREDS HERE
description: After months of trying to leave the Soviet Union, Leonid G. Rigerman and his mother, Mrs. Esther Rigerman, arrived at Kennedy International Air port last midnight to a warm welcome by several hundred people.

title: PNOMPENH SEEKS TO SAVE STATUES
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb 20Cambodia's only archeolo gist is trying almost single handedly to save Cambodia's vast treasure of ancient tern pies and statues from the war by bringing them to the mu scum basement here or by burying them if they are too large to move.

title: Macao, the Monaco Of the East, Wants To Be Paris, Too
description: MACAOA luxury hotel here reg ularly stages races in its din ing room the waiters rush around as if competing in track event. What they are trying to do is to minimize the time required to feed a party of tourists more in terested in streamlined sightseeing than leisurely dining. And the reason for the rapid service lies in Macao's current drive to compete for the tourists now saturating Hong Kong,40 miles to the east.

title: The House On Jefferson Street
description: No sane mother would ever pray for her unborn baby to be a poet. The going is too rough. Poets are openly perse cuted in the Soviet Union. Here in the United States they are merely ignored. Their medium requires too much thought; it is too hard to handle after the softening of TV.

title: Literary inventory
description: Splendid instances of cultural ap propriationfirst Al Carmines's off Broadway production of In Circles, then the Museum of Modern Art show of the Stein family's acquisitions in Paris, latterly the 90minute profile of Gertrude Stein's long life on national television networksuch manifestations are cheery enough, though sometimes teary, testimonials to a legend, memorials of an ener getic egoimpresario and amo ur propridtaire, the Grandest Mannerist of the self since Mme. de Stael. But what have such occasions to do with the writer Gertrude Stein, au thor of 30 volumes published in her lifetime (many by herself), and of eight vast tomes in the Yale edi tion of her Unpublished Writings, the woman who until her death in sisted she wanted her books read, not owned? Is it not true of Gertrude Stein today, as it was 40 years back when Edmund Wilson wrote the first serious review of her career in Axel's Castle, that most of us read her less and less?

title: New Penalties for Court Delays Are Announced
description: A new system of punishments for excessive delays in process ing cases for trial in the city's Criminal Court was announced yesterday by Administrative Judge David Ross.

title: For Yanks, It's Year of Delivery
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20  The 69th version of the New York Yankees will begin spring training here Mon day, for the eighth time under Manager Ralph Houk and for the 10th time in the trim little stadium built for the Yankees in 1962.

title: New York as Watchdog
description: A middleaged woman walked to a receptionist at the New York State Insur ance Department downtown the other day and asked how to go about cashing in an old insurance policy.

title: San Diego Players Get Best Seats in the House
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20 (AP) A guy who plays hard likes to relax afterward, says Toby Kimball, a reserve forward of the San Diego Rockets of the National Bas ketball Association.

title: John Shaw to Marry Maureen Finch
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Miss Maureen Finch, daugh ter of Robert Hutchinson Finch, counselor to President Nixon and former Secretary of Health, Education and Wel fare, and Mrs. Finch of Falls Churdh, Va., plans to become the bride of John Elton Shaw, a law student at Loyola Uni versity in Los Angeles. He is a son of John R. Shaw, a realtor, and Mrs. Shaw of Broomfield, Colo.

title: Michigan State Six Wins
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Feb. 20  Michigan State scored three straight goals in the final period today and defeated Colo rado College, 64, in a Western Collegiate Hockey Association game.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA TRIUMPHS, 7266
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 20 (UPI)John Roche sank five free throws in the final minute today to lead South Carolina to a 72.66 victory over North Carolina.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: FOR MORE ON NANETTE ?? Section 2 or Today's N.Y. Times and the current Life & Vogue Mags. (advt)

title: Education
description: For better or for worse, America has become a cre dentialsminded society which often shuts out capable peo ple from important and crea tive employment simply because they lack college degrees. This has led reform minded educators to call for a new kind of schooling that would eliminate some of the artificial barriers to higher education.

title: A Short Course In the Three Types Of Radical Professors
description: THE predicament of the radical professor is essentially the same as the predicament of all intel lectuals in American societyuncer tainty over his own usefulness. In normal times Americans tend to ig nore ideas and denigrate their impor tance; the clich image of the profes sor is the absentminded fussbudget fiddling harmlessly with esoteric in terests, fit to be patronized or ig nored. In times of crisis, however, even Philistines lunge at metaphysical explanations of threatening events, and ideas and ideamakers suddenly appear as strong, sinister and highly effective manipulators of reality.

title: Authenticity Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 State Department sources noted today that a similar message received previously in Monte video had been considered not authentic by Uruguyan police authorities.

title: L. I. Doctors Protest Duties
description: EAST MEADOW, L.I., Feb. 20 Many of the nearly 200 staff physicians at the Nassau Coun ty Medical Center today re fused to perform what they de scribed as parainedical du ties. Their action was based on the refusal of the county to give them a $1,000 housing al lowance.

title: Architecture
description: PROFESSOR John Cool idge of Harvard's Fogg Museum writes to tell of one happy epi sode in the otherwise un happy and continuing ar chitectural attrition of our cities. His good news concerns the salvation and restoration of a rare and charming Art Nouveau shopfront in Cam bridge, Mass, and he is right; it helps.

title: Cities
description: The urban crisissupplanted now by newer ones (pollution has spun off into its own fullblown crisis) seems to have diminishing urgency precisely as the situation becomes increasingly critical. Not that the urban crisis was ever quite defined; we each supply our own definition according to where we live, how quickly we accept ready answers and how much we are in convenienced, threatened or thwart ed by our separate urban worlds. Thus, to some, the most important paperback on the urban crisis will be Park  A  Plan: Garage Parking in Central Manhattan (Wry Products, $1.25), 13 pages of maps for the frustrated driver.

title: Denise Harvey Will Be April Bride
description: MEDFIELD, Mass., Feb. 20 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Harvey have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Denise French Har vey, to Alexander Thomas Liebowitz. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Libo witz of New York. A wedding this April in Mons, Belgium, is planned.

title: ISTOMIN IS SOLOIST WITH CLEVELANDERS
description: Georg Semkow was the con ductor and Eugene Istomin the piano soloist for the concert given by the Cleveland Orches tra at Carnegie Hall on Friday night.

title: International Travel
description: ATHENS It's against the law to neck in an Athens taxi. I was ad vised of this fact by the taxi driver who was bringing me and a Greek woman passenger from the new Athens international airport. He said that a violation could get him ar rested.

title: Indians Cancel Drill
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 20 (AP) The Cleveland Indians can celled a workout today on the second day of spring training for pitchers and catchers be cause of rain and snow flurries, coupled with temperatures that didn't climb above the low 40's.

title: Worth Reading
description: THE Brooklyn Botanic Garden has published a revised and updated directory of nursery sources for woody ornamentals. The 96page paperback is designed to aid both ama teur and professional plantsmen in se lecting and purchasing the finest plants available in the United States and Canada.

title: INDICTED POLICEMAN IS DISMISSED HERE
description: Patrolman John. Finan, who is under indictment on charges of taking money in exchange for confidential police informa tion, was dismissed from the force yesterday.

title: Through the keen and mischievous eye of one who loves
description: The opening photograph, taken at the turn of the century, of Jacques Henri Lartigue as an impish boy with his precious camera sets the tone of this book: one of human tenderness, humor and intimate charm. It is family album illustrated by a keen, mischievous and surrealist observer. Because of the wide range of the family's experience and Lartigue's curiosity, it becomes the history of century. The first photograph of his father and mother also reveals the eye of the one who loves. He will not only photograph everything he loves but only at the moment of vivid life and motion, and incidentally give the portrait of an age. He has sense of motion, change, elusiveness. No figure is posed. If at first he prac tices on the family, later he will treat celebrities in the same informal, inti mate way.

title: Paperback Books
description: Have you any notion how many books are written about women in the course of one year? Have you any notion how many are written by men? Are you aware that you are, perhaps, the most discussed ani mal in the universe? So Virginia Woolf, in 1929, was provoked to a cry of exasperation: just give us A Room of One's Own, and as you leave, shut the door.

title: Reading What They Wanna Read
description: While visiting a friend recently, asked if her daughter, a first grader, liked to read. An innocent enough question, but it provoked an explo sive response. Read! I can't drag her away from books. That's good isn't it? I suppose. She gets them through a club at school  it's like having a continuous Christmas. What club? Scholastic, I think. Fun ny, I thought it was a magazine. I read it myself in high school.

title: Two Flying Machines That Can Make the Spirit Soar
description: TALKEETNA, AlaskaHere in the bush country of Alaska, small planes are almost as plentiful as Volkswagens on the Los Angeles freeways. But piloting those frail craft through the fierce Arctic weather and landing them on homemade strips is even more dangerous than negotiating the concrete corridors of southern California.

title: For Young Readers
description: It's promising: beachside setting likable young heromysterious, van ishing girl  orphaned cousin arriv ing by trainhints of Doppelgangers and psychic powers. It starts out with real characters, as a good, creepy, solid kind of fantasy. But soon it flits off to an Alternate Earth, complete with evil masterminds and telepathic yeomanry; the boy becomes im probably resourceful, the cousin im probably detestable; the action goes into a highspeed blur, and we're left with nothing real or solid, finally, but an amiable cat. The trouble is that the science fiction is faked. To convince, such notions as telepor tation, antimatter, parallel worlds, must be thought through and taken seriously. Misused, they are mere chic decorations, like the fairies and elves of oldfashioned children's books, which borrowed their trap pings from folklore rather than from the physics laboratory. One does not achieve fantasy just by mentioning fantastic concepts, whether they be elves or antimatter. Still, the cat is a good character, and any catowner might agree that a hungry Tom's desire for dinner is almost enough to teleport himself and two people across the Galaxy.

title: Harvard Beats Princeton And Yale in Track Meet
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20 Capturing seven of 13 events, Harvard's track team scored 63 points today to 50 for Princeton and 24 for Yale to win the an nual triangular meet for the second consecutive year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY OPERA STAGES INITIAL BUTTERFLY
description: It took the first act to settle in, but thereafter the New York City Opera's initial Ma dama Butterfuly of the spring season was a radiant success at the State Theater Friday night.

title: TIGER CAGE CAMP TO GET NEW CELLS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20An agency in the United States mission here has contracted for the construction of a prison compound consist ing of 288 isolation cells on Con Son, an island off South Vietnam.

title: Dorcas A. Berry Becomes Bride Of C. C. Beatty
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 20Miss Dorcas Ann Berry and Calvin C. Beatty were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony, which was written by the bridegroom.

title: EASTERN MICHIGAN WINS TRACK TITLE
description: YPSILANTI, Mich., Feb. 20 (AP)Eastern Michigan, paced by Eugene Thomas, took five first places to win the Central Collegiate Conference indoor track and field meet today.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When, in 1969, I covered a quaint reprinting in the field of true crime (1886 Profes sional Criminals of America, by Thomas Byrnes), I observed that this body of literature con tained many titles long out of print and worthy of reissue, and wondered why there was so little activity. But inactivity there was not, only ignorance on my partfor the Patterson Smith Reprint Series in Crimi nology, Law Enforcement, and Social Problems, begun in 1967, is a monumental and enormous ly praiseworthy endeavor that already runs to more than 100 volumes. Its objective is to pro vide a cornerstone library of at least 200 titles.

title: Mailbox:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: In Brief
description: THE CAT AND THE FLYING MA CHINE. By Laszlo Kubinyi. Illustrated by the author. (Simon & Schuster, $3.95. Ages 7 to 10)Flying about in his preWright Brothers plane, Shukru Geeyatmaz, a talking cat, comes to free an alchemist from the dungeons of Count Zlotgar and gets in volved in a peasant revolt. The story is in the mode of the traditional folk tale, but with whimsy, fantasy, threads of social justice and bravura adventuring thrown In. The pictures of brighteyed peasants, turreted cas tles and quaint cottages are soft toned and pleasant.

title: Army 8351 Victor Over N.Y.U.
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 20Army limited New York University to four field goals and 11 points in the first half and erupted for an 8351 vic tory over the Violets in a re gionally televised basketball game today.

title: The Islands at the World's End
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar They have been called islands at the world's end, and few Ameri cans, oilier than philatelists, have even heard of them. They're the is lands in the southern Indian Ocean, once fiercely contested by the world's naval powers but now well off the pathways of most travelers.

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNS TEMPLE BY 7467
description: St. John's and Temple, two of college basketball's most successful teams, battled through all the fine points of the game last night at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, with St. John's finally gaining a victory over the visitors, 7467.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 20 Army jumped to an early 20 lead before going on to defeat Colgate, 31, tonight. The vic tory was Army's seventh of the season, against 11 losses and one tie. Colgate is now 714 on the season.

title: End of Racial Strife in Schools Is Aim of Changes in Freeport
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Feb. 20 School authorities in this racially mixed Nassau County area have combined a tough code of conduct with a progres sive curriculum in an attempt to end blackwhite confronta tions that have plagued Free port schools for several years.

title: Sharon Segall Bride Of Stephen. E. Metz
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 20Miss Sharon Frances Segall, daughter of Mr. and. Mrs. Samson Segall was mar ried here tonight to Stephen Edward Metz of New York, son of Philip Metz of Great Neck, L. I., and Mrs. Rose Metz of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ed ward Glassman performed the ceremony at Temple Tiferith Israel.

title: The Berrigan Affair: How It Evolved
description: There was an electronic metal detector set up in the hallway of the Federal Build ing in Harrisburg, Pa., and the walls were lined with un smiling United States Mar shals and F.B.I. agents.

title: Britain's Stately Hotels
