description: LONDONFour years ago my husband and I were facing up to the familiar problem of de ciding which resort to choose for our annual vacation. We liked pleasant beaches, inter esting scenery, entertain ments, excursions, all the us ual holiday ingredients; but when we looked back on pre vious vacations in Britain and asked ourselves what we had enjoyed most of all, we both had the same answer: the visits we had paid to nearby historic country houses open to the public.

title: 150M.P.H. Air Cushion Train Planned Between Washington Suburb and Dulles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The Department of Transpor tation has announced plans for a 150mileanhour ground pas senger system to be built be tween suburban Washington and outlying Dulles Interna tional Airport.

title: Decision Is Due Soon on Production of Concorde
description: LONDON, Feb. 20  Britain and France are approaching the moment of decision on their proposed supersonic transport, the Concorde, amid growing op position to the project.

title: Mailbox:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. Tuna Boat Is Seized By Ecudorian Navy Patrol
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20 (AP) An American tuna boat was fired upon and seized off the coast of Ecuador today in the continuing dispute over fishing waters, spokesmen said here.

title: Lindsay, Suburban Chiefs Discuss Mutual Problems
description: In the belief that many prob lems of the metropolitan area in the nineteenseventies can only be attacked regionally, Mayor Lindsay and the County Executives of Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester have been discussing common issues and exploring the possibility of ur bansuburban cooperation.

title: Miss Mancusi Is Fiancee
description: Deputy Fire Commissioner Leonard L. Mancusi and Mrs. Mancusi of Whitestone, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Elisabeth Ann Man cusi, to Alfred J. Mullen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullen of Atlantic City. The future bridegroom is with Mayor Lindsay's office working on liaison with the Board of Estimate.

title: Soviet Paper Says Judge Here Tried To Blackmail Aide
description: The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda charged yes terday that a judge in Criminal Court here had tried to black mail a Soviet newsman into dropping charges against mem bers of the militant Jewish De fense League who allegedly as saulted him in December, 1969, in the New York offices of Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Long discussions with Fidel Castro during a stay in Cuba from 1965 to 1967 led Regis Debray, the young French radical, to write his book, Revolution in the Rev olution? which outlines the struggle of Latin American revolutionary movements. The book was widely read by young revolutionaries in the United States and elsewhere.

title: Glimpses Of the Sicilians
description: SYRACUSE, Sicily  The town of Vicari does not appear on tourist maps. It is just another stony outcropping on a dry inland plain west of Syracuse (Sira cusa). We stopped in Vicari for coffee but when I el bowed my way through a dense gathering of blackclad men in the town's only cafe I could think only of all the stories I had ever heard about Sicilian violence and cruelty.

title: Foreman Sentenced
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 20 (AP)  Mr. Buckalew ap peared this afternoon before Federal District Court Judge John A. Field Jr. in Charleston and pleaded guilty to two counts of the indictment.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.Pay ing a call on Mack Ballard at the clubhouse on his Squash Hill Shooting Pre serve in Charlotte, I was im mediately plied with roasted peanuts, strong black coffee, venison burgers and a hint of a great surprise if I would but daily.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Captain Will Stand Trial On Maiming of Vietnamese
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Feb. 20 (UPI)  The Army has an nounced that it is dropping sev eral charges of murder and as sault against a captain charged in the alleged Mylai massacre, but that he will be courtmar tialed for allegedly maiming and assualting a suspected member of the Vietcong.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONWith a sud den, unexpected rush over the past fortnight, the secret diplo macy on the Middle East has fi nally reached what one insider aptly terms the nub.

title: Two U.S. Teams Lead Bobsled Championships
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 20, (UPI)American sleds finished first and second to day in the first half Of the world four man bobsled championships in the Ken nedy international games at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: A Major at Khesanh Recalls 1968
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 13Maj. Tommy Stiner, a Vietnam veteran who is once again in Khesanh, has an old fashioned Army face at the age of 33. It is a big, blunt face, slightly lined, with ser ious eyes, not unlike the faces of the marines under siege at Khesanh in 1968.

title: Judge Bars Force On Political Funds By Guard Officers
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 20 A Federal judge ?? today that the commander of Alaba ma's Air National Guard had vi olated Federal statutes in at tempting to force guard officers to make political contributions.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: She Checks Stars for Earthly Advice
description: PARISIn the last four months, a rotund, 57yearold, astrologist, Madame SoleilMrs. Sunshinehas become the biggest radio success in French history. Even President Georges Pompidou has taken note of her fame. In reply to a question at a press conference he quipped:

title: Ship Named for Aviator
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) The Navy announced this week that it would name its newest destroyer escort for Jesse L. Brown, a native of Hattiesburg, Miss., who was the first black American naval aviator to be killed in the Korean war. The keel for the vessel will be laid April 9 at the Avondale Shipyards in Westwego, La. She will be 438 feet long and displace 4,100 tons.

title: 2,000 at Rally Here Urged To Aid Berrigan Defendants
description: David Dellinger, a defendant in the Chicago 7 conspiracy trial, called yesterday for sup port for six persons charged With conspiring to kidnap a Presidential aide, Henry A. Kis singer, and blow up heating systems under Government buildings. He spoke before 2,000 persons at a rally at Hun ter College here.

title: The World
description: Cartoonists had a field day with Britain's switch to a new decimal currency system last Monday, but the changeover caused less confusion than was expected. An educational program paved the way.

title: Canadiens Rout Hawks, 71
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (UPI) Peter Mahovlich scored two goals within five seconds and a rookie, Phil Roberto, had a threegoal perfonmance tonight as the Montreal Canadiens stretched their winning streak to five games with a 71 rout of the Chicago Black Hawks.

title: Charles Lyman Stewart Weds Miss Sharon Patz Campbell
description: Miss Sharon Patz Campbell and Charles Lyman Stewart were married here yesterday afternoon in St. Bartholo mew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Andrew J. W. Mul lins.

title: Miss Denise Wed Upstate
description: DE WITT, N. Y., Feb. 20 Miss Patricia Blackmore Den ise was, married here this afternoon to Nicholas Perry White of Ann Arbor, Mich. State Supreme Court Justice Richard Aronson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Denise of De Witt and East Northfield, Mass.

title: PRINCETON SCORES OVER HARVARD, 7674
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20 Princeton jumped to a 17point halftime lead, then held off Harvard rally and beat the Crimson, 7674, tonight. The Tigers extended their Ivy League streak to five games.

title: WROCLAW'S LEADER IS PURGED IN POLAND
description: WARSAW, Feb. 20Poland continued a purge of party chiefs in provincial cities today by replacing the Wroclaw party leader with one of his deputies.

title: NEW CENTER AIDS SKILLED JOBLESS
description: BOSTON, Feb 20A statis tical profile of the clients of Massachusetts' newest govern ment office, the 128 Profes sional Service Center, indicates a picture of ability, talent and success.

title: Religion
description: KINSHASA, CONGO  The history of Christian missions has generally been viewed as an effort to extend a pre dominantly European faith to the far corners of the earth. Right now, however, Chris tianity is doing a great deal better in Africa and other nonwhite areas than it is in the countries of Europe and North America; and the prospect has arisen that Christianity is about to be come h nonwhite religion.

title: Headliners
description: Canada's bachelor Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau is known to have a penchant for strong language, in both English and French. On several occasions, for example, he has pub licly used rough language in encounters with union repre sentatives and striking truck drivers. Last week his epithets alleged or realcreated a cause clbre in the House of Commons where Mr. Trudeau was under questioning by the Opposition on unemployment. John Lundrigan, a New foundland Conservative, asked sarcastically if the Prime Minister would condescend to tell us whether any new programs are to be announced now? Mr. Trudeauwho said to become irritated frequently at what he considers the low caliber of questioning in the Houseresponded by cupping his mouth and making lip movements that Mr. Lundrigan said formed a wellknown AngloSaxon vulgar ism. While Mr. Trudeau insisted inside Commons that he had not said anything wrong, he told newsmen outside that he had intended a gesture of derision that included the mouthing of fuddle duddle or something like that. M. McCutcheon, an Ontario Conservative, commented that Mr. Trudeau wants to be obscene but not heard. By the end of the week, enterprising stores were selling sweatshirts and buttons featuring a likeness of the Prime Minister's head encircled by the words Fuddle Duddle, and buttons with a picture of the opposition leader, Robert Stanfield, and the words, Qu'estce que c'est dat Fuddle Duddle?

title: City Starts Search for a Head of New Taxi Panel
description: The Lindsay administration began a search yesterday for the key element in the city's new test of taxicab regulation a politically skillful indi vidual to head the ninemem ber Taxi Commission.

title: Elinor Goldstein to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Elinor Goldstein to Bruce Michael Cohen has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Elias Goldstein of Far Rockaway, Queens. Mr. Cohen is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cohen of Los Alamitos, Calif.

title: Pipes Thought to Carry Molten Lava
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16 A Princeton geophysicist be lieves molten rock flowing tip from deep within the earth through some 20 pipes is pushing the continents hither and yon.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: The telephoned assignment from the Keeper of the Col Umn (K.C.) was terse and to the point, as are all of his dicta:

title: The Costa del Sol and . . . Pepe Gomez, Too
description: NERJA, Spain  If you thought that the vision of Spain you had pieced together from Death in the Afternoon and Don Quixote was dead, take heart and hurry to Nerja. But repeat hurry. The bulls are still here, but as everywhere else on Southern Spain's bustling Costa del Sol, so are the bulldozers, and more are in the offing.

title: Alicia F. Ritts Wed in Suburb
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 20Miss Alicia Flavelle Ritts was married here this after noon to Spec. 5 Frederick Clayton Emery Jr., U.S.A. The Rev. Harold Bassage per formed the ceremony in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: Lee Shaw Marries Nancy Fendrich
description: WAYNE, N. J., Feb. 20 Miss Nancy Fendich and Lee Nelson Shaw were mar ried here this afternoon in the Packanack Community Church by the Rev. Ronald Stegall. The couple are with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. The bride is an assistant treas urer and her husband is a vice president.

title: DARING STEP, $5, SCORES AT BOWIE
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 20 (AP) Greystone Manor Stables' fa vored Daring Step won by six lengths in the $23,600 Conniv er Handicap at Bowie race track today.

title: BarbadosSocial Patterns on Mast Stable of All the Islands'
description: ST. JAMES, BarbadosThere are still some of the trees around, their long, heavy branches stooping to reach the ground. They gave the island its name almost four centuries ago when Portuguese sailors who spotted them went on to describe this sunny, 21mile long strip of coral in the Caribbean as Barbados, the bearded fig tree.

title: Mrs. Curtis Has a Son
description: A son was born Feb. 9 to Mr. and Mrs. Edward Pere grine Sacheverell Curtis of Richmond, Surrey, England. Mrs. Curtis is the former Miss MarieAdele Smoot of Washington. The child has been, named Charles Edward. His father is manager of the SevenUp Bottling Company for the United Kingdom and Scandinavia.

title: Medicaid Agencies in States Told to Check on Indigents
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)  The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has or dered state Medicaid agencies to make annual medical re views of needy patients in nurs ing homes and mental institu tions.

title: Floral Park Civic Association Feels Forgotten
description: When municipal officials re ceive a complaint from the Lost Community Civic Association they look up knowingly, aware that even the name of the group is a plea for action.

title: Tate's 263 Long Jump Beats 2 Russians
description: While two dozen spectators looked on in the canvas bub ble at Baker Field, Norman Tate took off his red Soviet sweatsuit with the C.C.C.P. lettering yesterday morning, ran like a sprinter, leaped and made the longest long jump, in the United States this year.

title: 17 Dead in Colombian Crash
description: BARRANCABERNIEJA, Co lombia, Feb. 20 (AP)Seven persons were killed yesterday when a Colombian military DC4 crashed and burned on landing here yesterday, the air force announced. Earlier re ports had put the toll at. 30 of the 36 persons aboard.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: What do many Southwest oilmen and cattlemen wear as they clamber in and out of their Cadillacs? A $100 Stetson hat, $150 western boots, $5.95 jeans, an $8 shirt and a $1 corded string tie.

title: What's So Funny? Murders
description: LITTLE MURDERS, now at the Beekman The ater, is not only a very funny very in telligent, very affecting movie, it is also a most contrary one. Set in the last days of our ur ban civilization, it is about the defeat of the kind of posi tive thinking that believes it's always darkest before the dawn, that if you don't look for trouble, trouble won't look for you, and about one family's successful arrival at a state of total estrange ment, which, in this case, means doityourself assassi nation. Little Murders suc ceeds, at times triumphantly, and it does everything more or less backwards.

title: INTENSE FIGHTING AT SAIGON'S BASE IN LAOS REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20  Intense ground fighting was reported today on the northern flank of the South Vietnamese advance into Laos, which remained stalled for the third day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNOR ATTENDS SERVICES FOR SPENO
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I Feb. 20About 1,000 people, including Governor Rockeffeller and Mayor Lindsay, attended funeral services here today for State Senator Edward J. Speno, East Meadow Republican, who died of a heart attack Wednes day in Albany.

title: Drama Mailbang
description: THE Drama Review has been the most com prehensive, informa tive, and radical thea ter magazine in the English language. Two weeks ago, New York University, under whose auspices TDR was be ing published, decided to fire the editors and business staff, and to reconstruct the maga zine, with faculty and stu dents of the NYU School of the Arts putting it out. The new editor's stated intention is to reduce TDR's size, its scope, and its contentiousness by obvious extension, re moving TDR's radical thrust, its libertarian imagination, and its willingness to make spectacularly healthy mis takes.

title: International Travel
description: EAST AFRICA is the most beau tiful place on earth. Because is located halfway around the other side from New York some 20 hours by jet flightarriving Americans are looked on as 1) rich and 2) indifferent to the attendant costs of seeing the sights. To see the game you must leave the city; and in Kenya, movement in any direction beyond the city limits of Nairobi is considered a safari. Once such movement begins, no bills are presented, no chits signed and no money changes hands  until the traveler returns to town, at which point he is presented a statement, with out itemization, of the total amount due. (After all, one safari leader re marked, you wouldn't expect your tailor to itemize the cost of cutting your suit.)

title: Youth
description: Sitting here, speculating selfcon sciously about the young and what they read, and about the books about them, I keep wanting to make a kind of hologram: to arrange this book here and that one there and create, in their shadows and light, a con vincing image that will reveal the inner dimensions of the young. But what emerges from that is absurd: a longhaired hermaphrodite striding through the suburbs with a prayer wheel in one hand and a rifle in the other.

title: AMELIA T. FITZGERALD
description: Miss Amelia T. Fitzgerald, who taught at Public School 186 here for 40 years before her retirement 15 years ago, died yesterday at her home, 148 Bobolink Road, Yonkers. Her age was 85.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The year 1970 in the United States brought hack memories of the thirties. It is generally hoped that the worst part of that experience is behind us. In any event, it has been considered most un likely that in terms of human suffering the experience would be even closely slmilar. However, other as pects of the, analogy bear close scrutiny.

title: BULLETS DEFEATED BY HAWKS, 122115
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 (UPI) Pete Maravich and Lou Hudson scored 31 points each to offset Earl Monroe's 33 points as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Baltimore Bullets, 122115, to night in a National Basketball Association game.

title: TV Fight Center: And in This Corner... Cecil B. DeMille
description: On the black marble wall in the lobby of 277 Park Ave nue, the office is identified as Management Tele/Vision Cen ter. But among the two dozen people inside, it's known as the TV Fight Centerthe op erations headquarters for the closedcircuit TV network for the Joe Frazier  Muhammad Ali heavyweight title fight.

title: PENTAGON DENIES CHAVEZ'S CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The Defense Department has denied new charges by the United Farm Workers' Organizing Commit tee that It used its purchasing power to thwart farm workers seeking union recognition from California growers.

title: ALFRED BALL, EDITED WOODHAVEN PAPER
description: Alfred J. Ball, founder and former editor and publisher of The LeaderObserver, a weekly newspaper in Woodhaven, Queens, died yesterday in Nas sau Hospital, Mineola, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived at 189 Stewart Avenue, Garden City, L.I.

title: Collier to Succeed Graham As College AllStar Coach
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20 (AP) Blanton Collier, who retired after last season as coach of the Cleveland Browns at the age of 64, was named today as head coach of the College AllStars for their football game with the Super Bowl champions, the Baltimore Colts, in Soldier Field on July 30.

title: New Pesticide Law
description: ON Jan. 1, a New York State law went into effect that is a major step in keeping toxic pesticides out of the hands of the general public. The law established a list of restricted use pesticides that will be available only to permit hold ers. Ten pesticides have been singled out for no use what ever in the state.

title: Miss Peri Pike Bride of Dr. John Jacobs
description: The marriage of Miss Peri Pike, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Pike of the Bronx, to Dr. John William Jacobs, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Jacobs of Harrison, N. Y., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Rabbi Henry Skir ball, director of the National Federation of Temple Youth of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: VISITING NURSES SERVE BROOKLYN
description: As Geraldine Coxson, a vis iting nurse, entered the worn out tenement in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn the other day, she noted is sign on the front door that read: We Need Oil.

title: National Notes
description: A fresh approach to the urban dilemma was offered last week by David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, but it was far removed from New York City's immediate woes. His notion: the creation of a corpora tion to raise $10billion in pri vate investment to start building, from scratch, 110 new American citiesout in the boondocks.

title: VOICES FROM THE PIT
description: We wish to take strong issue with Martin Mayer's statement in his article, Marilyn Horne Becomes a Prima Donna (Jan. 17), that the Metropolitan Orchestra bullies Richard Bonynge.

title: GWEN NORMAN IS 2D IN MOSCOW 400 RUN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 20 (AP) Gwen Norman of Washington failed to match her preliminary recordbreaking time and fin ished second In the final of the women's 400meter run at the Moscow international indoor meet today.

title: May Seize Nitrate Mines
description: MARIA ELENA, Chile, Feb. 20 (Reuters)President A Ilende announced today that his Gov ernment might nationalize Chile's nitrate mines in the not too distant future.

title: Photography
description: A NEW camera tripod re cently introduced by QuickSet, Inc., 8121 Central Park Avenue, Skokie, Ill. 60076, Is not only exceptionally light in weight (about 3 pounds) and unusu ally sturdy, it is also much faster to set up or fold down than most other models. Built with square aluminum alloy telescoping legs, rather than the more common round ones, it has no bushings, threaded collars, screws or knobs to turn when legs are to be extended. To open, the legs aro simply pulled out; they then automatically lock in place with builtin brakes. To collapse, special levers are depressed, after which the legs can be pushed back to their shortened positionor to any Intermediate length in between.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: There'll Be Camping Ce Soir, If Le General Says Ca Va
description: THE French have taken to camping out in tents in a big way, es pecially along the Mediterranean coast come August, and last sum mer my wife and I decided to join them. But we had not reckoned on The General.

title: Recordings
description: CONTRAST is a neces sary element of any large  scale musical work, but it more than usually pervades Berlioz's Requiem. It is manifest in large, obvious ways  the alternation of powerful and quiet sections; in small ways setting the words Dies Irae, or Day of wrath, to a pianissimo melody; in the scoring, which ranges from no accompaniment for the chorus and the barest of in strumentation to the sonori ties of a full orchestra with added percussion and brass ensembles. All of these be tors suggest a musical met aphor appropriate to the theme of the Requiemthe human condition pitted against God's mighty, judg ment.

title: Montclair Clinches Tie
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 20 With its starting guards con tributing 45 points Montclair State assured itself tonight of at least a tie for its fourth consecutive New Jersey State College Conference champion ship by trouncing Paterson State, 10980.

title: And l cry every time you slip in one more dime and let the boy sing the sad one one more time. James Taylor, a New Troubadour
description: FOUR thousand kids sit on their coats and sweaters in a dark ening auditorium in Columbus, Ohio. In a backstage dressing room, James Taylor sits on what looks like a cartoonist's version of a psychia trist's chaise lounge. He hunches his broad shoulders and wipes his sweat ing palms on his worn dungarees. He pushes a hank of his long hair behind his ear and stares at the floor, obliv ious to stagehands and agents bran dishing bottles of brandy, Vanquish and Nyquill.Livingston Taylor, above, works hard at catching up with brother James. Of four Taylors following in James's footsteps, only one has not yet made an album.

title: FINES ARE ASSESSED IN POLICE DATA SALE
description: Five companies and three in dividuals were fined yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ger ald P. Culkin on charges stem ming from the alleged sale of confidential information from police files.

title: Bills Widening and Restricting Aid for Crime Victims Proposed
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20  A Democratic State Senator has urged the Legislature to liberalize the law under which the state pays com pensation to the victims of crimes of violence, but a Re publican Assemblyman has called for tightening it.

title: NAVY RALLY TOPS MANHATTAN, 6560
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 20 Navy's tough mantoman de fense held Manhattan to 20 points in the last 20 minutes to overcome an 11point half time deficit and go on to a 6560 basketball victory today before 1,230 fans at the Naval Academy field house.

title: Letters
description: No one would quarrel with the overall theme of Prof. John P. Roche's article, The Jigsaw Puzzle of History (Jan. 24). In the preface of my book, To Move a Na tion, for example, I wrote, No single person, not even the President himself can per sonally be acquainted with every facet of a large and complicated issue of foreign policy. But one can make the point without being unfair to men on either side of the policy argument. The de bates were passionate, but, as I also said in my book, the people on both sides of the argument were honest, intelligent, reasonable and pa triotic men struggling man fully with mean and intricate problems of the highest im portance.

title: Man Seized Here in Securities Theft
description: A man collecting unemploy ment insurance was arrested yesterday and charged with possession of $2million in stolen, negotiable securities.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Dow's View
description: Our physical plant is in tremendous shape. We have awesome depth in our man agement group. Our processes for our most important products are as good or better than others in the industry.

title: GOLF LEAD TAKEN BY SANDRA PALMER
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. Feb. 20 (AP)Sandra Palmer shot a twounder par 71 today and took the lead by three strokes in the $60,000 Sears Womens World Classic at windblown Port St. Lucie Country Club.

title: Court Set Up in 1969
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 18  The Jewish Agency set up the court in Vienna 18 months ago main ly for the convenience of refugees from Communist coun tries, many of them accompan ied by Gentile wives and chil dren who wanted to embrace Judaism.

title: U.S. Aides Discount Soviet Role in Egypt's Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 With ArabIsraeli diplomacy now at a crucial stage, Ameri can specialists on the Middle East report that the Soviet Union is cautiously signaling its approval of the current trend but that its commitment to an ultimate peace agreement is still untested.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Adelphi Halts A. I. C.
description: Adelphi University downed American International College, 7869, last night.

title: In the first novel is a second that is the first
description: In these days it's remarkable to find an author who can write about joy, unmitigated joy, without sound ing simpleminded or insular. And who can write again of the American road in a style so personal and authentic that you aren't reminded of all those other hooks about it. That's what Mason Smith has done in his first novel, Everybody Knows and Nobody Cares. There is a patina to each page of this book that can usually be found only in the books of longstanding practitioners of prose, and Smith's prose, when it's at its best, has an apparent ef fortlessness and a poetic flex and lilt that make you sit up straight.

title: Michael Panayotopulos To Wed Kemper Penney
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20Miss Willa Kem per Penney of New York and Michael Alexander Panayo topulos of Sands Point, LI., Hinson's Island, Bermuda and Athens plan to be married in New York on April 24. The ceremony in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will be followed by a recep tion at the River Club.

title: Williams Hits Homer
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20 (UPI)  Ted Williams, 52 years old and carrying a bulg ing stomach, demonstrated to day that he hadn't lost his powerful swing.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: State of the Paperback
description: Most book publishers, like most U.S. businessmen, are singing the blues these short winter days, but not those whose mission in life is to keep the newsstand and bookshop racks stocked with paperbacks. It's hard to find a soft cover publisher who won't acknowledge that he's selling at least 10 per cent more copies of his wares than he was a year ago, with an average increase of more than 30 per cent in cover price making up for rises in production costs. (Firm figures won't be available until next fall, but an educated guess is that more than 400 million paperbacks were sold in the past year, at an average retail price close to one dollar.)

title: Fryman Accepts Phils' Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (UPI) The Philadelphia Phillies an nounced today the signings of Woodie Fryman, a pitcher, and Greg Luzinski, a rookie first baseman. The Phils open spring training at Clearwater, Fla., on Monday with 12 of their 38 players still unsigned.

title: Suffolk Village Split on Incorporation
description: LAKE GROVE, Feb. 20 A group of residents, of this Suffolk County community, which was incorporated as a village in 1968, are urging that it return to its previous status as an unincorporated area in the Town of Brook haven.

title: The Nation
description: Nineteen months ago I said that America's medical system faced a massive crisis. Since that statement was made, that crisis has deepened.

title: EARLY COMPUTERS DISPLAYED AT IBM
description: Charles Eames's Computer Perspective is a bit like the Bibleit can be read as a his tory of wars, politics, thought, culture, social change or, as, the architect  designer  filmmaker prefers, in totd.

title: BOAC Said to Have Doubts
description: LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)Brit ish Overseas Airways Corp. has told the British Government that it sees no way it can oper ate the Concorde economically, The Observer reports.

description: CAGLIARI, Italy, Feb, 20 (AP)Spain's soccer team up set Italy, the European cham pion and World Cup finalist, 21, today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Creed of a Congressman
description: This word portrait is painted by one of Congressman F. Edward He bert's most unabashed admirers. The book is further decimated as a ser ious study by a breathless, gollygee biographical sketch authored by a lady who commands the Congress man's district office in New Orleans. Their combined huzzahs stop just shout of proclaiming Mr. H6bert's ability to turn water into wine.

description: To the Editor:

title: ARMY TRACKMEN PIN 6940 LOSS ON NAVY
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 20 Kevin James, who missed practice all week with a severe heel bruise, set a meet and field house record in the pole vault tonight to lead Army to a 6940 indoor victory over Navy.

description: INZELL, Germany, Feb. 20 Anne Henning, a 15vear old Northbrook, Ill., girl, shat tered the women's world 500 meter record today in the international sprint speed skating championships.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 20  Education Commissioner Sidney P. Marland Jr. announced today that his office had frozen be tween $8million and $10mil lion allocated for research and development in education, pend ing a review.

title: Rock or Bach an Issue to Plants, Singer Says
description: DENVER, Feb. 20  It's certainly not pure science and Mrs. Dorothy Retallack is the first to concede it as she roars enthusiastically for ward playing recorded music for her plants at Temple Buell College.

title: Elspeth Merck Royster Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Royster Jr. of New York and Henderson, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elspeth Merck Royster, to Eric San ford Holch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Holch of Green wich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass.

title: Copenhagen's TivoliOften Spied Upon
description: COPENHAGENPromoters of other amusement parks spy rather shamelessly on Tivoli Gardens, which has been one of the top attractions of the Danish capital for the past century and a quarter. They have tried to duplicate it in other places (at Expo 70 in Montreal, for example) but the only Tivoli that counts is the one that sprawls downtown here across the boulevard from the old City Hall and the main railroad station. The Danes say that summer has ar rived when Tivoli opens each year on May 1. To them, although it is pri vately owned and operated, the park is a national institution. Five million visitorsDenmark's population is less than thisenter Tivoli each year. Danes, who come from all over the country, represent 70 per cent of all visitors (the Danish royal family makes at least one visit, incognito, each season); the next largest group of visitors are the Swedes, who account for half of the foreign contingent. Americans are out numbered by 15 to 1.

title: The World
description: MOSCOW  One consumer story being told in Moscow these days is about the woman who burst excitedly Into her neigh bor's apartment.

title: Opera: Revival of Werther at the Met
description: Massenet's Werther, re vived Friday by the Metro politan Opera in a new pro duction, went on without one of its big guns. There was delay before the curtain went up, and then Osie Hawkins, the stage manager, appeared to make an announcement. He said that Franco Corelli was indisposed, and that on 15minute notice, Enrico Di Giuseppe would replace him.

title: 12 SOCCER TEAMS IN ACTION TODAY
description: Twelve Major Division teams of the GermanAmerican Soc cer League will play six games on four different fields in the metropolitan area today, with the New York Hota vs. Ger manHungarians game high lighting the action.

title: PAUL A. SWEENEY, 75, MITCHELL AIDE, DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)Paul A. Sweeney, a Gov ernment lawyer since 1965 and a special assistant to Attorney General John N. Mitchell, died Thursday. He was 75 years old.

title: Proposal to Bridge L.I. Sound Is in Crucial Stage
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20A ques tion that has nagged Long Is land homeowners, politicians and businessmen for much of the last decadewhether and where to bridge Long Island Soundis to be answered once and for all by June 21, if Gov ernor Rockefeller has his way.

title: Miss Murray and Hugh Sloan Jr., Aides of the Nixons, Are Wed
description: LAKEWOOD, Ohio, Feb. 20 St. Peter's Episcopal Church was the setting here tonight for the marriage of Miss Deborah Louise Murray, who is a member of Mrs. Nixon's staff at the White House, to Hugh W. Sloan Jr., staff assistant to President Nixon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard M. Morris.

title: Hawaii Camping, Mark Twain Said, Is a Picnic
description: LIHUE, Hawaii  Several mornings while we were camping on Han amaulu Bay here on the island of Kauai, we were awakened at day break by a rooster's crowing somewhere in the distance. We did not mind, since we had gone to bed with the chickens, lulled by the peace and the soft rhythms of the wavelets only a few yards from the wheels of our camper. Besides, a dewfresh dawn in Hawaii can be a wholly delightful experience, worth the effort it takes to stir from a comfortable bed about the time the wandering tat tlers and other sandpipers start their beach patrol.

title: HODGSON WINDS UP TALK WITH UNIONS ON BUILDING COSTS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson ended his meetings with building trades leaders here today without publicly an nouncing progress in working out a plan for curbing wage and price rises in the construction industry.

title: PRINCETON COEDS AIDED BY BEQUEST
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 20 A $5million bequest earmarked for Princeton University in 1936, decades before women were allowed in its classes, has now been received by the uni versity and will be used to support coeducation.

title: Headliners
description: During the Feb. 5 performance of his play Two by Two, Danny Kaye tore a ligament in his left leg and had to leave the show indefinitely. Needless to say, with the irrepressible Danny out, the musical sufferednot the least at the box office. Last Thursday word circulated that Mr. Kaye was back in the cast and crowds began to form. Sure enough, when the curtain rose, there he washobbling on a crutch with his leg in a cast. To the delight of the audience, Danny stumbled and adlibbed, and when he received an ovation at the end, he said happily, This is what life is made for. The show must go on.

title: Their Troubled Paradise Might Be America Itself
description: I HAD heard that National Educa tional Television was going to broadcast Clifford Odets's Paradise Lost with Eli Wallach, Jo Van Fleet and other wellknown actors; the news stirred remembrances of things past. I directed the play when it opened in New York on Dec. 9, 1935. The cast then included Morris Carnovsky, Stella Adler, Sanford Meisner, Luther Adler, Elia Kazan, Robert Lewis and other members of the Group Theater's perma nent company.

title: Ohio Weekly Chronicles Nonviolent World of the Amish
description: SUGARCREEK, Ohio, Feb. 17 For the Amish, who are scat tered in isolated rural settle ments in 19 states, the grape vine is a nationally circulated weekly newspaper, the only one anywhere devoted to news of the small religious sect.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Kelly To Wed Aug. 14
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Feb. 20Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Kelly have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Co nant Kelly, to Robert Pierce Tweedell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Fleming Tweedell of Athens, Ga.

title: DUQUESNE VICTOR OVER ST. PETER'S
description: Duquesne, bigger and strong er, wore down St. Peter's and gained a 10498 victory yes terday in the first game of a college basketball doublehead er at Madison Square Garden.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The re port on the Federal Govern ment by the Ash Council is something less than a work of a great depth.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Music
description: WHEN Norman Singer was ad ministrator of the Hunter College Concert Bureau, he ex tended its activities signifi cantly, introducing series devoted to music that was very old, very new or for unusual combinations of performers. Omus Hirshbein, the current adminis trator, has pursued the same course, with the result that the college's two auditoriums, the Playhouse and the As sembly Hall, have become an important center of New York's concert life.

title: STUDY IS SOUGHT IN DELAY OF TRIAL
description: The New York Urban League has called for an investigation into the case of a 27yearold black artist who has been awaiting trial in the Tombs for 27 months, partly because he refuses to follow the advice of court  appointed lawyers to plead guilty to murder. He in sists that he is innocent.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Environmental awareness has been rising sharply of late. Diverse interests, rang ing from Wall Street analysts and stock market investors to the Sierra Club member ship (among others), are deeply engaged in evaluating commitments, measuring po tentials  increasingly rein forced by Federal, state and local proposals and, in some instances, pressures.

title: Reader's Report
description: These sturdy vignettes would have seemed at home in the pages of transition or Broom. Which is not to say that they are dated, but rather that they have a timeless quality about them. Miss Dillon excels at slightly outoffocus percep tions that can give a gothic twist to the mundane. Consid er Second Bedroom, which delineates a lovers' quarrel be tween a girl who barricades her bed with back issues of Life magazine, and a middle aged man who finds total re lease in folk rock. Or In duce, in which a doctor's wife decides that her spouse is in fatuated with his chihuaha.

title: Disney: A World of Show
description: BURBANK, Calif,  Ques tion: Is there a Matterhorn in Florida?

title: Ch. Ancram's Simon, English Cocker Spaniel, Named Best at Hartford Show
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 20The topwinning English cocker spaniel in the history of the breed in America, Ch. Ancham's Simon, a 5yearold blue roan owned by Joyce ScottPaine of Ancramdale, N. Y., was named best of 1,268 dogs at the 42d dog show of the First Company Foot Guard Athletic Association at the State Armory tonight.

title: 4,928 Teams in Tourney
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 20 (AP)A total of 4,928 five woman teams have been en tered for the 1971 champion ship tournament of the Wom an's International Bowling Con gress, scheduled to open in At lanta April 8.

title: Bolin, Pitching Batting Practice, First Casualty of Red Sox Training Camp
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla. (UPI) The Boston Red Sox camp received a scare today when Bob Bolin was hit in the face at batting practice.

title: Ponies Are Too Tired, Polo Match Ends in Tie
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 20 Dave Wright scored a goal seconds before the final bell to give the Ox Ridge Hunt Club a 1010 tie with the To ronto Polo Club today in the first game of a homeand home series.

title: NETS WIN, 120100, FROM CHAPARRALS
description: DALLAS, Feb. 20 (AP)The New York Nets recorded their fifth consecutive road victory tonight, defeating the Texas Chaparrals, 120.100, in an American Basketball Associa tion game.

title: URBAN UNIT URGES BUDGET REFORMS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The National Urban Coalition suggested today a dollarby dollar recasting of the nation's priorities through a greatly revised Federal budget for the next five years.

title: Dy Wd Bill in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 20. (AP)The Utah Attorney Gen eral's office has come up with a bill to outlaw socalled dirty words in public. But the pro posal only identified the words by their first letters and ap propriate dashes. Deputy At torney General Robert B. Han sen said he saw no need to spell out the words since lie felt the courts could figure out the intended words without trouble.

title: Law
description: NEW HAVENLast May, his case still pending, he drew 15,000 people to the Town Green. Last Thursday, on trial for his life, he drew 15.

title: Mrs. Godsick Has Son
description: A son was born on Jan. 19 to Dr. and Mrs. Peter A. Godsick of New York in Len ox Hill Hospital. Mrs. God sick is the former Miss Aileen Lewisohn, daughter of Rich ard Lewisohn, New York City Finance Administrator, and Mrs. Richard Feldon of New York. Dr. Godsick is an orthopedic surgeon. The child has been named Anthony Lewisohn.

title: Movies
description: WITH filming completed on his The Anderson Tapes, di rector Sidney Lumet is preparing to switch from the con crete thrills of a contemporary milliondollar heist to the shifting sands of Biblical interpretation. Lumet said the other day that he had very quietly acquired the rights to Nikos Kazantzakis's novel, The Last Temptation of Christ, about a year ago. Now I've got a completed scriptit's his first for a filmby Seymour Simckes, he added. Simckes is the playwright whose Seven Days of Mourning, a drama about a Jewish family in the Depression, won praise in an Off Broadway production last winter.

title: EDWARD R. WILD
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 20 Edward Raymond Wild of 261 Rivergate Drive, Wilton, vice president of the General Elec tric Credit Corporation of Stam ford, died yesterday at Nor walk Hospital. His age was 49.

title: CHILE TO PRESENT ECONOMIC PLANS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20 Chilean officials flew to Wash ington today carrying an op timistic estimate of economic prospects and a message wel coming some foreign, invest ment.

title: Brock Endows College With Batting Machine
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Feb, 20 (UPI)The St. Louis Car dinal baseball player, Lou Brock, has given a batting machine and a check for $2,000 to his alma mater, Southern University.

title: Ryan Ties World Mark in Mile With 3:56.4 in Track Comeback
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20 (AP) Jim Ryun gave credit to the lastplace finisher and Kerry O'Brien gave credit to the track as they raced to world record victories in stunning displays of distance running last night.

title: Susan H. Chambers Fiancee of Student
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y., Feb. 20Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Edmund Chambers have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Hathaway Chambers, to Steven Paul Hirshberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvan Hirsh berg of Haverhill, Mass.

title: View in Capital: Airlines' Financial Ills Are Serious but Temporary
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 When an industry slides in five years from peak annual profits of nearly $500  million to a 1970 deficit of roughly $175 million, no one doubts that it is hurting.

title: Fouls Decimate School Five
description: GARBS, Nev., Feb. 22 (AP) Virginia City High School scored an 8769 basketball vic tory over Gabbs last night. The home team has only seven players and with one second left, it lost its sixth player on fouls.

title: A poet's prose and poetry
description: AS well as it can, the hooked fish while it dies, Gasping for life, threshing in terror and pain, Its torn mouth parched, grit in its delicate eyes, Thinks of its pool again.

title: Reader's Report
description: Other survivors of the 1940's will feel a twinge of recognition at the stencils this author so well remembers. In those dead days, to do your own thing was to believe in yourself; a writer  even a film writer  hoped he could really say something, preferably some thing significant; and if you were of uncertain goals you had to find yourself. Sic transit not so much. A young girl named Christine Mull lives in the midst of these aspira tions, out in Beverly Hills, where mother is a contract screenwriter and father a failed literary man. Like Marjorie Morningstar, her East Coast sis ter, Christine has vague ideas of romantic independence. But she has also (these are the forties) strong ties of family loyalty. So Christine's tenta tive move, at the close of the novel, to leave college and go all out for selfexpression in volves a cataclysmic family crisis.

title: Deliberately Depressing?
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: For Young Readers
description: Who among us has not expe rienced the physical reenactment of a dream. This feeling, sometimes called dj vu, is one of the many fas cinating and often chilling subjects discussed in this excellent book about psychic phenomena. Although E.S.P. and other experiences of this nature had for a long time been dismissed as pure superstition or relegated to shadowy place in the minds of in telligent people, it has now begun to receive the attention and serious re search that it deserves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bench, Merritt, Rose, Perez Among Absentees as Reds Open Training Camp
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 20The Cincinnati Reds began to re assemble the Big Red Machine today, but found half the vital parts missing.

title: Yonadab sees all, tells all
description: Dan Jacobson has made out of the Biblical story of Amnon and Tamar a beautifully crafted novel of unflagging intelligence by resisting all the temptations of cinematic sensationalism and archeological reconstruction in herent in his material, and in the historical novel as a genre. The story told in II Samuel 13 exceeds even the norms of Old Testament narrative in its stark ness, its brutality, its haunt ing suggestiveness: Tamar, David's daughter, is craved, then raped, by her halfbrother Amnon, who immediately after the act hates her with a hatred greater than the love with which he had loved her.

title: Joseph Kahns Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Kahn of Cainbridge, Mass., on Feb. 15 at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. Mrs. Kahn is the former Miss Marian Baker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Baker of Tucson, Ariz. Mr. Kahn, a senior at Harvard University, is a son of Mrs. Virginia R. Kahn and Elias J. Kahn Jr., both of New York. The child, named Jahns Thomas, is a great grandson of Elias Jacques Kahn, the architect, and Mrs. Harold H. Rice of East Rindge, N. H.

title: Design Called Modern
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The State Department said to day that prison cells being in stalled by an American con tractor on Con Son were de signed according to modern, penal standards.

title: Quality of Schools Varies Widely Under Local Board
description: At Public School 101, which is nestled among the neoTudor uppermiddleclass homes of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, Edwin Colbath, the principal, said school decentralization had made it easier for him to order books and to give teachers sabbaticals.

title: KIND R. RECEPTION FIRST AT OAKLAWN
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark, Feb. 20 (AP)Kind R. Reception out ran Sado in the stretch today to win the $20,000 Akkansas Traveler Handicap at Otklawn Park.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20There is a certain kind of day during which you close a heavy drawer on your finger. It is possible to recognize this day almost immediately after rising. It often begins with discovery that there is no toothpaste.

title: AN EXGOVERNOR ACCUSED OF BRIBE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Former Gov. William Wallace Barron of West Virginia was indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Charleston, W. Va., on charges of paying $25,000 to the foreman of a jury that acquitted him of ear lier bribery charges in 1968.

title: Army Rifle Team Snaps St. John's Wining Streak
description: St. John's University rifle team suffered its first defeat yesterday after 12 victories. Army beat the Redmen, 1,423 to 1,382, at the St. John's range in Jamaica, Queens. Army's total, with 1,500 as the best possible score, was an Academy record.

title: Birchmore Upsets Colson At Princeton Net, 63, 6.4
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 20 Danny Birchmore of Georgia up set Bill Colson of Princeton 63, 6.4, in the semifinals of the Princeton indoor intercollegiate tennis tournament today. Col son, seeded first, won the event last year.

title: National Notes
description: The New York Telephone Com pany sent a distress signal to the Public Service Commission last week: If telephone service in the state is to be improved, the com pany needs additional annual revenues of $391millionwhich translates into a 29.1 per cent, twostage increase in the basic rate charged customers.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: An Amazonian OdysseyBogota to Lima
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  As we shivered in the glacial dawn at Bogota's El Dorado Airport, waiting to board the Colombia Air Force plane that was to take us to the Amazon, our apprehension was overcome only by the bargainbasement features of the military run.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Evin J. Rosenbaum Plans Bridal; Brother to Wed Patricia Howell
description: Announcement has been made here of the engage ment of Miss Evin J. Rosen baum to Warren P. Willman and of the engagement of Miss Patricia Louise Howell to Miss Rotenbaum's brother, Stephan L. Rosenbaum.

title: HARVARD SEXTET DEFEATS PENN, 71
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 20 Led by Joe Cavanagh's three goals, Harvard's hockey team defeated Pennsylvania, 51, in an Ivy League game.

title: Michael King, M.B.A. Student, Is Fiance of Susan E. Robinson
description: HILLSDALE, N. J. Feb. 20 Miss Susan Ellen Robinson will be married in April to Michael Christopher King, di rector of production for the College Marketing Corpora tion in New York:

title: Letters
description: Merle Miller is, I suppose, to be congratulated for what ever courage it took to come out of the closet after nearly half a century, especially now when (in New York if not Marshalltown, Iowa) it is safe, fashionable and not in frequently remunerative to make the trip.

title: EXNIXON AIDE JOINS ANTIWAR CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Common Cause, the new public interest lobbying organization, will begin next week a major campaign against the Nixon Administration's Indochina war policies and has hired a former White House aide as an adviser to the effort.

title: Turkish Students Battle Police 5 Hours
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 20, (Reuters)At least 220 stu dents were arrested in a gun and dynamite battle with the police at a university in An kara last night and several bomb blasts in different parts of the country today.

title: Planning Office at Brown U.
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 20 (AP)  Brown University has established an Office of Anal ysis and Plans to study the school's operations and future, its president, Dr. Donald F. Hornig has announced. The as sociate provost, Paul F. Maeder, will serve as director of the new office.

title: Harlem Buddies Are College Court Foes
description: Harlem is basketball territory. Behind every school yard fence, grudge games boil and recruiters lurk. During the summer months some of the nation's top collegians battle one another on the hot cement courts.

title: F. L. Kramers Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lawrence Kra mer of New York on Jan. 13 in Lenox Hill. Hospital. Mrs. Kramer is the former Del phine McCosker.

title: Great Pyrenees Popular Breed At the Providence K.G. Fixture
description: News of Dogs

title: The World
description: TEHERAN  The Shah of Iran seldom speaks to the press in his own country. But, buoyed by the success of the Teheran agreement on international oil, the Shah agreeably mused over the pact's significance last week before flying off for his annual vacation in St. Moritz.

title: CHARLES A. BERNS, 21 BRANDS HEAD
description: Charles A. Berns, chairman of the board of 21. Brands, Inc., and the original Charlie of Jack and Charlie's 21 Club, died yesterday of a heart attack in Palm Springs, Calif., where he was on vaca tion. He was 69 years old and lived at 24 Central Park South.

title: Eased Regulations for the New Navy Tightened Up by Chief
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20Senior officers charged with imple menting Adm Elmo It. Zum walt's new Navy regulations have persuaded him to rewrite or clarify several of his tradi tionshattering Zgrams that re laxed dress and hair styles for enlisted men.

title: Cannon Uninjured in Crash At 120 M.P.H. in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 20 (Reuters)John Cannon of the United States and Graham McRae, of New Zealand es caped injury in highspeed crashes today in practice runs for the Tasman series In auto racing at the Sandown track.

title: Television
description: FOR any weekly televi sion comedy situation series to generate an iota of controversy is akin to having network heads William S. Paley, Leonard H. Goldenson and Julian Goodman do a festive May pole dance in Central Park Mall. Not that such pirouet ting executives would be wanting in consummate grace; it just ain't going to happen.

title: Annex Belle Triumphs
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Feb. 20 (AP) Annex Belle, winner of five consecutive claiming races in two months at Lincoln Downs, scored again today in his first attempt in a handicap feature.

title: L.I.R. Is Expected to Get More Aid From the State
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20If a su permarket were run the way the Long Island Railroad is a person could expect to find lettuce in the meat section, some erratic computations at the checkout counter and cus tomers stealing apples.

title: The Gallagher Who Gives Nanette Its Sheen
description: OKAY, so that's Helen Gallagher up there, but where's Helen Gal lagher? The curtain's risen on the new No, No, Nanette, the Boys and Girls are chattering, and from stage left sidles this haughty, linear vamp in burnt orange, sleek as a lac quered cigarette holder, who purrs few sentences from the chest, not the heart, signals the conductor with eyes that have seen almost but not quite everything, and does Too Many Rings Around Rosy like Constance Bennett with singing lessons. She throws away lines with such serene precision that Burt Shevelove sounds like Noel Cow ard; she slinks hipless with Bobby Van through You Can Dance With Any Girl; and in Act III she discreetly moans the WhereHasMyHubby Gone Blues with the aid of the most articulate chiffon handkerchief seen in New York since Hildegarde did Keep 'Em Laughing. And she's delicious, but it takes some getting used to. Where's Gallagher the manic, the kinetic? Where's Gladys Bumps of Pal Joey, Nicki of Sweet Charity, the wise mouth kid with the bangs, the voice like a sterlingsilver pavement drill and the fastest hips on West 45th? Where's the definitive soubrette from the days when musicals still had lots of sax in the overture?

title: Martha Weeks To Be a Bride
description: BELMONT, Mass., Feb. 20 Mr. and Mrs, John W. Weeks have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Martha Sinclair Weeks, to Edgar Jewett White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. White of Lincoln.

title: Norfolk's Chief Export Is Ghosts
description: KINGSTON, Norfolk IslandIn an unhappier eraback in the 1780's most visitors to this tiny, isolat ed and serene South Pacific island, 1,035 miles northeast of Australia, ar rived as prisoners in chains. Many were glad to risk their lives on a slim chance of escaping from the notorious penal colony that existed here in those days.

title: Popularity of Big Families Put At a Record Low in Gallup Poll
description: The percentage of Americans who favor large, families has declined dramatically since 1967, according to the Gallup Poll, and is now at the lowest point in the 35 years that the, polling organization has conducted regular surveys on the subject.

title: Boys High Team Regains P. S. A. L. Indoor Track Crown
description: Boys High, upset by Brooklyn Tech last year, won on two counts over its borough rival yesterday in the 67th annual Public School Athletic League indoor track and field cham pionships at the 102d engineers armory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: Loran L. Stewart's article, New Forest Law Needed (Jan. 31), is extremely one sided. If one considers only economic values, as one who is president of the National Forest Products Association should, then the cutting of a tree the moment it matures is, of course, the optimal thing.

title: PAKISTANIS OPEN CHINA ROAD LINK
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 20 Pakistan and China were linked by motor road this week when Gen. Abdul Hamid Khan, Army Chief of Staff, declared open the Karakoram highway over the 15,500foot Khunjerab Pass.

title: Poll Called Camouflaged Smear; Quayle Denies Official's Charge
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Feb. 20(AP)The County Executive of Dutchess County has asked a State Supreme Court justice here to orddr one of the na tion's leading political polling firms to halt a survey that he says is a camouflaged smear campaign.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INTEREST RATES dropped further last week as the. Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Admin istration rolled rates on Governmentbacked home loans back to 7 per cent from 7 per cent, and as banks lowered the prime rate to 5 per cent. The banks' action was the sixth cut of  percentage point since November and brought the rate to its: lowest level since November, 1967.

title: Juliet Grennan Bride in Capital Of Army Officer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Miss Juliet Catherine Gren nan, and Lieut. Kent Mc Gregor Ronhovde, U.S.A,, were married here this after noon in the Little Sanctuary of St. Alban's School.

title: EXPERT FORESEES PROFITS ON SPACE
description: Dr. Wernher von Braun, the space agency's chief planner, says he is convinced that in 20 years we shall have reached the point where space travel will earn more than it is cost ing.

title: Fiction and The Figures of Life
description: Some people read literary criticism the way they listen to a sermon. They hope to be edified, but they don't expect to enjoy themselves. Some treat criticism as a kind of social register. They want to know who is on and who is off, what is in and what is out. Is it still safe to praise James? Has the Dickens revival gone too far? And then there are those who are looking for a New ton or Darwin or Einstein among lit erary critics. They yearn for some one to straighten out the mess, to provide a formula or at least a theory that will relieve some of the burden of subjectivity and uncertainty art always seems, to thrust on us.

title: Five Trustees Reappointed To Library Posts in Queens
description: Mayor Lindsay has reap pointed five members of the board of trustees of the Queens Public Library.

title: Notes From the Orient: A Disneyland and Other Surprises
description: TOKYOWe flew from Los Angeles to Tokyo and were overwhelmed to see a man in the crowd at the Tokyo Airport holding a large sign reading, Welcome, Mr. and Mrs. Smithers. We knew no one in Japan. But we had made a hotel reservation, and this was the acknowledgement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Zanzibar: Where the Unpredictable Is Predictable
description: ZANZIBAR, Tanzania, Feb. 11When parts of Pakistan were ravaged by floods last November, this little dot of an island off the East African coast sent a million dollars to help the injured and the homeless.

title: Big E of $67,480 Goes Begging at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP)The Big Exacta at Liberty Bell's harness track totaled a record $67,480.60 last night. Track officials said no one had yet produced a winning ticket.

title: Student Is Fiance Of Amy Luskind
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, LI, Feb. 20The engagement of Miss Amy Susan Luskind, to Edward Seth Weltman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul N. Welt man of. Valley Stream, has been made known by her par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Luskind.

title: Ne Win, III, Flies to London
description: RANGOON, Burma, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Burma's Chief of State, Gen, Ne Win, flew to night to London for medical treatment. The Burma radio said lie had postponed a visit to Nepal, lo have begun today, because of his health. But it gave no indication of the ail ment.

title: Gardens
description: THE GREAT American plantsman, Liberty Hyde Bailey once dis cerned that, If a window or garden can have but one plant, that plant is likely to be a geranium. Beauty of leaf and flower, freebloom ing habit, and ability to withstand ne glect, attest to the wide appeal of ge raniums.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONPresident Nixon's news conference of Feb. 17 made clear what skeptics have long believed. His Vietnam policy is by no means one of steadily withdrawing Americans from South Vietnam, then letting the people of Indochina work out or fight out their own affairs. It is instead policy of escalation by American air power and South Vietnamese man power, with the aim of military vic tory.

title: Brooklyn Poly to Honor 2
description: A. physics prolessor and a Brooklyn businessman have been selected Lo receive the distinguished alumnus awards of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. The recipients are Prof. Hubert W. Schleuuing, chairman of the institute's un dergraduate physics depart ment, and Samuel Wunsch, secretarytreasurer of the Silent Hoist and Crane. Company. The awards will be made at the Polytechnic Alumni Associa tion's annual dinner at the La Guardia Airport Sheraton Hotel on March 20.

title: America's Most Exciting New Theater?
description: THE most exciting new theater in America is the Chelsea Theater Center at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music. In this first year of its prime, Chelsea has given New York a regionalstyle theater, free of the aspirations of Lincoln Center to pres tige, free of the aspirations of the late APA to Broadway. At the same time, Chelsea has helped fill the gap that Off Broadway left when it went so completely commercial.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP) The Minnesota Twins had little to report in negotiations with Jim Perry, their 24game winner last season, but Man ager Bill Regney had a report about Rod Carew.

title: Mansion in Brooklyn Is Home To Group of 55 Krishna Devotees
description: They live almost like re cluses in a 54room mansion in Brooklyn except fbr the curi ous journeys they make through the streets of New York every afternoon. Then people stop and look at them, wondering who they are.

title: Ali Invited to Arabia
description: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Muhammad Ali has accepted an invitation of the Ministry of Labor and So cial Affairs to visit Saudi Ara bia next month, local news papers reported today.

title: After a Stanley CupHomex
description: AVON, N. Y.  Harry Sin den drives about 20 miles from his home in Pittsford, N. Y., to the headquarters of the, Stirling, Homex Cor poration here every morning. As director of sales engineer ing, his job is to sell modular housing.

title: Ice Fishermen Flock to Lakes, Bringing the Comforts of Home With Them
description: BEAVER DAM, Wis., Feb. 16There were curtains in the windows, a rug on the floor, a radio hanging from the roof and a woodburning stove in the corner, Out side a howling wind made the 10degree weather seem more like 30 below zero.

title: Movies
description: EVERYONE has been babbling lately about the return to romance in movies, but no one seems to have any idea what genuinely romantic movie looks like. Many of the same critics who wel comed Love Story as a beautiful romantic movie have attacked The Music Lovers, Ken Russell's stunning film on Tchaikovsky, as absurdly over wrought. Romantic movies are sweep ing, expansive, touching uncontrollable extremes of feeling and experience. But Love Story Is narrow, mechanical, morbid, a cozy domesticated romance with Christmas card settings; the hard, snappy preppielovers may be attractive and talented, but they are practical and smallminded enough to settle down to a humdrum suburban dream. The char acters in The Music Lovers, by con trast, are extraordinary people with extraordinary dreams, extraordinary re sponses to ordinary dilemmas. They do not adjust their aspirations to the limits of middleclass reality; they dare life to rise to their expectations.

title: Regaining the Trade Initiative
description: The Mills bill, the most protectionist trade legislation since the disastrous SmootHawley Act of 1920, was blocked in the last session of Congress by a determined group of liberal traders in the Senate, aided by the Senate logjam resulting from Senator Long's folly seeking to couple Social Security liberalization, welfare reform and trade.

title: Christianity as Fairy Tale
description: The Passion and the Resur rection, Faith, Death, Creation, Redemption, Grace, all the great Christian assumptions are here, transformed into vital, witty fairy tales for childrenchil dren who, having once read them, will never quite be chil dren again. In the fourteen hun dred odd pages of The Narnia Chronicles (Collier, 7 vols., il lustrated, 95 cents each), and without a single overt refer ence to Christ, C. S. Lewis has allegorized the entire Christian world view.

title: CHRYSLER NAMES PUBLIC ISSUE UNIT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20  The Chrysler Corporation has estab lished an Office of Public Re sponsibility headed by three top officers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article entitled Recycling: Will We Drown in Trashor Learn to Re use It? in The Week In Review Feb. 7, misstates the role of the Nixon Admin istration in the enactment of the Re source Recovery Act of 1970.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fordham Sets Back Rutgers Five, 8784
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 20  Fordham staged an other of its thrillers tonight as the Rams rallied from well back to beat Rutgers, 8784, at the Rutgers gymnasium and move a big step closer to an expected National Collegiate Athletic As sociation basketball tournament bid.

title: Stamps
description: MANY ANY American stamp collectors organize tions are planning spring conventions and exhibitions, and a num ber have scheduled gather ings in New York during the weekend of March 12.14 to coincide with Interpex, the spring stamp show at the Americana Hotel.

title: NEW LINE MAY GET DOUBLE TRACKAGE
description: The projected superex press transit line between the Queens Plaza area and Forest Hills in Queens may turn out to be a doubletrack route in stead of the single track orig inally proposed.

title: M'LERNON VICTOR IN GOLD RACQUETS
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 20David McLernon, Canadian raquets champion, gained the semifinals of the 69th annual Tuxedo Gold Racquets Tourna ment today in the Tuxedo Rac quets and Tennis Club. He de feated David Minot of Boston, 151, 1512.

title: DR. LOUIS SAPIRSTEIN
description: Dr. Louis Sapirstein, a dentist in Jamaica, Queens, died Friday in Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing. He was 82 years old and lived at 17506 Devonshire Road, Jamaica Estates.

title: Salavarria Outpoints Hayes In 12Round Nontitle Fight
description: MANILA, Feb, 20 (AP)  Erbito Salavarria of the Philip pines, World Boxing Council flyweight champion, outpointed Harry Hayes of Australia to night in a nontitle 12round fight.

title: Irish Beat W. Virginia, 10798;
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Feb. 20Austin Carr poured in 47 points today to lead Notre Dame to a 10798 victory over erratic West Virginia Univer sity. A crowd of 13,652, the largest basketball gathering in the state's history, was on hand.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Bank holding companies have been taking second looks at some of their more ambitious diversification pro grams in the light of the Bank Holding Company Act of 1970, which, among other things, restricted their activi ties to those so closely related to banking or manag ing or controlling banks as to be a proper incident thereto.

title: DOG GROOMOBILES PROVING POPULAR
description: MERRICK, L. I. Feb. 20 The Rockville Centre housewife was on the phone asking Could you come and take care of the only man in my life?

title: L.I. CONGRESSMAN SETTLING INTO JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20  Representative Norman F. Lent was taking a guided tour of the White House with his family the other day when some Nas sau County constituents, who were also on the tour, spotted him and wanted to know what their Congressman was doing there.

description: The heavy weather that is now buffeting the nation's econ omy may destroy Long Island's only professional symphony or chestra.

title: Bridge How not to set a grand slam with three aces
description: PEOPLE who speak similar lan guages, such as the Germans and Dutch, or the Spanish and Por tuguese, often run into some con fusion when they try to communi cate with each other verbally. Such problems arise in speech and bridge where Americans and English are concerned.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: For a Nightclub in Queens, It's Rock No
description: The heavy, arched wooden doors, lit on both sides by lamps in black wrought iron fixtures and set in a plain, undecorated facade that reaches two sto ?? high, might be the entrance to a chapel or monastery. There is nothing to indicate what is inside those doors on Queens Boulevard near 40th Street until the eye travels up to the roof, where a modest, multicolored sign twinkles Honka Monka.

title: Mets Get Agee to Sign For Estimated $65,000
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20  Tommie Agee agreed to terms with the New York Mets today and solved what General Manager Bob Scheffing had termed his toughest problem.

title: For Young Readers
description: This is an excellent account of the horror of Hitlerismthoroughly re searched and told with brutal detail. There is here no effort to spare the reader the grisly facts of Germany's surrender to racist insanity, no turn ing away from the realities of terror and torture and pogrom and geno cide.

title: At the Talk Center, they talk of drugs
description: IT is 7 P.M. and the secondhand electric heater is already giving hints that it will be a cold night in the threeroom apartment. The telephone rings. Cindy Nast puts down her physics bookshe has a test the next dayand answers it. Hello, drug help line.

title: Homeowners Number Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)  About 39.9 million Ameri cans were living in homes they owned or were in the process of buying when the census was taken last year, the Census Bureau said yes terday. This represents an in crease of 7.1 million, or 22 per cent, over that for 1960, the bureau reported.

title: The Nation
description: FORT DENNING, Ga.  A hypothetical statement of facts six pages long, prepared by the defense and assumed by the prosecution and the court to be trueand four questions arising from it became the focus last week of the court martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.

title: Police Attacked as Revolt Goes On in Reggio Calabria
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy Feb. 20 (AP)Insurgents threw a flaming gasoline bottle at a police truck today as the revolt in Reggio Calabria dragged on.

title: H. Bart McHugh, 64, Dies; Active in TV Talent Field
description: H. Bart McHugh Jr., who had been active in the radio, tele vision and talent fields for 40 years, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 140 East 83d Street.

title: Dartmouth Wins 3d Williams Carnival in Row
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 20Dartmouth won the Williams Winter Carnival today for the third straight year. In recording a winning total of 387.4 points in the twoday car nival, the Big Green scored high in every event, finishing 12 in crosscountry, 2 and 4 in the slalom, 34 in the giant slalom and 56 in the jumping.

title: Photography
description: When a photojour nalist has a museum showI am think ing of W.Eugene Smithapos;s mammoth exhibition of some 500 pictures now at the Jewish Museumyou can expect program.Because it is not always true that one picture is worth a thousand words.It is true only when you want to show how some thing looks.But it is usually not true when you want to explain some thing, or place it looks.To do these things you need words.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISA certain American envoy to France, named Benjamin Franklin, used to say honesty was the best policy and this is what the French today assert with respect to their enormous arms trade with the rest of the world, a commerce described by rivals or disappointed clients as warmongering or outrageous. French arms policy may be cynical but it is not obscured by cant.

title: Miss Jacobs Engaged
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 20Mr. and Mrs. Nahman J. Jacobs have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Deena Ann Jacobs, to William J. Mack 3d, son of Mr. Mack Jr. of New Haven and Mrs. Nancy Stein bach Mack of Hamden.

title: Outlook Brightens for Shellfishing on Long Island
description: RONKONKOMA, L. I., Feb. 20Long Island's shellfishing industry, which has been on the downgrade in recent years, is expected to improve markedly soon and bring with it the pros pect of greater quantities of succulent clams, scallops and mussels.

title: Miss Jacot Captures Giant Slalom
description: KINGFIELD, Me., Feb. 20 After 17yearold Anne Marie Proell of Austria had taken the play from her for the past two days, petite Michele Jacot got back on center stage today with a sparkling victory in World Cup giant slalom event.

title: African Nations at Tunis Parley Stress Economic Cooperation
description: TUNIS, Feb. 16A majority of African nations have pledged to strengthen cooperation among themselves as a way of speeding the continent's eco nomic development.

title: The Guilt of Silence
description: In establishing a civiliandominated board to review the military's domestic intelligence activities, Defense Secretary Melvin Laird has shown some recognition the dangers involved in the Army's forays into political investigation. Nevertheless the newly created Defense Investigative Review Council still constitutes only a poor substitute for a bold order to the military to get out the business of spying on civilians.

title: Where Gnomes Guard Lovable Swiss Franc
description: ZURICHYou go to Burgundy to sniff wine and to Holland for the Van Goghs; why not go to Zurich for the money? Zurich fairly reeks of money its the financial capital of country that has made money manipula tion a national inclus:ry and a major export commodity. Even if the good people of Zurich wanted to play clown their financial preoccupations, they couldn't.French Impressionist works, an expected generous collection of modern Swiss artists, and a whole wing dedicated to Alberto Giacometti, the great contem porary sculptorpainter oflet's not for get itSwiss origin. There are examples of his early work, sketches for his sculp ture, magnificent late oil portraits.

title: UCONNS REPEAT IN YANKEE TRACK
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 20 (AP) The University of Connecti cut successfully defended its Yankee Conference track and field championship today.

description: CHICAGO.

title: Bloom Off Franchises
description: On March 3 In New Orleans a hearing will be held in Fed eral Court to determine if sev eral oil companies owned by John W. Mecom should be forced into involuntary bank ruptcy. The assets of the hard pressed Mecom empire include oil, gas, sulphur and the New Orleans Saints football team, run by his son, John Jr.

description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 20Miss Lynn Ann Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Harris, was mar ried here at home this after noon to Robert Edward Trump of Rochelle Park. The ceremony was performed by County Court Judge Harvey Smith.
