description: MILAN, Tenn., Feb. 20  Every sunrise and sunset, like a scene from the Hitchcock movie, millions of birds darken the sky over the Milan Army Ammunition Plant.

title: Catskills Nearing Offtrack Bets
description: Greene County will seek state approval tomorrow to begin operating an offtrack betting system that differs substantially from the stalled New York City entry.

title: CARTIER CAPTURES JERSEY 2MILE RUN
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 20 Vince Cartier of Scotch Plains missed a meet record by one second as he won the Group IV twomile run in the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association track and field championships at the Jersey City Armory today.

title: The World
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy For many months, neoFascists have been painting Reggio Wins! in big, black letters on house walls all over Italy. But this city now looks very much like a loser in the longest com munal rebellion this nation has seen in 50 years.

title: Increased Speed Limits Urged for Nassau Roads
description: MINEOLA, L. L, Feb. 20 The establishment of higher speed limits on most of Nas sau County's 270 miles of major roads has been recom mended in a Federal study.

title: PRESSCURBS DECREE CANCELED IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (Agence FrancePresse) Premier Tran Thien Khien has canceled a press decree he signed on Jan. 21, after an outcry by the Saigon press, official sources disclosed here.

title: Two Flying Machines That Can Make the Spirit Soar
description: MIAMIEver taken a ride on jumbo? my Boeing 747 seat mate asked with a grin, Smugly (although a bit puzzled), I started to say yes, but he interrupted me. Not this jumbo. His smile broad ened. I followed his gaze out the win dow and way down below us I could see one of the three silver sausages operated by the Goodyear Tire and Rub ber Company as part of a multimillion dollar advertising program.

title: National Notes
description: Mr. President, asked a re porter at the White. House press conference last week, would you explain why you have not found time to see these 12 black Congressmen who have been asking to see you for about year?

title: Law and Order
description: In his introduction to the paper back edition of the report of the Na tional Commission on the Causes and Prevention of violence, James Reston observed that American people are better at committing crime than read ing about it. This is understandable; until recently, if you went into a bookstore and asked for something on crime, you would be directed to the murdermystery shelf. Little else was available. But things have changed. Law and order has emerged as a political issue, and along with women's lib and ecologypaperback books on the subject abound.

title: MRS. C. D. HILLES JR.
description: Mrs. Helen Train Hilles, an au thor of book and magazine stor ies for children, died Friday in New York Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 333 East 68th Street and in Mill brook, N, Y.

title: Ecology
description: The best books on the environment are still the crisis screeds. One keeps thinking that the thing can't get much worse because surely, now the alarm is up, they will do something. The angry appraisals of our condi tion and auguries of catastrophe seem to have roused a few young people for a while and then sifted into our violencedulled public mind like so much softly falling snow.

title: Veale Signed and Fined
description: BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP)Bob Veale signed his 1971 Pittsburgh Pirate contract today and was fined $300 for what Joe Brown, Pirate general manager, called Veale's irre sponsible approach toward contract negotiations.

title: Figonero Scores by a Head In Coast Mile, Pays $3.60
description: ALBANY, Calif., Feb. 20 (UPI)Alvaro Pineda booted Argentinebred Figonero from next to last to a head victory today in the $30,000 added San Francisco Mile at Golden Gate Fields.

title: Pop
description: THE GOOD BOOK: Mel anie (Buddah BDS 95000). Is she complex or just erratic. She con tradicts herself all the time, turning from cynic to pare noiac to starryeyed senti P mentalist, each time passion ately sincere. And then, once in a while, she says some thing actually wise, and you wonder whether all this other stuff has been a puton, which it hasn't.

title: Early Date to Enrich P.G.A. Victor
description: Championship golf is ahead of its usual schedule this year. The Professional Golf ers' Association champion ship starts Thursday at Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., or roughly six months earlier than customary. Why?

title: Judy Ann Schendel Plans June Bridal
description: ALTAMONT, N.Y., Feb. 20 The Rev. and Mrs. Lyndon L. Schendel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Ann Schendel, to Charles Pedersen Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Williams of Short Hills, The wedding is planned for June 26.

title: The Nation
description: Let's see how much specula tion we can get going, Richard R. Aurelio said to one of his as sistants two weeks ago.

title: Vaudeville Has VanishedOr Has It?
description: DO you realize that en tertainment has a way of getting its own back? Entertainment is not a highly regarded com modity in our time, and a considerable effort has been made to purge drama, at least, and often even our lighter theatrical forms of the ignoble desire to please. (Musicals were once thought a lighter form; now they are frequently as sober, and sink es quickly, as Ari.) This is no longer clown country, the making of a joke is thought to be a despicable matter, vaudeville has vanished, hasn't it?

title: LEADERS OF LABOR APPEAL FOR UNITY
description: BAL HARLOUR, Fla., Feb 20 The dream of reuniting the fragmented labor movement had a strong appeal for many union leaders gathered here this week for the executive council meeting of the Ameri can Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organi zations.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE selection and instal lation of drapery hard ware is often a con fusing chore because there are a great many dif ferent sizes and styles from which to choose, and because nowadays these items are often sold in helpyourself stores with no one available to give needed advice or help ful suggestions.

title: Review 1  No Title
description: It did not seem likely. This was Mr. Segal? The David of a dozen let ters? He was too short, too heavy to be a hero. He looked like a melted cone in his summer suit. Later thought that the way he perspired was a symptom. I noticed a similar smallness in our hands when we shook. How was it possible? His body was a rented room. Often in the win ter he would write that he had the flu, and 1 imagined his eyes under their own water struggling with type scripts. I have been wondering off and on what makes your book so noisy. . .

description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 20 Sacred Heart hit on 37 of its 67 fieldgoal attempts tonight and defeated C.C.N.Y., 10377, for its 10th straight victory.

title: Mary S. Deddish to Be May Bride
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Feb. 20 Miss Mary Susan Deddish and Edward Thomas Mazilauskas Jr., son of Mr. Mazilauskas and the late Mrs. Theresa Teleisha Mazilauskas, will be married in May.

description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Foreign Notes
description: It was a most unusual pro test march. There were bail iffs in white ties, cutaway coats and heavy silver chains. There were magistrates, pros ecutors and lawyers in black robes, many with ribbons and medals. There were higher judges wearing red sashes and goldrimmed hats. Finally, there were female secretaries, more modestly dressed than most of their fashionconscious contempo raries.

title: Tuition Rise Rejected
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP)The Massachusetts Board of Higher Education has voted unani mously against a proposal to double the $200 annual tuition charged to the 44,000 students in the state's college and uni versity system. It should be the aim of the commonwealth to provide adequate financial assistance to ensure that access to higher education is open to all, the board said yesterday.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Dunning letters from Prague to Czechoslovak ref ugees abroad, demanding money to pay for their de fense at trials in absentia on charges of leaving the coun try without permission, raised a fuss in the United States, Canada and Australia last year. There were complaints that Czechoslovakia was try ing to blackmail the 70,000 Czechoslovaks who fled to the West after the Sovietled invasion in 1968.

title: Off to Ireland? Bring the Clubs, too
description: IF you take seriously what they tell you hereabouts, the Emerald Isle began as one enormous golf course catering to a clientele of prehistoric giants who are said to have inhabited the area eons ago. Strongest among these was a certain Cuchalain, a low handicap hero who used the trunk of a tree for a club and a monstrous granite boulder for a ball. He was a notoriously careless fellow, and it is said that the thousands of Irish lakes are the direct result of his unreplaced divots.

title: Reader's Report
description: The humor in this lampoon of cur counterculture is on the Mad Magazine level  not leth al, but sharp enough to inflict severe flesh wounds. If there is a cliche posture that has es caped laceration at the hands of Messrs. Wren and Shepherd, I can't imagine what it is. A groovy chaplain who calls his sermons rap sessions. An an anarchist catering service (brings together freaks and pigs on time and at the right place.). An encounter group that teaches joy by the num bers (Eight Gurus  No Wait ing!). Sex on cinma vrit.

title: News of the Rialto
description: HAVING recently resurrected the genial Will Rogers (in the shape of actor James Whitmore) and, be fore that, the poet Walt Whitman, Paul Shyro confessed the other afternoon that he expects be doing the same with the acidulous H. L. Mencken.

title: Aid Program a Boon to Shoe Company
description: The first fruit of a long battle to obtain government help for the beleaguered shoe industry, is beginning to show.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMMUNITY HELP URGED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20A state commission studying the pow ers of local governments today endorsed a proposed new ar ticle to the State Constitution that would permit the state to lend or give money to private businesses or individuals for community development pur poses.

title: Snow Puts Off 2d Round of Tucson Golf Until Today
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 20 (AP)Snow forced the post ponement of secondround play today in the already de layed Tucson open golf tourn ament and sent the 72hole event to a projected Monday windup.

title: Yale Beats Princeton, 85
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 20Yale broke open a close game with five goals in the second period tonight and defeated Princeton, 85. Greg Luck scored three goals for Yale, which is 5141 over all and 36 in the Ivy League. Princeton is 119 on the season, 09 in the league.

title: CAPE COD AREA IS HIT BY A POWER FAILURE
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)  More than half a million per sons on Cape Cod and in south eastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island lost all electrical power for up to three hours today when a major transmis sion line failed.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH, 20;
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20After losing their last three games away from Madison Square Garden, the New York Rangers found the proper locale tonight Pittsburgh's Civic Arena.

title: Shelley Scarney And Nixon Aide. Plan to Marry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Miss Shelley Scarney, recep tionist in the West Wing lobby at the White, House, plans to be married here in May to Patrick J. Buchanan, special assistant to President Nixon and one of his speech writers.

title: Music
description: THE other week I heard a very fine concert, when Joseph and Lillian Fuchs and Artur Balsam collaborated in a Tully Hall con cert. I was especially struck by Balsam's work at the piano. It was not that he took the play away from Joseph Fuchs in the F minor Sonata by Prokofiev and the E flat by Strauss. Nobody can take the play away from so powerful a vio linist as Fuchs. Rather it was that Bal sam met Fuchs on equal terms, both artists collaborating for the common good. One had expected no less. It is not for nothing that Balsam is gen erally recognized as the best (as well al the dean) of American accompanists.

title: Working Mothers Lost in Nassau DayCare Shuffle
description: INWOOD, L. I. Feb, 20  There is space in Nassau County daycare centers for the children of mothers on welfare who plan to take a job or train for one. But working mothers face long waiting lists to get their chil dren into existing centers or, in many cases, find no cen ters at all.

title: Double Delta Scores
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 (AP)Double Delta took full command in the stretch for a 12length victory in the $15,000 aded Bayou Handicap at the New Orleans Fair Grounds to day.

title: Mexico: Fighting a Giant
description: MEXICO CITY  So far from God and so close to the United States has long been the lament of Mexican offi cials striving to cope with the social and economic shadows cast by the giant of the North upon their country.

title: Friends of the enemy
description: At the Geneva Conference in 1954, the efforts of North Viet namese delegates to promote the interests of the Pathet Lao insurgents in Laos were brushed aside by the Western powers as well as the Chinese and Russians. It then seemed clear that the Pathet Lao repre sented no constituency in Laos beyond those political maver icks like Prince Souphanouvong who had been sponsored and supported by the Vietminh as part of their struggle against the French.

title: Barbara Deiss And Executive Wed in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 20 Miss Barbara Ann Deiss and William T. Schwendler Jr. were married here this morning in Holy Cross Ro man Catholic Church by the Rev. Paul E. Waldschmidt, president of the University of Portland.

title: Seeing the Sinai: Smashed Guns Dot the Vastness
description: TEL AVIVMost of the ship's pas sengers lost interest in the desert's monotonyor had tired of dancing to tambourines on the deckand turned their thoughts to the evening meal. Many had the foresight to bring aboard their own food and the deck soon became a huge picnic blanket, covered with wine bottles, loaves of crusty bread and containers of cheese, meat and fish. Whole roasted chickens were divided up and devoured, Portable gas stoves began to boil water for cups of coffee and tea.

title: Wesleyan Court Mark Falls
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 20 (AP)Joe Summa set a Wes leyan Field House record with 38 points today as the Car dinals defeated Tufts, 9787.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It's an odd thing, is'nt it, said Dave Stockton, that you find yourself rooting for Arnie Palmer in a suddendeath play off. You do it even though you know that he has everything and has won everything. But I guess it's his personality that sweeps you away.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinelawn Is a Prosperous City of the Dead
description: PINELAWN, L. I., Feb. 20 A homeowner on Wellwood Avenue sat on his living room couch and gazed out his picture window at the thousands of marble tomb stones that stretched into the horizon in perfect, dizzying rows.

title: MRS. JOHN S. SHERMAN
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 21Mrs. Edith Bishop Sherman, author of children's books and magazine articles, died Friday at her home, 453 Melrose Place. Her age was 81. She was the wife of John S. Sherman, a re tired civil engineer.

title: Plan to Outlaw Strip Mining Is Assailed by Union Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The United Mine Workers branded as so much political grandstanding Today attempts to outlaw strip mining in the coal industry.

title: The Judas Medicine
description: There is no more versatile or essential aid of modern medicine than the blood transfusions which annually save thousands of lives. But blood becomes a Judas medicine when it contains the hepatitis virus that can sicken or even kill the patient it is supposed to help. The menace has become greater recently with the spread of drug addiction since the use of unsterile needles by groups of drug addicts makes them particularly liable to hepatitis, and their blood is therefore particularly dangerous when it enters the supplies available for transfusion.

title: KREMLIN ORDERED REVISIONS IN PLAN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21A Soviet planning official said today that the Kremlin had turned down the first outline of the new five year plan because it did not provide enough of a rise in the standard of living. The plan was made public in outline last Sun day.

title: F.D.A. IS CHALLENGED ON FOOD ADDITIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) Leaders of the food industry told the Food and Drug Admin istration that they insist they have the right to add chemicals and other substances to foods without advising the Govern ment.

title: STATE PLAN TO AID ADDICTS IN PRISON DECLARED FAILING
description: A city study for Mayor Lind say, paralleled by a report by District Attorney Frank S. Ho gan, said yesterday that there had been a breakdown in a state program set up to treat drug addicts who had been convicted of crimes.

title: Koosman Riddle Batiks Hodges
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 21Not Cleon Jones's bat, not Tommie Agee's knee, not Ron. Swoboda's temper. The biggest question mark of spring train ing for the New York Mets, said Manager Gil Hodges today, is Jerry Koosman's arm  and Hodges has no idea how effec tive it will be.

title: COMMUTER TRAINS ARE DEFINED BY I.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Interstate Commerce Commis sion has established a defini tion of commuter service that makes it unlikely that com muter trains would be discon tinued as a result of the crea tion of a new national rail network run by a quasigovern mental corporation.

title: American Symphony Plays Russian Staples
description: Igor Markevitch was the American Symphony Orches tra's guest conductor yesterday afternoon in Philharmonic Hall. His nononsense program con sisted of two Russian staples: Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 and Stravinsky's Rite of Spring.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Among the more interested observers of the low com edy and high politics of New York's foundering OffTrack Betting Corporation is Carl M. Loeb Jr., who has a scheme of his own: a Federally controlled, nationwide parimutuel system that would take bets on all sporting events, major league baseball, college basketball, car racing, fencing tour naments and make taxfree payoffs. Loeb is afraid that people will use offtrack's failure as an example that the whole system can't work. With his current base the presidency of the private National Council on Crime and Delinquency, Loeb has discussed his plan with Con gressional committees, and in frequent statements, in cluding one in which he called O.T.B.'s head, Howard J. Samuels, naive.

title: Munson and Peterson Unsigned As Yankee Batterymen Report
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb: 21  Thurman Munson, firststring catcher and 1970 rookie of the year, and Fritz Peterson, the lefthanded 20 game winner, were on the brink of being classified as holdouts today as New York Yankee pitchers and catchers gathered to begin spring training tomor row morning.

title: All Pirates in Fold
description: BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP)All the Pittsburgh Pirates have signed their contracts for the 1971 season, club officials said today after the shortstop, Gene Alley, arrived In camp and agreed to terms.

title: A she and Ralston Meet Tonight For Spot in Tennis Semifinals
description: Shunning a flip of a coin, a toss of the racquet, or a 9point tiebreaker on an out door court in Queens, Dennis Ralston and Arthur Ashe will meet at Madison Square Garden tonight in a twoof threeset singles match for the final berth in the semi final round of the Tennis Champions Classic.

title: How the Two Sides Stand
description: The United Nations Security Council resolution Nov. 22, 1967, is the basis of the indirect Middle East peace talks being conducted by Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring. Its chief provisions call for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from areas occupied in the war of June, 1967 the end of the state of belligerency; the recognition, of the territorial integrity and independence of all countries in the area and their right to secure and recognized boundaries; free navigation through internationalwater ways, and a just settlement of the refugee problem.

title: Peking Gains Favor With Chinese in U.S.
description: The Communist Government in Peking is gaining greater ac ceptance and qualified approv al from significant segments of the traditionally conservative and largely apolitical Chinese community in the United States.

title: Police and Fire Unions Reach Pacts in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21Negotia tors for the policemen and fire men of this city tentatively agreed tonight to a fouryear contract providing for salary increases of $1,490 plus costof living adjustments.

title: Tilla Durieux, Grand Old Lady of German Stage, Dead at 90
description: BERLIN, Feb. 21 (AP)Tilla Durieux, the grand old lady of the German theater, died in a hospital here today after an operation necessitated by a fall she suffered Jan. 26. She was 90 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Central Park South Seeks To Recapture Old Elegance
description: The Talk of Central Park South

title: The Quake Still Afflicts Community on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 21  Only a day after the earthquake of Feb. 9, life had returned to normal for the vast majority of people here.

title: Amin in Uganda Presidency
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)Ugan da's head of state, Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, has accepted the title of President that the army of fered him yesterday, the Ugan da radio reported today. The general overthrew President Milton Obote last month.

title: LLOYD E. JOHNSON
description: MANKATO, Min. ?? 21 (AP)  Lloyd E. ?? a former tool and die made a fortune after ?? a backlashfree 1949, died here ?? the age of 57.

title: Shrinklits Rhymes the Plot, Puts Novel to a Trot
description: The student's trotcom plexity squeezed to essentials is speeded to a gallop in a new book just out. Shrink lits (Doubleday)a collec tion of plots rendered in rhyme, fat of dialogue and development removedtakes the great works of literature for a, very quick ride.

title: SQUATTERS SEIZE UPTOWN BUILDING
description: About 200 welfare clients moved their beds, clothes, food and television sets into a new but still unoccupied 26story apartment building on the Upper West Side yesterday afternoon and declared they intended to stay forever.

title: Warning by the Vietcong
description: TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 22 (AP)The Vietcong said today, that any United States military action against North Vietnam would be matched by retalia tory attacks in South Vietnam.

title: Alabama Agency Is Under Investigation for Alleged Misuse of NoStrings Federal Anticrime Funds
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 21 Alabama, a stronghold for state rights, is being shaken by disclosures of alleged misuse of Federal anticrime funds entrust ed to a state agency, with few strings attached.

title: MISS DOROTHY BUNKER
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 21 Miss Dorothy Bunker of 44 Beveily Road, a teacher in New York for 39 years, died yester day at her home. She was 73 years old.

title: Hogan Recommends 57 Court Reforms
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan called yesterday for unified action by the police, the courts, correction officials, awyers and legislators to cut delays in the administration of criminal justice in the city.

title: WHITE, MISS JONES TRIUMPH IN TRACK
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21 (UPI) Tom White, a hurdler, and Katheryn Jones, a sprinter, registered victories for the traveling Amatenr Athletic Union track team today in an indoor meet at Luzhniki Sports Palace.

title: Soviet Pianist Excels in Varied Program
description: Grigory Sokolov, at 21, is one of those rare performers who play the piano so easily and with such seeming naturalness that they seem to have some special relation to, or with, the instrument that is denied most people.

title: JUSTICE AIDE BACKS WIRETAPPING RIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst defended today the Nixon Administra tion's contention that it has an inherent Presidential right to wiretap dissident domestic groups.

title: Faban Is Jersey Victor
description: THREE BRIDGES, N.J., Feb. 21Faban wan two of the four classes to capture the junior working hunter championship today at the Hunt Cap Farms horse show with 14 points. The winner is owned by Carmen Paterniti and was ridden by Annie Glaser.

title: Boy, 8, Falls 15 Floors to Death at Welfare Hotel
description: An 8yearold boy plunged 15 stories to his death last night down an elevator shaft at the Kimberly Hotela hotel at 74th Street and Broadway that houses welfare recipients.

title: Advertising:
description: The advertising agencies of the nation increased their worldwide billings 2.6 per cent in 1970, Advertising Age, the respected weekly journal of marketing and ad vertising, will report today.

title: P.S.C. IS STUDYING PHONE PROBLEMS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 21Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the state's Public Service Commission, an nounced today that his staff had been analyzing the New York Telephone Company's records on service to pinpoint weak points in that utility's operations.

title: Japanese Set Auto Goal
description: TOKYO, Feb. 21 (Reuters) The Japanese automotive in dustry has adopted an export target for 1971 of 1.35 million vehicles, up 17.4 per cent from last year's level, the industry's association said this weekend. In 1970, the association said, the United States took 46 per cent of all the cars exported from Japan.

title: BOND MEN DOUBT STORM IS ENDED
Swedish Lifter Sets Mark
description: BOLLNAIS, Sweden, Feb. 21 (AP)  Hans Bettembourg, a Swedish middleweight weight lifter, set a world record in the press today by hoisting 412 pounds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Newsman Found Dead In Cambodia, Saigon Says
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 22 (UPI)South. Vietnamese soldiers have found the body of a French freelance journalist, Francis Bailly, about. 10 miles southeast of the Cam bodian provincial capital of Kompong Chain, a military spokesman said today. He gave no details of the cause of death or exactly when it might have occurred.

title: Bing Scores 54, a Club Mark, But Bulls Top Pistons, 125112
description: DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP)The Chicago Bulls, despite Dave Bing's 54, points, downed the Detroit Pistons, 125112, today for their fifth straight victory in the National Basketball As sociation. It also was their 12th triumph in their last 15 games.

title: Shikler Discusses Painting the Kennedys
description: Aaron Shikler, the artist who painted the recently un veiled official White House portraits of President and Mrs. Kennedy, has become the latest family associate to share his intimate observa tions with the public.

title: Niagara Scores, 7659; Snaps Bonnie' Skein
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 21 (UPI) Marshall Wingate scored 23 points to lead Niagara to a 7659 victory over St. Bona venture, today as the Purple Eagles stopped the Bon nies' Little Three Conference streak at 22 games. Wingate made two steals and sank three short Jumpers to spark a 195 Niagara surge that moved the Eagles from a 3534 deficit to a 5339 lead with 6:20 left in the game. It was also Niagara that, 10 years ago this week, ended St. Bonavanture's 99game victory streak on its home court in Olean.

title: PAKISTANI CABINET DISSOLVED BY YAHYA
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 21 The President of Pakistan, Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, today announced the dis solution of his 10member Cab inet, effective tomorrow.

title: A Counterweight to A.C.L.U. Thrives
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21  Backed by the endorsement of Attorney General John N. Mitchell, a legal foundation formed to file friendofcourt briefs on the Iaw enforce ment side of court cases is beginning to prosper.

title: Kimberly Duo Triumphs
description: DARIEN, Conn., Feb. 21 Oliver Kimberly of New Canaan and Mrs. Allan Hannas of Sum mit, N. J. won the national mixed doubles platform tennis championship today. They de feated David ?? and Mrs. Rona?? both of Ru??

title: U.S. Drops Plan to Build Road in Kilmer Forest
description: The Federal Government has abandoned a longdisputed plan to build a highway through the country's sole national me morial forest, the Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest in the south western tip of North Carolina.

title: Fire Hits Boston U. Complex
description: BOSTON, Feb. 21 (AP)  A twoalarm fire of suspicious origin caused heavy damage to a complex of buildings at Bos ton University's School of So cial Work early this morning, fire officials said. A fireman sustained a leg injury while battling the blaze, which fire officials said was suspected to have been the work of an ar sonist.

title: 3 WHITES GUILTY IN CAROLINA RIOT
description: DARLINGTON, S.C. Feb. 21 (AP)An allwhite jury con victed three Darlington County white men today of rioting when school buses carrying Negro pupils pulled onto the grounds of newly desegregated Lamar public schools last March 3.

title: Leguia and Freeman Join For Dynamic Recital
description: Luis Leguia, cellist, and Rob ert Freeman, pianist, a pair of expert and thoughtful musicians from Boston, appeared at Town Hall late Saturday afternoon to play Beethoven's Sonata in A (Op. 69) and Elliott Carter's So nata (both for cello and piano), Cockily's Sonata for Unaccom panied Cello and Schubert's Pi ano Sonata in A minor (D. 536).

title: Elizabeth Hines Warton Dies; Musical Comedy Star of 20's
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Feb. 21 Elizabeth Hines Warton, a musical comedy star, of the nineteentwenties for George M. Cohan and Florenz Zieg feld, died Friday at her home here. She was 76 years old.

title: Smaller Cars Are Getting Bigger Share of Market
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20More than half of America's new car buyers are taking smaller cars, at least smaller than the full size models that dominated the highways until recently.

title: M'GOVERN ASSAILS NIXON WAR POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today that the North Viet Vietnamese troops in South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos more nearly represented the nationalistic aspirations of the Indochinese people than did American forces in Southeast Asia.

title: LEE GARRETT DIES; EDITOR IN CAPITAL
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 21 (AP)Lee Garrett, an editor in the Washington bureau of. The Associated Press for 20 years, died today of cancer at his home here. He was 59 years old.

title: Bacallao Duo on Top
description: SEABRIGHT, N. J., Feb. 21 Dr. Pedro Bacallao of the Princeton Club and Bailey Brown of the Bronxville Field Club won the 20th annual Sea bright invitation squash rac quets doubles tournament today by defeating Terry Fox and Dennis Lynch of the host club, 115, 1511, 815, 158, 1511.

title: McRae Takes Tasman Race
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 21 (UPI)Graham McRae of New Zealand won the sixth race of the Tasman inter national championships today in a McLaren M10B. Teddy Pil lete of Belgium and Australia's Frank Matich were second and third.

title: Ruth Jessen, on Return From Surgery, Takes $60,000 Golf by Two Strokes
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP)Ruth Jessen, fighting back from cancer and five major operations, today won the $60,000 Sears Women's World Classic, the Ladies Pro fessional Golf Association's richest tournament.

title: QUOTAS IMPOSED ON STEEL ORDERS
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21Steel mills were allocating tonnage last week.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
MISS M DOWNS MRS. KING AGAIN
description: LIGHTHOUSE POINT, Fla., Feb. 21 (UPI)Francoise Durr, the Parisian queen of the clay courts, stunned Mrs. Billie Jean. King for the second straight week today to win the final of a women's professional tennis tournament.

title: EAST GERMAN. GIRL WINS SKATE TITLE
description: INZELL, Germany, Feb. 21 (AP)  Ruth Schleiermacher of East Germtiny won the wom en's world ice skating sprint championship today with a world record 175.73 points. She edged Anne Henning of North brook, Ill., who shattered her dayold world mark in the 500 meter event.

title: Housing Plan Is Approved by Jerusalem Council
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21Jeru salem's Municipal Council to night approved the national Government's plans for exten sive new housing projects that critics fear will disfigure the scenic hills around the city and complicate negotiations for an ArabIsraeli peace settlement.

title: Squires Top Cougars, 124119
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 21 (AP) The American Basketball As sociation's East Divisionlead ing Virginia Squires wentahead to stay in the third quarter today and beat the Carolina Cougars, 124119.

title: Personal Finance
description: It doesn't seem possible, but the big vacation season of 1971 is practically here. Have you begun planning for it?

title: Saigon's Rangers Driven From an Outpost in Laos
description: PHULOC COMMAND POST, South Vietnam, Feb. 21  A battalion of South Vietnamese rangers was driven from a Lao tian mountaintop six miles northwest of here last night after North Vietnamese soldiers overran their position.

title: Graebner Beats Richey in 6Set U.S.Indoor Tennis Final
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 21 Clark Graebner won a tennis match today that made a grown man cryCliff Richey.

title: Construction Unions Hedge on Taking Part in a Federal WagePrice Review Program
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 21 Leaders of the building trades unions, who met here yester day with Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson, reportedly have not yet agreed to serve on a wage and price review board if one is set up in the construction industry.

title: M'LERNON TRIUMPHS IN TUXEDO RACQUETS
description: TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 21David McLernon of Mon treal, the Canadian racquets champion, won the 69th An nual Tuxedo. Gold Racquets tournament today in the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club, defeating Jesse Sammis of New York, 152, 153, 156.

title: Welfare's Outrage
description: This nation's hodgepodge system of welfare, varying widely in bene fits from state to state while gener ally undermining family stability and perpetuating poverty, is just about everything that President Nixon and other critics have said about it. As the President charged in his State of the Union Message, it is a mon strous, consuming outrage.

title: New President Is Chosen For JerseyCentral Line
description: NEWARK, Feb. 21 (UPI) A new president of the bank rupt Central Railroad of New Jersey has been named, Robert T. Timpany, railroad trustee, announced over the weekend.

title: Bridge:
description: In a cardplaying career spanning more than six dec ades, Jay Feigus of New York has won many honors. At the national level he won the Vanderbilt Cup in 1948, and he was second in the Spin gold Cup in 1942. In New York he has twice been run nerup in the Reisinger Knock out Team Championship.

title: Wharton Seminar Challenges Popular Investment Gauges
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 It was a diverse group that had gathered at the Univer sity of Pennsylvania's Whar ton School of Finance and Commerce and Prof. Irwin Friend, the diminutive major domo of the proceedings, was frankly a bit skeptical that the 40 people he had as sembled would produce a profitable result.

title: CELTICS ARE BEATEN. BY LAKERS, 124116
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21 (AP) Jerry West's 34 points and Wilt Chamberlain's 25 led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 124116 National Basketball Association triumph over the Boston Celtics tonight. It was the Lakers' ninth triumph in their last 12 games.

title: Season's First Figaro Finds City Opera Cast in Fine Form
description: Every opera production needs to be run through the wash now and then, and there is no better time than the first per formance of a season for clean ing off whatever smudges have accumulated. Since routine is the arsenic of the performing, arts, it is a wise opera im presario who keeps his com pany off balance just enough to keep it alert.

title: Gaston, Unsigned, in Uniform
description: YUMA, Ariz., Feb. 21 (UN) The San Diego Padres opened spring training today with their top hitter, Clarence. Gaston, in uniform but not signed.

title: Campaign Finance Bill Sets No Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The campaign finance legislation that Republicans are preparing to introduce this week sets no limits ?? amount candidates may ?? to get themselves elect ??

title: Mother With 2 Girls In IND Death Leap; One Child Survives
description: A woman holding two little girls by the hand jumped in front of subway train at a Harlem IND station yesterday; the woman and one child were killed and the other child was seriously injured.

title: Text of Communique
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 (AP) Following is the text of the Israeli communiqu:

title: RACING ON SUNDAY IS DELAWARE HIT
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 21 (AP) Sunday racing made its debut in. Delaware today. More than 8,000 fans turned out at Dover Downs and wagered a record $573,856 through the parimu tuel machines.

title: Chess:
description: It is a rare occasion when a former world chess cham pion is on the losing side of a brilliancy prize. This hap pened in the 1970 Vinkovci, Yugoslavia, international tour nament, where young R. Maric of Yugoslavia, as White in a Pirc Defense, defeated Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union after 26 moves.

title: Johanna Drooz Wed to Alan Yoffie
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 21  Miss Johanna Davis Drooz, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Herbert Emanuel Drooz, was married here this morning to Alan Steven Yof fie. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs William Yoffie of Wor cester, Mass.

title: DE VICENZO CARDS 63, TAKES PANAMA GOLF
description: PANAMA CITY, Feb. 21 (AP) Roberto de Vicenzo of Argen tina won the Panama open to day with a nineunderpar 63 oh the final round.

title: VENEZUELA GIVEN A TRADE WARNING
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 21The recent surge of eco nomic nationalism here has evoked a subtle warning from Washington that further re strictions on United States in vestors in Venezuela could cause trade reprisals.

title: Rutgers Six Captures Title
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J. Feb. 22. Rutgers (Wonted Lehigh, 54, tonight in overtime to win the MidAtlantic Hockey League championship. Terry Sortwell scored at 3 minutes 50 seconds of the overtime to break a 44 deadlock. Rutgers record is now 10 victories and six ?? The game was played ?? South Mountain Arena.

title: Miss Devlin, on Coast, Assails Jail Treatment of Miss Davis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21 (UPI)  Bernadette Devlin of Northern Ireland, the youngest member of the British Parlia ment, called the solitary con finement of Angela Davis in the Marin County Jail scandal ous today and said they were both participating in the same class struggle.

title: Blues Triumph, 3I
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 21 (UPI) Frank St. Marseille scored two powerplay goals tonight and Craig Cameron added a goal while St. Louis was shorthanded as the Blues beat the Buffalo Sabres, 31.

title: Amy Goodman's Hunter Wins
description: WESTON, Conn., Feb. 21 Amy Goodman's Without Warn ing captured the regular work ing hunter championship at the Nimrod Farm's horse show to day after a hackoff with Debee Porter's Strictly Business. Each horse had one blue ribbon for 5 points.

title: Bellevue Inmate's Death Investigated
description: The death of an inmate in the Bellevue Hospital psychi atric ward yesterday, apparently of an overdose of heroin, touched off an investigation of hospital employes.

title: Munich: The Decline of Cinematic Art
description: Arts Abroad

title: ABRAHAM GREENBERG
description: CLIFTON, N. J., Feb. 21 Abraham B. Greenberg, a public accountant who retired as a cost analyst for the New York Post Office in 1966, died today at the Daughters of Miriam Home. His age was 71.

title: A New Breed of Arkansas Lawmaker Evokes Pride and Regret
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19It has been two years since a member of the Arkansas legislature last in vited another to step outside to settle a personal dispute.

title: FRANK ROBINSON ASKS 2YEAR PACT
description: MIAMI, Feb. 21 (AP)Balti more's 35yearold superstar, Frank Robinson, is seeking an increase in his 1970 baseball incomeestimated at $125,000 and has asked the Orioles for a twoyear contract.

title: Cowardly Lion, Broadway Joe Victors at Florida Horse Show
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 21The Cowardly Lion, owned by Mrs, Sally Sexton and rid den by Rod Jenkins, finished fourth in the stake today, but it didn't mean a thing because he had already won the regu lar working hunter champion ship at the Central Florida hunter and jumper horse show.

title: Frank Martori, Pianist, Returns After 11 Years
description: Carnegie Recital Hall was filled to capacity Saturday night for a piano concert by Frank Martori, his first here in nearly 11 years. Mr. Martori, who was born in New York, made his Town Hall debut in 1953. He is chairman of the Music De partment at the Brearly School here.

title: Douglass and J. C. Snead Pace Tucson Golf by a Stroke at 137
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 21 (AP) Dale Douglass caught the fal tering leaders with a four underpar 68 today and moved into a firstplace tie after two rounds in the weatherplagued, $110,000 Tucson open golf tournament.

title: St. Peter's Bowlers Win
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 21 Ed Tarrant and Jim Tracy of St. Peter's won the Eastern In tercollegiate Bowling Confer ence doubles championship to day. They had a score of 2,465 for 12 games.

title: Pacers Subdue Floridians
description: TAMPA, Fla. Feb. 21 (AP) Behind the sharpshooting of Freddie Lewis, the Indiana Pacers surged in the last 2 minutes for a 121107 Ameri can Basketball Association vic tory over the Floridians.

title: White House Puts Aside a Plan To Shift a Mine Bureau Power
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Nixon Administration has set aside a proposal to take safety enforcement powers away from the Bureau of Mines, which is part of the Interior Department, and place them in the Labor De partment, officials said yester day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Quebec Curlers Win
description: MT. HOPE, N. Y., Feb. 21 The Bale D'Urfe (Quebec) Curling Club rink won the BarnesFiske Trophy today by defeating the Philadelphia rink, 124, in the final of the St. Andrew's international mixed bonspiel.

title: ISRAEL SAYS U.A.R. HAS CLEARED WAY FOR SERIOUS TALK
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21The Israeli Government said today that the way had been opened for meaningful negotiations with the United Arab Republic, following Cairo's declaration last week that it was ready to reach a peace agreement with Israel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Experiments Worth Saving
description: Two unorthodox but promising educational ventures the New York Urban League's Street Academies and, the independent Harlem Preparatory Schoolare in seri ous difficulty. Both projects aim at salvaging disad vantaged youngsters who have dropped out of school and are on the brink of dropping out of society. After an encouraging beginning, the two experiments now face the loss of much of their financial support from industry and foundations.

title: 200 Soviet Jews Plead Again For Right of Free Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 21  Two hundred Soviet Jews have made a new appeal to the au thorities to recognize the right of Jews to emigrate freely to Israel whether or not they have relatives there.

title: Books of The Times
description: REVOLUTION AS THEATRE. Notes on the New Radical Style. By Robert Brustein. 170 pages. Liveright. $5.95.

title: BRITISH WORKERS MARCH IN PROTEST
description: LONDON, Feb. 21  Thou sands of British workers carry ing banners and singing We Shall Not Be Moved, marched in central London today in a demonstration against the Con servative Government's labor policies.

title: MRS. HARRY M. ENGEL
description: Mrs. Violet Polstein Engel who formerly operated high fashion dress shops here, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospi tal. She was 82 years old and lived at 151 West 86th Street.

title: Advertising:
description: Army Recruiting, is not going to take the chance of loosing any impulse buyers during its coming saturation 10.6million, 13week broad cast advertising campaign.

title: Arab Recognition of Israel Called for by Senator Scott
description: Senator Hugh Scott, Republi can floor leaders, said last night that the United States must not be satisfied with peace nego tiations in the Middle East un less the Arab states recognized Israel and obligate themselves to achieve a lasting peace.

title: Improving U.S.Soviet Relations
description: Rapid action by Washington on two fronts might usefully influence Russia's foreign and defense poli cies and its priorities for the 1970's.

title: PETER NERO RESCUES POPCLASSICAL BILL
description: Another attempt to multi mediate pop and classical music was collapsing of its own selfconsciousness Sunday after noon at Carnegie Hall when Peter Nero strode to the rescue with an effective barrage of his glossy keyboard stylings. The occasion was the first of three concerts in a World of Music series, conducted by Stephen Simon.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT HAWKS BY 121119
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 21 (AP)  Earl Monroe's jump shot from 15 feet out with 36 seconds re maining gave the Baltimore Bullets a 121119 victor, over the Atlanta Hawks today.

title: Retailers Stem Their Inventory Shrinkage
description: For the first time in several years, retailers across the coun try have begun to stem the tide of inventories that just melt awaygoods that van ish through shoplifting, internal theft and human error.

title: SOVIET SAID TO HELP SUDAN FIGHT BLACKS
description: Time magazine says that So viet advisers are helping, the Arab Government of the Sudan fight black insurgents.

title: Elizabeth Keen, Ze'eva Cohen Create Dances for Workshop
description: Elizabeth Keen and Ze'eva Cohen, rattling against the Shackles of performing disci pline or social reality, produced two taut, lovely and economical works Saturday evening at the Dance Theater Workshop's 17th studio series. Miss Keen created Parentheses, a solo of epi sodic movement separated by pauses, and Miss Cohen, Cloud Song, a monologue of two separate modes of life.

title: TieDye Fabrics From the Reservation
description: Mrs. Alice Begay, her 18 yearold daughter, Virginia, and her 4monthold grand son, Christopher, made their first visit to New York recently. The two women head. Red Rock TieDyeing Inc., a concern based on the Navajo Indian Reservation at Gallup, N, M., Chistopher, ensconced on a bead decorated cradleboard, came along for the ride.

title: ExCon Ed Officials Blamed by Swidler For Power Crisis
description: The present tight electric power situation in New York City stems from poor planning by the Consolidated Edison Company before the oresent management took over, Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the State Public Service Commis sion, said last night.

title: McLain Losing Weight
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21 (UPI)Denny McLain has sweated off 13 pounds and is down to 207 since the start of the Washington Senators' train ing camp last Wednesday.

title: DAVID ROHN, AIDED WALL ST. JOURNAL
description: WEST ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 21David A. Rohn, who retired in 1954 as field circula tion sales manager for The Wall Street Journal, died today in Hackensack Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 391 Warwick Avenue.

title: Earthquake Rocks Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20 (AP)  A strong earthquake shook the northern part of Chile this morning, the Govern ment's central telegraph office reported, adding that it had no word of casualties or damage. The earthquake apparently was centered in Atacama Province about 450 miles north of San tiago.

title: DARTMOUTH'S BERRY TAKES HARRIS JUMP

title: The False Emergency
description: The major blunder last weekend by the National Emer gency Warning Center raises questions about the relia bility of the entire system of complex and expensive arrangements built up these past decades to protect the national security. The center's explanation is that human error caused unauthorized declaration of national emergency. Could similar human errorhere or in the Soviet Unionsend American or Soviet weapons into action? Those who deny such a possibility must ex plain why the safeguards governing instantresponse weaponswhich are also subject to human errorsare more trustworthy than those which failed to prevent the false emergency announcement.

title: The Screen: An Almost Perfect 'Claire's Knee'
description: Eric Rohmer's "Claire's Knee," which opened yesterday at the 68th Street Playhouse, comes very close to being a perfect movie of its kind, something on the order of an affectionate comedy of the intellect that has no easily identifiable cinema antecedents except in other films by Mr. Rohmer, most notably "My Night at Maud's."It is the product of a literary sensibility, and it grows out of a literary tradition, but it is, first and foremost, a superlative motion picture. Like "Intolerance," "My Darling Clementine," "Rear Window" and "Le Gai Savoir"movies I mention only because it resembles them not in the least"Claire's Knee" could exist in no other form.The film is the fifth in Rohmer's projected cycle of "Six Moral Tales," each of which is designed as a variation on the theme of the man who, in love with one woman, feels drawn to another, whom he finally rejects in order to pursue the first, whom he may or may not win. Carlos Clarens, writing in Sight and Sound, has called this official schema "a snare for professional film decoders," and I agree.The joys in Rohmer's Moral Tales exist not so much in the variations he works, nor in contrasting one film with another, but in responding to the various levels of experience contained within each film. Of the three Moral Tales I've now seen, including "Maud" (the third) and "La Collectionneuse" (the fourth), which has not yet been released here, "Claire's Knee" is by far the most fascinating. It is both more easily accessible than "Maud," and more complex, less of a conventional narrative and more of an emotional experience.The setting is near Annecy in western France, not far from the Swiss border, a lovely, slightly out-of-fashion summer community that faces the overwhelming Alps across the Lake of Annecy. The time of the film is most exact: it opens on Monday, the 29th of June, and closes on Wednesday, the 29th of July. Among other things, the movie is all about the disciplines by which civilized man maintains his sanity, including the concept of time.Jerome (Jean-Claude Brialy), a diplomat in his thirties, engaged to Lucinda whom he will join in Stockholm shortly, has come to Annecy to sell the villa where he spent his vacations as a boy. There by chance he meets an old friend, Aurora (Aurora Cornu), a beautiful, wise, amused novelist, with whom he's always been somewhat in love, and the two teen-age daughters, Laura (Beatrice Romand) and Claire (Laurence De Monaghan) of the family Aurora is staying with.Both Aurora and Jerome are, as they say, "in transit"their real lives are elsewhere. Out of curiosity, and to amuse Aurora, who says she needs inspiration for a story, Jerome allows himself to become drawn to 16-year-old Laura, who, according to Aurora, is in love with him. Suddenly, however, he finds himself full of desire for the somewhat older Claire, specifically for her right knee, that "magnet" of his desire that, in another woman, might be located in the nape of the neck, the waist or the hands.If "Claire's Knee" can be said to have a story, it would relate, I suppose, to how Jerome succeeds, for one brief moment, in possessing Claire's knee. Through plot permutations I need not go into, Jerome's gesture of desire is accepted as one of consolation."Claire's Knee" unfolds like an elegant fairy tale in a series of enchanted and enchanting encounters, on the lake, in gardens heavy with blossoms, in interiors that look like Vermeers. Everything in this world has sharply defined edges, like the lake, which is not bordered by beach but by a manmade quay.Jerome, Aurora and Laura live according to sharply defined rules of behavior. Although they may seem romantic in that their conversation is mostly of love and friendship, this is, of course, a human activity of the most refined sort. When they explore their own emotions, test their feelings and exercise aspects of their will, it is a sport for esthetes. For them, in spite of all their talk about being bored with love and suffocated by beauty, each polite meeting becomes as fraught with suspense and danger as a confrontation of gladiators.Beneath this surface level, "Claire's Knee" is also about self-deception, about cruelty, about a certain kind of arrogance that goes with wisdom, and very much about sex. It is no accident that the beautiful, lean, comparatively stupid Claire, for whom Jerome conceives his "pure desire," is the only person in the movie enjoying, at the moment, a completely satisfactory, uninhibited sex life.The film is as physically lovely as any I've seen in years, and the performances are of such variety and wit that they should remove forever the notion that Rohmer, with his literary sensibility, is not essentially a filmmaker. Everyone is fine, but I have special feeling for Miss Romand, who grows up in such mysterious and wonderful ways in front of the camera, and for Miss Cornu, a novelist and poet in real life, who comes close to being a total woman."Claire's Knee" is a difficult film to do justice to without over-selling it. It is so funny and so moving, so immaculately realized, that almost any ordinary attempt to describe it must, I think, in some way diminish it.

title: End of the Line
description: As the New York Telephone Company seeks a 29 per cent rate increase, an episode in the life of a Manhattan telephone user maypardon the expressionnot be out of order. After finding a number unresponsive for several hours, alternately producing no ring and the busy signal, the caller enlisted an operator's aid. Having confirmed the customer's difficulties, she volunteered to call the Verifying Office. It failed to answer. Later in the day, another operator did manage to establish connection with Verifying, only to be told: Sorry, my equipment out of order. Asked what might be done about it, the caller was told: Just keep trying.
