description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Feb. 22 (AP)Jody LaPlante of West Layden, N.Y., is the over all champion of the first Snow mobile Grand Prix on Watkins Glen's autoracing course. La Plante won three events to take the title.

title: Senators Hear General Got $1,000 a Month From PX Supplier
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The friendship of an Army general cost Vietnam's leading post ex change profiteer at least $1,000 a month, Senate investigators weretold today.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that the follow ing servicemen from the New York area had been killed in the War in Southeast Asia:

title: McGovern Forms Youth Unit To Support His Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) Senator George S. McGovern formed a nationwide youth or ganization today to pump en ergy into his Democratic Presi dential campaign.

title: Put That in Your Pipeline
description: Secretary of the Interior Morton's testimony to Con gress on the proposed Alaskan pipeline comes as a great relief to all who feel that the time has long passed for Government to connive in oil rushes, gold rushes and similar elevations of quick profit above respect for the land. The Secretary's flat statement that any decision on the pipeline is months away has all but extinguished the expectation of the oil companies that construction can be started this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recent Times articles suggesting re duced ties between Bonn and West Berlin indicate that the consequences of Chancellor Willy Brandt's Eastern policy now must be reckoned with. Since the beginning of BrandtSoviet discussions last year, the Western public has been assured that Moscow would bring East Germany to heel, that the Kremlin's eagerness for better relations with Bonn would compel Walter Ulbricht to yield unaccustomed concessions on West Berlin.

title: New City U. Program of Study To Start Next Fall Is Approved
description: The city's Board of Higher Education approved a plan last night to allow students at the City University to substitute parttime employment, volun tary service in local or national projects such as the Peace Corps, travel, or other activi ties for part of their school work.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Give Awards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will present awards to the winners of the national cleanup contest at ceremonies tomorrow, the White House announced today.

title: Further Heavy Assaults Expected in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 American officials expect fur ther heavy assaults by North Vietnamese forces against South Vietnamese troops in southern Laos.

title: Kahane, at Trial, Says Police Blocked Access to Synagogue
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane testified at his own trial on charges of obstructing governmental ad ministration yesterday that he attempted to cross a police barricade only after he was denied access to a synagogue across the street from the So viet Mission to the United Na tions.

title: Albert Pledges House Support For U.S. Consumer Agency Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Speaker Carl Albert pledged today an allout drive for House passage of legislation to create an independent Federal agency with broad. powers to advocate and protect consum er interests.

title: KENNEDY DEBATES WITH RICHARDSON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 Two of the main Republican and Democratic spokesmen on health affairs debated today the private approach vs. the public approach to national health in surance. They traded compli ments as well as philosophical jabs.

title: DOUBLE BASS SHOWS VIRTUES OF WOLFE
description: Sensitive, serious musician ship and apt stylistic sense are welcome attributes in a young musician. Lawrence Wolfe, who played at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night, has these virtues in abundance.

title: U.S. ACTOR INDICTED IN ITALIAN DRUG CASE
description: ROME, Feb. 22An Ameri can actor, William Berger, who has been detained in Italy for more than six months, was in dicted on narcotic charges to clay and is expected to be tried next month.

title: Columbia to Raise Its Tuition by $300 For Most Schools
description: Tuition at Columbia Univer sity will be increased again next September by about $300 in most of its schools, includ ing Columbia College, where tuition will become $2,800.

title: Hungary, in Move to Build Public Interest, Plans to Strengthen Local Councils
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 19A dose, of grassroots politics is to be administered to Hungarians this spring, a first cautious re versal of a centuriesold auto cratic tradition strengthened by the last 25 years of central Communist rule.

title: Tennessee Beats L.S.U.
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 22 (UPI)Mike Edwards scored 25 points tonight to lead Ten nessee to an 8867 victory over Louisiana State University in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: NORTON LIFTS PRICES FOR GRINDING ITEMS
description: Price increases ranging from 5 per cent to 10 per cent were announced yesterday in Wor cester, Mass., by the Norton Company on its line of grind ingwheel accessories  grind ing fluids, tool items and simi lar materials and equipment.

title: A Town's Luck Ends as Tornado Hits
description: INVERNESS, Miss., Feb. 22  This quiet cotton town in the middle of the Mississippi Delta finally drew the un lucky number.

title: E.E.C. Policies Scored
description: PARIS, Feb. 22Walter B. Wriston, chairman of the First National City Bank, said today that anachronistic attitudes on the part of Europeans troubled transAtlantic trade relationships and clouded mon etary affairs.

title: U. Mass. Downs Syracuse
description: AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 22 (UPI)Julius Erving's 36 points and 32 rebounds led the Uni versity of Massachusetts to its 20th victory of the season to night, an 8671 decision over Syracuse.

title: PRICES ON AMEX TAKE STEP BACK
Two New Men Give Rangers a Big Lift For Stretch Drive
description: Despite the recent shake ups  or is it because of them?  the Rangers have managed to stay within sight of the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League's East Division. A key addition to the New Yorkers staff may be Bruce MacGregor, who finally delivered an out standing perform ance and three assists in the Rangers victory over the Detroit Red Wings on Sunday. Just about a year ago at this time, Coach Emile Francis said; I'd never trade away youthI'd sooner trade myself than the young play ers. Since then, he has dealt the rookies Syl Apps, Tom Miller and Mike Robitaillc and others.

title: Newark Housing Authority Rejects H.U.D. Charge That Its Staff Is Too Big and Wasteful
description: NEWARK, Feb. 22The Newark Housing Authority, fac ing possible loss of Federal funds because of charges that its staff is too big and too wasteful, said today that all its increases in staff had been at the direct order of the Federal Housing Administration.

title: More Hair Now More Acceptable, but There Is a Cutoff Point
description: Henry J. Stern to see what it would look like, grew a beard during his sum mer vacation.

title: Indians Riot Over Election
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 22 (AP)Hindus battled Moslems today in the Hindu holy city of Allahabad, where the Prime Minister, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, was born, on the eve of an elec tioncampaign visit by her.

title: Dealers Seek to Reduce Large Inventories of Unsold Securities
GALLEY, ON STAND, TELLS OP HATRED
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 22First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr., accused of killing 102 men, women and children dur ing the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, took the witness stand today and said that he had been indoctrinated by the Army to treat all Vietnamese, includ ing children, as potential ene mies.

title: Wings Give Injured Howe Week Off for Florida Rest
description: DETROIT, Feb. 22 (UPI)Gordie Howe of the Detroit Red Wings will be given time off to recuperate from a wrist injury aggravated in Saturday's game with the Buffalo Sabres, the National Hockey League club announced today.

title: MRS. CYRUS CLARK
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 22 Mrs. Jane Quintard Clark, the wife of Cyrus Clark, presi dent and owner of Cyrus Clark, president and owner of Cyrus Clark, Inc., textile manu facturing concern, died today after a heart attack at her home. She was 72 years old and lived at 419 East Shore Road, Kings Point.

title: Home Loan Board Sets Liquidity Rise For Savings Units
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today an increase in liquidity requirements for sav ings and loan associations.

title: Bess Myergon Grant Loses Bid for Temporary Alimony
description: Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Commissioner of Con sumer Affairs, yesterday was denied temporary alimony of $3,500 a month and exclusive possession of a cooperative apartment at 25 Sutton Place, pending court disposition of her marital dispute with her es tranged husband, Arnold M. Grant, a lawyer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have for a long while been listen ing to people classified as doves and hawks. I have yet to find anyone, re gardless of what he is called, who does not have the same desirethe end of the war.

title: Beecham, Ltd., Plans Acquisition Offer For Massengill Co.
description: The Beecham Group, Ltd., of London announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the controlling sharehold ers of the S. E. Massengill Company, Bristol, Tenn., to make a cash offer to purchase all the outstanding shares of Massengill.

title: Belgium Rejects Soviet Protest on Rally
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 22Belgium today rejected, a Soviet protest against the conference opening here tomorrow on the condition of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: JOSEPH ABRAMSON
description: Joseph Abramson, an assist ant vice president and assistant secretary of Bache & Co., the nation's second largest broker age house, died yesterday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 38 Brookfield Gardens, Bloomfield, N. J.

title: J. C: Snead Cards 66 for 273 and Beats Douglass by Stroke in Tucson Open
AIMS IN CONGRESS SET BY DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Senate Democratic Policy Committee adopted today a broad statement of objectives for the 92d Congress, including withdrawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of 1972.

title: How to Treat Addicts
description: Over the weekend, the state's system for treating heroin ad dicts came in for renewed criti cism. This time, the critics were the Criminal Justice Coordinat ing Council, which prepared report for Mayor Lindsay, and Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. In separate statements, both voiced concern that drug addicts were spending long periods in jail rather than in a facility that might rehabilitate them and that the court system was burdened with sick people whose antisocial activitieses pecially stealingwere at least a partial result of their sickness. Most heroin addicts cannot hold steady jobs and do not have the money to support their habits.

title: U.S.Troops in Vietnam Fewest Since Fall of '66
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI)The number of United States fighting men in South Vietnam has de clined to the lowest point since the fall of 1966, the United States command said today.

title: 2 Die in Coast Plane Crash
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 22 (UPI)Paul J. Sigler, 45 years old, a copy editor for The San Diego Union, and Donald K. Litzen berger, a former news editor of radio station KSDO, were found dead yesterday in the wreckage of a rented light plane on the south slope of San Miguel Mountain, 18 miles east of here. They had been flying from San Diego to Phoenix, Ariz.

title: 2 Cross Atlantic in Sailboat
description: NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 22 (Reuters)Robert Munroe, 81 years old, and Ian Campbell, 69, who set out to sail across the Atlantic from Scotland in Au gust, have reached the Ba hamas.

title: Books of The Times
description: Revolutions are not made, Wendell Phillips remarked. They come. In John Speicher's bitter, corrosive and despairing novel you can watch one come. You can see its sproutings in the anarchic, festering life in the ghetto of New York's East Vil lage, where the filth, the violence and jun gle existence are barely contained by the police from spill ing over into more genteel surround ings. You can see those sproutings in greener form in the smug, fastidi ous and fearful ex istence in the sub urbs, where each man is trying to build up a small enclave against disaster. Speicher uses the aftermath of a Yale victory in the Bowl as a metaphor to illus trate the lofty so cial and financial strivings of these passionate and professional Yale alumni and the vulgar and flimsy values on which they are based. It is a passage crudely written and broadly done, but nothing near the crudity and vulgarity of the people he is writing about.

title: S. I. SCHOOL CLOSED BY STUDENT FIGHT
description: Fights between black and white students, which broke out after a black liberation flag was displayed in the school cafeteria, forced the early closing yesterday of ra cially tense Port Richmond High School on Staten Island.

title: BOSTON U. SEXTET TAKES FINAL, 41
description: BOSTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)Font. Boston Univeraity Players scored tonight in :a 41 victory over Harvard in the Beanpot tonrnarnent final.

title: Lancaster Turns Down Sparring Role
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22Burt Lancaster, who hasn't been a boxer since his motion picture role in The Killers during the forties, had been advertised as the sparring oppo nent for Joe Frazier today, but the 57yearold actor stood safely outside the ropes.

title: State's Jobless Rate Increases to 5.6%, Highest in 5 Years
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22 (AP)The state's unemployment rate soared to 5.6 per cent last monththe highest level in five years, the State Labor De partment reported today.

title: Storms Hit Midwest
description: As the area ripped by Sun day's tornadoes struggled to estimate the toll in lives and property damage yesterday, the eastern half of the nation was whipped by a latewinter storm that flung heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain across the midcontinent.

title: HAROLD T. LARSEN
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Feb. 22 Harold T. Larsen, retired edi tor and manager of technical publications for the American Society of Civil Engineers, died Saturday at Meadow Lakes Village, a retirement commu nity. He was 74 years old.

title: Bans on Women Noted Despite Antibias Law
description: The chairman of the city's Commission on Human Rights expressed surprise yester day at continuing complaints about prohibiting or discour aging women from entering bars and restaurants in de fiance of last year's law bar ring sex discrimination.

title: Bank Merger Approved
description: The proposed merger of the Bank for Savings of West chester into the Westchester County Savings Bank has been approved by the State Superin tendent of Banks, William T. Dentzer Jr., it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Advertising:
description: The Ladies Home Journal and McCall's are both an nouncing great firstquarter results.

title: Libyan Oil Talks Deferred
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 (UPI)Talks aimed at a sub stantial price increase for Med iterranean oil were postponed in Tripoli, Libya, today until tomorrow because of the late arrival of delegates, the offi cial Libyan News Agency said.

title: Birthplaces in Europe Lure Retired Americans
description: FERENTINO, Italy, Feb. 12At dawn Andrew Lisi steps onto the terrace of his new threeroom, $35amonth apart ment here overlooking the hills 40 miles south of Rome.

title: CON ED STRIKE VOTED AS OFFER IS SPURNED
description: Consolidated Edison employes voted last night to reject a new contract offer and to au thorize a strike against the utility on March 11.

title: Munitions Barge Blown Up
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 22 (AP)An ammunition barge being towed up the Mekong River to Pnompenh was blown up, another was badly dam aged and three American civil ians aboard the towing boat were wounded by enemyshells today.

title: Tight Pitch From Machine Breaks Alley's Left Hand
description: BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 22 (UPI)Gene Alley of the Pitts burgh Pirates, troubled by shoulder miseries in recent seasons, suffered a broken hand today when he was struck by a pitch thrown by a pitching machine.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Edward Skinner, Manager Of San Francisco Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 (AP)Edward K. Skinner, man ager of the San Francisco Opera for 20 years, died Saturday. He was 80 years old and had been undergoing treatment for a heart ailment.

title: U.A.R. Delegate. Sees Jarring
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 22 (Reuters)Egypt in formed Dr. Jarring today that her offer for a peace agree ment with Israel would become invalid if it were not matched by a positive Israeli response.

title: Texas Gas Transmission
description: The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation reported yesterday a. 28 per cent gain in 1970 net income on record revenues. The report placed operating revenues and sales at a new high of $426,494,000 against $388,007,000 a year earlier.

title: Pathet Lao Role Reported
description: PARIS, Feb. 22 (UPI)The Hanoi delegation to the Viet nam peace talks said in a state ment today that the troops who attacked South Vietnamese Rangers in southern Laos were Pathet Lao guerrillas and not North Vietnamese as they gen erally have been described. However, the statement did not specifically deny the presence of North Vietnamese troops in Laos.

title: 8 Nuns Hurt in Convent Fire
description: DUNMORE, Pa., Feb. 22 (UPI)A Roman Catholic con vent was destroyed by fire early today. Eight nuns and two firemen were injured. The fire destroyed the convent of Marywood College, the nation's largest Roman Catholic wom en's college.

title: Taxi Chairman
description: After years of effort, Mayor Lindsay has finally gained councilmanic approval for creation of a regula tory taxi commission charged with bringing some degree of order out of the existing chaos. As had long been foreordained, the vote for a commission was linked a substantial rise in taxi fares.

title: Jewish Appeal Will Open Campaign Here Tomorrow
description: The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York will open its 1971 campaign for $150 million at a dinner tomorrow night at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Senator Jacob K. Javits has rein troduced his bill, to curb the war making powers of the President. He thinks that the pendulum has swung too far on the side of the Executive in this allimportant matter and that it is time it were swinging beck to ward Congress. On, both of these counts the Senator is unquestionably, right.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Suppose the United States were a more dutiful child than it really is and, on the occa sion of her father's birthday every year, wrote the old gentleman to tell him how she was getting along. This year's report might go as follows:

title: Drive With Ads Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The aerospace industry and the machinists union, which stood quietly on the sidelines last year when the Senate nearly killed the supersonic transport, announced today a $350,000 advertising program to counter doubts expressed by environ mentalists and stress the SST's importance to the national economy.

title: SPACE EXPERIMENT IN ESP IS DESCRIBED
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (UPI)Oof Jonsson, the partner of Capt. Edgar D: Mitchell of the Navy in extrasensory percep tion experiments in space, said yesterday that he received clear images of experimental cards from Captain Mitchell and felt some of the emotions ex perienced by Apollo 14's astro nauts.

title: MORE PRO RAIDING ON COLLEGES SEEN
Gov. Mandel Saves Guard
description: JESSUP, Md., Feb. 22Gov. Marvin Mandel went to the Patuxent Institution here yes terday and persuaded 10 maxi mum security inmates to re lease a guard they had been holding hostage under a death threat for some two hours. The guard, Robert E. Chumley, 56 years old, was beaten about the face and head before several of the inmates carried him to a stretcher and released him with the understanding that Mr. Mandel and an Associated Press newsmen would stay and listen to their grievances.

title: Class 44: Teachers Ponder Union Attitude on Problems
description: Dorothy Boroughs led Class 44 to the cafeteria and left the children there for lunch, then carried her container of apricot yogurt to the library. Other teachers brought cot tage cheese, raw carrots, pas trami sandwiches, Danish pastry and mugs of coffee.

title: RevenueSharing Chief Murray Lew Weidenbaum
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Murray Lew Weidenbaum, the Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for. Economic Pol icy, believes that he is not the only Republican to have graduated from City College of New York. But he said today, I still haven't found the other one. The fact that Mr. Weidenbaum was born of poor Jewish parents in the Bronx, grew up in Brooklyn during the De pression surrounded by lib eral Democrats and turnec out to be a Nixon Republican indicates an independent turn of mind. This is evident even as he goes about the country beating the drums for Presi dent Nixon's revenuesharing proposal.

title: Cairo Warns That Israeli Stand Is Creating Dangerous Situation
description: CAIRO, Feb. 22The United Arab Republic warned the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France today that what it termed the Israeli re fusal to withdraw from occu pied Arab territories was creat ing a dangerous situation in the Middle East.

title: KENNETH W. ERICSON
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 21Kenneth W. Ericson, former general sales manager of the titanium pigment division of the National Lead Company of New York, died Saturday night. He was 80 years old.

title: Cast Off, Namath Hopes To Be Passing by April
description: Joe Namath had the cast removed yesterday from his right wrist, which was frac tured in the JetsColts game at Shea Stadium last Oct. 18. Namath; wintering in Fort Laudetdale and Miami, said he hoped to start throwing a football again in April.

title: Heath's Economic Strategy
description: Prime Minister Heath's decision early this month let RollsRoyce go into bankruptcy dramatized the radi cal nature of his politicoeconomic strategy in a way that months of speeches, legislative proposals and even budget revisions failed to do.

title: Advertising:
description: Warner, Bicking & Fen wick is an ad agency that is almost seven years old and is billing almost $7million. It is almost ahead of most agencies in doing what al most all of them want to dodiversify.

title: Jacksonville Wins No. 15
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 22 (AP) Jacksonville made East Carolina its 15th straight vic tim tonight, 12769, but may have lost Greg Nelson for the National Collegiate Athletic As sociation tournament.

title: Dance: Two by Nikolais
description: The coauthor of a rock musical that has earned mil lions was spotted, notebook on knee at last night's open ing of the Nikolais Dance Theater at the ANTA The ater. It has been apparent for some time that Alwin Niko lais, responsible for the chore ography, sound scores, cos tumes and lighting designs of the company he directs has something to say to the theater world in the broadest sense.

title: Ohio Teamster Fined
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 22 (AP)William Presser, 63 years old, the Ohio leader of the Interna tional Brotherhood of Team sters, was fined $12,000 today

title: KNICKS AND ROCKETS PLAY HERE TONIGHT
Heavy Fire Continues to Slow Saigon's Laos Drive
description: SAIGAN, South Vietnam, Feb. 22 (AP)With heavy enemy fire continuing, the South Viet namese drive against Commu nist supply trails and bases in southern Laos was reported stalled today for the fifth con. secutive day.

title: New Art Treasures Shown at the Morgan
description: New Treasures, which opened at the Morgan Li brary last week, is an exhibi tion of autographs, books, drawings and manuscripts ac quired during the last two years. No one can quarrel with the title. The most sur prising thing is that objects of luck quality are still to be found for purchase. Ag gressive search and a bit of handy loose change does the trick for the Morgan.

title: For Some in India, Drought Persists
description: MANDAWA, India, Feb. 18 Mullou, a small, lively man who is a farmer here in Rajasthan State, has never heard of the Green Revolution that is bring ing India closer to selfsuffi ciency in food.

title: Warning by Canterbury
description: NAIROBI, Kenya Feb. 22 (Reuters)The Archbishop of Canterbury, Arthur Michael Ramsey, said here today that there was a terrible danger of violent revolution in South Africa.

title: High Court Will Review F.P.C.'s Role on Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  The Supreme Court agreed today to examine the standards of the Federal Power Commission for establishing ju risdiction over electric utility companies.

title: Flood Takes First Swings, Makes Hit With Senators
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22Curt Flood, whose antitrust suit against baseball's reserve clause system is still pending in the Federal courts, resumed his baseball career to day as just another member of the Washington Senators.

title: SAIGON SAYS DRIVE BLOCKED INVASION OF FIVE PROVINCES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 22While reports from the battlefield indicated that South Vietnam's push into Laos was stalled for a fifth day, Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu said today that the incursion had already succeeded in deterring a North Vietnamese plan to seize the five northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.

title: We Must Talk With Moscow
description: WASHINGTONAlthough the ideo logical conflict between the Soviet Un ion and the United States is so basic that overall dtente is not possible under present circumstances, there are real opportunities now for agreement in important areas.

title: MEETINGS DISCUSS LINDSAY'S SWITCH
description: Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio has held a series of secret meetings with Democrat ic county leaders in which the Mayor's possible switch to the Democratic party was discussed in what Mr. Aurelio called gereral terms.

title: AIRPORT, PATTON' TOP OSCAR ENTRIES
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 22 (AP)Airport and Patton scored top honors in the 43d nomina tions of the Motion Picture Aca demy of Arts and Sciences today with 10 apiece. Love Story placed third with seven followed by M*A*S*H and Tora! Tora! Tora! with five each.

title: CAPITAL RISE SET FOR SPECIALISTS
description: The New York Stock. Ex change announced yesterday that it would impose a 150 per cent increase in minimum capital requirements on stock specialists next June 1 and dis closed plans for closer monitor ing of specialists performance.

title: Fire Closes Brooklyn School
description: A Brooklyn junior high school was shut down and its 1,800 students were sent home yes terday after a fire of suspicious origin badly damaged an unoc cupied fourthfloor classroom, fire officials reported. The stu dents were evacuated at 11 A.M., from Berriman Junior High, 829 Belmont Avenue, in the East New York section. Firemen had the blaze under control 15 miutes later but not before it severely damaged the classroom.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Rockefeller Says. U.S. Aid Could Wipe Out Tax Rises
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22Governor Rockefeller declared today that all or part of his request, for $1.1billion in higher taxes could be canceled if the Fed eral Government approved revenue sharing and additional welfare or education aid.

title: Reports on Cases Of Lead Poisoning Rise 300% Here
description: By testing the blood of 87, 000 slum children here, the Health Department was able to identify 2,649 victims of lead poisoning during 1970  nearly four times the number found the preceding year.

title: City Ready to Challenge Mandated Welfare Costs
description: The city announced yesterday that it would file suit tomorrow to challenge the constitutional ity of the basic Federal and state laws regulating welfare programs and costs.

title: General Denies Getting Gifts
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Feb. 22 (UPI)General Meyer, retired, denied today that he had ac cepted expensive gifts from Mr. Crum or provided Mr. Crum with favors in South Vietnam. General Meyer said, however, that he and Mr. Crum were friends and he had. visited Mr. Crum's home in Saigon many times.

title: Syrian Leader Says Only Force Will Settle Conflict in Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22Lieut. Gen Hafez alAssad, the Syrian Premier, said tonight that force of arms mild in the end determine the outcome of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Living Amid a Forest of Tiffany Lamps
description: In his East Side town house apartment, Dr. Egon Neustadt stood on the edge of what he calls his forest of Tiffany lampsa wonderland of glass and bronze, shot with irides cence, aglow with color, thick with tree trunk forms that flower into wisteria, magnolia and dogwood blos sems.

title: Fire Kills Official's Children
description: WESTPORT, Wis., Feb. 22 (AP)Five young daughters of a Wisconsin tax official died early today in a fire that de stroyed their home. The parents, Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Lyons, and one of the six chil dren escaped. Mr. Lyons is an administrator for the State Inheritance Tax Division. The police said the dead girls ages ranged from 5 to 10 years.

title: Ford Fund Gives $10.3Million for News Programs
description: The Ford. Foundation has awarded grants of $10.3mil lion in support of news and public affairs programing on public television stations in New York, Washington, Dal las and Chicago. In addition, $1.5million has been given to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and to Commu nity Television of Southern California to support public television's Hollywood Televi sion Theater.

title: Textile Action Urged on Japan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) Wilbur D. Mills, the chair man of the House Ways and Means Committee said today that if the United StatesJapan ese agreement on textile re straints could not be arranged by negotiation, similar results could be achieved by the Jap anese Government and industry taking action by themselves.

title: HARRIMAN CALLS FOR NIXON DEFEAT
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22W. Averell Harriman and former Attorney General Ramsey Clark joined members of Congress, clergyman and others at an antiwar teachin at Yale Uni versity tonight.

title: A Profile of the Woman Boss
description: BOSTON  She owes her business success to at least two strong and supportive men. She attains her career goal by the age of 35. Then she suffers an identity crisis. But she lives happily ever after as a wife, stepmother and senior officer of a com pany.

title: New PaItz Triumphs
description: New Paltz State upset Ba ruch College, 9482, last night, employing a mantoman press in the second half that erased a 4730 deficit.

title: NOISE REDUCTION IN SST PREDICTED
description: Recent engine redesign and airplane improvements will en able this country's supersonic transport to meet Federal rules on noise limits, according to the Government's SST noise committee.

title: Igor Oistrakh Turns His Skill To Rare Pieces
description: Although familiar names filled Igor Oistrakh's recital program on Sunday night at Philharmonic Hall, much of the music came from cob webbed shelves of the violin repertory. How often does one hear any of Eugene Ysaye's sonatas for solo violin, for instance? Or the Paganini Caprices that Schu mann felt it desirable to fill out with accompanying piano parts?

title: NIXON SEEKS RISE IN STUDENT LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22President Nixon asked Con gress again today to enlarge the funds available for fed erally guaranteed loans to college students and to give special emphasis to students from needy families.

title: PILOTS LOCKED OUT
description: PARTS, Feb. 22 (Reuters) A lockout of pilots today grounded Air France and France's two other major air lines.

title: 2 PreCollege Exams to Be Combined
description: About 800,000 American high school students will have to undergo one less day of major testing from now on along the academic road to college.

title: Zoo Society Names an Aide
description: Dr. F. Wayne King, curator of herpetology for the Bronx Zoo, has been appointed chair man of the educational pro gram of the New York Zoo logical Society, which operates both the zoo and the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I protest the action of the officials of the Episcopal Church in threatening economic sanctions against General Motors Corporation because of its South African operations, and in seek ing to draw other Protestant churches into this economic sanctions campaign.

title: The Soviet Jews
description: Thanks in part to the, fury of the Soviet attack, the Brussels conference on Soviet Jewry that opens today will receive worldwide attention.

title: Assembly Votes for. Audits of 3 Cities

description: CHICAGO, (UNI) Feb. 22The Commonwealth Edison Company will ask stockholders at the annual meeting April 2 to authorize an increase in common stock to 75 million from 60 million shares and to authorized a new class of pre ference stock, the company said today.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)The Defense Department asked the Selective Service System to day to draft 2,100 doctors this year in the first callup of physi cians since 1969.

title: Screen: 9 Film Portraits at Whitney
description: Taken all together, the Nine Film Portraits that make up the current program (through tomorrow) of the Whitney Museum's New American Filmmakers Series, suggest not so much a unity as a small corner on the variety of approaches available to the idea of portraiture in film.Among the nine, only one, Ralph Arlyck's "Sean," is a portrait in the more or less conventional, documentary-interview sense we have come to expect on film. And the subject isn't so conventional  a casually charming 4-year-old who smokes grass (which he would rather chew) and, a child of his time, thinks the police are "icky."On the other hand, there are a few "portraits" in a purely visual, quite rigorously formal sense. Mike Kuchar's "Variations" examines moving heads in a series of variously colored monochromatic negative prints. And Hollis Frampton's long (25 minutes) silent, black-and-gray "Manual of Arms" first bisects faces and then reveals whole people in intermittent flashes from what appears to be a single light source. I didn't much like the Kuchar exercise, and the strict economies of "Manual of Arms" after a short while get to look like nothing so much as arbitrary excess.But "Originatetransfiguratedisintegrate," by Dennis Kugler and John Schnele, is a formal portrait, showing animated photographic images in one stage of chemical decay or another, of feverish vitality that really does seem to favor the medium. And I suppose, all other things being equal (they are not) I should have to call it the best film of the show.Niel White's "Putting the Babies Back, Part II," has been reviewed here recently. It does not improve with second viewing. I cannot imagine a second viewing for Bruce Baillie's inexpressive program of close-ups in "Valentin de las Sierras" or for Gary Galsworth's opportunistic study of a found object, an old tattooed man named "Blacky." At the other end of the scale, Leonard Lipton's lovely home movie "People," in its affection for valuable inconsequential gesture, indicates in the course of its three minutes why there has to be a continuing alternative to the commercial cinema.Nothing of the kind is indicated by Ken Schneider's "Chicken Soup," which was, however, if only for its malice aforethought my favorite among the Nine Film Portraits.Dealing with the complete home prepartion of "a delicious Jewish chicken soup" from killing the chicken to slurping the soup, Schneider's film treats its subject in a manner that might best be described as affectionate revulsion. For those of us who, after a childhood of Sunday suffering, contemplate chicken soup with rather less equanimity than Socrates brought to the hemlock, Schneider says it allor almost all. There should be a sequel on matzoh balls.Nine Film Portraits is the last of the Whitney's current program, which though uneven, have nevertheless furnished welcome exception to a mostly dull New York movie season. They have included some very exciting and ambitious new work, such as Beverly Conrad's "Coming Attractions" and Arakawa's "Why Not."And the programing, even of bad movies, seems always to have worked from interesting premises. For this, I believe credit is due to the series director, David Bienstock, and, for the general efficiency of the series, to his associates, Bruce Rubin and Deborah Freedman. Projection at the Whitney has been exceptionally conscientious. I don't know whom to thank for that, but I am grateful.

title: Antimanagement Unit Picks 3 to Run for GAF's Board
description: Richard B. Schneider, Den niston L. Slater and Phillip H. Willkie will be nominees of the GAF Corporation's stockholders protective committee for elec tion to GAF's board of direc tors at the company's annual meeting, scheduled for April 16.

title: Meeting to Be in April
description: GENEVA, Feb. 22  The world's leading intergovern mental agency on trade policy has scheduled an informal meeting eh which senior Gov ernment officials will be ex pected to discuss how to revive the stalled drive for the liberal ization of trade.

title: Florida Beats Ole Miss
description: OXFORD, Miss., Feb. 22 (UPI)Earl Findley scored 24 points, 18 in the second half, to spark Florida to an 8568 southeast conference victory over Mississippi tonight The Rebels played without Johnny Neumann, the nation's leading collegiate scorer, who was in Memphis with his ailing father.

title: Western Kentucky Triumphs
description: RICHMOND, Ky., Feb. 22 (AP)  Western Kentucky's 7 foot Jim McDaniels scored 41 points tonight, but it took a 20foot jump shot by a substi tute guard, Danny Johnson, with six seconds left in an overtime period to give the Hilltoppers a 9493 victory over Eastern Kentucky.

title: Elizabeth Potts Dies at 81; An Interior Designer Here
description: Mrs, Elizabeth Potts Tobey of 200 East 66th Street, widow of Reginald S. Tobey and founder of the American Institute of In terior Designers, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla. She was 81 years old.

title: Hughes of Flyers Sidelined
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (UPI)The Philadelphia Flyers said today that Brent Hughes, defenseman, would miss three weeks of National Hockey League action because of strained ligaments in his right knee. Hughes injured the knee last Friday against Vancouver.

title: MARGUERITE BRENNAN
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 22Marguerite M. Brennan, retired head of the foreign exchange department of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died yesterday at her home, 542 Jersey Avenue.

title: NINA OLIVETTE, 63, ACTRESS, IS DEAD
description: Nina Olivette, who M 1928 played the lead opposite Bert Lahr in the musical comedy Hold Everything!, died Sun day in Polyclinic Hospital after a heart attack. She was 63 years old.

title: Can Strike in Second Week
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 22 (AP)A strike by 35,000 members of the United Steelworkers of America against three major can manufacturers entered its second week today. No talks were scheduled with the com paniesContinental Can, Amer ican Can and Crown, Cork and Seal.

title: Lives in a Welfare Hotel Go On After a Boy Dies
description: Yesterday, back at the Kimberly Hotel after taking part in a 12hour occupa tion by welfare families of a new apartment building, Mrs. Lillian Hill, a mother of four children, said:

title: 2 Panther Defendants Are Missing
description: The trial of 13 Black Panthers her was told yesterday that the brother of one of the ac cused went to Detroit to ar range for false identification and working papers for part of the defendants, apparently to facilitate their flight.

title: M'CARTHY SCORES A DIFFERENT WAR
description: BOSTON, Feb. 22  Efforts to start an expanded public movement to end the war in Vietnam opened here today by returning to a tactic as old as the involvement of many of its organizers  the university teachin.

title: Matuszak Joins Saints Staff
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 (AP)Marv Matuszak, a form er standout linebacker, has been named to the New Orleans Saints coaching staff as as sistant coach in charge of the linebackers, officials of the National Football League club announced today. Matuszak is the fifth man to join the staff of the new head coach, J. D. Roberts.

title: Italian Premier Quips With Mayor On Fiscal Plight
description: Comparing financial prob lems, the prime, minister of Italy, Emilio Colombo, suggest ed with a twinkle to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that he ought to go to Rome if he really wanted to see something.

title: A Commonwealth of Palestine Is Suggested by 4 U.S. Professors
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 22Four American law professors have suggested a Middle. East settlement that would include the formation of a Commonwealth of Pales tine, consisting of Israel and an Arab state as its two fully independent and sovereign com ponents.

description: Tiebreakers have become the rule, not the exception in ten nis these days, and Dennis Ral ston won the points that count ed last night for a berth in the semifinal round of the. $210,00Q Tennis Champions Classic.

title: Scheuer Advises High School Voters of Future to Become Involved
description: Students at De Witt Clinton High School were told yester day that it was not enough for the merely to register and vote.

title: CHRISTOPHER J. MURPHY
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. (AP)  Christopher J. Murphy, a former city judge, died today in New Rochelle Hospital, where he had been undergoing treatment for pneumonia. He was 65 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)Spencer Haywood, a professional basketball star, asked the Supreme Court to day to allow him to continue to play for the Seattle Su perSonics pending litigation over his status in the Na tional Basketball Association.

description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (Reuters) Samuel Montagu & Co., Lon don bankers and bullion mer chants, forecast today that gold producers should be able this year to sell all their newly mined metal on the free market at a reasonable premium. Mon tagu added that the price should reach $40 an ounce at times.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is clearly approaching the time when we should be look ing to the equity market for our financing needs, H. I. Romnes, chairman, said yester day in the company's annual report.

title: Politics of Blame
description: At a critical time in the history of American federal ism, when states are trying to assert a broader influence over the course of public affairs, some are measuring up by reshaping their machinery and adopting progres sive, broadbased taxes to help meet mounting needs. Some are doing this. But some are not. Two examples from the latter category are close at hand: Connecticut and New Jersey.

Fire Destroys Brooklyn Club, Heights Landmark Since 1816
description: A 155yearold Brooklyn land mark, which since 1915 has been the headquarters of The Brooklyn Club at 131 Remsen Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section, was destroyed by a threealarm fire early yester day. The fire, discovered at 12:30 A.M., burned out of con trol for three hours, during which time the building's roof and stairways collapsed.

title: Theater: Siobhan McKenna'sLadies
description: The English language was always too good for the Eng lish, which is why, with se vere misgivings, God gave it to the Irish. The Irish prompt ly translated it into Gaelic and then translated it back, and the result has been a dark and elfin poetry that has immeasurably enriched the world.

description: MOSCOW, Feb. 22 (AP) The Soviet Union kept up its (press campaign against Zionism today, giving especially bitter criticism to the Jewish confer ence in Brussels.

description: The trial of more than 30 supporters of Operation Bread basket on charges of violating State Supreme Court injunc tions against sitin protests at the executive offices of the A. & P. food store chain was post poned yesterday until March 8.

title: Scientist Foresees a Longer Life Span, Mainly for the Affluent
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22If efforts to understand and alter the aging process are pursued full tilt, by the end of this century the useful life span of some individuals may be ex tended 20 to 40 years, a scien tist predicted today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The United States Constitution is supposed to be an impartial document guaranteeing all citizens the rights of life, liberty and the pursuit of hap piness. The imposition of unbridled smut upon American citizens and the abridgement of decency In judicial opinions by the Supreme Court, pro tecting smut producers, is a sober and tragic realization for us to contem plate.

description: TOKYO, Feb. 22  The final stage of a fiveyear bat lle between airport construc tion officials and diehard farm ers began today. The officials formally notified the farmers that they would forcibly cut trees and remove other ob Stecles hindering the comple tion of a 13,000foot runway.

title: U.S. Reserves Judgment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The State Department reserved judgment today on Israel's handling of the latest Egyptian peace initiative until the for mal Israeli response is trans mitted to Dr. Jarring.

title: Dyce Hopes Book On His Past Races Will Aid A.A.U. Bid
description: Byron Dyce works at being a track competitor with such intensity that he now con siders the sport a part of daily life. It's like eating or breath ing, he said yesterday at the track writers luncheon. It's something I do.

description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany has sent the Interior De partment an engineering study on the effect of its projected Astoria, Queens, plant expan sion on the ecology of the East River.

title: Holy Cross Is Victor
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 22 (AP)Holy Cross kept its tour Inament hopes alive by defeat ing Catholic University, 8271, tonight. Gene Doyle and Jim Schnurr led the attack as the Crusaders won their 17th game against six losses.

title: Kentucky Rolls On
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 22 (AP)Kentucky overwhelmed Alabama, 10174, tonight in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the mi nority leader; is circulating a cam paign finance bill that is apparently not an official Nixon Administration proposal, and which does not provide for limitations on what candidates may spend to win election.

title: Two Youths Die in Collision
description: JEFFERSON, N. Y., Feb 22 (AP)Two State University at Cobleskill students were killed and four other youth were in jured last night when their car struck the car of another stu dent in a headon collision near here. The police said there were five youths in a car driven by Robert Cappel, 18 years old of Glen Cove, L.I., when it struck the second car. Mr. Cappel and David DeMaria, 18, of Geneva, a passenger, were killed.

title: Salomon Firm Predicts a Record Demand for Credit This Year
description: A moderate pace of eco nomic expansion in 1971 will generate record demand for credit, a leading investment firm predicted yesterday.

title: WEBSTER'S PAPERS READY ON MICROFILM
description: A reception commemorating the publication of a compre hensive microfilm edition of the papers of Daniel Webster will be held at 5 p.m. Friday, in the Dartmouth College Club in the Commodore Hotel. Webster was a Dartmouth graduate.

title: Californian in Race to Head Democratic Group in House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) Representative Phillip Burton of California announced today that he would seek election as chairman of the House Demo cratic Study Group.

title: F. P.C. Warns Much of Nation Faces Summer Power Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Federal. Power Commission warned today that most areas of the country were in danger of power shortages this sum mer.

title: Nixon to Act This Week to Curb Wage d Price Increases in the Construction Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 President Nixon will announce this week action to halt the upward spiral of wages and prices in the nation's construc tion industry, Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson re ported today.

title: Old Friend Is Serving on Nixon's Staff as Liaison to Business Community
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22President Nixon has installed an old hometown neighbor, Roger E. Johnson, an oilman, on the White House staff to serve as a liaison with the President's friends in the busi ness community.

title: MUNSON ACCEPTS YANKEE CONTRACT
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., 22  Thurman Munson signed on the dotted line this morn ing and went to work with the rest of the New York battery men, but Fritz Peterson did not, making himself the only official Yankee holdout of the moment.

title: Neutralize Southeast Asia Now
description: LONDONThe speed. and scale of America's withdrawal from Vietnam Is impressive by any standard. Po litically more important still, as against 14,592 Americans killed in the last year of the Democratic Administration, only 4,180 were killed in 1970.

title: Gierek and Gomulka:A Comparison
description: WARSAW, Feb. 22  Ed ward Gierek is being told by his friends that he is losing weight.

title: High Court Lets Stand Ban on Building in Bay
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)The Supreme Court let stand today a decision that empowers the Army Corps of Engineers to pre vent private construction in coastal areas solely to pro tect wildlife and the environ ment.

title: BODY FOUND IN FIRE; SLAYING IS SUSPECTED
description: A man who the police say may have been murdered was found in his Manhattan apart ment last night by firemen called to put out a blaze in the wellfurnished apartment.

title: All 3 Big Eight Contests Postponed by Snowstorm
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 22(AP) Allthree Big Eight basket ball games scheduled for to night were postponed because of the snowstorm that has paralyzed much of the mid west.

title: Heady Price Cut in Wine
description: PARIS, Feb. 22Baron Philippe de Rothschild, the Bordeaux maverick, has shaken up the wine market again, this time by cutting the price of his Mouton Rothschild 1970 to half the price of 1969. He did it, he said, to make the wine available once more to deserving consumers.

title: Hatcher Sees Revenue Sharing. As a Threat to Blacks in Cities
description: AIRLIE, Va., Feb. 22Richard G. Hatcher, the Mayor of Gary, Ind., warned today that President Nixon's revenue sharing plan could result in a setback for black Americans now gaining political power in the central cities.

title: Wood, Field and Strearm
description: MANSFIELD, GaIt was a warm, windy and altogether lovely afternoon when set forth with Billy Hester, man ager of the 3,500acre Mar ben Farm, Shooting Preserve; and two of the: farm's point ers in quest of quail.

title: SEALE DENIED BID TO HALT HIS TRIAL
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 22Lawyers for Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins tried again this morning to have their clients trial halted, charging that pretrial publicity hart been so extensive that even the 10 jurors already selected could not be impartial.

title: West Ham Buys Robson
description: LONDON, Feb. 22 (AP)West Ham United, the London soccer team struggling to stay in the English First Division, bought Bryan Robson from Newcastle today for $288,000.

title: Hacker on Queens Faculty
description: Andrew Hacker, former politi cal science professor at Cornell University, was appointed last night by the Board of Higher Education to the faculty at the City University of New York's Queens College. Mr. Hacker, 41 years old, teaches courses in American Government and is the author of four books and several magazine articles. He said he was attracted to the City University system because of its open admission policy.

title: State Funds to Be Sought for Black Museum Here
description: Sidney A. von Luther, the newly elected State Senator from Harlem, said yesterday he believed a proper structure, to house the deteriorating Schomburg Collection of Black Literature and History should be financed with state funds because the city did not have the money.

title: OCEAN RATE RULING ALLOWED TO STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)  The Supreme Court let stand today a lower court decision supporting the Federal Maritime Commission's actions In a com plex dispute over ocean transit rates set on cargo moving to and from the Midwest.

title: Mayor to Speak Tomorrow On Business and the City
description: Mayor Lindsay is scheduled to speak tomorrow at a noon luncheon sponsored by the Har vard Business School Club of New York. The subject of the Mayor's address, a luncheon spokesman said, will be what the city does for business and what business can do for the city.

title: GUY (RED) MACKEY OF PURDUE, IS DEAD; Athletic Director Since 1942 Was Dean of Big Ten
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 22 (AP)Guy (Red) Mackey, ath letic director at Purdue Univer sity since 1942 and associated with the university for 45 years, died last night in Lafay ette Home Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Dartmouth Six Wins, 53
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 22Mike Turner scored three goals today to lead Dartmouth to a 53 hockey victory over Army.

title: BEAME CRITICIZES CAPITAL BUDGET
description: Mayor Lindsay's proposed capital budget for 197172 was criticized yesterday by the City Controller for lumping many appropriations together and by a City Council leader for not explaining a backlog in con struction projects.

title: COPPER FUTURES SHOW ADVANCES
description: What always surprises some followers of commodity futures trading is that sometimes the market seems to move in strange, unaccountable ways. Yesterday an instance could be found in copper futures.

title: More Meningitis at Base
description: GREAT LAKES, Ill., Feb. 22 (AP)The Navy reported today another case of spinal menin gitis at its Great Lake base, the 13th case since Feb. 3. One recruit's death has been attrib uted to the disease

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: DA Alan L. Berkley's recent letter (To the Fore With SST) is full of unsupported statements. From where does he draw the conclusion that There seems to be no doubt that the SST... will revolutionize intercon tinental travel? Doubts are many, and have been published in The Times and elsewhere. Cutting the flight time to Europe another third hardly seems revolutionary when we cannot expect ground time to and from airports to les sen. Military implications hardly seem astounding. We already have fighters that have been breaking the sound barrier, and missiles at much greater speed are more efficient for delivering firepower. Rocketry techniques should soon be (or perhaps already are) ca pable of delivering other payloads effectively and faster, in trajectories avoiding much of the atmosphere.

title: Black Congressmen Leave South Africa and Whites Stay
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Feb. 22 (Agence France Presse)  Five United States Representatives touring Africa took different routes here to day, with two Negroes making only a transit stop.

title: REPORTED CRIME RISES 8.2% HERE
description: After a oneyear decline, serious crimes reported to the Police Department increased 8.2 per cent in 1970, the de partment said yesterday.

title: Supreme Court to Decide if Free Legal Counsel Must Be Offered to the Poor in Trials for Petty Offenses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Supreme Court agreed to day to decide if the millions of poor persons who are prose cuted each year for petty of fenses must be offered free legal counsel.

title: U.S. Evacuates G.I. From Post in Laos Besieged by Enemy
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI)  A wounded American helicopter crew chief who had taken virtual com mand of a besieged South Viet namese outpost in Laos was airlifted to safety today, the United States command said.

title: RELIGIOUS SCHOOLS WIN PLEDGE OF AID PROM ROCKEFELLER
description: ALBANY, Feb. 22Declaring that parochial schools faced a greater crisis than public Ischools, Governor Rockefeller pledged today additional state aid for religious schools this year.

title: Stanley Gains in Court Play
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22Peter Stanley advanced to the semifinals of the court tennis championships for the Pierre Etchebaster Cup today by de feating Dr. David Y. Cooper, 61, 64, at the Racquet Club.

title: Briton Arrives to Oppose New York Bill on Jet Noise
description: Anthony Wedgwood Benn, former British Minister of Tech nology, arrived here yesterday to speak in opposition to a pro posed state law that he said would effectively kill the BritishFrench Concorde super sonic transport.

title: A Floor of Styles For the Young Set
description: Alexander's third floor is jumping with youth unlim ited. Teenagers and those in their early 20's linger over the displays of short shorts and the long country dresses currently in stock. Among the prettiest on hand in the Bridge Shop are two designs from Sandy Delnet, a Califor nia designer. One is a double knit that looks like denim but feels like jersey in an overall top with a long, ruf fled skirt. It's priced at $24 and comes in sizes 5 to 13. The other dress, a colorful combination of gold on blue, combines stripes and minute flowers and looks demure enough for a church picnic. Also in sizes 5 to 13, it is $28.

title: Retain Equalization Tax, Treasury Asks the House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The United States has not made hoped for progress in cutting the balanceofpay ments deficit, the Nixon Admin istration said today in asking for continuation of a special tax on the raising of foreign capital in this country.

title: Dress to Be Happy, The Invitation Said
description: Leopold Stokowski, the 88yearold conductor of the American Symphony Orches tra, looked around Dinty Moore's last. night and said he enjoyed Nor No, Nanette.

title: TwoWeek Delay of Trial Is Granted Mrs. Crimmins
description: The second murder trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins was post poned yesterday in Supreme Court, Queens, until March 8 to give her defense further time to prepare its case.

title: Jersey Names Commissioner
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22 (AP)Assemblyman Thomas J. Shus ted, a Camden County Republi can, was named today to fill the vacancy on the State Com mission of Investigation. Mr. Shusted, 44 years old, was ap pointed by Assembly Speaker Barry T. Parker, Republican of Burlington. Mr. Shusted, who is from Haddonfield, replaces James T. Dowd of Caldwell in the $15,000ayear post.

title: Report of Laos Action
description: HONG KONG. Feb. 23 (Reu ters)  The North Vietnamese news agency today distributed a report from a Vietcong news man who accompanied units that overran a South Vietnam mese ranger post in Laos last weekend.

title: Senators Hear PX Officials, Aided by General, Ordered Oversupply of Beer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Post exchange custodians, with the help of a general, told their stateside superiors they were running out of Carling's beer in Vietnam when there were 99, 000 cases on hand there and 125,900 more coming in every month, a Senate inquiry was told today.

title: MRS. NELLIE M'CUTTE
description: Mrs. Nellie McCutte, who came to The New York Times as a young widow in 1909 and worked in the building services department until her retirement at the end of 1957, died on Feb. 16 after a long illness at the home of her son, George, of 2594 42d Street, Astoria, Queens. She was. 89 years old.

title: Carol Dudek Bride of Mark Amsterdam
description: Miss Carol Dudek, daugh ter of Mrs. Anna Dudek of Weehawken, N.J., was mar ried last Wednesday to Mark Lemle Amsterdam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Amsterdam of Hewlett Har bor, L.I. The civil ceremony took place in Koza, Okinawa, where Mr. Amsterdam is rep resenting the Law Center for Constitutional Rights as de fense counsel for American servicemen being courtmar tialed. His bride is an as sistant counsel. She attended Fairleigh Dickinson Univer sity.

title: Furor Over Accounting
description: The public accountant plays an interesting and vital role in the, functioning of a modern industrial society. At one and the same time, he is a historian of business accomplishment, a watchdog over commercial mo rality, as well as an economic philosopher, with responsibility to define the nature of transac tions and thus how they are to be recorded. How well the account ing profession has acquitted itself in its multiple roles  which clearly are crucial to any evaluation of economic performancehas been the subject of intense de bate for many years.

title: J. C. Brown to Marry Mrs. Byers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Mrs. Richard King Mellon of Ligonier, Pa., announced here today the engagement of her daughter, Mrs. Constance Mellon Byers of Washington, to J. Carter Brown, also of Washington. He is the direc tor of The National Gallery of Art.

title: RICHFIELD REPORTS OIL FIND IN ALASKA
description: The Atlantic Richfield Com pany announced here today a significant new oil find 25 miles west of the Prudhoe Bay State No. 1 discovery well on the North Slope of Alaska. Robert O. Anderson, chairman, said the company's exploratory well, the West Salt River State No. 1, has encountered oil sand in the upper Cretaceous forma tion in a 340foot interval from 3,745 to 4,085 feet on acreage wholly owned by the company.

title: RICARDO ALFARO OF PANAMA DIES
description: PANAMA, Feb. 23 (AP)Former President Ricardo J. Alfaro died today after emer gency intestinal surgery.

title: KAHANE IS GUILTY IN DISORDER CASE
description: Rabbi Meir D. Kahane, the na tional chairman of the Jewish Defense League, was convicted here yesterday on charges of obstructing governmental ad ministration and disorderly conduct.

title: Mathew McHugh, Actor On Stage and in Films, 77
description: NORTH RIDGE, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP)Mathew McHugh, a veteran character actor whose career dated back to Mack Sen nett two reel comedies, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: Union chief Says Offtrack Problems Can Be Settled in a Hurry
description: Leaders of the three unions whose members man the pari mutuel windows at race tracks in the metropolitan area said yesterday they were complete ly united in their efforts to gain two major guarantees from offtrackbetting operators.

title: City Planning Convention Center
description: Mayor Lindsay announced plans yesterday to build the nation's largest convention and exhibition center above the Hudson River piers between 44th and 47th Streets.

title: Nikolais Dance Premiere
description: The Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater, which has just opened a twoweek season, ending March 6, at the ANTA Theater, will present the premiere of Mr. Nikolais's new work, Scenar io, on Thursday. The group is appearing as part of the Ameri can Dance Season sponsored by tee City tenter.

title: 3 SEIZED IN JERSEY IN CROSSBURNING
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23 Three men were arrested here early today and charged with burning a cross at mid night at the World War Monument in this university community.

title: A Hint of Superheavy Elements Found
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23For years, scientists have sought evidence for an entire family of superheavy ele ments that, according to theory, should exist. They have studied medieval stained glass from Russia, platinum ore from Africa, plastic sheets suspended in the stratosphere, meteorites and moon rocks, without convincing results.

title: A Jersey Legislator Cited on Bar Ethics; 2d Guilty in U.S. Suit
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23David 3. Friedland, minority leader of the State Assembly, was found today to have improperly tried to have a criminal case against a reputed Mafia loan shark dropped.

title: Egypt and Jordan Protest
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23Egypt and Jordan pro tested anew today against Is rael's plans to build 35,000 housing units and other build ings in areas around Jerusalem that were seized from Jordan in 1967.

title: Strong Clue Links Virus to Leukemia
description: A team of scientists in Seattle has reported the of clue that some cases of human leu kemia can be caused by a virus.

title: Helicopters for South Africa
description: Prime Minister Heath's decision to sell helicopters and replacement parts to South Africa's Navy was probably inevitable. There is a legal argument of sorts that Britain is obligated under the Simonstown Agreement of 1955 to make at least this limited range of supplies available for joint defense of the sea lanes around the Cape of Good Hope.

title: Ozark Seeks New Routes
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23 (AP)Ozark Air Lines said today that it had asked the Civil Aeronau tics Board for permission to operate nonstop flights between Denver and five other cities.

title: Habib Bank Enters U.S.
description: Habib Bank, Ltd., Pakistan's largest bank, opened its first United States office yesterday at 40 Wall Street.

title: A Schumann Concert Marked by Daring and Vitality
2 BRITONS ASSAIL BILL ON JET NOISE
description: Two members of Britain's Parliament, one a former Cabi net Minister, warned yesterday that barring the Concorde su personic transport from New York by passage of a pending state bill could seriously dam age the foreign relations of the United States.

title: News Summary and Index WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1971
description: International

title: Unser Top Driver According to Buff Rating 1,965 Races
Yelverton on Honor Five
description: Charlie Yelverton, a 6foot 2inch jumping jack who has led Fordham to a 201 wonlost record this season, was selected to this week's Eastern College Athletic Conference Division basketball team. It was the fourth time this season that Yelverton had been chosen to the squad.

title: Wells, Raiders Receiver, Fined for Drunken Driving
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (AP)Warren Wells, star re ceiver for the Oakland Raiders, was fined $360 today, received a 30day suspended jail sen tence and placed on probation for one year for drunken driving.

title: An Uncertain Remedy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Af ter brandishing almost to the last his formidable power to control wages and prices, Presi dent Nixon today took the gentlest course of action open to himshort of doing nothing to stop the spiraling wages and costs in the nation's con struction industry. Mr. Nixon said he was sus pending provisions of the Davis Bacon Act reluc tantly because of the skyrocketing wages and prices in the con struction industry. But how suspension would interrupt the flight of the skyrocket, or in deed whether it would do so at all in any significant way, is still an unknown.

title: William B.Hartsfield, 80, Dies; Atlanta's Mayor for 23 Years
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 23William B. Hartsfield, Atlanta's mayor for 23 years, died here last night two months atfer a heart attack. In a week he would have been 81 years old.

title: Nixon Urges Geneva Arms Conference to Agree on a Treaty Banning Bacteriological Weapons
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23President Nixon urged the Geneva disarm ament conference today to agree at its 1971 session on a treaty prohibiting bacteriologi cal weapons. The President reiterated United States opposi tion to the Soviet Union's long standing demand for a simul taneous ban on chemical weap ons until the problem of veri fying compliance is solved.

title: Well, They Don't Have to Look Like Boots...
description: If summer comes, will boots be left behind? With no one quite certain whether hemlines are up, down or gone, shoe designers have made the wrapped leg their answer to any fashion question. To them, a wrap ped leg can mean anything from a sandal strapped thighhigh to a boot that has an open toe, open heel, open frontin fact, almost no boot at all.

title: Union College Raises Tuition
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 123 (AP)  Union College said today it would increase its tui tion by $300 over the next two years to $2,700, The rates will be increased by $100 in September to $2,500, and $200 more will be added in Septem ber, 1972. Dr. Harold C. Mar tin, college president, said the school had been operating with deficits for six of the last sev en years.

title: U.S. AIDES PORTRAY A SUCCESS IN LAOS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Administration stepped up efforts today to portray the allied drive in Laos as a success though some officials privately acknowledged that South Viet namese forces would have to move much farther across Laos to curtail the flow of enemy supplies significantly.

title: DRUGGIST GRAINS PLANNING MERGER
description: The Rite Aid Corporation an nounced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire Clinton Merchandising, Inc., of Roches ter, through an exchange of stock valued At about. $23mil lion. Both companies operate chains of retail and discount drugstores.

title: Senators Told of Severe Malnutrition Among Migrant. Workers Children
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Serious malnutrition among the children of migrant workerssometimes as severe as that seen in Biafrais 10 times greater than among children generally, a Colorado expert told a Senate committee today.

title: April 1, 1972, Deadline Set By Amex for Using CUSIP
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had established April 1, 1972, as the deadline for mandatory use of the socalled CUSIP number ing system by member firms that channel their trades through the Amex Clearing Corporation.

title: JAMES II. DUNCAN, INDUSTRIAL AIDE
description: HADDONFIELD, N. J., Feb. 23  James H. Duncan, presi dent of the Science Manage ment Corporation of Moores town, died yesterday in Paris during a business meeting. He was 55 years old and lived at 10 Lane of Acres here.

title: JOHN F. ANDERSON,38, A BROOKLYN LAWYER
description: John F. Anderson, president of the Bay Ridge (Brooklyn) Lawyers Association and a partner in Wingate & Cullen, 142 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, died after a heart attack. Sun day in Aspen, Colo., whore he was skiing. He was 38 years old and lived at 107 80th Street Bay Ridge.

title: Nixon to Name Jerris Leonard To Head Law Enforcement Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 President Nixon will shortly appoint Jerris Leonard, chief of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, to the longvacant directorship of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, it was learned today.

title: Mexico City's Airport Police Seize 53 Pounds of Cocaine
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 23 Policemen at the international airport here have seized 53 pounds of cocaine being smug gled by travelers from Chile during the last week.

title: Film Institute Gets Grant
description: The American Film Institute has received a grant of $800, 000 from the Ford Foundation for the support of its Center for Advanced Film Studies in Beverly Hills, Calif. The grant, which covers a period of two years ending June 30, 1972, calls for a matching fund to be raised by the institute through donations from non governmental sources. The in stitute's center, which opened in September, 1969, currently has 40 students on fellowships working in various filmmaking and criticism courses.

title: Air France, 2 Other Lines Continue Pilot Lockout
description: PARIS, Feb. 23 (Reuters)A bitter pay dispute kept France's three major airlines grounded again today in an action the companies said was costing them $1 8million daily.

title: Senators Hear of Threat of a Dossier Dictatorship
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The private life of the aver age American is the subject of 10 to 20 dossiers of per sonal information in the files and computer data banks of Government and private agencies, a Senate subcommittee was told today. Two lawyers and a social scien tist testified that most Amer icans are only vaguely aware of the extent to which they are watched, contending that the controls over abuse of information gathering and dissemination are limited. One said that the chilling effect of snooping was leading the nation toward a dossier dictatorship. Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, the chairman of the Subcommittee on Constitu tional Rights, opened nine days of hearings on the problem of making computer ized information systems serve society and the individual citi zen without suppressing polit ical liberties.

title: Swedish Army Officers Face a Lockout
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 23The Swedish Government, facing the most severe labor conflict in postwar years, announced to night that 3,000 army officers would be locked out of their bases next week in a move to bring pressure on striking Gov ernment employes.

title: BOYCOTT CLOSES HARLEM SCHOOL
description: A total boycott, by parents, teachers and supervisors forced the closing yesterday of a 70yearold Harlem schoolPublic School186in a protest against what they termed antiquated and unhealthy conditions there and the delay in the construc tion of a replacement school.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Our State Department has said that certain plans by Israel to build apart ments in the area of Jerusalem are unacceptable.

title: Bill Rates Show Sharp Drop At Treasury's Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Monthly Treasury bill rates posted another sharp decline from previous month's levels, at today's auction of 274 and 366day bills, the Government announced late this afternoon.

title: Saigon's Strategy Meets Obstacles in Laos
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 23Brooding about pos sible obstacles to the South Vietnamese drive against the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos, senior American military advis ers last week saw three major problems: the roads, the mon soon weather and antiaircraft fire. Yet, over the weekend, in good weather, far from any road, one of the finest South Vietnamese combat battalions was lost to an enemy attack on its mountaintop landing zone five mild across the border in Laos. American helicopters, un able to bring supplies or rein forcements through the curtain of ground fire, returned to their base here while the 39th Ranger Battalion was losing more than half its men.

title: GEORGE W. ELLIOTT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP) George W. Elliott, former di rector of public safety of the City of Philadelphia and retired general secretary of the Phila delphia Chamber of Commerce, died yesiel day in Shore Memo rial Hospital, Somers Point, N. J. He was 87 years old.

title: Big Board and AmexEase Rules Affecting Fiduciaries
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that their boards of governors had amended the rules of both exchanges to fa cilitate the sale and delivery of securities by fiduciaries, such as domestic executors of es tates, guardians, or trustees.

title: Lindsay and Caso Seek City and County Rapport
description: The city and the suburbs took another step closer to ward cooperation yesterday when Nassau County Execu tive Ralph G. Caso attended a weekly meeting of Mayor Lindsay's cabinet and dis cussed problems affecting the county and the city.

title: G. Frederick Reinhardt Dead; Ambassador to Italy, 106168
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23G. Fred erick Reinhardt, the former. United States Ambassador to Italy, died last night after, a heart attack.

title: Why Women Seldom Wear Their Phi Beta Kappa Keys
description: I think it's in the back of my jewelry box along with my Junior Red Cross pin and my sharpshooter's medal from camp, said Mrs. Robert Sommer, whose Phi Beta Kappa key has found a typical resting place.

title: Police Arrest Bronx Man In Death of Store Owner
description: A 20yearold man, who the police said was a narcotics user, was arrested yesterday and charged with the fatal stabbing of the owner of a Bronx shoe store on Monday.

title: Muskie Asks That U.S. Troops Quit Indochina by End of Year
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23Senator Edmund S. Muskie, contending that the Adminis tration's program of Vietnanii zation provides no answer for ending the Vietnam war, called tonight for withdrawal of all American troops from Indo china by the end of this year.

title: Bridge: 4 Slain Deals Liven Finals Of Swiss Team Championship
DEMOCRATS SEEK WAR WITHDRAWAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Over the resistance of its hawk ish flank, the Democratic par ty in the Senate went on rec ord today in favor of with drawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of 1972.

title: Shanker's Foes Call His Rule Autocratic
description: Albert Shanker, who has led the United Federation of Teachers to a position of great power and influence, is under sharp attack by a coalition of opponents within the unionsome of them for mer allieswho charge him with increasingly autocratic rule.

title: WILLIAM J. CARRY, 67, OF IGNITION COMPANY
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23William J. Carry of Gulf stream and Norwich, N. Y., where he was chairman of Gen eral Laboratories Associates until his retirement in 1968, died today in Bethesda Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS EQUALIZATION TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  The House Ways and Means Committee ap proved today the Administra tion's proposal to extend the interestequalization tax until March 31, 1973, a committee chairman announced.

title: Satellite Mission Ends
description: UCHINOURA, Japan, Feb. 23 (AP)Scientists said today that they had stopped monitor ing radio signals from Japan's second earth satellite, which was launched last Tuesday. Prof. Tamiya Nomura of Tokyo University's Institute of Spaae and Aeronautic Science said batteries carried by the satellite had weakened and would go dead tomorrow.

title: Former Mayor Admits Guilt
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Feb. 23 (UPI)  Clarence Sprinkle, a former Jackson Township mayor already on trial for ex torition, pleaded guilty today to two other charges of conspiracy and misconduct in office.

title: Snake River Power Dams Urged by F.P.C. Examiner
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) A Federal Power Commission examiner recommended a con ditional construction license to day for a $275.8million pri vate electric power project in a stretch of the. Snake River that forms the OregonIdaho border.

title: MARKET WANDERS TO A MODEST GAIN
Excerpts From Calley Testimony on Mylai Killings
description: FORT DENNING, Ga., Feb. 23Following are excerpts from testimony here today by First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. at his courtmartial for the murder of Vietnamese civillans:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CLOSURE IS BEATEN 2D TIME IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The Senate rejected again to day an attempt to halt the Southern filibuster against a rules change that would make it easier to end filibusters.

title: Giacomin Sets Goal for Tonight: Keep Flyers From Early Goals
Actions by Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The Supreme Court :took, the following actions today:
