title: FontaineYonkers Rift Still a Mystery
description: YONKERS, Feb. 23  Lucien Fontaine, one of the leading harness racing drivers in North America, will do no more driv ing during the Yonkers Race way meeting, which will ter minate one week from tonight.

title: hugging and Kissing Set
description: Hugging and Kissing, a pro gram of two plays by Norman Wexler, will be produced on Broadway this season by Ed and Michael Gifford and Claire Teitel, it has been announced.

title: ALGERIAN OFFICIAL WARNS WEST ON OIL
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 23 (Reuters  The Algerian Min ister of Industry and Energy, Belaid Abdesalam, warned to day of other measures in store should Western oil com panies fail to respond to new price demands.

title: Lawyers for Seale Urge Start of Trial WithOnly 11 Jurors
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb, 23 Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins asked today that they be brought to trial before the 11 jurors selected so far, rather than try to find a 12th juror and two alternates.

title: Stalled Rangers Remove Wounded
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 24The South Vietnamese military command said yesterday that its forces had no intention right now of penetrating more deeply into Laos.

title: Valenti Says Films Gross Rose in '70
description: Despite the problems that plagued business including the movies, the film busi ness recorded major gains in 1970, according to Jack Valenti, president of the Mo tion Picture Association of America, in his annual ap praisal of the state of the movies last year.

title: Supply Problem Stressed
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Lieut. Gen. Hoang Xuan Lam, commander of the South Vietnamese forces in Laos, said today the most serious problem he had was supplying his units.

title: Papal Aide Who Will Visit Soviet
description: ROME, Feb. 23President Tito genially slapped the Most Rev. Agostino Casaroli, the Vatican's fraillooking and usually smiling top negotia tor, on the shoulder. A Peking diplomat talked with him in confidence. Communist offi cials in Warsaw, Prague and Budapest warmed up to him.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Nebraska. President Nixon declared Nebraska a major disaster area. The state has been hit by severe storms and flooding.

title: OPEN REHEARSAL FOR JAZZ GROUP
description: The first of a series of 10 open rehearsals by the Jazz Composer's Orchestra was held Monday night at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. the series, which is free, will be held every Monday at 7:30 P.M. through April 26. It has been arranged with the support of the New York State Codicil On the Arts.

title: A MAROONED TOWN IN NEBRASKA AIDED
description: National Guard troops em ployed a trucktosnowmobile relay yesterday to carry food to a Nebraska town cut off by snowdrifts and floodwaters. And thousands of cattle ma rooned by snow were reported in dire need of food in cen tral Kansas.

title: Prints and Photographs On View at Metropolitan
description: Prejudices that have raised painting and sculpture to a high stature in the arts and relegated prints and photog raphy to a lower level have often been the cause of great esthetic injustices and have frequently been sad deter rents to the discovery of fine works of art in the so called secondary media.

title: Galley Concedes Killings; Says He Acted on Orders
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 23First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. admitted from the witness stand today that he shot some civilian prisoners who had been herded into a ditch in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 three years ago, but he said he was act ing under orders.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hebert Backs Big Pay Increase for Draftees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, F. Edward Hebert, urged today that draftees be given a larg er raise than the Nixon Ad ministration has recommended.

title: U.N. RIGHTS TEAM REPORTS ON AFRICA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 23A sixman team of experts for the Human Rights Commission of the United Na tions reported today after four years of investigation that there were what they described as elements of genocide in the treatment of black Africans in some parts of southern Africa.

title: Censors at the Source
description: Censorship is an expression of cowardice. To seek security through the suppression of the printed word a vote of noconfidence in the free market of ideas and in the people's ability to let reason be their guide. The periodic emergence of selfappointed censors is a danger signal of declining faith in the democratic process.

title: Amex Stocks Rise as Volume Drops
Three Jews Who Left Denounce Soviet And Praise Israel at Brussels Meeting
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 23  Three Zionist Jews who recently left the Soviet Union said today that the attitude of three mil lion Jews there was one of in creasing alienation and protest and the policy of the Govern ment was hypocritical and ly ing antiSemitism.

title: Brannick, 77, Leaves Giants After 65 Years
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., Feb. 23 (UPI)Eddie Brannick, 77 years old, resigned today as secretary of the San Fran cisco Giants. He had been as sociated with the club for 65 years.

title: Thousand Islands Bridge Panel Is Criticized by State. Auditors
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23  Several members of the Thousand Is lands Bridge Authority, which operates bridges across the St. Lawrence River between the United States and Canada, were cited for a possible conflict of interest in a report made pub lic today by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: Route 9, Now a Cemetery Hanoi Army Paper Asserts
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 23 (Agence FrancePresse) The North Vietnamese Army newspaper, Quan Doi Nhan Dan, said today that Route 9, the road over which South Vietnamese forces invaded Laos, had become the cemetery of helicopters and armored vehicles.

title: Samuelson Derides Nixon's Forecast on the Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The 1970 winner of the Nobel Prize for economics used such terms as poppycock, ludi crous. cynical and comic opera today to describe the Nixon Administration's relative ly optimistic projections of the economy for this year.

title: Action in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, Feb. 24 (AP)The Cambodian command reported today that Government troops had repulsed repeated attacks by North Vietnamese and Viet cong soldiers on a frontier vil lage for a second successive night.

title: BUCKS CLINCH TIE FOR SECTION TITLE
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Feb. 19 letter of Kenneth L. Johnson, Federal Regional Air Pollu tion Control Director, restates his op position to the generating unit at Astoria. Mr. Johnson's chief concern is the effect of this unit on sulfur dioxide pollution.

title: T. LEWIS MOORE
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23T. Lewis Moore, for mer executive vice president of the West Side Association of Commerce, Inc., died today after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Press in South Africa Hails Heath on Arms
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 23.Britain's de cision to sell military heli copters to Africa is seen here as a victory for South Africa's persistence and a personal triumph for Prime Minister Heath, who received wide praise in newspapers today.

title: Miss di Niscemi And a Romanoff Are Wed Here
description: Miss Maria di Niscemi, whose father was a Sicilian prince, and Alexander Ro manoff, whose grandmother was the sister of Czar Nicholas II of Russia, were married here yesterday after noon at a civil ceremony per formed by Deputy City Clerk James H. Scalfaro at the Municipal Building.

title: 15 Youths Cut 7 Others In Chinatown Poolroom
description: A gang of 15 youths, all but two of them Chinese, invaded a Chinatown pool hall yesterday afternoon armed with knives and attacked seven Chinese youths there, the police said.

title: Nixon Is Criticized By Auto Union Head Over Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers and a supporter of national health insurance, severely crit icized President Nixon's health care proposals today in testi mony before Congress.

title: No Retreat in Southeast Asia
description: CHARLESTON, S. C.I just re turned from another trip to the Far East which included visits to Korea, Taipei and Vietnam.

title: ROLLS SUSPENDED BY LONDON BOARD
description: LONDON, Feb. 23  The gambling spree in the stock of bankrupt RollsRoyce, Ltd., was called to a halt today with the announcement that the London Stock Exchange was suspend ing the quotation and that the stock register would shortly be closed.

title: U.S. Command Is Seeking Cause of Copter Crash That Killed Saigon General and Newsweek Man
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23  The United States com mand searched in vain today for the cause of a helicopter crash that killed 10 persons, in cluding South Vietnam's best known field commander and correspondent of Newsweek magazine.

title: A Nothing Benefit Brings In Something Like $90,000
description: Lillian Boscowitz can still hardly believe it. For the last 14 years she has been chair man of one of those annual charity affairshers were theater parties or musical pro grams in Philharmonic Halland they always made money. Altogether, she has raised close to $1million for her beneficiary, The George Junior Republic.

title: Nepala Leads in Figure Skating As Petkevich Slips to 5th Place
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ALGIERSThe most distressing fact of this decade is that everybody pro fesses deep concern with the fate of the underdeveloped or developing nations but nobody, especially those same nations, does enough about it. The result is that the gap between rich and poor countries continues to widen.

title: Sawchuk to Receive Award Posthumously
description: Terry Sawchuk, considered the finest goalie of his era, was named yesterday a post humous winner of the Lester Patrick Memorial Trophy.

title: BAR LOYALTY RULE IN STATE UPHELD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 New York can require law school graduates to prove that they are loyal to the United States Government before it grants them licenses to practice law, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: 4 Hostages Freed By Escaped Convict After Coast Flight
description: FULLERTON, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI)Two women and two children were released un harmed today by an Arkansas born barber and escaped con vict who held them hostage at scissors point for 12 hours.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Rise Again
description: Industry investment in plant and equipment this year will rise 11 per cent from the 1970 level to $89.43billion, Pierre A. Rinfret, the consulting economist, said yesterday. Ex penditures last year totaled $80.58billion.

title: NIXON ACTS TO CUT CONSTRUCTION PAY ON, U.S. PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23In an effort to curb inflation in the construction industry, Pres ident Nixon suspended today provisions of a law requiring that union scale wages be paid to workers on Federal and fed erally assisted construction projects.

title: A Clarification
description: The General Electric Com pany said yesterday that in come of its five operating categories over the last four years as reported in the pre liminary prospectus for its coming debenture offering was gross income before taxes. These figures were reported in yesterday's editions of The New York Times as net income. The five categories are: consumer goods, industrial power equip ment, other industrial products, aerospace and international. Figures for the General Electric Credit Corporation were net in come after taxes as carried in the story.

title: Metropolitan Area
description: Mayor Lindsay and the executives of Westchester, Nas sau and Suffolk Counties have begun to grope their way toward a meeting of minds on the problems they have in common. In what, it now appears, was only the first of such talks, they touched on the city's commuter tax, the possibility of reserved expressway lanes for com muter buses, the flight of industry to the suburbs, airport noise and Nassau's dwindling water supply.

title: MERLE LISTER GROUP DANCES AT CUBICULO
description: Merle Lister's choreography is modest in ambition and ac complishment. Her most suc cessful pieces rely on captur ing the momentary lyric mood rather than sustained dramatic development. Monday evening at the Cubiculo she and her company presented a program of five works, the most success ful of which was her own solo Seatrans.

title: Emergency Job Bill in Senate Opposed by Administration
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 23 (UPI)  Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson informed Congress to day that the Nixon Administra tion opposed an emergency bill to put the unemployed to work in local government and public service jobs.

title: Marshals in Soviet, Marking Army Day, See a U.S. Threat
description: MOSCOW, Fob, 23  De fense Minister Andrei A. Grechko and other Soviet mili tary leaders today made their case for continued heavy arms spending by asserting that the Soviet Union remained threat ened by the United States and other Western powers.

title: Filling the Potholes
description: The winter has been severe. February has been excep tionally wet. Water has seeped into cracks in New York City's streets. It has frozen and thawed and frozen again, opening even more numerous fissures than usual and creating even more potholes than usualwhich are con tinually enlarged by the pounding of heavy traffic. Some of New York's streets now look like a cratered moon scape, and are almost as hazardous to ride or walk upon.

title: Legislator Sells Bank Stock
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) Representative W. R. Archer, Republican of Texas, said today that he had sold all the stock in held in a Houston bank to serve on the House Banking Currency Committee without conflict of interest. Mr. Archer did not say how many shares of Heights State Bank he had or what price he got for them, but he promised to make a full disclosure of his net worth before the deadline for members of Congress to list their holdings of certain invest ments.

title: O'Shea of Stars Sent to Hawks In Deal for Two
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP)The Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League traded Doug Mohns and a minor leaguer, Terry Caffery, today to the Minnesota North Stars for Danny O'Shea.

title: Caution Urged in Eurobond Borrowings
description: Money managers of interna tional companies were warned yesterday that floating rate borrowing in the Europond market, while offering advan tages in flexibility of costs, still involved hazaids of sudden sharp rises in interest rates.

title: RACONTEURS ARISE IN YANKEES CAMP
description: FORT LAUDERDALE Fla. Feb. 23Spring training brings out the raconteur in everyone. When Bruce Henry, the New York Yankee road secretary, handed travel expense checks to Whitey Ford and Curt Blew fary yesterday, Blefary started to put his away automatically, without really looking at it.

title: WORKERS COMPLETE CON ED STRIKE VOTE
description: In the second half of a special membership meeting, employes of the Consolidated Edison Company, voted yes terday to authorize a strike against the company on or after March 11.

title: WILLARD VON HAGEN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 23 Willard von Hagen, who re tired as manager of public re lations for the International Paper Company in 1958 after 30 years with the concern, died today at a nursing home in White Plains. He was 78 years old and lived at 7 Wilgarth Road.

title: Hirohito Plans First Trip Abroad by Reigning Japanese Emperor
description: TOKYO, Feb. 23For the first time in Japan's 2,631year history, a reigning Emperor and Empress will travel abroad this autumn to visit seven countries in faraway Europe.

title: Governors Urged to Push Fund Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The White House opened a campaign today to recruit the nation's Governors, who have been pressing for a system of revenue sharing for years, as lobbyists for the Administra tion's program.

title: Royal Commission in Britain Calls for Quick Steps to Reduce Noise and Sea Pollution
description: LONDON, Feb. 23A royal commission called today for early action to give Britain the quiet life and reduce pollution of the surrounding seas.

title: Sports of The Time
description: In the not very distant past, the indoor track and field season was virtually the exclusive property of one section of the Country. Like big league baseball and foot ball, it was confined to the quadrant in the upper righthand corner of the map.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stars, Seals in Trade
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 23 (AP)  The North Stars traded Tommy Williams, a center, to the California Golden Seals today for another center, Ted Hampson.

title: REOGIO POLICE ENTER BASTION OF RIOTERS
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Feb. 23Police forces backed by armored personnel carriers entered the Sbarre section on this city's southern outskirts before 6 A.M. today in a show of strength. The area is the last bastion of rioters here.

title: U.S. Marshals to Serve As Antimugging Escorts
description: In an effort to combat muggings, United States marshals will be available to escort employes, jurors and visitors from the subway station to the Federal Court and Internal Revenue Serv ice offices in downtown Brooklyn.

title: JUSTICES CURTAIL U.S. COURTS'
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Supreme Court instructed Federal trial judges today to curtail the growing practice of halting state prosecutions against defendants who assert that their constitutional rights are being violated.

title: TV: C.B.S. Explores Pentagon Propaganda Costs
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System's news division packed its oldtime wallop last night in a brilliant docu mentary entitled The Selling of the Pentagon. The fur seems certain to fly in Wash ington, since C.B.S. nailed down traveling colonels dab bling in foreign policy, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee making a propaganda film for the De partment of Defense, small children being introduced to genuinely deadly weapons and a frank admission that C.B.S. and its nightly anchor man, Walter Cronkite, had either been duped or had knowingly cooperated in shows not under their inde pendent supervision.

title: Labor Leaders Denounce Wage Action
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23Leaders of building trades unions said today that Presi 'dent Nixon's suspension of pro visions of the DavisBacon Act would have a negligible effect in curbing inflation but might adversely affect the wages paid nonunion workers.

title: MAYOR AND POLICE MOURN '100% COP
description: He was a cop, and I don't say that loosely. He gave 100 per cent. It's easy to say nice things about someone at a fu neral, but you could say that about him any day. Anyone can tell you the same thinghe gave far more than he had to.

title: LOUIS GROGIN
description: Louis Grogin, a retired com mercial artist of 205 Main Street, Spring Valley, N. Y., died Monday in Memorial Hos pital after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: CONSUMERS UNION IS ACCUSED IN SUIT
description: BOSTON, Feb. 23  A cor poration formed by a Massa chusetts Institute of Technolo gy professor has filed suit here against Consumers Union seek ing $500,000 in damages and a public retraction of what it calls a biased and fraudulent rating of its product.

title: COMMUTING SLOWED BY VARIOUS MISHAPS
description: An assortment of delays, at tributed to power failures, me chanical difficulties, a fire and a dispute over fares, plagued commuters on subways and railroads here during the rush hours yesterday morning.

title: Safeway's Investment Plans
description: Safeway Stores, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it planned to invest $140million to $160million in new facilities this year. Quentin Reynolds, chairman, said at a meeting of the New York Society of Securi ty Analysts that the company planned to open 150 new stores in 1971.

title: Pearson Court Tennis Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb: 23Corning Pearson gained the semifinal round of the Pierre Etchebaster Cup court tennis tournament today by defeating Robert Grinnell, 63, 61, at the Racquet Club. Jim Zug, a for mer Princeton university squash racquets player, defeated Wil liam Mannion, 62, 61.

title: Ford, Citing Strikes, Rules Out New British Plant
description: LONDON, Feb. 23The Ford Motor Company disclosed to day that it had ruled out Brit ain as a site for a $72million engine plant because of this country's persistent labor troubles.

title: Small Aid to Higher Education...
description: In resubmitting to Congress last years student aid program, President Nixon has erroneously assumed that, in the intervening months, the world has stood still. The proposals, which seemed far from perfect a year ago, are entirely inadequate now.

title: Rivers's Godson Wins South Carolina Primary
Red Cross Says Aid Is Needed By Indians in Amazon Urgently
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23  A three man mission of the Internation al Committee of the Red Cross said today that quick action was needed to save the native Indian population of Brazil's Amazon region from extinction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The reaction by the Council of Supervisors and Administrators mem bership assembled at Freeport, Baha mas; to. Chancellor Scribner's keynote address and the subsequent statement by C.S.A. President Degnan (news story Feb. 16) again point up with painful clarity in what kind of sad upsidedown world we live today.

title: SMETONA PERFORMS DEBUT PIANO RECITAL
description: Antanas Smetona, who bears the name of his grandfather, the last president of independ ent Lithuania, gave a debut piano recital in Tully Hall on Monday night. Now 31 years old and largely trained in this country, he is an artist with some valuable qualities, among them a ringing tone and speedy fingers.

title: Nixon Foreign Talk On Radio Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  President Nixon will make a halfhour address to the nation on radio at 11 A.M. Thursday on his foreign policy message to Congress that day.

title: Statement by Jordanian
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Abdullah Salah said today that Jordan was ready to recognize the existence of Israel if the Israelis would withdraw from all occupied territories.

title: ... and None to Negro Colleges
description: The inadequacy of the President's understanding of the crisis in higher education is dramatized by the special plight of the Negro colleges. Originally created as a courageous response to America's most shameful lapse in social justice, they are today the victims of social progress. After a century of lonely service to black stu dents, these institutions now face, in addition to higher education's general fiscal crisis, a severe drain of their best talent as the cream of black students and faculty are attracted to the predominantly white universities.

title: Advertising:
description: It was one of those morn ings. No really big news. Just a tidbit here and a tid bit there.

title: Methods of Aiding Religious Schools in State Studied
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23  Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges is considering support ing a bill that would extend additional state aid to private schools by paying for the teaching of secular subjects by lay teachers.

title: Community Police Team Goes on Midtown Duty
description: A neighborhood police team went on duty in Mid town Manhattan yesterday, expanding an experimental program designed to develop closer relationships with communities.

title: Channel 13 Is Preparing Newsroom Program for Fall
description: New York, like San Fran cisco, Dallas, Pittsburgh and Washington, will by September have its own version of News room, public television's ven ture into spontaneous personal journalism.

title: NEW YORK
description: It is now just about a year before the first Presidential primary election in New Hampshire and the political prophets are talking rather confidently about a race in 1972 between President Nixon and Senator Edmund Muskie of Maine. But don't bet on the front runners.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: It is hazardous for one with no Russian to pass judgment on the merits of the poetry of Vladimir Mayakovsky. With the best will in the world, one ends judging poems in English, and their faults and virtues may be those of the translator rather than of the original pogt. Yet this bulky, cumbersome, though continually revealing collec tion of materials by and about Mayakovsky has an interest above and beyond that provoked by the quality of his work. In fact, the nature of his lit erary achievement is virtually ignored in the book. One can get a better idea of the texture of his writing from the introduc tory essay by Patricia Blake in The Bedbug and Selected Poems, just reissued by World ($6.95). Mayakovsky's career has an extraliterary fascination. For he experienced in himself the artistic freedom and experimental exuberance of those early years right after the Russian revolution, and he lived long enough to see the shadow of the prison house descend on all artistic endeavor. He saw art lose its autonomy and become a sloganmaking activity, an element in production goals, a cheer leader for the state. He did not have to face the worst of that situation. He committed suicide in 1930 at age 36.

title: Musicians'
description: VIENNA  Musicians in prestigious orchestra suffer as much stress as pilots of transAtlantic airliners and industrial managers, a team of Viennese scientists has found. Severe anxiety, setting in as early as two weeks be fore a challenging concert, extreme tension during the performance and fatigue after it, sleeplessness and an almost permanent mood of frustration were named as symptoms.

title: Uncle Vanya to Move
description: Chekhos's Uncle Vanya will be transferred from the Roundabout Theater to the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Com merce Street, on March 4.

title: Eximbank Plans to Borrow 500Million in Eurodollars
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The ExportImport Bank an nounced today a second large borrowing of Eurodollars from over seas branches of United States banks: The amount will be $500million. Last month's borrowing was $1billion.

title: Stage: A Tilt on the Pinball Machine
StudentFaculty Report Urges Hard Line on Drugs at C.C.N.Y
description: A studentfaculty commission on drug abuse at the City College of New York has en dorsed the use of policemen to rid the campus of all drug pushers.

title: Armless L. I. Girl Gets $1.3Million Settlement
description: A Long Island girl who lost her arms after she touched an electrical trans former in May, 1968, will receive $1,350,000 in what her lawyer called the largest such outofcourt settlement in the country.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Apartheid11 A.M.

title: ARGENTINE MUSIC PRESENTED HERE
description: Stylistic news, travels quick ly on the new music circuit these days, and national char acteristics have been pretty well obliterated by cosmopoli tan musical idioms practiced from Tokyo to Terre Haute. So it was hardly surprising that the program of new Argentine music presented in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night by the Musica Viva of Buenos Aires suggested very little that could be immediately identified as South American.

title: Canada Bank Rate Is Reduced to 5%
description: TORONTO, Feb. 23  The Bank of Canada tonight an nounced a reduction in the bank rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, effective to morrow, in an effort to ease the pressure on the Canadian dollar and reaffirm expansion ary emphasis in monetary policy.

title: Congolese Christian Sect Is Thriving
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Feb. 15  The Matete Temple, a large, airy auditorium with pale green walls and multicolored felt banners hanging from the rafters, was about half filled.

title: Joffrey Season to Include Three New Productions
description: The City Center. Jeffrey Bal let will present three new pro ductions during its current six week season at the City Cen ter, which ends March 28.

title: Laotians Take Hilltop
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Defense Ministry said today Government forces had recaptured a hilltop near the Plaine des Jarres and 10 miles north of the army base of Long Tieng. The base is 75 miles north of Vientiane.

title: LEGISLATOR ASSAILS WELFARE PROGRAM
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23The chair man of the Assembly Social Services Committee protested today that persons with rela tively highpaying jobs were collecting welfare benefits un der a Federal workincentive program.

title: Commerce Panel in House To Air Penn Central Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) The House Commerce Com mittee Plans to explore the money problems of the Penn Central Railroad, Chairman Harley O. Staggers said today.

title: Scribner to Name Unit to Study SpecialSchool Entrance Tests
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner announced last night that he would soon appoint a broadbased committee to ex amine all the admission poli cies and procedures of the city's four specialized academ ic high schools.

title: DETECTIVE KEPT COVER JOB'S PAY
description: While pretending to be a Black Panther, a police under cover agent testified yesterday he obtained a cover job that paid more than he was receiv ing as a policeman.

title: DAVE SMUCKLER, 56; EXEAGLE FULLBACK
description: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif., Feb. 23 (AP)Dave Smuckler, a former star fullback for Tem ple University and later for the Philadelphia Eagles, died yester day after a heart attack. His age was 56.

title: MasseyFerguson Will Lay Off 2,460 Employes Next Month
description: TORONTO, Feb. 23  Mas seyFerguson, Ltd., the global farm machinery manufacturer, which lost a record $19.7mil lion last year, said today that it would lay off 2,450 employes next month.

title: G. M. HELD VAGUE ON WASTE IN RIVER
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it was not satisfied with a proposal by the General Motors Corpora tion for ending the discharge of industrial waste from the company's North Tarrytown plant into the Hudson River.

title: WarnerLambert Gains;
description: Earnings of diversified chemi cal producers have continued to increase, particularly for those in wellestablished con sumer lines such as the Warner Lambert Pharmaceutical Com pany, the ScheringPlough Cor poration and Borden, Inc.

title: Alexandre Breffort, 70, Author of Irma la Douce
description: PARIS, Feb. 23Alexandre Breffort, who wrote Irma la Douce, died here today. He was 70 years old.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Rise Again
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23New orders for durable goods continued to rise in January and reached their highest level since last.July, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MODEL LEASE SET IN PUBLIC HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Despite opposition from some local officials, the Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment ordered into effect today the first standard lease and grievance procedures for the 2.8 million tenants of public housing.

title: MINERS IN CAPITOL SEEK EARLY TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23About 300 angry Appalachian coal miners roamed the Capitol corridors today demanding that Congressional pressure be put on the Labor and Justice De partments to bring to trial a longdelayed, sixyearold Gov ernment lawsuit against their union, the United Mine Work ers of America.

title: Court Delays Rail Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) The start of daytime train service by the Southern Rail way between Washington and Atlanta was postponed today by Federal court order. The court acted. on a complaint by the National Association of Railroad Passengers, that the new schedule would inconven ience passengers traveling be tween Salisbury and Asheville. N.C. A hearing was set for March 2.

title: UConn Upsets Rutgers
description: STORRS, Conn., Feb. 23 (UPI) Bob Staak, playing his last home game, scored 20 points and the gamewinning basket tonight to lead the University of Connecticut to a 7066 up set victory over Rutgers.

title: Market Place: Realty Trusts And Leverage
description: Talk to experts who invest in real estate investment trusts and they are likely to tell you that the romance in this type of investment is the promise of leverage.

title: ExChief of F. I. duPont Is Joining Bache
description: Wallace C. Latour, the for mer chief executive of F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co. who shepherded the huge bro kerage firm through its near collapse last year, has resigned to take a top position at Bache & Co., one of duPont's biggest competitors.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The dilemma of the ArabIsraeli con flict centers on when the next war will be fought. Sides are drawn be tween those who support the struggle of Israel for its continued existence and those who are angered by the suf fering of the Arab refugees.

title: School Construction Funds Argued at Budget Hearing
description: The Board of Education warned yesterday that thous ands of children would be faced with intolerable overcrowd ing and double sessions for the next 10 years unless it received sufficent money to build enough new schools.

title: EINSTEIN COLLEGE CITES VINDICATION
description: The Albert Einstein College of Medicine said yesterday that it had won vindication in court decisions absolving it of charges of discriminatory em ployment and attitudes.

title: Marchesa Quarantotti, 72; Aided in Charitable Work
description: The Marchesa Anne Pelle grini Quarantotti of this city and Rome died at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. She was 72 years old and lived at 125 East 74th Street.

title: Obote Still Popular in Uganda; Battle Against New Chief Wanes
description: LIRA, Uganda, Feb. 18The Lira Hotel finally got enamel to taking down its picture of Milton Obote the other day, more than two weeks after the army had deposed him from the presidency.

title: Ali Stuns Fans With Silent Drill, Then Relents
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 23Muhammad All stepped com pletely out of character to day, surprising longtime ac quaintances and 200 paying customers at his training ses sion.

title: Key Witness Against Colombo Recants His Earlier Testimony
description: The Government's chief wit ness against Joseph Colombo Jr. startled the jury and spec tators in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday by recant ing previous testimony and swearing that he had falsely ac cused Mr. Colombo.

title: DrugUse Policy Of Schools Scored By Mrs. Shapiro
description: Mrs. Rose Shapiro, former president of the Board of Edu cation who is now special as sistant to Governor Rockefeller for narcotics education pro grams, criticized the presedent board last night for not having a firm policy on drug use in the schools.

title: U.S. Tells of Tayninh Attack
description: SAIGON, Feb. 23 (AP)One of the sharpest attacks against United States forces in several months was reported early to day in the Tayninh area.

title: Bob Hope Sees Role For Agnew as Golfer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 23 (UPI)Bob Hope teed off on Vice President Agnew's golf ing skill tonight and told the nation's Governors that Pres ident Nixon should send him to Laos with a No. 3 wood.

title: Inequities in the Draft
description: WASHINGT9NAlthough I share with many of my colleagues a deep and abiding respect for the concept of voltuitarism in a democratic society, I cannot believe it should be raised above the demands of social justice. For that reason, I remain unalterably opposed to a volunteer army in war time.

title: Two Officials Indicted
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 (AP) Two inspectors of the New Jersey Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control were indicted today on charges of extortion and misconduct in office.

title: CAHILL TO SUPPORT KENNEDY RAIL LINK;By ROBERT LINDSEY
description: Gov. Wiliam T. Cahill of New Jersey agreed yesterday to sup port efforts by New York State to require the Port of New York Authority to finance the planned $140million highspeed rail line from Pennsylvania Station to Kennedy. Interna tional Airport.

title: Hawaii Five Ripens a Year Too Soon
description: The University of Hawaii's basketball team has suddenly blossomed into an independ ent power to be reckoned with. But the team from the island of Oahu has reached full bloom a year too soon to be a threat in the Na tional Collegiate Athletic Associa tion champion ship tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Team Captures Metropolitan Track Lead
Shippers Indicted in Deaths of Cargo Animals
description: A Federal indictment charged yesterday that a giraffe, two gazelles and 18 zebras died as a result of in humane conditions aboard a ship transporting wild animals from East Africa to zoos in the United States.

title: Last 4,000 Tickets on Sale Today for RamsMarquette
description: The 4,000 remaining tickets for tomorrow night's basket ball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden, featuring Ford ham against Maiquette, go on sale at 10 A.M. today. Man hattan meets Connecticut in the first game starting at 7 P.M.

title: Knicks Lose 16Point Lead and Succum to Rockets, 126109, at the Garden
Advertising:
description: J. Walter Thompson, the big one, reports that, despite a slight drop (1.6 per cent) in domestic billings, a nice 13.6 per cent surge interna tionally allowed it to post an overall 4.5 per cent increase for 1970. And, even better, net income was up 10 per cent. The numbers, for col lectors of such facts, are $773million (billings) and $7.3million (profit).

title: Joining Exchange Is Being Weighed By Equitable Life
description: The nation's third largest in surer, the Equitable Life Assur ance Society, disclosed yester day that it was giving. active and serious consideration to joining a stock exchange to save commissions on its huge common stock purchases.

title: Goldmann Stresses Culture
description: GENEVA, Feb. 23  Dr. Na hum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that enforced assim ilation of Soviet Jews threat ened their spiritual, religious and cultural survival.

title: Screen: Making of a Bright Dropout
ISRAEL SAID TO ACT ON FRONTIER MAPS
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 23 (AP)Informed sources reported to day that the Israeli Govern ment had formed three commit tees to draw up territorial terms and new borders that it would accept in a Middle East peace agreement.

title: Drive Cuts Mumps Cases
description: BOSTON, Feb, 23 (AP)The State Department of Public Health said today that its twoyear vaccination drive against the mumps had reduced the disease by 63 per cent. Dr. Nicholas Flumara, director of the Division of Communicable Diseases, said the number of cases of mumps was 4,475 in 1969, compared with 9,024 the previous year and 3,270 in 1970.

title: U. S. Diplomats Trailed
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Soviet plainclothes men have started trailing United States diplomats here, in retaliation apparently for attacks on Rus sian cars in Maryland last week.

title: Record Capital Outlay at PPG
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23PPG Industries during 1970 spent a record $153million on new plants and equipment, Robinson F. Barker; chairman and chief executive officer, said today at a meeting of the Secu rity Analysts of San Francisco. He said the glassmaking paint and chemical company would spend more than $100million on capital expenditures this year.

title: Mets Training Base Shows Telltale Marks of 3d Place
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 23Cleon Jones left his boat borne, Gary Gentry left his Ferrari home and Tug Mc Graw lost 12 pounds in a weekthose are some of the signs of the times for the the New York Mets one year after they squandered their world championship.

title: Big Eight Game Put Off Again
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 23 (AP) Oklahoma State's Big Eight Conference basketball game with the University of Missouri was postponed again today and reset for tomorrow night in Co lumbia, Mo. Oklahoma State was originally scheduled to play in Columbia last night but the team was caught on a Kansas highway by Sunday night's snow storm.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Apartheid11 A.M.

title: Cardinal Cooke Celebrates Mass in the Tombs as Lent Starts
description: Cardinal Cooke celebrated Ash Wednesday mass yesterday in the Tombs, the Manhattan Men's House of Detention, dis tributed ashes to 100 inmates, and told them in a brief homily that we are all sinnerswe must be concerned for each other.

title: Wisconsin Town, Geared to Tourism, Divides Over Amish Values
description: NEW GLARUS, Wis.  This picturesque, hilly community on the Little Sugar River in southern Wisconsin has been trying hard for more than a decade, not without success, to attract tourist at tention with its pronounced Swiss personality. Now visi tors also ask about the area's newest residents, the 22 Older Am ish families, who have focused na tional interest on the village by winning a Wisconsin Supreme Court decision making them the first group in the coun try to be excused from com pulsory high school attend ance laws as a matter of religious freedom.

title: Pompidou Calls Advisers
description: PARIS, Feb. 24  President Pompidou called an emergency meeting of advisers at the Elyse Palace tonight to decide whether to fight the Algerian nationalizations or to yield as gracefully as possible.

title: RYE MAN IS ACCUSED OF RAPE AND MURDER
description: An accused rapist, kidnapper and killer was indicted yester day by a Bronx grand jury on 87 charges carrying maximum penalties of two life sentences and 1,074 years in prison.

title: Senate Approves Audit by State Of Books of Three Large Cities
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24After a tepid debate and with only one negative vote, the state Senate today approved a bill authoriz ing the State Controller to au dit the books of New York City, Buffalo and Rochester.

title: Echo and Tower Heighten Rapport In Nikolais Dances
description: It is difficult if not impossi ble to think of the Alwin Niko lais dancer without objects, usually ordinary things but with their potential for stage magic brought out. Tuesday evening the Nikolais Dance Theater presented Echo, Tower and a selection of short excerpts that displayed again Mr. Nikolais's special wizardry in inflecting mundane materials with his own special brand of human dance energy.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: SISAL, Yucatan, MexicoDawn was not far off, but in the dark recesses of our jungle lagoon the light was poor. Bluewinged teal were corning in by the dozens, dip ping and wheeling over our blind and over the decoys, but we could see them only when they were against the sky.

title: ZECKENDORF OFFERS NEW EAST SIDE PLAN
description: William Zeckendorf Sr., the real estate developer, has pro posed an alternate plan to the proposed expansion above the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive of major hospitals, medical schools and research institutions on Manhattan's East Side.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24In Chicago, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, one of the ablest black leaders in the country, is having trouble getting on the ballot to run as an independent candidate against Mayor Daley. The Board of Elections has ruled him out for not having enough nominating signatures, and the issue has gone to the courts.

title: Gore to Speak in Tenafly.
description: Former United States Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee will speak on Lessons from Viet nam, Cambodia and Laos at a meeting Monday night at 8:15 in the Tenafly (N. J.) High School auditorium. The lecture is being sponsored by the Tenafly Wom en for Peace in memory of Sara Blather, one of the group's founders.

title: Gov. Rockefeller on Schools
description: Two weeks ago Governor. Rockefeller warned that the Republicanbacked proposals for aid to nonpublic schools would be the first step to undermine, if notdestroy, the public school system. If those measures were adopted by the Legislature, he added, he would have to protect the State Constitution by exercising his veto power.

title: Bronx Airman Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The names of five United States servicemen killed in ac tion in the war in Southeast Asia were announced today by the Defense Department. Among them was Airman 1st Cl. Aaron Davis Jr. of the Bronx.

title: CastIronFront Building Is Heading for Museum
description: The tedious task of mount ing a fourstory museum piece to put it on exhibition was begun yesterday when a demolition crew, under the supervision of a noted archi tectural historian, began re moving the roof of a struc ture at Washington and Mur ra Streets.

title: Thant Rebukes Britain on South African Arms
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 24  Secretary General Thant rebuked Britain today for de ciding to supply helicopters to South Africa.

title: Market Place: Credibility Gap For Technicon
description: Technicon, the bloodanaly sis company that made its debut as a publicly owned concern amid great fanfare in early 1970, has since begun to develop a credibility gap in Wall Street.

title: Industry Urges Eliminating the Animal as Middleman to Get Cheaper Foods
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 24More nutritious, cheaper foods can now be created by elimi nating the animal as the middle man, food industry executives, told the Senate Nutrition Com mittee today.

title: Colombo Trial Prosecutor Calls Recanting by Witness Sinister
description: A Federal prosecutor yester day characterized the recant ing of testimony by his chief witness against Joseph Colombo Jr. as sinister.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES PERJURY CHARGES
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice has dismissed a fourcount indictment against a police lieutenant who was accused by a grand jury last July of per jury and criminal contempt.

title: ISRAEL TO REPLY: NO FULL PULLBACK
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 24, (UPI) Israel said today that in her reply to Egyptian peace pro posals she would formally re fuse total withdrawal from Arab areas seized in the six day war of 1967.

title: Eastern Wrestlers Wind it Down
description: Eastern college wrestling fans will have two straight weekends of action as the Eastern Intercollegiate Wres tling Association holds its annual tournament at the United States Naval Acad emy in Annapolis, Md., on March 5 and 6, followed by the National Collegiate District 2 qualifying tournament at Princeton on March 12 and 13.

title: U.S. Copter Will Carry Correspondents to Laos
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that news correspondents in South Vietnam would be per mitted aboard a specially des ignated helicopter to cover South Vietnamese and Amer ican operations in Laos.

title: Followers Here Protest
description: Thirty members of the Jewish Defense League protested the ouster of Rabbi Kahane from the Brussels conference yester day by occupying the offices of the American Jewish Con ference on Soviet Jewry at 55 West 42d Street. The confer ence Is sponsoring the Brus sels meeting.

title: DALEY ASSOCIATES KEEP COUNCIL GRIP
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 24 (UPI) Democrats associated with Mayor Richard J. Daley re tained their grip on the city council yesterday, winning at least 37 of 50 aldermanic seats.

title: N.Y.U. AIDE IS FOUND SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: The stabbed and garroted body of the art director of the New York University publica tions department was found late yesterday afternoon in his Brooklyn Heights apartment.

title: Soviet Ousts Bonn Aide
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has expel led a West German diplomat in apparent retaliation for a simi lar case involving a Soviet dip lomat in Bonn last year, it was disclosed here tonight. The West German Embassy an nounced that the diplomat, Dr. Immo Stabreit, had been asked to leave for activity incom patible with his diplomatic sta tus, but gave no details.

title: SEALE LOSES HIS BID FOR 11JUROR TRIAL
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 24 Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Hug gins lost their bid today to cut short jury selection and be tried before the 11 jurors cho sen so far  a request they said they made because they had run out of peremptory chal lenges and were no longer able to exclude biased persons from their jury.

title: Calley Testimony Excerpts
description: FORT BINNING, Ga., Feb. 24  Following are excerpts from crossexamination today of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.:

title: CLENDENON SIGNS $75,000 MET PACT
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 24  The New York Mets, sadder and presumably wiser young men, assembled today for the first time since Oct. 1, when they lost to the Chicago Cubs in Shea Stadium and finished the 1970 season in third place.

title: Drug Users Spur Malaria Revival
description: Hypodermic needles are ri valing mosquitos in spreading malaria in this country.

title: CORONA DISPUTE STIRS UP HEARING
description: Lingering antagonisms from the fight over plans to oust sev eral Corona families to make way for a school stirred an angry argument yesterday at a city budget hearing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We had been aware that many senior officers in the U.S. Army were dis pleased because Lieut. Louis Font, a West Point graduate, filed for consci entious objector status.

title: BARBARA COCHRAN WINS CUP SLALOM
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI)Barbara Coch ran of Richmond, Vt., one of the world's leading woman sla lom racers this year, won her specialty at the Heavenly Val ley World Cup Series today in the unofficial combined time of 1 minute 36.37 seconds.

title: JAN PROCHAZKA, FILM WRITER, DIES
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 24 (AP)Jan Prochazka, a noted Czecho slovak screen writer who ada mantly backed the reforms of 1968, was buried today. His funeral brought a mass turnout of sympathizers.

title: DR. JACOB HEYMAN
description: Dr. Jacob Heyman, an in ternist of Elizabeth, N. J., for mer assistant professor of clin ical medicine at New York Uni versity Medical Center, died Saturday at the center after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 330 West Jer sey Street, Elizabeth.

title: Sideshow at Geneva
description: The Geneva disarmament conference, which reconvened this week, is essentially a sideshow, something to keep the smaller powers occupied while the Big Two thrash out the larger disarmament issues in the bilateral SALT talks which are scheduled to resume on March 15 in Vienna. But the Geneva canfarence should be able to produce something more substantive than banning bac teriological weapons, as President Nixon has urged.

title: Stanley Court Tennis Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 Peter Stanley gained the final round of the Pierre Etchebaster Cup court tennis tournament today by defeating, a fellow Philadelphian, Jimmy Zug, 60, 62, at the Racquet Club. Dan Pierson will play Corning Pear son tomorrow for the other final berth.

title: A STATE RAIL UNIT SOUGHT IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24An As sembly committee recommend ed today the establishment of a state railroad corporation to maintain and improve passen ger service.

title: Edwin H. Guest Dies at 76; Led Miliworking Concern
description: NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 24 Edwin H. Guest, a millwork ing company executive, died last night after an automobile accident on Route 7 in Wilton, where he lived. He was 76 years old.

title: Corona Community Unit Upset By Limits on Holding Hearings
description: In the big, paneled back room at Jeantet's restaurant under the soft light of the fake Japa nese lanterns, the conversation at a table of 12 diners was getting louder and sharper.

title: Wyoming Legislator Killed
description: RAWLINS, Wyo., Feb. 24 (UPI)Mrs. Nancy Wallace, 59 years old, one of three women in the Wyoming House of Rep resentatives, was killed yester day when her car went out of control near Rawlins.

title: Tidal Wave of Babies Is Forecast by an Expert
description: A population expert said yes terday that the Unid States was at the beginning of a new tidal wave of babies.

title: Palmer, LowBall Hitter, In P.G.A. Spotlight Today
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 24Now that Arnold Palmer has returned to winning form, everyone concerned with the Professional Golfers As sociation championship begin ning here tomorrow is asking the same question: Can Arnie win this one?

title: Calley Says He Never Questioned Mylai Orders
description: FORT KENNING, Ga., Feb. 24 The defense rested in the murder trial of First Lieut. Wil liam L. Calley Jr. late today after the officer maintained under crossexamination that he was obeying orders when he shot South Vietnamese civilians during the socalled Mylai mas sacre three years ago.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON FINISH DAY MIXED
U.S. Seizes 54 in 4 Cities In Drive on Heroin Selling
description: Federal agents arrested 54 persons in four cities early yes terday in a massive assault on wholesale heroin dealers

title: Justice for the Campus.
description: The recent acquittal of Hobart College of charges brought by a special grand jury in Canandaigua, N. Y., finally ended an absurd distortion of criminal law. The college had been accused of having recklessly tolerated threats by students to riot unless three of their fellows were released from jail after a drug raid.

title: President Urges U.S. Set Product Safety Standards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 President Nixon asked Congress today to authorize mandatory Federal safety standards for consumer products.

title: A GAIN FOR QUARTER REPORTED BY SWIFT
description: Earnings of Swift & Co. in the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 30 rose 34 per cent over the preceding year, exceeding expectations, Robert W. Rene ker, president of the world's largest meat packer, told some 250 stoskholders at a twohour annual meeting in Boston yes terday.

title: Harvard Six Triumphs, 124
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 24Dan De Michele, scored four goals tonight and Joe Cavanagh scored one and had six assists to lead Harvard's hockey team to a 124 victory over Prince ton. Princeton, which has beaten Harvard in hockey only twice since 1953, is without a triumph in 10 Ivy League games.

title: Laos: View From the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Nixon Administration, along With everyone else here, rec ognized today that the long fuse of antiwar protest was moldering again in Congress and on the campuses, fanned in part by the skimpiness of the information from the battle field in Laos and the spreading impression that all is not well there. The Pentagon's re sponse was a 90 minute news con ference on the course of battle, offering some modest and vague claims of success and some careful warnings that more tough fighting lies ahead. Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird finally ended the exchange, long before the questions had run Out. As both the Secretary and some of the reporters made plain, concern about the Gov ernment's credibility was once again in the air.

title: Hanoi Notes Victories
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 24 (Agence FrancePress)De fense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap said last night that the Com munist victories in southern Laos constitute a severe warning to the American imperial ists against further escalation of the war.

title: Miss Ludwig Stars as Operas Switch
description: The midseason accidents and illnesses that customarily plague the Metropolitan Opera were drastic enough to re quire a switch in production on Tuesday night. Birgit Nilsson, a Rock of Gibraltar among singers, tore a liga ment in her foot in last Thursday's performance of Elektra  not surprisingly, considering the creviced floor of the set. She was still unable to tackle the strenuous title role of the Strauss opera in Tuesday night's scheduled repetition. Inge Borkh, who normally would have replaced her, had appeared the night before in Die Frau ohne Schatten, which made her unavailable.

title: MAX N. NATANSON, BUILDER IN CITY
description: Max N. Natanson, a major real estate developer, died yes terday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he was spending the winter, after a short illness. He was 84 years old and lived here at 146 Central Park West.

title: Dance: Reflections Has Premiere
description: Gerald Arpino, the princi pal choreographer for the City Center Joffrey Ballet, is an admirable fellow for many reasons, but two spe cial qualities make him one of those rare ideal choreog raphers to build up a reper tory. First, he is fluent. He obviously sets up appoint ments with his muse, and his muse keeps them. Second, he understands his dancers. Give him any group of dan cers and he will enable them to put their best feet for ward.

title: Environmental Ad Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) Sen. William B. Spong, Dem ocrat of Virginia, introduced today a bill to impose criminal sanctions for false advertising of environmental protection products.

title: Lindsay Cautions Runaway Concerns
description: Mayor Lindsay told a lunch eon audience of Harvard Busi ness School graduates yester day that he questioned the wis dom of company managers who moved their, operations from the city to the suburbs.

title: Chopin Played By Youra Guller In Carnegie Hall
description: Youra Guller, a pianist who enjoyed some renown in Europe in the period between the two World Wars, appearedout of the past, as it wereat Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night to play a recital.

title: Golar Says City Crime Level Exceeds That in Public Housing
description: Serious crime has been drastically lower in low income public housing proj ects here than in the city as a whole, according to Sim eon Golar, chairman of the City Housing Authority.

title: Change by U.S. Urged
description: Floyd D. Hall, chairman and chief executive officer of East ern Airlines, said yesterday the nation's airlines simply can not rely on a revived economy or hasty cutbacks in their own capacity to cure their economic ills.

title: Tuition Charges Are a Mistake
description: The decision of the trustees of the State University of New York to nearly double tuition fees at state col leges and universities over the next three or four years is an aggravation of a policy that is basically unsound and should never have been adopted in the first place.

title: Informer to Stand Trial
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP)  Joseph (Barboza) Baron, an underworld informer, was flown today by chartered airplane to Sonoma County, Calif., where he is to stand trial for murder. Baron, 37 years old, whose testimony in Massa chusetts led to the conviction of five persons on murder charges, was indicted in the death of Clayton R. Wilson, 27, whose body was found last October about 60 miles north of San Francisco.

title: STATE'S PRIMARY MOVED TO SEPT. 14 FROM JUNE DATE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24The Leg islature approved a Sept. 14 primary date today despite Democratic charges that the Republican majorities in both houses were trying to undo the permanent spring primary re form enacted in 1965.

title: Schwarzkopf Recital Off
description: Elisabeth Schwarzkopf's re cital scheduled for Philharmonic Hall on Sunday afternoon has been canceled because of her illness. Refunds will be made at the Philharmonic Hall box office.

title: MONETARY RESERVE HELD BY U.S. GROWS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Total United States interna tional monetary reserve assets rose by $212million in January to $14,699,000,000, thanks en tirely to the receipt of the sec ond allocation of Special Draw ing Rights, or paper gold, from the International Mone tary Fund.

title: Looking for Furniture LowIncome Families Can Afford
description: What's the most suitable furniture for families with annual incomes of under $5,000? How can it be man ufactured and sold at prices they can afford?

title: TradeBloc Talks Proposed for U.S.
description: The Nixon Administration was urged yesterday to begin parallel negotiations now to prevent damage to American trade interests likely with Brit ish entry into the European Economic Community (Common Market).

title: Administration Under Pressure to Take a Stronger Stand on the White Regimes in Southern Africa
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Congressional and other critics of American policy to ward whitedominated southern Africa are increasing pressures on the Nixon Administration for a change.

title: Route 9 in Laos Still Closed
description: KHESANH, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 (AP)Brig. Gen. Pham Van Phu, commander of the South Vietnamese First In fantry Division, said today that Route 9 in Laos remained closed to supply missions be cause of North Vietnamese ambushes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kahane, Barred by Parley, Is Ousted From Belgium
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 24Rabbi Meir Kahane, the controver sial leader of the Jewish De fense League, was expelled from Belgium today after he had been refused admittance to a conference of Jewish or ganizations on the situation of Soviet Jews. The rabbi, who was convicted yesterday in New York of having pro voked demonstrations against the Soviet mission to the United Nations, arrived here this morning to press his ac tivist viewpoint. After having been barred from the meet ing, he was detained 10 hours by the Belgian police for questioning and was then forced to depart on a plane to London. Sam Shoshan, a spokesman of the Jewish De fense League, who was de tained with the rabbi, was allowed to remain in Belgium. Rabbi Kahane's expulsion threw the conference into an uproar, embarrassed its organizers and sharpened a split between a majority favoring peaceful pres sure on the Soviet Government to improve the lot of Jews and those who think that violence is necessary.

title: Ousted Alter Sitting In at Coop, Relief Families Occupy Church
description: Twenty welfare families that moved into an uncompleted apartment house on the West Side on Sunday and were later evicted by the police, moved last night into the Harlem church that sponsored the con struction of the apartment, house.

title: Apollo 15 Set for July 26; Mission Will Last 12 Days
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI)The Apollo 15 launching date has been changed to July 26, and the mission has been lengthened to 12 days, accord ing to the latest tentative flight plan calculations, the space, agency said today.

title: India's Fight on Population Snagged
description: TOONGA, India, Feb. 19The old woman, her ankles ringed with heavy silver bangles, has for years been the midwife in this poor farm ing village in the North India state of Rajasthan. She ad mits to being over 50, but her skin, wrinkled into lined, brown parchment by decades in the sun, says she is much older.

title: Big Board Backs a Shift In Capital Rules on Firms
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its governing board had approved a series of broad changes regulating the capital structure of its member firms.

title: A $19Million Trust Suit Upheld for Zenith Radio
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today in favor of the Zenith Radio Corporation in its $19million antitrust suit against Hazeltine Research, Inc., a subsidiary of the Hazel tine Corporation, and others. The court reversed a Court of Appeals ruling that a trial judge had made a mistake in rejecting Hazeltine Research's claim that damages should be reduced.

title: 4 Cuban Fishing Vessels Are Captured Off Florida
description: KEY WEST, Fla., Feb. 24 (AP)  Four 50foot Cuban fishing boats were seized south of the Dry Tortugas tonight by Federal and Florida authorities, state officials reported.

title: OFFICIAL ASKS RISE IN REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 24A net increase of nearly $200million in Gov. Ronald Reagan's proposed $7.6billion budget for California was urged today in a report by the nonpartisan legislative analyst.

title: J. C. Penney Sales and Profits Advanced for Fourth Quarter
PRIME RATE IS CUT TO 6.5% IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, Feb. 24At the prodding of the central bank Canada's commercial banks cut their prime interest rate to 6.5 per cent today, the Canadian dollar eased and foreign exchange trading and bond prices rose sharply.

title: JAILED AMERICAN FREED BY PRAGUE
description: AMSTERDAM, The Nether lands, Feb. 24 (AP)  A young American was freed from a Czechoslovak prison today aft er serving seven months of a fouryear sentence.

title: Swiss Avant Garde Echoes the Trend
description: At first hearing, The Swiss Avant Garde, the title of the show that opened yesterday at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, has the ring of a contradic tion in terms: But think back.

title: Insiders'
description: The New York and American Stock Exchange yesterday reported on the latest changes in stock ownership by major shareowners, directors and of ficers of listed corporations. The lists include the following:

title: G.M. NAMES PANEL ON ENVIRONMENT
description: DETROIT, Feb. 24  The General Motors Corporation an nounced today that it had set up a committee of six scien tists to advise the company on the environmental effects of its products and operations.

title: Mistakes Are Made to Be Forgotten
description: Twenty years ago this month, Nat Holman gathered several of his City College basketball players round him on the platform at Penn Station. During the trip from Philadelphia, detectives from the New York District Attor ney's office had approached Holman and asked him turn over the boys quietly. Now, gesturing at the waiting detectives, Holman said: I don't know what the story is, but if your conscience is clear, have no fears. Tell the truth and don't back up from anyone.

title: Changes Proposed for Campaign Spending and Absentee Voting
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Two Democratic Senators with Presidential ambitions made separate proposals today to re shape the 1972 national cam paign.

title: Fordham Marquette Gives Luster to Garden Tonight
Manhattan Track Victor, Ending St. John's Streak
description: Sparked by Tom Donahue and John Lovett, Manhattan's brash band of runners burst out of a morass of confusion last night and stole the Metropoli tan Intercollegiate indoor track championship from St. John's grasp.

title: Bridge: Brilliant Defensive Play Helps To Defeat Makable Contract
description: Two players at the Kis sena Bridge Club in Flush ing, Queens, were, subject to confirmation, the winners of the Greater New York Bridge Association's unitwide game played Sunday at 12 differ ent centers. They were Ralph Goldberg of New York and Milton Kassman of: Great Neck, L. I. with a score of 69.05 per cent.

title: D. &
description: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., which for almost a century has been rating the financial capacity and creditstanding of Ameri can business, announced yes terday the most significant changes in the process since it began employing such little known credit reporters as Abraham Lincoln.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: An increasingly common argument against public aid to parochial schools was repeated by Governor Rockefeller on Feb. 8. The argument is that tuition grants to private schools would encourage white parents in both the North and South to send their children to segregated white schools.

title: Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: College President Named
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24 (AP)The trustees of the State Univer sity of New York today ap proved the appointment of Dr. Alfred B. Light as president of Clinton County Community College in Plattsburgh, effec tive immediately. Dr. Light, 46 years old, has been vice presi dent and dean of Adirondack Community College in Glens Falls. He will be paid $23,500 a year in the new post.

title: Colonel Amends Remarks
description: SAIGON, Feb. 24 (AP) Lieut. Col. Le Trung Hien, the South Vietnamese military spokesman, today amended his statement of yesterday that Saigon's forces had no intention right now of advancing any farther in Laos.

title: Snyder &
description: Henry M. Snyder & Co., Inc., the export sales organization for more than 100 American book and magazine publishers, has received President Nixon's E award for its high level of exports relative to the United States publishing industry.

title: PRINCIPALS SCORE EDUCATION BOARD
description: The High School Principals Association accused the Board of Education and its Chancellor yesterday of undercutting the authority of school principals and thus permitting lawless ness in the city's schools.

title: Union College Names Aides
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Feb. 24 (AP)  Union College pro moted Bruce Allison today to athletic director and Gerry Evening to head football coach.

title: Volpe Warns of New Nixon Action on Construction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Transportation Secretary John, A. Volpe suggested today that President Nixon would take further action to curb the up ward spiral of wages and prices in the construction industry if labor and management did not soon reach voluntary agree ment to do so.

title: 18 Seized in Hospital SitIn
description: The police arrested 18 em ployes of the Hebrew Hospital for the Chronic Sick in the Bronx yesterday after an eighthour sitin over a demand for a wage increase. The 18, all members of Local 144, Ho tel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Employes, A.F.L. CIO., were arrested at 3 P.M. when the police were sum moned to the hospital at 1776 Clay Avenue. All were booked at the Bathgate Avenue sta tion on charges of criminal tresspassing and harassment.

title: F. JOSEPH O'HARE
description: AVON, N.J., Feb. 24F. Jo seph O'Hare, a former chair man of the Hudson County Board of Freeholders and presi dent of the Peoples Security Savings and Loan Association of Harrison, died yesterday at his home, 408 Sylvania Ave nue. He was 82 years old.

title: Suit by Gig Young Denied
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP)Superior Court denied yesterday the nonpaternity suit of Gig Young, the actor, who contended he was not the, father of a girl born in 1964 to his fourth wife, Elaine.

title: G.I.'s in Vietnam Get Heroin Easily
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24It is so easy to buy heroin from peddlers in Viet nam wherever there are American troops or convoys that a tiny plastic vial can be purchased for $3 outside the headquarters of an Amer ican general.

title: SUIT ON WELFARE FILED BY LINDSAY
description: Mayor Lindsay personally filed a lawsuit for the city yes terday against the Federal and state governments to have man dated welfare costs declared unconstitutional.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Committee Is Endangered
description: LONDON, Feb. 24Britain's decision to go ahead with lim ited arms sales to South Africa threatened tonight to kill a spe cial Commonwealth committee on Indian Ocean security. cial Commonwealth committee on Indian Ocean security.

title: Shellls Fined $340,000 For Safety Violations
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP)The Shell Oil Com pany, which is fighting an offshore oil well fire in the Gulf of Mexico, was fined $340,000 in Federal District Court here today in connec tion with charges that it failed to have safety devices on some other wells in the Gulf.

title: State Department Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The State Department said today that the United States was pleased the Czecho slovak Government had re leased Mr. Eidlin.

title: High Vatican Official Arrives In Soviet to Endorse Atom Pact
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24  The hig estranking Vatican official to ?? the Soviet Union ar rived today to endorse the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons and to resume the Holy See's dialogue with the Kremlin.

title: Advertising:
description: Joseph Monserrat, who should know as much if not more than anyone about the Puerto Rican community, is prepared to share that knowledge.

title: Pennsy Sees Debt Pact
description: The Penn Central Company which conceded earlier this week that it was in technical default on certain obligations of a European subsidiary, ex pects to announce in the next few days, possibly by tomor row, that agreement has been reached to extend the maturi ties of the debt involved.

title: H.E.W.'s Own Women's Rights Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24And now, with the official blessing of Elliot L. Richard son, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, there is a women's rights group in the Federal Government.

title: SHORTLINE REPORTS IS PUNISHED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the investment adviser registration of Shortline Reports, Inc., New York. Among other things, the S.E.C. accused the company of false and misleading advertis ing.

title: Screen:
description: The sky is an absolute azure. In the heat, the two lane macadam highway has a life of its own. It actually seems to undulate across the valley, over the mounds of purplish lava left by the small, perfect cones of once active volcanoes.

title: 14 Uptown Schools Boycotted To Protest Construction Delay
description: All 14 schools in District 6, which covers parts of Harlem and Upper Manhattan, were closed yesterday when the en tire student body of more than 16,000 elementary and junior high school pupils stayed home.

title: Spanish Court Ruling Curtails Effects of Scandal
description: MADRID, Feb. 24  The spreading political effects of the Matesa case  Spain's big gest financial scandal  were cut short today when the Su preme Court decided to issue no further indictments.

title: Ellis Leach, ExChairman Of Textile Manufacturer
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., Feb. 24 Kills Leach, who retired in 1966 as chairman of Collins & Aikman Corporation, makers of upholstery and apparel fabrics, died yesterday in Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 1001 First Avenue.

title: 180 Die in Brazil's Carnival
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24 (Reuters)  More than 180 people died in Brazil's fourday carnival, which ended last night, but police said that it was less disorderly than in pre vious years. The deaths came from road accidents, fights and other causes as hundreds of thousands took to the streets in dancing and merrymaking in Rio and other Brazilian cities.

title: Jersey Student Found Dead
description: RUIDOSO, N. M., Feb. 24 (UPI)Searchers who fought through snowdrifts have found the body of Wayne Seagriff, 19 years old, a college student from Pompton Plains, N. J., in a canyon here.

title: West German 7YearOld Held for $54,000 Ransom
description: BONN, Feb. 24 (AP)Leftist terrorists have kidnapped a 7yearold boy as a hostage for the release of a jailed leftist lawyer and $54,000 ransom, au thorities said today.

title: Governors Rebuffed on Fund Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A delegation of Governors was re buffed today by Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the chairman of the Huase Ways and Means Committee, when they tried to persuade him to support Presi dent Nixon's revenuesharing program.

title: Peter Schumann's Giant Puppets Provide a Spooky Experience
description: In the past, I have seen Peter Schumann's Bread and Puppet Theater only in pass ing, at rallies or demonstra tionsand it seemed a men acing presence, like the liv ing dead Come to haunt us with reenactments of our transgressions.

title: Forest Hills Judge Convinced Craft's Is the Show of Shows
description: The huge number of dogs and tremendous crowds, at Cruft's overwhelmed James W. Trullinger of Forest Hills, Queens, who had the distinc tion of being the only all rounder (qualified to judge all breeds) among the 342 American fanciers who flew to London from New York on the recent Dog Fanciers Club tour. West minster is far more comforta ble for the spec tator, said Trullinger in comparing the British and American classics. At the Garden you can sit upstairs and get a good overall view. At Olympia, the show is held in two hallsGrand and Na tionalwith enormous bal conies.

title: LINDSAY IS URGED TO REMAIN IN G.O.P.
description: Two liberal Republican Rep resentatives went to City Hall yesterday to try to persuade Mayor Lindsay not to desert his party.

title: LUCIUS D. TOMPKINS, A UNIROYAL OFFICER
description: Lucius D. Tompkins, a for mer vice president and execu tive officer of Uniroyal, Inc., formerly the United States Rubber Company, died Tues day at his home in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Construction Unions Win
description: After all the brave talk of a wagdprice freeze to halt runaway inflation in construction costs, Prdsident Nixon has come up with an alternative so modest that it borders on political surrender to the hard hats in the building unions.

title: Suit Here Calls for Destruction Of Secret Passport Office File
description: A suit filed yesterday calls for prohibiting and destroying a secret surveillance file of 243,135 names in the State De partment Passport Office.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lockheed Postpones Talks With Its Airlines Customers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The Lockheed Air craft Corporation said today it had postponed its scheduled Friday meeting in New York with its L1011 jet airline cus tomers until March 5.

title: BUSINESS WARNS CITY ON PENSIONS
description: A delegation of business lead ers urged Mayor Lindsay yes terday not to grant improved pensions to the uniformed serv ices with which the city is ne gotiating new contracts.

title: Poland Announces Shifts in Research And Apprenticeship
description: WARSAW, Feb. 24  Po lish authorities announced ma jor reforms in the education and research fields today to improve the efficiency of an uneven economy.

title: An Expert in Counterintelligence
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Army, although on the receiving end, had reason to day to be proud of Chris topher Howland Pyle, a for mer captain of military in telligence.

title: Chileans In Series At Hunter
description: The Chilean Chamber Or chestra, in its United States debut at Hunter College Play house Tuesday night, made a good impression in a program that ranged from a Baroque sonata for strings by Albinoni to Celso GarridoLecca's An taras, a 1969 piece for dou ble quartet and double bass. The 13member group, led by Fernando Rosas produced a cohesive, cultivated tone at all times, and its ensemble teamwork testified to much serious preparation.

title: Prices on Amex Move Ahead as Rally Continues
Richard Ettinger, PrenticeHall Cofounder, Dies
description: Richard Prentice Ettinger, cofounder and chairman emeritus of PrenticeHall, Inc., publishers of books and busi ness and professional informa tion services, died yesterday, in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 77 years old and lived in South Norwalk, Conn.

title: JUSTICES NARROW A CRIME DECISION BY WARREN COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Supreme Court split along con servativeliberal lines today in a 5to4 ruling that limited the effect of Miranda v. Arizona, the Warren Court's landmark decision that restricted police interrogation.

title: Dr. Thornton Roby, 46, Dies; Tufts Psychology Professor
