description: NORTH READING, Mass., Feb. 24Dr. Thornton B. Roby, professor of psychology at Tufts University, died yester day in Boston, after a long ill ness. He was 46 years old.

title: Vietcong Warn U.S. It Risks Peking's Intervention
description: ROME, Feb. 24  The chief Vietcong delegate to the Paris peace talks, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, charged today that the United States was preparing a new military adventure against North Vietnam.

title: Heart Recipient Doing Well
description: STANFORD, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI)  Stanford University Medical Center's 29th heart transplant recipient, Harry Knudson, 47 years old, of Pleasant Hill, Calif., was in satisfactory condition today. He received the heart of Jack Nye, 26, of San Jose, Calif., Monday. Mr. Nye had died of injuries suffered in a motor cycle accident.

title: PINCAY RIDES VICTOR FOR 17TH DAY IN ROW
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (AP)  Laffit Pincay, Jr., rode a winner for the 17th consecu tive racing day at Santa Ante today, breaking a track record of 16 set in 1947 by Johnny Longden.

title: Giving Guests Reason to Forgo Cocktails
description: To judge from the number of times the question is put to those who work professionally with wines and food, the question of whether cocktails are prop erly served before a meal with fine wines is persistent.

title: Britain Moves to Keep Out Commonwealth Migrants
description: LONDON, Feb. 24  The British Government, in another symbolic break with the im perial past, moved today to clamp down hard on the right of Commonwealth citizens to settle here.

title: L. L U. Beats C. W. Post
Republican Assembly Caucus Is Told Of Possible Cuts in Proposed Budget
description: ALBANY, Feb 24  Legisla tive fiscal experts today out lined $300million worth of items in Governor Rockefeller's proposed budget that might be cut.

title: Radio Station Run by Students Marks 30th Year at Columbia
description: Columbia. University's radio station, WKCR, which matured during the 1968 campus disturb ances on Morningside Heights, became 30 years old yesterday.

title: Only Radio Will Carry Nixon's Message Live
description: President Nixon's 20min ute address on foreign policy will be carried live at 11 A.M. today on radix only here.

title: THREE FIRMS AGREE TO SETTLE IN SUITS
description: Abraham L. Pomerantz, counsel for customers of Rob inson & Co., Blair & Co. and the First Devonshire Corpora tion, announced yesterday that his clients had agreed with the New York Stock Exchange to settlements of their lawsuits against the exchange.

title: Books of The Times
description: Prologue. It is the first Sunday in April, 1970, sunny, fresh, alive. Will the man here called The Spectator therefore hike or bicycle or skim a Frisbee with children or perhaps even rake up the winter litter from the yard? No, he will not. He will glance at the TV schedules in The Sunday Times, descend to the gloom of his basement, and catch a little sports on television. Six hours worth, to be precise. He will begin at 1:30 P.M. with an exhibition baseball game be tween the New York Nets and the Minnesota Twins, and not mind in the least the green haze surrounding players the height of highball glasses swinging bats no thicker than swiz zle sticks. At 2:00 he will switch to a basketball game between the New York Knickerbockers and the Baltimore Bullets and absorb along the way the news that Vitalis can help keep the greaseball out of basketball. Later, before his very eyes, Gary Player will win $36,000 in the Greater Greensboro Open golf tournament. But under no circum stance will The Spectator look in on an actor named Horst Buchholz killing a moose in Alberta, Canada. Eventually, The Spectator will emerge from his cellar. It will be dark.

title: Chess: A Repetitive. Opening Helps Bilek in Hungarian Tourney
WERNER LEHNBERG, COMMODITY BROKER
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 24 Werner Lehnberg, a former chairman of the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, died in an automobile accident last night on the Saw Mill River Parkway in Yonkers. He was 65 years old and lived at 5 Ludlow Drive.

title: ECONOMISTS URGE WIDER '72 DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Two more noted economists urged President Nixon today to swing his budget for the fiscal year 1972 into deficit even on the full employment basis of measurement, probably enlarg ing the estimated actual deficit of $11.6billion.

title: A SHIFT REPORTED IN SURVEILLANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A former captain of military in telligence asserted today that an intelligence unit in the Jus tice Department had sup planted an Army counterintel ligence detachment as the Government's principal watch dog on political protest.

title: Longden, 64, Announces Retirement as Trainer
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 24 (UPI)  Johnny Longden an nounced his retirement as a trainer last night after four years of conditioning horses for Frank McMahon of Canada.

title: Now Ana??; Transit Pact Roadblock; '62 Port Authority Covenant Is Said To Bar Accord of Two Governors
description: Governor Rockefeller and Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey announced with, pride Tuesday that they, had reached an agree ment to try to force the Port of New York Authority to spend some of its funds on rail transportation.

title: Robert Wilson Play, Deafman, Opening
description: Robert Wilson, a 27yearold softspoken Texan, has planted 676 telephone poles into the ground as a com mission from a religious in stitution in Loveland, Ohio. He hopes to engage 30 per sons in building a wall near Johnson City, Tex., over the next few years. Last year, his unconventional theater piece, The Life and Times of Sigmund Freud, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, caused a stir in the artistic underground.

title: TV: N.E.T.'s Revival of Paradise Lost by Odets
description: In effect there were two men named Clifford Odets. The dramatist carved his lasting niche as a writer of plays about the oppressive economic conditions in the early 1930's; these he im parted to the youthfully com mitted Group Theater, which has never had its peer as a unified acting company in the American theater. The driving excitement and verve are still remembered. The second Odets was the writer. in Hollywood, consumed by the ruthless insensitive eco nomics that he knew only too well.

title: AIR RESERVE UNITS TO GET NEW PLANES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) A number of Air Force Re serve and Air National Guard units will be reorganized and receive newer aircraft, includ ing the first F4 Phantom jets to be turned over to the Guard, the Air Force announced today.

title: Pentagon Prohibits Dumping Weapons And Gas in Ocean
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, in a move to protect the environment, banned today the dumping of obsolete gas and explosive weapons into the ocean.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Grant for Computer Work
description: The National Science Founda tion yesterday announced grant of $1,465,000 for the es tablishment of a center in New York that will do research on applying computer technology to economics and management science. The center will be set up by the National Bureau of Economic Research in collabora tion with scientists at various universities.

title: ANOTHER INMATE IS SUICIDE IN CELL
description: A drug addict hanged him self in his cell on Rikers Is land yesterday  several hours before the city, in an unrelat ed action, obtained a court or der to show cause why certi fied addicts should not be trans ferred from city jails to state facilities.

description: LONDON, Feb. 24  On the eve of President Nixon's sec ond message on the state of the world, a survey on the reaction to his first essay in the form shows mixed regard and skepti cism.

title: MAIN ALLIED BASE OF LAOS DRIVE HIT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Feb. 25The main allied rear base for the South Vietnamese drive in Laos was shelled by enemy gunners last night for the first time since the operation began.

title: RICHARD P. O'ROURKE
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 24Richard P. O'Rourke, chair man of the board of the Wo burn Chemical Corporation of Harrison, died yesterday in his home at 210 Lenox Avenue at the age of 77.

title: JOHN NUVEEN &
description: John Nuveen & Co., Inc., an investment banking concern acquired in September, 1969 by Investors Diversified Serv ices, Inc., reported yesterday that earnings amounted to $1.77million in 1970, its sec ond most profitable year since World War II.

title: Laos and the Old Illusions
description: So this time it is Laos. On and on it goes: Who would have thought that instead of the light at the end of the tunnel we would have found a tunnel at the end of the tunnel. The rationalizations are familiar: shorten the war, bring the troops home quicker, protect American lives, improve the morale of the South Vietnamese Gov ernment, serve notice on Hanoi of the seriousness of our intent.

title: High Court Widens the Protection of the Press Against Libel Suits by Political Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Supreme Court widened to day the constitutional protec tion of the press against libel suits by politicians.

title: Two Arrested on Culebra
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 24 (UPI)  United States Navy sources said today Federal mar shals had arrested two persons in restricted areas of Culebra Island and dispersed six small boats in the same general area. The Navy has been carrying on a running battle with demon strators who are seeking to force the Navy to give up its firing range on the island.

title: Van Alen Beats MacDonald To Advance in Court Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24James L. Van Alen Jr. of Phila delphia gained the quarter final round of the United States amateur courttennis champion ship by defeating Robert S. MacDonald of New York, 56, 63, 62, 46, 64, today at the Racquet Club.

title: Miss Casals Easy Victor In National Indoor Tennis
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 24 (UPI)Rosmary Casals breezed to a 61, 62 victory over Vale rie Ziegenfuss in the first round of the $12,500 women's na tional indoor tennis champion ships today.

title: Ballet: Two by Joffrey
description: Two ballets, contrasting in mood, had their first per formance of the season Tues day night at the City Center where the City Center Jof frey began the second week of its current sixweek en gagement.

title: Melee Disrupts Classes In Brooklyn High School
description: Classes at Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn were disrupted for 45 minutes yes terday after a fight broke out in the school cafeteria and rampaging students smashed several windows and display cases.

title: An Economic Team From Chile Puts Its Case in Washington for Continued Investment by Foreigners
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 An economic team representing Chile's new Socialist govern ment bid here today for con tinued public and private for eign investment.

title: COURT EXTENDS CONVICTS RIGHTS
description: A decision that substantially advances the rights of prison inmates was issued yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals here.

title: ADOLPH WEISS DIES; BASSOONIST WAS 79
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., Feb. 24Adolph Weiss, bassoonist and composer, died Sunday in a hos pital here after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Panther Trial Scheduled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 (UPI)Federal Judge Samuel Conti today set May 3 for the trial of the Black Panther chief of staff; David Hilliard, on charges of threatening the life of President Nixon in a speech at a Vietnam war moratorium rally in Golden Gate Park Nov. 15, 1969.

title: FIGHT IS PRESSED BY HOMOSEXUALS
description: A group of homosexuals known as the Gay Activists Alliance filed suit in New York Supreme Court yesterday to re quire the state's Secretary of State to grant them a certificate of incorporation.

title: Polaroid Ousts a Black Leader Of Boycott Over South Africa
description: A young chemist of the Pola roid Corporation said yesterday that she had been dismissed for organizing a boycott of the company's products to protest its business dealings in South Africa.

title: Canadian Expert Doubts China Seeks Expansion
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 24 (Cana dian Press)  Chester A. Ron ning, an Asia expert and re tired Canadian diplomat, said today that he was convinced that Communist China did not wish to expand beyond its pres ent borders.

title: Laird Says Laos Drive Adheres to Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 24The Secretary of Defense and a sen ior military aide insisted today that South Vietnamese forces had deliberately paused in the Offensive in Laos rather than being bogged down as a result of enemy attacks.

title: Swoon's Flower Wins
description: MIAMI, Feb. 24  A success by Howard Sams Swoon's Flower in the $63,200 Black Helen Handicap, a Hialeah record perfecta payoff of $4, 615.40 and a smashing defeat of a highly rated Flamingo prospect entertained the crowd of 18,198 at Hialeah today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24  Marty, who had entered politics, said, Come have lunch with me, dear old beloved goodhearted decent friend. Who could refuse? Even though Two barely remembered Marty, as a rather dim figure in the yearbook with too much hair oil, the papers said he was Presidential timber and one of the newsmagazines had even said Presi dential timber trying to become Presi dential plastic.

title: McDonnell Enters Con Edison's Labor Dispute
description: The chairman of the State Mediation Board entered the dispute yesterday involving a threatened strike against the Consolidated Edison Company, on March 11.

title: Parity for Jersey Linked to Transit Pact

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP)  President Nixon and key aides. met today with seven Negro leaders to discuss the Administration's 1971 domestic program.

He said: I think that any time there is pressure to have someone whose views are not popular silenced, it is very, very bad, not just for myself but for the general process of democracy.

title: Verbanic Adds Irony to Yanks'
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24  Little personal dramas, of little moment ex cept to those directly in volved, surround every base ball training camp. Around the exceptionally peaceful New York Yankee camp right now, a miniirony involves Fritz Peterson and Joe Ver banic.

title: WagePrice Guide Offered
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) A wageprice guidepost for mula designed to reduce the inflation rate to 2 per cent by early 1973 was offered today by the National Planning Asso ciation, a nonprofit economic research organization.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) President Nixon will fly to Des Moines next Monday for the first of a series of regional meetings aimed to promote his 1971 legislative program.

title: 17 QUEENS TEACHERS WIN REINST ATEMENT
description: Seventeen teachers who were transferred to other schools for joining parents in a boycott of Intermediate School 142 in Ja maica, Queens, have been rein stated in their Jamaica classes, a mediation panel announced yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The President and the Secretary of Defense have tried mightily to sell the public on their winding down of the war. But let's look at the facts, as Mr. Nixon would say.

description: CAIRO, Feb. 24 (Reuters)The United Arab Republic said today that it might resume fighting with Israel unless the Israeli Government produced positive peace moves.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 24 (AP)The Newark Teachers Union was fined $50,000 today for violat ing a court order prohibiting it from striking.

title: Increased Pressure Seen
description: LONDON, Feb. 24  The Algerian assumption of ma jority control of French oil companies in the Sahara was seen by oil experts in London tonight as increasing the pres sure on American and British companies negotiating in Libya.

title: Through 'The Body,' With Music
description: The newspaper ads for "The Body," which feature a picture of a probably nude couple sort of embracing, along with a selection of really high-toned testimonials from M.D.'s, Ph.D.'s and various upper media types, might suggest a certain dichotomy in the minds of the film's distributors as to how to make their product salable. I think the dichotomy derives from the film itself, which touches almost all sensational body bases in a mad, pretentious, mostly futile attempt to hold together birth and death, sex and science, the heart, the lungs, the liver and the large intestine. It opened yesterday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, and it is an aggressively awful movie.At the center of "The Body" sits a cast, unidentified, but more or less a cross-section of bodies of various ages and sexes and types, mostly dressed in terrycloth bathrobes and mostly occupied in holding serious impromptu discussions and in sensitizing one another. Around the edges of "The Body" are convalescent hospitals, a couple making love, various polluted rivers, a few plastic models showing internal organs and several living, palpitating internal organs themselves  photographed from the inside."The Body" makes rather a thing of taking its audience places they have never been and may very well never wish to go. Thus, you may accompany a mouthful of air down the esophagus and follow a bit of lunch through the large intestine. My favorite of these adventures among the vital functions is the passing of urine into the bladderwhich is backed by some unusually deep rapture-of-the-deep music, as if it were all part of the Undersea World of Jacques Cousteau. Which is what you might expect from a movie that places a string quartet behind its red corpuscles, and over the figures of its love-making couple has the voices of Vanessa Redgrave and Frank Finlay stage-whisper: "What is it men in women do require? The lineaments of gratified desire . . ."The practice of never leaving well enough alone is raised to an esthetic principle in "The Body," and this in large measure accounts for the film's special offensiveness. It might be possible to grant the good intentions of the film-makers (not really), but never their good judgment. They have made a massive effort to balance youth and age, pain and pleasure, natural childbirth and equally natural senility. And yet "The Body" is always out of balance, precious, disproportionate, grotesquelike a vain attempt at humanistic harmony by some opportunistic offshoot of the gothic imagination.

title: The Mystery of No. 990
description: Earlier this month, the Internal Revenue Service on orders from highranking officials of the Treasury Department recalled thousands of copies of a new tax form, No. 990, before they could be trucked away for distribution. The new form would have required certain taxexempt organizations such as labor unions, chambers of commerce and trade associations to file a detailed description of their political or lobbying activities.

title: LTV GETS OFFER FOR OKONITE CO.
description: LingTemcoVought, Inc., an nounced yesterday it had re ceived a proposal to sell its 100 per cent stock ownership in the Okonite Company to Omega Alpha, Inc., for $40.5million.

title: Title Figure Skating Won By Soviet Pair
Economic Index Advances
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The composite index of lead ing indicators of economic activity rose further in January to its highest point in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: More Executives Becoming Workers for Planned Parenthood
description: Family planning started out as a women's movement because, back in 1912, when Margaret Sanger coined the phrase birth control, most men considered it indelicate. Furthermore, many saw fam ily planning as ?? threat to the natural rights of their sex.

title: Executive Changes
description: American Standard Inc., announced yester day the election of Wil liam A. Marquard, 50 years old, as president. He succeeds William D. Eberle, 48 years old, who was made chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Marquard, who was previously senior execu tive vice president and chief operating officer, will continue in the lat ter position. In making the announcement, Mr. Eberle said, This new organization broadens and deepens the top man agement and will pro vide flexibility to con centrate on the various aspects of our enlarged operations. The office of chairman has been vacant since 1968 when Joseph Grazier retired.

title: Advertising:
description: Do you feel that you didn't get your share of freebies last year? Are you sore? Feel discriminated against? Well don't.

title: Nixon Proposes a Job Plan To Get 225,000 Off Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Administration revised its stalled welfare reform program today to include an $800 million plan to put 225,000 Federal welfare recipients into city and state public jobs. John G. Veneman, Under Sec retary of Health, Education and Welfare, presented the new family assistance pro gram to the House Ways and Means Committee in an effort to get President Nixon's pri ority legislation moving in Congress.

title: A PANTHER LAWYER CITED FOR CONTEMPT
description: Sanford M. Katz, one of the defense lawyers in the trial here of 13 Black Panthers, was cited for contempt of court yesterday and sentenced to a fine of $250 or 30 days in jail for being too sarcastic.

title: So. Africa Bars Ashe 3d Time, Calls Him Persona Non Grata
description: CAPETOWN, Feb. 24South Africa rejected today a visa application by Arthur Ashe, the black American tennis star.

title: SEVER FUTURES SHOW PRICE DIP
description: The pace of silver futures trading increased sharply yes terday to 3,956 contracts from 2,810 on Tuesday. Much of the activity centered on the nearby March delivery. Prices moved down a little perhaps because disappointed holders of long positions in silver were selling to settle their accounts.

title: Blackout on Staten Island
description: A blackout affected 200 homes in the Westerleigh sec tion of Staten Island yesterday. It was caused by a blown junc tion fuse, a spokesman for the Consolidated Edison Company said. The fuse went out of serv ice shortly before 2:30 P.M. Service was restored at 3:40 P.M. The spokesman said he did not know what caused the trouble.

title: HEBERT DENOUNCES C.B.S.PENT AGONSOW
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisi ana, chairman of the House I Armed Services Committee, to day accused the Columbia Broadcasting System of one lof the mast horrible examples lof antimilitary presentation he had ever heard of, in a doc umentary called The Selling of the Pentagon.

title: STREET ACADEMY FACES NEW LOSS
description: Three more corporate spon sors are considering an end to their financial support of the New York Urban League's street academy program, ac cording to the league's execu tive director, Livingston L. Win gate.

title: Police Triple Anticorruption Forces
description: The number of New York policemen assigned to rooting out corruption in the depart ment has almost tripled in the last year and will be increased even more during the next few months.

description: VIETIANE, Laos, Feb. 25 (AP) The Defense Ministry today reported five skirmishes be tween North Vietnamese sol diers and Laotian troops around Dong Hene, on Route 9, about 75 miles west of the South Vietnamese operation.

title: NARCOTICS ARRESTS ROSE 49.2% IN 1970
description: Narcotics arrests here in creased 49.2 per cent in 1970, the Police Department report ed yesterday. A total of 52,479 narcotics arrests were made last year, compared with 37, 178 in 1969.

title: Col. Albert Gilmor, Fought In Philippine Insurrection
description: Col. Albert Gilmor, U.S.A. re tired, died Wednesday in Roose velt Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 55 East 72d Street.

title: GERMAN REDS EASE POSITION ON BERLIN
description: BONN, Feb. 25In a major policy turnabout, the East Ger man Government has offered concessions toward allowing West Berliners to visit East Berlin and East Germany and has acknowledged that Big Four negotiations on the status of the divided city take prece dence over talks between the two Germanys.

title: DOCTORS TESTIFY CALLEY WAS SANE
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 25  Two Army psychiatrists testified today that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was sane at Mylei and was suffering no more from battle strain than were any of his soldiers on the day the officer, according to his admission, killed South Viet namese civilians three years ago in the hamlet of Mylai.

title: Paris Bids Algeria Take All Oil Holdings, Not 51%
description: PARIS, Feb. 25The French stateowned oil company de manded tonight that Algeria nationalize 100 per cent of the company's holdings there, rath er than 51 per cent, and pay a just indemnity.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25By word, by nuance and sometimes only by omission, President Nixon's second annual bulky compendium on the state of the world suggests some interest ing things about the state of his mind and mood.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Under Secretary of Commerce, Rocco C. Siciliano, has resigned to become president and chief administrative officer of the TI Corporation of California, the nation's largest total insurance company. Mr. Siciliano's resignation will become effective in April, and he will then take over his new duties from Ernest J. Loebbecke, who will become chairman and remain as chief executive officer. Mr. Siciliano cited pressing Personal rea sons in asking President Nixon, in a letter Dated Feb. 12, to accept his resignation.

title: Miranda Juan Wed in Taipei To John Woodruff Ewell jr.
description: Announcement, has been made by Mrs. H. Yolanda Juan of Washington of the marriage of her daughter, Miss Miranda Juan, to John Woodruff Ewell Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Ewell of North ford, Conn. The ceremony took place last Saturday in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: WORLD JEWS MAKE A PLEA TO MOSCOW
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 25The leaders of organized world Jew ry appealed to international opinion today to urge the So viet Union to give its Jewish citizens the right to their own cultural and religious life and. the right to emigrate.

title: Mario Merola, the Man Who Makes Budget Numbers Game Add Up
description: Two years ago, when Mayor Lindsay was warning New Yorkers that a multimillion dollar budget gap threatened to bring about the closing of hospitals, museums and li braries, Mario Merola stepped out of a City Hall hearing one day and said it wasn't so.

title: Vietnamization Termed No Quick Path to Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon said for the first time today that the policy of Vietnamization cannot, ex cept over a long period, end the war in Indochina.

title: Reaction in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP) News that Chile would bypass the London exchange reached the market too late to cause price movements.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25  Big Ed Muskie discusses his Presidential pros pects these days like a detached phi losopher analyzing some unlikely his torical character. He is remarkably objective, candid, and even selfcritical, still visibly surprised to find himself leading the Democratic race, but ob viously determined to make the most of his chances.

title: Chick Gandil, 82, White Sox Star Who Threw 1919 Series, Dies
description: CALISTOGA, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP)  Arnold (Chick) Gandil, the reputed leader of the 1919 Black Sox Scandal, died 10 weeks ago but his death went virtually unnoticed until today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to recent news stories in The Times, it appears to be increasingly true that only the very rich or, by extension, their. candidates can afford to run for major office in the United States. The very rich Rockefellers are alleged to have spent millions in getting one of themselves reelected Governor of New York. Governor Rockefeller has defended the leap frogging cost of his Albany Mall with one breath and demanded increased, nostrings Federal revenue sharing with the next. [Editorial Jan. 30.]

title: Reporters Aid Charity
description: The Newspaper Reporters As sociation of New York City yesterday, presented a $1,000 check to Jerry Lewis, the en tertainer, as a donation to the Muscular Dystrophy Associa tions of America. Mr. Lewis, national chairman of the asso ciation group called the amount of the donation a beautiful number and said it will go a long, long way toward helping dystrophic Children.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25President Nixon appealed to the Soviet Union and other adversaries today to join the search for peace, but he warned that he would not be hurried along the road of disengage ment from Indochina or any where else:

description: The City Council voted unan imously yesterday to override the first veto of Mayor Lind say's second term.

title: DR. WALTER FORD, 96, EXMATH PROFESSOR
description: WATERLOO, N. Y., Feb. 25 (AP) Dr. Walter B. Ford, philanthropist and mathemati cian, died here yesterday at the age of 96.

title: Hanoi Delegation at Paris Says Message Lies About Indochina
description: PARIS, Feb. 25North Viet nam declared today that Presi dent Nixon had lied on three crucial aspects of the Indo china war in his State of the World Message.

title: Lindsay Pays Visit To Queens to Open Pothole Campaign
description: The city expanded its annual battle against the pothole yes terday with a threepronged at tack.

title: Screen: Argentine Epic
description: "La Hora de Los Hornos" (The Hour of the Furnaces) is a three-part, four-hour and 20-minute, political documentary film, directed (as well as photographed and written in part) by Fernando Ezequiel Solanas, a young Argentine filmmaker who has committed himself to the cause of violent revolution as the only means to true liberation and the establishment of a national Argentine consciousness. On the basis of the 90-minute Part One, subtitled "Neocolonialism and Violence," the work might well turn out to be a polemical epic, an essay film of a political, cinematic and psychological complexity unlike anything I've ever seen.For reasons I do not know, Solanas has allowed only Part One to be released for commercial distribution here, although the entire film has been shown at the Museum of Modern Art and is available for 16 mm. showings by film societies, universities and such. It has also been widely screened in Europe but, understandably, only privately in Argentina.Part One opened here yesterday at the New Yorker Theater on a program with Joseph Strick's 22-minute "Interviews with Mylai Veterans," which has been nominated for an Academy Award. As its title implies, the film is a series of interviews with five enlisted men who participated in the Mylai action and all of whom are now out of the Army. The effect of the testimonyrueful, matter-of-fact, unsentimental, a lot of it smiling (at the interviewer and at the fact of being interviewed, rather than at the subject)is terrifying, and almost indescribably sad.Because no movie genre makes quite as personal demands on the viewer as the political documentary, or plays on his prejudices with such accuracy, perhaps I should explain something of my own experiences, which, of course, I took with me when I entered the theater to see "The Hour of the Furnaces." I'm no student of either Argentina or Latin America, and just about everything I know of them is the more or less chance result of several short visits to Argentina in the early 1960's.First of all there was, for me, each time I arrived in Buenos Aires international airport, the feeling that I'd arrived at the end of the line, if not the world. Although the airport services the largest city in South America, and is modern and efficient and handsome, it seemsas Solanas says of Buenos Aires itselfto have "turned its back on the country." It faces north and east and west, but not south, and if one had wanted to go to Tierra del Fuego, or even Crdoba, one had to go to another airport.Seen from the perspective of either British Empire or United States hegemony, Argentina is, quite literally, as far away as you can get, the last stop before the South Pole, a fact that has shaped a kind of national inferiority complexpolitical, cultural and economic. It has set out to demonstrate that being Argentine, as well as Latin American, can be beautiful."La Hora de Los Homos," Part One, is a cool but furious examination of first the British and then the American neocolonialism that, according to Solanas, had as its aim the "Balkanization" of Latin America for economic exploitation. Here is no unbiased report, but a vivid, angry, indoctrination lesson, sometimes crude but always cinematic, that has the look of the kind of documentary film Godard might make if he opted to play on the bourgeois emotions he now scorns.The film employs old prints, newsreels and interviews, as well as clips from the work of Joris Ivens and Fernando Birri (the only other young Argentine filmmaker I know who shares, with Solanas, an authentic Argentine vision), On the soundtrack there are lengthy quotations from Sartre and Fanon, slogans, and masses of facts, none of which I can easily authenticate.Some of Solanas's juxtapositions are so obvious they are unworthy of the quality of the passion of the film that contains them. Mostly, however, the images, the editing and the sound track are fine, even witty, as in the section on the Argentine aristocracy, defined by its grandiose cemetery that looks like Washington's Resurrection City, sculptured in marble. The aristocrats, he notes, "take the past as [if it were] a future."I find difficult (and depressing) Solanas's conclusions in favor of Pernism, which he describes as the first popular expression of Argentina's national consciousness, and suspect that, in the style of other contemporary revolutionaries, he may well feel that the past can be rewritten, through re-evaluation, according to the needs of the present. Solanas's conclusions thus escape me; his arguments do not."La Hora de Los Hornos," Part One, is, most importantly, a unique film exploration of a nation's soul. It's full of tremendous vigor, unlike the tired Buenos Aires dinner party at which the hostess, before introducing me, gave me quick sketches of everyone in the room. "Over there," she said, pointing to a handsome, morose man, who seemed to be getting quite drunk, "is Jos. . . . Poor Jos. He always wanted to be the Minister of War. In the last regime, he wasfor three weeks. Now he has nothing to look forward to."

title: Newsmen Going Into Laos by Helicopter Will Be Without U.S. Military Escorts
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 25Military officials in Quang tri said today that no United States military men would es cort correspondents and pho tographers who, in a, reversal of policy, will be allowed to fly into Laos on American heli copters to coyer the South Vietnamese incursion there.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activites. The President gave his State of the World Message over nationwide ra dio. He attended the swear ingin ceremony of Thomas S. Kleppe as administrator of the Small Business Adminis tration. Mr. Nixon met with Felipe Herrera, president of the InterAmerican Develop ment Bank. Later he met with Ambassador at Large David M. Kennedy.

title: Reform Rabbis Here Elect
description: Rabbi Herbert H. Rose of Temple OrElohim, Jericho, L. I., has been elected president of the Association of Reform Rab bis of New York City and Vicinity, succeeding Rabbi Bern hard Cohn. The association rep resents 175 Reform spiritual leaders serving 150 synagogues here and in eastern Connecti cut and New Jersey.

title: JUDGE ASKED TO FREE 2 WOMEN PANTHERS
description: Lawyers for two women de fendants in the trial of 13 Black Panthers argued yesterday that it was illegal to hold the women in jail as reprisal for acts of two male defendants.

title: 4 Seized Cuban Boats Held at Key West
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25Four Cuban fishing vessels, one seized last night by a United StateS Coast Guard cutter and, three early this morning by state of Flor ida patrol boats, are being held in Key West on charges of il legal fishing in United States waters.

title: Market Place: Trust Advisers  Facing a Battle
description: Judging from rumblings out of the New York State Insurance Department, in vestment advisers and brok ers will have to fight to keep their share in the manage ment of billions of dollars in pension and profitsharing trusts.

title: Boy and Girl Slain, in Jersey; Third Youth Injured in Escape
description: MIDDLEBUSH, N. J., Feb. 25  Two teenagers were slain on a lonely hillside outside this village last night and a third youth's throat was slashed in the same incident.

title: Kellogg Fund to Help Negroes Prepare for Medical Careers
description: The W. K. Kellogg Founda tion announced yesterday a $357,000 program to increase the number of black students who enter the medical pro fession.

title: Industrial Wholesale Prices Edge Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The rise in industrial whole sale prices, seasonally adjusted, moderated in February, but a jump in farm prices produced a large increase in the overall wholesale price index, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: 7 Missed Short Putts. Jolt Bolt After His 72
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 25 (AP)One by one, the leading golfers were checking into the locker room after varied experiences in the first round today of the Professional Golfers Associa tion tourney.

title: Michigan U. Post Filled
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 25 (AP)Robert H. Maier, vice chancellor of the University of Wisconsin at Green Bay, has been named to the newly created post of chancellor or the University of Michigan at Dearborn. His appointment, ef fective July 1, must be con firmed by the University Re gents, who meet March 19. He is a native of New York City and is 43 years old.

title: 3D SUIT DISCLOSED BY S. E. C. NOMINEE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25William J. Casey, President Nixon's nominee to head the Securities and Exchange Com mission, has informed the Sen ate of the existence of a third lawsuit, growing out of his varied business activities, in which he was named as de fendant.

title: Rebuttal Witness Barred, Colombo Trial Nears End
description: The Federal Government moved unsuccessfully yesterday to produce a lastminute witness who, it said, would testify that its chief witness against Joseph Colombo Jr. had expressed great fear for himself and his family.

title: Sports of The Times
description: They sauntered together through the huge mall that leads into Madison Square Garden, the presidents of the two teams that keep the turnstiles spinning. One was Ned Irish, the inventor of the Knicks, and the other was Bill Jennings, boss of the Rangers. Their mission was prosaic, lunch, although they would be at a directors meeting later to approve a major financial merger and takeover by the Garden. On the way in, Jennings seemed to become aware for the first time of a glistening new automobile on fencedin platform in the center of the mall. It had identifying signs around it. fencedin platform in the center of the mall. It had identifying signs around it.

title: 4 NEW WORKS GIVEN IN CONCERT SERIES
description: Four works new to New York were heard on the con cert of the Evenings for New Music series Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, and all resembled one another somewhat.

title: White Elephant With Wings
description: In November, 1964, the Concorde, the AngloFrench supersonic transport plane, was in about the same stage of early development as the SST is in the United States today. In Britain, the newly elected Labor Government undertook an urgent review of this expensive project, which it had inherited from its Conservative predecessor.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS TRADING DIPS
description: The American Stock Ex change finished slightly higher yesterday in slower trading.

title: Faster Money Rise Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Nixon Administration applied more pressure on the Federal Reserve Board today to pump more money into the na tion's sluggish economy.

title: Frazier Out of a Line of Fire
description: Separate weighin rituals and separate prefight physi cal examinations were or dered yesterday for the Joe FrazierMuhammad AU heavy weight championship bout.

title: Suffolk Housewives Educated as Detergent Ban Nears
Tcherepnin Cello Music Performed
description: Singlecomposer cello pro grams rarely turn up outside of the Bach and Beethoven repertory. On Wednesday night at Tully Hall, Paul Ol efsky, cellist, and Alexander Tcherepnin, pianist, devoted an evening to the latter's music for the two instru ments or for cello alone. Al though the works were not equally effective, the concert was engrossing. The com poser is, at least, a skill ful artisan. His clean and varied textures and rhythmic vitality make his music lis tenable, and there was the in terest in hearing a style de velop over a number of years.

title: Advertising:
description: One of the first things that Robert T. Colson did after taking over the mar keting function of Falstaff Brewing was to fly around the country visiting some 100 distributors. He found them sadly lacking in pointofsale material and other promo tional devices. He's, going to do something about that.

title: HOGAN DENOUNCES RULING BY JUDGE
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday denounced a State Supreme Court justice's dismissal of an indictment against a police lieutenant as vague, illogical, inaccurate, misleading and grossly unfair to the people.

title: Quotas May Die, Mills Hints
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 25The Japanese plan for a volun tary restriction of textile ex ports to the United States could kill tradequota legislation in Congress, Mr. Mills indicated today.

title: FOUR JUMP VICTORS RIDDEN BY JENKINS
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 25Rod Jenkins rode Brendan to victory in the open jumper classand, for good measure, rode Idle Dice to second place today at the Winter Haven Hunter and Jumper Charity Horse Show.

title: EXAMINER CLEARS SHINER PRINCIPAL
description: Mrs. Desiree Greenidge, who was removed as acting princi, pal of the Shinier Intermediate School in Jamaica, Queens, aft er she and 17 teachers joined picket lines to protest condi tions at the school, was cleared yesterday by a trial examiner who recommended that she be given a better job.

title: 7 Sons in Naval Service
description: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Feb. 25 (UPI)The family of Kirby Newman Sr. of Twin Falls, which already has six sons on active duty with the Navy, has sent a seventh son, Raymond, and a grandson, John Anthony, to the naval service. An eighth son, Kirby Jr., was killed last February in an airplane crash while on active duty with the Navy Raymond Newman's in duction set a record for the most sons from one family to serve in the Navy.

title: Excerpts From Nixon's Address
description: Following are excerpts from Presi dent Nixon's radio address to the na tion yesterday announcing his annual message to CoNgress on foreign af fairs, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: West Virginia Plan
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 25 (AP)The lower house of the West Virginia Legislature passed today, 60 to 39, a Con gressional redistricting bill that would put Representative Ken Hechler of Huntington and Rep resentative James Kee of Blue field in the same district. The bill now goes to the Senate. It would cause Mr. Hechler and Mr. Kee to become opponents in a 1972 Democratic primary if both ran again, but the state's other three House incumbents, also Democrats, would not face opposition.

title: A.M.A. Presents Its Plan for Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The amount of proposed legis lation on health care before Congress increased today as the American Medical Associ ation introduced its own in surance bill, which was sup ported by 104 Senators and Representatives.

title: Murcer and Kenney Sign Contracts With Yankees
description: FORT LAUDERDALE. Fla., Feb. 25Bobby Murcer and Jerry Kenney agreed to terms today, leaving only Fritz Peter son, Danny Cater and Ron Han son still negotiating salaries with the New York Yankees.

title: Nixon Joins in Naming a FiveMember Panel With Power to Discipline or Oust Capital Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25A new legal institution that has become widely adopted in the states the judicial removal commission with power to dis cipline or remove unfit judges will appear for the first time in the Federal system tomor row.

title: High School's Head Seeks Better Transit To Ease Tensions
description: The acting principal of Sheepshead Bay High School, where violence broke out Wednesday, said yesterday that she was moving to obtain spe cial transportation for students who must travel long distances.

title: Nixons to Fete Astronauts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) President and Mrs. Nixon will entertain the Apollo 14 astro nauts, their wives and other top space officials at a White House dinner Monday evening. Military singing groups are ex pected to entertain after the dinner in the State Dining Room, a departure from the Nixon tradition of small gath erings for Apollo astronauts in the Family Dining Room on the second floor of the White House.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's total retail store sales at $6,587, 000,000, up 5 per cent from the yearearlier $6,283,000,000.

title: Women Pricks Finger In Test of Moon Dust
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 25 (AP)A 22yearold woman labora tory worker punctured a finger with a needle while working with lunar material and is being placed in quaian tine, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said here today.

title: SILVER FUTURES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Silver futures prices man aged to confound some of their ardent followers yesterday. It was the first notice day for de liveries and 2,466 notices went out indicating delivery of sil ver covered by that many con tracts.

title: DEBT PLAN ISSUED BY PENN CENTRAL
description: The Penn Central Company announced yesterday a refund ing plan for $59million of Swissfranc promissory notes, some of which already are past due, issued last year by a Netherlands Antilles subsidiary. It also announced that, to settle litigation, it had agreed to rescind its February, 1970, acquisition of two oil com panies.

title: SUSPECT, 78, HELD IN RANCH AMBUSH
description: CODY, Wyo., Feb. 25Anson Eddy, a slight, amiable, 78yearold mountain man who lives in a junkcluttered coulee on Ishawoa Creek, 15 miles south of Cody, is being held on a complaint of probable cause in the murder of Robert E. Meyers, a New York illus trator who came west to find a new life as a rancher.

title: Irish Primate Confers With Ulster's Leader
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, Feb. 25William Car dinal Conway today became the first head of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland to have formal talks with a Prime Minister in Northern Ireland in the 50 years since Ireland became an independ ent nation.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE INFORMATION MACHINES. Their Impact on Men and the Media. By Ben H. Bag dikian. 359 pages. Harper & Row. $8.95.

title: BRITON HERE ASSAILS THE CONCORDE SST
description: A leading British opponent of the FrenchBritish supersonic transport took issue yesterday with the contention of a mem ber of Parliament that banning the plane here would create a major potential conflict be tween Europe and the United States.

title: SUBWAY REPAIRS CRITICIZED ANEW
description: The subway system's huge repair shop in Coney Island was criticized yesterday by CitY Councilman Dertram R. Gel fand as an overburdened shop with archaic equipment as he and four other Councilmen toured the facility.

title: THOENI CAPTURES SLALOM ON COAST
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy turned in the best times in both runs of the men's slalom today at Heavenly Valley to retain his lead in the World Cup ski standing.

title: Dr. George H. Roberts Jr. Dead; University Medical Teacher, 76
description: Dr. George. H. Roberts Jr., an internist, cardiologist and former medical teacher; died, yesterday in Long Island Col lege Hospital, after a short ill ness. He was 76, years old and, lived and practiced medicine's at 79 Pierrepont Street, Brook lyn.

title: Baseball Subtleties Force Mets Into Who's on First Act
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 25Like the New York Yankees, the Mets found to day that the most urgent business of spring training came down to filling three positions in 1971: First base, third base and right field.

title: Tunnel Escape Foiled
description: BERLIN, Feb. 25East Ger man guards foiled the escape of 17 East Berliners with the discovery today of a long tun nel secretly dug under a border street from West to East Berlin.

title: B.P. REPLY IS COOL TO BURMAH OFFER
description: LONDON, Feb. 25The Brit ish Petroleum Company gave a cool reception today to the proposal by the Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., to exchange some of its B.P. stock interest for B.P. oil and gas reserves to sweeten Burmah's proposed affiliation with the Continen tal Oil Company.

title: NICKLAUS GETS 69, LEADS BY STROKE
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 25Jack Nicklaus, in pink shirt and red slacks, walked off the 18th green in the sunshine today after posting a threeunderpar 69 in the Pro fessional Golfers Association championship tournament. His score, completed at midday, was good enough to hold a onestroke edge after the first round.

title: Court Allows State to Bar Areas On Thruway to Charter Buses
description: ALBANY. Feb. 25  The Court of Appeals ruled unani mously today that the State Thruway Authority could close its service areas to charter bus es between New York City and Albany on summer weekends without violating the equalpro tection clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions.

title: Miscellany Caps Structure of Color Show
description: It has been amply appar ent to even the most casual observer of the current art scene in recent years that color  larger areas of col or, heavier saturations of col or, color freed of almost all conventional expressive ob ligations  has played an in creasingly important role in the creation of abstract painting. We have not only reached, but have already rapidly passed beyond, the phenomenon of a painting that consists of nothing but a single color covering the entire surface of a canvas rectangle. We have geometri cal color painters, expres sionist color painters, mystical color painters, and a good many others who seem to have missed their proper vo cation as designers of floor covering materials. Color, in other words, has lately been in.

title: VIRGINIA REALIGNS HOUSE DISTRICTS
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 25The Virginia Legislature gave final approval late today to a plan for realignment of the state's 10 districts for the. Unit ed States House of Representa tives. It thus became the first, of the state legislatures to pass a Congressional redistricting, bill under 1970 census figures.

title: Air France Talks to Resume
description: PARIS, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Pilots and management of France's three main airlines, including Air France, agreed to night to resume talks tomorrow morning aimed at ending the deadlock that has kept their planes grounded for a week. The shutdown followed a threat day strike.

title: Governor Seeks More Parking On Periphery of Urban Areas
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25  Gover nor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to give the state the authority to build parking facilities near outlying public transportation centers to reduce the flow of traffic into congested urban areas.

title: Boat Dealers Warming to Miami
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 25Take the four levels of New York's Coliseum, spread them into one gigantic room, assem ble over $30million of new sailboats and power craft, add a week of 80degree weather and you'll have the Miami edi tion of the New York Boat Show, right? Wrong?

title: Canada Calls for Curbs on Underground Nuclear Tests
description: GENEVA, Feb. 25Canada called on the nuclear powers today to limit underground tests as a first step toward a complete ban on them.

title: HARRYM. HUBBELL, A CLASSICIST, DIES
description: NORTH: HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 Dr. Harry M. Hubbell, emeritus Talcott Professor of Greek of Yale University, died yesterday in a ,nursing home here. He was 89 years old and formerly lived in Hamden.

title: EXECUTIVE PREDICTS MORE RERUNS ON TV
description: BOSTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  A broadcasting executive predict ed today that the major com mercial television networks soon would begin double repe tition of primetime programs.

title: Bet Unit Makes a New Move: Forward
description: The city's stalled OffTrack Betting Corporation appeared yesterday to be making major progress in its effort to begin operations by March 15.

title: Geiger Named to Post at Brown
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 25 Ferdinand A. (Andy) Gei ger, the assistant commis sioner of the Eastern College Athletic. Conference was named today as athletic di rector of Brown University, effective July 1.

title: Chile Announces She Will Sell Copper Directly to Red China
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 25 (AP)  announced today that she would sell copper directly, to Communist China.

title: NASALIKE APPROACH TO URBAN ILLS URGED
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 Barbara Ward, the author and lecturer, called today for a multibilliondollar public and private attack on what she called the crisisridden state of the cities.

title: POLISH UNIONS OUST 3 HIGH EXECUTIVES
description: WARSAW, Feb. 25Poland's trade union leadership, a major I target of worker wrath in the December riots, ousted three top executives and pledged a new program today in an ex tensive renovation of union, practices.

title: Sections of the President's Foreign Policy Report on Other Areas of the World
San Juan Bus Strike Ends
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 25 (UPI)  A strike of city bus drivers that stranded thousands of commuters and aggravated the normal traffic jams ended today after union leaders were promised a meeting with Gov. Luis A. Ferri to air their griev ances. The 350 drivers walked out yesterday when office workers at the metropolitan bus authority struck in sympathy with striking port authority employes.

title: Liza Polakova, a Worker For Jewish Labor Bund
description: Mrs. Liza Polakova, a veter an of the Jewish Labor Bund, a Socialist International organ ization, died Wednesday in the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged, the Bronx. She was 90 years old.

title: PRICES OF LIQUOR SCRUTINIZED HERE
description: Largescale discount liquor dealers have cut retail prices one some major brands to what they were selling for 25 years ago.

title: Excerpts From President's Report on Indochina in His State of the World Message
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Following are excerpts from the Indo china section of President Nixon's annual report to Congress on foreign policy, which is titled United States Foreign Policy for the 1970's: Building for Peace:

title: Grassroots Elderly Call for Reforms
description: More than 300 delegates from 35 Jewish Community Centers and homes for the aged met yesterday to draw up a list of recommendations and demands to make the living conditions of old people better.

title: West Europe Urged Not to Let Efforts for Accord With East Mar Allied Unity
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Western commitment to seek a relaxation of tensions be tween the East and the West, in Europe was renewed by President Nixon today with a caution to Western nations against accomplishing this at the expense of allied solidarity.

title: 70,000 Hungry Cattle Bombed With Hay After Kansas Storm
description: GREAT BEND, Kan., Feb. 25 Tom Brower normally works within Ashland, Kan., not above it.

title: Ishii Leads Philippine Golf
description: MANILA. Feb. 25 (AP)Tomoo Ishii of Japan posted a threeunderpar 69 today to pace an international field of 160 players in the opening round of the $15,000 Philip pine open golf tournament. Ishii toured the 7,035yard course of the suburban Wack Wack Golf and Country Club with a two under 34 going out and came in at 35. Hsieh Yungyo of Taiwan, the de fender, was four strokes be hind the leader.

title: CHANGES ADVOCATED IN BANK SUPERVISION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (Reu ters)The conference of state bank supervisors recommended today transferring the Federal Reserve Board's supervisory authority on nonmonetary, matters to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: O.E.O. Overrides a Veto By Mississippi Governor
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Office of Economic Op portunity said today that it had overridden the veto of Missis sippi Gov. John Bell Williams and reinstated a legal services program for the poor in his state.

title: New Message Old Doctrines
description: President Nixon's second State of the World Message is essentially a restatement and updating of last year's document. It does not appear at first reading to contain any new thoughts or proposals. Indeed, what is most striking is the manner in which the emerging Nixon Doctrine increasingly resembles old United States policies of the past two decades.

title: SpartansArlen Merger Cleared
description: An impassioned defense of soninlaw and a glowing por trait of the potential in real estate were used yesterday to sway stockholders to approve one of the period's most unus ual mergers.

title: JOHN CLAIR JR., 62, SKIING OFFICIAL
description: John S. Clair Jr., a prominent skiing official, was s killed Wednesday night in an automo bile accident on a mountain road in Granada, Spain. He was 62 years old, and lived, in Ja maica, Queens.

title: Mystery of Vermont Miler Adds New Chapter to A.A.U. Track
description: Another mystery man has emerged in track and field, to compete in the 83d annual Na tional Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: Nikolais Unit Dances A Somniloquy Debut
description: Somniloquy, a dance that dates from 1967, rep resents for Alwin Nikolais a turning away from the full evening works that had pre occupied him during the pre vious decade in favor of the 20thcentury ballet length of half an hour or thereabouts.

title: Obscenity Charges Faced by Library In Magazine Furor
description: GROTON, Conn., Feb. 25The chief prosecutor for the 10th Circuit Court said today that he would charge either the Groton Library Board or its director with violation of the state's antiobscenity law unless all issues of the magazine Ever green Review were removed from library shelves.

title: Sammy Gallop, Lyricist, Dead; Wrote There Must Be a Way
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., Feb. 25 (AP)Sammy Gallop, who wrote such songs as There Must Be a Way and Wake the Town and Tell the People, died yesterday at the age of 55.

title: David Black to Present Songs to Assist Club
description: An Evening With David Black, a program including excerpts from two forth com ing stage shows, will be pre sented on Sunday at the Manhattan Theater Club, 73d Street between First and Sec ond Avenues.

title: An Open Letter to Mayor Kollek
description: Dear Mayor Kollek, Nothing in history has prepared you for your present dilemma in the planning of Jerusalem. At once the most Sacred of spiritual sites, the most torn and disputed area of modern times, the capital of a new and force ful country, the agglomeration of cen turies of different ownerships with dif fering ideologies. In other words, you have a mess.

title: JOHN RYAN, LAWYER AND COUNCILMAN, 71
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Feb. 25 John F. Ryan, a patent attor ney and formerly active in the local Republican party as a town Councilman, died today is New Rochelle Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 226 Elderwood Avenue.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: 7,000 G.I.'s to Get Vaccine
description: FORT LEONARD WOOD, Mo., Feb. 25 (AP)The Army will start an immunization program to combat meningitis at Fort Leonard Wood, with about 7,000 men to receive the vac cine this weekend.

title: Service Costs Cited
description: The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday decline in 1970 net income de spite a 10.5 per cent increase in revenues. The annual report released yesterday placed oper ating revenues at $2,048,251, 000 against $1,853,669,000 a year earlier. However, net in come fell to $168,226,000, or $1.33 a share on 126.7 million shares, from $178,410,000, or $1.65 a share on 107.9 million shares in 1969.

title: GERTRUDE R. BRIGHAM
description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 25Gertrude R. Brigham, impres sionist painter and former mem ber of the faculty of George Washington University, died in her home here Tuesday after short illness. She was 91 years old.

title: Police Battle With 1,000 At. Airport Site in Japan
description: NARITA, Japan, Feb. 25 (AP)  Riot police, trying to evict about 1,000. squatters from small plots of farmland needed to complete a new international airport, clashed today with hundreds of helmeted students who hurled stones and charged with bamboo spears.

title: South Vietnamese Base in Laos Reported Under Heavy Attack
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Feb. 26  Heavy fighting was reported yesterday at a South Vietnamese base in Laos as enemy resistance continued to stiffen against allied efforts to disrupt enemy supply, lines there.

title: ExAgents Tell of Duplication and Competition in Army Watch on Civilians
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Two former military intelli gence agents disclosed today details of political surveillance] operations run by Army com bat divisions that duplicated and often competed with the nationwide watch on civilians of the Army intelligence com mand.

title: PARR, HALL, $7, SETS DASH MARK
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25  A record breaking performance was con tributed by A. L. Tasner's Faneuil Hall in the main event, a 5furlong sprint on the Hia leah program today.

title: Soviet Cars Vandalized
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI) Cars belonging to two staff members of the Soviet Embassy were vandalized today in front of an apartment building in suburban Hyattsville, Md., the police said. It was the second such, incident in a week.

title: McGovern to Shun Gridiron
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern Democrat of South Dakota, an nounced today that he was de clining an invitation to the an nual Gridiron Club dinner March 13 because the group of newsmen excludes women. Some 250 Washngton newsmen, calling themselves Journalist for Professional Equality, have urged those invited to the an nual menonly dinner to decline invitations.

title: The Medals Pour In On a Surprised Veteran
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 25 (AP) A World War II veteran here got more than he ex pected recently, when he asked the Army if he could have a replacement for a lost Purple Heart medal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The information in the Feb. 3 news article describing the difficulties faced in visiting Auburn Prison calls for reform of some of the prison practices.

title: RAIL TOMILEAGE OFF FROM '70 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Feb. 20 were both below the corresponding nonholiday week last year.

title: Retreat on Welfare
description: The city's suit challenging the constitutionality of Fed eral and state welfare requirements is more of a flight from governmental responsibility than a creative ap proach toward solution of a harrowing social problem.

title: Bill by Magnuson Would Permit E1 Paso Gas to Keep, a Pipeline It Acquired Illegally
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Sometime in the next few weeks, Senator Warren G. Mag puson, the Washington Demo crat who is one of the most influential insiders in the United States Senate, will in troduce a legislative proposal of about 350 words.

title: Merger Negotiations Disclosed By Continental and Burmah Oil
description: The Continental Oil Com pany and the Burmah Oil Com pany, Ltd., of Britain, an nounced yesterday negotiations for a merger that would create a new multinational concern that would be the eighth larg est oil company in the world in terms of assets.

title: New Nevada Law Bars Brothels in Las Vegas
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Feb. 25 (UPI)A bill to prevent the legalization of brothels in the Las Vegas area was signed today by Gov. D. N. O'Callaghan, who said, The less said about it the better.

title: State Democratic Chiefs Urge PayPrice. Controls
description: ALBANY, Feb. 25  Demo cratic legislative leaders charged today that President Nixon's economic policies were largely responsible for a $300 million drop in state revenues in the current fiscal year and for sharply increased unem ployment in the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a film director wishing to make a documentary about America today, I asked Ambassador Jacob D. Beame last Sept. 23 for U.S. visas for myself and, my film unit. When I saw the Ambassador I told him not only what I wanted to do but that I also wanted to present the United States as seen by a visitor, in this case my selfa person from the U.S.S.R.

title: President Says Arms Pact Should Limit All Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25President Nixon insisted today that any strategicarms agree ment with the Soviet Union limit both offensive and defen sive missiles. He thus rebuffed a Soviet proposal made last December for defensive limita tions first.

title: EDGAR SALINGER, 83, AIDED WAR VICTIMS
description: Edgar Salinger, formerly a prominent figure in internation al trade, who, had. been active in relief and rehabilitation, work for refugees in World War II, died Monday at his home, 125 East 72d Street. He was 83 years old.

title: Brige:
description: Two of the world's great est players, Giorgio Bella donna and Benito Garozzo of Rome, were in New York this week en route to Cincinnati, where they begin a twoweek American tour today. They will spearhead an allstar group playing the Precision Club System, a method whose recent successes have at tracted worldwide attention.

title: Nixon Seeks to End Loan Ban on Those In Strife on Campus
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  The White House is seek ing to eliminate legal restric tions that bar persons convict ed of campus disruption from receiving Federal student loans and loan guarantees.

title: NIXON PROPOSES FUNDFLOW STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon proposed today an intensive examination by the leading industrial countries of massive movements of shortterm capital funds from one country to another.

title: Dining Out in What May Be the City's Tiniest Restaurant...
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: F.D.A. IS CRITICIZED ON LISTING CONTENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (UPI)  Consumer advocates accused the Food and Drug Administra tion today of a regulatory lapse dating back 38 years and urged the agency to require labeling of ingredients of all food prod ucts.

title: Soviet Scores Art At Show in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 25  A major exhibition of Russian art from the early years of the Revolution opened here tonight with one room sealed at the insistance of Soviet of ficials.

title: Textile Leaders in Japan Plan to Restrict Exports
description: TOKYO, Feb. 25The leaders of Japan's textile industry have agreed to draft a proposal to limit voluntarily exports of all varieties of textiles to the United States, a spokesman for the Chemical Fiber Asso ciation said today.

title: Other Key Points in Review of U.S. Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25In addition to areas major dispute, President Nixon's State of the World Message dealt with the following subjects:

title: AUSTIN M. FISHER
description: Austin M. Fisher, a labor rela tions consultant to manage ment, formerly of New York, died Feb. 16 in Port of Spain, Trinidad. He was 60 years old.

title: Jack Walker, 48, Manager Of Radio Station WLIB, Dies
description: Jack Walker, operations man ager and vice president of radio station WLIB, died last night at Lenox Hill Hospital after com plications developed from a stab wound inflicted on New Year's Eve. He was 48 years old.

title: Oil Delegation Leaves Libya
description: LONDON, Feb. 25An inter national delegation of oil ex ecutives that had hoped to bar gain jointly with the Libyan Government on oil price in creases flew back to London from Tripoli tonight without re sults.

title: Colette Boky Sings First Met Rosina; Gail Robinson Is Ill
description: Colette Boky, the soprano who did her first Rosina in Ros sini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia with the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night, had the part well in hand. She had sung it just the night before in Fort Lauderdale with the Opera Guild of Greater Miami follow ing four previous performances within a few days in Miami itself.

title: AIRLINES APPOINT A SECURITY CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  The. Air Transport. Associa tion chose a former Central, In telligence Agency official to day to head, a, new program to rid the airline industry of crime and criminals.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ALGIERSThe United States and Algeria are planning a massive joint enterprise to liquefy natural gas in this country, transport it across the Atlantic in tankers, recompress it and pipe it to American consumers.

title: White Motor Terminates White Consolidated Deal
description: The White Motor Corporation yesterday terminated its merger with White Consolidated Industries, Inc., because of the preliminary injunction granted against the merger on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Cleveland.

title: An. Alternative to Revenue Sharing
description: The recent treks to Washington by Mayor Lindsay, Governor Rockefeller, and other harassed leaders of states and cities underline the severe finan cial crises of local governments. With 11.6 per cent being the annual rate of increase in expenditures of state and local government for recent years, little room remains for maneuver.

title: Justice Black, 85 Tomorrow, Has No Plans to Leave Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Justice Hugo L. Black, who will be 85 years old on Satur day, is not thinking about re tiring from the Supreme Court.

title: Plane Carrying Army Inductees Hijacked From U.S. to Canada
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Feb. 25 (AP)A hijacked Western Air Lines jetliner with 94 passengers, many of them United States Army inductees, landed here tonight, end a man was taken into custody by the Royal Canadian Mounted Po lice.

title: A HEPATITIS TEST LICENSED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25The Government has, for the first time, licensed a substance for use in screening blood for hepa titis virus.

title: Jersey Rate Rise Asked
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24The New Jersey Blue Cross has applied for a rate increasee averaging 18.4 per cent for most of its more than two million, com munityrated !subscribers, the State Department of Insurance announced today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: SISAL, Yucatan, MexicoGiddy with fatigue after a night with less than two hours sleep and a duckhunt ing trip that morning that had begun at 2 A.M., Duncan Barnes and I clung doggedly to the notion that we had to fish the tarpon hole that evening.

title: SOVIET SCORES HIS VIETNAM PLAN
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 25  The Soviet Government denounced President Nixon's Vietnamiza tion policy today and said the increased fighting in Indochina cannot fail to affect Soviet American relations.

title: Williams Signs for $100,000; Top Salary in Cub History
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 25 (AP)  The Chicago Cubs awarded Billy Williams, an ironman outfielder, the club's first $100,000 contract in his tory today and a few hours later signed Ken Holtzman, the lone remaining holdout.

title: Ionesco Changes Camps At Academie Francaise
description: PARIS, Feb. 25Eugne Ionesco, the surrealist play wright, changed camps today at the Acadmie Franaise.

title: TIBETANS IN CITY GUARD TRADITION
description: Mr. and Mrs. Phintso Thon den waited last night in their East Side apartment for the precise moment when the clock struck 12. Then they raised goblets and bade each other a Happy New Year.

title: White Collar Strike Forces Swedes To Question Welfare State's Future
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 25For three weeks Sweden's teach ers, railwaymen, civil, servants and whitecollar municipal workers have staged a series of strikes, stirring a sharp class division in the labor movement and evoking a deli cate and profound question among officials: Is the welfare state in trouble?

title: Warming Up in Winter
description: He is beginning to emerge from his cottonwool haze, the hopelessly addicted baseball fan for whom lifeif that's the word for ithas amounted to nothing much since the last play of the 1970 World Series. He has been through this before, but he has never learned to accept it with equanimity. Winter is a dark time, with no light at the end of the tunnel until a touch springtraining camp gossip creeps into the sports pages.

title: Anaconda Cuts Dividend
description: Anaconda announced in New York yesterday that it would slash its quarterly dividend rate almost in half. It will pay 25 cents a share on March 29 to stockholders of record March 8. The previous rate was 47.5 cents a share.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
Japan's Gold Reserves Up
description: TOKYO, Feb. 25 (Reuters)Japan's gold reserves totaled $532million at the end of last month, compared with $455 million a year ago, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: School Accountability
description: The joint announcement by the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers that the New York school system will develop an action program for professional accountability could represent the beginning of important public school reforms. Properly imple mented, the plan might at least put an end to the tradition of always blaming the pupils for educational failure, without serious effort to find out what improve ments might be made in the quality of instruction.

title: Anaconda Announces a Slash Of Almost 50% in Dividend Rate
description: The Anaconda Company, one of the nation's producers of primary copper, announced yes terday that it would slash its quarterly dividend rate almost in half.

title: Appointments to 10 Vacant U.S. Judgeships in New York Area Bogged Down in Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 The filling of 10 Federal judge ship vacancies in the New York City area, one of which has been vacant nearly 18 months, has bogged down in a tangle of conflicting lists of prospective nominees and potential politi cal differences.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your Feb. 16 issue Edwin L. Dale Jr. called attention to. Gottfried Haber lees. and Lawrence E. Krause's advocacy of a passive balanceofpay ments policy for the United States. These eponemists rightly Maintain that in View of the practice most coun tries to peg their currencies to ours, it Is up to them to revalue upward relative to the dollar; Provided they consider themselves oversupplied with dollars.

title: Security Police Raid the Homes Of Churchmen in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca, Feb. 25  Security police raided offices and homes of, church leaders today in new pressure against opponents of the Government's policy of racial separation.

title: INVASION OF NORTH FORESEEN BY THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23President Nguyen Van Thieu was quoted today as hav ing said that an invasion of North Vietnam by South Viet namese troops was only a mat ter of time.

title: Advertising:
description: The broadcasting director of Ogilvy & Mather, whose This Is Your Life is now the toprated syndicated tele vision show, discussed the whole syndication field on the West Coast the other day.

title: Housing on the Waterfront Urged by Planning Agency
description: The City Planning Commis sion urged yesterday that new housing, industrial and recrea tion facilities be built on un used areas of the city's 220 mile waterfront.

title: Canadiens Beat Kings. 53, As Mahovlich Gets 3 Goals
2 G.O.P. BILLS URGE ELECTION REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 Hugh Scott, the Senate Repub Bean leader, introduced today] an election reform bill without campaign spending limits and said ho believed President Nix on would approve a measure along these lines.

title: On Defense, Options Are Urged In Response to Nuclear Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 President Nixon declared today that the United States must de velop the ability to respond in a limited way to certain kinds of nuclear attack in an effort to avoid a nuclear exchange that would slaughter millions of civilians on both sides.

title: Ford Sets a Bond Issue;
description: The corporate bond market's newfound optimism evaporated yesterday as the Ford Motor Credit Company announced $200million of new securities and underwriters worked on perhaps half a dozen, other large but as yet undisclosed issues.

title: An ItalianAmerican Group Clashes With Police on S.I.
description: Members of the ItalianAmer ican Civil Rights League clashed with the police yester day outside the offices of The Staten Island Advance as the league picketed the newspaper for the second day in a row.

title: 17.8% Rise in Blue Cross Rate To Affect 3.4 Million in Area
description: The New York State Insur ance Department yesterday an nounced the approval of Blue Cross rate increases, averaging 17.8 per cent, for about 40 per cent of the health insurer's subscribers in the city, Long Island and 10 nearby counties. The increase will mean month ly payments ranging from 90 cents to $3.51 higher.

title: Separate Votes Are Set On Bill on Bond Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)  Democrats supporting the present 4per cent limit on the interest the Government may pay on longterm bonds won a preliminary skirmish to day.

title: 2 Youths Guilty in Riot At Rikers Remand Shelter
description: Two youths pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court, the Bronx, to charges of riot and assault arising from disruption last October in the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Bikers Island.

title: Nepela of Czechoslovakia Wins FigureSkating Title
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The State Department's reassurance, which I fully believe, that China will not respond to the Laotian incursion because she knows that we Americans are withdrawing should cause some second thoughts. If. China will resort to arms only to respond to an Ameri can military threat near her frontiers as the reassurance affirms, why then are we in Indochina, at all, and why are we delaying our. departure? [Edi torial Feb. 21,]

title: Congressional Criticism on Vietnam Policy Flaring Up Again
