description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Long smoldering Congres siongl criticism of the Admin istration's Indochina policy showed signs of flaring up again today as a Republican Senator warned that President Nixon might become a one term President and a group of Senate Democrats proposed a Congressional injunction against supporting an invasion of North Vietnam.

title: LEADERS IN TEXAS ARE SEIZED IN RAID
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb, 25 Prominent Texas business men and civic leaders were among more than 500 persons taken into custody early today when Police Department Vice Squad officers raided a gam bling and stag party.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In Adolf Berle's death America has lost one of its greatest citizens. In tensely stimulating, keenly interested in any point one had to makebut only if it was a good one  he had that rare combination of a razor edged logic with a sage realism and commonsense about current events. [Editorial Feb. 20.]

title: Hijacker Pleads Guilty
description: MIAMI, Feb. 25 (AP)Leonard S. Bendicks, a former Pennsylvania school teacher, pleaded guilty today to kidnap ping in connection with an air line hijacking to Cuba in 1968. Federal District Judge William Mehrtens said he would sen tence Bendicks, 36 years old, at a later date.

title: National Program Seeks to Encourage Those Who Give A Helping Hand
description: WASHINGTONIt's been a long time since I thought I had anything to give any body, the Brooklyn welfare mother said as she finished her first day as a volunteer visitor at a mental hospital in upstate New York.

title: Partner in DeBoer Barred as Member By Stock Exchange
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that it had permanently barred from membership or allied member ship Charles D, Erb. who had been an allied member as the managing partner of Baerwald & DeBoer.

title: F.C.C. Revises Tests Of Emergency Alerts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)The Federal Communi cations Commission said to day that automatic takeover of the major news wires for national emergency an nouncements would be tem porarily discontinued in the wake of last weekend's sys tem failures.

title: MILLS REPORTED FOR U.S. CONTROL OF ALL WELFARE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is re ported to have told a group of Governors that he plans to press for a stepbystep Federal takeover of the welfare sys tem.

title: Girl, 21, Is Raped; Boyfriend Attacked In a Queens Park
description: Two men abducted a 21yearold girl from a car parked at Baisley Pond Park in Queens early yesterday morning, as saulted her boyfriend and raped her before she was released, the police reported.

title: Panel Approves Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Senate Public Works Committee approved today President Nixon's nomination of Donald W. Whitehead as Fed eral cochairman of the Appa lachian Regional Commission.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BID BEGUN BY M'GOVERN
description: CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 25 (AP)Senator George S. Mc Govern of South Dakota for malty opened his campaign to ward the 1972 New Hampshire Presidential primary today, de claring he would go the whole way with primary campaigns in several other states.

title: Columbia to Build a Housing Project
description: Columbia University and the city have announced a joint housing proposal for the devel opment of six universityowned buildings near Morningside Drive between 121st and 122d Streets.

title: British Ready for Talks With Lockheed on Rolls
description: LONDON, Feb. 25  The British Government is ready to begin serious negotiations with officials of the Lockheed Air craft Corporation next Tuesday on the future of the RollsRoyce RB211 engine.

title: Aggressive Oil Manager
description: John Godfrey McLean, president and chief executive officer of the Continental Oil Company, remarked to a visitor one day that a major curse of large corporations is the time it takes to get decisions made.

title: Unwed Mother Loses Her Plea; Baby Given to Adoptive Parents
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday awarded the custody of a 3yearold illegitimate boy to the parents who had adopted him.

title: Nixon's Pledge to Shun Politics Being Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Don't let the Democrats get away with any lies, Presi dent Nixon admonished as he bade farewell to a White House aide taking a new post with the Republican national committee. Lyn C. Nofziger, the departing assistant, re plied: Mr. President, I'm not even going to let them get away with tailing the truth. The recent exchange, which the President is said to be recounting with glee, illustrates more than Mr. Nofziger's quick wit. Mr. Nixon said on Jan. 4 he would not be wearing his political hat this year, and like Mr. Nofziger, politics is supposed to be moving out of the White House.

title: Big Four at U.N. Discuss Mideast Peace Guarantees
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, Feb. 25Representatives of the Big Four, powers today cen timed to discuss bigpower guarantees for an eventual set Content of the ArabIsimael con flict.

title: Where the Elderly Try to Escape and Be Young Once More
description: MIAMI BEACHLook at em, mutters the blonde in a seethrough blouse and skintight black pants. You can almost hear their joints creak.

title: Canadian Bill Rate Drops
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 25 (Canadian Press)New 91day Govern ment of Canada treasury bills auctioned today totaled $165 million at an average price and yield of 98.999 and 4.06 per cent.

title: San Diego Mayor to Run
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 25 (UP)Mayor Frank Curran, acquitted last month on bribery and con spriracy charges, will seek third term. Mr. Curran, 57 years old was one of eight public of ficials accused by the county grand jury of taking bribes in return for a favorable vote on a 1967 taxi cab rate increase. He said yesterday he would run for election in the Sept. 21 primary.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in the war in Southeast Asia:

title: Books of The Times
description: Some men sit on top of a rocket and get shot to the moon; some sail the oceans of the world all alone in tiny ships; some drag themselves to the peaks of airless, cloud shrouded mountains. And others make house companions of golden eagles. Or at least one didSam Barnes, outdoorsman and falconer, a Lancashire man who now lives in Wales. His friend is a rapacious bird of prey, with killer talons and a beak that can shred a man like an electric powered buzzsawan enormous bird that in silhouette on the dust jacket of David Bruce's book looks like the Angel of Death.

title: Brussels Declaration on Soviet Jews
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 25Fol lowing is the text of a decla ration issued in English to day by the World Conference of Jewish Communities on Soviet Jewry:

title: Cerro Seeks Great Southwest;
description: The Cerro Corporation dis closed yesterday that it was negotiating with the Pennsylva nia Company to buy Pennco's 90 per cent stock interest in the Great Southwest Corpora tion.

title: Weatherman Case Dropped in Bronx; Inquiry Continues
description: Charges against six persons arrested last November and re portedly involved in a Weath erman operation were dis missed yesterday by a Bronx Criminal Court judge.

title: U.S. Steel Raising a Price
description: The United States Steel Cor poration said yesterday it would raise the price about 6.6 per cent April 1 on alloysteel plates. This is a minor product category, accounting for 0.3 per cent of total American steel shipments.

title: We Need Radicals
description: Fairly often, late at night around the country, when the regular meet ings are over and the celebrities have gone to bed, I have sat with the radical students in their apartments and we have got down to bedrock.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: While Lyndon Johnson occupied the White House, Republicans periodically demanded a Federal income tax deduc tion or credit for parents who were paying for the college education of their children. We were told by the minority leaders, Senator Everett Dirksen and Representative Gerald Ford, that this proposal was part of the Republican platform.

title: LEFKOWITZ VOWS ABORTION ACTION
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that commercial abortion refer ral agencies must either be outlawed or subjected to strict regulation.

title: Legal Monstrosity for Students
description: President Nixon deserves congratulations for his pro posal to eliminate the restriction barring Federal loans to students convicted of campus disruption. The provision is a legal monstrosity, not merelyas an Administration spokesman put itan administrative nightmare.

title: SAFEGUARD URGED IN AID TO SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Senator Walter F. Mondale said today that Congress must write safeguards against the misuse of school desegregation aid into any version of the $1.5billion extension of the program Presi dent Nixon has requested.

title: Jordan Welcomes Speech
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 26 Jordan today joined Egypt in welcoming President Nixon'a stand on the Middle East as ex pressed in his State of the World Message to Congress yesterday.

title: Union Calls Plan a Farce
description: The executive board of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, in a statement is sued yesterday in Bal Harbour, Fla., denounced the Japanese proposals for voluntary textile restraints as a farce.

title: Market Place:
description: Perhaps it was Inevitable, lint there are shareholders of Schenley who are not happy. with Glen Alden's plan to ac quire the minority: interest in the liquor company.

title: Westinghouse Meeting Set
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day that its annual meeting would be held in Houston on April 7. This will be the first time the company has held its meetings in the Southwest. There are 2,800 Texans who own stock in the company.

title: SONYA WATSON SINGS WITH A TRIO AT MUSE
description: Sonya Watson, a young singer who is not quite ready to venture out in a solo con cert, had the good fortune to have three imaginative jazz musicians as her accompanists on Thursday night at Muse, Bedford Avenue at Lincoln Place, Brooklyn.

title: Lockheed Gets $20Million From Navy Toward Claims
description: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 26 (UPI)The Navy has paid the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation $20million as a provisional payment to settle the com pany's ship construction claims.

title: MAYORS BID STATE RAISE SCHOOL AID
description: The Mayors of the state's six largest cities warned yesterday of imminent drastic reductions in education services and re newed their plea for a phased state takeover of local educa tion budgets.

title: An Open Letter to Yale's President;A OneTime Supporter Wonders if the School Is Worth Saving
description: Dear Mr. Brewster: From what I read about college financial problems I feel a touch coming on. You will soon be asking for special gifts to save Yale. When the appeal is made I hope it will face the sober question: Is Yale, along with other private institutions of higher learning, worth saving? Let me outline the reasons for seriously doubting that the answer is affirmative.

title: Democrats Say President Indicates an Endless War
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Democratic National Commit tee's Policy Council charged today that President Nixon's State of the World Message of fered the prospect of an end less war in Indochina.

title: Improving City Council
description: The heart of the legislative process is the work done committee. The City Council of New York City is much smaller than either the Congress or the State Legislature, and its powers are more circumscribed, but it has 37 members and powers enough to conform to this general assertion. The politically independent Citizens Union yes terday released a thoughtful study of Councilmanic com mittees that recommends a number of desirable reforms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Surely it takes only a modicum of political literacyand editorial re sponsibilityto understand that a piece of official Soviet invective like the recent diatribe [OpEd article Jan. 22] against the Jewish Defense League by Spartak Beglov of the No vosti Press Agency in Moscow does not constitute a legitimate dissenting view on the question of Soviet anti Semitismon a par in some implied debate with the differing views printed alongside it.

title: Pounding a Beat in a Car Pound
description: This goes on all day long, growled. Patrolman Noel Weiss through teeth clamped on a tattered cigar. Nothing but mud and gar bage and stalled cars.

title: TEDDI KING IS HEARD IN DOWNBEAT SERIES
description: Teddi King, who was lured out of the audience to sing few songs when the Friday noontime Jazz series was begun early in January at Downbeat, 42nd Street at Lexington Av enue, returned yesterday as the star of the occasion.

title: Students Are Not Oatmeal
description: WALTHAM, Mass.America's mass media, in trumpeting the end of the student movement, are now employ ing the same kind of verbal overkill used to elevate student protest to the status of a national issue.

title: Wide Gains Seen in World Drug Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, Feb. 26Experts in nar cotics controls here are hoping for substantial benefits from new intertnational treaty that seeks to curb the illicit traffic in stimulants, tranquilizers and hallucination drugs such as LSD.

title: Japan, Short of Labor, Is Seeking Older Workers
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26A labor shortage is forcing Japanese companies to explore largely untapped sources of workers such as parttimers, middle aged and retired people and women.

title: Oil Ashore at Cape Cod
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Patches of oil from an unde termined source have been coming ashore at the Cape Cod National Seashore for the last two days, the Coast Guard said today.

title: NICKLAUS WIDENS EDGE TO 2 SHOTS
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Feb. 26Yesterday Jack Nicklaus said his 69 was a good, bad, beautiful, terrible round. After another 69 today that kept him in the lead for the Professional Golfers Asso ciation championship by two strokes, Nicklaus changed his description. Just eliminate the bad and terrible', when you talk about my golf this after noon, he said.

title: 5 Postal Unions Plan Merger of 300,000
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Leaders of five postal unions have tentatively agreed to merge their organizations into a single unit of 300,000 postal workers.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF IN QUIET TRADING
The Great Electrolysis Debate: Should Operators Be Licensed?
description: Garo Artinian, director of the Kree Institute, was dis cusing the opportunities of fered by a career in electro lysis.

title: Jamaica Bay Half Saved
description: Jamaica Bay and Kennedy Airport, a study commis sioned by the Port Authority a little over a year ago, offers two major conclusions. One is excellent and the point. The other is extremely dubious, not to say beyond the scope of the assignment undertaken by the Jamaica Bay Environmental Study Group of the National Academies of Sciences and Engineering.

title: SCHOOL DISORDERS WORRY CITY AIDES
description: School officials are becoming increasingly concerned about outbreaks of disorder at public schools here in the last two weeks.

title: British Seize Marijuana
description: LONDON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)  A ton of marijuana was seized tonight by customs of ficials at a house in north Lon don. The seizure was the largest ever made in Britain.

title: Queens Five Upsets Hunter To Join C.C.N.Y. in Final
CONNALLY BALKS ON TAX REVISIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. opposed today a number of tax reform proposals, that continue to have some sup port in Congress.

title: Executive Changes
description: Textron, Inc., has named Erskine N. White Jr. as executive vice presidentoperations. In his new as signment he will coordinate the activities of the company's corporate group officers in their work with the operating divisions. Mr. White has been group vice president since April, 1969.

title: Slump Worst in New England
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  The 1970 economic decline hit New England more sharply than the rest of the country as a whole, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston.

title: West Point Head Offers Plans For $1.6Million Jewish Chapel
description: Maj. Gen. William A. Knowl ton, superintendent of the United States Military Academy, disclosed last night, that plans had been submitted to the Pen tagon for the construction of a Jewish chapel and religious cen ter at West Point.

title: LOUIS S. WEEKS, 90, ARCHITECT, IS DEAD
description: LAWRENCE, L.I., Feb. 26Louis Seabury Weeks, an archi tect who had executed designs for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in many parts of the world, died yesterday at his home at 264 Albert Place. His age was 90.

title: Top Fives Keep City Bouncing Today
State Mediation Head Enters Contract Talks at. Con Edison
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, met yesterday with ne gotiators for the Consolidated Edison Company and Local 12 of the Utility Workers in an effort to help avert a strike threatened for March 11.

title: Colonel Faces Mylai Trial Over Charge of CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The Army announced today that Col. Oran K. Henderson, former commander of the Am erica Division's IIth Brigade, would be tried by a general courtmartial on charges of covering up the alleged mas sacre at the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 in March, 1968.

title: Larger Loss Than in 1969 Forecast by Zanuck for Fox
description: Darryl. F. Zanuck, chairman of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Company said yesterday, that the concern expected to show a bigger loss for 1970 than its 1969 pretax deficit of $65million.

title: Barn at Roosevelt Home In Hyde Park Destroyed
description: HYDE PARK, N. Y., Feb. 26 (AP)A centuryold barn at the burial place and former home of President Franklin D. Roosevelt was destroyed by fire early today.

title: REGENTS APPROVE TEACHING DEGREE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  The state Board of Regents today approved study guidelines for the new degree of doctor of arts, an experimental program that is aimed at producing more college teachers and that re quires more training in teach ing and somewhat less narrow ly focused training than does the Ph.D.

title: NIXON TO PROPOSE OPTION ON 4TH SITE IN MISSILE SHIELD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Nixon has decided to ask Congress to approve a modest continuation of the Safeguard missile defense pro gram with an option to choose later between defending Wash ington or a missile site in Wyoming, ranking Administra tion officials say.

title: TAXFREE ROLE LOST BY WOLFSON FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service has suspended the taxexempt status of the Wolfson Family Foundation Inc., which had an arrangement with former Jus tice Abe Fortas that led to his resignation from the Supreme Court.

title: U.S., at U.N. Parley, Attacks Soviet Policy on Jews
description: GENEVA, Feb. 26  The United States and Israel com plained here today against, what they called discrimination against Jews in the Soviet Union and urged Moscow to permit the emigration of those who wish to leave.

title: Bridge: Blackwood Managed League As Well He Managed Play
Foster, a Johnson Arms Aide, Now Favors a Total Test Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Wil liam C. Foster, disarmament di rector in the Administration of President Lyndon B. Johnson, tonight urged a total ban on all nuclear weapons tests as a step to slow the arms race and give a psychological lift to the ne gotiations for strategicarms control.

title: A Woman Lawyer Alleging Sex Bias, Sues City Bar Unit
description: An investigation has been ordered into a complaint by a woman lawyer that she has been barred from membership in the Metropolitan Trial Law yers Association because of her sex.

title: 13 EXPERTS UNITE TO AID CONSUMERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26At President Nixon's request, 13 experts in consumer affairs and commercial law have banded together to search for improved methods of settling disputes between buyers and sellers.

title: Greek Owners Planning Yards for Building Ships
description: ATHENS, Feb 26  Greek shipowners, who control one of the world's largest merchant fleets, are moving into the shipyard business on a scale that will enable them to build and repair their ships in Greece.

title: Air Fare Increases Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Pan American World Airways proposed today to raise its fares to Puerto Rico by an average of 9.2 per cent and to the Virgin Islands by 9.8 per cent, effective April 15.

title: Richard Rush Shows His Investment
description: Paintings are a good in vestment and they will re main so until there are defi nite signs of a serious depres sion, wrote Richard H. Rush, an investment banker and art collector, in Art as an Investment, his 1961 book. They are a good investment as compared with other in vestments, including real estate and the stock market.

title: Cairo Hints Extension of Truce
description: CAIRO, Saturday, Feb. 27 (AP)  Cairo's semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram indicated today Egypt is satisfied that progress is being made in Middle East peace talks at the United Nations and will ex tend the ceasefire past March 7.

title: Calley Trial Suspended Because of Tornado Alert
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 26  A tornado alert forced a suspension today in the My lai murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., interrupt ing a sharp debate over wheth er the Government should be allowed to introduce testimony regarding other acts of al leged misconduct by the young officer.

title: Chancellor of Regents Joseph Washington McGovern
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26The al ways genteel atmosphere of the end of the monthly meet ings here of the Board of Re gents was ruffled slightly today.

title: Thurmond Still Urges Quota.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb., 26 (UPI)Senator Strom Thurmond said today that the offer of the Japanese textile industry was a subterfuge that in no way lessened the need for quota legislation.

title: EDUCATION BOARD, CITING FISCAL GAP, PLANS SHARP CUTS
description: The Board of Education an nounced yesterday that it would make a series of severe cuts in educational services, effec tive within two weeks, because the school system is $40mil lion short of the money it needs for the balance of the 197071 term.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A few minutes before the fight, the stepfather said, He's a good kid. He's going to win tonight. He went to the gym every day this week.

title: BANKRUPTCY FILED BY TRANSOGRANI
description: The Transogram Company, Inc., an oldline toy company that held a central position in the financial dealings of Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., filed yesterday under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, listing liabilities of $12, 067,307 and assets of $3, 009,072.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts Two Leaders Of Rebel Unit of Miners'
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The President and another top officer of the international union of District 50. Allied and Technical Workers  formerly District 50 of the United Mine Workers  were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury. They are accused of embez zling nearly $15,000 from the union treasury over the last five years to pay for vacation trips to Florida and Puerto Rico.

title: L. S. Pratt Marries Mrs. Kremer
description: Mrs. Emily Carpenter Kre mer of Montclair, N. J., widow of James Brainerd Kremer 3d, was married here yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building to Lawrence Southwick Pratt of New York, a partner in the law firm of Willkie, Farr & Gallagher.

title: EARL L. LAWIT
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Feb. 26 Earl L. Lawit of 8 Essex Road, a mortgage broker for Heritage Mortgage Associates and a Jewish leader, died Wednesday in East Orange General Hospital at the age of 50.

title: Richard W. Clarke Dies at 74; A Former Editor of Daily News
description: Richard W. Clarke, who re tired as editor of The Daily News in June, 1968, died last night in Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Lewistone, Me.

title: BOEING STEPS UP PROFIT FOR YEAR
FIRE SET ON CAMPUS IN TEXAS DISORDERS
description: PRAIRIE VIEW, Tex., Feb. 26  Arsonists eluded campus guards before dawn today, climbed a fire escape and set fire to the military science building at the Prairie View Agricultural and Mechanical College.

title: Real Estate Expert Urges Variable Mortgage Rates
description: A leading real estate ex pert, warning that tremendous demands for capital make inev itable a periodic dryingup of funds for the construction of housing, urged yesterday the broadscale adoption of vari able mortgage rates.

title: Israel Fears Clash With U.S.
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 26Israelis fear that President Nixon's for eign policy statement yesterday presages a collision with Israel over Middle East peace borders.

title: Dr. Theodor Svedberg Is Dead; Nobel Laureate in Chemistry
description: STOCKHOLM, Feb. 26 (UPI) Prof. Theodor H. E. Sved berg, Swedish nuclear scientist and winner of the 1926 Nobel Prize in chemistry, has died at the age of 86, his family an nounced today.

title: Warner &
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 26 (AP)The Warner & Swasey Com pany announced today the pur chase of the commercial winch line of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., of Wayne, Mich. Details of the transaction were not dis closed. Warner & Swasey is a manufacturer of utility and Underground cable pulling winches.

title: Hanoi Dismisses Message by Nixon
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 26 (Reu ters)Hanoi today dismissed President Nixon's message on foreign affairs yesterday as inflated rhetoric that offered the world nothing new.

title: Cambodian Asks Invasion
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Koun Wick of Cambodia called today for an invasion of North Vietnam by the United States and its allies.

title: White House Ready to Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  White House officials said today that the United States would certainly discuss a pro posal for voluntary restraints by Japanese textile leaders. The new talks would be held here between Peter Flanigan, a Presi dential assistant, and Japan's Ambassador, Nobuhiko Ushiba.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A recent decision by the Second U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that flags and emblems bearing a peace symbol are permitted by the Constitu tion's First Amendment. The court also indicated the state general business law was vague about such usage.

title: Cholesterol Treatment Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 A Long Island inventor pro poses to detect the buildup of cholesterol in the human circulatory system and to re move it, in either case, by ultrasonic vibra tions. Arthur Ku ris was granted Patent 3,565,062 this week for the method and ap paratus to be used in dis lodging the deposits from the blood vessels. A second pat ent has been allowed and will be issued to him soon for the diagnostic procedure. Both are assigned to Ultrasonic Systems, Inc., Farmingdale, of which Mr. Kuris is pres ident.

title: Transit Authority Agrees to Modify Central Park Plan
description: The Transit Authority ac cepted yesterday modifica tion of its plans for construc tion of the new QueensMan hattan subway under Central Park to reduce the ripping up of park land by 53.4 per cent and to cut construction time from three years to two.

title: Japanese Textile Offer
description: Japanese textile producers have agreed to limit their export sales to the United States voluntarily in an effort to head off far more restrictive compulsory quotas. The Japanese firms have apparently decided to hold the growth of their sales in this country to 5 per cent per year for at least the next two years, with no restrictions placed on particular groups of products or specific items.

title: ISRAELI MESSAGE GIVEN TO JARRING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 26  Israel informed Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, today that she was willing to discuss in detail territorial and other terms of a peace agreement with the United Arab Republic, informed sources reported.

title: For the Moment, Home is Where a Hindu Goddess Is Painted on the Wall
description: On an Air India flight from Bombay to New York three years ago, Sita Murari wasn't at all sure she should but she did it anyway: When the hostess wasn't looking, she quietly put the airline menu card in her handbag. Later, in New York, she made a mural based on it.

title: JOE LAYTON DANCE GIVEN IN ENGLAND
description: STRATFORDONAVON, Eng land, Feb. 25Joe Layton, di rector and choreographer of many successful Broadway shows, has achieved a lifetime's ambition by creating his first work for a ballet company. The Grand Tour, given by the Royal Ballet's touring company at the Royal Shakespeare Thea ter tonight, is a stylish and en tertaining evocation of the early 1930's.

title: Economic Growth In '71'72 Is Seen
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) Two professors at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce predict an ex panded economy by the end of 1971, but say this recovery will not bring the nation's econ omy to the goal President Nixon has set for the 1972 election year.

title: News Analysis
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Another major oil production problem, thornier in some re spects than the Alaska pipeline case, is lying on the desk of Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton, awaiting action. It is the question of expanded oil development in the Santa Bar bara Channel, where production already is in prog ress, and where the attendant en vironmental haz ards were dramat ically manifested in the offshore well blowout of January, 1969. already is in prog ress, and where the attendant en vironmental haz ards were dramat ically manifested in the offshore well blowout of January, 1969.

title: Administration Reported Split On U.S. Carrier Visit to Chile
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The Chilean Ambassador, Or lando Letelier, said here today that the United States aircraft carrier Enterprise would pay a fourday port call to Val paraiso starting Sunday.

title: PrivateCollege Applications Decrease Sharply
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26A wide spread shift in the patterns by which young Americans apply to colleges, marked by a precip itous drop in applications to highcost private schools and a rise in applications to lower cost public institutions, is causing uncertainty and some apprehension this year on campuses across the country.

title: Garden Adds to Roosevelt Stock
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation announced yester day it held more than 80 per cent of the outstanding capital stock of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., and had completed its ac quisition of the assets of the Transnation Development Cor poration.

title: Taiwan Is Critical
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 26 The press of Nationalist China today roundly criticized Pres ident Nixon's comments, in his message on foreign affairs, that the United States would seek to increase contacts with Com munist China and draw Peking into a constructive relation ship with the world commu nity.

title: Student Killed in France
description: AIX EN PROVENCE, France, Feb. 26 (AP)Steven Spigner, 20 years old, of the State Uni versity of New York at Buffalo was killed last night when he was hit by a train at a grade level crossing near here. Mr. Spigner was in his third year of studies at the American in stitute here.

title: Antiques: Vizcaya is Open to Public
description: Anyone interested in see ing antiques in an ideal set ting should visit Vizcaya, the Miami residence of the late James Deering.

title: Developer of Silicones Honored
description: One of chemistry's highest awards was presented last night to the man who played a major role in developing a versatile family of synthetic, substancesthe silicones. They are used in airplanes and kitch ens, delicate surgery and astro nauts spacesuits and a wide variety of other products.

title: Barbara Cochran Is First In Cup Giant Slalom
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Feb. 26 (AP)Barbara Ann Cochran of Richmond, Vt., captured the giant slalom to day to sweep the women's events of the World Cup ski races, and Gustavo Thoeni of Italy took the lead after the men's first giant slalom.

title: U.S. and France Sign Antidrug Accord
description: PARIS, Feb. 26France and the United States signed an agreement today sealing their cooperation in the police war against the drug traffic. At torney General John N. Mitchell declared that if other coun tries joined in, then the ty ranny of narcotics can be en circled and overthrown.

title: Salvatore Bonanno Given Year's Term in Conspiracy
description: Salvatore Bonanno, son of former reputed leader of or ganized crime here, Joe Bonan no, was sentenced to one year in prison and fined $1,500 yes terday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: SIX EXCASINO AIDES INDICTED IN NEVADA
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (UPI) Six persons, including known underworld figures, racetrack officials, and a former Michi gan judge, were charged today with concealing their past con trol of a Las Vegas gambling casino now owned by Howard Hughes.

title: CATHERINE LINDER, ON CHURCH'S STAFF
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 26Mrs. Catherine Linder, who had long been active in religious and welfare publicrelations work, died today in St. Agnes Hospital after a heart attack. She was 70 years old and lived at 2 Orchard Parkway.

title: WITH ZVI STRESSES PIANO'S SOMBER SIDE
description: Idith Zvi, a 24yearold Is raeli pianist, was presented in a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night by the Concert Artists Guild.

title: Fort Marcy to Carry 128 Today
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26The Hia leah Turf Cup, one of the more popular events on the winter racing calendar, has attracted a field of 13 for its running tomorrow, with the Rokeby Stable's Fort Marcy the strong choice.

title: Alleged Top Heroin Importer Convicted on 15Count Charge
description: The reputed top heroin im porter in the United States and an associate were convicted by a Brooklyn Federal court jury yesterday on 15 counts of vio lating narcotics laws.

title: A Skating Party for Brooklyn Benefit Lures the Young
description: They came wearing blue jeans, lame pants, chiffon evening dresses and printed cotton peasant outfits. In stead of tiny evening bags, their hands clutched sturdy canvas totes into which their skates were stuffed.

title: U.S. HIJACKER ASKS TO STAY IN CANADA
description: VANCOUVER, B. C., Feb. 26 (UPI)A United States Army draftee applied for permanent residence in Canada today after hijacking an airliner with 92 passengers aboard to Can ada to avoid military service.

title: Bureau Declines to Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26A spokesman for the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs declined today to discuss wheth er French and American efforts against international drug syn dicates were successful and whether the amount of opium coming from Turkey had de clined.

title: NIXON PICKS AIDE IN LOCKHEED PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Nixon has asked his new Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally Jr., to over see whatever role the Admin istration assumes in the nego tiations between the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the British Government, White House sources said today.

title: BonnMoscow Trade Talks Under Way
description: BONN, Feb. 26  West Ger many and the Soviet Union have opened talks here on a trade agreement that the Ger mans hope will formally in clude Soviet trade with West Berlin.

title: KENT V. LUKINGBEAL, LAWYER, DIES AT 53
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Feb. 26Kent V. Lukingbeal, a part ner in the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, died today in the Stamford Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived on Bridle Path Lane here and had a summer home in Barnstable, Mass.

title: Deerfield's Tuition Raised
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP)Deerfield Academy an nounced today that its tuition would go up $200 next fall, putting the total cost for a year at the private boys prep aratory school at $3,950.

title: MIDI VIETNAMESE BATTERED BY FOE AT A BASE IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 27Heavy en emy tank and infantry attacks were reported yesterday to have routed South Vietnamese troops from many defensive positions on a Laotian hilltop.

title: 11 ARE ARRESTED IN RELIEF PROTEST
description: Welfare rights activists ended a City Hall demonstration yes terday afternoon, rode uptown in chartered buses andexhort ed by shouts of right on, right in and how many more chil dren will have to diedashed into a vacant new apartment building on Manhattan's West Side.

title: Students at Stanford Urge Lindsay for '72
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 Three dozen Stanford Uni versity students spent several hours today carrying signs through downtown San Fran cisco to urge Mayor Lindsay of New York to run for President as a Democrat in 1972.

title: 15 Reported Killed As Students Battle Colombian Troops
description: CALI, Colombia, Feb. 26 (AP) Troops fought bloody battles today with students trying to oust a university president. The armed forces command said 15 persons had been killed and 49 wounded, 1 seriously.

title: U.S. Approves Reply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reu ters)State Department spokes man, Robert J. McCloskey said today that in general, we have told the Mayor of West Berlin we endorse his reply.

title: Blackfriars Group Gives And the Devil Makes 5
description: The year is 1990, with a lawless world on the brink of a third war. Inside the strange house, where a middleaged couple has sought refuge, the jittery wife watches as her scholarly husband dabbles in the occult. He passionately wants to contact the devil to beg compassion for sur viving humanity.

title: Eagle Quickly Steps Her Mast To Defend OceanRacing Title
Frank Robinson Accepts $130,000 Oriole Contract
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)Frank Robinson, the 35yearold su perstar who has ambitions of becoming the first black major league manager, signed a con tract today with the Baltimore Orioles for $130,000.

title: Census Finds Rise In Negro Families Headed by Women
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The proportion of black fami lies headed by women in creased sharply in the nineteen sixties to a level three times that of whites.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This is in response to the extraor dinary letter of Richard C. DeBold (Feb. 14) in opposition to a volunteer armed service.

title: Egypt Reacts Favorably
description: CAIRO, Feb. 26  Cairo's leading newspaper, AlAhram, which reflects official views on foreign policy, said today that President Nixon's remarks on the Middle East crisis in his State of the World Message were worthy of thorough study.

title: Shouting Jordanian Seized On Swissair Jet to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 26 (AP) A Jordanian began shouting and waving a pocketknife aboard a Swissair jetliner in flight yesterday because, he said, he could no longer stand the body searches at the airports and the suspicious looks.

title: MRS. EDGAR J. BOGGS
description: DOVER, Del., Feb. 26 (AP)Mrs. Edgar J. Boggs, mother of United States Senator J. Caleb Boggs, Republican of Delaware, died yesterday in a hospital at the age of 86.

title: WHEAT FUTURES HIGHER AT CLOSE
description: Reports that Spain and some African countries were in the market to buy wheat led to an increase in wheat futures prices yesterday. As prices ad vanced, some short sellers also bought to settle their posi tions.

title: Books of The Times
description: Negative Space. Manny Farber on the Movies. 288 pages. Praeger Publishers. $7.95.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: David Rockefeller is to be com mended for endorsing the creation of public agencies to help acquire land and provide financing for the develop ment of 110 new cities.

title: Daniel Boone on Campus
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The willing suspension of disbelief is as important to the Movement as it is to the theater. And surely one of the greatest attri butes students have brought to recent efforts for change in America is a faith that hard work will bring results. Therefore to say that students have lost their innocence in the past eight months is to wax extremely pessimistic about the chance for change in the future.

title: ABRAHAM WIENER, CHEMICALS MAKER
description: Abraham Wiener, a chem ical manufacturer, died on Thursday at New York Hos pital after a short illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 820 Park Avenue.

title: Tullio Carminati, Actor, Dies; Star in Strictly Dishonorable
description: ROME, Feb. 26 (UPI)Tullio Carminati, the actor, died to day of a stroke. He was 77 years old.

title: Miss Schuba Gains Commanding Lead In Figure Skating
Colombo Acquitted In Conspiracy Case
description: A Federal Court jury in Brooklyn last night acquitted Joseph Colombo Jr. and Joseph Ianacci of charges that they had conspired to melt American silver coins into more valuable ingots, but a third defendant, David Lennard, was found guilty the same charge.

title: TV Industry Layoffs Continue Despite 1970 Profit
description: Despite the national business recession that continues to be devil the country's broadcast ers, the television industry Made a profit last year. The Television Bureau of Advertis ing says that 1970 television revenues will be $3.66billion, up 2.1 per cent over 1969's $3.58billion.

title: Teacher Here Beaten And Robbed in School
description: A 53yearold general sci ence teacher at a Queens intermediate school was as saulted and robbed of $380 in his classroom yesterday afternoon by two teenaged boys who entered during a firedrill evacuation.

title: Dropping of Lines Proposed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) The Penn Central Transporta tion Company, which hopes eventually to eliminate about 8,000 of its 20,000 route miles as it undergoes reorganization, filed plans today to eliminate 819 of those miles.

title: Local School Funds to Be Discussed
description: In the midst of a crisis over its budget, the Board of Educa tion will meet over the weekend with the 31 community school boards to hear their views on how funds should he allocated to meet the districts special needs.

title: Graebner Sets Back Koch, Gains Macon Net Semifinals
description: MACON. Ga., Feb. 26 (UPI) Clark Graebner of New York, the topseeded American, de feated Thomas Koch of Brazil, 63, 36, 75, tonight and gained the semifinal round of the Macon international tennis tournament.

title: Plane Crash Kills Eight In a South Carolina Fog
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 26 (UPI)A twinengine private plane crashed and burned today while attempting to land in fog and rain at Columbia Metropol itan Airport and eight persons were killed.

title: Interrnedia Work by Subotnick For Quintet Flickers at Hunter
description: Morton Subotnick, the elec tronicmusic composer, believes the concert hall is no more than a living museum, an argu able if not exactly startling idea in our culture's old age. What to do, then, when a living concert group, the Dorian Quintet, asks him to write a new work for concerthall use? Why, accept, of course, and try to demonstrate in the piece how foolish and futile his own efforts are.

title: STUDENTS RECRUIT ANTIDRUG PATROL
description: Students at Bronx Commu nity College formed a patrol yesterday to combat the grow ing narcotics use on campus and forestall an ultimatum by the college's president to bring the police into the school.

title: CLAYTON RAND, 79, EDITOR, PUBLISHER
description: GULFPORT, Miss, Feb. 26 (AP)Clayton Rand, a syndi cated columnist, author and publisher, died today after a short illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Nixon Given D.A.V. Stamps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)President Nixon received to day at a White House cerc mony an album of commemo rative stamps honoring the Dis abled American Veterans. The organization's national com mander, Civil W. Stevenson and the assistant national ad jutant, Frank G. Wood, made the presentation of the stamps honoring U. S. prisoners of war and those missing and killed in action.

title: A Job Where Time With One's Family Becomes Very Scarce
description: WASHINGTON  Who wants a job that requires a sevenday week, a cut in sal ary and so little time for family life that a 7yearold girl who wants to see. her lather must get up at 6:30 to talk to him while he's shav ing?

title: Dartmouth Skiers Capture Two Events at Middlebury
New Factory to Build Mississippi Homes
description: BILOXI, Miss., Feb. 26The Stirling Homex Corporation, builder of modular housing, an nounced today that it would build a $5million factory mid way between Biloxi and Gulf port.

title: Mrs. King and Mrs. Jones Reach Tennis Semifinals
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 26 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., the top seeded American, defeated Mrs. Judy Tegart Dalton of Aus tralia, 60, 62, today and moved into the semifinals of the $12,500 national women's in door tennis championships.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Statements quoted from the recently released report of the National Acad emies of Sciences and Engineering on Jamaica Bay raise questions about the inclusion of the bay in the proposed Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: Art: Poetic Drawings by Masurovsky
description: It is rare nowadays for an artist to establish his reputa tion entirely on the basis of drawings. We somehow as sociate the higher levels of seriousness with painting or sculpture or their various amalgamswith media that make a bigger splash and oc cupy larger physical spaces. Yet for artists of a certain dispositionadmittedly, they are now a distinct and de creasing minority  drawing remains the conscience of the visual arts, the esthetic area in which individual vi sion is tested and formed.

title: A MAIL TEST FINDS ZIP CODE IS NO HELP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  A nationwide test of mail service indicates that adding the zip code to an address does not guarantee faster delivery of first class or airmail letters, but postal officials say future mechanization will bring a distinct advantage in zip cod ing.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 26A year ago, a British expert on American foreign policy was doing an appraisal of President Nixon's first Message on the State of the World. He felt it necessary to begin with a comment on the state of America.

title: OIL STOCKS DROP ON LONDON BOARD
New Issue Offers Stay on Even Keel In an Active Week
description: The newissue market, which posted sharp gains over the last two months, lost some of its punch this week but re mained on an even keel as underwriters stepped up their efforts to bring privately held companies public.

title: New Zealand's Hopes Roused by Mineral Prospects
description: AUCKLAND, New ZealandWorldwide interest in Aus tralia's fabulous minerals boom has spilled over into this neigh boring country. Prospects of previously unsuspected wealth underground has diluted some of the gloom engendered by in flation, labor strains and un favorable prospects for New Zealand's big export market of dairy products in Britain if that country succeeds in efforts to join the European Economic Community.

title: College Magazines Short of Humor and Funds
description: The Princeton Tiger, was once a fearsome creature, but its next trip could be down the drain.

title: Alaska Pipeline Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that its board of directors had adopted a resolution supporting con struction of the proposed Alas kan pipeline.

title: Reagan Rebuffed on Bid To Unveil Welfare Program
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 26 (UPI)State Senate Demo cratic leaders yesterday denied Gov. Ronald Reagan's request to appear before a joint session of the California Legislature to unveil his welfare reform pro gram.

title: Cosmos 398 Is Launched
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Soviet Union today launched an unmanned satellite, Cosmos 398, into the earth's orbit, Tass, the official press agency, said.

title: SEX FRUSTRATION THEME IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Feb. 26  At first glance you could mistake Stanley Eveling's Mister at the Duchess Theater for a standard trip round the museum of male sexual frustration.

title: National Steel Is Sued by U.S.; Accused of Reciprocal Dealings
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)The Government today sued the nation's fourth largest steel producer, the National Steel Corporation, charging it with using reciprocal purchasing arrangements with sup pliers and customers.

title: France Protests Nationalizing Of Oil Interests by Algerians
description: PARIS, Feb. 26The French Government formally protested today against nationalization of French petroleum interests in Algeria, and the Bank of France considered suspending mone tary privileges Algeria has re ceived as part of its special relationship with France.

title: U.S. Helpless on ClamBed Pollution Oil Jersey
description: WILDWOOD, N.J., Feb. 26Top Federal environmental of ficials rolled in an oceangoing clam boat in the. Atlantic off this city today and agreed that a serious pollution problem was developing that they had little power to remedy.

title: U.N. Peacekeeping
description: The United Nations came last and received relatively, short shrift in President Nixon's second State of the World Message. But in the end the President did recog nize the transcendent importance to the United States of a more effective international organization to deal with a wide range of world problems, from peace and security to environmental pollution.

title: U.S. AIDES REJECT MOVE INTO NORTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Au thoritative Administration offi cials said today that the United States has no intention of send ing ground troops into North Vietnam, and they strongly dis counted the likelihood of a South Vietnamese ground at tack on North Vietnam.

title: CATARINA LIGENDZA HAS TIDELIO DEBUT
description: Catarina Ligendza, a Swedish soprano despite her Italianate name, had been scheduled to make her debut with the Metro politan Opera as Leonore in Fidelio several weeks ago. Illness delayed her appearance, but she at least made the final performance this season of the Beethoven work on Thursday night.

title: TEXTILE ACCORD GAINING IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 27The outline of a settlement of Japan's protracted textile dis pute with the United States emerged here this week follow ing Representative Wilbur D. Mills's reported proposal for unilateral voluntary selfre straints by the Japanese textile industry on exports of cotton, woolen and syntheticfiber goods to the United States.

title: U.S. Bars Soviet Film Crew in Retaliatory Step
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The State Department said today that it had turned down for the present the visa applica tions of a Soviet documentary film crew because of Soviet treatment of American film makers.

title: Shorter Wins A.A.U. 3Mile Run
description: A thick film of smoke that blanketed Madison Square Gar den may have snuffed out Frank Shorter's chances for a world indoor record in the threemile run last night at the national Amateur Athletic Union cham pionships.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES COUNCIL MAKEUP
description: A report permeated with crit icism of the absolute domina tion of the City Council by its majority leader was made public yesterday by the Citi zens Union.

title: RollsRoyce Extension
description: LONDON, Feb. 26 (AP)The British Government is ready to extend its pledge to keep Rolls Royce working on the costly RB211 jet engine, authoritative sources reported today.

title: Expos Bring Bailey Home
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26 (UPI)Bob Bailey, the Expos last unsigned player, agreed to terms with Montreal today for an estimated $42,000.

title: Gitmo: 7,500 Americans on a Hostile Shore
description: UNITED STATES NAVAL BASE, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, Feb. 19The Soviet freighter Yemelyan Pugachev, homeward bound from Boqueron, Cuba, for Lenin grad with a cargo of sugar, nosed her way past destroy ers, frigates, supply ships and submarines of the United States Navy.

title: COLOMBO DENIES U.S. INTERFERES IN ITALY
description: ROME, Feb. 26Premier Emilio Colombo, in a report to Parliament today on his recent visit to the United States, re jected Communist charges of American interference in Italian domestic politics.

title: A NEWSPAPER TRUCK BURNED ON STATEN I.
description: Four men burned a truck delivering The Staten Island Advance and assaulted the driver and his helper yesterday.

title: Dr. Carl Deuber, Director Of Research Laboratory
description: ARDSLEY, N. Y., Feb. 26Dr. Carl G. Deuber, director of the Deuber biochemical testing and research laboratory here, formerly of New York, died yesterday in Dobbs Ferry Hos pital. He was 72 years old and lived at 531 Ashford Ave nue.

title: Governor of Rhode Island Signs Income Tax Measure
description: PROVIDENCE, Feb. 26 (AP)Gov. Frank Licht signed into law today Rhode Island's first income tax. He acted minutes after the Senate approved the measure, 26 to 24, in a session marked by a rowdy demonstra tion in the statehouse corridors.

title: Thieu Said to Be Misquoted
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (AP)A spokesman for Pres ident Nguyen Van Thieu said today that Mr. Thieu had been misquoted as having said that an invasion of North Vietnam was only a matter of time.

title: SIX INDICTED HERE ON DRUG SELLING
description: A suspended policeman, a former policeman and four oth er men were charged in a Fed eral indictment yesterday with a conspiracy to sell narcotics here.

title: Skepticism in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26  The Soviet Union reacted with skepticism today to President Nixon's foreign policy message. It found nothing to praise in the document and the Ameri can press was quoted to show that it contained no new ele ments.

title: Film: Mastroianni and Loren Team Up
PROBLEMS LISTED BY PUERTO RICANS
description: Puerto Rican college and high school students appeared yes terday before a White House task force on problems of minority groups and recounted the problems in their schools and communities.

title: Harvard Six Tops Yale, 114
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26Harvard defeated Yale in hockey to night, 114, at the Boston Arena. Harvard was paced by Dan DeMichele, who scored three goals. Joe Cavanagh got a goal and four assists and Dave Hynes scored two goals and three assists for the Crim son.

title: Prices to Farmers Up 5% for Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  Prices paid farmers for their products soared 5 per cent the month ended Feb. 15, the Agriculture Department an nounced today.

title: PETERSON AGREES TO YANKEE TERMS
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26  Fritz Peterson, Dan ny Cater and Ron Hansen, the last three New York Yankees to agree to terms, did so today and the first two signed in time to take part in the first scheduled workout for the en tire squad.

title: January's Trade Surplus Below Any Month in '70
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The United States's surplus of exports over imports, after im proving in December dropped in January to a level lower than any month last year, the Com coerce Department reported to day.

title: Esso Research Co. Ends Jobs of 250; Scientists Included
description: LINDEN, N.J. Feb. 26 (AP) The Esso Research and En gineering Company, a sub sidiary of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has notified 250 employes more than half of them scientists and engineers  that they arc to be discharged, a company spokesman said today.

title: Subpoenaed Film Used by Newark In Teachers Trial
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26 (AP) Essex County Prosecutor Jo seph Lordi said today that filmed footage used at the con tempt trial of three leaders of the Newark teachers strike had been subpoenaed from two New York television stations.

title: 20 Die in Gold Mine Blast
description: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Afri Ca, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Twenty African gold miners were killed in a methane gas explosion to day at a mine in Virginia, 80 miles northeast of here. Twenty seven other persons were in jured.

title: Plainfield Rink Advances In Eddison Medal Bonspiel
description: ARDSLEY ON HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 26The Plainfield (N. J.) Curling Club rink, skipped by Robert Fuller, led the way into the quarter final round of the Eddison Medal bonspiel at Ardsley Country Club today.

title: Title Ski Flying Put Off
description: IRONWOOD, Mich., Feb. 26 (AP)For the second consecu tive day, practice rides for the North American ski flying meet at Harbor Park here were post poned because of cross winds and soft snow. Winds contin ued to gust up to 15 miles an hour across the takeoff and temperatures in the 40's soft ened the snow on the landing hill. Action is expected to re sume tomorrow.

title: Equity Library Gets Grant
description: The Equity Library Theater, the showcase for professional performers, sponsored by the Actors Equity Association, has been awarded a grant of $10, 000 by the New York State Council on the Arts. The thea ter's next production is Gilbert and Sullivan's Ruddigore, opening next Thursday.

title: Traditional Indian Art Is Exhibited
description: The prejudices that whites have fostered in this count toward the Indian and his way of life have also extend. ed to his art. Indian objects, which have usually been dis paragingly referred to as artifacts and rarely as art, have been grossly neglected to the point of ruin and even irretrievable loss.

title: Boston Gets U.S. Aid For Study of Transit
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP)Transportation problems in the metropolitan Boston area will be studied under a $3.5 million grant from the De partment of Transportation.

title: Miss Falck Sets Run Mark
description: KIEL, Germany, Feb. 27 (AP) Hildegard Falck of West Ger many set a world record to night for the Women's 800 meter run of 2 minutes 3.9 seconds in the finals of the German indoor athletic cham pionships. She bettered the previous mark of 2:05.3 set by Barbara Wieck of East Ger many.

title: Italian Group Puts Picketsat S.I. Paper For the Fourth Day
description: About 75 members of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League picketed for a fourth day yesterday outside The Staten Island Advance to pro test the use of the terms Mafia and Cosa Nostra in newspaper articles.

title: Prospect Park's Future Is Pondered: A Place to Play or a Place to Find Tranquillity?
description: Prospect Park is the center of a controversy among many Brooklynites who wander in 526 acres of bril liantly designed rolling meadows, picturesque bluffs and luxuriant vegetation. The debate is over whether mas sive city efforts to halt the park's decline are doing more harm than good.

title: Television
description: ZALMAN KING (no Lef kowitz) is a Jewish boys front Trenton, New Jer sey, with sheepdog hair, bassett hound eyes, and a profile no collie would dream of. In fact, it's a pro file any actor who hoped to be a leading man would have had nightmares about not very long ago. It's evidently a psychopathic killer's face by Hollywood standards, for that's how King had been typecast on TV shows such as Gunsmoke and The F.B.I. when he gave up com mercial acting for under ground filmmaking three years ago, determined to be a leading man whether he got paid for it or not.

title: Kerr on Subject to Fits
description: ROBERT Montgomery's Subject to Fits, which is billed as A Response to Dosto yevsky's The Idiot,  is the sort of play at which the audience, during intermission, quickly hurries to the blow ups of the critics reviews in the lobby not so much to see what in heaven's name the critics can have found to praise in the occasion as to see what in heaven's name they thought it was all about. Quick guidance is wanted.

title: No Problem Too Small for village Managers
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 13Five mornings a week at 8:45, Mil ton White parks his car near the duck pond, unlocks the door of his 18thcentury Vil lage Hall, climbs a flight of narrow, carpeted stairs and be gins his work of running this village of 3,000 citizens.

title: The Pleasures Of Helen
description: The Pleasures of Helen is a smooth commercial novel about a career woman who longs des perately to become a sex ob ject. (Shut up, Women's Lib, I'm telling it like it is in the book.) Helen Miley, age 32 or thereabouts, a ferociously com petent p.r. executive with a heart as big as a whale, would like nothing better than to marry one of the male clucks she cultivates. But one after another they turn out to be a mama's boy, or an intransigent single, or some kind of a nut, or married. Helen is about as stylized in speech and deport ment as one of Damon Runyon's brassy ladies, but if you can accept her on Mr. Sanders's terms, she is part of an un pretentious entertainment.

title: State Agency Predicts Growth Of L.I. Area's Water Problems
description: Increasingly severe water Supply problems for Long Island, as well as New York City and the lower Hudson Valley, are being forecast by the State Office of Planning Coordination.

title: California Agents Halt Cancer Shuttle on Border
description: IMPERIAL BEACH, Calif., Feb. 27California Food and Drug agents moved this week to break up what they described as an underground railroad that has been transporting can cer victims hit Mexico for treatment with a drug that is banned in the United States and Canada.

title: Legend of Gael, a Gordon Setter, Is Judged Best at Providence K. C. Show
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 27  America's No. 1 Gordon setter. Ch. Legend of Gael, C.D., was No. 1 among the 1,507 dogs at the Providence County Kennel Club's 60th show today at the Cranston Street Armory.

title: Florida Prison Shootings Called Effort to Protect the Inmates
description: RAIFORD, Fla., Feb. 27I gave the order to shoot... I did It to protect the inmates themselves.

title: Boy Scout Saved After Fall Of 120 Feet in Palisades
description: APINE, N. J., Feb. 27 A 13yearold Boy Scout hiking in Palisades Interstate Park today fell 120 feet into a gulley where he was trapped for two hours with a broken leg.

title: Lebanon Seeks New Foreign Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon (Reuters)  Lebanon, which attracted a wave of foreign capital in the early nineteensixties, is now worried about the num ber of foreign companies that choose other countries as a base for their MiddleEast op erations.

title: Joel Pocock Wed to Paul Mitchell
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Feb. 27 Miss Kathryn Joel Pocock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Pocock of Villa nova, was married in the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church this afternoon to Paul Alexander Mitchell, son of John M. Mitchell of Stam ford, Conn., and Greensboro, Vt., and Mrs. Barbara ,J. Mitchell of Stamford. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. David B. Water mulder.

title: Reader's Report Lives to Give By Sanche de Gramont. 320 pp. New York:
description: For many of us the German occupation of France in World War 11 is a misty epoch, its dimness occasionally brightened by heroic saboteurs blowing up a Nazi troop train Mr. de Gra ifront's astringent book is a welcome contrast to such sim plism, to wartime stereotypes and to distortions of hindsight. His novel of France prostrate is a subtle recreation of life as it was: fascinating in its variety of responses to oppres sion. Resistance fighters, col laborators and citizenry of vary ing intermediate hues jostle one another, each making his in dividual accommodation to life. Mr. de Gramont (author of The French) has freshly minted ob servations to make concerning political figures of the day like Charles Maurras, and de Gaulle ta master at the art of dis pleasing). He anatomizes the bureaucracy of Vichy (a king dom of illusion), and he re constitutes the smell of the oc cupation.

title: Education
description: American higher education faces two separate finan cial problems: the universi ties deficits and the stu dents (or their parents') strained budgets. University deficits, as a result of ris ing costs and declining re search funds, have become critical in the past two years, with no end in sight. As the deficits increase, colleges must raise tuition, thereby further threatening family budgets, already hard pressed by inflation and re cession.

title: SPACE NETWORK URGED BY COMSAT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)  Comsat, the Communi cations Satellite Corporation, proposed today to put up three satellites to provide tele vision, telephone and data serv ices for all the United States and Puerto Rico.

title: A Touch of Spring in the City Brings Out a Touch of the Poet in U.S. Weather Service's Forecaster
description: Coats were being worn loosely or not at all, and miniskirts were replacing slacks yesterday as the tem perature here rose into the midsixties, 19 degrees above normal.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: LAST Sunday a letter head ed End of the Drama Review? appeared in The Times signed by a number of people for whom I have very great respect. Be cause I understand that at least some of the people whose names appeared on the letter never read it, much less composed it, and be cause the letter contained such a distortion of the facts as to suggest that deception was involved, I would like to present my explanation.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONLieutenant Calley's sad account of not having questioned the legality of his superior's orders to waste some unarmed Vietnamese civilians chillingly suggests the brutal ity of a war for the pacification of whole populations.

title: Dance
description: WHAT is a dance image, and can you buy one in a shop? Dance image has become part of the very lim ited esthetic vocabulary of dance criticism, and yet sometimes we use the phrase very loosely. What then is meant by a dance image? I was thinking about the ques tion the other week watch ing the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: Anne Henning's 44.02 Wins In 500Meter Speed Skating
description: INZELL, Germany, Feb. 27 (AP)Anne Henning of North brook, Ill., who set a world speedskating record of 42.91 seconds for 500 meters in the sprint championships here last weekend, won the event today at the twoday Golden Skates competition.

title: Evans Phelps To Be a Bride
description: PASADENA, Calif., Feb. 27 Miss Evans Phelps, a student at Hunter College in New York, will be married July 24 to Steve Michelson, a sen ior at the University of Penn sylvania. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Mason Phelps of Pasadena and Des barats, Ontario, where the wedding will take place.

title: Study Calls the City's Social Services Inadequate
description: Social services to help in dividuals in New York City were pictured in a new study yesterday as not sufficient in quantity or equal to their mis sion today, with most in adequately responsive to the need around them.

title: More Homosexuals Aided To Become Heterosexual
description: You are a sad and pathetic man, says Harold in Mart Crowley's play The Boys in the Band. You're a homo sexual and you don't want to be. But there is nothing you can do to change it.

title: Staunch Avenger Upset
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark, Feb. 27 (AP)Barbizon Streak, an Arkansasbred 3yearold colt, scored a threequarterlength upset victory over previously undefeated Staunch Avenger in the $20,000 Southwest Handi cap today at Oaklawn Park.

title: Up the Escalator
description: It is difficult to deny the right of military commanders to send American ground combat troops into Laos if necessary to help effect the rescue of American pilots who are downed there while supporting South Viet namese forces in the southern panhandle.

title: NoFrill Furniture Selling
description: In New York, the 17store Furniture Clearance Centers, operated by W. & J. Sloane, Inc., seeks new store sites in both Manhattan and Staten Island as the newest links in its highly successful chain.

title: MORTIMER D. SIMPSON
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 27Mortimer D. Simpson, a retired sales director who had been with the Elizabethtown Gas Company in Elizabeth for 28 years, died yesterday in a nurs ing home at Edison. He was 79 years old and lived at 427 West Hazelwood Avenue.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Certainly Arthur Miller, one of the most brilliant and successful playwrights of all time, does not need me to defend him. His plays speak for themselves and will live forever. If we had more dramatists like Miller, we might not have so many peo ple crying about the death of the theater. Who ever heard of Julius Novick? Has he ever written a play? I suppose his idea of a play that speaks to the present would be one of the nudies like Oh! Calcut tal

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: James C. Fletcher, Utah College Head, Named NASA Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)  President Nixon today nominated James C. Fletcher, president of the University of Utah, to be administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. He will succeed Dr. Thomas O. Paine, who resigned Sept. 15 to ac cept a post in private industry.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY SAYS SPACE FOR COURTS EXISTS
description: An architectural study of the Manhattan Criminal Court commissioned by the Appellate Division states that space for new courtrooms can easily be found within the existing struc ture at 100 Centre Street.

title: OSCAR SERLIN, 70, PRODUCER, IS DEAD
description: Oscar Serlin, who produced the hit play, Life With Father, died yesterday in his home at 53 East 91st Street, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: The World
description: LONDONIt has been evident for some time that Edward Heath was bringing a more com bative tone to British politics. Since the Conservatives took over last June, the Government's ideology has been more rigid, its language more pugnacious.

title: Royals to Dedicate Baseball Academy
description: SARASOTA,Va., Bowie Kuhn, Joe Cronin and Chub Feeney will be sitting on the dais at a college dedication ceremony here on March 21 at 11 A.M. instead of watch ing major league baseball teams in action.

title: U.S. Declines Chile's Invitation for Visit by Warship
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27After 36 hours marked by in tense bureaucratic infighting, the Administration decided today not to accept Chile's in vitation for the aircraft carrier Enterprise to pay a courtesy call.

title: Towzie Tyke Rallies to Take Bowie Handicap by ThreeQuarters of a Length
In Sudan, Women's Lib Wears a Veil
description: KHARTOUM, SudanThe women of Sudan have ,devised a wily way to win their rights. They call it the toub tactic.

title: Carolyn Hecht Fiancee
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Feb. 27Mr. and Mrs. Mar vin E. Hecht have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Barbara Hecht, to Richard Bennett Schwartz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schwartz of Hewlett Harbor. Miss Hecht is a graduate of Western College in Oxford, Ohio. Her father is president of Jettee Fabric, Inc. Mr. Schwartz was graduated from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsyl vania. His father is president and chairman of the board of Gay Togs, a division of U. S. Industries, Inc.

title: DISSENTS SHAKING BONN'S SOCIALISTS
description: BONN, Feb. 27  Chancel lor Willy Brandt's Social Dem ocratic party is undergoing in creasing internal difficulties as young members press to swing the party to the left.

title: Son to the Metzgers
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Burton F. Metzger of New York on Feb. 8 in the Klingenstein Pavilion. Mrs. Metzger is the former Miss Leslie Kraus. The child, the couple's second, has been named Michael Andrew.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I believe that your Carib bean black power story over emphasizes a problem that exists throughout the world, including our own country. The fact is that American tourists in the Caribbean have to face up to the facts of life today just as they have to when they are at home. There are havenots in many countries, and they have justifiable reasons for complaint. However, the dis couragement of tourism in their countries does them a disservice, because it is only by peopletopeople contact plus the influx of revenue that tourism brings, that we can hope to overcome the in equities. Drawing battlelines only feeds the trouble, not cures it.

title: St. Francis Wins. 6563, On Dottrina's Foul Shots
WHO'S CONDESCENDING?
description: To THE EDITOR: Richard Gilman (The Fem Lib Case Against Freud, Jan. 31) attacks others for what he does himself. He accuses Freud of a condescending atti tude toward women, but con descends himself. He says most feminist writers put him off by their overstatement, tendentious reasoning, lack of humor and subtlety, arguments that frequently throw out the baby with the bath water, and proceeds to string togeth er just such arguments. Iron ically, when he tries to tear others down, he builds up their case. Freud's thoughtful observations, for example, show up the shallow rhetoric of Gilman's article.

title: Massachusetts, Duke Fives Triumph in Garden Games
Thinking Ahead
description: THOUGH the ground is frozen or covered with snow, the true gar dener thinks ahead to spring now. If orders for flower and vegetable seeds, rosebushes, perennials and tubers of tuberous begonias, gloxinias, cannas and dahlias have not been sent in, they should be.

title: For Young Readers; The Summer Of the Swans; By Betsy Byars, Illustrated by Ted CoConis. 142 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $3.95. (Ages 10 to 14)
description: English is supposedly the most precise of language, but still we don't have an exact word for themas if the language itself actually re flects our desires to avoid the sub ject and thus shy away from the responsibilities implicitly predicated. So sometimes we call them men tally retarded, other times we refer to them as brain damaged or brain injured or seriously disturbed, and we even trot out such euphemisms as special or exceptional. But we really aren't fooling anyone; language can never hide as well as it can describe; we all know what it is we are not talking about. It is, of course, those children who by this worldly accident or other worldly design are fated to have extraordinarily low thresholds of learning capabilities.

title: Foreign Notes
description: President Josip Broz Tito is 79 and an increasingly pertinent question in European politics has been: Who will succeed him as Yugoslavia's leader? Marshal Tito himself raised the issue last September, and yesterday there were further revelations about what he had in mind.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: PROVIDENCE, Feb. 27 (AP)Dave Tatterson's 20foot shot with 4:12 remaining in the final period tonight carried Brown to a 32 victory over Pennsylvania in an Ivy League game. Brown, with one game remaining, is 128 over all and 92 in the league. Pennsylvania is 98 over all and 65 in the league.

title: Gloria C. Jones Is Married
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 27In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Gloria Callen Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Erskine Jones Jr., was married to Thomas Needles McJunkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Phillip Mc Junkin. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. William Kirkland, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Morris.

title: Hofstra 9060 Victor
description: KINGS POINT, Feb. 27Kings Point was defeated by Hofstra, 9060, tonight.

title: RentaCars Also Sell
description: Looking for a used car? The major rentacar compa nies such as the Hertz Cor poration, Avis Rent A Car Systems, Inc., and National Car Rental System, Inc., may meet your need.

title: City to Repair Old Singer Bowl on Fair Grounds
description: After more than five years of debate, the city has decided to save the Singer Bowl, one of the temporary structures built for the 196465 World's Fair at Flushing MeadowsCo rona Parkin Queens.

title: Norman Rockwell Is Exactly Like A Norman Rockwell
description: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. NORMAN ROCKWELL got an other letter from Mrs. Harold S. Schutt of Wilmington, Del., the other day: We still have not given up our quest for a Norman Rockwell painting. Mrs. Schutt went on to explain that her husband had bought Andrew Wyeth's The Pas ture Wall, and now wanted to trade the Wyeth for any Rockwell original.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: EXECUTIVE OPINION. WHAT BUSINESS LEADERS SAID AND THOUGHT ON ECONOMIC ISSUES, 1920's 1960's. By Dr. Herman E. Krooss. Doubleday. 438 pages. $8.95.

title: Offtrack Unit Weighs Small, HighOdds Bet
description: In an attempt to harness for the city the untold millions of dollars now going to organ ized crime through the num hers racket, the New York City Offtrack betting Corporation is currently considering ,a form of betting that could compete! with the daily numbers game.

title: Miss Carol Louise Kemp Fiancee
description: Miss Carol Louise Kemp and Gregory William Brab bee, Northwestern University graduates, will be married April 24 in New York.

title: National Notes
description: The charge against New York Police Lieut. Francis X. Ward was contempt and per jury before a grand jury. Last Tuesday State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Cul kin dismissed the indictment, and New York District At torney Frank S. Hogan re acted. The decision, Mr. Hogan said, was vague, illogical, inaccurate, mislead ing and grossly unfair to the people and would be ap pealed without delay.

title: The Arabs and the Israelis: Suspicion, Fear and Ignorance Keep Neighboring Peoples Worlds Apart
description: CAIROThe first thing an American traveler who has been living in Israel learns on a visit to some Arab capi tals is Ito stop saying shalom on every meeting.

title: Jet Rookies Visit the Big Apple and Learn It's Not Kansas City
description: The New York Jet coaches got their first look at their 1971 draft choices yesterday after most of the draft choices got their first look at New York. Both groups were im pressed.

title: Cornell Six 93 Victor
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 27The Cornell hockey team main tained its narrow firstplace lead in the Ivy League today by routing Princeton, 93, in Lynah Rink, Ray Ranta, a sophomore with only one previous goal this season, scored four times against Princeton, all in the second period. Brian McCutch eon added a pair for Cornell.

title: She Can'f Get Greece Out of Her Mind
description: Melina Mercouri has a onetrack mind. Oh, she'll talk about the usual female subjects (women's lib, hot pants, getting around in the kitchen, the merits of marriage) as she nervously runs her fingers through her caramelcolored hair. Or prances stockingfooted around her hotel suite. Or stretches her 5feet 7inches out on the couch.

title: HIGH SPACE COSTS BACKED IN SOVIET
