description: MOSCOW, Feb. 27Leonid I. Sedov, one of the founders of the Soviet space program, today rejected the contention that heavy expenditures for space research could be better spent in trying to solve man's problems on earth.

title: Pop
description: FAREWELL AMERICAN TOUR: Sally Eaton (Paramount PAS 5021). If the name sounds un familiar, Sally Eaton is best known for her appearance in stihurbia's favorite wicked musical, Hair. She doesn't quite survive the transition to solo performance. A strong, aggressive and selfconfident outing, yes. But so lacking in character that I found my self more intrigued by the prevailing influence for each tune  a bit of Melanie's phrasing on I Don't Want To Need You Anymore, a sob or two from Judy Garland on Once Before You Go, Lotti Golden's whining hoarseness, even a stab at Joni Mitchell's gentle soprano warbling than by the music as such. Somewhere beneath it all are stirrings of something per sonal and, I suspect, poten tially fascinating, but it sure doesn't surface on this tour.

title: jittery Industrialists in India Seek Office
description: PILANI, India, Feb. 27It used to be good business for businessmen in India to stand slightly offstage in poli tics, gives cues to loyal, financially indebted legislators, who emoted and voted for them. But in the current elec tion campaign the, stakes have grown higher, so the industrial giants have stepped directly in to the footlights for the first time.

title: Art
description: THE eggthat perfect, natural formplays a vital role in the paint ings of Alvin Ross, now on view in an attractive show at the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison Ave. The exhibi tion is comprised of approxi mately 40 small oils, predom inantly still Hies of kitchen subjects, in several of which the egg serves as an unlikely but major protagonist. Ross, now 51 and a painter in the realist tradition since his early exhibitions in the late forties, paints the egg in varying situations: clustered on a white tablecloth; nestled in a white enameled pan; stationed in an egg cup, cracked open to reveal the paperthinness of its curved shell.

title: Wadsworths Have Child
description: A daughter was born Feb. 5 to Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wadsworth of New York in University Hospital. Mr. Wadsworth is a concert pian ist and founder and artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Cen ter. Mrs. Wadsworth, the for mer Susan Popkin, is founder and director of Young Con cert Artists, a nonprofit concert management.

title: She Knew She Was Right
description: Ivy Litvinov has written a delight ful collection of short stories whose subtle charm draws the reader into a trance of pleasure, insight and wit. Several have appeared in The New Yorker. An Englishwoman, she is the widow of Maxim Litvinov, who was Russian Foreign Minister from 1930 to 1939 and Ambassador to the United States from 1941 to 1943. Curiously, except for a few brief references, there are no revelations here of life inside the Kremlin. She has managed, despite some relatively weak stories and incomplete comprehension of either English or Russian character, to devise a booklength collection of tales whose whole is greater than the sum of its parts, tales that seem more like a good novel than separate in cidents.

title: Western Ky. Retains Title
description: BOWLING GREEN; Ky., Feb. 27 (AP)Western Kentucky captured its second straight Ohio Valley Conference title and its second consecutive Na tional Collegiate tournament hearth tonight by routing Murray State, 7359.

title: Alaska and Oil: Tough Questions
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Feb. 27Public hearings here this week made it clear that Alas ka's vast oil reserves in the Arctic will eventually be de veloped. The key remaining questions involve when that development will pine, the form it will take and how it will be controlled.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: With unparalleled disbelief, I have just read Roger Green spun's review of the latest John Wayne epic, RioLobo. There can be no ex cuse for calling this piece of cinematic junk close enough to greatness to stand above everything else so far in the current season. Whaaat? Special beauty? Where? In what film? Certainly not this!

title: In Desolate Cambodian Town, NoodleandMeat Soup for Sale
description: SKOUN, Cambodia, Feb. 22 At least one man in this bombed out and abandoned town says he Is better off now than before the war began.

title: Nassau, in a Recruiting Effort, Gives Foster Parents Increases
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 27 The Nassau County Depart ment of Social Services has ap proved increased board and clothing allowances for children in foster care in an effort to recruit additional foster par ents.

title: the traveler's world
description: BUT suppose it rains on the sunny, semitropical island? At $25 a day per person it can be an expensive, holidaywasting calamity. And when you get to $50 a day, or $100 or more for two, American plan, as you can in some of today's more highly over priced places, a dismal drizzle can real ly hurt.

title: Can a humorous author be illustrious? Yes, the most illustrious; The Girl in Blue By P. G. Wodehouse. 190 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $5.95.
MUNICH ENSEMBLE DISPLAYS SOLIDITY
description: The performance by the Munich Chamber Orchestra in the Concerto Series at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night were the kind that allowed the listener to find the delights in the music by himself. The ensemble, con ducted by Hans Stadlmair, plays with strength, solidity and accuracy, but it seldom adds anything of its own to the works it plays.

title: Queens Homeowners Make Annual Tax Queries
description: Queensborough Hall, the stately building at Union Turn pike and Queens Boulevard in which the borough conducts of ficial business, resembles a be sieged fortress these days.

title: Doctor Aims at Keeping Mets in Pink
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27The New York Mets, who are substituting science for magic this year, began a series of detailed physical examina tions today under an internal medicine specialist from New York.

title: Incomes Policy Needed
description: Events are propelling the Nixon Administration toward the development of a national incomes policy, but in such a spasmodic and confused way that it is still impossible to know what sort of policy will emerge.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I WAS deeply distressed to read. Arthur Cohen's article in which he en deavors to pressure the board of governors of the Jewish Museum on a philo sophical issue by the tech nique of public embarrass ment and trivialization.

title: Miss BromleyDavenport Is Bride of Basil Keiser
description: Miss Antonia BromleyDav enport and Basil Edward Keiser were married here yes terday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. John Verdery, headmaster of the Wooster School.

title: Troland S. Link, Lawyer, Weds Lee Auchincloss
description: The marriage of Miss Lee Auchincloss to Troland S. Link, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, took place in Calvary Episcopal Church here at noon yesterday. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Samuel Todd, was fol lowed by a small luncheon at the home of Robert Mont gomery, the actor, and Mrs. Montgomery, aunt of the bride.

title: The War In Vietnam
description: Burton R. Tauber is a clean shaven Wall Street lawyer with his own firm and a kind of Nelson Rockefeller aura of capi talist geniality. There can be no better illustration of pro football's ability to survive the downturn in the busi ness economy than the re cent history of the Patriots, for years the sport's sister of the poor. Be cause the team is moving 27 miles south of down town Boston to Foxboro, Mass., and into a new 61,000seat stadium, the board of direc tors recently changed the geographic title to Bay State, Massachusetts nickname.

title: Home Improvement
description: When measuring for drapes it is best to install the rod first, then measure down from this. Height should be measured from the top of a regular traverse rod, but if a decorative traverse rod is used, then measure from  inch below the rod. The three common lengths are indicated by the vertical arrows in the drawing at left: (A) to the top of the window sill; (B) to the bottom of the window apron, and (C) floor length. The draperies width is deter mined by the length of the rod, plus 16 inches4 inches extra on each panel for the return at each end of the rod, and 4 inches each to allow for overlap in the center.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: When the Air Force pulled out of the James Connally Air Force Base at Waco, Tex., in 1965, the state and some alert industrialists were ready to make the most of it. They proceeded to convert the vast physical plant to a state technical school, which has since gone on to become the Texas State Technical In stitute (TSTI). It now con sists of four campuses across the state  Waco, Harlingen, Amarillo and Sweetwater all housed at former military bases.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The words were disturbing. What gave them such impact were the underlying notes of wistfulness and sadness that ac companied them. Joe DiMaggio was play ing golf in Panama last week when he was asked what part he'd take in baseball's spring training.

title: Good and cheap
description: Homemade noodles like those that Grandmother used to fixor so they sayare a boon for fight budgets, espe cially when teamed with chicken giblet stew or added to a homemade soup. Most markets sell the cheaper chicken parts separately, but whole chickens, bought by the dozen when on special sale, are even more economical. Use the giblets, necks and wings for these thrifty meals and re serve the meaty parts, which freeze well, for other dishes.

description: RICHMOND, Feb. 27The marriage of Miss Margaret D. Chase to John Henry Hager took place here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The. Rev. John Shelby Spong performed the cere mony.

title: Mrs. Thesieres Gains Final In Squash Racquets Event
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 27. Topseeded Mrs. T. R. Thesi cres of BalaCynwyd, Pa., and secondseeded Marigold Ed wards of Pittsburgh, Pa., beat two opponents each today to advance the final of the United States women's squash racquets singles championship.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Caribbean Black Power Will. Their Plans Affect Yours? by Wade Greene (Travel section, Feb. 7) should move people to reconsider their reasons for traveling to the Caribbean (or anywhere else, for that matter). Does one visit another country to spend his waking hours in a state of sunburned torpor, bringing nothing home with him but a peeling epidermis? Does one travel to gather new experiences and meet different kinds of people? Should relaxation empty the mind or refresh it? If Americans venture abroad with the idea of getting away from it all and have not freed themselves from the political and racial in tolerance many carry around with them, they will findwhen they open their suit cases in that island hotel roomthat those same prej udices will be lying right there, all crisp and ready to be unfolded.

title: BERNARD WIDMANN, A RADIOLOGIST, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP)Dr. Bernard P. Widmann, internationally known radiolo gist, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: Sabich Wins Opening Race Of Rainier Cup Slalom
description: NORTH BEND, Wash., Feb. 27 (AP)  Spider Sabich won the first race of the $15,000 (Rainier Cup slalom today at Alpental.

title: Terrier Symposium Listed Wednesday by Ramapo Club
description: The Ramapo Kennel Club will hold a symposium on terrier breeds at the North End Fire House, Cedar Grove, N. J., on Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. Some of the top terrier fanciers and handlers will bring dogs and demonstrate show techniques, grooming and take part in a questionandanswer period. Anyone interested in dogs is invited.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The Caribbean is about three hours by jet from New Yorkyet we seem to display there all our traditional mis understandings of the outside world. Wade Greene's Black Power article was a case in point. As a parttime resi dent of Jamaica for a number of years, I would grant Mr. Greene that a crisis is build ing up between islanders and American tourists. But his ar ticle can only contribute to that crisis by aggravating it, adding further misunder standings. AU his other prem ises, I submit, are dead wrong.

title: JOE TORRE ACCEPTS $115,000 CONTRACT
description: ST. Petersburg, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP)Joe Torre signed for an estimated $115,000 contract to day, giving the St. Louis Car dials a full complement of signed players for the 1971 season.

title: Marxist Group Urges Guerrillas To Foil Any Middle East Accord
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 27The Popular Front for the Lib eration of Palestine, a Marxist group, called on the entire Arab guerrilla movement today to mobilize its forces to foil a peaceful settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: The Structure Of Art
description: French structuralism is the new Key. Individual structural istsLeviStrauss in his own domain, Roland Barthes in his shorter essays and his superb book on Racineare exciting thinkers who use their Key to discuss the experience of a so ciety, a myth, a work of art; they do not, like their disciples, worship the Key. Jack Burn ham, who teaches art at North western, has produced a syn thesis of the following Keys: structuralism, semiology, Chom skyan linguistics, Piaget devel opment theory. He applies these Keys to works from the late 19thcentury right down to last week, hoping to unlock their mysteries. With every step, however, one gets farther away from the actual experience of art and deeper into Burnham's selfeducation.

title: 400 BATTLE POLICE IN ULSTER RIOTING
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 27Policemen used water cannons to disperse about 400 Roman Catholic rioters today as they attempted to attack homewardbound football fans on Shankill Road in a Protestant area.Heavy rain had dampened the rioters ardor after a long night of violence in which two police men were shot dead in the Catholic Ardoyne section of the city. But by midafternoon crowds began to mass in Unity Flats, another Catholic area.Soldiers sealed off the area to prevent clashes with the Protestants, but some bottles were hurled over the soldiers heads at the football crowd. The Catholics chanted Ardoyne, Ardoyne, a reminder of the killings last night. Protestants replied with songs before police hustled them away.Soon afterwards, the Cath olics rushed the British troops, and water cannons were called in to beat back stonethrowing mobs. The trouble lasted about an hour and is believed to have been provoked by extrem ists of the Irish Republican Army.A breakaway group called Provisionals hopes that by in flaming sectarian conflict they can cause Britain to rule Northern Ireland directly from London. Such a development, they believe, might result in a tripartite agreement with the Irish Republic.Meanwhile, Prime Minister Tames Chichester Clark cut short a visit to London and returned to Belfast.Intensive arms searches were carried out during the day in another Catholic, area of Bel fast where a pistol and ammu nition were found in a derelict house. The Government an nounced restrictions on move ment in the city, and the police were issued flak jackets in the troubled areas.The police, who have been unarmed since the fall of 1969, demanded protection. Some have been given guns and others will be accompanied by armed soldiers when on patrol.Eleven persons accused of rioting appeared In court today and were detained. Four geli gnite nail bombs were said to have been found in the pocket of one man.In the incident in which the two policemen were killed by automatic fire, two more po licemen were wounded. The most seriously injured man un derwent an operation for re moval of a bullet from his chest.Soldiers said that when re turning the fire they shot two and possibly three of the gun men but the wounded men had been dragged away by their comrades.The killing of the policemen, it is felt here, is bound to sharpen the pressure of the rightwing of the ruling Union ist party against the Prime Minister.

title: Chile and Cuba in a New Trade Deal
description: Chile and Cuba have agreed within the last two weeks to an exchange of sugar and to bacco from Cuba for agricul tural products and some indus trial goods from Chile, accord ing to the president of the Central Bank of Chile.

title: Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. ToWed Mrs. Billy Laster Cline
description: Hamilton Fish Jr. of Mill brook, N. Y., and Washing ton, the fourth generation of his family to serve in the House of Representatives, and Mrs. Billy Laster Cline, who lives in Millbrook, plan to be married in April.

title: Gilbert Sets Mark in Winning 104Mile Long BeachCatalina Boat Race
description: Gil Gilbert, driving a new 20foot Spectra Marine Spe cial, built by Ed DeLong's new Spectra Marine ?? of Burbank, Calif., averaged 64.8 miles an hour to ?? ?? recent 104mile Long Beach Catalina Island race.

title: Movies
description: WE'VE ALL got the Playboy bunny, stamped on our arses, says Kenneth Tynan. Roman Polanski raises an elbow and points to his armpit. I'm different. I have mine here. With my number on. There's even a bunny on the clapper board in front of every shot. Not only that, last Christmas every member of Polanski's cast received a card person ally inscribed with the good wishes of Hugh Hefner. All because Polanski's new film of Macbeth is Playboy's first mo tion picture financing venture. Other than that, Playboy has had no influ ence, says Tynan, who's production ad viser on the picture. Pause. Yet

title: This Is Not Circus. This Is Li fe an Marrakesh
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco  Re member those old Buster Crabbe movies about the French Foreign Legion in which a tribe of Bedouins roared across the Sahara firing muskets over their should ers and clenching cutlasses in their teeth? Did you ever wonder just where they were going in that getup?

title: Family Fights to Stay on an Army Base
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Feb. 25  A black mother and her seven children who have been ordered to leave this Army base by March 8 have vowed to re main in their home even if the Army tries to evict them.

title: Suspect Seized in Murder In Brooklyn of N.Y.U. Aide
description: An unemployed Brooklyn tailor was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder last Wednesday of a New York University art director in the latter's Brooklyn Heights apart ment.

title: Cut Ordered in U.S. Funds for Child Health Study
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Administration has ordered a sharp cutback in one of the largest studies ever organized to find causes of such health problems as mental retardation, nervous system defects and childhood behavior disorders.

title: Wife Doubts Guerrillas Captive In Uruguay Signed Latest Note
description: Mrs. Claude L. Fly, the wife of a United States agricultural expert kidnapped in Uruguay last Aug. 7, said yesterday that a handwritten postscript to a purported ransom note does not look like my husband's handwriting.

title: Norway's Cabinet Judging Premier, Who Admits Lie
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb. 27The Norwegian Cabinet sat in emergency session until late tonight to consider whether Per Borten should continue as Pre mier after he admitted that he had lied in denying he had dis closed confidential information about Norway's application to join the Common Market.

title: Somebody Nice Is Waiting to Meet You, Said the Cruise Ad
description: CHAMPAGNE bubbles were fizzing in my head as I leaned against the deck rail beside the three girls who were going to be my cabinmates. Bound for Freeport, Grand Bahama Island, with a giddy cargo of 392 singlesonly passengers, the T.S.S. Queen Anna Maria was backing out into the Hudson. Huge ropes were cast off. (Like inhibitions?) Tugboat horns let out businesslike blasts. Party horns bleated. Jubilation prevailed ev erywhereexcept in my slightly uneasy stomach. Now that I think back on it all, I realizethat it was trying to send up a visceral S.O.S. But I was too busy chat ting to listen to such vague distress signals. The pier slowly slid away. Soon all those waving hands and colorful handkerchiefs grew very small. And then Manhattan itself faded. We had out to sea.

title: D. F. SextonWeds Ann Hernelright
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Feb. 27Miss Ann Hemelright and Da vid Farrington Sexton were married here this afternoon in the Green Ridge Presby terian Church. The Rev. Carl D. Reimers performed the ceremony, assisted by the Revs. Brewer L. Burnett and Rees Warring.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR: Such naysayers on the left as Murray Kempton and Y. F. Stone, Richard H. Rovere wrote in his article, Eisen hower Revisited A Political Genius? A Brilliant Man? (Feb. 7), are finding virtues in him [Eisenhower] they failed to detect while he served. This reflects stereotyped con ceptions of my past positions, not the reality. I always rec ognized Ike as a man of peace and an enemy of militarism.

title: Philadelphia Jobless Up
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP)  Unemployment in the eightcounty Philadelphia labor market rose to a sixyear high of 5.4 per cent in January, the Pennsylvania State Employ ment Service reported yester day.

title: Amistad 2 Edited by John A. Williams and Charles F. Harris. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $5.95. Paper, $1.95. New African Literature And the Arts Volume 2. Edited by Joseph Okpaku. Illustrated. 251 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell in association with the Third Press. $8.95. The Black Aesthetic Edited by Addison Gayle, Jr. 432 pp. New York: Doubleday &
description: One of the geniuses of the 20th century has suggested that Don Quixote was a figment of Sancho Panza's imagination. That it was Sancho who read excessively in Ro mance and Chivalry, became ob sessed by it and, in order to free himself of the obsession, external ized it. So well did Sancho succeed in liberating himself from his demon (whom he called Don Quixote) that the latter set out on its own ex ploits. Thus, a free man, Sancho Panza philosophically followed Don Quixote... and had... a great and edifying entertainment to the end of his days.

title: Harvard Routs Cornell by 10490 After Tallying 61 Points in First Half
Gaslight classic
description: Gaslight glows once again in front of this Greek Revival town house that was built in Greenwich Village in 1845 on a block now designated as an Historical Landmark. The wisteriacovered dwelling had deteriorated until it was purchased two years ago by a stockbroker, who had decorator Anthony Hail execute the necessary repairs and the dcor. An old English street lamp (shown at left) was installed; mullioned windows, pilasters, iron railings, stairway and interior moldings were replaced or restored.

title: Houston Upsets Jacksonville, 8382, in fast Seconds for 28th in Row at Home
A Modest Proposal
description: While New York pursues a multicorporation course of off track betting, other states are exploring the possibility of letting the race tracks run the show.

title: In Brief
description: Shimon Peres, now a Minis ter in the Israeli Government responsible for the Adminis tered Territories, recounts the story of the arming of his coun try. This is potentially a good story; but Peres is a young, ambitious politician and can not afford to tell all There is also a good deal of padding about ArabIsraeli pasts and futures for the benefit of His constituency.

title: 49ers Add Preseason Game
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27 (UPI)The San Francisco 49ers announced today they would meet the San Diego Chargers in an exhibition game at Can dlestick Park. on Aug. 22. Pre viously, the 49ers announced they would open the exhibition season with a game against the Cleveland Browns in their new home base, which is undergo ing a $16million transforma tion to make it suitable for football and baseball.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Everyone concurs, no doubt he does so himself, that Peter Brook is a genius. He doesn't have to reach deep, if at all, into the theater's bag of tricks. If he wants to, he can make the old tricks workbut he prefers to de vise new tricks, fresh ones, tricks that are startling, amazing, outlandish, provoc ative, incredible.

title: Cornell Wrestlers Win
description: Cornell's wrestlers erased a 138 deficit by winning four of the last five bouts and defeated Columbia, 2016, here yester day. It was Cornell's third vic tory against nine defeats; Co lumbia closed its dualmeet schedule with 110.

title: F.T.C. GETS REPORTS OF SALE OF TAX DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion says it is investigating re ports that some concerns that prepare income tax returns for individuals have been selling income and other personal in formation to stores and other creditor.

title: Pollution Curb Voted
description: BOISE, Idaho, Feb, 27 (AP)As an antipollution device, committee in the Idaho House of Representatives has voted for a bill taxing soda pop and beer sold in nonreturnable con tainers. The measure would add one cent tax for each seven fluid ounces. The money would go for pollution control.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I HAVE seen recently on TV such films as Great Expectations, Oliver Twist, Night Train, and that wonderful African Queen, all greats made when they knew how to make movies, by people who knew how to make movies. A joy to see, no matter whether one had seen them before or not.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK.
description: THE NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE approved stricter capitalstructure requirements for member firms, but de ferred considering the issue of institutional membership until a study by William McChesney Martin Jr. was com pleted. The Big Board also decided to increase minimum capital requirements for stock specialists by 15 per cent next Jan. 1 and to monitor them more closely.

title: Senior Golf to Melnyk Team
description: SEA ISLAND, Ga., Feb. 27 (AP)Nick Melnyk of Bruns wick, Ga., and George Gucken berger of Wyoming, Ohio, cap tured the Sea Island seniors golf championship today with a 5and4 victory over Jack Norman of Winston Salem, N.C., and Hal Veasey of Alms kie, N.C.

title: THOENI IS VICTOR IN GIANT SLALOM
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP)Gustavo Thoeni of Italy won the giant slalom in a snowstorm at Heavenly Valley today to move closer to the World Cup ski champion ship for the season.

description: PUTNEY, Vt., Feb. 27The starter's gun sounds, and the doubleline of skiers surges forward across the tranquil cow pasture.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27George H. Bush takes over Monday as the new United States Chief Delegate and head of the American mission herea mission Adlai E. Stev enson called the most complex embassy in diplomatic history.

It said Stalin Prospect would form the center piece of the new Gori and would be lined with public buildings and fivestory apart ment buildings.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 27 Pete Bostwick, the world open champion from New York City, fought an uphill battle, to re gain the United States amateur court tennis championship to day at the Racquet Club.

title: WIDE CHANGES DUE AT THE TOP IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27  For a variety of in evitable reasons, the Secretary General of the United Nations faces a series of changes in top echelon posts here in coming months.

title: PROTEST DIVERTS TELEPHONE TAXES
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27About 75 Bostonians demonstrated their opposition to the Indochina war this week by turning over their Federal telephone taxes to the farm workers union rather than the Government.

title: New Fight Dimension Seems Open to Debate
description: The tale of the tape for the Joe FrazierMuhammad All heavyweight title bout has two new categories: mouth (closed) and mouth (open).

title: Medicine
description: In the Congress, last week, the debate sharpened over the ways and means of spend ing new billions of dollars for the nation's medical care. Yet for a small but increas ingly vocal group of econo mists, sociologists and even physicians, the whole argu ment seemed somewhat be side the point. More doctors and hospital beds for the millions, they believe, will do little to reduce serious illness or prevent premature deaths.

title: Interpex Souvenir
description: THE Bureau of Engraving and Printing, Washing ton, will sell an astro nautical souvenir card at Interpex, the stamp show to be held at the Americana Hotel here on March 1214. The card will utilize as its vi gnette a block of four in nor mal colors of the design of the 4cent Project Mercury stamp issued in 1962 on the afternoon of the day that Col. John R. Glenn made the first successful American flight into space.

title: Photography
description: ONE of the creative and/ or critical functions of the curatorial role is the isolation, from amidst the warp and woof of an uncompleted medium, of significant threads worthy of extended examination.

title: Skiflying Meet Put Off
description: IRONWOOD, Mich., Feb. 27 (UPI)Snow and winds gusting up to 40 miles an hour forced officials of the International Ski Federation to call off today's competition in the Copper Peak skiflying meet. It was resched uled for tomorrow.

title: In Nassau, 47 Women Play an Everyday Role in Fight on Crime
description: MINEOLA, Feb. 27 Twentyseven young women in Nassau County who gave up college, housework or secreta rial chores are devoting their efforts to the fight against crimefrom rape to the push ing of narcotics on the campus. Bored women in search of kicks? Hardly. They are mem bers of the 3.800member Nas sau County Police Department. What brought them together is the excitement and social value of police work and boredom with routine jobs. For some of them police work is a family tradition.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bacallao Gains Semifinals In Casino Squash Tennis
description: Pedro Bacallao, the Cuban born lawyer who holds the na tional title, advanced yester day to the semifinals of the annual Heights Casino invita tion squash tennis tournament.

title: Legacy of Abandoned Canal
description: RODMAN LAKE, Fla., Feb. 27 A shallow, 15milelong res ervoir, a 20mile ditch filled with muddy water and thou sands of dead trees and rotting stumps are all that remain in this part of central Florida of a wild river called the Oklawaha and the forest of hardwood trees that once surrounded it.

title: City Acts to Save Brooklyn Piers
description: City and union officials, fearing a loss of thousands of jobs and millions of dol lars in income to the New Jersey side of New York har bor, have begun a drive to save the Brooklyn water front.

title: Bridge
description: BEATING a retreat from a danger ous position may seem un heroic, but it can be the better part of valor, whether for the experienced general facing superior forces, for the experienced civilian facing a wouldbe mugger, or for the experi enced bridgeplayer facing a penalty double. To run or not to run can be a crucial question.

title: That Cosmo Girl On Romance and The Single Traveler
description: TRAVEL opportunities for single people have been multiplying rap idly lately, with more and more unattached young people signing up for things like singles weekends, singles cruises, singles beach outings and singles ski trips. The reasons for this development seem clear enoughamong them the economy of group rates and a tantalizing aura of romancebut how well do these travel ventures really work? To learn what an expert on the single life thinks, I looked up Helen Gurley Brown, the editor of Cosmopoli tan magazine and the author of five books for unmarried women, including the recent Sex and the New Single Girl.

title: Future of Flushing Airport Is Debated by City Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Overlooked in the current de bates over expanding the run ways at Kennedy International Airport and the future use of Brooklyn's Floyd Bennett Field is a disagreement over another aviation facility in the cityFlushing Airport In Queens.

title: Headliners
description: For the third time in three years, Arthur Ashe, the black American tennis player, last week was refused a visa to visit South Africa for the tennis championships. Officials in South Africa said privately the decision was based on Mr. Ashe's association with black causes in the United States and his support for black liberation move ments in Africa. Said Mr. Ashe: Maybe it's over for me, but to South Africa I say, there will be more after me and more after them.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  During the last decade, the Warren Court marched up the hill of judicial intervention, and during the past week it be came evident that the Burger Court has started to march down again. No two steps could have been more sym bolic of the change than the rulings made by the Supreme Court last Tuesday and Wednesday, backtoback.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: What a wonderhil treat you gave your readers oven the holiday weekend. Your Art page on Sunday was like a seminar in contemporary art history.

title: Arkansas Hires Bennett
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 27 (AP)Richard D. (Buddy) Ben net resigned today as Tennes see's defensive coordinator to accept a position on the Arkan sas football coaching staff.

title: Frederick Osborn 3d Is Fiance Of Anne Hampton de P. Todd
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Feb. 27Mr. and Mrs. James Todd have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Anne Hampton de Peyster Todd, to Frederick Henry Os born 3d, son of. Mr. and Mrs. Osborn Jr. of Garrison.

title: Miss Elizabeth Sidar Fiancee of C. L. Hall
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 27Mr. and Mrs. Alex ander George Sidar Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eliza beth Thomas Sidar to Chris topher Lee Hall. He is the son of Mrs. James Blackburn Hall of Waynesburg, Pa. and the late Mr. Hall.

title: Narcotics Centers Guards Ordered to End Sick Calls
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27 (UPI)A State Supreme Court justice signed a temporary restrain ing order today to force guards at state narcotics detention centers to end a large number of sick calls.

title: POLICEMAN IS KILLED BY TWO HITRUN CARS
description: A rookie patrolman was killed 25 minutes after going off duty at 2 A.M. yesterday when he was struck by two hitandrun cars.

title: Hanoi's Account of Battle
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)The South Vietnamese Third Paratroop Battalion on a hill in the La Thuong region of Laos just south of the North Vietnamese border was over run and taken by liberation forces according to an account purporting to be that of a South Vietnamese prisoner made public here today.

title: Comeback
description: Adler's reputation sagged after his death. A number of Adlerian clinics closed down, The Interna tional Journal of Individual Psychology was discontin ued, as were the activities of most of his European followers. Dr. Rudolf Drei kurs, now a prominent Chi cago psychiatrist, recalls how in the late nineteen thirties he was warned against revealing his iden tity as an Adlerian for fear of professional dis crimination.

title: Carolina's Mace Recovered
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 27 (AP)South Carolina's historic silver mace has been recovered after being taken from the state House of Representatives chamber three weeks ago. Charles Clayton Norton, 34 years old, former ,chief security officer of the statehouse, has been charged with interstate transportation of stolen prop erty valued at more than $5,000. The 215yearold mace, insured for $20,000, was found in Mr. Norton's car by F.B.I. agents.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The recent proliferation of various groups dedicated to changing practices of the business world in one way or another has left many busi nessmen confused as to who is attacking them and why.

title: LA SALLE SCORES IN C.H.S.A.A. MEET
The World
description: SAIGON  Late last week, in the 26th day of the allied push into Laos, American mili tary authorities finally permit ted correspondents to do what thousands of South Vietnamese troops have done: Cross the bor der in American helicopters. The ban on travel was just one of many restrictions on coverage of the war in Indochina. imposed on top of the most serious in herent restriction of all that it is dangerous.

title: EXPERTS QUESTION USE OF DATA BANK
description: Among the most vigorous opponents of government and private computerized data banks is a group of computer specialists whose jobs, in sonic cases, include helping to main tain such banks.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Does the trend in giant corporations to dress their employes more or less alike pose a threat to the apparel industries? Not if the gar ment manufacturers get a piece of a growing business called career apparel.

title: Risk Capital
description: PARIS  Because they could not raise the risk capi tal, Europe's inventors and entrepreneurs used to troop to the United States to de velop and market their new products.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Imagine for a moment: This, the second year of your marriage, has been going very well, considering it is only your sec ond year. Tonight's dinner is not startling  just a few beans cooked with love, lettuce, smoked neck  but you have been busy all day preparing the truly royal feast planned for Sat urday night when the Bactrians and the Dromes will come for dinner.

title: The World
description: SAIGONWhether as a re sult of advance overselling or an underestimate of North Viet nam's military capacity along the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the Amer icanSouth Vietnamese incur sion into southern Laos looked less successful last week than the image of it created by the advance buildup and the initial advance on the ground.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Roumanises Have Son
description: A son was born on Feb. 4 to Mr. and Mrs. George Rou manis at the LyingIn Hospi tal. Mrs. Roumanis, the for mer Miss Bonita Anne Gristede, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Gris tede of New Rochelle, N. Y. Mr. Gristede is the retired treasurer of Gristede Broth ers, Inc., the chain food stores. The child's father is an aide to Governor Rockefeller.

title: FRANULOVIC TOPS GRAEBNER, 62, 61
description: MACON, Ga., Feb. 27 (UPI)Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia defeated Clark Graebner of New York, 62, 61, in a match that lasted only 35 minutes today and moved into the final of the Macon international indoor ten nis tournament.

title: He Took a CloseUp of Claire's Knee
description: ONE night last week, when I surrendered my raincoat at a Man hattan restaurant, also left a copy of Charles Higham's Hollywood Cam eramen (University of Indi ana Press) with the some what overage ingenue who presided over the checking concession. She giggled, rolled her eyes up, towards the private dining room on the second floor, did a modi fied bump and then quivered, as if she'd bitten into a lime. She said she just might read the book or, at least, look at the pictures. When I re turned an hour or so later, she'd become so bored she was well into the third page of The Greening of Amer ica. It was apparent she'd expected something on the order of What Hollywood Cameramen See (When They Photograph Blue Mov ies)which is not, I guess, surprising.

title: Aspects of Religion In the Soviet Union 19171967 Edited by Richard H. Marshall Jr. 489 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. $19.75. Icon and Swastika The Russian Orthodox Church Under Nazi and Soviet Control. By Harvey Fireside. 245 pp. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press. $8.
description: Upon reading Gogol, Dostoevsky and some other Russian writers, many Westerners reach the conclu sion that the Russians were the most religious people on earth, a nation of God seekers in whom religion was so deeply rooted as to defy any challenge; and great importance has been attached to the impact of re ligion on Russian politics, society and cultural life.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THIS letter will not make brilliant sense. It's just a quick emotional re sponse that I have to share with you.

title: Players Union Prepares For Next Cycle of Talks
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 27For the first time in five years, there is no burning issue on the player management front in base ball, aside from the contin uing Curt Flood antitrust case now in the hands of the courts. As a result, yester day's businesslike meeting of player repre sentatives in Mi ami dealt largely with preparations for the next cy cle of conflict.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I want to say bravo to the article by Arthur Cohen in behalf of the Jewish Mu seum's great contribution to nonJewish contemporary art. I recall my deep pleasure at viewing the museum's show ings of Ad Reinhardt, the kin etic sculptors Schoffer and Tinguely, and the Young Ital ians on my infrequent trips to New York. I am sorry missed the other pioneering exhibitions.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Julius Novick's article, Arthur Miller: Does He Speak to the Present?, misses the point. Of course Miller speaks to the present. A playwright who can open up the human heart and show what is both ugly and beauti ful and tender in it, speaks to the present. It is fashion able to criticize Miller for not writing about contemporary issues: Vietnam, race, drugs, Women's Lib, revolution. That's like saying let's not produce Chekhov because nowhere in his plays does he write about air pollution.

title: NIXON DROPS PLAN TO CUT OFF FUNDS FOR MODEL CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The nation's Mayors, with the sur prising help of Vice President Agnew's staff, have persuaded the Nixon Administration to re verse a decision to cut off all funding for the Model Cities program next Dec. 31.

title: Frazier Gleams, in Dawn's Early Light
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27In the darkness before dawn, Joe Frazier emerged from the Franklin Motor Inn and snorted as he shadowboxed across the parking lot in his intense manner. He was warming up for morning roadwork. Nearby his ma roon Cadillac limousine, with two white telephones in it, glistened in the fine rain.

title: INVASION RUMOR SPREADS IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27Givral's is a pleasant cof fee house on Tudo Street, the most chic street in Saigon when it was still called Rue Catinat and Saigon was still chic. It serves a rich variety of French specialities, including pastries and fantastic political rumors.

title: Bogota Calls a State of Siege After Riots
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 27 Extra policemen and some troops were on duty at key points in Bogota today follow ing rioting yesterday in Cali, Colombia's third largest city, in which eight persons were killed and about 50 injured.

title: Increase in Gas Explosions Raises Fears of More Disasters
description: The number of naturalgas explosions reported here has increased sharply this year, and officials are worried about the possibility of other disasters such as the blast that shattered a tavern near City Hall last D'ec. 11, killing 12 persons and injuring 60.

title: Victoria Hodel To Be Bride
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., Feb. 27 Miss Victoria Anne Hodel and William Neil Bair, stu dents at the West Virginia University Creative Arts Cen ter, will be married here May 21 in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: Valerie Dickerson Wed
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 27  Miss Valerie LaVerne Dickerson, daughter of Lieut. Col. William O. Dickerson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Dickerson, of Riverside, was married here this afternoon to Ronald Dean Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee R. Cole man of San Francisco. The Rev. Laurent Largenti per formed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Roman Cathnlic Church. The bride is producer and cohost of the Target program on KRONTV in San Francisco and coanchorman on the Saturday Evening News. Mr. Coleman is in the executivemanagement pro gram with Sears, Roebuck & in San Mateo.

title: Modzelewski Coach Now
description: CLEVELAND (UPI)  Dick Modzelewski, now a Cleveland Browns line coach, played in 180 consecutive National Foot ball League games. The dur able Mo, who was an out standing defensive tackle, played 102 of those games for the New York Giants.

title: SAS: Transnational Success
description: STOCKHOLM  One of Europe's rarest birds, a trans national company, has been flying for nearly a quarter century in Scandinavia.

title: DUPREE IS HALTED BY RONDON IN 6TH
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 27 (UPI)Vicente Paul Rondon of Venezuela, scored a technical knock out over. Jimmy Dupree of Jersey City at 2:58 of the sixth round tonight to capture the World. Boxing Association's lightheavyweight champion ship.

title: Baby Bouncers Called A Threat to Children
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration has warned parents that some walker jumpers or baby bouncers have amputated infants fin gers and inflicted other seri ous injuries.

title: Soviet Increasing Aid to Cuba Under New Trade Agreement
description: MIAMI, Feb. 27Cuba and the Soviet Union have signed their annual trade and payment agreement.

title: Cairo Awaits Messages
description: CAIRO, Feb. 27As the Suez Canal ceasefire slipped closer to its expiration at midnight week from today, the Egyptian leadership waited for messages from Dr. Jarring and the Big Four powers.

title: Fernandel, Comedian, 67, Dies
description: PARIS, Feb. 27Fernandel, one of the most popular and longlasting comedians of the French screen, died here last night of cancer. He was 67 years old.

title: Political Leader Kidnapped
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, Sunday, Feb. 28A leader of the Sinn Feinpolitical arm of the out lawed Irish Republican Armywas kidnapped early today and taken away in a car that the police said headed for Ireland's border with Ulster.

title: Toyland '71
description: The man whose acid al literative addresses have helped him become a house hold name throughoutAmer ica may also become the closest thing in 1971 to a fad in the American toy in dustry.

title: Miss Waterman Fiancee Of Endicott Peabody Jr.
description: EAST GREENWICH;.R. I, Feb. 27  Mr. and Mrs. George H. Watennen Jr. of. East Greenwich. and Lever ing Farm, Woodstock, Vt., have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Greene Water man, to Endicott Peabody Jr., son of the former, Governor of Massachusetts and Mrs. Peabody of Washington.

title: JARRING'S REPORT MAY TELL OF SNAG Israel's Stand on Pullback Said to Slow Peace Bid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb, 27  Informed diplomats here said today that, barring an unexpected shift in Israel's po sition, Secretary General Thant might have to report next week that the Middle East peace ef forts of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring had bogged down.

title: Study Compares Subway Noise Level Here With Other Systems
description: The noise in a moving sub way car jammed with passen gers is about half as loud as in the same car when it is empty, because the passengers absorb some of the sound.

title: The World
description: LONDONA real estate agen cy manager, brought to court un der Britain's Race Relations Act, conceded last week that he had declined to show flats to colored people. But in promising not to discriminate again, he said the reason he had acted as he did was that his company knew per fectly well that colored people would have the door slammed in their face. We wanted to avoid causing distress to people who would not be acceptable.

title: FELONY SUSPECTS AIDED IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 27A pilot program known as Op eration Midway is offering felony suspects in Nassau County an opportunity for re habilitation before trial and the prospect of a dismissal of charges and return to society instead of jail.

title: SAIGON SAYS ARMY HAS WON CONTROL OF HILL 31 IN LAOS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27  Heavy fighting continued at major South Vietnamese outposts in Labs today and the South Vietnamese announced that they had regained control of a strategic hill position.

title: Action Priest
description: This book's title seems de signed for a film scenario but for whom? Pat O'Brien and Bing Crosby are too old. Ac tion Priest is indeed what Fa ther Joe Lauro almost always seemed to be, judging by the look he affords us of the ex terior of his disciplined life. A plethora of anecdotes, some halffunny in a passe religious joke sense, maddeningly ob scure the inner feelings of the man. There are only tantalizing, brief, abruptly terminated glimpses of his loneliness, doubts, pride, tenderness and introspection. Thus we never fully know this heroic man whose life continued to grow in surprising ways.

title: Pitt, Anchored by Richey's 3:59.7 Mile, Sets Indoor Mark in Distance Relay
description: NEWARK, Del., Feb 27The University of Pittsburgh with Jerry Richey running a 3:59.7 anchor mile, captured the distance medley relay with an American indoor, record time of 9:39.7 at the 11th an nual University of Delaware invitational track meet.

title: Coins
description: ANCIENT Greek and Ro man coins from the Massachusetts Histori cal Society's collection will be offered at an unre stricted public auction to be held by Stack's Inc. this week. The sales will be con ducted by Benjamin and Har vey Stack at two sessions in the ManhattanSkyline Suite of the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 56th Street. The first session is scheduled for 7 P.M. Friday, and the second for 1 P.M. Saturday.

title: Philadelphia to Honor Greer of 76ers Today
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 (AP)Hal Greer of the 76ers, who has scored more than 20,000 points in his pro fessional basketball career, will be honored tomorrow by the city of Philadelphia.

title: L.I. EROSION PLANS CAUGHT IN STORM
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Feb. 27The future of projects to pro tect Suffolk beaches: from ero sion and hurricane damage was clouded this week as the County Legislature approved one such program for West hampton, but killed another for East Hampton.

title: Music
description: EVERYTHING will be free, of course, when American soci ety reaches its ulti mate stage of PostReichian Greenhood. That is to say, when a working majority of the U. S. Senate and House wear Jerry Rubin hairpieces and striped gym shoes. At that time, when Conscious ness will have risen to a state whose Roman numeral is as yet not even computable, bread and dreams will be free. Not only the subways, which to turnstile hoppers are already free, but Buster Keaton film festivals and Harvard educations, Mounds bars and Riviera vaxations.

title: Some Phone Gains Seen In Brooklyn and Queens
description: Telephone service in Brook lyn, Queens and Long Island is better than it has been but not fully what it should be, the Public Service Commis sion has reported after a statewide study.

title: The Changing View of Homosexuality
description: A decade ago, the concept of homosexuality as an ill ness to be treated medically was considered an enlight ened view in a society that regarded homosexuals as criminals to be punished for acting on their sexual incli nations.

title: 40 U.S. Airmen in Vietnam Held in Drug Investigation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 27 (AP)The United States, Seventh Air Force an nounced today the arrest of about 40 American airmen after a monthlong investiga tion into an alleged narcotics ring at the air base at Cam ranh Bay.

title: Sport, Camping Show Opens Here Saturday
description: It's a far cry from the pup infantryman's pup tent of World War II to the alum inum and chrome tent trail ers and mobile homes of to day's camping scene.

title: Venezuela Receiving Signals for Change
description: CARACAS, VenezuelaThis country has received two clear messages recently. One came through the medium of the Middle East oil negotiations and the other from the radical economic experiments now under way in Chile, Peru and other Latin American countries, not to mention Cuba.

title: Alice I. Angelo Plans Wedding
description: The engagement of Miss Alice Irene Angelo to John Leonard Huff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Huff of Winnet ka, Ill., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joachim R. Angelo of Brooklyn. A summer wedding is planned.

title: In Finland the Skiing May Be Different, but Snow Is Guaranteed
description: LAHTI, Finland  As skiers discov ered earlier this season at such wellknown resorts as St. Anton and Bad Gastein in Austria, Cer vinia in Italy and Zermatt in Switzer land, there are times when the amount of snow leaves something to be de sired. According to reports from those and a few other ski centers in Europe at the start of the Christmas season, the snow was so patchy that brown spots were evident and uncovered stones dotted the terrain.

title: Gail Cummings Plans May Bridal
description: OLD LYME, Conn., Feb. 27 The engagement of Miss Gail Cummings to Richard Phillips has been announced by Mr and Mrs. George Rich ard Cummings of Old Lyme and Delray Beach, Fla., par ents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Robert Phillips of Northampton, Pa.

title: DALEY MAINTAINS COUNCIL CONTROL
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 27Mayor Richard J. Daley's Democratic organization, as usual, main tained its total control over Chicago's City Council in this week's aldermanic elections.

title: Vandenberg
description: Oliver Lange is the pseudonym of the author of Vandenberg, a first novel that has been chosen a Book oftheMonthClub selection. One wonders if the picture on the back flap is a pseudograph. Anyway, who ever he is and whatever he looks like, he's written a good book, suc cessfully combining a number of novelistic virtues. It's also hard to imagine this absorbing narrative not being made into a movie.

title: Moreen Cahill Becomes Bride Of E. C. Carey
description: Miss Maroon Cathleen Ca hill, daughter of the late Dr. and, Mrs. John D. Cahill of the Bronx, was married here yes terday in the Roman Catho lic. Church of Our Saviour to Edward Charles Carey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Carey of New York and San Juan, P. R.

title: A 14Man Presidency Is Planned to Succeed Tito
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb 27The collective presidency of Yugoslavia, the body that will succeed Marshal Tito as head of the federation after his death or retirement, is to be composed of 14 representatives and will have new legislative powers, according to a set of 21 draft constitutional amend ments published here today.President Tito himself pro posed the new body in a speech last September, defining it then as an organ that would bring together the most important politicians in the nation to act together as a streamlined fed eral executive. Some of the streamlining appears to have come out of his proposal in the lengthy public and private de bates that followed his speech and led to the proposed changes that are now offered.The draft amendments are to be discussed next year by the presidium of the Central Com mittee of the League of Com munists and by the federal par liament. Before the drafts are fi nally adopted, there is also to be a twomonth public discus sion of them throughout the country.

title: Son of Otto Graham Signs With Packers
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 27Duane Graham, son of the professional football star, Otto Graham, has signed a contract with the Green Bay Packers.

title: 1,200 MARINES FACE A DEMOTION IN RANK
description: WASHINGTON Feb 27 (UPI) About 1,200 Marine Corps officers will lose their officers bars tomorrow and drop into the enlisted or warrant officer ranks.

title: Soviet Farmer Finds Coins
description: MOSCOW, Feb, 27 (Reuters)  A Georgian farmer digging the foundations of his new house hay uncovered 230 Roman silver coins from the second and third centuries, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reports.

title: Flamingo Day Is for Birds and Horses
description: Every racetrack its rail birds, but only Hialeah has fla rningos.

title: Freezing Down
description: Cryobiology is the sphere of this eerie sciencefiction chiller, and the prognosis is bad, very bad. Anders Bodelsen, a Danish novelist, feels that if you start turning folks metabolism up and down like thermostats as they will do by 1993, you're going to have one hell of a mess. Bruno, a young editor on a weekly magazine, has himself frozen down to await a can cer cure. When he awakens, 20 years later, he is cured but his original kidneys have been filched and his profession has evaporated. (There aren't any weekly magazines any more. For the simple reason that there aren't any weeks any more.) Something to do with the deci mal system. There are a few other bugs in the freezing pro cess, and Bruno becomes a melancholy Dane indeed. Mr. Bodelsen speculates on the metaphysics of geriatry with wit and imagination, projecting a time in the future when one's vital organs will belong to so ciety (for transplant purposes) and life will be eternail and unbearable.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: The Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth largest, has 239 vice presidents, including eight executive vice presi dents and 25 senior vice presidents.

title: CLARKSON CONQUERS DARTMOUTH SIX, 53
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 27Clarkson University shut off a thirdperiod Dartmouth rally tonight and defeated the In dians, 53, at Davis Rink.

title: Massachusetts Six Victor
description: CLINTON, N.Y., Feb. 27 (AP) John Grabowski slapped in a tiebreaking goal in the third period to lift the University of Massachusetts to a 32 hockey victory over Hamilton today.

title: ARMY IN  68 FEARED CIVIL INSURGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.A directive issued by the Army in February, 1968, as part of its program to, keep civilians under surveillance, shows that senior officers feared a true insurgency, should external subversive forces develop suc cessful control of the racial and antiwar dissidents who were active at that time.

title: In Brief
description: The daily life of two young marrieds, with baby, who just happen also to be international opera stars Instead of the plumber not coming, a telegram arrives asking you to get on a plane and be in Vienna tomor row night to do a role you've never sung The physical and emotional slump the day after a performance, singing well and having your voice vanish for Act Three, fighting the terrible Mr. Bing and the recording companiesit's all there, but the very squareness and nor mality of Mr. and Mrs. Mc Cracken make for a rare mat teroffact picture of a highly specialized world.

title: Miss Kelley Wed to T. J. Wenz Jr.
description: YONKERS, Feb. 27The marriage of Miss Martha Maywood Kelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Kelley of Morristown, N. J., and Manchester, Vt., to Theo Mr. and Mrs. Wenz of Yonk ers, took place here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed in St. John's ,Epis copal Church by the Rev. Osborne Budd.

title: Miss Norwood Marries in Spring
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Feb. 27The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Cox Norwood to Kevin Patrick Callahan, son of Mrs. Daniel Francis Calla han of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mr. Callahan, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Rich ard Harland Norwood of Short Hills and Bay Head. The wedding is planned for the spring.

title: RECURRING THEMES
description: To THE EDITOR: I am in strong disagree ment with Julius Novick's critique. I differ, first, with his appraisal of A Memory of Two Mondays, which he likes with some restraint. To me, however, the play lacked the bold dramatic strokes for which Miller is known. More Important, it lacked proper character development. On the other hand, I found The Price full of insight and the natural dialogue which evol ves from resolute characters realistically mirrored. Where I object most to Novick's comments is his attitude about the sameness of Mil ler's themes. I need simply point to another Foremost Playwright, Eugene O'Neill, Tennessee Williams, whose theme hangups brought new light to the American theater. And what of Miller's play The Cruci ble? It is absent from Nov ick's article because it would not fit into his thesis.

title: REAGAN MAY FACE FIGHT ON BUDGET
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27Gov. Ronald Reagan's conserva tive Republican wagon train seemed almost surrounded this weekend by whooping war par ties of college professors, state, employes and welfare recip ients.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: ON a recent Saturday evening, a companion and I decided to see Little Murders at the Beekman Theater on the East Side. Knowing that the movie was a popular one, and that the theater was a small one, we decided to buy our tickets early (7:30 P.M.) and go to the last showing (11 P.M.) in an at tempt to avoid the lines.

title: Art
description: ONE of the interesting things about having been around for a while is that your early idols among painters and sculptors keep coming up for reinspection looking very different from the way they looked when you discovered them. They may look better or they may look worse, or they may look only different. But the fact that they used to look one way and now look another brings with it all kinds of side thoughts and speculations upon how things have changed, how you have changed, and how a painting or a sculpture keeps changing simply by the fact of having been created in the context of a certain time and place that may have become quite estranged from the time and place in which it again.

title: REP. HEBERT ASSAILS C.B.S. ON FILM USE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Representative F. Edward Hebert, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today that the Columbia Broadcasting System had lied about how it had obtained film from him that was used in a television documentary on the Pentagon.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: LONDONYou can't get there from here.

title: When the Bay Freezes, the Iceboatmen Cometh
description: PORT WASHINGTON L. I., Feb. 27Bob Capidaglis looked out at Manhasset Bay from near his home here the other day and made a startling discovery there was ice covering the bay. But this wasn't just any ordi nary ice; it was the type of ice that would allow Mr. Capidag lis and his iceyachting friends to take their boats out and en joy a rare day on the bay.

title: The World
description: BRUSSELS  The plight of 3.5 million Jews In the Soviet Union was dramatized here last week at an unusual assembly of Jewish organizations. They got together in the Belgian capital because they felt that, next to the defense of Israel, what hap pens to their Soviet brothers is the most important problem fac ing Jewry today.

title: WITNESS ACCEPTED BY GALLEY'S JUDGE
description: FORT BENNING, Feb. 27Testimony that First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. shot a woman who ran toward him with her hands above her head, pleading for mercy, is now ad missible, a military judge ruled today.

title: The Funny Girl In Brook's Dream
description: ITHINK they mean it as a com pliment, said Frances de la Tour, peering questioningly out from under her dark auburn bangs. The lanky young British actress was wondering out loud about the odd way people have of describing her in terms of other, more famous women. Right now, everybody swears she's just like comedienne Carol Burnett.

title: City to Repair Old Singer Bowl on Fair Grounds
description: After more than five years of debate, the city has decided to save the Singer Bowl, one of the temporary structures built for the 196465 World's Fair at Flushing MeadowsCo rona Parkin Queens.

title: hen Nanette Becomes A NoNo
description: SO much of the mixture of nostalgia and melody and color that make No, No, Nanette seem to be the bee's knees in the theater is a visual theatrical experi ence that there is relatively little that can be transferred to an original cast recording (Columbia S 30563).

title: Letters
description: To THE Emma:

title: Greyhound in South Korean Venture
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 27 The Greyhound bus lines re tires about 500 buses a year in the United States, and a search for a market for these vehicles has led the company into a joint venture with South Korean and Nigerian businessmen to operate bus services in those countries.

title: In Brief
description: A criminal lawyer's paradig matic explanation of the work ings of the law. Taking off from a variety of simple cases, an attempt is made to show the differences between the law as stated and the law as it oper atesthat is, as a vector of social forces and interests and the behavior of lawyers, police and judges within the bureau cratic maze. The style is non technical but difficult to follow. since, a la Harold Laswell, one class of abstractions is sub stituted for the conventional, in this case, legal ones.

title: State Bars Entry of Horses As Caribbean Is Hit by Flu
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27 (UPI)The State Department of Agri culture and Markets clamped an embargo today on allowing horses into the state from Puerto Rico because of an out break of equine influenza in the Caribbean.

title: Law
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.It was 4:30 last Wednesday af ternoon when the military judge, Col. Reid W. Kennedy, leaned across the bench and in a gentle voice told an ex hausted 1st Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that his ordeal on the witness stand was over. For nine hours over two and ahalf days, the 27yearold lieutenant  tense and nervous  had related his story of the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet known as Mylai 4 on March 18, 1968.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I want to tell you, as a reader and a traveler, that I thought the Feb. 7 Travel section was particularly fine. The stories about Trinidad and other islands in the Caribbean made excellent reading. They were real ar ticles instead of ones painting a picture of romance and beautiful sunsets and perfec tion everywhere.

title: Stocks: Why Fractions,?; Eighths A Plague For Both Man and. Computer
description: Now that the United King dom has converted to deci mal money, only one impor tant world currency remains outside the decimal realm: Stock prices.

title: Ack Ack, $4, Posts Easy Victory In $88,200 San Antonio Stakes
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 27 (UPI)Ack Ack, stretching out to 1 miles for first time in two years, ran away from his opposition today and won the 33d running of the $88,200 San Antonio Stakes at Santa Anita by 3 lengths.

title: Four Months of Social Whirl; Eight Months of Sheer Bliss
description: ST. JAMES, BarbadosA few years ago, Claudette Colbert, who is one, of the ranking celebrities of this sundreched, flowerladen island, awakened later than usual and wandered downstairs in her nightgown. It wasn't her usual practice but, as all her servants are women and her house is set back from the road, she, was unconcerned.

title: Miss Mohlman Bride of Robert Watson
description: Miss Katharine Hudson Mohiman, an editor with the Western Publishing Com pany, was married here yes terday afternoon to Robert Preston Watson, vice presi dent of InterAmerican En terprises, S.A., of San Jose, Costa Rica. The ceremony was performed at the Colony Club by the Rev. James L. Johnson of St. John'sonthe Mountain Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N. J.

title: COLLEGE'S PLANS STIR OPPOSITION
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Feb. 27Preliminary plans by Manhat tanville College to build apart ments for its staff have stirred opposition in this expensive residential area.

title: Fruit Pruning Points
description: ONE of the basic princi ples of pruning fruit trees is the establish ment of a good frame work. This must be done while the tree is young.

title: McGovern Fights to Look Like a Winner
description: BEDFORD, N. H., Feb. 27The problem for Senator George S. McGovern, his staff and admirers agree, is to per suade the faint of heart that he really does have a chance.

title: Pete Maravich: Problems of Adjustment Over, He Would Like to Make Hawks SoarInstead of Sore
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 27 (UPI) As Pete Maravich, perhaps the richest rookie in the history of professional sports, nears the end of his first season in the National Basket ball Association, he appears to have found his niche in the league.

title: AssignedRisk Insurance To Cost 20% More in State
description: New York State motorists in the assignedrisk pool will have to pay an average of nearly 20 per cent more for auto insurance starting to morrow.

title: Social Workers From Catholic Charities Help the Elderly in the St. George Hotel to Regain Confidence
description: For the 500 elderly men and women who still make their borne In the onceproud St. George Hotel, a battle to in still confidence and banish fear has begun.

title: Barbara Hillyard Is Fiancee Of Thomas Baird Campion Jr.
description: DENVER, Feb. 27  The engagement of Miss Barbara Lynn Hillyard to Thomas Baird Campion Jr. has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Ryan Hillyard of Denver and Aspen, where the wedding will take place on June 5.

title: St. John's Swimmers Bow To La Salle Here, 64 to 49
description: La Salle took an early lead and defeated St. John's in swimming, 6449, at the Red men's pool in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday.

title: Liberal Arts Dean Named
description: DURHAM, N. H., Feb. 27 (AP) Dr. Allen Spitz, professor and chairman of the international relations program of James Madison College at Michigan State University, has been named dean of the University of New Hampshire College of Liberal Arts.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: Your articles on the Carib bean were excellent. I have just returned from going native in the Dominican Republic. Whitey is still an important lady there among most of the over20 set School children in their early teens, learning black history in the schools, tend to deride whites. If one is a black/ white in soul (and politically) one will be taken aboard with open hearts in Dominica. But there is digging to be done to raise pay to merited levels. The standard of liv ing basis for pay is still used by black and white employers alike. A profitsharing ar rangement would possibly circumvent the whole Black Revolution movement. As for insulated tourists in large hotels: If you don't want to be with the people of the country, why go any farther than Miami Beach?

title: Dunlap Wins Second Race, Gains in Sled Dog Series
description: LACONIA, N.H., Feb. 27 (AP)Harris Dunlap of Bakers Mills, N.Y., won the second of three races in the $6,700 world championship sled dog derby today and gained second place, 10 seconds behind Dom Blodg ett of Hallowell, Me.

title: 134 Yearg of Growth
description: Procter & Gamble was founded in 1837 when two brothersinlaw, William Procter, an English candle maker, and James Gamble, an Irish soapmaker, signed a partnership agreement in Cincinnati. Each contributed $3,596.47 and P. & G. was afloat.

title: 4 Weatherpeople Placed On Probation in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP) Four women members of the Weatherpeople, formerly known as the Weathermen, a faction of Students for a Democratic Society, have pleaded guilty to charges stemming from dis turbances in Chicago in 1969.

title: AFRICAN DEFECTOR JOINS PORTUGUESE
description: LISBON, Feb. 27A former member of the Central Com mittee of the National Libera tion Front of Mozambique is now working here for the Por tuguese Army's Department of Psychological Action.

title: 3YEAR MARRIAGES ASKED IN MARYLAND
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb 27 (AP)Two women members of Maryland's House of Delegates are proposing to legalize threeyear marriage contracts with an option to renew.

title: Volpe Tells Governors To Move on Billboards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)  Transportation Sec retary John A. Volpe warned the nation's Governors yes terday they faced a 10 per cent cut in Federal highway funds unless they took action toward removing billboards.

title: Selassie Opens Drive On Red Sea Pollution
description: MASSAWA, Ethiopia, Feb. 27 (Reuters)Emperor Haile Selassie opened an anti pollution campaign in the Red Sea this week when he scattered plastic card appeals for cleanliness in the water about 20 miles outside this naval base.

title: Harvard Plans Alumni Week
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP)Harvard University has announced plans for a week long Alumni College next sum mer to give alumni and their wives a chance to take part in the intellectual life of the uni versity.

title: City Center Children's Theater Draws 200 ActorParticipants
description: Jason and his argonauts needed some outside help to get home. Come on, now, let's pray to the gods, said Frank Geraci, supervisor. Behind him a cluster of boys and girls, in papercostume trimmings, sim ulated a boat, with a mass of yellow curled paper thrust high in their midst as the Golden Fleece.

title: Drive for Labor Unity in Japan Is Set Back as an Advocate Is Forced From Post
description: TOKYO, Feb. 27Efforts to unify Japan's longdivided la bor movement suffered a set back last week when Fumihiko Takaragi, one of the main pro moters of the drive, was forced to resign after losing a crucial vote within his own 220,000 man union, the AllJapan Com munication Workers Union.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Music
description: THE Aaron Copland 70th birthday observances continue, and on Tues day the Metropolitan Museum will show some of the films for which he wrote the music. The entire Amer ican musical colony has been anxious to pay homage to Copland, as well it might.

title: SUBWAYCAR FUND MAY BE EXPANDED
description: Money for more new subway cars will be added to the city's proposed capital budget, Lind say administration officials have been told privately by leaders of the City Council.

title: Iowa State Names John
description: AMES, Iowa, Feb. 27 (AP)Iowa State University an nounced tonight its new basket ball coach would be Maury John, of Drake University. John succeeds Glen Anderson who was released Feb. 17.

title: For Japan, the Future Is Now
description: TOKYO, Feb. 25A little re luctantly but definitely, the Japanese are conceding that the future has become the present, that their country is a big boy nowwith a big boy's achievements and, sighing, a big boy's problems.

title: Dr. R. D., Bloomstein To Wed Linda Zients
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 27Mrs. Lewis Zients of South Orange has an nounced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Linda Sue Zients, to Dr. Richard Donald Bloomstein, a dentist in Sum mit. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Bloomstein of Summit, where his father is also a dentist.

title: Music
description: THE American Confer ence of Cantors, an organization of 165 cantors who sing in temples, is going to put on its first public concert on April 4 in Alice Tully Hall. It has several reasons for this move. It is celebrating its 18th anniversary, and in He brew tradition 18 is a signifi cant year, designated as Char or Life. It wants to dramatize the use of contem porary music in sacred serv ices and to call attention to the shortage of cantors.

title: 9YearOld Intruder Mars Kaffeeklatsch
description: Mrs. Rose Baglio of Canar sie had an unusual intruder at her kaffeeklatsch yester day afternoona 1962 Olds mobile.

title: In Brief
description: A manloving feminist's testi monial on love, life, lib (libido as well as liberation), family, etc. She sees The Pill as freeing women from the imperatives of childbirth, points out that over population adds another im perative against reproduction, understands that most women want babies even at the cost of stifling their social selves. She calls for more freedom of personal development in mar riagemore independence for both partnersand asks that women seek positions now held by men which men have used to threaten the environment and life itself. Nothing of this is new, but here it is passion ately expressed.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: The two remaining nation ally syndicated Sunday news paper supplements, which at one time almost failed to survive competition from TV, had a good 1970 and are looking forward to a better 1971, thanks in no small measure to the cigarette ad vertising that has been forced off the tube.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: News From Thrush Green
description: The news from Thrush Green is a mixed bag, if you must know. Dotty Harner has had an unexpected addition to her household of a cat and six kit tens. The Dr. Baileys are in for a fortnight's visit from their least favorite nephew, an organic food freak from Oxford. Albert Piggott, the village sexton, is having wife trouble. Yam Cur dle, the criminal element, has made a 10shilling heist. Ad miral Trigg's old cottage, Tul livers, has been bought by a Mrs. Prior, who has been aban doned with her 6yearold son. And like that. What is there about Thrush Green that makes it so special? muses young Mrs. Prior, just as she is about to live happily ever after. Why it's Miss Read, bless her heart, who crochets these samplers of English village life, happily ob livious to the cultural revolu tion.

title: Spinning Wheels That Shaped a Town's Destiny
description: SEAGROVE, N. C. We stand under the shelter that protects the groundhog kiln at Ben Owen's Old Plank Road pottery, and we are glad to be out of the bad weather and the mud. A hard rain is falling but our front side is warmed by the good smelling heat that puffs out of the kiln's mouth. A tall stack of logs blocks the cold wind from our backs.

title: NOT SO DUMB?
description: To THE EDITOR: Dear Sir, I admire Sesames Street very much, but I don't think they should show Pro fesser Haystings to be so stupid. My two year old brother watches him too. Our father is a Professer & al though he Is adsentminded he is not stupid. I don't think that they should teach two year olds that Professers are so dumb.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ALGIERS It Is obvious from con versing with Algerian President Houari Boumediene that his longrange for eignpolicy dream is creation of a North African state, the Maghreb, in cluding Algeria, Tunisia and Morocco, which would be linked to a federated Europe by a neutralized Mediterranean Sea.

title: Eastern Thaw on Berlin?
description: Is East Germany ready at last to grant the concessions that could bring a Berlin settlement within reach? It too early for this conclusion, but Premier. Willi Stoph's letter to Mayor Klaus Schtz of West Berlin does repre sent a positive advancethe first in many yearsby the East German Communist regime.

title: In Brief
description: Black protest and youth pro test in the United Statesa survey that sounds like a parody of the funded academic social studies style: Protest movements in general arise from the propensity of society to reach a condition of stability in which some members achieve a favorable position and the failure of others to keep pace create a condition of relative deprivation.... The author is now director of the Southwest Center for Urban Research at Houston and Rice.

title: Theater: Dirtiest Show Reappraised
description: How dirty is The Dirtiest Show in Town the second time around. Fortunately not very, for frankly, and per haps unfashionably, I dislike dirty shows.
