I am easily em barassed and a puritan at soul. Yet Tom Eyen's inge niously and ingenuously named show, now at the Astor Place Theater, is so frank and innocent that it could probably only give of fense to the dirtyminded.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The instant identification of a car representing the Englandbased McLaren Rac ing Team is its bright orange paint job. The prime coat, though, consists of green dol lars  hundreds of thou sands of them  that Mc Laren teams have won in the United States these last few years, notably in the CanAm se ries. This year, the team will make an allout effort for the Tri ple Crown of the United States Auto Clubthe 500 mile races at Indianapolis (May 29), Pocono (July 3) and Ontario (Sept. 5). The drivers are Denis Hulme and Peter Revson.

title: TAIPEI IS BRACED ON DATE OF REVOLT
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 27Leaves for the police force have been canceled, according to re liable sources, and the men in structed to remain on alert for the 24th anniversary of the February 28 incident tomor row.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: I was astounded to read your article on Caribbean Black Power. Last Decem ber, I flew to Curacao and boarded the S.S. Regina for a cruise to Antigua, Guade loupe, St. Lucia, Grenada and Laguaira. I was in the com pany of other travel people as well as members of a travel club who were not di rectly connected with the in dustry. I stopped into little outoftheway bars for a drink and for lunch. I visited small and large shops, drug stores and supermarkets. I traveled by cab everywhere, and nowhere did I run into situations of the attitude de scribed in your article. Eager cabdrivers, little boys anx ious to sell their spices and beads, old women marketing their straw products, yesand occasionally it can be wearing. But I was met with courtesy on every hand. Everyone I spoke to was anx ious and willing to tell me about their island. Nowhere did I encounter any difficulty as outlined.

title: Political Scientists Elect Pennsylvanidn as Chief
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27Dr. Richard D. Lambert has suc ceeded James C. Charlesworth as president of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

title: HEPTAGONAL TITLE CAPERED BY PENN
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 27 The bus carrying the Pennsyl vania track and field team to the 24th Heptagonal indoor championships broke down to day, but the Quakers still ran off with their first team title.

title: Vermont Sextet Triumphs
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 27 (AP)Vermont scored on firstperiod penalty shot by Pat Wright today in defeating Bowdoin, 52 in hockey at Gutterson Fieldhouse. The vic tory lifted Vermont into a firstplace tie with Bowdoin in the E.C.A.C.'s Division II. Each has a 132 wonlost record in the division.

title: Hoffmans Have Child
description: MEDFIELD, Mass., Feb. 27 A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Pope Hoffman on Jan. 22 at the Newton Wellesley Hospital. Mrs. Hoff man is the former Miss Elaine Walker.

title: Birds Are Saved From Oil Spills
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 27When two Standard Oil tankers collided in San Francisco Bay last month, some 840,000 gallons of oil swirled into the bay.

title: The Order Of Things
description: French intellectual life is a sce nario. It has its stars and histrionic polemics, its claque and fiascos. It is susceptible, to a degree remark able in a society so obviously literate and ironic, to sudden gusts of lunatic fashion. A Sartre dominates, to be followed by LeviStrauss; the new master is soon fusilladed by selfpro claimed Maoiststructuralists. The almost impenetrable soliloquies on semantics and psychoanalysis of Ja ques Lacan pack their full houses. Now the mandarin of the hour is Michel Foucault. His arresting fea tures look out of the pages of glossy magazines; he has recently been ap pointed to the College de France, which is both the most prestigious of official learned establishments and, traditionally, a setting for fashion able charisma.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: It looks as if accountants will be counting more than just profits and losses in the years ahead.

title: Movies
description: PETER BOGDANOVICH was talking about the film, Targets, which he directed. He was saying that they had a hard time photographing its star, Boris Karloff, because he was darktoo dark. Sitting right next to Bogdanovich was Reginald Bryant, a coal black filnimaker who snapped, What the hell you mean, too dark?

title: Massachusetts Pay BillLoses
description: BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP)The state House of Representatives has killed a bill already passed by the Senate that would have raised the base salary of Massa chusetts legislators $1,200 over the next two years. The 280 state legislators now receive a base pay of $11,400.

title: Illinois Relay Teams Break 2 Marks at Ohio State Meet
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 27 (AP)University of Illinois re lay teams set two records to day in the fourth Ohio State invitation indoor track meet.

title: The Embodiment Of Poor White Power
description: WASHINGTON.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: I read the Caribbean Black Power article on my return from beautiful Tobago (I have visited Tobago and nearby Barbados numerous times in the past several years) and it occurred to me that if the people of Tobago appear un friendly and resentful to the tourist, they may have just cause. As Mr. Greene sug gested, if the chef's assistant at the luxurious golf club earns $11 per weekand I believe it is a good yardstick, for domestics receive even lesswe should not criticize their hostility but admire their forbearance.

title: Announcements
description: NADELSam and Ann. Happy 45th anni versary from tho children and grand children.

title: Boys Find Dynamite On House Roof Here
description: Two teenaged boys, play ing on the rooftop of a Low er East Side home yesterday found seven sticks of dyna mite in a plastic bag.

title: Ithaca Picks Crew Captain
description: James Huntley of Hamburg, N. Y., has been elected captain of the Ithaca College varsity heavyweight crew. Huntley, a senior, had never: participated in crew before last year. He went out for the sport at the suggestion of a friend.

title: The Nation
description: INVERNESS, Miss.When the tornado had passed, the town's largest house, a proud old white mansion surrounded by acres of trees and gar dens, was still standing. It looked almost untouched: Within sight of the mansion, block after block of the humble Negro neighborhood lay in ruins.

title: Ray Is Denied a New Trial
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 27 (AP)Judge William H. Williams of the Criminal Court has denied a new trial to James Earl Ray, the slayer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Judge Williams ruled yesterday on a petition by Ray's lawyers seek ing postconviction relief for their client. The judge also ruled that no hearing was necessary to determine if a new trial should be granted.

title: Movie Mailbag; NOSTALGIA?
description: To THE EDITOR: I wonder whether all those people who vehemently de fend Love Story as an hon est tale of young romance aren't in their middle age, wistfully looking back on their own youth through the golden haze of nostalgia. happen to be the same age as heroic Ollie and Jennie, re cently out of college with many sweet recollections of Cambridge, Mass. But I can assure you that both for me and my friends, none of whom are particularly drug ridden or antieverything, life and loving has not been as blissful as Erich Segal paints it. Certainly Segal has em ployed the straw man of par ental ostracismbut true love conquers all, right?

title: Miss Sims Wed To James Davin. Attended by 7
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 2 Miss Christine Sims was married here this afternoon to James Manson Davin. in the Cathedral Church (Episcopal). The Very Rev. H. Lawrence Whittemore Jr., dean and rector of the church, and the Rev. Richard A. Powers, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Corinne Marshall Is Engaged To John R. Babson Jr, Engineer
description: FOX CHAPEL, Pa., Feb. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Houston Boggs Marshall have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Corinne Elizabeth Marshall, to John Ralston Babson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Babson of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Snowmobiles Bring Roaring Arrogance of Power to Lake Tahoe
description: INCLINE VILLAGE, Nev., Feb. 27  An implausible event being staged under im possible conditions by an un likely sponsor has rent the sylvan stillness of Lake Ta hoe, 6,700 feet above sea level. It's called the Snow mobile Grand Prix, a three day carnival of noise and color that will reach its cli max tomorrow.

title: Boldwood, $19.80, Triumphs
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 (AP)M. A. Van Berg Stable's Boldwood captured the $25,000 added A. B. Letellier Memorial Handicap before 16,571 today at the Fair Grounds.

title: Governor Scores System
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27  In ask ing for nofault insurance legislation, Governor Rockefel ler declared that the state was saddled with a slow, cumber some, costly and outmoded auto insurance system.

title: Belgian Fights a Draw
description: MONT ST. AMAND, Belgium, Feb. 27 (AP)Roger Van Laere of Belgium and Dante Pelaez, a Peruvian living in Paris, drew tonight in a 10round junior middleweight bout.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Augustinus to Wed
description: HARDING TOWNSHIP, N.J., Feb. 27  Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam Augustinus have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doreen Joy Augustinus. to Edmund David Toben, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Toben of New York. Miss Augustinus's fa ther is vice president of Maher Terminals in New York. She is a senior at Rose mont College. Mr. Toben was graduated from Villanova Uni versity. His father is sub scription supervisor for the New York Post.

title: MSGR. JEAN M. CASTEX
description: PENET ANGUISHENE, On tario, Feb. 27 (AP)Msgr. Jean Marie Castex, said to be Can ada's oldest Roman Catholic priest, died today at the age of 99.

title: Suffolk College Is Helping Freshmen;
description: SELDEN, L. I., Feb. 27While the State University at Stony Brook has decided to. cut its next freshmen class by a third, education officials in Suf folk County are hopeful that, other actions will ease the blow and assure students of a good opportunity for a college edu cation.

title: March
description: February ends and we come to a time of more rain than snow, more melt than new ice. To March, with day light now long enough to dull the fangs of cold; with the slow, creeping change that is so tantalizing when we are winter weary and hungry for spring.

title: 5 Men on the Ground Are Hailed by NASA
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)Praising Apollo 14 as the mission that put it all to gether, the newest moon explorers., other astronauts and space officials honored today five of the men on the ground who make space travel possible.

title: Orthodox Albanians Here Attend Queens Church
description: Snugly nestled on a three quarteracre wooded plot in Jamaica Estates is a handsome edifice that is not only one of the newest churches in Queens, but also a reflection of the changing life patterns of the 125 AlbanianAmerican families it serves as a house of worship.

title: Beatrix Schuba of Austria Captures World FigureSkating Crown at Lyons
Carolyn Hogen Plans Nuptials
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., Feb. 27 Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Hagen of Chappaqua and Peru, Vt., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Hogen, to C. Vaughn Mason Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde V. Mason of Bellevue, Wash. The wedding is plan ned for June.

title: ELECTRONIC MUSIC HEARD IN PROGRAM
description: The concert of Lejaren Hill er's music on Friday night dif fered a bit from those one usually attends. It began, for example, with a nude man and woman lying on their backs on the carpeted floor of the base ment of Automation House. at 49 East 68th Street. Nude may be too strong a word, since each was wearing a wristwatch on a wide leather band and each was blindfolded with a length of black fabric knotted at the back of the head.

title: Article 90678949 -- No Title
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 27  Ed Kenty, a sophomore, scored two goals and led Bos ton College to a 52 victory over Army tonight. Kenty tal lied in the first and second pe riods as the Eagles closed their season with 11 victories and 15 defeats. Army's record is 7131 with two games to play.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUPS SEEK PEACE IN '71
description: Representatives of 24 major religious denominations and agencies opened a campaign this week seeking an end to the war in Indochina by the end of this year.

title: Ford McKinstry. Fraker, Fiance Of Miss Anna Hayes, a Teacher
description: Dr. and Mrs. Guy Scull Hayes of New York and North Brooklin, Me., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Scull Hayes, to Ford Mc Kinstry Fraker. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Shedd Fraker of Princeton, N. J.

title: The Man Who Gave Us Inferiority Complex, Compensation, Overcompensation, Aggressive Drive And Style of Life
description: Do you think, Alfred Adler once demanded of Freud, that it is such a great pleas ure for me to stand in your shadow for the whole of my life? If Adler were alive today, he might well re iterate the question: it is chiefly as one of the great early Freudians that he is remembered. And yet he always insisted that he was not a disciple; he had never been psychoanalyzed by Freud nor attended his lectures. In deed, Adler became so radically op posed to the basic tenets of Freudian theory that the two men severed all connections in 1911 and remained bitter enemies for the rest pf their lives.

title: Your Environment
description: A good general ecology hand book. The problem areas are taken up seriatim, the diffi culties defined, and the steps citizen or government can take to remedy them listed. One of many similar books, but a use ful summary of the issues.

title: LEWIS KEY FIGURE IN U.M.W. LAWSUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The monthlong trial of a $75mil lion conspiracy and breach of trust damage suit filed by mem bers of the United Mine Work ers of America against their leaders ended yesterday with tacit agreement that the prin cipal defendant was, or should have been, the late John L. Lewis.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Former Governor Win throp Rockefeller, an admirer of the South Carolina pro gram, persuaded the Arkan sas Legislature in 1969 to appropriate funds to start a pilot, industrytraining pro gram. The legislators author ized $120,000 for each of the next two fiscal years, but the program did not get un derway until last February. Larry Brown, a South Caro lina TEC alumnus, was hired to direct the Arkansas proj ect.

title: Art in London
description: SOME time ago there was an exasperating lit erary vogue for biog raphies that bore mys terious titles. One opened The Stricken Deer to find that one had launched into an admirable book about the unhappy poet William Cow per, or was surprised to dis cover that A Flame in Sun light concealed a scholarly portrait of Thomas De Quin cey. Now the organizers of art exhibitions have appar ently taken up the habit; at London's Tate Gallery, the British Arts Council has ar ranged a splendid show which, for reasons I cannot entirely grasp, they have de cided to call The Shock of Recognition.

title: Unsafe at Any Height
description: A sober and sobering study of airline safety. After analyz ing reports on 15,000 accidents, the author finds that a good many were, caused by faulty design and imperfect safety facilities. There have been other books on the subject lately, but this is one of the simplest and most straightforward, empha sizing technical, rather than hu man, flaws.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y. U. Heat and Food Curtailed By a Strike of Maintenance Men
description: New York University may be forced to shut down or curtail its operations sometime this week if a 12dayold strike of Teamsters Union maintenance men that is holding up food and fuel deliveries is not settled, ac cording to the university's chan cellor.

title: Japan's SelfDefense Force Wins A Skirmish With the Past
description: TOKYO. IT was 9 o'clock in the evening, and in the halls of the comfort able modern barracks of the Third Company, Fuji Regiment, one could detect  among the odors of rifle grease, musty fatigues and persim monsthe smell of noodles cooking.

title: LAWRENCE CRANSTON
description: MAHWAH, N. J., Feb. 27Lawrence Cranston, who retired recently as development man ager for Uniroyal, Inc., in Pas saic, died today in Valley Hos pital, Ridgewood. He was 63 years old and lived at 21 Stone Fence Road.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS MEET ON SAVINGS
description: Leaders of community school boards in the five boroughs met yesterday with members the Board of Education and city officials to determine how $40 million could be cut from school services in the balance of the 197071 term.

title: Rome Film Studio Destroyed
description: ROME, Feb. 27 (AP)A workman tripped over a wire today, apparently touching off a fire that destroyed a Rome movie studio. About 100 fire men fought the blaze, believed to have been caused by a short circuit, to keep it away from eight other studios of the De Paolis Movie Company.

title: Riessen Turns Back Okker In $30.000 London Tennis
description: LONDON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Marty Riessen of Evanston, III., moved into the quarterfinals of the $30,000 Rothmans indoor tennis tournament tonight with a 64, 64 triumph over Tom Okker of the Netherlands.

title: Elm City Kennel Club Is Not Barking Up Wrong Tree
description: Although a serious blight has struck the elm trees, there has been no blight as far as the Elm City Kennel Club is concerned. Because of space limitations in the Goffe Street Armory, we limited our entry to 1,250 this year, said Mrs. Barbara Fournier, the hardworking president of the organization. We could have had another 300, for entries closed 10 days before the listed date. This is the 54th allbreed fixture for the New Haven club. A. Peter Knoop, who judged the Westminster hound group and who has just joined the selected group of allround ers licensed to do all breeds, will name the best in show.

title: HELEN H. SMITH, 68, RETIRED MISSIONARY
description: Helen Huntington Smith, a United Church of Christ mis sionary and executive for 37 years, died yesterday in Lu theran Hospital in Cleveland.

title: U.S. Rejects City's Bid to House Welfare Cases at Bennett Field
description: The city's plan to house 350 to 400 welfare families at Floyd Bennett Field was rejected yes terday.

title: Ferdinand Holcomb Brewer 3d Is Fiance of Pamela A. Peters
description: WAYNE, Pa., Feb. 27Mrs. H. Walker Peters has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Pamela Anne Peters, to Ferdinand Holcomb Brewer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brewer Jr., of South Orange, N. J.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The attainment by the United States economy of a trilliondollar gross national product has brought with it a new round of questioning about the quantity and quality of economic life in America.

title: In Brief
description: A straightforward, rather wellwritten public biography of Harding as newspaper editor and Ohio Governor, ending with his election to the Presidency which, of course, is the point at which he becomes most worth reading about. There's not a page here to bring a blush to a maiden's cheek, or a Harding's.

title: BUDGET BEARINGS STRAIN EMOTIONS
description: With a gesture of contempt, a 31yearold man in shirt sleeves glared at the Board of Estimate, took a drag on his cigarette and called out sharp ly tothe chairman:

title: Italian Regional Decision Stirs Disorders in L'Aquila
description: L'AQUILA, Italy, Feb. 27Disorders broke out in this mountain city 50 miles north east of Rome today in a re gional dispute similar to that which has led to recurrent riot ing in Reggio Calabria in the south.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27Deep down underneath, all the surface arguments about what we are doing in Indochina something In the American spirit keeps the nation from facing the facts in that tragic peninsula.

title: Panel of Catholics Endorses Concept Of Women Deacons
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) A report made public by the United States Catholic Confer ence endorses ordination of women to the Roman Catholic diaconate, or office of deacon.

title: New Twist at Roosevelt: Triple
description: From portal to portal, the distance between Yonkers Raceway, which completes its 50night, winter meeting on Tuesday, and Roosevelt Race way, which starts Its 70night spring session the following night, is 26.2 miles. The mea surements are not based on how the crow flies, but as the Dodge darts.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Walter Kerr, in his enthusi asm to save the theater, is surely playing on the wrong side of the field when he re peatedly refuses to accept any new concept of theatrical production. His objections to Peter Brook's A Midsummer Night's Dream show once again his inability to see the theater as a living art.

title: The World
description: DELHI  To help the masses of illiterate voters in In dia, every party is identified on the ballot by a symbol: A cow nursing a calf, an earthen Alad din's Lamp, a star, a banyan tree. Yet, perhaps the most apt symbol for India's fifth national election since independence, for which polling begins tomorrow, would be a question mark.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONIt begins in the inner chambers of the De fense and State Departments, whose anonymous experts pre pare position papers of all kinds. These in turn are sent to Dr. Henry A. Kissinger's office at the White House, where the best are sifted, trimmed or expanded by the bright young Ivy Leaguers who work for him. The Presi dent polishes the final draft, and what emerges is a multichap tered product of mixed origin known as the President's Annual Report on Foreign Policy.

title: Mrs. King in Final
description: WINCHESTER, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals moved into the final of the $12,500 national women's indoor tennis cham pionships today.

title: Agriculture Aide to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI) Harold R. Lewis, the Agricul ture Department's director of information since 1963, has an nounced plans to retire March 31. Mr. Lewis, 62 years old, a career civil servant, had served with a succession of Agricul ture Department agencies since 1936.

title: Judges Try New Scoring System Of Flashing Cards in Florida
description: A new judging system similar to the ones used in figure skating and diving, is being tried in the horse shows on the Florida Sun shine Circuit.

title: Recordings
description: IF Erik Satie were alive today  and what a pity he isn't  he would be just short of 105 years old and, very like ly, astonished by the atten tion his music is getting now adays. It is the kind and quality of the attention, I think, that would have sur prised him, for he was not Without a certain renown during his lifetime. But his fame, outside his own lim :lied circle of devotees, was chiefly as a perpetrator of musical jokes and gags. For most musicians he was an ec centric not to be taken seri ously, and he had no commer cial success at all. He lived in poverty.

title: Their Dreamboat as a Freighter Until...
description: IN that first flush of enthusiasm a year ago, it had seemed like a per fectly feasible idea. John P. Thom son, a 47yearold dentist from Birmingham, Mich., and his family were going to give up jobs, home, schools and savings to sail for one year around the world. Not on a cramped yacht, but on a real ship. Not someone else's ship, but their own.

title: Chen Holds OneShot Lead In Philippine Golf With 212
description: MANILA, Feb. 27 (AP)Chen ChienChung of Taiwan carded a 74 today, but held a one stroke lead with 212 after 54 holes of the $15,000 Philippine open.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The Times has rendered a conscientious service to the public as well as to travel agents in publishing the Caribbean black power article by Wade Greene.

title: Queen Mary Ties Up for Last Time as Dispute Flares Anew
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Feb. 27  The liner Queen Mary made her final docking here today, about two years be hind schedule but just in time for a rekindled statewide de bate over her worth.

title: ARE TEAMS WIN IN THREE SPORTS
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 27  Army recorded victories in swimming, gymnastics and rifle against Navy today.

title: The Nation
description: The Nixon Administration's plan for speeding the econ omy along an optimum feas ible growth path this year to a Gross National Product of $1,065billion, with un employment and inflation both dropping, ran into heavy resistance last week:

title: Florida Ban on Closed Meetings Merges Candor and Confusion
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 27 When Governor Reubin As kew met in his office with legislative leaders to discuss taxes, reporters walked in and, sat down to listen. He did not stop them. Florida's govern, rnent in the sunshine law says, they're entitled to be there.

title: Nonprofit Institutions Seen in Decline
description: About 51,300 private and nonprofit cultural, educational, medical and other institutions may be in the first stage of decline that could affect the basic fabric of American so ciety, according to the Car negie Corporation of New York.

title: It's Saw, Snip and Clip Time for Greenery
description: PRUNING is important to maintain an attractive garden. It is not an alternative for poor selection of plants nor for inadequate spac ing in the landscape. Rather pruning is a means to maintain strong, well balanced plants.

title: Road Deaths Decline First Time in Decade
description: Deaths on United States highways decreased in 1970 for the first time in 10 years, the Insurance Information In stitute reports. It also re ported the economic loss fell for the first time in 25 years, United Press International said.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The battle of the banks for checking accounts escalated a notch last week when the First National City Bank an nounced its newest check book covers are the work of Emillio Pucci, the Italian de signer of silk prints.

title: TRAINING BY U.S. OF ALLIES STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UPI)  The General Accounting Of fice reported today that the Defense Department spent half a million dollars training Thai soldiers in this country to op erate a missile system that has not been made available to Thailand.

title: Roston College Triumphs
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP)  Boston College over took Holy Cross with seven minutes remaining today and went on to a 6959 basketball victory.

title: Andree Lillian Brulatour Wed To Douglas C. Etman, Engineer
description: ROSELAND, N. J., Feb. 27 Miss Andree Lillian Brula tour of Lincoln Park, daugh ter of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Jules Brulatour of New York and Harrison, N. Y., was married here today to Douglas Clayton Etman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Etman of Saddle Brook. The cere mony was performed in Our Lady of the Blessed Sacra ment Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Edward J. Fleming.

title: St. John Wrestlers Win
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 (AP)Wrestlers from St. John. College of Minnesota compiled 97 points and captured four indi vidual crowns in winning the National Catholic invitation championships today.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Despite much carefuland evidently sincereexplanation by the members of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advis ers, there remains a sense of mystery here as to what the Government sought to achieve by its very optimistic forecast of the economy for 1971.

title: Merger in Attleboro
description: ATTLEBORO, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP)The Attleboro Sun and The North Attleboro Chronicle have announced that they are merging, effective March 1. The new daily newspaper wilt be called The Son Chronicle Bind will have an expected circula tion of 18,000. Guy S. DeVany, president of The Attleboro Sun Publishing Corporation, will be publisher of the new paper, it was announced. Paul A. Rixon, published of The Chron??, will he general manager of the merged paper.

title: Frances B. Tripp Wed to Lawyer
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Feb. 27 In the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here today Miss Frances Beale Tripp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Tripp Jr., was married to G. Michael Hawkey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Hawkey of Mont clair, N. J. The Rev. Clarke K. Caor performed the cere mony, assisted by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger.

title: Students Seek Voting Power in Alabamat
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 27 A Federal court lawsuit in volving voting rights for 18yearolds, combined with mass registration campaigns, may soon bring about a major ex tension of student power in the local politics of college commu nities in Alabama. The outcome could have a national impact.

title: Temple EmanuEl Names Three to Trustees'
description: Three new trustees have been added to the board of Temple EmanuEl, the 3,200 family Reform Jetvish congre= gation at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street.

title: Defiant Newsmen in Uruguay Plan New Leftist Daily
description: MONTEVIDEO. Uruguay, Feb. 27  Leftist journalists, whose efforts to publish a daily newspaper Vruguay have been regularly thwarted by the Government, announced plans this week to attempt publica tion of a new newspaper.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Norman Donaldson's study of R. Austin Freeman and his scientistdetective, IN SEARCH OF DR. THORNDYKE (Bowling Green University Press, Bowling Green, Ohio, cloth $7.95, paper $3.) is a brilliant achievement that leaves precious little for future commentators. Mr. Don aldson's style is fresh and lucid, his control of chronology exem plary, his approach affectionate but still objective, his judg ments incisive and soundly rea soned, his attention to detail remarkable.

title: Soviet Seeking. U.S. Patents
description: WASHINGTON  The So viet Union is making a strong effort to license the use of its inventions in this coun try, and is attaining some success. Group visits of So viet officials to Washington and of Americans to Mos cow are being arranged to explore the subject.

title: Harvard's Hairy Five Makes Some Foes Bristle
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. I don't know how Brian Newmark wakes up in the morning and can look in the mirror, says George Blaney, the Dartmouth basketball coach.

title: Stamps
description: MISSOURI this year is celebrating the 150th anniver sary of its entry into the Union on Aug. 10, 1821. In addition, it will, along with many other Ameri cans, share in celebrating the 87th birthday of for mer President Harry S. Truman on May 8. The Postal Service will participate by issuing a stamp on May 8 at Independence, Mo., to tie in with the former President's birthday and at the same time commemorate the sesquicentennial anniversary Missouri's entry into the Union as the 24th state.

title: Music
description: To their thousands of fans, Blood, Sweat & Tears threenight stand at Philharmonic Hall tomorrow, Tues day and Wednesday is nothing short of spectacular. To other thousands of deep ly committed, longtime rock enthusiasts, it is nothing less than a farce. To Blood, Sweat & Tears, it is the most prestigious set of concerts in three busy years that have included over 100 live concerts a year.

title: AUCTIONEERSELLS ART BY THE CRATE
description: Who cares about signed? tell them Gertrude Stein In Henri Matisse over to ti house. He drew her a pictur So he didn't sign it. So wha So it's still andan unsigned Matisse is goo enough for Gertrude Stein, it's good enough for me.

title: Education
description: ALBANYThis thing has taken more twists and turns than a Nijinsky bal let, a Democratic legislator said last week, He was re ferring to the decadelong controversy over state aid to religious schools, a contro versy that has produced a series of reversals.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It is distressing that Clive Barnes should be so lacking in objective judgment as to let himself be seduced by the outer trappings of Peter Brook's A Midsummer Night's Dream and call it the greatest production of Shakespeare I have ever seen in my life. What Brook has done is to bring back to the American public the theater of cruelty of his Marat/ Sade. Only this time it's cruelty to the playwright, the play and the discerning play goer.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONConsider the implications of these three propositions, said the legal scholar who is troubled by the assaults on privacy in America today.

title: C. G. Jung.
description: Carl Gustav Jung, in his books Freud and Psycho analysis and Practice of Psychotherapy, had this to say about the two other members of the first tri umvirate of psychoanal lysis:

title: Sure, Sure, Shirley
description: WHO would ever have thought it! Broadway's newest sensa tion is a genuine 1925 musi cal comedy starring one of the major stars of the 1930's who has been in retirement for years. The show costars famous character actors of that era and the most interesting aspect of the production is that it is done serious ly and not camped. Are we discussing. Ruby Keeler's new show, No, No, Nan ette? No! What made you think that?

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Two months ago this no longer somnambulic state added a Germanowned plant, Mayer & C.I.E. (USA), Inc., to its growing industrial base. Situated on a 110acre site in Orangeburg, the $6 million, 92,000squarefoot fa cility now employs 100 South Carolinians, producing the first of the company's circularbed knitting ma chines to be manufactured in the United States.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Quail Hunt Under a Hot Sun
description: MERIDA, Yucatan, Mexico At 5:30 A.M., perhaps 40 miles from the hotel in Merida where we had spent a fragment of the night, our Club de Patos driver stopped the car at a roadside cafe where strong and black cof fee and a rich bread, similar to rusk or the sweet bread of the Portuguese, made the coming quail hunt seem not only possible but welcome.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Brock Calls Baseball's Drug Program Neither Preventive Nor Corrective
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27Lou Brock, outfielder for the St. Louis Cardinals, reflect ed today on the fact that the baseball commissioner, Bowie Kuhn, had scheduled three seminars on drugs, and said:

title: HARD HATS SEETHE OVER WAGE CURB
description: President Nixon's plan to curb inflation by holding down wages in the construction in dustry has touched off an up ward spiral of resentment here among workers, their union of ficials and employers.

title: BONN'S FARM POLICY PROTESTED AT RALLY
description: BONN, Feb. 27About 50,000 West German farmers staged a peaceful demonstration here to day against the Bonn Govern ment's farm policy.

title: Pressure on Legislators Rises For More Aid to Schools on L.I.
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27Pres sures are building on the Long Island legislative dele gation to seek additional state aid for public schools as a result of Governor Rock efeller's call for extra aid for the parochial schods.

title: Allende Replies to Nixon
description: SANTIAGO, Chile (AP)President Allende criticized President Nixon today for say ing Chile had challenged the interAmerican system by re suming diplomatic relations with Cuba. He said the system was in crisis because United States decisions dominated the Organization of American States.

title: City Opera to Give A New Waschera During 5th Week
description: The New York City Opera will introduce a new production of Verdi's Un Ballo in Mas chera on March 21 in the fifth week of the company's current season at the New York State Theater. The performance will be given as a benefit for the New York City Opera Guild's production fund, and a masked ball will be held in the Grand Promenade of the theater fol lowing the opera.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Flies to South Carolina For Address to State's Jaycees
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Feb. 27 Senator Edward M. Kennedy made a rare speaking appear ance in the South today.

title: Home Improvement
description: SELECTING and buying the right type and style drapery hardware is the first step that must be taken to insure a good job of hanging curtains or drapes (the various kinds of rods available were described in this column last week). The next step is to mount the rod properly in order to achieve the desired effect while still insuring a sturdy installation that will permit smooth opening and closing without pulling out from the wall or ceiling.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Is it possible to believe that this is not a world gone mad? Imagine, if you please, a nation which loses one third of its number in a few years through unspeakably vile forms of murder; vast amounts of Jewish artistic and historic treasures de stroyed, and others disap peared, possibly forever.

title: Eastern's Shuttle Riders Cool. Toward Cocktails
description: To the surprise of almost everybody at Eastern Airlines, only 29 per tent of the busi nessmen on Eastern's 6 P.M. airshuttle flights want a cock tail on their way home after a day of work.

title: Insulin
description: 0NE of the great medical discoveries of the 20th century will be commemorated post ally on Wednesday when Can ada issues a 6cent, multi colored stamp to honor the work of Sir Frederick Grant Banting. Under the direction of Dr. J. J. R. Macleod and assisted by Dr. Charles H. Best, Dr. Banting succeeded in isolating insulin, the hor mone used in the treatment of diabetes.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Hilton Kramer is a quite interesting art critic, more so than most. However, his piece on Picasso finally ce mented one important fact for me when he wrote in his article of January 10, ... it is pure folly to look to artists, even great artists [Picasso] as guides to pond. cal intelligence. I now know that art critics, even quite interesting ones, are to be looked to for political intel ligence even less. I will even saynever.

title: Asian Nations Stress Social Justice Goal Under Colombo Plan
description: MANILA, Feb. 27  The 24 nation Colombo Plan organiza tion closed its 21st consultative committee meetings here this week with a policy statement stressing social justice as a goal for economic development.

title: $10.1.Million in State Aid Given Religious Schools in New Plan
description: ALBANY, Feb. 27Governor Rockefeller today announced the disbursement of $10.1mil lion in state aid to 1,365 reli gious schools in the state.

title: TEACHER WINS FIGHT OVER FLAG SALUTE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 27  A black social studies teacher in Holly wood, Fla., suspended last No vember from his job for refus ing to recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the flag, has been ordered reinstated by a Federal judge here.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: On Jan. 27, when the tem perature was 9 degrees, 1 attended the evening per formance of A Midsummer Night's Dream at the Billy Rose. Being uncomfortably cold, I asked the usher if there was any heat on in the theater and was told that since the actors prefer to per form in an unheated theater, the management obliges by not providing any, and by selling tickets to a public that does not know this.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEM  Gamal, where are you? This was the lament last week of Ephraim Kishon, Israel's most popular satirist, as he contemplated the tortuous road of peacemak ing ahead.

title: Chicago 7 Defense Files Appeal Brief
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 27The de fense in the Chicago Seven case filed today a 547page appeals brief contending that the con victions for crossing state lines with the intention of inciting disorders at the 1968 Demo cratic National Convention should be reversed.

title: Antimalarial Drug Scarce for U.S. Civilian Users
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27The one million American civilians traveling to malariainfected areas of the world are find ing it difficult to buy the pills that can protect them against the sometimes lethal parasitic disease.

title: The Green Pope
description: It is easy to understand why, in the context of Latin America's po litical situation, this book has been judged controversial. It is the sec and volume of a fictional trilogy on a banana empire in Central America. Originally published in Buenos. Aires in 1954, where the Guatemalan nov elist was then living, The Green Pope deals basically with the ma neuvers of George Maker Thompson to control Tropical Banana Inc., and through the control of the company to rule Central America. In his ma neuvering, Thompson fights against other American empire builders and some (very few) Central American idealists. The fight involves not only control of the plantations, the rail ways and the merchant fleet but also the control of the police and the army, the bureaucrats and the peas ants of the native countries.

title: Anne Gram Is Betrothed To Edward T. Shear Jr.
description: The engagement of Miss Anne Valiquet Gram, a sen ior at New York University, to Edward Townsend Shean Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Gram Jr. of New York and East Hampton, LI, parents of the future bride. Her fianc, who is a senior at N.Y.U.'s School of Commerce, is the son of Mr. Shean of New York and the late Mrs. Caroline Wain wright Shean, and a great greatgrandson of Jay Gould, the financier.

title: After the ComputerMaintenance
description: The computer, despite its press clippings and capabili ties real and imagined, is still a machine, and, like all ma chines every now and then, it needs maintenance.

title: Buried Utility Lines In All of the State Proposed by P.S.C.
description: The State Public Service Com mission made public yesterday proposed rules to require elec tric and telephone companies to put their existing overhead localservice lines and equip ment underground throughout the state.

title: Serina Martin Will Be Bride Of J. A. Sanchez
description: Announcement has been made by Esmond Bradley Martin of Westbury, LI., and Mrs. Edwina Atwell Martin of Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Serina Bradley Mar tin, to Jorge A. Sanchez, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rafael San chez of Palm Beach, formerly of Havana.

title: WILLIAM HARD JR.
description: William Hard Jr., a senior editor of The Reader's Digest, died Friday of cardiac arrest in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at Flattown Road, New Canaan.

title: Take Our Land, Take Our Life
description: Legally and morally, the Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts of Alaska can claim 90 per cent of that state's land. The Organic Act of 1884, which established the territorial government, properly acknowledged their rights, but in the ensuing 87 years Congress failed to convey title.

title: Joe Yancey: Pioneer Club CoFounder Is Still Going Strong After 35 Years at the Track Team's Helm
description: As a competitor, Joe Yancy never set the universe on its ears with his 35pound weight throw or his times for the quartermile and the half but as a coach and a human being he's proved to be strictly a worldclass longdistance per former.

title: Oceanography Head Named
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Feb. 27 (AP)Dr. John Knauss, dean of the Graduate School of Oceanography at the University of Rhode Island, has been named chairman of the Na tional Scientific Committee on Oceanography.

title: Beame Says Lag on Medicaid Cost the City Over $2Million
description: Because of failure by the de funct Department of Hospitals to file Medicaid claims on time, the city has lost more than $2 million, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: Thant Signs Proclamation For Earth.Day, March 21
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 27  Secretary General Thant has signed a proclama tion for the celebration of Earth Day on March 21, the first day of spring.

title: Eastern Churches to Begin Lenten Season Tomorrow
description: Eastern Orthodox Christians will observe their most sacred period of the year beginning to morrow when the Lenten sea son starts. And they will mark Eastern on April 18, one week later than other Christian churches.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Some where in the South Pacific, or perhaps unnoticed in Ma drid, is a stocky, 52yearold man of medium height with a limp, a glass eye, a gin ca pacity of two quarts a day and an infinite capacity for making profitable friendships with the military and the civilians who serve them.

title: For Young Readers; Yellow Yellow; By Frank Asch. Illustrated by Mark Alan Stamaty. Unpaged. New York: McGrawHill Book Company. $3.95. (Ages 4 to 7)
description: With only a handful of words Frank Asch tells a simple little story. It's about a boy who finds a construction worker's yellow hat, returns it to the owner and consoles himself by making a new hat from yellow paper. That's all. But Mark Alan Stamaty has drawn a city scene that Hieronymous Bosch would have enjoyed walking through. Surprises are all around. Store windows, people on the street, animals on the curb are labeled with halfhidden, sometimes ironic mes sages. Tiny dream creatures pop up in the most unexpected places. The streets are cluttered with unspeak able creatures doing preposterous things: a little girl licks a barber pole, a cowboy walks a broken duck, a barber stands waistdeep in hair cuttings, people sit on the curb at the bus stop because the traffic sign reads no standing, a football player wears tiny tanks instead of shoes, a toy train travels around a man's waist. Minutes can be spent examin ing each page. In a bookstore win dow is a volume, Pretentious First Novel, by a young writer, Author Young. Scrawls, doodles, graffiti and hieroglyphics abound. The beauty of these touches may be missed by the child but will certainly delight the parent.

title: Theater: Alwin Nikolais's Scenario
description: Alwin Nikolais's latest theater piece Scenario is presumably called Scenario because it has no scenario. It is another abstract adven ture into the never never land of Mr. Nikolais's particu lar and potent brand of the atrical magic.

title: Marker Missed by Class A Yachts Brews Tempest in Lipton Cup Race
description: MIAMI, Feb. 27The Lipton Cup yacht race turned into something less than a tea party today.

title: SOUTAR IS VICTOR IN P.B.A. BOWLING
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 27 (UPI)  Dave Soutar recorded the 12th Professional Bowlers As sociation title of his career today when he defeated Don Johnson, 209160, in the finals of the Miller Open Tournament.

title: Television
description: NOT until the end of Marchand perhaps much later  will there be any real clue as to the nature of tele vision In the months ahead. The medium is undergoing the most stringent shakeout since its beginnings more than 20 years ago. The eco nomic viability of the home screen turned soft following the loss of cigarette advertis ing, a development paving the way for a ruthless price war in the sale of spot com mercials.

title: Sea Cliff Man Will Direct Antiquities Society on L.I.
description: SETAUKET, L. I., Feb. 27The Society for the Preserva tion of Long Island Antiquities has announced the appointment of Robert R. Gamble of Sea Cliff as its executive director.

title: Child to Mrs. Freund
description: A daughter was born on Feb. to Mr. and Mrs. Harry Y. Freund of New York at Mount Sinai Hospital. The child, named Rebecca Chaya, is the granddaughter of Dr. Miriam Freund, editor of Ha dassah magazine. The child's father is an institutional rep resentative. of CWBLHayden, Stone, Inc., New York invest ment bankers.

title: Child to the S. L. Patts
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Patt of Riverdale, the Bronx, on Jan. 29 at the LyingIn Hospital. The child, the couple's second, has been named Audrey Elizabeth. Dr. Patt is a psychiatrist.

title: Campaigner Killed in France
description: PARIS, Feb. 27, (Reuters)A man was shot and killed and three were wounded when they were attacked in a Paris suburb today while putting up posters for candidates in the municipal election campaign. A former Socialist mayor of suburban Puteaux, Georges Dardel, said youthsing car opened fire on a group of his supporters.

title: Miss McDevitt to Be Wed
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Feb. 27Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mary Mc Devitt of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Rose mary McDevitt, to Mayor Eugene J. Carmody of Roselle Park. The future bride is a graduate of Chest nut Hill College. Mayor Carmody, a graduate of Johns Hopkins University, is a department chief in the customer planning division of the Western Electric Company in Kearny.
